illustrations.title: Desperate Cries for Salvation
illustrations.text: We're going to sing this song Hosanna, which means save now, and we literally see on the news people shouting the same thing, save now, because people are desperate. We have the opportunity and obligation to show the world that He has already saved us. The gospel is a life-changing message that goes beyond temporary troubles, saving us from death and sin.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize that while people desperately call for immediate help, the gospel provides eternal salvation through Christ.

illustrations.title: Hosanna and Temple Purification
illustrations.text: When I hear this voice, I can't help but think of the story in Matthew 21 where people are shouting hosanna to Jesus on the donkey, yet they're saying save us from Rome and save us from a political enemy. Then Jesus goes straight to the temple and purifies it. This shows that while people wanted salvation from external issues, Jesus focused on cleansing the internal sin within us.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that Christians often seek deliverance from external problems, but God prioritizes purifying internal sin for true healing.

illustrations.title: Jesus' Ascension and Miracles
illustrations.text: Think about when Jesus ascended to heaven and suddenly there were no miracles for 10 days, not even recorded in the Book of Acts. It might have felt like the day of great miracles was over with Him gone. But the rest of the Book of Acts shows the next 30 years full of God moving in power, with greater things happening because Jesus said they would do greater works since He goes to the Father. They had to believe His word was true, even without seeing it at the time.
illustrations.context: To illustrate that God's power and miracles continue after Jesus' ascension, encouraging faith in His promises.

illustrations.title: Gideon's Story of Faith
illustrations.text: I think of Gideon in the Old Testament, who said to the angel that God would use him, asking where the miracles were that their fathers saw. Gideon felt under the control of the enemy, the Midianites, with lives full of fear and misery. But if you read the rest of his story, you know that God did incredible miracles through him for the deliverance of His people. It's a reminder that God can use anyone to do great things, just as He did then.
illustrations.context: To show that even in times of doubt and oppression, God performs miracles through faithful individuals.

illustrations.title: Professor's Prayer Insight
illustrations.text: My professor at Biola wrote a book on prayer called 'Let's Pray.' In that book, he said what the church needs—and still needs—is less reaction and more knee action, less organizing and more agonizing. This means we should focus on fervent prayer rather than just reacting to problems. It's a reminder that prayer is a powerful tool in spiritual battles.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to stress the importance of prioritizing prayer over mere organization in addressing spiritual challenges.

illustrations.title: Satan's Plaque on Devotions
illustrations.text: There was a plaque that I saw that said, 'If you're really having a busy day, skip your devotions,' signed 'Satan.' And how true that is, as it highlights the enemy's tactic to distract us from what's essential. This simple sign serves as a reminder of the spiritual battle we face daily. Pastor Bob uses it to emphasize the importance of not neglecting prayer and devotions.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this real-world example to illustrate the danger of prioritizing busyness over spiritual disciplines like devotions.

illustrations.title: Chuck Smith's Prayer Priority
illustrations.text: Pastor Chuck Smith, whom many of us know and respect, said that the most important thing a born-again Christian can do is pray. This quote underscores the foundational role of prayer in the Christian life. Pastor Bob connects it to the idea that God wants to work through answered prayers, emphasizing that prayer is not just an activity but a vital connection to God's power.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to stress that prayer is the most crucial action for believers, highlighting its role in advancing God's purposes.

illustrations.title: Spurgeon's Teaching on Prayer
illustrations.text: Spurgeon said, 'I would rather teach one man to pray than ten men to preach.' This powerful statement from the renowned preacher highlights the transformative impact of prayer over mere speaking. Pastor Bob ties it to the theme of what God desires to accomplish through prayer, showing that effective prayer leads to greater spiritual outcomes than eloquent preaching alone.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to illustrate that teaching prayer is more valuable than teaching preaching, as it unlocks God's work in the world.

illustrations.title: Bunyan's Insight on Prayer
illustrations.text: It was John Bunyan, the author of Pilgrim's Progress, who said, 'You can do more than pray after you have prayed, but until we pray we can't do more than pray.' This quote from the historical figure reminds us that prayer is the essential starting point for any effective action. Pastor Bob connects it to the tendency to treat prayer as a last resort, urging believers to make it their first response in faith.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to show that prayer must precede and enable all other actions, countering the idea that it's ineffective or secondary.

illustrations.title: Child's Prayer in Church
illustrations.text: One Sunday, a young child was acting up during the morning worship. The parents tried their best to maintain order in the pew but were losing the battle. Finally, the father picked up the little guy and walked sternly up the aisle. Just before reaching the foyer, the child called out loudly to the congregation, 'Pray for me, pray for me!' We laugh at that, but I wish more children would think that way, learning to ask for prayer when in trouble.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize the importance of asking others for prayer, as Jesus taught.

illustrations.title: King Asa's Faith Failure
illustrations.text: In the Old Testament, God had shown Himself strong repeatedly to King Asa, giving him victory over larger enemies. Later, when Asa faced a threat from the King of Israel, he sought help from a foreign king, Ben-Haddad, instead of crying out to God. This led to a temporary solution, as Ben-Haddad's troops forced the enemy to stop, but Asa put his trust in man rather than God. The prophet rebuked him for this, highlighting the need to rely on God's help.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that we should ask God for help in faith rather than relying on human solutions.

illustrations.title: John Courson's Prayer Stories
illustrations.text: One of the things I loved about John Courson is that he would say when talking to non-Christians, he treated them as if they were Christians already. For example, he once went into the gym locker room and when a guy used the Lord's name in vain, John said, 'Oh, you know Him too? Isn't He wonderful?' That approach surprised people. Then, when John was heading to the mountains for a youth retreat, he stopped at a gas station and told the attendant, a total stranger, 'Hey, I'm going up to a retreat right now and I could really use some prayer. Would you just pray for me right now? I just want God to use me.' The kid mumbled through a prayer and sent him on his way. Guess who was in church the next Sunday when John was preaching? That same kid, and he gave his life to Christ within about two weeks.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how God works through prayer in unexpected ways to bring people to faith.

illustrations.title: Billy Graham on Conscience
illustrations.text: Billy Graham says, 'God has put within each one of us something that cries aloud against us whenever we do that which we know to be wrong.' Conscience is the detective that watches the direction of our steps and decries every conscious transgression. Conscience is a vigilant eye before which each imagination, thought, and act is held up for censure or approval. He said, 'I believe there is no greater argument for the existence of God in the world today than conscience.' There is no greater proof of the existence of a moral law and law giver in the universe than this little light of the soul. It is God's voice to the inner man. Conscience is our wisest counselor and teacher, our most faithful and most precious friend.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to illustrate the importance of keeping a healthy, clean conscience to encourage honorable conduct and spiritual integrity.

illustrations.title: Misunderstood Sermon on Authority
illustrations.text: Last week I preached about authority, including government authority from Hebrews, because church leaders were telling people to submit and obey. I had repeated numbers of people get convinced that I was teaching Christians needed to get vaccinated, which wasn't my intent. This tells me it was my fault, my failure in communication, even though I emphasized obeying God over man.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal experience to highlight his own shortcomings in clearly conveying messages about authority and conscience.

illustrations.title: IRS Conscience Fund Example
illustrations.text: The IRS has something called the Conscience Fund for people who realize they've cheated on their taxes and want to make it right. Millions of dollars have been collected in that fund over time. For instance, one person wrote in saying, 'Here's a thousand dollars for the taxes I should have paid; if I can't sleep at night, I'll send the rest.'
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this real-world example to emphasize the role and impact of a clear conscience in daily life.

illustrations.title: Martin Luther on Self-Fear
illustrations.text: Martin Luther said, 'I'm more afraid of my own heart than of the pope and all his cardinals, because I have within me the great pope self.' This quote highlights the internal struggle with self-trust, showing that even a great reformer feared his own heart more than external authorities. Pastor Bob uses it to emphasize the need for humility and self-examination.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to illustrate the danger of over-trusting oneself and the importance of fearing one's own heart.

illustrations.title: Oswald Chambers on Conscience
illustrations.text: Oswald Chambers said that the one thing that keeps the conscience sensitive to the Lord is the habit of being open to God on the inside. When there is any debate, just quit; there is no debate possible when your conscience speaks. For example, if your conscience tells you not to call in sick when you're not sick, obey it immediately, and if it convicts you of being unkind, confess and repent without defending yourself.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to stress the importance of immediately obeying one's conscience to maintain sensitivity to God.

illustrations.title: David's Numbering of Israel
illustrations.text: The Bible describes David as a man with a heart after God, and when he became king, he decided to number the people of Israel, a common practice among kings. However, after doing so, his own heart smote him because his motives were wrong, even though the act itself wasn't inherently sinful. This story shows that true conscience examines not just actions but the reasons behind them, leading David to seek God's examination.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob retells this story to illustrate that conscience addresses personal motives, not just outward behavior.

illustrations.title: Conscience in Daily Life
illustrations.text: When your conscience says not to call in sick to work because you're not sick, you should go to work without hesitation. Similarly, if it convicts you of being unkind or critical in your words, don't deny, defend, justify, or minimize it; instead, confess and repent immediately. This example demonstrates the practical need to listen and respond to conscience in everyday situations.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show how to apply conscience sensitivity in real-life decisions and behaviors.

illustrations.title: Pearl Goode's Faithful Prayers
illustrations.text: In the annals of world history, you won't find many mentions of a lady named Pearl Goode. She was a widowed nurse in her mid-60s living in Pasadena, California in 1949 when a young evangelist, Billy Graham, held tent meetings in LA. That first night, she felt a burden to pray for him and his team, so she traveled to dozens of his crusades, praying during each event. She joined the volunteer prayer team and put over 48,000 miles on buses, mostly paying her own way, without ever attending the meetings herself. In 1994, Billy Graham acknowledged her impact, saying she prayed all night many nights and he could sense the presence and power of that prayer when she died.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate the importance of faithful prayer and sensitivity in supporting ministry leaders, as seen in the biblical text about praying for others.

illustrations.title: Spurgeon's Blackmail Response
illustrations.text: It was Spurgeon who had some people come to see him, trying to blackmail him by threatening to publish things that would ruin his reputation if he didn't meet their demands. He responded confidently, saying, 'Write all you know about me across the heavens.' In other words, he knew they had nothing on him and it wouldn't ruin his ministry. They never printed a thing, proving his point.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the importance of maintaining a clean conscience so that accusations don't affect one's integrity.

illustrations.title: Parable of the Persistent Widow
illustrations.text: Jesus told his disciples a parable to show that they ought to pray and not lose heart. There was a judge in a certain city who did not fear God and did not respect man. A widow kept coming to him, saying, 'Give me legal protection from my opponent.' At first, he was unwilling, but eventually he said to himself that because she bothered him, he would give her justice so she wouldn't wear him out. Jesus concluded that if an unrighteous judge responds, God will surely bring about justice for his elect who cry to him day and night.
illustrations.context: This story emphasizes the need for persistent prayer to ensure God's timely response.

illustrations.title: Muller's Prayer Persistence
illustrations.text: George Muller, known as a man of great faith, said that it is not enough to begin to pray, nor to pray aright, nor to continue for a time to pray. We must patiently and believingly persist in prayer. This quote connects to the idea that ongoing, faithful prayer leads to results. Pastor Bob uses it to encourage continued intercession.
illustrations.context: This quote underscores the necessity of persistent and believing prayer for seeing God's answers.

illustrations.title: Persistent Friend at Midnight
illustrations.text: Jesus said, suppose one of you has a friend and goes to him at midnight, saying, 'Friend, lend me three loaves because a friend of mine has come to me from a journey and I have nothing to set before him.' From inside, he answers, 'Don't bother me; the door is shut and my children and I are in bed; I can't get up and give you anything.' But Jesus explained, I tell you, even though he won't get up because he's your friend, yet because of the man's persistence, he will get up and give him as much as he needs.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize that persistent prayer leads to answers from God.

illustrations.title: Stone Cutter's Persistence
illustrations.text: It's like that man who saw a stone cutter chiseling away at marble, hitting it over and over, and after 100 hits, it finally broke on the 100th stroke. It wasn't just that last stroke; it was the sum total of all the efforts that caused it to break. Some of us have given up too soon, thinking our efforts are in vain.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that persistence in prayer and faith accumulates and leads to breakthroughs.

illustrations.title: Son Valor's Early Timidity
illustrations.text: You know, my middle son Valor is in his 30s now, but as a little boy, he was very quiet and compliant, almost the exact opposite of what his name means, which is bravery and courage. We named him Valor hoping to inspire that quality, but he was quite timid. I remember how he grew into a more courageous person over time.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that persistence in faith and character development can transform lives.

illustrations.title: Son Shares Fries Generously
illustrations.text: I remember once, Becky had taken the boys out, probably to McDonald's or Del Taco, and got some fries. He was at the house, and I was studying when he came up to me and said, 'Dad, do you want one?' I said okay, and he gave me a fry, even though it was his lunch. He kept offering more, delighting in giving to me more than he wanted to eat himself, and at the end, I told him he was my hero, but he humbly responded in his own way.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the boy's generous and selfless nature, connecting to themes of giving and relationship with God.

illustrations.title: Son Persistently Asks for Fries
illustrations.text: Then there was another time when I had fries, and he had already eaten, but he smelled them and came right up to me. He got very close and kept asking, 'Can I have one? Can I have one? Can I have one?' His persistence made me want to respond. This shows how repeated asking can influence a positive reaction.
illustrations.context: This demonstrates the value of persistence in prayer, encouraging believers to keep asking God and believing His promises.

illustrations.title: Jesus and the Demon-Possessed Boy
illustrations.text: Remember when Jesus went up on the Mount of Transfiguration? He comes down and finds a man whose son is demon-possessed, and the man had brought the boy to Jesus' disciples, but they couldn't cast out the demon. The disciples had authority to cast out demons from previous missions, yet in this case, they were ineffective. Pastor Bob suggests that sometimes, no human effort can fix the problem—it's a job for the King himself. That's what prayer is all about, as Jesus said, 'Bring him to me.' Later, Jesus explained to the disciples that this kind of demon only comes out through specific means tied to faith and prayer.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to show that prayer is necessary for situations beyond human capability, emphasizing reliance on God.

illustrations.title: Prodigal Son Retelling
illustrations.text: I think often of the parable of the prodigal son, which Jesus told to highlight the self-righteous older brother, but we focus on the lost son who leaves home, wastes his inheritance, and hits rock bottom. He realizes his sin has led to misery and decides to return, rehearsing his apology to his father. When he starts to confess, the father interrupts with overwhelming love, embracing him and declaring him restored, saying he was dead but is now alive.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate God's redemptive love and encouragement for those praying for lost loved ones to return.

illustrations.title: Restaurant Waiting Analogy
illustrations.text: Waiting on the Lord is not just sitting around doing nothing. When I go to a restaurant and they wait on me, it shows active service rather than passive idleness. This contrasts with impatiently watching the clock for someone else's change.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob emphasizes that waiting on the Lord renews strength and is an active process, unlike passively waiting for a loved one's repentance.

illustrations.title: Peter's Prison and Prayer
illustrations.text: The Bible tells us that after they killed Herod, they decided to go for Peter, so Peter was kept in prison. But prayer for him was being made fervently by the church to God. Do you remember what happens? The church was crying out to God on behalf of Peter, who was locked up and couldn't get out. But God has ways to get people out of their bondages without you even being involved other than praying and interceding.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that persistent prayer can lead to God's deliverance from bondage.

illustrations.title: Holy Spirit's Personal Analogy
illustrations.text: It's like the Holy Spirit is saying, 'Do you see what I did for Peter? I can do this for your son, your daughter, your husband, your friend.' Keep praying, as God can replicate that deliverance in your life through intercession.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates that God's power in Peter's story applies to personal situations, encouraging continued prayer.

illustrations.title: Moses Intercedes for Israel
illustrations.text: As Moses intercedes for the children of Israel, God says He is going to wipe them out because they are stiff-necked and have blown it. God tells Moses He will start a whole new nation with him instead of Abraham, even suggesting they call it the Moses Heights. Moses responds by saying, 'Whoa, you can't do that,' reminding God of His promises to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. He argues that God's reputation is at stake since the world has seen Him save the people from Egypt. God is actually training Moses to intercede and become a type of Christ, one who takes on the weight of guilt and punishment.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate how God trains people to intercede and remain faithful to His promises, encouraging persistent prayer.

illustrations.title: Jim Cymbala's Prayer Revival
illustrations.text: The author of Fresh Wind, Fresh Fire, Jim Cymbala, had his marriage on the rocks as his wife threatened to leave him. His daughter Chrissy was far from God, living a drug-addicted and messed-up life, breaking his heart as his firstborn. For two and a half years, they tried everything—manipulation, money, and more—but nothing worked, and his wife even became suicidal. They started a church prayer meeting that drew more people than regular services, and during one meeting, a leader felt led to pray for his daughter. Despite his reluctance to shift focus, Cymbala followed God's prompting, and about a thousand people interceded intensely, like a labor room with groaning and cries to break Satan's hold. At the end of the night, Cymbala sensed a release that it was done, even though he hadn't heard from his daughter. He went home, told his wife it was over, and experienced peace the next day.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to emphasize the power of persistent prayer and how God answers when we call on Him.

illustrations.title: Chrissy's Prayer and Confession
illustrations.text: His wife said, 'Honey, come down—Chrissy's here.' With shaving cream still on his face, he went down and found her on the floor in the kitchen, crying and weeping, saying, 'Daddy, I've sinned against you, against Mommy, and against God. I know it.' She said, 'Last night, I had a dream where I was heading to hell, and God stopped me, put his arms around me, and told me he loved me. God reached down to me, Daddy, and I just want to know one thing—who was praying for me last night? I know somebody was.' Well, the whole church was praying for her.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate the power of communal prayer in bringing about spiritual breakthrough and conviction.

illustrations.title: Paul and Silas in Prison
illustrations.text: I think of Paul and Silas there in prison in Philippi. As they prayed to God at midnight, He released them from their shackles, just like He did for Peter. The difference was that in Philippi, all the prisoners' chains fell off, which is amazing and miraculous. But the real story is that the warden and his family got saved.
illustrations.context: Praying can lead to the salvation of others, as demonstrated by the events in Philippi.

illustrations.title: Cabbie and Preacher in Heaven
illustrations.text: I heard a story of a cabbie going into the pearly gates with his name in the Lamb's Book of Life, and they gave him a golden staff and a silk cloak. Then, a preacher who had preached his whole life received only a wooden staff and cotton fabric. He complained, asking why the cabbie got better rewards, and Peter explained that it's about results—the cabbie drove people who prayed, while people slept during the preacher's sermons. So, asking people to pray for you might dramatically change them rather than just you.
illustrations.context: Asking others to pray can transform their faith and lead to greater spiritual results.

illustrations.title: Light Overcoming Darkness
illustrations.text: We are the salt of the earth and the light of the world through Jesus, so we can reflect His glory to those around us as we sing and encourage one another with psalms and spiritual songs. We can take this light from this place and go into dark places to light them up. The darkest night can be lit up because of you, because He has His people in the world lighting up the darkness.
illustrations.context: Believers should actively spread God's light into dark areas to counter evil and reach unreachable souls.

illustrations.title: Cab Driver at Pearly Gates
illustrations.text: There's a cab driver who reaches the pearly gates and announces his presence to Saint Peter. Saint Peter looks him up in the big book and invites him to grab a silk robe and a golden staff and proceed into heaven. A preacher is next in line, watches the proceedings, and announces himself to Saint Peter. Saint Peter checks the book, gives the preacher a cloth robe and a wooden staff, and the preacher is astonished, saying, 'Well, I'm a minister of the.'
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to show that asking people to pray for you benefits them as well, emphasizing the broader impact of prayer beyond personal needs.

illustrations.title: Cab Driver Heaven Story
illustrations.text: A preacher arrives in heaven and complains to Saint Peter about the rewards, saying, 'You gave the cab driver a gold staff and a silk robe; surely I should do better.' Saint Peter responds matter-of-factly that they're interested in results: when you preached, people slept, but when that cab driver drove his taxi, people prayed. This story highlights the importance of real impact in one's life and faith.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize that God values the results of one's actions, like leading people to pray, over mere appearances.

illustrations.title: Job Prays for Friends
illustrations.text: In the Book of Job, Job's friends offered miserable comfort, insisting he had sinned and was being judged by God, which wasn't true. At the end, God was unhappy with his friends and didn't restore them on their own; the only way they could be restored was if Job prayed for them. This shows how God uses prayer from others to bring resolution and healing.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates that we must ask others to pray for us because God works through their faith to accomplish what He might not through our own prayers alone.

illustrations.title: Abraham Prays for Abimelech
illustrations.text: When Abraham lied about his wife Sarah, saying she was his sister to save himself, God closed up the wombs in Abimelech's household as a consequence. God then required Abraham to pray for Abimelech and his household for the situation to be resolved. This demonstrates that even in innocence or ignorance, God mandates prayer from others for full restoration.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that God has specific reasons for requiring us to ask others to pray, as it fosters relationships and faith.

illustrations.title: Woman Seeks Prayer for Husband
illustrations.text: After the first service, a woman came up to me in tears about her husband, who might become a paraplegic unless God intervenes. She needed prayer, and I prayed for her, showing care and support. This moment highlights how asking for prayer not only seeks healing but also builds relationships and demonstrates God's work through community.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob emphasizes that requesting prayer from others creates blessings in relationships and expresses faith beyond one's own.

illustrations.title: Moses Intercedes in Battle
illustrations.text: When the Amalekites came out to fight against the children of Israel, Joshua was sent to fight in the valley, but Moses went up on the mountain to pray and intercede. Aaron and Hur helped hold up his hands. While the battle was fought in the valley, it was decided on the hill of intercession, showing that battles in life are influenced by prayer.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that spiritual battles are decided through intercessory prayer.

illustrations.title: Apostles Pray for Holy Spirit
illustrations.text: In Acts, they were praying for ten days waiting for the Spirit of God to come upon them. When the Spirit came, everything changed, and the New Covenant was instituted with power. Jesus had told them not to leave Jerusalem until they were clothed with power from on high.
illustrations.context: This shows that the church's power comes from persistent prayer.

illustrations.title: Church Needs More Prayer
illustrations.text: In his book 'Let's Pray', Dr. Mitchell said what the church needs is to realize that it began in prayer. He emphasized less reaction and more knee action, meaning more dedicated prayer. This connects to the idea that prayer is foundational for the church's effectiveness.
illustrations.context: This highlights the importance of prayer as the starting point for spiritual power.

illustrations.title: Satan's Temptation Plaque
illustrations.text: I saw a plaque once that said, 'If you're really having a busy day, skip your devotions,' and it was signed 'Satan.' This sarcastically warns against neglecting prayer and devotions. It serves as a reminder of how the enemy tries to distract believers from spiritual priorities.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the danger of prioritizing busyness over spiritual disciplines.

illustrations.title: Prayer as Top Priority
illustrations.text: Pastor Chuck Smith said, 'The most important thing a born-again Christian can do is pray.' This quote underscores that prayer is the essential foundation for a believer's life. Pastor Bob connects it to emphasize prayer's role in spiritual growth.
illustrations.context: This stresses that prayer is the most crucial activity for Christians.

illustrations.title: Teach Prayer Over Preaching
illustrations.text: Charles Spurgeon said, 'I would rather teach one man to pray than to teach ten men to preach.' This highlights the greater value of prayer in ministry. Pastor Bob uses it to show that prayer's impact outweighs even effective preaching.
illustrations.context: This points out that fostering prayer is more important than teaching preaching skills.

illustrations.title: Prayer as First Response
illustrations.text: John Bunyan said, 'You can do more than pray after you've prayed, but until we pray we can't do more than pray.' This means prayer should be the first step, not the last resort. Pastor Bob connects it to encourage making prayer a priority in daily life.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that effective action begins with prayer.

illustrations.title: Child's Church Outburst
illustrations.text: One Sunday, a young child was acting up during the morning worship hour in a church where families gathered together. The parents tried their best to maintain order in the pew but were losing the battle. Finally, the father picked the little guy up and walked sternly up the aisle, and just before reaching the foyer, the child called out loudly to the congregation, 'Pray for me!' Now, we laugh at that, but wouldn't God want more of our children to think that way? It's a humorous reminder that kids can learn to seek prayer in tough moments if they see us modeling it.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to emphasize the importance of children seeing adults model prayer and seeking help from God during problems.

illustrations.title: King Asa's Faith Battles
illustrations.text: In the Old Testament, King Asa is the king of Judah, and he learned his lessons about trusting the Lord early in his reign when a massive Ethiopian army, over a million strong, along with the Lubim, threatened him. Overwhelmed, Asa cried out to God for help, and God delivered the victory, establishing him in his kingdom. But years later, when King Ba'asha of Israel attacked, Asa forgot to turn to God and instead made an alliance with the foreign king Ben-Haddad to fend off the threat. This decision worked temporarily, but it highlights the consequences of not relying on God in every situation.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this biblical story to illustrate the importance of consistently trusting and praying to God rather than relying on human alliances during challenges.

illustrations.title: Pastor John's Prayer Stories
illustrations.text: I love Pastor John Corson and the way God works through him. He likes to talk to non-Christians as if they are Christians, like when he was in the gym and a guy was yelling, using Jesus' name in vain, so John said, 'Oh, Jesus Christ, you know Him too, isn't He wonderful?' Another time, he was on his way to speak at a retreat and stopped for gas, where a young stranger helped him. John asked the kid to pray for him right then, and the kid mumbled a prayer on the spot. Two weeks later, that young man showed up at church for the first time and received Christ a week after that.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that amazing things happen when you ask people to pray, even those who may be less spiritual.

illustrations.title: Billy Graham on Conscience
illustrations.text: Billy Graham said this: God has put within each of us something that cries aloud against us whenever we do that which we know is wrong. Conscience is the detective that watches the direction of our steps and decries every conscious transgression. Conscience is a vigilant eye before which each imagination, thought, and act is held up for either censure or approval. He said, I believe there's no greater argument for the existence of God in the world today than conscience. There is no greater proof of the existence of a moral law and a law giver in the universe than this little light of the soul. It is God's voice to the inner man. Conscience is our wisest counselor and teacher, our most faithful and most patient friend.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that conscience serves as an internal witness to God's existence and moral law, supporting his point about maintaining a good conscience.

illustrations.title: IRS Conscience Fund Story
illustrations.text: The IRS has a Conscience Fund started in the 1800s, beginning with someone who sent in five dollars for unpaid taxes. Now, it contains hundreds of millions of dollars from people, including Christians, who feel guilty and make amends. For example, one man sent a thousand-dollar check with a letter saying he'd send more if he still couldn't sleep.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how a guilty conscience drives people to correct their wrongs, even after the fact.

illustrations.title: Moody and Luther Quotes
illustrations.text: D.L. Moody said, 'I have had more trouble with myself than with any other man I've ever met.' Martin Luther said, 'I'm more afraid of my own heart than of the Pope and all of his cardinals, because I have within me the great pope self.' These quotes highlight the internal struggles even great figures faced.
illustrations.context: These quotes emphasize the importance of self-awareness and the challenges of dealing with one's own conscience.

illustrations.title: Chambers on Sensitive Conscience
illustrations.text: Oswald Chambers said the one thing that keeps the conscience sensitive to God is the habit of being open to God on the inside. When there's any debate, quit; there's no debate possible when your conscience speaks. For instance, if your conscience says not to call in sick when you're not sick, obey it; if it convicts you of being unkind or critical, confess and repent instead of denying it.
illustrations.context: This quote stresses the need to listen to and act on one's conscience to maintain sensitivity to God.

illustrations.title: Paul's Conscience Defense
illustrations.text: Paul said in Acts 24:16, 'In view of this, I also do my best to maintain always a blameless conscience both before God and before man.' Once, when standing before the high priest and leaders questioning him, he claimed he had kept a good conscience from his youth, and the high priest ordered him slapped. Despite this, Paul remained committed to a clean and clear conscience.
illustrations.context: This retelling shows Paul's dedication to maintaining a blameless conscience as an example for others.

illustrations.title: David's Census Error
illustrations.text: David was a man after God's own heart, but he was sensitive to his own self. On one occasion as king, he took a census of his army, which was not wrong in itself since other kings did it. The problem was his motive: he did it to feel secure in his own power instead of trusting in God. When his conscience smote him, he repented and asked God for forgiveness. This shows the importance of examining one's intentions.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate the need to check personal motives before consequences arise.

illustrations.title: Spurgeon's Blackmail Response
illustrations.text: Charles Haddon Spurgeon, the prince of preachers, became extremely popular with his sermons featured in newspapers. A group of men came to his office and threatened to blackmail him, saying they would publish damaging information to ruin his reputation if he didn't pay them. He responded boldly by telling them to write everything they had against him. This demonstrates his openness to scrutiny and trust in God's examination.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize the importance of being honest and open to God's examination of one's life.

illustrations.title: Persistent Widow Parable
illustrations.text: Jesus gave a parable to show that at all times they ought to pray and not lose heart. There was a judge in a certain city who didn't fear God or respect man, and a widow kept coming to him saying, 'Give me legal protection from my opponent.' For a while he was unwilling, but eventually he said to himself, 'Because this widow bothers me, I'll give her justice so she doesn't wear me out.' Jesus contrasted this by saying, 'Shall not God bring about justice for his elect who cry to him day and night?' He will bring about justice for them speedily.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that persistent prayer leads to God's timely justice and restoration.

illustrations.title: George Muller's Prayer Quote
illustrations.text: George Muller of Bristol was an incredible man of faith who said it's not enough to begin to pray, nor to pray aright, nor to continue for a time. We must patiently and believingly continue in prayer until we obtain an answer. Pastor Bob connects this to show that many fail by giving up too soon when they don't see immediate results.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that true intercession requires persistent prayer until something happens.

illustrations.title: Midnight Friend Parable
illustrations.text: Jesus said to them, suppose one of you has a friend and goes to him at midnight saying, 'Friend, lend me three loaves because a friend of mine has come from a journey and I have nothing to set before him.' The friend inside replies, 'Don't bother me; the door is shut and my children and I are in bed.' Yet because of the visitor's persistence, the friend will get up and give him as much as he needs. Jesus uses this to teach about bold and persistent asking in prayer.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates that persistent intercession, like the friend's request, leads to God responding despite initial reluctance.

illustrations.title: Stone Cutter Persistence
illustrations.text: Someone was describing a stone cutter with their hammer and chisel, watching them hammer repeatedly with no result until about the 100th blow, when the chip finally came off. They realized it wasn't that the last blow was any different from the 99 before it, but the accumulation of all of them that made it happen. This shows how persistent effort leads to breakthrough.
illustrations.context: This analogy emphasizes the importance of persistent asking, seeking, and knocking, as results come from accumulated effort rather than a single attempt.

illustrations.title: Son Valor's Early Fears
illustrations.text: Many of you know my middle son, his name is Valor, which is interesting because he was a timid young man when he was born. I remember when he was three or four years old, he wanted to go to the neighbor's house but ran back crying, terrified of a sleeping cat on the lawn, so I had to walk with him. We've seen him grow into his name over time. On another occasion, he was eating fast food and offered me some, insisting I take one even when I declined, showing his generous spirit.
illustrations.context: This personal story illustrates how God works to grow faith and persistence through everyday experiences and challenges.

illustrations.title: Valor and the French Fries
illustrations.text: My son Valor started feeding me his fries, insisting I take more even when I hesitated, showing his generous spirit. Later, I remembered another time when I had the fries and he persistently asked for some, not stopping until I gave in. This illustrated a determination that God honors in pursuing Him through prayer.
illustrations.context: This story illustrates the persistence needed in prayer to pursue God's presence.

illustrations.title: Jesus' Surrender in Prayer
illustrations.text: Jesus prayed, 'Father, this is my will, but nevertheless not my will be done but yours,' demonstrating His surrender to God's plan. Pastor Bob explains that this shows prayer is about aligning with God's will, not just fixing problems. Through this, we learn to prioritize God's presence over our own desires.
illustrations.context: This quote emphasizes surrendering to God's will during prayer rather than focusing solely on resolving personal issues.

illustrations.title: King's Daily Allowance Story
illustrations.text: I heard once of a king whose adult children he said, 'I used to give my children an allowance once a year and I saw them once a year. Now I give them a daily allowance and I see them every single day.' So when you pray, pray like this: 'Father, give us this day our daily bread.' The Lord wants to be with you today about your need, and that's why you have needs—to draw you into the presence of God.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that God desires daily interaction through prayer for our needs, just as the king sought daily connection with his children.

illustrations.title: Jesus and Demon-Possessed Son
illustrations.text: Remember when Jesus came down from the Mount of Transfiguration? The Bible says that a man had a demon-possessed son who would often throw him into the fire or water to harm him. The man brought his son to Jesus's disciples, but they couldn't cast out the demon. So the man said to Jesus, 'I brought him to your disciples, and they couldn't help me.' Jesus said, 'Bring him to me,' showing that prayer is essential to access His power directly.
illustrations.context: This retelling emphasizes that prayer is the master key to bring problems directly to Jesus, as the disciples' efforts alone were insufficient.

illustrations.title: Prodigal Son Retelling
illustrations.text: I think of the story of the prodigal son, which wasn't called that when Jesus gave it, and in context, it's really about the self-righteous older brother. But it offers great hope and encouragement to parents whose children are out in the world and gone, not knowing if they'll even live. The father in the story pictures God himself, who is so gracious that he gives his son his inheritance early, even though he knows it'll be taken and used to dishonor him. The son goes off, wastes it on riotous living and drunkenness, makes friends until he runs out of money, then takes a job feeding pigs—which is humiliating for a Jewish boy. He's so desperate that he wishes he could eat the pig food, realizes his father's servants eat better, and decides to repent, though motivated by his hunger and consequences.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that parents should pray for their children in sin, as it shows God's grace and the hope for repentance and restoration.

illustrations.title: Prodigal Son Retelling
illustrations.text: He came to himself and said, I will arise and go to my father and say to him, Father, I've sinned against heaven and before you. I'm not worthy to be called your son, just hire me as one of your hired servants. The father sees him a long way off and runs to him. The boy starts into his prepared speech, but the father cuts him off, saying, I don't need to hear your speech; you're my son, you were dead and you're alive, you were lost and you're found. It's time to party and kill the fatted calf as he's received back.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate God's unconditional forgiveness and quick restoration of the lost.

illustrations.title: Good Shepherd Analogy
illustrations.text: We know that Jesus came to seek and save that which was lost. He's the Good Shepherd who will leave the ninety-nine sheep and go find the one that is wandering and bring it home. This shows how God actively pursues those in sin to restore them.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize that prayer unleashes God's power to deliver and restore those in bondage, like children trapped in sin.

illustrations.title: Moses Intercedes for Israel
illustrations.text: Moses is told by God that because the people have made a golden calf, He wants to destroy them as they are a stiff-necked people. God even offers to start a new nation with Moses, making him famous. But Moses responds by reminding God of His promises to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, declaring that these are God's people, not his own. Moses says, 'Don't do this, God; they're your responsibility.' This shows how Moses stood up for the people by recalling God's covenant.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate the importance of reminding God of His promises during times of crisis.

illustrations.title: Apostles Waiting After Ascension
illustrations.text: I think of how the apostles might have been tempted to feel discouraged after Jesus ascended to heaven, having experienced nothing but miracles for the previous three and a half years and during the forty days after His resurrection. They didn't see any miracles happening immediately after He left, so they just prayed every day as He instructed them to wait. It might have seemed like the days of God doing great things were over. But then, as we read in the book of Acts, God exploded on the scene through the Holy Spirit, enabling the apostles to perform even greater miracles.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to encourage persistence in prayer, showing that God can bring revival even when it seems like He's not moving.

illustrations.title: Gideon's Fearful Encounter
illustrations.text: Gideon was threshing wheat in a wine vat, not the usual place, because he was terrified of the enemy controlling the nation. An angel appeared and called him a mighty valiant warrior, which was ironic since he was hiding in fear. He questioned where the miracles of the past were, knowing what God had done for Israel but feeling abandoned in their current bondage and fear. God went on to do incredible things through Gideon, though he didn't realize it at the time.
illustrations.context: To show that God can use ordinary, fearful people for extraordinary purposes, encouraging listeners to trust in His power.

illustrations.title: Jim Cymbala's Family Struggle
illustrations.text: Many of you have heard of Pastor Jim Cymbala and his book Fresh Wind and Fresh Fire, where he describes starting a church in New York's inner city amid great challenges. His family endured severe trials when his daughter Chrissy backslid and lived in the world, leading to his wife becoming suicidal and their marriage falling apart. They tried everything to bring her back, including manipulation and money, but things only worsened over two and a half years. At their church, powerful prayer meetings drew more people than Sunday services, and during one meeting, Jim was prompted to have the congregation pray for Chrissy despite his reluctance.
illustrations.context: To demonstrate that God responds to persistent prayer and faith in desperate situations, urging listeners to believe and obey.

illustrations.title: Prayer Brings Family Restoration
illustrations.text: He described the prayer meeting as like being in a labor and delivery room, with a thousand people praying earnestly, moaning, and groaning before the Lord, crying out for deliverance and releasing her from the enemy. At the end of the night, he sensed it was over and done. The next morning, his daughter Chrissy, whom he hadn't seen in five months, returned and knelt on the floor, weeping and broken, asking for forgiveness from her parents and the Lord. She shared that she had a dream of heading into the abyss of hell, but Jesus came and saved her by putting his arms around her. She knew someone had been praying for her and asked who it was, even though she wasn't there. This power of God through prayer set her free and led her into ministry.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating the power of collective prayer to bring speedy restoration and deliverance for those in bondage to sin.

illustrations.title: GPS Detour Nightmare
illustrations.text: I remember coming back from Lancaster years ago when my mom was in the final stages of her cancer, and I drove up there alone. I used a laptop with a USB device as a makeshift GPS, thinking it would show the fastest way home. It led me through the Angeles Crest mountains, a terrifying route full of twists that made me feel sick and took three extra hours. I thought about how this mirrors the detours in life that lead us astray.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how making wrong choices or following misguided paths can lead to difficult and prolonged consequences, similar to the detour in Genesis 16.

illustrations.title: Abram's Famine Journey
illustrations.text: Remember in Chapter 12, what happened? Abram was living in a tent, walking by faith, making altars everywhere as he went in the promised land of God's promise. There was a famine in the land, and when that happens in Canaan, everybody goes to Egypt because Egypt has everything you need. Abram didn't ask the Lord; he just went to solve his problem on his own, and while he took care of his needs, it led to complications.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how the flesh leads to unwanted trials and temptations by relying on human solutions instead of God.

illustrations.title: Egypt as Costco Analogy
illustrations.text: Everybody goes to Egypt when there's a famine in the land because Egypt is the place that has everything you need. I mean, it's like going to Costco—not that I don't like Costco, I do—but the problem is that people turn to these worldly sources for satisfaction without seeking God first. In the Bible, going to Egypt often represents depending on human means rather than divine provision.
illustrations.context: This analogy shows how the world tempts us with easy solutions that can lead us away from trusting God.

illustrations.title: Abram's Consequences in Egypt
illustrations.text: Abram lies about his wife being his sister to protect his life and gain blessings, leading him to stop living in a tent and building altars, putting his faith life on hold. As a result, Pharaoh takes Sarah into his harem, and one ancient commentator suggests it was for two years, though we don't know for sure. This brings consequences like losing his wife, his witness, and emerging richer materially but poorer spiritually.
illustrations.context: To illustrate the spiritual consequences of compromising faith for worldly gain.

illustrations.title: Lot's Temptation from Egypt
illustrations.text: Lot's problem with wanting to go to Sodom stems from the time he spent in Egypt, where he saw the way the other half lives and what's available, which affected and infected him spiritually. This exposure leads to his desire for worldly pleasures. It's like a time bomb waiting to explode in his life.
illustrations.context: To show how worldly influences can infect and lead to spiritual downfall.

illustrations.title: Adam Blaming God
illustrations.text: Remember what God said to Adam after he sinned: 'Have you eaten from the tree which I commanded you not to eat?' Adam's response was 'The woman that you gave me,' shifting blame instead of answering directly. This shows how unbelief often disguises itself as blaming God or others. It's a clear example of avoiding responsibility.
illustrations.context: To illustrate how people blame God for their failures instead of believing His promises.

illustrations.title: Son's Bike Frustration
illustrations.text: I remember when I was with some friends with Becky that when we bought my middle son his first two-wheel bicycle, he was so excited about it. He got on the bike and would ride a few rotations then fall, getting extremely frustrated. After the fourth or fifth time, he got up, walked toward the house, and said, 'Why did you buy me a bike that always falls down? It's gotta be somebody else's fault.'
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate how people shift blame to others when facing failure, mirroring the biblical account of sin.

illustrations.title: God Helps Those Who Help Themselves Myth
illustrations.text: Besides, people say 'God helps those who help themselves,' and 82% of Americans think that's in the Bible, but it's not—it's actually from 'first Harriseeh' or 'flesh alone Ian's,' which aren't real books. This idea promotes self-reliance and impatience, suggesting we should take matters into our own hands when God's promises seem delayed. Pastor Bob connects it to the story, showing how such worldly wisdom leads us away from trusting God's timing.
illustrations.context: He uses this quote to highlight that self-reliance is a fleshly, unbiblical response to God's promises.

illustrations.title: Saul's Impatience and Loss
illustrations.text: If you want to know why Saul lost the Kingdom of Israel, it wasn't just his failure with the Amalekites in 1 Samuel 15. It was because he was impatient. Samuel had told him to wait for the offering, but Saul thought Samuel wasn't coming and the people were scattering. He decided to act on his own and offered the sacrifice, which he shouldn't have done. This failure led God to declare that Saul would lose the kingdom due to his impatience.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate how impatience can lead to losing God's favor and promises.

illustrations.title: Romaine's Yell of Encouragement
illustrations.text: Romaine, whom some of you know, was the assistant pastor under Pastor Chuck Smith and oversaw the staff at Calvary Chapel. If he saw someone on staff running or looking upset, he would open his office door and yell out, 'If you're worrying, you're not trusting.' This was his way of reminding people to trust in God. He did this as a light-hearted encouragement during the day. Some might even think of him as the 'lettuce guy' due to the name mix-up.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that worrying indicates a lack of faith and to encourage patience in God's timing.

illustrations.title: Job and Wife's Discouragement
illustrations.text: You read the book of Job; besides Job's friends who weren't all that kind, who else wasn't really a big encouragement to him? Mrs. Job said, 'You're still trusting God after all this? You still maintain your integrity?' Her counsel was to curse God and die, as she had the gift of discouragement. Fortunately, Job responded by saying, 'Should we only receive the good things from God and not the hard things? No, you're wrong about that,' and he corrected his wife.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating how Satan uses people close to us, like family members, to tempt and lead us into compromising our faith.

illustrations.title: Peter Rebukes Jesus
illustrations.text: Jesus said, 'Blessed are you, Simon son of Jonas, for flesh and blood has not revealed this to you, but my Father in heaven.' A few verses later, Jesus mentioned going to Jerusalem to be turned over and crucified, and Peter rebuked him, saying, 'This shall never happen to you, Lord.' Jesus then responded sharply, 'Get behind me, Satan! You are thinking like a man, not like God.' This shows how Satan can work through even those we love.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate how Satan influences people to prioritize human thoughts over God's will, leading to arrogance and resistance to divine plans.

illustrations.title: Sarai and Hagar's Strife
illustrations.text: In verse 4, Abram went in to Hagar, and she conceived. When Hagar saw that she was pregnant, she despised her mistress Sarai. Sarai then blamed Abram, saying, 'This wrong is upon you; I gave my maid to your arms, and now she despises me.' Abram responded that it was her problem to handle, so Sarai mistreated Hagar, making her life miserable. This led to attitudes of pride, blame, and strife among them.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to show how arrogance, mistreating others, and unbelief produce the deeds of the flesh, leading to conflict and broken relationships.

illustrations.title: Thatcher's Authority Quote
illustrations.text: Margaret Thatcher, Prime Minister of Great Britain, once said that being powerful is like being a lady—if you have to tell people you are, you aren't. She meant that if you have to tell people you're powerful, your authority over them is already lost. Pastor Bob uses this to show how demanding respect reveals weakness and pride.
illustrations.context: This quote illustrates how pride and demanding respect lead to a loss of true authority.

illustrations.title: Hagar and the Angel's Pursuit
illustrations.text: In verses 7 through 9, the angel of the Lord found Hagar by a spring of water in the wilderness and asked her, 'Where have you come from and where are you going?' She admitted she was fleeing from her mistress Sarai. The angel instructed her to return and submit to her authority, revealing God's pursuit of the rebellious.
illustrations.context: This retelling shows how God reveals Himself to and pursues those who are rebellious.

illustrations.title: Early Marriage Anger Test
illustrations.text: Becky and I decided before we got married that we would never leave each other in anger. If we disagreed, we could argue but agreed to stay in the house and cool off. However, it wasn't long after we got married that this was tested, and I was the one who ended up saying I was out of here. I don't remember what the conversation was about, but I just remember walking out, breaking our commitment.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate how easy it is to run away in anger despite prior commitments, emphasizing the need to stop running and submit to authority like Hagar.

illustrations.title: Car Escape and Return
illustrations.text: I got my keys and Eddie didn't seem to care, so I stormed out, got in my car, and drove away from our little apartment in Placentia, thinking I was showing everyone who's boss. As I drove down Chapman Avenue, the Spirit of God whispered to me, asking where I was going, and I realized I was heading to my parents' house out of habit. I felt convicted and turned around, walking back with my tail between my legs, embarrassed but knowing I had to submit.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the importance of submitting to authority and returning when you're in the wrong, as God teaches us not to rebel.

illustrations.title: Battleship and Lighthouse
illustrations.text: You've probably heard the story of the captain on the bridge of a large naval vessel who saw a light ahead on a collision course and signaled for the other ship to alter its course 10 degrees south. The reply came back to alter his course 10 degrees north, and this exchange escalated with the captain asserting his rank as a battleship. Finally, the reply was to alter his course because the responder was a lighthouse. It's a humorous reminder that some authorities, like unmovable truths, can't be ignored.
illustrations.context: This analogy emphasizes that we must recognize and submit to true authority, as designated by God, rather than insisting on our own way.

illustrations.title: Teenage Chores and Song Writing
illustrations.text: I remember the first song I ever wrote when I was 15; it was terrible, and I had a job at a gas station. My parents went to church, but I didn't see the fruit of the Spirit in their lives, so I prayed for their salvation and tried to witness to them, though they didn't like it. They gave me chores like taking out the trash and cleaning the pool, which felt unfair after a long day of work. I wrote a song complaining about it, titled 'Take out the Trash and Clean Your Room and Then Go Clean the Pool,' where I asked God for wisdom. Through that experience, I realized God was testing me to honor my parents despite their flaws, even as a young Christian.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to illustrate the challenge of obeying authority and humbling oneself, even when it feels unfair, tying into the theme of rebellion against God.

illustrations.title: Midianites as Locusts
illustrations.text: The Midianites in the book of Judges came up like locusts, covering the land so you cannot count them. This description is used in the Bible for the enemies of Israel. It illustrates that vast numbers can be a curse rather than a blessing, depending on the context.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is using this to show that multiplication, like the enemies of Israel, isn't always positive and can represent transgression.

illustrations.title: Multiplying Cockroaches Analogy
illustrations.text: If you're multiplying cockroaches in your house, that's not a good thing at all. It depends on what you're multiplying; some things, like pests, bring trouble. This contrasts with positive multiplication, showing that Hagar's descendants represent the products of the flesh.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that not all growth or increase is beneficial, especially when it stems from the flesh rather than faith.

illustrations.title: Isaiah Prophecy Connection
illustrations.text: Isaiah 7:14 says, 'Therefore the Lord Himself will give you a sign: Behold, a virgin will be with child and bear a son, and she will call His name Immanuel.' God declared to Hagar that she would have a son named Ishmael, similar to how Mary was told about Jesus, who would be called Emmanuel. Both names prove that God hears us and is with us, connecting the Old Testament promise to the New Testament fulfillment.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is using this quote to illustrate that God actively hears our afflictions and remains present, as seen in the stories of Ishmael and Jesus.

illustrations.title: Wrath of Men Praises God
illustrations.text: Let me give you one great reference from the Old Testament, Psalm 76:10, which says, 'The wrath of men shall praise You, Lord.' This means that even the wrath of men, which is of the flesh, God will use to praise Him. It's an example of how God redeems negative things for His glory.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that God can use even human wrath, born from the flesh, to ultimately glorify Himself.

illustrations.title: Joseph's Brothers and God's Plan
illustrations.text: What did Joseph say to his brothers who wanted him dead but sold him instead? They meant it for evil, as they hated him and were selfish, but God meant it for good. God allowed it in His permissive will, turning their wicked actions into something that glorified Him. This story shows how God redeems even the worst intentions.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that God can take things meant for evil by people and use them for good, demonstrating His ability to redeem the flesh.

illustrations.title: Pinocchio's Sin Transformation
illustrations.text: In the story of Pinocchio, remember the scene on Pleasure Island where boys abandon school and indulge in sin. They're drinking beer, smoking cigars, playing pool, and mocking others when donkey ears suddenly pop out. They start braying accidentally and literally turn into donkeys as they give themselves to their rebellion, making the wild donkey the perfect image of a self-willed, rebellious resister.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate how sin leads to a wild and rebellious nature, similar to the biblical description of Ishmael.

illustrations.title: Wild Donkey Analogy
illustrations.text: The wild donkey has no interest in socialization at all, totally does its own thing, and is an utter loner living out in the desert, not listening to anybody. That's what the flesh produces, a kind of self-willed jackass. Whereas faith produces a sacrificial lamb, which is who Jesus is.
illustrations.context: This analogy illustrates how the flesh leads to self-willed isolation, contrasting it with the sacrificial nature of faith in Jesus.

illustrations.title: Sunni-Shia Conflict History
illustrations.text: The Sunni-Shia conflict is 1,400 years in the making, dating back to the years immediately after Muhammad's death in 632 AD. The Prophet died without appointing a successor, leading to a massive split over whether the next leader should be chosen by consensus or only from Muhammad's blood relations. Essentially, Sunnis believe Abu Bakr was the rightful first caliph, while Shiites believe Ali was chosen by Allah, and this schism has caused ongoing strife, with Arab nations constantly fighting one another.
illustrations.context: This historical reference shows how the flesh produces relentless strife, as seen in the enduring conflicts among Arab nations stemming from succession disputes.

illustrations.title: Hagar's Repentance Story
illustrations.text: Hagar is running away from home, rebellious and not looking for God, but the angel of the Lord finds her and tells her to go home and repent, which means to change her mind and direction. She obeys, meets the Lord, and calls Him the God who sees. As a result, she goes back, submits to Sarah, and honors the Lord, showing that even someone with a troubled past can turn things around.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses Hagar's story to illustrate that your past does not determine your destiny, as she repented and changed her direction after encountering God.

illustrations.title: Pastor's Personal Testimony
illustrations.text: Hagar's experience is like my own testimony where I was not looking for God, but He found me anyway, similar to how the angel found her. I don't know how you became a Christian, but I know in my case, I wasn't seeking it. This shows that God can intervene in unexpected ways in anyone's life.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses his personal testimony to emphasize that God can find and change people even when they are not seeking Him, tying into the idea that past actions don't define destiny.

illustrations.title: Pastor's Personal Faith Journey
illustrations.text: I thought I was already a Christian because I believed in God, Jesus, and the Bible, and I went to church every Sunday as a child. I was raised in a Lutheran church that didn't preach the gospel, so I didn't understand that I needed to receive Christ or be born again. My parents dragged me to church and Sunday school, which made an impact, but I wasn't seeking God until I went on a retreat and someone explained the truth to me. There, I prayed and God revealed himself, changing my rebellious life completely. I realized that just being religious wasn't enough; I needed a personal encounter with Jesus.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses his own experience to show that attending church and believing in God is not the same as being born again and having a personal relationship with Christ.

illustrations.title: Nicodemus and Spiritual Rebirth
illustrations.text: Jesus met Nicodemus, a respected religious leader and Pharisee, and told him that he must be born again to enter the kingdom of God. Nicodemus didn't understand and asked if he could re-enter his mother's womb, showing his confusion about spiritual matters. Jesus explained that being born of the flesh is just human, but one needs a spiritual birth to have a relationship with God. Despite Nicodemus's religious status, he lacked true faith and needed this revelation. This story highlights that even the most devout people require a personal encounter with God.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob retells this story to emphasize that religious observance alone is insufficient; one must experience spiritual rebirth.

illustrations.title: Woman at the Well
illustrations.text: Isn't there a rebellious woman in John 4 who's sitting by a well, whom Jesus finds and starts talking to, bringing awareness of her sin? He says, 'Call your husband,' and she replies she doesn't have one, but Jesus knows she's had several and the guy she's with now isn't her husband. Oh, I perceive you're a prophet, she says, realizing he knows all about her sin, not to make her feel guilty but to reveal himself to her, leading her to say, 'Come meet a man who told me everything I ever did.' This woman at the well saw God, just like in our passage.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate how God confronts sin with grace, seeking to reveal Himself even to those running from authority.

illustrations.title: Kadesh and Promised Land
illustrations.text: This all happens at a place called Kadesh, the gates that lead into the promised land. It's at Kadesh Barnea that the children of Israel go in to spy out the land and have their opportunity to enter by faith, but they don't do it the first time and blow it. Kadesh is where God says, 'Come live by faith and enter all that I have for you.' The angel of the Lord reveals himself to this woman, giving her an opportunity to repent and come back into the place where she'll walk by faith.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this reference to show how God offers opportunities for faith and repentance, even in moments of rebellion.

illustrations.title: Webby's Quote on Sinful Heart
illustrations.text: I like what Webby said. He said, 'Man's sinful human heart is prone to forget God's presence, ignore God's promise, and find fault with God's providence.' This quote highlights the natural tendency towards complaining, which Pastor Bob connects to the biblical passage about complainers.
illustrations.context: To illustrate how people naturally forget God's goodness and complain.

illustrations.title: Police Term for Complainers
illustrations.text: When I was a police officer at Placentia Police Department, I remember reading an article about certain people they called WSM, which stands for whining, sniveling malcontents. This term describes those who are always negative and hard to deal with. It's sometimes accurate, and you might encounter such people in your workplace, just like in the biblical story of the Israelites.
illustrations.context: To show that complainers exist in everyday life, similar to those in the Bible.

illustrations.title: Israelites' Journey Complaints
illustrations.text: It's interesting that it was just three days after they left Egypt when they first started complaining. Only three days old in the Lord, miraculously saved, and they're complaining because there's no water. Now, they've been at Mount Sinai for a year, enjoying the presence of the Lord, and then on their journey, they found something else to complain about, perhaps like 'This isn't as fun as where we were camped before. Are we there yet?' People say things on journeys, and kids do at least.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that even after being saved, people like the Israelites can still struggle with complaining.

illustrations.title: Complaining on Journeys Analogy
illustrations.text: I don't know what it was, but maybe it was like, 'This isn't as fun as where we were camped before. Are we there yet?' People say things on journeys, and kids do at least. This shows how complaining can happen even on a spiritual path, mirroring everyday family trips.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to show that complaining is a persistent issue in both biblical and modern contexts.

illustrations.title: Taxi Cab Wisdom Quote
illustrations.text: Somebody once said, 'Why is it that everyone who really knows how to run the country is so busy driving taxi cabs and cutting hair?' In other words, they seem to all know how things should be done better. This highlights that everyone has opinions on fixing problems, much like common complaining.
illustrations.context: This quote illustrates that grumbling about how things should be done is a universal human tendency.

illustrations.title: 21-Day No Complaining Challenge
illustrations.text: Some years ago, a pastor decided to challenge his congregation to stop complaining. He gave them a purple plastic bracelet to wear as a reminder and instructed them to wear it for 21 days without complaining. If they complained, they had to switch the bracelet to the other wrist and start over, as this is supposedly how long it takes to change a habit. This challenge has spread to millions of people in many countries.
illustrations.context: This example shows a practical way for believers to commit to stopping grumbling as instructed in the Bible.

illustrations.title: Peter's Distance from Jesus
illustrations.text: Remember what the Bible says about Peter when he denied the Lord. He was following him at a distance. And that's always wrong. We're still following the Lord, but we're just farther away than other people are. This shows that keeping distance from God makes us more susceptible to sin.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that people are most susceptible to complaining when they are farther from God's presence.

illustrations.title: God's Lightning on Soldiers
illustrations.text: We do know that God sometimes used lightning to judge people. Certainly, those who wanted to arrest the prophet discovered that it wouldn't work when God sent down lightning and burned up 50 men at one time. This serves as an example of God's fiery judgment. It's possible this relates to the fire in the camp described in the text.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that God employs fire, like lightning, as a form of judgment against wrongdoing.

illustrations.title: Tongue as a Destructive Fire
illustrations.text: James 3:5-6 states that the tongue is a small part of the body, yet it boasts of great things and can set a great forest ablaze. James is talking about the damage we do with our words, describing the tongue as a fire and the very world of iniquity that defiles the entire body. This illustrates how something small like the tongue can cause massive destruction, much like complaining ignites harmful fires.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that the tongue, when used for complaining, can start destructive fires in our lives.

illustrations.title: Pentecost Fire Contrast
illustrations.text: It's interesting that you can create so much damage by an unkind or critical word spoken. In the scriptures, in the book of Acts, on the day of Pentecost, the Spirit of God was poured out and appeared over their heads as a cloven tongue of fire. James says the tongue is naturally set on fire by hell, but it can also be set on fire by heaven. This shows that the question is who's got your tongue and whether you're spirit-filled, pouring forth blessing or complaining and hurting people.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that just as the tongue can be destructive, it can also be empowered by the Holy Spirit for good.

illustrations.title: Insignificant Complaints Quote
illustrations.text: I like what John Corson said about their complaint: the Lord had given instruction to them before, appeared to them, and been patient, but now they complain about something so insignificant that Scripture doesn't even record the reason. We're not told what they complained about, and Corson noted it must have seemed important to the Israelites at the time, but from God's perspective, it wasn't worth recording. This highlights how trivial grievances can arise even after God's guidance, emphasizing that we often fixate on minor issues.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to show that complaining can be about unimportant things and is not worth God's attention.

illustrations.title: Prayer as Fire Extinguisher
illustrations.text: I believe prayer is our God-given spiritual fire extinguisher to deal with the flare-ups that go on inside of us and among us. We need to get before the Lord, have people pray for us, and pray for ourselves. This analogy illustrates how prayer can extinguish the fires of frustration and complaint, just as a fire extinguisher puts out a literal fire.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that prayer is the key to stopping complaints and inner turmoil.

illustrations.title: Javon McGee's Quote on Identity
illustrations.text: I like what Javon McGee says. He explains that the mixed multitude didn't know who they were and didn't know where they belonged. This refers to people who left Egypt with the Israelites but were not full-blooded Israelis, likely from mixed marriages. They had one parent from Egypt and one with them, so they didn't fully belong to any tribe and felt caught between cultures. Pastor Bob uses this to highlight their in-between state, similar to those who don't fully commit to faith.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to illustrate the confusion and lack of belonging among the mixed multitude, drawing a parallel to spiritual inconsistency.

illustrations.title: Divided Christians Analogy
illustrations.text: There are Christians who feel like they have one foot still in the world and one foot with God's people. They might come to church on Sunday, sing the songs, and enjoy Sunday school for their kids, but the rest of the week they act just like the world. This could indicate a carnal believer or even a makebeliever who only appears saved. Pastor Bob warns that such a divided life risks self-deception about true salvation.
