illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to caution against living a half-committed Christian life, which blurs the line between genuine faith and pretense.

illustrations.title: Elijah's Mount Carmel Reference
illustrations.text: I think of what Elijah said to the children of Israel up there on Mount Carmel. They had been worshiping the Baals for some time while also worshiping Jehovah, depending on their mood, which left them divided in their own hearts. Elijah challenged them not as a group split between two gods, but as individuals internally conflicted. Pastor Bob connects this to the danger of mixed allegiance in faith.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this retelling to emphasize the problem of divided hearts in worship, mirroring the mixed multitude's uncertainty.

illustrations.title: Preaching and Geep Encounter
illustrations.text: I remember preaching about this some time ago and said there's no such thing as a geep, a mix of sheep and goat, because they don't survive well. In God's creation, you're either one or the other. A guy came up to me right after the sermon and said, 'Hi, I just wanted to meet a GE.' I thought he wasn't even listening.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that people are either fully committed to God or not, with no spiritual in-between.

illustrations.title: Bad Apple Analogy
illustrations.text: Remember the story of the barrel of apples, right? All good apples. You put one bad apple in there, and even if you're Michael Jackson singing about it, it doesn't work that way. You put in a bad apple, and the good apples will never turn the bad apple good. Instead, the rot from that bad apple will spread.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how bad company corrupts good morals among God's people.

illustrations.title: Doubts in Correction System
illustrations.text: I was just talking to Pastor Raymond today because he has a relative who works in corrections. We were talking about the probation system, and I said that as a police officer, even though it's my job to arrest people, I never put my faith in our correction system. First of all, our correction system is bankrupt in terms of its philosophy compared to what God says about punishment.
illustrations.context: This highlights the flaws in human justice systems compared to God's standards, emphasizing the limitations of earthly corrections.

illustrations.title: Mantle's Contagious Anger Story
illustrations.text: In his autobiography called Number One, Billy Martin told about hunting in Texas with Mickey Mantle. Mickey had a friend who let them hunt on his ranch but asked Mickey to shoot his blind mule as a favor. When Mickey returned to the car, he pretended to be angry and said his friend wouldn't let them hunt, announcing he would shoot a mule. Billy protested but then followed Mickey's lead, grabbing his rifle and shooting two cows in a fit of anger. This story shows how one person's outburst can influence another to act impulsively.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that anger is contagious and can lead people to make poor decisions when they associate with angry individuals.

illustrations.title: Jesus Before Pilate
illustrations.text: I was reading this morning in my devotional about the Gospels, where Jesus stands before Pontius Pilate. Pilate hears the accusations against Jesus, finds out he's from Galilee, and sends him to Herod to avoid dealing with him. Herod sends Jesus back because Jesus doesn't say much, and the crowds scream for his crucifixion. Pilate investigates and declares that Jesus has done nothing worthy of death, but the crowd insists, and their voices begin to prevail. Pilate, who has the authority of life and death, is influenced by those voices and ultimately washes his hands to remove his guilt, though it doesn't.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate how people can be influenced by critical voices, leading to poor decisions.

illustrations.title: Quote on Shared Dislike
illustrations.text: Somebody has said that nothing can bring you closer faster to someone else than discovering you dislike the same person. If you have a relationship with somebody, whether Christian or not, that is based on or totally involved with criticizing someone else, you need to repent of that. It may even involve breaking off that friendship, as such bonds are unhealthy and revealing of one's own character.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to warn against building relationships on mutual criticism, emphasizing the need for repentance.

illustrations.title: Israelites' Manna Complaint
illustrations.text: Then it describes what we studied before in Exodus. It's like coriander seed. The people would go about and gather it, preparing it in different ways, such as cakes baked with oil, provided every morning as supernatural bread from heaven to meet all their daily needs. I'm sure if Mrs. Moses had a cookbook, she'd have a thousand ways to make manna, like manna bread, mannakotti, and manna split for dessert. But they were sick of it already and got tired of it very quickly.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how complaining leads to losing appreciation for God's perfect provision, like the manna in the wilderness.

illustrations.title: Modern Churches Entertaining
illustrations.text: There are whole churches nowadays that are based on this idea. They think they have to entertain the people because they don't have an appetite for the word of God. So, they try to make the Bible more interesting by showing movie clips or doing fun activities, otherwise they'll lose the audience. Be careful not to satisfy the desires of the flesh instead of focusing on God's word.
illustrations.context: This example warns against churches prioritizing entertainment over teaching God's word, which stems from a lack of appetite for spiritual truth.

illustrations.title: Parental Complaint Analogy
illustrations.text: Moses says to the Lord, 'Did I conceive these people?' Have you ever heard a husband and wife talk about one of their sons or daughters who's doing something wrong? It's like they say, 'Did I adopt him?' implying they question their connection to the child. They might even act as if they've disowned the child.
illustrations.context: This illustrates Moses' frustration and complaint about the burden of leading the people.

illustrations.title: Moses Overwhelmed by People
illustrations.text: Moses says, 'This is not my people. These are your people. You conceived them, I just was out in the desert tending sheep, and now you expect me to carry them like a nurse carries a nursing infant.' He questions, 'Was it I who conceived all these people? Was it I who brought them forth?' Moses adds, 'Where am I supposed to get meat for all these people? They weep before me, saying, "Give us meat that we may eat," and I alone am not able to carry all this people because it is too burdensome for me.'
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that Moses felt overwhelmed by a burden God never intended him to carry alone.

illustrations.title: Disciples and Feeding Multitude
illustrations.text: It sounds like the disciples when Jesus said, 'Let's feed the 5,000 guys out here in the wilderness.' They responded, 'We can't do that. It's impossible.' This mirrors Moses' situation where he felt the task was beyond his capabilities.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that overwhelming tasks can seem impossible, just as they did for Moses, emphasizing reliance on God.

illustrations.title: Apollo 13 Mission Crisis
illustrations.text: Something goes wrong and there's an explosion, and we're not sure exactly what's happening, but mission control is aware of it through their readings. Then the astronaut says, 'Houston, we've got a problem.' That's a classic statement because it shows someone realizing they have a big issue and turning to the one who can help. The real story of the movie shifts from the mission to getting the astronauts home, highlighting what mission control does that the astronauts can't.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that we should take our problems to God, who can handle them, rather than complaining to people who can't help.

illustrations.title: Elijah's Isolation Retold
illustrations.text: What did Elijah say? I alone am left. Everybody else, God says, 'There's others who have not bowed the knee. You're not the only one.' And they're not complaining like you are, Elijah. This shows that even prophets like Elijah felt alone in their trials, but God reminded him that others remained faithful.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that believers are not alone in their struggles, as others have faced similar challenges.

illustrations.title: Fear of Sharing Burdens
illustrations.text: We don't want other people to know we can't handle it because it's embarrassing. We're afraid we'll tell them and they'll say, 'Oh, call me when it's over.' Or somebody might respond, 'Yeah, I used to have that. Mine was way worse.' This highlights how vulnerability in sharing problems can feel risky and uninviting.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that God provides resources like community to handle trials, but pride often prevents us from using them.

illustrations.title: Bearing Burdens Quote
illustrations.text: The Bible says in Galatians, 'Bear one another's burdens and fulfill the law of Christ.' God brings you problems that you can handle with his resources, which include his people, because sharing burdens is key to fulfilling Christ's law. This quote matters as it connects to relying on community during trials rather than facing them alone.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize that handling trials involves community support as a God-given resource.

illustrations.title: Two Better Than One Quote
illustrations.text: Ecclesiastes says, 'Two are better than one. One can get whipped, but two can withstand them.' This means that with God's resources, like partnerships, we can handle problems that seem overwhelming alone. The quote matters because it illustrates how community strengthens us against trials, fulfilling God's design for support.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is showing that God's resources for trials include relying on others, as two people together are stronger than one.

illustrations.title: Jonah's Desire to Die
illustrations.text: Jonah wanted to die, even though he was a faithful prophet before his famous story. He asked to be thrown overboard during the storm, essentially choosing death by sailors. Later, after Nineveh repented, he became upset about a dying gourd plant and again wished for death. God questioned if he had good reason to be angry, highlighting Jonah's struggles. Despite his flaws, Jonah's experiences show that even servants of God can face deep despair.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses Jonah's story to comfort Christians who feel like giving up, showing they are in good company with biblical figures who struggled.

illustrations.title: Elijah's Post-Revival Despair
illustrations.text: Elijah wanted to die even after a great national revival where God showed up powerfully. The nation had repented, and Elijah had confronted the prophets of Baal successfully. However, he fixated on the threat from Jezebel, leading to his own desire for death. This highlights how even after victories, servants of God can feel overwhelmed. Elijah's story serves as a reminder of human vulnerability amid spiritual highs.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses Elijah's story to illustrate that even after apparent successes, believers can still face moments of wanting to give up.

illustrations.title: Peter's Moment of Weakness
illustrations.text: It just reminds me of Peter. Peter in the garden takes out the sword when soldiers come to arrest Jesus, and he strikes without waiting for Jesus's response. Peter boldly claims he would die for Christ and not deny him, but soon after, he denies Jesus in front of a mere slave girl. He stands against armed soldiers but falters before a simple threat, showing how quickly courage can turn to fear.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate how Elijah's discouragement mirrors Peter's inconsistency in faith, emphasizing that even strong believers can waver.

illustrations.title: Biblical Figures' Despair
illustrations.text: Paul said, 'We had the sentence of death in ourselves and despaired even of life,' and Jesus said, 'I'm sorrowful even to the point of death.' These statements show that great leaders in the Bible experienced deep discouragement and a desire to give up. Pastor Bob connects this to encourage listeners that feeling like checking out puts them in good company with these figures.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses these quotes to comfort people who feel like giving up, showing that biblical heroes like Paul and Jesus felt the same way.

illustrations.title: Hezekiah's Desperate Prayer
illustrations.text: Hezekiah was going to be attacked by the Assyrians and received a threatening letter from Sennacherib, boasting of defeating all enemies and claiming Hezekiah's god couldn't save him. Realizing the enemy's strength and his own helplessness, Hezekiah spread the letter before the Lord in prayer, admitting they didn't know what to do. This act of turning to God in the face of overwhelming odds illustrates a model of faith in desperation.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show how responding to discouragement by bringing problems to God, as Hezekiah did, is crucial for believers.

illustrations.title: Peter's Desperate Prayer
illustrations.text: Just remember Peter's prayer. He cried out, 'Lord, save me,' as he was sinking in the water, filled with total unbelief but still calling for help. Jesus reached down and pulled him out, not letting him drown. This shows that even in moments of doubt, God responds to our cries.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that God answers prayers even when we lack faith.

illustrations.title: Cast and Release Analogy
illustrations.text: I call this cast and release. We often give our problems to the Lord in desperation, but then we take them right back and worry about them. Sometimes we're praying while still worrying on our knees, not fully letting go. The key is to cast our cares to God and truly release them without strings attached.
illustrations.context: This analogy highlights the importance of fully surrendering worries to God instead of holding onto them.

illustrations.title: Doctor Prescription Analogy
illustrations.text: Have you ever gone to the doctor? He checks you out, diagnoses your problem, and gives you a prescription, saying to take it and follow up later. But if you don't bother to fill the prescription or take the medicine, you won't feel any better, even if you keep the paper around for months. This shows how ignoring the doctor's advice leaves you unchanged, just like ignoring God's instructions.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that believers must follow God's prescriptions for peace, or they won't experience the promised benefits.

illustrations.title: Help My Unbelief Quote
illustrations.text: What did the man in the Bible say? 'Lord, I believe. Help my unbelief.' This quote shows a person honestly admitting their struggle with faith while still turning to God. Pastor Bob connects it to praying with doubts, emphasizing that even in weakness, we can claim God's promises by giving our burdens to Him.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to point out that it's acceptable to confess unbelief in prayer and still trust God for peace.

illustrations.title: Baptism Joy Experience
illustrations.text: Last Sunday, with all those baptisms, I had the best seat in the house because I was leading worship the whole time. I could see everyone go down into the water and come back up with a look of sheer joy on their faces. It brings tears to my eyes and serves as a powerful reminder of God's work in our lives.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the joy of new believers and reminds the congregation of God's faithfulness in their own lives.

illustrations.title: Salt and Light Analogy
illustrations.text: Jesus said, 'You are the salt of the earth, and if salt loses its savor, it's worthless. You are the light of the world; don't stay hidden.' As believers, we must have contact with a lost world and have a counteracting influence on a decaying society. Salt was a preservative, so we are to live differently and use all means, including our voice and vote, to stand against unrighteousness, like legislation in California that allows babies to be killed in the womb or thereafter.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that Christians must actively influence and preserve society against moral decay.

illustrations.title: Exodus Quote on Chosen People
illustrations.text: Peter is bringing things in the text of words that God spoke concerning Israel, not only about the Messiah that he'd be this stone and prophesying that he'd be rejected, but also really about the nature of Israel and God's desire for Israel to use Israel. He's alluding to a passage in Exodus 19 verses 5 and 6. God speaking to his people: 'Now then, if you will indeed obey my voice and keep my covenant, you shall be my own possession among all the peoples, for all the earth is mine, and you shall be to me a kingdom of priests, a holy nation. These are the words that you shall speak to the sons of Israel.' God intended very clearly in the Old Testament that his people would become an example to the rest of the world of the blessings they were enjoying to reveal God's love and his faithfulness.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to illustrate that believers, like ancient Israel, are chosen by God to proclaim His excellencies and live as a holy nation.

illustrations.title: Pastor Bob's Forgetful Moment
illustrations.text: I have a pretty good memory, but my forgettery is better, and now I'm having times when certain words just don't come to my mind. I mean, I'm there with my grandson who's five, and I'm saying, 'What is that?' Thankfully, he remembered, but I can't even remember what it was—I forgot now. So anyway, I can't even tell you.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate how people, including himself, forget important things, tying into the need to remember God's actions like the Israelites did.

illustrations.title: Exodus Remembrance of Deliverance
illustrations.text: Here's what God said to His people in Exodus 13: remember this day that you went out from Egypt, from the house of slavery, for by a powerful hand the Lord brought you out from this place. He tells them it was the month of Abib, which is around April, and it was Passover—don't forget this day for the rest of your life. In fact, God required an annual feast to celebrate their memory of what He did in bringing their forefathers out of bondage. It's a picture for us of how we were once slaves to sin and God delivered us, just as He birthed a nation from slavery in Egypt.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob retells this story to emphasize the importance of remembering one's divine identification and God's deliverance to understand who we are in Christ.

illustrations.title: Songwriter's Salvation Testimony
illustrations.text: One songwriter said, 'Oh what a wonderful, wonderful day I will never forget after I'd wandered in darkness away. Jesus my Savior I met. Oh what a tender, compassionate friend He met the needs of my heart. Shadows dispelling with joy I am telling, He made all the darkness depart. Heaven came down and glory filled my soul.' This quote highlights a personal experience of transformation through encountering Jesus.
illustrations.context: To encourage listeners to remember their own day of salvation and the joy it brought.

illustrations.title: Ephraim's Defeat and Forgetfulness
illustrations.text: Asaph wrote in Psalm 78 that the sons of Ephraim were archers equipped with bows, like special forces, yet they turned back in the day of battle. They did not keep the covenant of God and refused to walk in His law because they forgot His deeds and His miracles that He had shown them. This led to their defeat despite being equipped for victory.
illustrations.context: To illustrate how forgetting God's works leads to disobedience and spiritual defeat.

illustrations.title: God's View of Identity
illustrations.text: When we say, 'God, I'm just a sinner,' He responds, 'No, you're a saint.' If we claim, 'I'm a failure,' God says, 'Yeah, but I'm your Father.' If we insist, 'I'm unworthy,' Jesus says, 'You are precious, you're a precious pearl,' and if we say, 'I'm unlovely,' He'd say, 'I'm going to marry you.' This series of exchanges paints a picture of God's higher perspective on our identity.
illustrations.context: To challenge believers to adopt God's view of themselves rather than their own negative self-perceptions.

illustrations.title: Pride in Heritage Examples
illustrations.text: People like to talk about their heritage and get their DNA done, sometimes getting pretty proud of it. They say things like, 'Hey, I got 23 and Me and now I know my roots.' Some boast that their ancestors came over on the Mayflower, while others joke that theirs came on the Ark, or reference sayings like, 'If you ain't Dutch, you ain't much.' This shows how people can get overexcited about their background.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that while it's fine to be proud of heritage, people often overdo it, contrasting with God's emphasis on the unity of the human race.

illustrations.title: God's Choice of Israel
illustrations.text: God said, 'For you are a holy people to the Lord your God. The Lord your God has chosen you to be a people for His own possession out of all the peoples on the face of the earth.' You might think it's because you were numerous, but no. The Lord did not set His love on you or choose you because you were more in number than other peoples, for you were the fewest of all peoples. Instead, He chose you because the Lord loved you and kept the oath He swore to your forefathers. He brought you out with a mighty hand and redeemed you from the house of slavery, from Egypt, from the hand of Pharaoh king of Egypt.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that God chooses people not because of their own merits but because of His gracious love and faithfulness.

illustrations.title: Moses and the Golden Calf
illustrations.text: Here's Moses up on the mountain with God, having a 40-day quiet time and receiving the law. God interrupted to say there was sin in the camp and told Moses to go down and deal with it. The people were already breaking the law before they even received it, so Moses asked, 'Who is on the Lord's side?' The sons of Levi stepped up, girded their swords, and went through the camp to kill those involved in worshiping the golden calf. These men of Levi showed faithfulness by choosing the Lord, and as a result, God chose their tribe to be the priestly one in Israel. It's fascinating how God redeemed the Levites, who were once a cursed tribe, to be closer to Him than any other.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate how God originally intended all of Israel to be priests but selected the Levites after their faithfulness during the golden calf incident.

illustrations.title: Meeting Dying Church Sister
illustrations.text: I met with a sister from our church this last week; I haven't seen her in a little while and I don't know if I'll see her again on earth. She expects to go to heaven within the next 90 days, and we were talking about how she's feeling about that. She said she's excited because she's going to get to see His face. I shared this with her to encourage her faith.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate the excitement of seeing Jesus' face as part of being a royal priesthood.

illustrations.title: Fanny Crosby's Blindness Quote
illustrations.text: I mentioned the name Fanny Crosby, a famous hymn writer who lived her whole life blind except for the very beginning. A quack doctor treated her eyes as a baby and caused her blindness, but she grew up thanking God for it. She once commented that if she could go back and see her whole life, she would choose not to, because the first face she'll ever see will be that of Jesus. Pastor Bob shared this to connect it to the sister's excitement about heaven.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize the joy and anticipation of seeing Jesus, reinforcing the privileges of priesthood.

illustrations.title: Faye's Bible Conversation
illustrations.text: He has more for you than just that. Faye said, 'What?' I said, 'The Bible says you're going to rule with Christ for a thousand years in Jerusalem. You're going to actually represent him.' The Bible is clear that we have this position of honor, not only as priests now but also to rule and reign with him forever.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal conversation to emphasize the Bible's promises of ruling with Christ.

illustrations.title: Celebrities with Dual Citizenship
illustrations.text: It is possible for a person to be born in the United States but also have citizenship of another nation. For instance, Jim Carrey is an American but also a Canadian. Tom Hanks is an American citizen and also a citizen of Greece, and Sandra Bullock is an American and a German citizen. This shows that dual citizenship exists in the real world.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses these examples to illustrate that Christians have dual citizenship, with heaven as their primary one.

illustrations.title: Marching to Different Drummer
illustrations.text: Christians are out of step with the world because we march to the beat of a different drummer, sing a different national anthem, and pledge allegiance to a different flag. Our home is in a totally different zip code, which is why we don't fear death—we're just going home. This sets us apart as followers of Christ.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to show that Christians are set apart and different from the world.

illustrations.title: Jesus Cleanses the Temple Twice
illustrations.text: When Jesus started his ministry, he came into the temple, cleansed it, and returned it to the way God intended as a house of prayer, not a den of thieves—he repossessed his house. For a day, it functioned properly with children crying out and Jesus healing people in God's power. At the end of his ministry, he did the same thing again, overturning the money changers' tables and repossessing the house once more.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob retells this story to illustrate the privilege of being possessed by God, showing how Jesus reclaims what belongs to Him.

illustrations.title: Hymn of Spiritual Change
illustrations.text: George Robinson wrote a hymn that describes what happens when a person comes to Christ. The first stanza says: 'Heaven above is softer blue, earth around is sweeter green, something lives in every hue that Christless eyes have never seen. Birds with gladder songs overflow, and flowers with deeper beauty shine, since now I know that I am His and He is mine.' This illustrates the transformation and deeper appreciation of life after surrendering to God.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to show how coming to Christ changes one's perception and brings new joy and beauty to life.

illustrations.title: Ownership and Value Analogy
illustrations.text: If you think about common things like a book, a desk, a pipe, or some sheet music, they're not exciting on their own. But they become extremely valuable when you discover the book belonged to Abraham Lincoln, the desk is where Churchill wrote his memoirs, the pipe belonged to C.S. Lewis, and the sheet music was handwritten by Beethoven. Suddenly, these ordinary items are worth so much more, and that's what you need to understand when God says He owns you and chooses you—your value goes off the charts.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to illustrate how belonging to God elevates a person's worth and significance.

illustrations.title: Recalling Big Bill Sprouse Song
illustrations.text: What a verse! I remember hearing Big Bill Sprouse, who did the song we called Psalm 5, which David wrote. This song connects to the idea of God's deliverance and light. It's a personal memory that ties into the biblical truth we're discussing.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this memory to emphasize the transformative power of God's deliverance from darkness.

illustrations.title: Big Bill's Conversion Story
illustrations.text: Big Bill Sprouse was a country western singer who had gotten saved. He was up on the stage in the tent days, speaking to a couple thousand kids, and he described his conversion like this: the day I got saved, it was like I realized my whole life I had been living in a big blob of Jello, and I broke out and could take my first breath. I thought it was a perfect picture, pretty accurate for someone who had no spiritual life before.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the transformative experience of salvation and gaining spiritual life.

illustrations.title: Star Trek Translation Analogy
illustrations.text: God has translated us, which is kind of like in Star Trek where you beam someone up and move them from one place to another. This means a complete change out of spiritual darkness into God's wonderful light. Paul describes it as being transferred from darkness to light in the Lord.
illustrations.context: This analogy shows how salvation involves a complete and sudden shift from spiritual darkness to light.

illustrations.title: Hosea's Marriage to a Harlot
illustrations.text: God calls His prophet Hosea to live out an analogy of His own experience by marrying a prostitute and having children with her. The first child is named Jezreel, but the second is Lo-Ruhamah, meaning no mercy, and the third is Lo-Ammi, meaning not my people, reflecting Israel's unfaithfulness. Despite this, God promises to forgive Israel, change their names to ones of mercy and belonging, and take them back as His own, illustrating His incredible grace.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that God redeems and shows mercy to those who were once not His people, emphasizing the transformation through grace.

illustrations.title: Pastor's Rebellious Testimony
illustrations.text: I can't tell them my story without changing the rating. I was a rebellious, pot-smoking thief before I was a Christian. Someone said, 'Whoa, I didn't know that. I don't like who you were and I don't trust who you are, Pastor.' Well, I don't blame you; I don't like who I was and I don't trust who I am either. So that's quite all right with me, but I'm not asking you to trust me; I'm asking you to trust Him. There's a world of difference between those two.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses his personal story to emphasize that people should trust in God rather than in imperfect individuals like himself.

illustrations.title: Church Visit Comparison
illustrations.text: A man on the west coast was going on a vacation to the east coast, where there were two very famous preachers on the radio at the time. He told his Christian friend he was going to visit both churches, and the friend asked for a report on the services. When he returned, he compared them by saying, 'Pastor A is a wonderful preacher, but Pastor B has a wonderful Savior.'
illustrations.context: This story illustrates that the true value lies in knowing and proclaiming a wonderful Savior, not just in being a skilled preacher.

illustrations.title: LED Car Advertising Example
illustrations.text: I saw one the other day, maybe you've seen them. It was a passenger car with an LED light on top displaying messages, which is way more effective than billboard advertising. People remember these mobile ads because they move around, and I tried to drive up to see what it said, but it was crashed anyway.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that believers are God's mobile advertising plan to proclaim His grace and mercy.

illustrations.title: First Day at Biola Story
illustrations.text: My first day at Biola, my first class was Koine Greek. I'll never forget, I walked into class and saw a guy I had met at orientation, though I didn't know him well, and I said, 'Hey, what's new?' He replied with the 13th letter of the Greek alphabet. I thought it was odd; he had already been studying and was trying to raise the curve, but I joked back, 'Well, it's all Greek to me.'
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal anecdote to transition into discussing Paul's words about being a new creation, emphasizing how to respond when asked 'what's new.'

illustrations.title: Personal Salvation Testimony
illustrations.text: Let me tell you, I was once not a people but now I'm owned lock, stock, and barrel. Jesus paid for me; He created me and then paid for me on the cross. This shows how I've been transformed through His grace.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that believers are chosen and redeemed by Jesus, emphasizing the opportunity to witness and join God's family.

illustrations.title: Jesus Choosing Disciples
illustrations.text: Jesus said to His disciples, who thought they had chosen Him, 'You did not choose Me, but I chose you.' This retelling highlights how God initiates the relationship, not us. It's a reminder that following Jesus reveals His prior choice.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that God chooses us first, encouraging believers to respond by following Him and living out their faith.

illustrations.title: Grandson and Coffee Cup
illustrations.text: Coming back to my grandson, because it always does, I'll never forget when I went to get a cup of coffee at his dad's house and grabbed a cup. I don't know what it is, maybe it's an identity issue, but I don't like girl cups even though we have a lot of them in my house and they're gorgeous. This story illustrates how our preferences reveal deeper beliefs about identity.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to demonstrate that our actions and choices reflect what we truly believe about ourselves and God's view of us.

illustrations.title: Grandson's Cup Story
illustrations.text: Thankfully, my son has all die-cut cups, so it's pretty easy. I grabbed a cup, and my grandson said, 'Oh, you don't want that cup.' I asked why not, and he replied, 'Because there's one with a picture of me on it; you want that one, right?' This shows how we might question affirmations just like I did with his suggestion.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that people often doubt positive affirmations about themselves, just as he initially questioned his grandson's suggestion.

illustrations.title: Heaven's Uncertain Welcome
illustrations.text: Do you really believe what God says about you, or do you think God's struggling with his commitment, like you're going to get to heaven and he's going to say, 'What are you doing here? Well, I was kind of hoping you were expecting me, like he's saying well done to other people, but for you, well, look who's here; I guess I ain't promised.' This paints a picture of God's potential frustration with our doubts.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to challenge listeners to fully accept God's promises and not doubt His commitment to them.

illustrations.title: Encouraging Becky's Talents
illustrations.text: I came to my wife and said, 'Hey, you're incredibly beautiful,' but she replied, 'No, I'm not; I'm getting older.' I told her, 'You're an amazing cook,' but she said, 'No, the food didn't turn out the way I expected.' Then I mentioned, 'I love the way you decorate our house,' and shared how right after we got married, I tried to decorate one piece of the house myself, thinking it was modern from Sam's Club, but it was a big mistake because nothing else matched. Despite that, I tell her she's an incredible designer, and most beautiful things in this building are thanks to her, yet she still doubts it, which gets frustrating.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to show how God might feel when we reject His affirmations and words of love, just as he feels frustrated when his wife rejects his compliments.

illustrations.title: Titanic Rescue Analogy
illustrations.text: Can you imagine yanking somebody off the Titanic who was in the water and bringing them on board? They say, 'Oh, I just feel like I'm still out there.' Well, you'll get over that. If they think they're going down, well, I don't know why you need a shrink, but you're safe.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that people should accept God's assurance of salvation despite their feelings of doubt.

illustrations.title: Church Members' Trials and Faith
illustrations.text: I can look around the room and see people who have lost children singing with conviction, 'Great is your faithfulness.' I see people who have struggled with cancer singing with the same conviction about God's faithfulness. Through their perseverance in trials, they display God's faithfulness and become sources of hope to everyone around them.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating God's unwavering faithfulness through the real-life struggles and perseverance of church members.

illustrations.title: Joy of Recent Baptisms
illustrations.text: I'm still moved by last week's baptisms that we witnessed. I had the best seat in the house, seeing people go into the water and come out with joy on their faces. There's something unique that happens in that moment, and it's such a blessing to be part of a church body taking the Great Commission seriously.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the joy and spiritual significance of baptisms in a church community.

illustrations.title: Metamorphosis Analogy
illustrations.text: You all know the word metamorphosis. You think of a pollywog turning into a bullfrog or a caterpillar turning into a butterfly. That's radical transformation, and that's exactly what the Greek word metamorphosis means. It's a complete change, just like the Bible describes in Romans 12.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to illustrate the radical transformation believers experience through the renewing of their minds as mentioned in Romans 12.

illustrations.title: Remembering the Exodus
illustrations.text: Moses said to the people, 'Remember this day in which you went out from Egypt, from the house of slavery by a powerful hand the Lord brought you out from this place. On this day in the month of Abib, you are about to go forth.' God required the nation of Israel to remember annually what He did, including through the plagues in Egypt, the parting of the Red Sea, and Moses as their savior. This remembrance was crucial so they wouldn't forget how God saved them and made them a nation.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this retelling to illustrate the importance of remembering God's actions to maintain a true understanding of one's identity.

illustrations.title: Ephraim's Forgetfulness in Psalm
illustrations.text: Asaph wrote in Psalm 78: The sons of Ephraim were archers equipped with bows, yet they turned back in the day of battle. They did not keep the covenant of God and refused to walk in His law because they forgot His deeds and His miracles that He had shown them. This forgetfulness led them to become defeated and disobedient, highlighting the consequences of not remembering God's works.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that forgetting God's miracles results in defeat and disobedience, underscoring the need to derive identity from God.

illustrations.title: Childhood Pride in Fathers
illustrations.text: When I was a little boy, some of you remember the story I told about meeting my neighbor for the first time. I was five years old, and our first discussion was about whose father could beat up the other kid's father. This had nothing to do with our fathers and everything to do with our view of ourselves, as people often take pride in something about their history.
illustrations.context: To illustrate how people, even as children, take pride in their personal heritage and associate it with their own identity.

illustrations.title: Ancestral Heritage Examples
illustrations.text: I've done genetic testing like 23andMe to see what percentage of greatness might be in my background. People often say things like, 'My ancestors came over on the Mayflower,' or even jokingly, 'Mine came over on the Ark.' There's that saying, 'If you ain't Dutch, you ain't much,' which shows how people sometimes get into their nationality a bit too much.
illustrations.context: To show how people take pride in their ethnicity or history, though God created diversity to be celebrated.

illustrations.title: Revelation on Redemption
illustrations.text: In Revelation chapter 5 and verse 9, they sang a new song in heaven, saying, 'Worthy are you to take the scroll and to open its seals, for you were slain, and by your blood you ransomed people for God from every tribe and tongue and people and nation.' This verse highlights the context of diversity among races, showing that we're all different kinds of sinners redeemed by God. God uses this diversity to demonstrate His power to redeem every kind of sinner.
illustrations.context: To emphasize that God redeems people from every tribe and nation, countering the tendency for one race to exalt itself over another.

illustrations.title: King's Forbidden Priesthood
illustrations.text: There's a guy in Second Chronicles 26 who was a successful king and believed in the Lord, but he got too big for his britches and decided he could be a priest. He went into the temple to offer incense, and eighty priests told him to get out because he wasn't a priest, just a king. He got angry, and leprosy broke out on his head, making him a leper until the day he died.
illustrations.context: This story illustrates that royalty and priesthood do not mix, emphasizing the distinct roles except in rare exceptions.

illustrations.title: Melchizedek as King and Priest
illustrations.text: In Genesis 14, we meet a very interesting man named Melchizedek on Abraham's return from war, where he had recovered his nephew and the spoils. Melchizedek was the king of Salem, which later became Jerusalem, and his name means king of righteousness and king of peace. He was both a king and the priest of the most high God, which was unusual as it combined the two roles.
illustrations.context: This reference shows that God intended to unite kingship and priesthood, foreshadowing Jesus as both king and priest.

illustrations.title: McGee's Priest Analogy
illustrations.text: J. Vernon McGee once gave a message to a congregation titled 'You are a Catholic priest,' which surprised everyone because he meant it in the lowercase sense as universal, not tied to a specific church. He was playing with words to explain that every Christian is a priest, even if they don't realize it yet. This highlights that all believers are called into ministry as a universal priesthood.
illustrations.context: This quote emphasizes that every Christian is a priest, connecting to the idea of the church as a priesthood.

illustrations.title: Priest as Bridge Builder
illustrations.text: Do you know the word 'priest' in Latin is 'pontifex'? It means bridge builder. That's what you're meant to be as a believer. That's why you work where you work, why you live where you live, and why you go to school where you go to school—because you have an experience with God that others don't have, and you're responsible for helping them discover it.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that believers, as priests, have the responsibility to help others connect to God, acting as bridges in their daily lives.

illustrations.title: Faye's Peaceful Anticipation
illustrations.text: A sister from this church will go see Jesus in the next 90 days, and she's accepted that and is at peace with it. I met with her and her husband to pray, encourage them, and hear how they're doing. She told me with a big smile that she has been waiting years to see Jesus's face and cannot wait for it to happen.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate the peace and excitement believers can have about heaven.

illustrations.title: Fanny Crosby's Blind Faith
illustrations.text: Fanny Crosby was a great hymn writer who was blind from infancy due to a doctor's mistake that caused her condition. She had no memories of sight her whole life but loved the Lord and wrote incredible hymns. When asked about heaven, she said that if she could go back and have vision her whole life, she would never do it, because Jesus would be the first person she sees when her eyes open.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show how Fanny's anticipation of seeing Jesus mirrors the church sister's excitement and highlights the joys of heaven.

illustrations.title: Marching to Different Beat
illustrations.text: If it seems we Christians are kind of out of step with the rest of the world, it's because we march to the beat of a different drummer, we sing a different national anthem, and we pledge allegiance to a different flag. It's because our home is in a totally different zip code. This illustrates that as followers of Christ, we live by different standards and values.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that Christians are called to be holy and different from the world.

illustrations.title: Dual Citizenship Examples
illustrations.text: There are some who are dual citizens, like my wife who was born in Brazil but is American, born to American parents, so she had dual citizenship for a time. Jim Carrey is American and Canadian, Tom Hanks is American and a citizen of Greece, and Sandra Bullock is American and German. This shows it's possible to have dual citizenship, and as Christians, we have it too, with our true home in heaven.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that Christians have dual citizenship, with their primary allegiance to heaven.

illustrations.title: Ambassadors for Christ
illustrations.text: We are ambassadors for Christ, which means we represent one nation to another, going to that other nation to represent the king or leader of our nation. As ambassadors, we entreat on behalf of Christ, urging others to be reconciled to God. This analogy highlights our mission as Christians in the world.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that Christians are on a mission to represent God's kingdom while living in this world.

illustrations.title: Kingdom Not of This World
illustrations.text: As Jesus said, 'My kingdom is not of this world,' which means we have a different nationality and must never forget that. This quote emphasizes that our true citizenship is in heaven, not here. Pastor Bob connects it to show Christians' primary allegiance is elsewhere.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is using the quote to highlight that Christians' kingdom is heavenly, not earthly.

illustrations.title: Childhood Home Alone Story
illustrations.text: I remember as a little boy, the youngest of five, my parents thought I was old enough to be home alone—I was probably five or six years old. They went to the store, leaving me alone, and I felt like I had full ownership of the house. I thought about telling neighborhood kids to stay off my lawn. Then, a stranger knocked on the door; he was about 18 with paint on his hands and said they were painting addresses on the curb for a dollar. I told him my parents weren't home, feeling protective of my territory.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate the feeling of personal ownership, contrasting it with the biblical truth that believers are God's possession.

illustrations.title: Decision as Disciple Story
illustrations.text: I said my mom and dad are here, and I don't own this house, so I don't have a dollar, so I can't really give you an answer right now. She got frustrated and walked off. This illustrates that as a disciple of Jesus, I've given up making decisions on my own.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to show that disciples of Jesus no longer make their own decisions but discover God's will.

illustrations.title: George Robinson Song Quote
illustrations.text: George Robinson wrote a song that some of us grew up singing and can relate to. He said, 'Heaven above is softer blue, earth around is sweeter green, something lives in every hue that Christless eyes have never seen, birds with gladder songs overflow, flowers with deeper beauty shine, since now I know I am His and He is mine.' In other words, when this transition happens, everything changes because I see the world differently knowing I belong to God.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that belonging to God transforms one's perspective on life and the world.

illustrations.title: Auction Items Analogy
illustrations.text: Think about common things like a book, a desk, a smoking pipe, or sheet music; they're not that exciting in themselves at an auction until you learn that the book belonged to Abraham Lincoln, the desk was where Churchill wrote his memoirs, the pipe was C.S. Lewis's, and the sheet music was handwritten by Beethoven. Then, their value goes way up because of who they belong to. This shows that ordinary things gain significance through their ownership.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to illustrate that our value and perception change when we realize we belong to God.

illustrations.title: Ephod and Stones Retelling
illustrations.text: God gives us a picture in the Old Testament of imperfect people who are His, and the way He describes them is through the high priest wearing an ephod with a breastplate that had 12 stones, each representing one of the tribes of Israel as different gemstones. They were each unique and precious, reminding us that God values all His people. This wasn't like some were precious and others were just dirt clods; they were all gemstones to Him.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob retells this biblical story to convey that God sees His followers as precious and valuable, despite their imperfections.

illustrations.title: Pearl of Great Price Retelling
illustrations.text: You have a completely wrong view of yourselves, but God gives us this picture of His people as precious though imperfect. You are the pearl of great price the Bible says, when that man who was looking for merchants found one that was worth it, he sold everything that he might have you. And that was before you were in Christ, showing how valuable you are to God.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that God sees His people as immensely valuable, even in their imperfection.

illustrations.title: Gods People as Jewels Quote
illustrations.text: Jot down Malachi 3 and verse 17; listen to what God says in the King James: 'And they, God's people, shall be mine, saith the Lord of hosts, in that day when I make up my jewels.' That's how He sees you and me, as His precious jewels.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob emphasizes that God views His people as treasured possessions, highlighting our worth in His eyes.

illustrations.title: Translation into Gods Kingdom Quote
illustrations.text: We jot down Colossians 1:13; I like the way Paul puts it here: God has delivered us from the power of darkness and has translated us into the kingdom of God's dear Son. This shows how God has moved us from separation to mercy and belonging.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob connects this quote to illustrate the transformation from not being God's people to receiving His mercy.

illustrations.title: Big Bill's Conversion Story
illustrations.text: Years ago, I was at Calvary Chapel Costa Mesa during the 10 days. There was a group called Sanctified, later renamed The Road Home, and their leader was a big guy nicknamed Big Bill Sprouse. He shared his conversion, describing it as being inside a giant blob of Jello, and getting saved was like breaking out and taking his first breath. This painted a vivid picture of what conversion feels like. You don't even know what it's like until it happens, and you come alive in Christ.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the radical transformation and new life experienced in conversion to Christianity.

illustrations.title: Star Trek Kingdom Analogy
illustrations.text: Referring to Colossians 1:13, it's like Star Trek: 'Beam me up, Scotty' – I was in one kingdom and got translated into God's kingdom. This shows a complete shift from being part of the dark world to becoming light in the Lord. It's a picture of the radical transformation that happens through God's grace.
illustrations.context: This analogy emphasizes the instantaneous and complete transfer from the kingdom of darkness to God's kingdom upon salvation.

illustrations.title: Hosea and Unfaithful Wife
illustrations.text: Hosea had this incredible calling from God, who wanted to illustrate His broken heart over Israel's unfaithfulness. God saw Israel as His wife from the covenant at Mount Sinai, but due to their idolatry, He planned to write a certificate of divorce. So, God instructed Hosea to marry a prostitute and have children of harlotry to embody this pain, showing how God feels about spiritual infidelity.
illustrations.context: This retelling highlights God's heartbreak over Israel's unfaithfulness and parallels it to spiritual truths in the sermon.

illustrations.title: Hosea's Redemption Story
illustrations.text: God tells Hosea to marry Gomer, and they have three children with names that reflect God's judgment on Israel's unfaithfulness. The second child is named Lo-Ruhamah, meaning no mercy, and the third is Lo-Ammi, meaning not my people, symbolizing God's disownment. But later, God instructs Hosea to buy Gomer back from prostitution and restore her, just as God will redeem and show mercy to His people when they repent, changing the children's names to reflect mercy and belonging.
illustrations.context: This illustrates God's unwavering mercy and redemption for unfaithful people, showing that He restores them despite their unworthiness.

illustrations.title: Pastor's Rebellious Past
illustrations.text: While I'm not proud of it, I'm not ashamed to be honest and tell you I was a rebel, pot-smoking thief before I got saved. Some of you might not like who I was and therefore don't trust who I am now, and I don't blame you because I don't like who I was either. But I'm not asking you to trust me; I'm asking you to trust Him, because He's done amazing things in my life.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses his personal transformation to show that God can change anyone, emphasizing trust in God rather than in people.

illustrations.title: Famous Pastors Story
illustrations.text: Years ago, there were two very famous Christian pastors who led different churches on the East Coast, and two Christian friends on the West Coast. One of them was going to the East Coast for a vacation and planned to visit each of those pastors' churches. When he returned, his friend asked for a comparison, and he said that Pastor A was a wonderful preacher, but Pastor B had a wonderful Savior.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to highlight the importance of a personal relationship with Jesus over mere skillful preaching.

illustrations.title: LED Screen Car Story
illustrations.text: I saw it just this last week while driving home, and it caught my attention because I hadn't seen anything like it before. It was a normal car with an LED screen on top displaying different advertisements, and I even sped up to read it, almost causing an accident. I went home and googled it because it's becoming one of the most effective advertising methods, as it moves around and keeps people's eyes on it, unlike static billboards.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that Christians are like mobile advertisements, declaring God's excellencies and grace to those around them.

illustrations.title: First Day at Biola
illustrations.text: It was the first day at Biola for me, which stands for Bible Institute of Los Angeles, and I was starting as a Bible major after attending a secular school. I walked into my very first class, which was Koine Greek, the Greek of the New Testament, and I saw a guy I met at orientation, so I sat next to him to feel more comfortable. I said to him, 'Hey, what's new?' and he replied, 'The 13th letter of the Greek alphabet,' because he had already started looking at his textbook.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to connect to the Greek word for excellencies, emphasizing the importance of understanding and declaring spiritual truths.

illustrations.title: Complimenting Becky Analogy
illustrations.text: What if I went up to my wife Becky and said, 'You are incredibly beautiful,' but she replied, 'No, I'm not; I'm getting old.' If I told her she's an amazing cook, she might say her mom was better and that she struggles with it. I could praise how she decorates everything beautiful in the church, but she'd downplay it, saying it's not that great.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show how people often reject positive affirmations, similar to how we might doubt God's truths about ourselves.

illustrations.title: Peter's Transfiguration Retelling
illustrations.text: Remember, Peter, James, and John had a unique experience where Jesus took them to a high mountain and was transfigured before them. Elijah and Moses showed up, and they discussed future events, proving that those who have died are still very much alive. Peter, not knowing what to say, suggested building tents for them, but God interrupted and said, 'This is my Son, listen to him.' Peter never forgot that day and later wrote about it in his epistle to affirm the gospel's truth.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that believers should trust the prophetic word and God's direct revelation, even if they weren't present for such events.

illustrations.title: Pastor's Own Admission
illustrations.text: Peter didn't know what to say, so he opened his mouth too often. I'm guilty of that; I have nothing to say, so I'll say it anyway. This personal flaw mirrors Peter's impulsiveness and highlights human imperfection.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob shares this to connect his own experiences with Peter's, emphasizing that everyone struggles with speaking without wisdom.

illustrations.title: Mormon Experience Misunderstanding
illustrations.text: People can misunderstand their subjective experiences. For example, I'm a Mormon and I believe Jesus is the spirit brother of Lucifer because I have a burning in the bosom. You can have a quiver in your liver all you want, but if it doesn't match up with the Word of God, it's not true.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that subjective experiences can be misleading if they do not align with God's Word.

illustrations.title: Truth Sets Free Quote
illustrations.text: Jesus said, 'You will know the truth and the truth will set you free.' He would say that to us today because some of us in this room or listening are still in bondage, even as believers, because we really don't believe all of God's Word about ourselves. We can believe it about Jesus—that He is precious, the cornerstone, and everything God accepts—but we must realize that we are accepted in Him and nowhere else.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to show that embracing God's truth can free believers from personal bondage caused by unbelief.

illustrations.title: Youthful Confusion with Pestilence
illustrations.text: For years as a young person, I didn't know what pestilence was. I had no idea and thought it might involve calling someone to get rid of it. It just means disease, as I learned later.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal anecdote to show that biblical terms can be unfamiliar and need explanation.

illustrations.title: Mad Cow Disease Comparison
illustrations.text: We've all heard of mad cow disease, and this plague was like mad donkey disease and a variety of others. It illustrates the results of sin and disobedience. God uses disease to describe the effects of sin in people's lives.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob connects this real-world disease example to show how sin leads to consequences like the plagues in Egypt.

illustrations.title: Isaiah's Sin as Disease
illustrations.text: In Isaiah chapter 1 verses 4 through 6, God speaks through the prophet, saying, 'Alas, sinful nation, people weighed down with iniquity, offspring of evildoers, sons who act corruptly, they have abandoned the Lord and despised the Holy One of Israel.' He continues, describing them as if the whole head is sick and the whole heart is faint, with bruises and wounds from head to toe. This comparison shows how sin ravages a person like a horrible disease or being hit by a train.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to explain that God compares sin to sickness to highlight its destructive effects on lives.

illustrations.title: Fish in Water Analogy
illustrations.text: It's like that old expression: Does a fish feel wet? We've talked about that before. How would a fish know what wetness is? It's only ever known wetness, just as we don't know what it's like to be free from sin because we've always been sinful from conception. Even after forgiveness, our nature quickly pulls us back.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to illustrate how people become accustomed to living in sin and compromise, making it hard to recognize a healthier spiritual state.

illustrations.title: Friend's Dialysis Experience
illustrations.text: I have a friend who comes to our church, and years ago he needed dialysis due to kidney issues. He was getting weaker, had to leave his job, and spent most of his time in bed, unable to do much. When he talked to his doctor, the doctor insisted he wasn't doing well because he had grown so used to being sick that he didn't recognize true health. His life changed dramatically after a transplant, showing how we can adapt to substandard conditions without realizing it.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to show how people often accept a compromised spiritual life as normal, just as his friend accepted physical sickness.

illustrations.title: Jesus Healing the Sick
illustrations.text: Remember when Jesus was walking this earth, he healed all kinds of diseases, no matter what they were. People came to him with incurable illnesses, and he healed them every time. For example, he even raised Lazarus from the dead, which is about as incurable as it gets. This shows that Jesus had power over every form of sickness and villainy.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob retells these stories to emphasize that God desires to heal and restore us from spiritual separation caused by sin, just as Jesus healed physical diseases.

illustrations.title: Blindness as Spiritual Truth
illustrations.text: Jesus heals the blind, not just out of compassion, but because it's a picture of how we are blind to spiritual truth until we come to him. For the unbeliever, Satan has blinded their minds so they can't see the hope of the gospel. When you get saved, you say, 'I was blind and now I see,' and your life changes in terms of why you're here and what you're living for.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to show that physical healing represents spiritual awakening and the opening of eyes to God's truth.

illustrations.title: Deathbed Healing Hope
illustrations.text: There was a guy racked in pain on his deathbed, and his friend came up and quietly asked how he was doing. He replied, 'Almost better, give me a few minutes, not much better.' This illustrates that ultimate healing comes when we die and go to heaven.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this example to counter the doctrine that it's always God's will to heal in this life, emphasizing that true restoration happens in the afterlife.

illustrations.title: Misunderstood Healing Prayer
illustrations.text: Years ago, I prayed for a man who was going blind. After we finished praying, he looked at the group of men laying hands on him and said, 'You know, five years from now, you might see me bumping into trees, but I'll know one thing: even if I can't see a thing, I'm healed.' I thought, 'Yeah, that is just utter deception, buddy. That's not true.'
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate that claiming false promises of physical healing can lead to deception and misunderstanding of Scripture.

illustrations.title: Unearthed Egyptian Bull Tomb
illustrations.text: Just last year, they unearthed in Egypt in one of these places called the palace of the Dead, which is still being excavated, this ancient tomb of mummified bulls. We have a picture of the size; this is the size of the casket for the bull, 90 tons of solid granite with 24 of these, and they had to blow it open with dynamite to discover what was inside, and they were shocked at what they found. The Egyptians saw this bull, the God Apis, as a source of power, strength, protection, and fertility, which is why they worshipped it.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how the Egyptians idolized the bull as a god, representing their dependence on it for power and fertility, which was judged by God.

illustrations.title: Wall Street Bull Worship
illustrations.text: We have in our country a bull that's worshipped by too many, that's the Wall Street bull. By the way, that bull was set up the day after the market crash in 1987 as a symbol of strength. This serves as a modern example of how people idolize symbols of financial power and success, much like the Egyptians did with their bull god.
illustrations.context: This analogy shows that modern society still worships symbols of power and wealth, mirroring the Egyptian idolatry that faced God's judgment.

illustrations.title: Frogs Plague Retelling
illustrations.text: They didn't like the frogs; they were all over the land. So Moses said, okay, you want the frogs to go away? I can help with that. I asked the Lord to get rid of them, and he says tomorrow. We say tomorrow, yeah, one more night with my frogs. How weird is that? We talked about how there's something within us that wants to hold on to our sin just one more day, not today—I'll get rid of that, but just not today. That whole thing of procrastination.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show how people procrastinate in repenting from sin, contrasting human delay with divine timing.

illustrations.title: Gods Compassion Quote
illustrations.text: The Bible says this about God: he takes no pleasure in the death of the wicked. Why will you die? he says to the wicked. This reveals God's heart, as seen in how he gives sinners time to repent before judging, just like in the story of Jezebel in Revelation where God gave her time to repent but she did not.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to illustrate God's compassionate nature, giving people time to repent before judgment.

illustrations.title: Abraham's Land Promise
illustrations.text: God promised Abraham the land of Canaan but said you're not going to have it right now; you'll live in tents, and your descendants will too. They would go to Egypt for 400 years and eventually return, but not yet because the sin of the Amorites or Canaanite people is not yet full. It's like their sin is at three-quarters, and God is waiting for the right time to judge them.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate God's patience in giving the wicked time to repent before judgment.

illustrations.title: Peter's Explanation of Delay
illustrations.text: Peter said don't think that God is slow about his promise of Jesus's return, as if he's distracted or busy elsewhere. Instead, God is patient, not willing that any should perish but that all would come to eternal life. This means God is giving people time to be saved, even when we're eager for Christ's return.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob emphasizes that God's apparent delay is actually patience, allowing more people to repent.

illustrations.title: Jerusalem's Modern History
illustrations.text: Jerusalem wasn't always part of modern-day Israel and became part of it in 1967 during the Six-Day War. In my first Bible, the maps showed Jerusalem as a divided city under Jordanian authority. Jesus said that Jerusalem would be trodden underfoot by the Gentiles until the fullness of the Gentiles comes in.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates God's timing in history, showing how events like Jerusalem's reunification reflect divine patience for salvation.

illustrations.title: Pastor's Personal Reflection
illustrations.text: I've often thought about how I wasn't saved until 1971, and wondered why God hadn't brought everything to an end by then. If God had acted sooner, I might not have been saved, and I'm so glad He was patient. This shows how God's patience allows time for individuals like me to come to faith.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses his own experience to highlight the value of God's patience in giving people time to repent and be saved.

illustrations.title: Matthew Henry on Repentance
illustrations.text: Matthew Henry says we only have one deathbed confession or deathbed conversion in the whole Bible, which is the thief on the cross. We have one, so we shouldn't lose hope, but we only have one, so we shouldn't be presumptuous. It's true the thief went to heaven; this day you'll be with me in paradise. That's a great testimony, but I just don't want it to be mine.
illustrations.context: This warns against presuming on God's grace for last-minute repentance.

illustrations.title: Thief on the Cross Repentance
illustrations.text: It's true the thief went to heaven; this day you'll be with me in paradise. That's a great testimony, but I just don't want it to be mine.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that while last-minute repentance is possible, one should not rely on it.

illustrations.title: Plague of Boils in Egypt
illustrations.text: Then the Lord said to Moses and Aaron, take for yourselves handfuls of soot from a kiln and let Moses throw it toward the sky in the sight of Pharaoh. It will become fine dust over all the land of Egypt and will become boils breaking out with sores on man and beast. So they took soot from a kiln, stood before Pharaoh, Moses threw it toward the sky, and it became boils on man and beast. The magicians could not stand before Moses because of the boils, for the boils were on the magicians as well as on all the Egyptians. Then the Lord hardened Pharaoh's heart, and he did not listen to them.
illustrations.context: This demonstrates the consequences of stubbornness and God's use of judgment to enforce repentance.

illustrations.title: Diet Temptation Struggle
illustrations.text: Paul talks about the struggle with the flesh, and how many of us wake up determined to stick to our diet, saying 'Today's the day I'm going to eat right and stay committed.' But then temptation hits, like the smell of bacon, and our resolve crumbles. That's not just a description; it's a confession of our human weakness.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the internal battle with sin and temptation, as described in Romans 7, where good intentions fail due to the flesh.

illustrations.title: Ancient Corpse Torture Analogy
illustrations.text: Paul might be using an analogy from an ancient form of torture where they took a murderer and tied the corpse of the victim face to face with them. The decaying flesh of the corpse would be pressed against their body, causing constant suffering and misery. They didn't just kill the prisoner; they made sure they couldn't escape the horror, symbolizing how sin traps us in our own flesh.
illustrations.context: This shows how Paul feels enslaved by his sinful nature, unable to free himself from the body of death as mentioned in Romans 7:24.

illustrations.title: Wiping Tears Analogy
illustrations.text: Ever thought about that? Anybody ever wipe tears from your eyes besides you? Maybe your mom, maybe your husband or wife, maybe a close friend. I mean, strangers don't go around saying, 'Hey, let me get that one.' Yeah, somebody cares about you, something that's close to you. This illustrates how personal and intimate God's care will be.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to explain the intimate care in Revelation 21:4 where God wipes away tears.

illustrations.title: Chronic Pain Example
illustrations.text: There are some people in this room that I know who live in chronic pain. Your only release is when you go to sleep, and not always even then. Life is tough, and it's a daily struggle that highlights the misery of such conditions.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating the reality of pain and suffering in life to contrast with the promise of no pain in eternity.

illustrations.title: Job's Boils Retelling
illustrations.text: Remember the final attempt of Satan to get Job to curse God was with boils. He had taken Job's children, wealth, reputation, and servants, even gave him bad breath. Job said his breath was odious to his wife, and he had these boils breaking out on his body, scraping them in a sad sight. It was tough to live in that misery, as Satan thought touching his skin would make him curse God, but Job didn't.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob retells Job's story to show how physical suffering tests faith, connecting it to the plagues and God's judgment.

illustrations.title: Las Vegas Shutdown Analogy
illustrations.text: Jay Vernon McGee talked about this as something interesting. I don't know if you've ever been in a plane flying over Nevada or Las Vegas, but you know how Las Vegas looks from space—it's as bright as day at night. He shared that once there was a strike years ago, and all the casinos closed down because they didn't have enough workers, so it was completely dark. He makes an analogy between the shutdown of these altars and idols in Egypt and Las Vegas being shut down. Basically, it shows that the place of sin is closed and revealed as the dark place it truly is.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate how false worship in Egypt was halted, revealing sin's true darkness, much like Las Vegas during a shutdown.

illustrations.title: Jeremiah's Lament of Mercy
illustrations.text: Lamentations 3:22 states it is of the Lord's mercies that we're not consumed. Jeremiah wrote this book as a lament, a funeral dirge, during the destruction of Jerusalem by the Babylonians. He was witnessing his people taken captive and the city burned, yet he acknowledged that God's mercy spared them from total annihilation. In this context, Jeremiah emphasizes that despite deserving destruction, God's purposes remain for His people.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that God's mercy prevents complete destruction, urging recognition of His ongoing purposes even in suffering.

illustrations.title: David's Prayer on God's Greatness
illustrations.text: In 1 Chronicles 20:9-11, David prays about the greatness, power, glory, victory, and majesty of God, declaring that all in heaven and earth belongs to Him and that He is exalted as head above all. Pastor Bob presents this as a great prayer that highlights God's sovereignty over everything. He connects it to the discussion of God's power demonstrated through the plagues, showing how David recognized God's control over creation.
illustrations.context: This quote illustrates God's supreme power and authority, encouraging awe and dependence on Him.

illustrations.title: Police Car Complaint Story
illustrations.text: I'll never forget, when I was a police officer in La Habra one night, I had to drive the old station wagon cop car that nobody wanted—it was the car no one liked, not cool at all. I was complaining about it to the schedulers, saying what could be worse. Another officer responded, and I said yeah, it could be you. That exchange actually comforted my heart big time, even though it was ironic.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to show that gaining perspective, like realizing things could be worse, can bring comfort in difficult situations, relating to thanking God despite hardships.

illustrations.title: Shadrach in the Fiery Furnace
illustrations.text: Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego go into the fire to die, but they're protected from burning alive. A figure like the Son of God is seen in the fire with them, so they're not destroyed but are with Him. Even people outside who aren't believers can see Jesus in their lives, and the king has to call them out, but they're content to stay and hang out with Jesus.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that God is present in the midst of suffering, allowing people to experience Him deeply and even draw others to faith.

illustrations.title: Losing a Father and Comforting Others
illustrations.text: If your dad dies, you're struggling with that loss, and you've discovered God is your father, faithful and close to you, taking care of you. Now, when a friend whose father is dying needs help, you can say something to him that you couldn't have said before. This shows how your experiences equip you to minister to others in similar pain.
illustrations.context: This example demonstrates that personal hardships allow you to comfort and help others who face the same struggles.

illustrations.title: Hailstorm in Egypt
illustrations.text: The Lord told Moses that about this time tomorrow, He would send a very heavy hail such as has not been seen in Egypt from the day it was founded. Pharaoh's servants who feared the word of the Lord brought their livestock and people to safety, while those who ignored it left everything in the field. When the hail came, it struck all that was in the field, destroying man, beasts, plants, and trees, but the land of Goshen where the Israelites lived was spared. This event shows that even in the midst of God's wrath, obedience brings protection. Only in the land of Goshen, where the sons of Israel were, there was no hail.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that there is safety in trusting and obeying God's Word, even among unbelievers.

illustrations.title: Proverbs on Battle Safety
illustrations.text: Proverbs 21:31 states that the horse is prepared against the day of battle, but safety is of the Lord. Pastor Bob connects this to the idea that even unbelievers who obey God's Word and principles experience safety. For example, he notes that the horse is uniquely associated with Egypt in the Bible, emphasizing reliance on God rather than human preparations.
illustrations.context: This quote illustrates that true safety comes from the Lord, highlighting how obeying God's principles leads to protection.

illustrations.title: Divorce in Past Society
illustrations.text: When I was growing up, divorce was almost unheard of among unbelievers, and people generally did not live together outside of marriage. This reflects a time when societal norms aligned more closely with God's principles, even without full faith. Pastor Bob uses this to show that adhering to such principles brought stability and safety in relationships.
