illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that unbelievers who follow God's Word and principles experience safety and benefits, as seen in past societal norms.

illustrations.title: Noah's Ark as Safety
illustrations.text: I think of what Noah was preaching to the people. He was saying judgment is coming, he knew God was gonna cause it to rain, and he had built an ark. There was only gonna be one safe place on earth, it's in the ark, and so he is telling them come inside. Now, other than his family, nobody came, but all that did come inside his family were totally safe. They were just in the right place, and the Ark is a type of Christ, so you're safe regardless of your relative holiness and spirituality.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that being in the right place, like in Christ, ensures safety from judgment.

illustrations.title: Judgment on Egyptian Goddess
illustrations.text: It's interesting this hail and fire they believe was a judgment on the goddess of Isis, who was the goddess of the sky called the lady of heaven and in charge of the rain. The Egyptians thought that rain was the tears of Isis, the heavenly Nile, the water coming out of the sky that they worshipped. But here, coming out of the sky from their sky god, isn't the rain that they need, but hail that's destroying everything and killing everything, along with fire from lightning bolts setting fires.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that God judges the wicked in righteousness, specifically targeting false gods like Isis.

illustrations.title: Modern Plagues and Storms
illustrations.text: Are you following these wildfires in Australia, like 28 million acres, the size of like Paraguay, out of control completely? Also, other things like a huge hailstorm 90 days ago with giant hail breaking car windshields all over various places, and dust storms causing everything to be completely blackened out in mid-day. It's like biblical plagues are coming on, and I think God is saying wake up.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses these real-world events to draw parallels to biblical plagues, warning that God is signaling people to wake up to impending judgment.

illustrations.title: Pharaoh's False Repentance
illustrations.text: Pharaoh sent for Moses and Aaron and said to them, 'I have sinned this time; the Lord is the righteous one, and I and my people are the wicked ones.' He asked Moses to pray for the thunder and hail to stop, promising to let the people go. Moses agreed and spread out his hands to the Lord, and the thunder, hail, and rain ceased. However, once the plague ended, Pharaoh hardened his heart again and did not let the Israelites go, showing his confession was insincere.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this retelling to illustrate that true confession must be more than just words; it requires genuine fear and obedience to God.

illustrations.title: Grandson's Naked Face Comment
illustrations.text: My grandson once told me one night when I was getting ready, 'You're naked, your face is naked.' It's a humorous way he pointed out something obvious, much like how Adam knew he was naked after sinning. God asked Adam how he knew, and Adam made excuses, just as we often do. This little story shows how children can innocently highlight truths.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate how people recognize their shame or sin, similar to Adam and Eve's story.

illustrations.title: Freedom Beyond Government
illustrations.text: A lot of posts yesterday said our freedoms are under attack, but if you're a Christian, your freedom is not under attack because where the Spirit of the Lord is, there's liberty. We have a freedom that is beyond the grasp of our government or any kind of election. As Pastor Bob said, we have an eternal election, for God elected us to be His children, so we are free.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that true Christian freedom, derived from the Spirit of the Lord, cannot be threatened by worldly forces like government or elections.

illustrations.title: Jesus' Resurrection Victory
illustrations.text: Darkness is rejoicing quite a bit this year, but we have an eternal perspective because we see the cross and it's just three days in the grave, and then He rose from the dead to prove that He has the authority to arrest death. Death has no hold on us, sin has no hold on us, for we are forgiven and free. This came at a cost, at the cross, where Jesus paid for those sins and was a Man of Sorrows acquainted with deepest grief.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob retells the story of Jesus' crucifixion and resurrection to illustrate that believers have hope and victory over darkness and death.

illustrations.title: Ex-Cop Analogy for Death
illustrations.text: I think Pastor Bob likes that song because he's an ex-cop, you know, death was arrested but it's 100% defeated. Death has no hold on us because of this victory. It's a way to see how Jesus overcame death completely.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses the analogy of an ex-cop arresting death to show that, just as an officer might arrest a criminal, Jesus has authority over and defeated death entirely.

illustrations.title: Police Academy Training Excitement
illustrations.text: When I finished the police academy, I remember that when you're in a police academy, you get very excited about going out and doing the job. You spend time in training learning how to handle different things, and it's all academic, but you're doing it for a reason: to get out there and actually perform the job. It's kind of exciting to be called into something.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to illustrate that uncertain times, like the election, can be exciting opportunities for action, similar to graduating from training.

illustrations.title: Aladdin Trust Scene
illustrations.text: In the prayer room, a scene from the Disney movie Aladdin came to mind. Aladdin says to Jasmine, 'Do you trust me?' and she remembers it later when she encounters him again. This phrase resonated with me as a reminder of trust in uncertain situations.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize trusting God during difficult times.

illustrations.title: Healing of Synagogue Ruler's Daughter
illustrations.text: In Mark, Jesus is on his way to heal the synagogue ruler's daughter when he is interrupted by a woman with a hemorrhage who touches his garment and is immediately healed. Despite the delay, news comes that the daughter has died, but Jesus tells the ruler not to be afraid and just believe. He then proceeds to the house and raises the daughter from the dead, showing that God can work even in the midst of interruptions.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that we should trust God and maintain faith even when circumstances seem hopeless.

illustrations.title: Jesus's Dracula Sermon Retelling
illustrations.text: I'm talking about when Jesus preaches what I call his Dracula sermon in John 6. He says, 'Unless you eat my flesh and drink my blood, you'll have no part in me.' Everyone starts leaving, and Jesus turns to the disciples and asks, 'Do you trust me now? Do you want to leave, or do you want to trust me?'
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize trusting Jesus even when his teachings are hard to understand.

illustrations.title: School Test Preparation Analogy
illustrations.text: I used to hate it when a teacher gave a test in school without going over the material first. The Lord never gives you a test that he didn't prepare you for. You are ready for whatever you're going through, and we'll go through it together.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob assures that God prepares believers for life's challenges, just like a teacher prepares students.

illustrations.title: John Corson on Commandments
illustrations.text: I love John Corson as a man, pastor, and friend, and I appreciate how he puts things. He said that of all the Commandments, the last one is probably taken the least seriously. If a person breaks the sixth commandment, they might be executed; if they break the eighth, they might end up in jail; if they break the ninth, they might be sued. But if they break the tenth, not only are they forgiven, they're applauded because coveting is a key component of our culture. That's why this commandment is unique and different.
illustrations.context: To highlight that the tenth Commandment is the least seriously regarded and often celebrated in society.

illustrations.title: Jesus and the Crowd's Greed
illustrations.text: In Luke 12:13-15, someone in the crowd said to Jesus, 'Teacher, tell my brother to divide the family inheritance with me.' Jesus replied, 'Man, who appointed me a judge or an arbitrator over you?' Then he warned them, saying, 'Beware and be on your guard against every form of greed, for not even when one has an abundance does his life consist in his possessions.'
illustrations.context: To show that coveting and greed are dangerous attitudes, distinct from outward actions.

illustrations.title: Man Seeks Inheritance Justice
illustrations.text: The man thinks he's coming to Jesus for some justice because his brother is being selfish and won't share the inheritance. He's convinced that Jesus would support his noble cause. But Jesus redirects him, saying to forget about that and focus on what's going on inside him. Jesus warns that he's coveting his brother's possessions and that life doesn't consist of material things. This story shows how people often approach Jesus with the wrong motives.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate how coveting leads to misplaced priorities, as Jesus shifts the focus from external disputes to internal heart issues.

illustrations.title: Lucifer's Prideful Fall
illustrations.text: Lucifer, a very high-ranking angel, said in his heart, 'I will ascend to heaven, I will raise my throne above the stars of God, I will sit on the mount of assembly, I will ascend above the heights of the clouds, and I will make myself like the Most High.' This shows his desire to covet what God has. Pastor Bob uses this to highlight how pride and coveting led to rebellion.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that coveting, like Lucifer's desire for God's position, was the original sin leading to rebellion.

illustrations.title: Eve's Forbidden Desire
illustrations.text: Eve faced a temptation where there was only one thing in the whole universe she couldn't do, and that's what she wanted. She saw that the fruit was good for food, a delight to the eyes, and desirable to make one wise, leading her to covet and eat it. This act stemmed from wanting to be like God in a way that disobeyed Him. Pastor Bob explains that coveting often twists good desires into sin.
illustrations.context: This retelling shows how coveting what God has, as Eve did, leads to disobedience and sin.

illustrations.title: Cain's Envious Murder
illustrations.text: Think about Cain, who killed his brother Abel not out of a bad mood, but because he envied Abel's acceptable offering to God. Abel's offering was accepted, but Cain's was not, which made Cain angry and covetous of his brother's spiritual favor. In his unspiritual rage, Cain murdered Abel, thinking it would solve his problem. Pastor Bob points out that coveting can lead to breaking other commandments, like murder.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to demonstrate how coveting spiritual blessings can drive people to commit grave sins like murder.

illustrations.title: Rich Young Ruler's Greed
illustrations.text: Remember the Rich Young Ruler who came to Jesus saying he wanted to follow Him and asked what he needed to do. Jesus told him to keep the law, and the man claimed he had since childhood, so Jesus challenged him to sell all he had, give to the poor, and follow Him to gain treasure in heaven. The man couldn't do it because he coveted his wealth more than spiritual treasure. Pastor Bob uses this to show that coveting material things violates the first commandment by making them idols.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how coveting possessions can prevent full commitment to God, revealing it as a form of idolatry.

illustrations.title: Spurgeon on Dissatisfaction
illustrations.text: Spurgeon said, 'If I had a little more, you say if I had a little more I should be satisfied. You make a mistake if you are not content with what you have; you would not be satisfied if it were double.' This quote highlights how people mistakenly think more possessions will bring contentment. Pastor Bob connects it to the idea that coveting leads to ongoing dissatisfaction, as seen in the pursuit of wealth. It's a reminder that true satisfaction doesn't come from material gains.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to show that coveting deceives people into thinking more possessions will satisfy them, but it only leads to further discontent.

illustrations.title: Rockefeller's Endless Wealth Quest
illustrations.text: JD Rockefeller was the wealthiest man in the world, founding Standard Oil in the early 20th century. When asked as a young man how much money he wanted, he said a million dollars. After earning that, when asked again, he replied he wanted another million, showing that wealth brought diminishing returns. This example illustrates how the pursuit of money never truly satisfies.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to demonstrate that coveting and gaining possessions leads to a cycle of wanting more, without achieving real happiness.

illustrations.title: Solomon's Pursuit of Abundance
illustrations.text: In Ecclesiastes 5:10, it says, 'He who loves money will not be satisfied with money, nor he who loves abundance with its income; this too is vanity.' This was spoken by Solomon, the wealthiest man who ever lived, who had more money than he could count, making gold as common as stones in Jerusalem. He tried to fulfill himself through every desire, like building, growing things, hobbies, and even having numerous wives, but found it all meaningless. Pastor Bob connects this to show that even extreme wealth and experiences don't satisfy the soul.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this biblical quote and Solomon's life to illustrate that coveting and loving money leads to dissatisfaction, as experienced by the richest man in history.

illustrations.title: MRI as Spiritual Insight
illustrations.text: Have you ever had an MRI? It's no fun, but it's different from an X-ray. An MRI takes multiple images of skin, bone, and muscle to find imperfections or diseases in your body. It's an amazing thing. In a sense, this commandment is like God's spiritual MRI; it can see things deep inside you that no other commandment addresses.
illustrations.context: This analogy illustrates how the 10th commandment reveals hidden inner sins like coveting that other commandments do not.

illustrations.title: Money's Limitations List
illustrations.text: I'm sure you've heard this before, but it's worth mentioning: Money can buy a house but not a home, except in Orange County where even that's tough. It can buy a bed but not sleep, a clock but not time, an education but not wisdom. It can buy food but not an appetite, position but not respect, medicine but not health, and stuff but not satisfaction.
illustrations.context: This analogy shows that money cannot solve deeper spiritual or emotional problems, emphasizing the need for contentment beyond material wealth.

illustrations.title: Leona Helmsley's Downfall
illustrations.text: Listen to this true story: She owns a string of hotels and the Empire State Building, and she's a billionaire, yet in September 1989, Leona Mindy Rosenthal Helmsley was convicted of 33 counts of tax evasion and spent time in prison. According to Time Magazine, she emerged as a penny-pinching tyrant who tried to stiff just about everybody, fighting over even the smallest amounts of money. After the sudden death of her only son at age 40 in 1982, she sued and won the lion's share of his estate, $149,000, leaving his four children with just $432 each and his widow with almost nothing.
illustrations.context: This real-world example illustrates how the love of money leads to harmful desires and personal ruin, warning against the dangers of greed.

illustrations.title: Pastor and Large Church
illustrations.text: I remember a pastor who had been blessed as his church grew on the East Coast. It was the biggest Calvary Chapel I'd ever seen, like a college campus with a steak restaurant. He shared at a conference that many pastors are impressed with the size of their campus but have no interest in the size of their mortgage. In other words, everyone sees the blessings but not the costs. This story highlights how success can have hidden burdens.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that coveting material success overlooks the underlying costs and challenges.

illustrations.title: Grass is Greener Analogy
illustrations.text: You've heard the expression that the grass is always greener on the other side of the fence. It always appears greener, but someone said the water bill is also much higher. This means that what others have might look more appealing, but it comes with its own expenses and responsibilities.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to show that coveting what others have ignores the true costs and realities involved.

illustrations.title: Fear of Singleness Gift
illustrations.text: When I was young, I remember hearing about the gift of singleness, and it was a scary thing. I thought it was like a disease that nobody wanted, something that meant nobody would ever like me. We always worried about it, as if it were the worst thing that could happen. It's a complete misunderstanding, but that's how it felt back then.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating how people often misunderstand and fear the gift of singleness, treating it as undesirable rather than a blessing from God.

illustrations.title: Adam's Garden Preparation
illustrations.text: When God made man, He put him to work in the garden before giving him a wife. Adam needed to learn how to take care of the garden to get ready for that relationship. This shows that God uses experiences to prepare us, and there's a timing involved in His plan. It's not just about being self-sufficient but discovering needs in due time.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is using this to explain that singleness is a gift from God meant for preparation and growth, similar to Adam's time before marriage.

illustrations.title: Three Rings Analogy
illustrations.text: I used to talk about the three rings of marriage: the engagement ring, the wedding ring, and the suffer ring. My wife told me to stop saying it because it might sound negative, but it's a humorous way to highlight that marriage involves challenges and suffering. As mentioned in the Bible, this illustrates the tribulations that come with married life.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to show that marriage brings hardships, as described in 1 Corinthians 7, emphasizing undistracted devotion to God.

illustrations.title: Lady's Marriage Quote
illustrations.text: That lady says when I got married, I was looking for the ideal, but what I found was an ordeal, and now I'm looking for a new deal. This quote highlights the disappointment and regret that can arise from unmet expectations in marriage. Pastor Bob connects it to the idea that coveting a different marital status won't necessarily bring happiness.
illustrations.context: He uses this quote to illustrate the futility of coveting and striving after what one doesn't have, as warned in Ecclesiastes.

illustrations.title: Abraham's Wealth Example
illustrations.text: In that culture, many people had servants, not just the rich ones. For example, think about Abraham; he was wealthy and had many servants, showing how common this was. This historical reference illustrates that even abundance, like having servants, can lead to coveting and dissatisfaction.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to explain the cultural context of coveting possessions, tying it to the biblical teaching on contentment.

illustrations.title: Abraham Rescues Kidnapped Lot
illustrations.text: Remember when Lot got kidnapped in the battle down in Sodom and was taken away? Abraham led his trained men out of his home, like special ops guys, and they defeated the enemies and rescued Lot and his family. That's quite impressive, showing how some people have more resources than others.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that some people will always have more resources, making it easy to covet what they have.

illustrations.title: Coveting a Better Vehicle
illustrations.text: Donkeys were used for transportation, like a service vehicle, even by poor people. Maybe you have an old clunker of a car, and your friend gets a new, powerful vehicle like a turbo burro. You might wish you had something like a monster mule instead, highlighting how people covet others' assets. This connects to coveting in an agrarian society.
illustrations.context: This analogy shows how coveting a neighbor's donkey translates to desiring better transportation in modern life.

illustrations.title: Jealousy Over Friend's Engagement
illustrations.text: I remember when you want to get married, and then your friend announces their engagement. You're happy for them, but it makes you feel a pang of why not you. This can be a hard thing, seeing someone blessed with something you desire, like relationships or popularity.
illustrations.context: This personal story illustrates the challenge of coveting blessings in others' lives, such as marriage or friendships.

illustrations.title: Dog on Water Anecdote
illustrations.text: There was a man on the beach with his dog. He threw a stick into the ocean, and the dog ran on top of the water to fetch it and brought it back the same way. Another guy watching asked what was going on, and when it happened again, he remarked that the dog doesn't know how to swim. This story leads into the idea that criticism is often just envy.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that criticism is frequently rooted in low-grade envy.

illustrations.title: Friend's Ministry Blessing
illustrations.text: I have a friend whose ministry God has chosen to bless, making it a worldwide effort. I've known him for a long time and I'm excited for him because we're seeing answers to prayers we shared years ago. He told me that I'm a true friend because I'm genuinely happy for his success, unlike some of his other friends who aren't as supportive. This highlights the importance of celebrating others' blessings.
illustrations.context: This shows that true friendship involves rejoicing in others' successes and avoiding covetousness.

illustrations.title: Man's House Realization Story
illustrations.text: I heard a story of a man who had lived in his house for a long time and decided it was the right time to sell. He called a realtor and was asked to write down everything commendable about his house and neighborhood. After creating an extensive list, he realized how amazing his home truly was. As a result, he chose not to sell and decided to stay, recognizing the value in what he already had. This illustrates that we need to take more time to consider the blessings God has given us.
illustrations.context: Contentment begins with appreciating the blessings we already have.

illustrations.title: Jacob's Reflection on Blessings
illustrations.text: Jacob was always wanting more for himself from his brother, his dad, and others, always striving to be successful and rich. God chose to bless him, giving him wealth, children, and servants, but also sought to change him. As Jacob returned home, he remembered his past when he was just a single man crossing the river alone, and now he had wives, children, flocks, and riches, realizing how different things were. This moment made him look back and appreciate God's mercies, saying, 'I am not worthy of the least of your mercies.' He recognized he didn't deserve any of these blessings, and this reflection is something we all need to do.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses Jacob's story to illustrate that gratitude comes from reflecting on God's blessings to combat covetousness.

illustrations.title: David's Psalm of Thankfulness
illustrations.text: David says in his presence there is fullness of joy and at his right hand are pleasures forever, emphasizing that thankfulness is the key to entering God's presence. Asaph declares, 'Whom have I in heaven but You? And besides You, I desire nothing on earth,' which is the opposite of covetousness. David also urges in Psalm 103, 'Bless the Lord, O my soul, and all that is within me, bless His holy name; forget not all His benefits,' and lists them, starting with how He pardons all your iniquities. Pastor Bob connects this by asking when was the last time we thanked God for these mercies.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses these quotes to show that thankfulness leads to joy in God's presence and counters covetousness.

illustrations.title: Friend's Wealth and Regret
illustrations.text: I remember when I was a police officer, I had a friend who was a Christian and single, but God had blessed him with great business sense. He ran a side business with vending machines, was making a lot of money, and even bought houses in Orange County back in the late 70s and early 80s. We were all impressed with his success and he invited us cops and our wives to his beautiful home, while many of us were still struggling to buy our first house. But I'll never forget, he came up to me and said that he'd give it all up in a heartbeat if he could have what I had, implying a deeper satisfaction in family and faith.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate that material success does not equate to true satisfaction, emphasizing that God meets all needs as described in Psalm 23.

illustrations.title: Emerson's Stars Parable
illustrations.text: He said, can you imagine if the stars only came out one night a year? Everyone would stay up all night to see them. But because they're far more available to us, we ignore them. The point is that God's blessings are so abundant in our life that we tend to take them for granted.
illustrations.context: To illustrate how people take God's blessings for granted because they are always present.

illustrations.title: Manna in the Wilderness
illustrations.text: Think of Manna in the Old Testament. It was a miraculous bread that God provided when they were starving in the wilderness; they could grind it up and make different items out of it. At first, it was exciting and new, something amazing that satisfied them. But after eating it every day for years, they grew tired of it and even wished for other food, longing for the past.
illustrations.context: To show how people can start taking God's provisions for granted over time.

illustrations.title: David's Repentance Journey
illustrations.text: When David sinned with Bathsheba and lived in sin for a year, he was miserable. Psalm 32 describes how he withered away spiritually like the heat of summer and felt dried up. Finally, he confessed his sin, and the Lord healed him, restoring the joy of his salvation as he prayed in Psalm 51 for a clean heart.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that sin leads to misery for believers and that confession restores joy and closeness with God.

illustrations.title: Marital Separation Practice
illustrations.text: In the law, the husband and wife's sexual relationship was interrupted during the woman's menstrual cycle. They were required to refrain for a short period and then come back together. God designed this guidance to create times of abstinence so that couples would appreciate their intimacy more.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that God sometimes uses separation to help people value and appreciate their blessings.

illustrations.title: Church During Separation
illustrations.text: The Lord has given the church times of separation, like when we couldn't gather together and had to wear masks. This period helps us appreciate the joy of being together again. I look forward to when we won't need masks anymore, highlighting how absence can deepen our value for fellowship.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that God allows times of absence to increase appreciation for spiritual community and blessings.

illustrations.title: Fire Evacuation Perspective
illustrations.text: Some of our folks at church got evacuated during the fires, and there's an interesting thing that happens when you have to leave your house wondering if it's for the last time. We had to evacuate a few years ago, and I remember meeting down at the 7-Eleven as they cleared the streets because the fire was coming over the hill. We thought it might be the end, but standing there with my wife and sons, I realized everything that matters—the Lord and my family—was right there. I said, 'I have the Lord and my family; it's all I need.' It was an emotional moment that showed me I don't care that much about material things if I have what's truly important.
illustrations.context: To illustrate that losing possessions can help appreciate the true value of faith and family.

illustrations.title: Beach Appreciation Story
illustrations.text: Becky and I love going to the beach; it's just a half hour away, and we enjoy taking the motorcycle down through the beautiful country. We cruise around Laguna and admire the ocean and the beaches in our favorite areas. Even though there are million-dollar houses with incredible views along the coast, we often talk about whether we'd want to live there, and we decide no, because we find contentment in what we have. It's amazing how these simple pleasures help us appreciate blessings without needing more.
illustrations.context: To show that we often don't appreciate everyday blessings until we reflect on them, emphasizing contentment.

illustrations.title: Ocean Appreciation Analogy
illustrations.text: I'll tell you why I don't want to live there. I know what would happen: I'd look out at that ocean every day, and soon I wouldn't even notice it because it would just be the view that's always there. For me, I like going once in a while, and then it's amazing every time. There's something about learning to appreciate what we have, that sometimes absence makes the heart grow fonder.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to show that constant presence can lead to taking things for granted, emphasizing the need to appreciate what we have.

illustrations.title: Famous Last Words Examples
illustrations.text: I have been interested in reading and studying the last words of various people over the years. There are some profound sayings and some quizzical ones that seem odd, as people have said them while dying. We have the expression 'famous last words,' and I suppose that's what we call Second Timothy—famous and faithful last words. These are some that I read about, though I don't know who said them: one person said, 'I get a world record for this.' Another said, 'He's probably just hibernating.' One said, 'What does this button do?' And another, 'I'm making a citizen's arrest.'
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses these examples to introduce 2 Timothy as Paul's famous and faithful last words, contrasting them with quirky or humorous ones.

illustrations.title: Paul's Faithful Last Words
illustrations.text: Paul will say I have fought the good fight, I've run the course, I've done it, crowns laid up for me, the time of my departure has come, but I did it, I finished it. It's very interesting Jesus said something very similar. Paul is going to say to his follower in the faith, do what I've done, be faithful Timothy.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to illustrate the importance of faithfully completing one's ministry, just as Paul did.

illustrations.title: Jesus's Completed Work Quote
illustrations.text: Jesus said something very similar in the high priestly prayer: I have finished the work Father that you gave me to do. Well it's important that you can say that at the end of your life, that you knew what the work was and you did it.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob connects this quote to show that, like Jesus, believers should aim to complete their God-given tasks.

illustrations.title: Nero's Persecution of Paul
illustrations.text: From early church tradition, Paul the Apostle was swept up in the first statewide persecution of the church under Caesar Nero. Around 64 AD, a fire broke out in Rome and burned for six days, destroying much of the city. It's believed that Nero set the fire himself to rebuild Rome into a glorious new capital, but he blamed the Christians as scapegoats to deflect suspicion. Early Christians and historians like Tacitus noted this hatred, leading to Paul and Peter becoming martyrs under Nero's rule. This event highlights the dangers faced by early believers.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this historical event to illustrate the importance of faithfulness in the face of persecution.

illustrations.title: Clement's Praise of Paul
illustrations.text: Clement, an early church father and pastor in Rome in the first century, says this about Paul: by reason of jealousy and strife, Paul by his example pointed out the prize of patient endurance. After being seven times in bonds, arrested, driven into exile, and stoned, he preached in the east and west, even as far as Spain. He won noble renown for his faith, taught righteousness to the whole world, reached the farthest bounds of the West, and bore testimony before rulers. Ultimately, he departed from the world as a notable pattern of patient endurance.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize Paul's example of enduring hardship faithfully as a model for believers.

illustrations.title: Kids in Church Example
illustrations.text: A couple of kids were in church one day, acting up and talking a little bit. Another kid said, 'Shh, in church so nobody can hear me.' They replied, 'Yeah, if you don't be quiet, the ushers are gonna tell you to be quiet.' Pastor Bob explains that these ushers represent the forces in life that discourage standing boldly for Jesus Christ.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that there are people or fears in life that tell you not to stand boldly for Christ.

illustrations.title: DL Moody's Evangelism
illustrations.text: DL Moody, the great evangelist, once walked up to a man on the street corner, a total stranger he didn't know. He asked the man, 'Sir, are you a Christian?' The man replied, 'That's none of your business.' Moody responded, 'Actually, that is my business,' and Pastor Bob connects this to the idea of knowing and fulfilling God's mission in our lives.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize that Christians are ambassadors for Christ with a mission to fulfill, just as Moody boldly shared his faith.

illustrations.title: Farmer Warns Officer
illustrations.text: There was a state officer checking fields for illegally grown marijuana and drugs, and he asked a farmer about his properties. The farmer warned him not to go into one particular field because it was dangerous. The officer insisted on his authority and entered anyway, only to start screaming for help as he ran from whatever was in there. The farmer yelled back, 'Show him your badge!' and the situation brought laughter.
illustrations.context: This illustrates Paul's authority as an apostle, showing it's not about boasting but about God's mercy and unexpected situations.

illustrations.title: Saul Transformed by God
illustrations.text: Saul in the Old Testament had never done anything particularly spiritual or noteworthy according to Scripture. Then the Spirit of God came upon him, and he became a different man, prophesying for the first time and speaking God's Word with authority. This event became famous in Israel, with people asking, 'Is Saul among the prophets?' It demonstrates that God can use anyone, no matter their background.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that just as God transformed Saul, He showed mercy to Paul, proving He can use impossible people like him.

illustrations.title: Grandson Learning Words
illustrations.text: My grandson is just 2 years old, and he is learning to talk. It's wonderful to watch as words slowly form, even though he can't say them perfectly yet, we know what he means. One day, I gave him a little mint, and he loves them, so I said, 'Do you want a mint?' He said, 'Bit,' and I tried to correct him by saying, 'Say mint,' but he kept saying 'Bit.' Sometimes, he just hasn't got it yet, but it's clear that children learn through imitation.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate that children learn primarily through imitation, applying it to the principle of spiritual growth and the 'like father like son' concept.

illustrations.title: Passing the Baton
illustrations.text: Paul is passing the baton to Timothy, meaning that at the end of his life, Paul knows his work must continue, so he entrusts it to this faithful young man. He says the things you have learned from me, entrust to faithful people who will teach others also, tagging Timothy as the one to carry on. It's Paul's way of saying it's your turn now, ensuring the mission goes forward even after he's gone.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to emphasize the importance of passing spiritual responsibilities to the next generation.

illustrations.title: Mentoring Young Men
illustrations.text: I am so grateful for the seven young men, half my age, that I meet with every week for a couple of hours. They love this church, love me, and love the Lord, and they allow me to pour into them while sharing their ideas with me. This group excites me about what God has for our church now and in the future, as we invest in the next generation together.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob shares this to illustrate the value of personally investing in younger people for the church's ongoing ministry.

illustrations.title: Boy Critiques Preacher
illustrations.text: After the church service, a little boy came up to the preacher and said, 'When I grow up, I'm going to give you some money.' The pastor asked why, and the boy replied, 'Because my dad says you're one of the poorest preachers we've ever had.' This story highlights the need for mercy toward pastors.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that pastors are human and need mercy despite criticism.

illustrations.title: Pastor Removes Blow Dryers
illustrations.text: One pastor had installed blow dryers in the bathrooms, but after two weeks, he took them out. When someone asked why, he explained that they worked fine, but he found a sign that said, 'For a sample of this week's sermon, push the button: hot air.' This incident underscores the challenges pastors face.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize that pastors need mercy in the face of humorous yet pointed criticism.

illustrations.title: Police Officer Advice
illustrations.text: When I was a police officer in Placentia and before that in La Habra, people often asked me, 'What's the best way to get out of a ticket?' I can tell you the two best ways: first, don't speed, as it aligns with biblical advice like Romans 13; second, if you're guilty, own up to it instead of making excuses. This personal experience ties into humility and avoiding pride.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to connect with the idea of humility and receiving God's grace, as mentioned in James 4:6.

illustrations.title: Traffic Court Excuses
illustrations.text: Have you ever gone to traffic court just for fun? We took our kids when they were little; it was cheap entertainment, and we just walked inside to watch. It's funny to see people make excuses to the judge, thinking theirs will work when the judge has heard them all a thousand times. Cops hear those excuses all the time too.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate how people persistently make excuses, similar to how one might need mercy in life.

illustrations.title: From Cop to Pastor
illustrations.text: People sometimes ask me why I became a pastor, finding it incredulous that I left law enforcement for this role. They think being a cop is exciting and being a pastor is boring, but they don't understand my job or the privilege it holds. I'm grateful for the men and women in law enforcement in our church and community, as we need them and other first responders.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob shares this to explain his career transition and emphasize the value of his current role while appreciating law enforcement.

illustrations.title: Paul's Prison Praise
illustrations.text: Here's Paul, getting ready to be executed in a dark, dank dungeon on death row, yet he's constantly praying for Timothy and praising God. He had a huge prayer list and praised the Lord even in that dire situation, not like his house arrest in Acts. Do you remember what happened in Acts 16 when he was in jail in Philippi? He learned to praise God wherever he was, knowing that if God wanted him out, he would be, or if home, that was even better.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that one should praise and pray to God in all circumstances, as Paul did.

illustrations.title: Angry Mechanic Coworker
illustrations.text: I worked with a man years ago who was a mechanic at the service station where I worked when I was young. I'll never forget him because when things went wrong, like slipping with a tool and hurting himself, he would get so angry that he would throw his glasses across the room and smash them. This happened repeatedly, and I don't know how many pairs of glasses he went through, but that was just his style. There are some people who are unforgettable because of their bad attitude.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that some people are unforgettable for their bad attitudes, in contrast to those who inspire gratitude like Timothy.

illustrations.title: Election Loss and Tears
illustrations.text: In grade school, there were only two people running for president: me and my best friend, who wasn't my friend after that, Paul. He beat me by 15 votes, and I remember the day they announced it over the PA speaker in 7th period while I was in PE. I heard it in the locker room: 'The new president is Paul Lewis.' As a kid, I acted like I didn't care, thinking who needs this stupid school, and headed to the bus. But there was Belinda Lizotte, sobbing as if someone had died, and I asked her what was wrong. I've never forgotten that moment, as it showed me the depth of her care.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to illustrate the importance of valuing others enough to weep for them when they are hurting.

illustrations.title: Ancient Sculptors and Wax
illustrations.text: In the ancient world, there were all kinds of products, particularly sculptures. Poor quality sculptors would cover up flaws or cracks with wax, fill in the mistake, and then paint over it. You'd pay a lot of money for a beautiful sculpture of yourself and display it proudly. But if it was poorly done, the sun could melt the wax, causing parts like your nose to fall off. In contrast, top-quality workers advertised their pieces as 'sine cere,' meaning without wax, ensuring nothing fake or falsified.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that sincere faith means nothing fake or hidden, just as high-quality sculptures were advertised without wax.

illustrations.title: Churches as Showcases Analogy
illustrations.text: Some churches become showcases for saints rather than hospitals for sinners. I pray we are never that kind of church. I pray there's not a person who can walk in the doors and not be immediately accepted and loved, for such were some of us and we've been forgiven.
illustrations.context: This analogy illustrates the danger of hypocrisy in churches, emphasizing that they should be welcoming places for sinners rather than perfect facades.

illustrations.title: Judas as False Disciple
illustrations.text: Remember Judas looked like the real deal when Jesus said one of you will betray me. They didn't all look at Judas; instead, they thought it might be themselves, saying, 'Is it I?'. He was not the one they suspected, showing how appearances can deceive.
illustrations.context: This retelling shows that you can't always be sure of someone else's faith based on outward appearances.

illustrations.title: Cynic on Hidden Non-Christians
illustrations.text: Some cynic once said if you scratch most Christians hard enough you'll find a non-Christian. Pastor Bob counters this by saying he doesn't believe it's true, using it to contrast with Paul's encouragement of genuine faith. This highlights the tension between doubt and assurance in faith.
illustrations.context: This quote illustrates the skepticism about true faith, but Pastor Bob uses it to affirm the reality of authentic belief.

illustrations.title: Centurion's Great Faith
illustrations.text: I think of the Centurion that comes to Jesus in the Gospel of Matthew. He's a Gentile who says his servant or boy—possibly a son or a slave—is sick and needs healing. We don't know exactly who it is, but he demonstrates remarkable faith in Jesus' power.
illustrations.context: This story illustrates the importance of commending and encouraging faith in others, as Paul did with Timothy.

illustrations.title: Centurion's Remarkable Faith
illustrations.text: Jesus marveled at this man and said, 'I have not seen such great faith in all of Israel.' Here's a Gentile who demonstrated great faith. Would you think that might have been encouraging to the guy besides getting the boy healed?
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate great faith in a Gentile that impressed Jesus.

illustrations.title: Syrophoenician Woman's Persistence
illustrations.text: How about the Syrophoenician woman, another Gentile in the Gospel of Matthew, who persists and persists, saying, 'Please cast the demon out of my daughter.' Jesus seems to be ignoring her, but she persists, and when he says it's not right to take the bread from the children's table and give it to the dogs, she replies that even the dogs get the crumbs. He then says, 'Woman, great is your faith; be it done unto you according to your faith.'
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to highlight persistent faith and how it leads to encouragement and healing.

illustrations.title: Salvation Encounter with Mentors
illustrations.text: When I thank the Lord for my salvation, I take time to think about the day I received Christ and how it happened through two men, Jeff Maples and Jean Schaeffer, who I believe are in heaven now. They were in their 30s, which seemed old to me as a 13-year-old, and they had the boldness to share the gospel with me, a junior high kid with quite an attitude. They didn't build a big relationship or take me to Bible studies; they simply shared for five minutes and asked if I would receive Christ, and I did. I thank God for those two men every day as part of that experience.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to illustrate the impact of bold evangelism and the chain of faith transmission.

illustrations.title: Unbroken Chain of Evangelism
illustrations.text: I say, Lord, would you send out the twelve as in the Great Commission, and there is an unbroken chain link after link through generations down to Jean and Jeff of people who shared the gospel with others. It's like a chain where each link connects to the next, from the disciples to those who shared with them, and so on, until it reached me. I reflect on how I want to be a faithful link in this history, passing it on to the next generation so they can hear the gospel again.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to emphasize the ongoing legacy of sharing the gospel across generations.

illustrations.title: Witnessing to My Parents
illustrations.text: My mom and dad attended a Lutheran Church and raised us five kids there. I got saved outside of that church and as a young man, I tried to witness to them by telling them they were going to hell. One time, I took the Four Spiritual Laws to my mom's room and asked her to pray the sinner's prayer, but she said it was for becoming a Christian and that she already was one. I dismissed their faith for a long time because I didn't get saved in that church. Now, I'm grateful for the foundation of gospel truths they provided through that church.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates the danger of judging others' salvation based on personal standards.

illustrations.title: Olympic Athlete Comparison
illustrations.text: Can you imagine if an Olympic athlete looked at you and said, 'Your heart rate is not as low as mine, your BMI is higher than mine, you don't exercise nearly at all, so I'm not sure you're actually alive'? That's going a little too far, just like deciding someone isn't saved because they don't seem as saved as you. This analogy shows how absurd it is to question others' salvation based on external measures.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to highlight the folly of measuring others' salvation by one's own standards.

illustrations.title: Monica's Persistent Prayer
illustrations.text: I want to tell you about a man named Patrick, who was married to Monica. Patrick was a hothead, easily angered, verbally abusive to his wife, and unfaithful multiple times in their marriage. Monica was a devoted believer who loved Jesus, but Patrick opposed Christianity until his death. She prayed passionately for her children's salvation, and it seemed her prayers went unheard as they grew up. Eventually, their son Augustine was radically converted at age 31 because Monica never stopped praying.
illustrations.context: This story shows that persistent prayer can lead to salvation, even in families with unbelieving and hostile members.

illustrations.title: Robin Williams Politics Joke
illustrations.text: I was thinking about that word politics, and probably the best definition of it is the one Robin Williams gave. He said it's two words in Latin: 'poly' which means many, and 'ticks' which means blood-sucking creatures, so he says that's what politics is. It's actually not true, but it humorously captures the frustration many feel with the current political climate.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to lighten the mood and illustrate the overwhelming nature of politics, encouraging the audience to focus on eternal truths amid turmoil.

illustrations.title: Fellow Sufferers Quote
illustrations.text: I love the quote 'fellow sufferers should be joint petitioners.' We're all suffering in some way, shape, or form, and in various stages of suffering, but we should turn that suffering into petitions to the Lord. This means we pull ourselves God's way on these scenarios and subjects, turning our pain into shared prayers. It's a reminder that in our struggles, we can come together as a community.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that shared suffering should lead to united prayers, fostering community and reliance on God.

illustrations.title: Watching My Sister's Dog
illustrations.text: Becky and I are currently watching my sister's dog. We haven't had a dog for a while, so we're glad to be doing that, and we're glad it's temporary. This is a little dog named Summer. Although this isn't a picture of her, I wanted to show you this picture because everyone who has a dog or has been around one knows that they love to have their tummies rubbed.
illustrations.context: To share a personal experience and engage the audience with a relatable, everyday example.

illustrations.title: Dog's Submission Behavior
illustrations.text: It's instinctive for dogs; most will come up to you if they're comfortable. My sister's little dog, Summer, comes up on the couch and lets me know she's ready for a belly rub. But you should know that in dog language, this isn't just about enjoying the rub; it's a way to submit to you. This behavior is built into the species, unlike most cats. We think it means they like it, and they do, but it signifies submission. There's a relationship between submission and fulfillment as seen biblically.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate the biblical connection between submission and fulfillment.

illustrations.title: Slaves in Roman Empire
illustrations.text: A lot of the people Peter was talking to weren't free; they were slaves, with about 60 million slaves in the Roman Empire, and many who came to Christ were from that class. These people had been bought and sold and were considered property, not persons. Yet Peter writes to believers in that condition, telling them to act as free men without using their freedom as a cover for evil.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that even slaves can act as free men in Christ, emphasizing spiritual freedom despite physical bondage.

illustrations.title: Freed from Law Analogy
illustrations.text: We are like a woman who's married to a man, and when her husband dies, she's free to remarry. Paul explains that she's freed from the law of marriage because he's dead. Through Christ, we have died to the law, and it no longer has authority over us, setting us free in many ways.
illustrations.context: This analogy illustrates how believers are freed from the Old Testament law through Christ.

illustrations.title: Free at Last Quote
illustrations.text: The child of God can sing those famous words from the old Negro spiritual: free at last, free at last, thank God Almighty, I'm free at last. This quote comes from a 1940 spiritual written by a man named Work, who was not talking about his current experience but about future freedom. Pastor Bob connects it to spiritual freedom in Christ, showing that true liberation comes from being set free by the Son.
illustrations.context: This quote emphasizes that believers experience true freedom in Christ, as echoed in the spiritual.

illustrations.title: Martin Luther King's Freedom Hope
illustrations.text: Even Martin Luther King, when he wrote about it, said we hope to someday have that experience, but as believers, we can say that is our experience. We are free at last, not because we're Americans, but because we're born-again Christians. This freedom comes from spiritual rebirth, not human citizenship.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that true freedom is achieved through being a born-again Christian, contrasting it with earthly hopes.

illustrations.title: Judaizers and Legalism in Acts
illustrations.text: In the book of Acts, there were Judaizers who came around and said that you need to be circumcised and keep the law of Moses. They told Gentiles that it's fine you accepted Jesus, but you also need to accept the law of Moses otherwise you're not really saved or not very saved. This example illustrates how people add extra requirements to the finished work of Christ.
illustrations.context: This retelling warns against legalism by showing how adding to salvation requirements undermines true faith.

illustrations.title: Speaking in Tongues Requirement
illustrations.text: There are people in just about every denomination, including our type of church, who say that unless you speak in tongues, you're not really saved or not very saved. This is an example of adding to the finished work of Christ, similar to historical legalism. It shows how modern believers can fall into the same trap of judging spirituality based on specific practices.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate the error of legalism in contemporary Christianity by adding unbiblical requirements to salvation.

illustrations.title: Personal Rules and Legalism
illustrations.text: Some people say things like, I don't smoke and I don't chew and I don't go with girls that do, and they have their own rules about the kind of movies or music they allow. This becomes legalism when they judge others' spirituality based on these lifestyle choices. It's an analogy for how easy it is to add personal standards to faith.
illustrations.context: This analogy highlights the tendency of Bible-believing Christians to become legalistic by imposing extra rules beyond Scripture.

illustrations.title: Paul's Galatians Warning
illustrations.text: Paul wrote to the Galatian Christians in chapter 5, saying it was for freedom from the law that Christ has set you free, so keep standing firm and do not subject yourself again to a yoke of slavery. He also warned them not to use their liberty as a covering for evil but to serve one another through love. Pastor Bob connects this to avoiding both legalism and misuse of freedom.
illustrations.context: This quote illustrates the balance between freedom in Christ and the danger of returning to legalism or abusing liberty.

illustrations.title: Thief on the Cross Excuse
illustrations.text: They might say the thief on the cross never went to church but he got into heaven. That's true, there wasn't a church for another 43 days if I read my Bible correctly. That's not a good excuse for why you should honor the Lord where He says not to forsake the assembling of yourselves together.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that the thief's salvation doesn't excuse neglecting church attendance as commanded in the Bible.

illustrations.title: Divorce Justification Story
illustrations.text: That person who years ago said to me, 'I know God hates divorce, but God understands my situation and He would not want His daughter to be unhappy, so I'm not going to honor that and stay with my husband.' I hear that and think about how people justify actions against biblical commands. It's an example of twisting God's word for personal comfort.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is showing how people misuse God's understanding to excuse sin like divorce.

illustrations.title: Dating Non-Christian Tale
illustrations.text: That one who said to me years before that, 'I know he's not a Christian, but I prayed about it and I feel led to date him; I have a total peace about it. After all, how can it be so wrong when it feels so right?' I hear that and say you're being led by your hormones and not the Holy Spirit. It's a clear example of confusing emotions with God's leading.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to demonstrate how feelings can mislead people into disobeying biblical principles about relationships.

illustrations.title: Paul in Philippian Jail
illustrations.text: Paul and Silas were beaten and thrown into the Philippian jail, but he never mentions his Roman citizenship to get out of being beaten or jailed. He brings it up when the magistrates want to release him quietly, saying, 'Oh no, it's not happening like that until they come down in person and release us.' They were terrified, and I think that's one reason the church in Philippi flourished, as even a government official like the jailer and his family got saved.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates how Paul wisely used his freedom and citizenship to advance the gospel and hold authorities accountable.

illustrations.title: Paul in Jerusalem Escape
illustrations.text: There was the time in Jerusalem where Paul almost got killed on the Temple Mount; the Jews were going to kill him right there if they could. He was spared by that Roman centurion on the Antonio Fortress. Can you imagine the tension as Paul faced that danger?
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to highlight how Paul's Roman citizenship protected him and furthered his ministry despite threats.

illustrations.title: Brother's Supreme Court Honor
illustrations.text: My brother was a defense attorney, and I was a cop, so it was always great for conversation because I'd get someone in and he'd get them out. The honor of a defense attorney is to present a case to the Supreme Court of the United States. My brother had that opportunity in his lifetime and actually won the case, and that's quite an honor.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the honor Paul felt in presenting his case and preaching to the Sanhedrin, drawing a parallel to a lawyer's prestigious opportunity.

illustrations.title: Sadducees' Sadness Pun
illustrations.text: The Sadducees were sad, you see, because they don't believe in the resurrection, whereas the Pharisees do believe in it. This highlights the doctrinal differences that caused conflict. Paul used this division to his advantage when preaching.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to explain how the Sadducees' disbelief in resurrection made them 'sad' and contrasted with the Pharisees, aiding Paul's defense.

illustrations.title: Old Testament Bond Servant
illustrations.text: In the Old Testament, a Jewish man who was poor could sell himself into servanthood, which was more like indentured service than harsh slavery. This servanthood lasted no more than six years, after which he must be released according to God's law. However, if the servant loved his master and chose to stay permanently, the master would pierce his ear with an awl as a symbol of lifelong commitment, signifying that his ears were open to the master's will.
illustrations.context: This retelling illustrates the voluntary commitment to serve God as a bond servant, emphasizing willing service over forced obligation.

illustrations.title: Proverbs on Advocacy
illustrations.text: Proverbs 31:8-9 instructs to speak up for those who cannot speak for themselves, for the rights of all who are destitute, and to judge fairly while defending the rights of the poor and needy. Pastor Bob connects this quote to the importance of using our freedom of speech in modern society. He explains that it calls believers to actively advocate for the vulnerable, tying it to current cultural issues.
illustrations.context: This quote underscores the need to use one's voice to defend the marginalized and promote righteousness.

illustrations.title: Supreme Court Violence Concerns
illustrations.text: There's concern in the news about a potential Supreme Court decision that could spark violence across the United States as soon as tomorrow. Pastor Bob relates this to the ongoing issue of abortion over the past 50 years, describing it as violence in the womb that has persisted. He urges prayer for peace and righteousness, framing it as a call to use our voices to speak up for the unborn and the needy.
illustrations.context: This real-world example illustrates the urgency of using freedom of speech and prayer to advocate for peace and end injustice.

illustrations.title: Chuck Smith on Freedom
illustrations.text: Chuck Smith wrote that we are not really free to live after the flesh or the lust of our flesh. As Christians, it's not a freedom to go sin; instead, you're free as a believer to not live after the lust of your flesh. The world is bound by their flesh as slaves to it, but in Christ, we have the freedom to live for righteousness and do as we ought.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to explain that Christian freedom means being free to obey God, not to indulge in sin.

illustrations.title: Train on Tracks Analogy
illustrations.text: I've heard it described this way: it's not the idea that I can do whatever I want, but the picture of a train locomotive on its tracks. That locomotive is powerful, but if you take it off the tracks and put it in the sand, it gets stuck and can't move, no matter how great its power. However, when it's on the tracks doing what it was designed to do, it operates in true freedom.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates that Christian freedom means staying on the path of righteousness, where we function as intended, rather than pursuing selfish desires.

illustrations.title: Drug Addict Transformation Story
illustrations.text: Like that guy who said he used to be a hopeless drug addict before he knew the Lord, but now he's a drugless hope addict. My life has completely changed in a similar way, as the Bible teaches that we were slaves to sin but are now free to become slaves of righteousness. This shows how encountering Christ transforms a person from bondage to hope and purpose.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this example to demonstrate the reality of being freed from sin's slavery through Christ, enabling a life of righteousness.

illustrations.title: Cloud Formation Message
illustrations.text: I don't know if you saw it in the news about 12 or 13 days ago, but there was a massive formation in the clouds seen from a satellite, forming a giant 'G' and a kind of 'O'. The article titled it 'Earth tells us to go in weird cloud message seen from space,' suggesting it might be a message. This real event highlights how unusual signs in nature can point to greater truths.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this real-world event to illustrate spiritual truths, possibly as a sign or reminder of divine communication.

illustrations.title: Saul and Ananias Mission
illustrations.text: In the book of Acts, Saul gets saved on the road to Damascus; he was the first terrorist in the church, and everyone was afraid of him. He's led blind into Damascus, where the Lord appears to a believer named Ananias and tells him to go pray for Saul to restore his sight. Ananias hesitates because he knows Saul is dangerous, but God simply says to get up and go, assuring him that Saul is now one of His own. It's the same command God gave to Philip, who was in the middle of a successful revival in Samaria, telling him to go to a desert area and wait for further instructions.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that Christians must obey God's call to go and make disciples, just as Ananias and Philip did.

illustrations.title: Chevrolet Nova Sales Issue
illustrations.text: You know, they say Chevrolet had a hard time selling one of its models in Mexico, the Nova, because 'Nova' means 'no go' in Spanish. I don't know if that's actually true, but that's what I've heard. This story shows that God can't steer you if you're not going, meaning you need to start moving in your life to follow His direction and fulfill the Great Commission right where you are.
illustrations.context: This example emphasizes that you won't know God's specific guidance until you take the first step to go and make disciples.

illustrations.title: Woman at the Well Contrast
illustrations.text: Remember John 4, the woman goes into town to bring people to meet Jesus. She had just met Him, but she's bringing men to meet Jesus. The disciples, who know Jesus, go into town and buy bread for Jesus, who's not even hungry. What a contrast! The people on the mission are bringing nobody to Jesus, while the woman, who's not even quite sure who He is, is bringing a truckload of people to Jesus.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that even newcomers to faith can effectively share the gospel, unlike those more familiar who might neglect it.

illustrations.title: Ancient Slave Culture Example
illustrations.text: In that culture, there were 60 million slaves who were considered things. The mentality of people was to use things and love people, but often it got reversed, leading to loving things and using people. These slaves, whom the letter was addressing, were seen as things, and the Bible calls for valuing all people equally.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is using this to emphasize the biblical command to honor and value all people, regardless of their status.

illustrations.title: Jesus Values Bartimaeus
illustrations.text: Remember when Bartimaeus was crying out, 'Son of David, have mercy on me,' and everybody told him to shut up, like who do you think you are? But Jesus said, 'Bring him to me,' and they excitedly said, 'It's your lucky day, he's calling for you.' It's interesting that we know his name, and Bartimaeus means 'son of the foul,' likely a nickname because of his blindness, showing how society judged him.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that Jesus valued even beggars like Bartimaeus, treating them as worthy despite societal rejection.

illustrations.title: Jesus Dines with Zacchaeus
illustrations.text: He saw spiritual zeroes like Zacchaeus as worthy of his time and even purposed to go eat with him. Let me tell you, that was no mistake; Jesus didn't just wander in because he was hungry. He was going into the house of a chief publican, knowing what the Jewish leaders thought about tax collectors, to show he valued them despite their reputation.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates that Jesus intentionally honored and valued outcasts like Zacchaeus, challenging listeners to do the same.

illustrations.title: Peter's Sword Transformation
illustrations.text: Remember, Peter once used the sword in the garden to defend Jesus against the government. Now, he's going to use the sword in a completely different way—the sword of the Word of God. This shift shows how Peter moved from physical defense to spiritual proclamation.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize honoring all people by contrasting Peter's past actions with his future role, tying into valuing everyone.

illustrations.title: Jesus and the Tricksters
illustrations.text: Remember when they came to Jesus to trick him, and they said, 'We know you're a teacher who teaches the truth and you defer to no man.' Some translations say you're a respecter of no man, but the fact is He was a respecter of all men. He saw every person as created in the image of God.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to emphasize that true submission to God means valuing all people equally, as Jesus did.

illustrations.title: Sharing a Hamburger
illustrations.text: If I'm sitting down having a hamburger and my neighbor is there and they're hungry and can't afford to buy one, I should cut my hamburger in half and give them half. That's the Old Testament way of loving your neighbor as yourself. It means treasuring them as I treat myself, but Jesus calls for even greater sacrificial love.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates the difference between Old Testament love and Jesus' new commandment of loving others as He loved us, emphasizing sacrificial love.

illustrations.title: Christian Camp Song Memory
illustrations.text: I don't know if any of you have ever heard this song; I only heard it one year at camp when I did a summer up north. It's a Christian camp song with words like 'Look all around you and see what is real, hear what is true and be sure what you feel.' Then it says, 'Touch someone near you in love if you can, give all you have and be part of God's plan.' At that point, kids would get up from their seats and touch someone, which was cute.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate a simple, physical act of love, contrasting it with the deeper, sacrificial love commanded in the Bible.

illustrations.title: Catholic Greeting of Peace
illustrations.text: There's a point in the Catholic service called the greeting of peace, where you turn around and say, 'The peace of the Lord be with you.' It's similar to how we greet each other in church. I was thinking about this in relation to the song I mentioned, but Pastor Bob clarifies that this isn't what the Bible means by fervent love. Instead, it's about loving beyond just those nearby.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that true biblical love is not limited to greeting people who are physically close, like in a church service.

illustrations.title: John and the Demon Caster
illustrations.text: Do you remember when John once came to Jesus and reported, 'Lord, we saw someone casting out demons in your name, and we forbade him to do so because he does not follow with us'? Jesus said, 'Don't do that anymore. No one who casts out demons in my name will speak evil of me, for if they are not against us, they are for us.' This story highlights how Jesus addressed exclusivity among his followers.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to emphasize that Christians should not exclude others who are doing good in Jesus's name, promoting unity and love beyond one's own group.

illustrations.title: God's Love in Romans
illustrations.text: God's love demonstrates itself by stretching out, as in Romans 5:8: God demonstrates his own love toward us in that while we were yet sinners, Christ died for us. It stretches out from eternity down to you and brings east and west together. Christ's love doesn't care about your background or differences.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to show that God's love extends to everyone, even sinners, calling for inclusive love among believers.

illustrations.title: Matthew and Simon's Unity
illustrations.text: Matthew the tax collector and Simon the Zealot were so different—one committed to the death of tax collectors and the destruction of the Roman Empire. I would have loved to hear their conversations around the campfire, perhaps singing Kumbaya, even if they didn't like each other. Yet Christ brought them together, making those differences mean nothing, and we never read about their conflicts in the Bible, though I don't know how long it lasted.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how Christ unifies people with vast differences, emphasizing that such unity should be evident in the church.

illustrations.title: Jesus on Loving One Another
illustrations.text: Jesus said the ultimate apologetic for why people will believe you're His disciples is not through voting conservative or subscribing to certain media, but by this: if you love one another. He didn't say people will know you're His disciples by correct prophecy or beliefs about His return. This shows that sacrificial love is the key evidence of true discipleship.
illustrations.context: This quote demonstrates that loving one another is the primary way to prove one's faith and attract others to Christ.

illustrations.title: Early Christians' Distinct Love
illustrations.text: He gave a report that has echoed down through the centuries, describing in detail how they lived, sacrificed for one another, gave up their money to free someone arrested for being a Christian, and reacted when someone died. He talked about their behavior and how people looked at these Christians and said, 'Behold how they love one another.' Christians were distinct in the first century for having a love for each other that was not available in the world. This illustrates the sacrificial love that set them apart.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that early Christians were recognized by their sacrificial love, emphasizing how such love makes believers distinct.

illustrations.title: Song of Christian Love
illustrations.text: That's why in 1966 Peter Scholtes wrote, 'And they'll know we are Christians by our love.' I would simply change it to 'They will know we are Christians by His love.' This quote highlights how love among believers identifies them as followers of Christ, connecting it to the idea that our love reflects God's love. It's a reminder that this love is what truly marks us.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that people recognize Christians through their love, which stems from God.

illustrations.title: Testimony of Believer Relationships
illustrations.text: J. Vernon McGee said this: the relationship of the believer to other people is a testimony that speaks louder than the message from the pulpit. The fact is, you have the opportunity to talk about and treat Christians in such a way that people in your life will see and sense it, not just at church but everywhere you live and have an impact. This means your daily interactions can powerfully witness to others about your faith.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to point out that believers' relationships and actions provide a stronger testimony than words alone.

illustrations.title: Cafeteria Honesty Note
illustrations.text: I heard of this Christian school in a college cafeteria where students were coming through for lunch. There was a pile of apples with a note that said, 'Take one only, God is watching.' At the other end, a student added a pile of cookies with a note that said, 'Take all you want, God is watching the apples.' This humorous twist highlights how people might test or mock the idea of divine oversight.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that fearing God means having a deep reverence that influences honest behavior, even when no one else is watching.

illustrations.title: Joseph's Temptation Resistance
illustrations.text: Think about Joseph with Potiphar's wife; he had endured a lot of hurt, abuse from his brothers, and enslavement in Egypt, far from his family with no hope. Despite this, he remained faithful to his employer and avoided her advances as much as possible. When she directly tempted him, saying 'Come lie with me,' he refused, reasoning that it would be a great sin against God, even though he could have justified it to himself.
illustrations.context: This retelling shows that true faith is demonstrated by one's actions and thoughts when alone and tempted, emphasizing living blamelessly before God.

illustrations.title: David's Integrity Failure
illustrations.text: Remember, David did great most of the time until things were going great, and then at a time when kings go out to war, he didn't go but stayed home, got bored, and in the middle of the night or afternoon, he was walking around, looked out the window, and saw his neighbor. He thought he should meet her, and that progression affected him for the rest of his life. I believe that's the context of why he wrote Psalm 101 verses 2 and 3.
illustrations.context: To emphasize the importance of maintaining integrity and fearing God even when alone, as David's momentary lapse led to lifelong consequences.

illustrations.title: John Knox's Fearless Encounter
illustrations.text: John Knox was a Protestant fiery preacher who lived during the time when Mary Queen of Scots was persecuting Protestants, and people were worried for his safety around her. On one occasion, when John Knox was going in to talk to her, somebody warned him not to go in that day. He replied that he had just spent three hours in the presence of Almighty God, so why would he be afraid of a queen.
illustrations.context: To show that spending time in God's presence reduces fear of people and helps one live without worrying about others' opinions.

illustrations.title: McGee's Lesser of Two Evils
illustrations.text: McGee said, 'I never voted for president for anybody I wanted to be president; I voted against the other guy who I definitely didn't want.' He added that voting for the lesser of two evils is inevitable because people are inherently evil, as explained in Jeremiah. Jeremiah asks, 'Can a leopard change its spots? Can an Ethiopian change his skin?' meaning some things, like human nature, won't change, so we must understand we're always choosing between flawed options. Pastor Bob connects this to remind us that in elections, we're not voting for a savior but acknowledging our own evil nature.
