illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to illustrate that voting involves choosing the lesser of two evils due to inherent human sinfulness, emphasizing the need to respect authority despite disagreements.

illustrations.title: Peter Under Nero's Rule
illustrations.text: I want you to remember who Peter is under and who he will die under. In a very short time, Caesar Nero will kill Paul; Paul will be beheaded. Peter, according to church history, was crucified upside down because he felt unworthy to be crucified in the same way as his Lord. This all happened under Nero, who blamed Christians for the fire he set and was a crazy man who committed suicide about a year after that fire.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize honoring leaders despite their flaws, as early Christians did under the tyrannical Nero.

illustrations.title: Challenging Modern Complaints
illustrations.text: John Corson said this: How then can we have the audacity to snivel about our president or whine about our governor when our brothers and sisters honored a demented king whose main objective was to annihilate them? Lord, forgive us. This quote highlights the contrast between past faithfulness and our current attitudes.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to convict listeners that they should honor leaders without complaint, just as early Christians honored a destructive king.

illustrations.title: Israel's Delayed Promised Land Journey
illustrations.text: I know it's been 50 years, and I'm glad for Roe v. Wade coming down, but I sometimes wonder how long it took the children of Israel to get to the promised land—it was 40 years when it should have been four months. Did it have to be that long? I don't know, was it because I didn't pray? Maybe it was because I didn't care or see myself as part of the problem.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that personal spiritual negligence, like lack of prayer, can prolong national problems and delays God's intended blessings.

illustrations.title: David Spares Saul
illustrations.text: David had Saul, a man whom God wasn't speaking to anymore, a man that God had rejected. He could have taken Saul out so easily, and his men said, 'Do it! This is the day the Lord has made; go for it; take him out. You got him all by himself; let's strike it.' But David refused because he knew God had put Saul there to test him, and if God wants him out, He'll take him out in a moment. Until then, Saul is dealing with him, and David was going to trust his God. And if he humbled himself under Almighty God, someday God would exalt him, and that's exactly what happened.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize the need to submit and trust God under difficult leaders.

illustrations.title: Sanctuary Walk Blessings
illustrations.text: I was walking through the sanctuary this morning and was so blessed by getting to know new people and rekindling old relationships while joking around. I've heard stories of prayers being answered and God's mighty work, as well as things I need to start praying about. I've shaken so many hands that my Purell bottle is empty, and it's made me realize how vibrant our community is.
illustrations.context: To illustrate the joy and informal blessings of church interactions that make the service feel less formal.

illustrations.title: Dad's Birthday Milestone
illustrations.text: It happens to be a very important person's birthday today; it's my dad, who is turning 65, and that's quite an accomplishment. He doesn't act or move like his age—he rides 20-mile bike rides pretty often, which makes him pretty cool. So, we're going to celebrate him right now.
illustrations.context: To emphasize personal blessings and encourage sharing joyful moments in the community.

illustrations.title: Robin Williams Politics Quote
illustrations.text: I love what Robin Williams said about politics. He explained that if you don't know the definition, it's two words in Latin: 'poly' which means many, and 'ticks' which means bloodsuckers, so it's many bloodsuckers. But actually, it's not accurate; in Latin it means city-state, and in Greek it means citizen, though I like his version. This humorous take helps us see that the church's politics is different—we are citizens of heaven.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses the quote to contrast worldly division in politics with the unity and citizenship of heaven in the church.

illustrations.title: Fellow Sufferers Quote
illustrations.text: It's a great quote: 'Fellow sufferers are joint petitioners.' We're all going through something at various stages and seasons of life, and there's strength and power in the prayer of many. So, we want to petition the Lord and turn our problems into petitions.
illustrations.context: He uses this quote to highlight the strength found in communal prayer during life's challenges.

illustrations.title: Peter's Impending Martyrdom
illustrations.text: Peter is writing this letter knowing he is going to die soon after, under the hands of Caesar Nero, after the fire of Rome. Christians will be persecuted, and Peter and Paul will give up their lives. He is addressing believers who are scattered and facing even more persecution because they are Christians.
illustrations.context: To illustrate the context of severe persecution that early Christians endured, emphasizing themes of submission and suffering in faith.

illustrations.title: Slavery in Roman Empire
illustrations.text: A lot of Christians in the first century were slaves, meaning they were actual possessions of other people. About 60 million people in the Roman Empire were enslaved; they didn't own anything and were possessions themselves. Many from their ranks came to faith in Jesus Christ, so some of Peter's audience were actual slaves.
illustrations.context: To show that Peter's teachings on freedom and submission applied to real-life situations like slavery, highlighting how faith operates in oppressive circumstances.

illustrations.title: Martin Luther King Freedom Quote
illustrations.text: It is in fact the child of God, if you're a Christian, who can sing from the heart the words that Martin Luther King quoted in his 'I Have a Dream' speech at the Lincoln Memorial in 1963: 'Free at last, free at last, thank God Almighty, I'm free at last.' By the way, he didn't originate those words; he quoted from an old Negro spiritual from around 1940, written by a man named Woke. This illustrates that true freedom comes through Christ, allowing believers to embrace such expressions of liberation.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that believers are truly free in Christ, just as the words express spiritual liberation.

illustrations.title: Martin Luther King and Hymn
illustrations.text: If you read that hymn and listen to the speech in 1963, neither the hymn writer nor Martin Luther King was saying they were free at that moment; they meant someday they would be. The context of the hymn is clear—it's about being free in heaven after death at the rapture. King applied it socially and politically to talk about freedom regarding race.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that true freedom in Christ is spiritual and future-oriented, not an excuse to ignore authority.

illustrations.title: Judaizers and Legalism
illustrations.text: There were Judaizers, Jewish Christians who told Gentiles that accepting Christ as Savior was good, but they also needed to follow Moses' laws, like getting circumcised. Men weren't signing up for that, especially circumcision on Sundays. This was an early form of legalism where people added requirements to faith, thinking it made someone more spiritual.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates how Christians might misuse spiritual freedom by falling into legalism, adding extra rules beyond Christ's work.

illustrations.title: Woman's Divorce Justification
illustrations.text: I remember the gal who was divorcing her husband. She was a Christian, and he was too; I'd helped with their wedding, and they were friends of mine. She said he hadn't been unfaithful, but she was done with the marriage. She knew that in the Old Testament, God hates divorce, and she did too, but she felt God wouldn't want His daughter to be unhappy. So, she'd prayed about it and felt led to go through with it.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how people misuse their freedom in Christ to justify decisions that contradict biblical teachings on marriage.

illustrations.title: Dating Non-Christian Example
illustrations.text: Or the other gal who said she knew the guy she was starting to date wasn't a Christian, but she had a peace in her heart about it. She felt like the Holy Spirit was leading her into this relationship, even though it says not to be unequally yoked. I told her I thought she was being led by her hormones, not the Holy Spirit.
illustrations.context: This shows how individuals might claim spiritual leading for choices that violate Scripture, like entering unequal relationships.

illustrations.title: Paul's Citizenship in Acts
illustrations.text: Now let's remember Paul the Apostle, who was a Roman citizen and had certain privileges that most people didn't. He used them three times in the Book of Acts, one being when he was in Philippi after being beaten and thrown into prison. He didn't use his citizenship to avoid the beating and imprisonment; instead, Paul and Silas were thrown into prison, beaten, and put in stocks, but then an earthquake came at midnight.
illustrations.context: This retelling demonstrates how Paul employed his freedoms as a bond slave of God rather than as an excuse for wrongdoing.

illustrations.title: Paul's Citizenship in Philippi
illustrations.text: The jailer and his family got saved, which is very interesting to me because Paul used his authority as a Roman citizen. When the magistrates had allowed him to be beaten and thrown into prison without a trial, Paul refused to leave quietly and demanded they come personally to release him. They realized they had mistreated a Roman citizen, which I believe provided protection for the newly formed church in Philippi. Lydia by the riverside had already received Christ, and now the jailer and his family became charter members. I think God blessed that church as a result of this mistreatment and Paul's stand.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating how Paul's Roman citizenship protected the early church and its members.

illustrations.title: Paul's Riot in Jerusalem
illustrations.text: When Paul was in Jerusalem, he had a passion to preach to the Jews despite being called to the Gentiles. A riot broke out on the Temple Mount because of a rumor that he had brought a Gentile into the wrong place, and the crowd was about to kill him. Roman soldiers rushed down from the Antonio Fortress to save his life, taking him into the barracks. When they planned to scourge him, Paul revealed his Roman citizenship, halting the beating and leading to an opportunity to speak to the entire Sanhedrin, the ruling body of the Jews. This shows how his citizenship opened doors for preaching despite the danger.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating how Paul's Roman citizenship provided opportunities to share the gospel with key Jewish leaders.

illustrations.title: Brother's Supreme Court Defense
illustrations.text: My brother was a defense attorney, and I was a cop for 10 years. We used to say he gets them off, and I get them in; we're on two sides of the same coin. The dream of most defense attorneys is to speak in front of the Supreme Court, and very few get that chance. My brother actually had that opportunity and prevailed in his arguments, which is a big deal. Paul, however, used his opportunities not for personal honor but because he cared about people, and God used his rights as a citizen to open doors for ministry.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates how Paul used his freedoms for ministry, drawing a parallel to his brother's achievement to emphasize using opportunities selflessly.

illustrations.title: Biblical Bond Servant Choice
illustrations.text: God said to his people, you are not to enslave your brethren. If one of your brethren becomes so poor that they sell themselves to you, you can only keep them in bondage for six years and on the seventh year, you must let them go free. And if one who becomes a slave to your brother at the time of release realizes their master is loving and caring, they can declare themselves a bond servant. Then the master will take them to the doorway of his house, put their ear against the wooden doorway, and pierce it with an awl, symbolizing that their ear is open to hear the master's voice. This means they become part of the household forever because they chose it out of love.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that serving God is a voluntary choice made out of love, not forced slavery.

illustrations.title: Proverbs on Speaking for the Voiceless
illustrations.text: Speak up for those who cannot speak for themselves, for the rights of all who are destitute. Speak up and judge fairly; defend the rights of the poor and the needy, as stated in Proverbs 31:8-9. Pastor Bob connects this verse to the need to use our freedom of speech to advocate for the unborn. He emphasizes that this biblical command urges believers to voice against injustice.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that Christians should use their First Amendment rights to speak up for the unborn and those without a voice.

illustrations.title: Long-Term Prayer Against Abortion
illustrations.text: I've been praying against that law since 1973, almost 50 years. This personal commitment reflects a lifelong stand against Roe v. Wade and its effects. Pastor Bob shares this to highlight the persistence needed in prayer for national issues like abortion.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating his personal dedication to praying for the end of Roe v. Wade, encouraging others to maintain long-term prayer for peace and justice.

illustrations.title: Pastor Chuck on Freedom
illustrations.text: Here's what Pastor Chuck said about this: You're not really free as a Christian to live after the flesh or the lust of your flesh. You're free to not live after the lust of your flesh. That's a freedom that the world doesn't have; they're bound by their flesh and slaves to it. Christian freedom does not mean being free to do as we like; it means being free to do as we ought.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that Christian freedom enables believers to resist sin and obey God, rather than indulge in selfish desires.

illustrations.title: Locomotive Freedom Analogy
illustrations.text: A locomotive, a powerful engine, is free but only so long as it's doing the right thing and in the right place. If you take that locomotive and put it down in the sands of Laguna Beach or Newport Beach, it can do nothing and that power goes nowhere. While it's on the train tracks, it is free to move and function as intended. We have freedom, but it is a freedom unto living righteously.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to show that believers are truly free only when they stay on the path of obedience to God, just as a locomotive functions properly only on its tracks.

illustrations.title: Radio Testimony of Change
illustrations.text: It's like that guy's testimony I remember hearing on the radio. He had become a Christian and called in to share it. He said, 'Before I met Christ, I was a hopeless drug addict, but now I'm a drugless hope addict. Everything has changed; before I didn't have a chance, but now I do.'
illustrations.context: This illustrates how encountering Christ transforms a life from slavery to sin into one of hope and freedom.

illustrations.title: Satellite Cloud Formation Sign
illustrations.text: I don't know if you saw this in the news about a week and a half ago, but a satellite caught a natural formation in the clouds that looked like a big G with an O on the right side. The article said it was a weird cloud message from space, asking if it's a message from Mother Earth or a trick of the brain. I would say it's not from Mother Earth, but it reminds us that Father God through His risen Son has said 'Go' as in Matthew 28, calling believers to mission.
illustrations.context: This example emphasizes that the true message from heaven is the Great Commission, urging believers to act on their mission through submission to God.

illustrations.title: Saul's Conversion and Ananias's Obedience
illustrations.text: Remember when Saul, whom we call Paul, got saved on the road to Damascus? Up until then, he had been the biggest threat to the church, arresting Christians and present at Stephen's martyrdom. He was full of rage and on his way to Damascus to arrest more Christians with government authority. But he met Jesus, became blind, and was led into Damascus as a new believer. Then, Jesus gave a vision to a Christian named Ananias, telling him to go to Saul, pray for his sight, and help him. Ananias hesitated because he knew Saul was dangerous, but Jesus commanded him to go anyway.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to show that God calls us to obey and go, even when dealing with ungodly authorities, as Ananias did with Saul.

illustrations.title: Chevrolet Nova Car Name Failure
illustrations.text: Do you know I was told that one of the cars I used to own, a Chevrolet Nova, didn't sell in Mexico when they first marketed it? Nobody wanted to buy them because 'Nova' means 'no go' in Spanish. They eventually changed the name to 'Caliente,' the hot one, to fix the issue. This story illustrates how a bad name can hinder progress, much like failing to obey God's command to go.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this example to emphasize that just as the Nova failed because its name meant 'no go,' we miss out on God's plans when we fail to obey His call to go and make disciples.

illustrations.title: Lincoln's Quote on Common Man
illustrations.text: It always reminds me of why Abraham Lincoln is on the penny. Abraham Lincoln said, 'God must love the common man; He made so many of them.' They put him on the penny because it would be in more people's pockets, especially the poor, since there are more pennies than other coins. Of course, that was before the 21st century when we don't carry much cash anymore.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to illustrate that Jesus valued all people, just as it emphasizes the worth of everyday individuals.

illustrations.title: Story of Blind Bartimaeus
illustrations.text: Think of Bartimaeus in Jericho; his name means 'son of the unclean,' likely because he was blind and people mocked him. He was a blind beggar by the road, and when Jesus came by, he cried out, 'Son of David, have mercy on me!' Everyone told him to be quiet, but he kept calling, and Jesus stopped and said to bring him over, making everyone suddenly eager to help. Jesus had time for outcasts like Bartimaeus whom others ignored.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to show that Jesus valued and cared for people society overlooked, emphasizing the importance of honoring all individuals.

illustrations.title: Zacchaeus the Tax Collector
illustrations.text: Zacchaeus was not just a tax collector; he was a chief tax collector. I think he was up in the tree for his own protection because the people hated him; he was considered an absolute traitor to the Jewish people. Jesus took time for him despite what others thought.
illustrations.context: To show that Jesus cares for outcasts and spiritual losers like Zacchaeus.

illustrations.title: Jesus and Politicians with Babies
illustrations.text: Jesus took time to take people's babies in his arms, even though his disciples didn't think he should. Politicians kiss babies, but it's always for the picture to improve their reputation. Jesus did it because he taught that to enter the kingdom of God, one must become like a child.
illustrations.context: To contrast Jesus's genuine compassion with the superficial motives of politicians.

illustrations.title: Psalm 8 on Human Value
illustrations.text: The Psalmist David said, when I consider the heavens, the work of thy fingers, the moon and the stars which you have ordained, what is man that you even think of him, and the son of man that you care for him? Yet you have made man a little lower than God and crowned him with glory and majesty, making him rule over the works of thy hands and putting all things under his feet. This reflects God's perspective on humanity.
illustrations.context: To illustrate that God values all people highly, so we should honor everyone as kings.

illustrations.title: Sandwich of Sacrificial Love
illustrations.text: See, the Old Testament says to love your neighbor as yourself, so if I have a sandwich and a neighbor who's hungry, then I should cut that sandwich in half. I'm going to love my neighbor as I love myself, which is hard enough to do. But if I'm going to do what Jesus said, love one another as I have loved you, you get both halves of my sandwich. Why? Because He gave up His life completely for us. He laid down His life, showing no greater love than this by laying down His life for His friends.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating the difference between Old Testament love for neighbors and the sacrificial agape love commanded by Jesus.

illustrations.title: Christian Camp Song Memory
illustrations.text: I was years ago involved in a Christian camp up in northern California, and I'll never forget there was a song I never heard before and haven't heard since. The song was called 'Look All Around You,' and one line was 'touch someone near you in love if you can, give all you have and be part of God's plan.' During the song, about 300 elementary-age kids would sing that line and then get up and touch each other before sitting down. It was a simple act that embodied stretching out in love.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that true love involves actively reaching out to others, even in small ways, to fulfill God's plan.

illustrations.title: Catholic Sign of Peace Example
illustrations.text: If you've grown up in the Catholic Church or ever been to a Catholic service, there is the sign of peace that is part of the mass, where the priest says to turn around and offer the sign of peace, and you shake hands saying 'the peace of the Lord be with you.' We do something similar in our service by saying hi to the people right behind you, but it's often just because it's convenient. This practice highlights how easy it is to limit love to what's comfortable, rather than truly stretching out.
illustrations.context: This shows that fervent love requires going beyond convenient interactions to genuinely connect with others.

illustrations.title: Gods Love on the Cross
illustrations.text: Think of how God loved the world; God demonstrates His own love toward us in that while we were yet sinners and afar off, He was stretched out on that cross to bring us who had no claim to any right at all to be close to God. This act of love stretched beyond any comfort or merit on our part. It's a powerful example of love that extends to the unlovable.
illustrations.context: This retelling emphasizes that fervent love means stretching out even to those who are different or undeserving, just as God did.

illustrations.title: John and the Exorcist
illustrations.text: In the Gospel of Mark, John told Jesus that they saw a man casting out demons in Jesus's name and forbade him because he doesn't follow us. John probably thought Jesus would approve, saying good job and giving two thumbs up, but Jesus didn't. Instead, Jesus said that no one who uses his name to cast out demons will speak negatively about him, and that he who is not against us is for us.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate that Christians should not exclude others who are not exactly like them, emphasizing unity and love across differences.

illustrations.title: Different Churches Example
illustrations.text: What about churches that aren't like Calvary Chapel East Anaheim? They might not teach the Bible verse by verse, call themselves Christians but aren't exactly like us, haven't heard of Chuck Smith, may not worship with the same songs, do communion the way we do, or have the same church government. They may not even believe Jesus is coming back as soon as we think he is, but I think he'll take them anyway.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this example to show that we need to love and accept Christians who differ from us in practices and beliefs.

illustrations.title: Aristades Observes Christians
illustrations.text: Aristades was sent to check out Christians and observe how they were living. He wrote back to Emperor Hadrian, noting that these Christians lived out their faith, giving everything to pay fees when one of them was arrested, and celebrating when someone died because they were going to heaven. He highlighted their sacrificial caring for each other and concluded that their love for one another was remarkable and convinced him they were truly following the real Savior.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that loving one another is the ultimate proof that convinces others of genuine faith in Christ.

illustrations.title: Pastor Chuck on Fearing God
illustrations.text: Pastor Chuck used to say that before he was saved, he was afraid of what God would do to him because of his sin. After meeting the Lord, he stopped being afraid of what God would do to him and instead feared what his sin would do to God. This shift shows that fearing God is about having reverence for Him, not being terrified.
illustrations.context: This explains that the fear of the Lord is foundational to a relationship with God and involves reverence rather than dread.

illustrations.title: Joseph Resists Temptation
illustrations.text: Think of Joseph with Potiphar's wife. Remember, Joseph was sold into slavery by his brothers, who told his dad he was dead, and he ended up in Egypt facing many hardships. He had dreams from God about great things, but they seemed impossible as he served Potiphar, an Egyptian official. Potiphar's wife was attracted to him and tried to seduce him, but Joseph refused, saying, 'How could I sin against God and commit this evil?' Even in his messy life, Joseph saw that God was watching over him.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to show that we should live as if God is always watching, even in difficult circumstances, to please Him regardless of who else sees.

illustrations.title: David's Integrity Pledge
illustrations.text: Think of David, who we all know stayed home instead of going to war, looked out his window, and saw his neighbor Bathsheba, leading to great sin and harm. Later, after he repented, David wrote in Psalm 101: 'I will walk within my house in the integrity of my heart. I will set no worthless thing before my eyes; I hate the work of those who fall away; it shall not fasten its grip on me.' In this context, David committed to living in the fear of God, even in private moments.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates that fearing God means choosing integrity in everyday life, especially after failure, to avoid sin and honor God privately.

illustrations.title: David's Psalm on Integrity
illustrations.text: David later wrote these words in Psalm 101:2-3, and I believe this is the context after he got right: 'I will walk within my house in the integrity of my heart. I will set no worthless thing before my eyes; I hate the work of those who fall away; it shall not fasten its grip on me.' He hadn't lived that way before, but now he declares his intent to live in the fear of God, even when no one else sees. This shows his commitment to godly living in private.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that fearing God leads to personal integrity and resistance to temptation in daily life.

illustrations.title: Peter's Sword Incident
illustrations.text: Remember, Peter in his flesh in the garden slept instead of prayed, then drew his sword to defend Jesus and attacked the authorities. Jesus rebuked him, saying, 'Put away your sword; those who live by the sword will die by the sword.' Years later, Peter realized the importance of honoring the king as he quoted scripture and lived by it. This shows Peter's growth from impulsively fighting authority to submitting to God's will.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate how Peter learned to honor authorities by resting in divine sovereignty.

illustrations.title: McGee's Voting Wisdom
illustrations.text: Jay Vernon McGee said he has never voted for a person to be president because he wanted them to be president; he was voting against the other guy, and that's what he said every single time. This highlights the reality of choosing between imperfect options. Pastor Bob connects this to the idea that we're always voting for the lesser of two evils, as no leader is perfect.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize the need to vote for the lesser of two evils while respecting the office.

illustrations.title: Honoring Nero's Rule
illustrations.text: John Corson said, 'How then can we have the audacity to snivel about our president or whine about our governor when our brothers and sisters honored a demented king whose main objective was to annihilate them? The Lord forgive us.' He points out that it was Nero who killed Paul and Peter. This quote reminds us to respect authorities despite their flaws, as early Christians did under persecution.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that we should honor even godless leaders by remembering historical examples of faithfulness.

illustrations.title: David's Respect for Saul
illustrations.text: Listen, David respected Saul even when Saul was rejected by the Lord. Why did he do that? He refused to kill Saul, knowing he was going to become king himself, and said, 'Absolutely not, he's the Lord's anointed.' Here's why David knew: remember Nabal and Abigail? God can take Saul out anytime He wants, and until He does, He doesn't want to; He wants to test me.
illustrations.context: To show that believers should respect godless authority and trust God's timing and testing.

illustrations.title: Israelites' Wandering in Desert
illustrations.text: The children of Israel came out of Egypt, and it took them 40 years to get to Canaan and go in. I don't mean it took 40 years to get to Canaan because it only took a little time to get to Kadesh Barnea. They could have gone in way sooner, not 40 years, maybe just four months, but because of unbelief, they didn't get to go in. It's been 50 years since Roe v. Wade, and I'm tired of that ungodly law, but could it have been just five months if we had prayed and trusted God as we should?
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate that unbelief delayed the Israelites' entry into Canaan, just as lack of prayer and trust in God's sovereignty may have prolonged the Roe v. Wade law.

illustrations.title: Jesus on Pilate's Authority
illustrations.text: Jesus, you said to Pilate that he would have no authority had it not been given to him by God. Lord, there's authority that you have created, and it isn't just because Satan wants to ruin our nation; it's because you, who are ultimately in control, want to get your bride ready for heaven and demonstrate that she trusts you and your sovereignty. This shows that even ungodly authority is under God's control, and we must honor it to honor God.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that all authority comes from God, teaching the importance of submitting to and honoring even ungodly leaders as an act of faith in God's sovereignty.

illustrations.title: Paul Before Sanhedrin
illustrations.text: Paul the Apostle is standing before the Sanhedrin and says, 'I've lived in a perfectly good conscience up until this day.' The high priest orders that Paul be slapped across the face, and Paul angrily responds, 'You try me according to the law, but you break the law by having me slapped. May God smite you, you whitewashed sepulcher!' When someone points out that he's speaking to the high priest, Paul pulls back and says, 'I didn't realize he was the high priest. The Bible says I shouldn't speak that way about my rulers.'
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to show the importance of controlling one's speech and respecting authority, even when provoked.

illustrations.title: Conversation on Giving Money
illustrations.text: I was talking with a gentleman the other day, and he said he liked how I say God doesn't need our money. I asked why, and he joked it was because he wanted to keep it all. But the truth is, God doesn't need it; however, if you love Him and want every aspect of your life to honor Him, money is a big part of that. It's a big part of my life—I'm always stressed and worried about it—but it's better in His hands than in mine.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to emphasize that giving honors God and it's wiser to trust Him with finances rather than holding onto them out of worry.

illustrations.title: Job's Praise in Sorrow
illustrations.text: Remember when Job realized that his children were gone? The Bible says that he responded by saying, 'The Lord gave, and the Lord has taken away.' He was celebrating their birth and acknowledged that God was in charge of how long he had them. He never guaranteed me I'd have them longer than I was going to be alive, but I will bless the name of the Lord. This moment highlights choosing praise amid loss.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that even after tremendous loss, one can still choose to bless and praise God.

illustrations.title: David's Worship After Loss
illustrations.text: When David lost the son that he bore with Bathsheba, a little baby about one year old, he had begged God not to take that baby's life, and God took that boy's life. You know what the Bible says? He got up and he went to church; he went into the temple and he worshiped God. This act of worship came despite his grief, showing that praise can follow deep personal pain.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that in times of sorrow, like David's, one can still rise and worship God as an act of faith.

illustrations.title: Paul and Silas in Pain
illustrations.text: Paul and Silas were in the midst of that pain, beaten and bleeding, when they worshiped God. Despite their suffering, they chose to praise Him in their dire circumstances. This example demonstrates that worship can happen even in physical and emotional agony.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize that worship is possible and powerful during times of intense pain and uncertainty.

illustrations.title: Disciples' Doubtful Worship
illustrations.text: The Bible says that after Jesus rose from the dead, the disciples proceeded to the mountain in Galilee that He had designated. When they saw Him, they worshiped Him, but some were doubtful. This moment captures a mix of faith and uncertainty, showing that worship can occur even when doubts linger.
illustrations.context: This retelling highlights that one can worship God amid doubt, encouraging believers in uncertain times.

illustrations.title: Pain Isolates in Worship
illustrations.text: I know this when you're in pain, it isolates you and makes it hard to think about anybody else because you're focused on two things: how long this will last and why it's happening. What worship does is get you outside of yourself and clarify things. So, we're here to let Jesus Christ be the center focus of our day and week.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating how pain isolates individuals but worship helps refocus on Jesus as Lord.

illustrations.title: John's Weeping in Revelation
illustrations.text: John said that he began to weep greatly because no one was found worthy to open the book or to look into it. Then one of the elders said to him, 'Stop weeping; behold, the Lion that is from the tribe of Judah, the Root of David, has overcome so as to open the book and its seven seals.' For some of us, the Lord wants to say that it's not time to cry, but time to praise Him and worship Him because He has overcome.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to encourage listeners that Jesus has overcome, so they should stop weeping and praise Him instead of dwelling in gloom.

illustrations.title: Paul's Promise of Provision
illustrations.text: Didn't Paul say that if the Lord gave His own Son for us, He would not with Him freely give us everything else? Whatever else I need or you need, it's included, and He'll take care of that too. This shows God's full commitment to us.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob connects this quote to assure that God, having given His Son, will provide all other needs.

illustrations.title: Jesus at the Last Supper
illustrations.text: Jesus, the night He was betrayed, took the bread that represented His own body and said, 'This is my body being given for you; remember me.' After supper, He took the cup of blessing, gave thanks, and said, 'This is the New Covenant in my blood; from now on, when you drink it, remember me.' This act reminds us of His sacrifice and the new agreement with God.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize remembering Jesus' sacrifice and the new covenant it establishes.

illustrations.title: Veteran's Blank Check
illustrations.text: Someone has described a veteran as someone who at one point in their life wrote a blank check made payable to the United States of America for an amount up to and including their life. We have a number of veterans in our fellowship, so we want to take a moment to recognize them. If you are a veteran, please stand so we can thank the Lord for you and acknowledge your service.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to honor and recognize the sacrifices of veterans in the congregation.

illustrations.title: Home of the Brave
illustrations.text: Someone said that this nation will remain the land of the free only so long as it is the home of the brave. With regard to veterans, we don't know them all, but we owe them all. If someone is standing near you who served, acknowledge them and say thank you for your service.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize the importance of appreciating and honoring veterans for their bravery.

illustrations.title: Drunk Driver in Wisconsin
illustrations.text: This is from the state where drinking and driving is considered a sport—Wisconsin. Recently, a true story from Wisconsin: A routine police patrol was parked outside a local neighborhood bar late in the evening. The officer noticed a man leaving the bar, so intoxicated he could barely walk. The man stumbled around the parking lot for a few minutes with the officer quietly observing. After trying his keys in five different vehicles, he finally found his car and fell into it. He sat there for a few minutes as other patrons left and drove off. Finally, he started the car, switched the wipers on and off even though it wasn't raining, flicked the hazard flashers, tooted the horn, switched on the lights, moved forward a few inches, reversed a little, remained stationary, and eventually pulled out and started driving slowly down the street as the police officer followed.
illustrations.context: This story illustrates the reckless and sinful behavior of the wicked, contrasting with God's protection of the righteous as described in the scripture.

illustrations.title: Deceived by Decoy Driver
illustrations.text: The officer, having patiently waited, started his car, put on the flashing lights, and pulled the man over. He carried out a breathalyzer test, and to his amazement, it showed no evidence of alcohol. Dumbfounded, the officer said, 'I'll have to ask you to accompany me to the police station; this equipment must be broken.' The man replied, 'I doubt it,' revealing it was a designated decoy. Even the well-trained can be deceived if they're not careful.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how false teachers can subtly deceive even the well-trained believers in the end times.

illustrations.title: Shoop Shoop Song Critique
illustrations.text: I remember a song called the Shoop Shoop song, written by Rudy Clark, where a woman sings about wondering if a man loves her. She questions if it's in his eyes, but decides you'll be deceived, and it's not in his eyes because he'll make believe. The song says if you want to know if he loves you, it's in his kiss—hug and squeeze him tight to find out if it's real. I call it a stupid song because it focuses on superficial signs, but Jesus teaches we know false prophets by their fruit, not empty gestures.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this song quote to contrast superficial ways of knowing love with the deeper truth of discerning false prophets by their actions.

illustrations.title: Trees and Fruit Analogy
illustrations.text: Jesus said you will know false prophets by their fruit, just like you know a tree by what it produces. For example, if you see apples, you know it's an apple tree; if you see oranges, it's an orange tree; if it's some weird fruit, you can identify it that way. I don't know much about trees myself, but my wife is amazing at identifying plants and flowers on sight. This analogy shows that we recognize the true nature of something by its output, not just its appearance.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to explain that false teachers are identified by their actions and character, not just their words.

illustrations.title: Wife's Plant Expertise Story
illustrations.text: I don't know much about trees, but my wife is amazing at it. Whenever we go through a garden, I'll point and ask, 'What is that plant? What is that flower?' and she nails it every time. I'm just like, 'It's green,' not knowing any better. This personal anecdote highlights how some people have natural knowledge that others lack, tying into the idea of recognizing true qualities.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob shares this story to add humor and illustrate his own limitations in understanding trees, reinforcing the fruit analogy for discernment.

illustrations.title: Pastors Mocking Demons
illustrations.text: I have seen many Christian pastors mock the devil over the years, saying things like 'he had his teeth pulled at the cross; he's trying to gum us to death.' These kinds of sayings accurately describe that the devil's power has been taken away, but mocking him is never something you'll find in scripture. It's a big mistake to treat such things lightly.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that mocking authority, like the devil, is unwise and not supported by scripture.

illustrations.title: Halloween Costume Warning
illustrations.text: That's one reason I don't think we should dress up our kids on Halloween as little demons and little witches. We don't play with or trifle with such things and act like they're really nothing. Making fun of them is not wise to do at all.
illustrations.context: This shows why we should avoid trivializing or mocking demonic themes, as it disrespects authority.

illustrations.title: Criticizing Authority Figures
illustrations.text: Listen, the next time you are tempted to criticize the president of the country, whether you voted for him or not, or your supervisor or parents, think twice about that. This applies to any authority in your life, as scripture teaches that all authority is from God. It's about exercising your freedom wisely rather than resisting what God has established.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the importance of respecting all forms of authority to avoid resisting God.

illustrations.title: Herod's Fatal Pride
illustrations.text: You see, Herod is proof of that in the New Testament. When he doesn't give glory to God but claims it's the voice of a god and not a man, God struck him dead. This shows God's power over human authority.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that God can remove authority when it fails to honor Him.

illustrations.title: Nebuchadnezzar's Insanity
illustrations.text: For that matter, we see God able to take away the authority of Nebuchadnezzar by stripping his sanity for seven years. He became a crazy guy, acting like an animal. This demonstrates God's control over rulers.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that God can remove authority at any time to enforce His will.

illustrations.title: Saul as Israel's King
illustrations.text: Why did Saul become king? He wasn't God's original choice, as God was ruling His people through Samuel. The people demanded a king like other nations, so God gave them Saul, who was tall, good-looking, and humble at first but lacked the character of David. This led to consequences as a form of discipline.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to explain that God sometimes allows imperfect leaders to discipline His people.

illustrations.title: Imperfect Fathers Example
illustrations.text: Let's just go back to our families; some of us had to struggle with our fathers, and some didn't because their fathers weren't there. Every single one of them was imperfect, even the best ones, to remind us that none of them are our true Father. God places these imperfect authorities in our lives so that we might trust Him who is over all.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that God uses imperfect authorities to teach reliance on Him.

illustrations.title: Michael's Dispute with Devil
illustrations.text: We are told by Jude in the New Testament about this incident. Remember, after Deuteronomy was written, God told Moses it was time to die and to go up on Mount Nebo to see the Holy Land, which he forfeited because he struck the rock twice. Moses went up the mountain, died, and God buried him. According to Jewish tradition, after Moses was buried, the Devil appeared to desecrate his body. God sent Michael the Archangel to confront him. Michael, the angel of war who once helped Gabriel in spiritual conflict, disputed with the Devil but did not pronounce a disrespectful judgment himself. Instead, he said, 'The Lord rebuke you,' showing deference to God's authority.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that even Michael the Archangel did not revile the Devil but left judgment to God, contrasting with the behavior of false prophets.

illustrations.title: Barking Dog at Son's House
illustrations.text: Many times when I go over to my son's house, he has a sweet dog, but for some reason, that dog thinks its mission is to bark its brains out at anybody, even if he knows you. He forgets that he knows you or that you're family. That's just his mission in life, like a lot of dogs do—they bark and make noise.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how animals act on instinct, paralleling the ignorant and arrogant behavior of false teachers.

illustrations.title: Jesus on Pearls Before Swine
illustrations.text: Jesus talked about not giving what is holy to dogs and not throwing your pearls before swine, or they will trample them under their feet and turn and tear you to pieces. In the New Testament, people didn't have pets like dogs; they were wild, rabid dogs. This shows how some things are wasted on those who don't appreciate them, connecting to the destructive instincts of false teachers.
illustrations.context: This quote highlights the ignorance of false teachers by comparing them to animals that reject valuable things.

illustrations.title: Empty Barrels Analogy
illustrations.text: It's like that teacher who said to her noisy class, 'You know what, you guys, empty barrels make the most noise.' This illustrates how people who lack substance can create a lot of commotion. The point is that false prophets are doing the same thing—making a racket without real knowledge.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to show that false prophets make a lot of noise but are completely ignorant of what they're talking about.

illustrations.title: Jesus Seminar Reference
illustrations.text: Some of you have heard of an organization called the Jesus Seminar, a group of liberal scholars who decided to vote on which parts of the Gospels, especially Jesus's sayings, were authentic. They used a polling method with colored beads: red for probably authentic, pink for possibly, gray for altered, and black for entirely fabricated. After their meetings, they concluded that only 31 percent of Jesus's sayings were unquestionably authentic, rejecting 80 percent and denying key aspects like his divinity or resurrection.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this historical reference to demonstrate how false prophets and critics wrongly judge and distort the Word of God.

illustrations.title: MacArthur Quote Critique
illustrations.text: John MacArthur said that a group of experts claimed Jesus didn't really say everything attributed to him, suggesting disciples added it. He described the Jesus Seminar's bizarre voting process with beads to determine authenticity, resulting in them rejecting 80 percent of Jesus's words, including his claims to be the Messiah or his sacrificial death. MacArthur concludes that such judgments should be thrown away, as it's wrong for man to judge God's Word—rather, God's Word will judge them.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that the Jesus Seminar's conclusions are misguided and should be rejected, highlighting the proper authority of Scripture.

illustrations.title: Minds Like Set Concrete
illustrations.text: Some people's minds are like some men thoroughly mixed up and permanently set. This means their thoughts are inflexible and unchangeable, much like concrete that has hardened. Pastor Bob uses this to warn about approaching the Bible with a closed mindset, contrasting it with being open to truth.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating how some people read the Bible with preconceived ideas that make them resistant to change.

illustrations.title: Paul's Apology to High Priest
illustrations.text: When Paul spoke negatively of the high priest, calling him a whitewashed wall during an interview, he was confronted for his words. Paul then realized his mistake and apologized, citing God's word from Exodus that one should not speak against a ruler. This shows Paul's respect for authority despite the high priest's flaws, as Pastor Bob explains to emphasize the importance of honoring positions of authority.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is using this story to demonstrate that true respect for authority is required, even when dealing with flawed leaders like false teachers.

illustrations.title: Romans and Daytime Partying
illustrations.text: Even the unsaved Romans didn't respect people who partied and got drunk during the day, as it was seen as inappropriate behavior. They believed such activities should be kept for nighttime or private times, not in the open daylight. Pastor Bob contrasts this with false teachers who revel in the day, using it to highlight their moral failings and deceptive ways.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating the immorality of false teachers by referencing ancient Roman cultural standards of propriety.

illustrations.title: Little Shop of Horrors Analogy
illustrations.text: You remember that stupid little plant from Little Shop of Horrors. It's a weird plant from outer space that's dying until Seymour discovers it needs blood to thrive. He pricks his finger, feeds it blood, and the plant grows stronger, eventually demanding more and growing vocal cords to say 'feed me.' This shows how feeding the flesh makes it stronger, just like in the story.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that feeding fleshly desires strengthens them, and believers must instead mortify them.

illustrations.title: Corinthian Agape Feasts Retelling
illustrations.text: Paul the Apostle addressed the carnal Christians in Corinth about their gatherings for the Agape Feast, which was like a potluck and celebration of the Lord. He pointed out that some were well-fed while others went hungry, and there was immorality and drunkenness happening. These behaviors showed a lack of care for one another, infecting the body of Christ just as false teachers do.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show how false teachers and carnal behavior harm the church by promoting selfishness and immorality.

illustrations.title: Young Man False Ministry
illustrations.text: I remember years ago a young man who decided he had a ministry, although he wouldn't have said it this way, but it turned out he targeted all the good-looking hurting wives in the church. This story shows how someone can disguise harmful intentions under a spiritual guise. It's a warning about those who exploit vulnerabilities within the congregation.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how false prophets can infiltrate the church and target the weak and vulnerable.

illustrations.title: Wolves Preying on Sheep
illustrations.text: Jesus said concerning the false prophets they come to you in sheep's clothing but inwardly they're ravenous wolves. Wolves prey on the young, the weak, the hurting, and the lonely sheep. This retelling emphasizes the deceptive nature of those who appear harmless but intend harm.
illustrations.context: This shows that false prophets disguise themselves to exploit the vulnerable in the church.

illustrations.title: Yosemite Bear Watch
illustrations.text: When I was a kid in high school, we used to go up to Yosemite, and the teenage boys would be in the truck bed with our food for the week inside, since it was a bear habitat. We had to take rotations on bear watch, banging pots and pans to scare off the bears that came to steal the food. This experience is likened to being on wolf watch in the church to protect against those who prey on the weak.
illustrations.context: This personal story illustrates the need for vigilance in the church to guard against false prophets who exploit the vulnerable.

illustrations.title: Hidden Reef Danger
illustrations.text: Jude describes them as hidden reefs when they feast with you, meaning they claim to be believers and fellowship with you but are there to cause damage. You discover a hidden reef by running into it or seeing wreckage from others who have hit it. This analogy shows how false prophets can secretly harm the body of Christ.
illustrations.context: This analogy illustrates how false prophets blend in but ultimately bring destruction to the church.

illustrations.title: Lucy's Deceptive Essay
illustrations.text: In a Peanuts comic strip, the first day of a new school year has students writing essays about returning to class. Lucy writes that vacations are nice, but it's good to get back to school, as there's nothing more satisfying or challenging than education, and she looks forward to expanding her knowledge. The teacher is pleased and compliments her on her fine essay. In the final frame, Lucy whispers to Charlie Brown, 'After a while, you learn what sells.'
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that false teachers are skilled at saying what people want to hear, just like Lucy knows how to 'sell' her essay.

illustrations.title: Lemon Squeezing Challenge
illustrations.text: Billy Graham used to tell the story of a strong man at a sideshow circus who demonstrated his power by squeezing juice from 11 lemons and then offered $500 to anyone who could squeeze even one more drop. Big guys from the audience tried and failed to get any juice out. Then, a thin, scholarly-looking guy came forward, picked up the lemon, and squeezed out several drops. The strong man paid him and asked for the secret, and the man replied, 'Practice. I've been the treasurer of a Southern Baptist Church for years and I do this all the time.'
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that false teachers are experts at their deceptive practices, much like the church treasurer is skilled in his role.

illustrations.title: Balaam's Reluctance to Curse
illustrations.text: King Balak hears about the huge horde of Israelites in the desert and fears they will destroy his wealth, so he decides to hire Balaam, a prophet from near the Euphrates River, known for cursing people effectively. Balaam consults God, who tells him not to curse the Israelites because they are blessed, so Balaam initially refuses the offer. Despite this, King Balak sends more representatives with a blank check, tempting Balaam to ask God again, highlighting the danger of begging for what God has forbidden.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to warn about the risks of persistently begging God for something He has already clearly denied, as it can lead to entering His permissive will.

illustrations.title: Balaam and the Donkey
illustrations.text: So, here we have Balaam on his donkey, riding to go to Balak to curse God's people, but something happens that he's completely unaware of: the Lord sends an angel because God is angry with him. Balaam is riding along, excited about the payday coming, and the angel stands in front of the donkey with a sword drawn. The donkey sees it and veers off into the field, but Balaam whips it and gets back on the road. Then, the angel stands between a rock and a hard place, and the donkey smashes Balaam's foot into the rock, making him angry and causing him to hit the donkey again. Finally, the donkey lays down under Balaam, and he beats it a third time. Before God opens Balaam's eyes, he has a conversation with the donkey, who speaks and questions its faithfulness. The angel then appears and tells Balaam he would have been killed if not for the donkey's actions.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to show that Balaam spoke eloquent, biblical words about God but was driven by greed, highlighting the danger of right words with wrong motives.

illustrations.title: Little Red Riding Hood Analogy
illustrations.text: You remember the story of Little Red Riding Hood, and you can't help but think of what Jesus said about false teachers. It's kind of like this: Oh teacher, what a big mouth you have! The better to declare the faults of others and exalt myself. Oh, but teacher, what a big tummy you have! The better to satisfy my lusts and tempt you to do the same. Oh, what big eyes you have! Yeah, the better to see exactly and only what is really in it for me.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate how false teachers appear innocent but are inwardly deceptive and self-serving.

illustrations.title: Placentia Neighbors Story
illustrations.text: For years, we lived in Placentia next to some wonderful people who wound up coming to faith before they passed away. I was involved in their funerals and saw them one by one give their lives to Jesus. One of them was a young man named Ronald from a Hispanic family that had lived there for many generations. From time to time, we would ask Ronald about Spanish words or Mexican culture, and he'd say, 'I don't know; I'm a coconut – brown on the outside but white on the inside.' This story highlights the contrast with false teachers.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob shares this to show that genuine people may appear one way but are true inside, unlike false teachers who are the opposite.

illustrations.title: Indian Chief's Daily Readiness
illustrations.text: I have a little saying on my devices, like my phone, which comes from an old movie from the 70s or 80s starring Dustin Hoffman. In the movie, there was an old Indian chief who kept thinking it was his time to die, but it never was. Every day, he would get up and say, 'It's a good day to die,' meaning he was ready to face whatever came. I thought to myself, that's exactly what I want to remind myself: today is a good day to die to myself, just as Jesus taught.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize the need to daily deny oneself and follow Jesus, contrasting with living for one's own desires.

illustrations.title: Freely Give Biblical Quote
illustrations.text: Lord, you said freely we've received, now freely give. May we be a people who are happy and fulfilled to give it away because Jesus, that's what you did. This reminds us to live out our faith by generously sharing what we've been given, just as Jesus modeled.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize the importance of living out faith through selfless giving, as Jesus did, to avoid using others for personal benefit.

illustrations.title: Childhood Spanish Rhyme
illustrations.text: I remember in the school district I attended as a child, when we got to sixth grade, we had Spanish lessons on Fridays where the teacher taught us basics like the alphabet and vowels. They used a little ditty to help us remember, and it went like this: when it was your turn, you'd say, 'My donkey knows more than you,' and then point to someone else to repeat it. This playful rhyme was a fun way to learn, but it ties into a deeper truth about wisdom and folly.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to illustrate how even a simple childhood rhyme parallels the biblical idea that Balaam's donkey knew more than he did, highlighting human stubbornness.

illustrations.title: Balaam's Moral Compromise
illustrations.text: We think of Balaam as a strange prophet speaking God's words in the Bible, but even after being reproved by God through his donkey, his story continues in Numbers 24. Since he couldn't curse God's people, he taught King Balak how to compromise them by instructing the women to invite Israeli men to parties, get them drunk, lead them into sex, and worship Baal. This led to moral compromise, and as a result, God judged His people, striking down 24,000 Jews because of their sin.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob retells this story to emphasize the dangers of willful sin and how even a prophet like Balaam can lead others into compromise, resulting in divine judgment.

illustrations.title: Paul's Quote on Self-Judgment
illustrations.text: Paul the Apostle says that if we judge ourselves as believers, we will be disciplined by the Lord so that we will not be condemned with the world. This means as believers, we need to examine our lives and ask if we're living the right way. Are we living a two-faced life, sowing to the flesh all week and then coming to church hoping for a crop failure, or are we genuinely living for God, not perfectly but honestly?
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize the importance of self-examination to avoid condemnation and live authentically for God.

illustrations.title: Dialogue on Financial Giving
illustrations.text: A man said to me, 'I like that you say God doesn't need my money.' I responded, 'Well, why do you say that? Is it because you want to keep all your money?' No, that's not the point—it's about understanding true giving from the heart.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this conversation to emphasize that giving is about gratitude and not because God needs our money.

illustrations.title: Mountains for Climbing Quote
illustrations.text: There are times when the mountain in your life doesn't move at all, and it seems like your only hope is for God to take it away because if He doesn't, you won't be able to get over it or through it. Someone once said that maybe that's why the mountains in our life aren't smooth, so we can learn to climb them. This illustrates the idea of growing through challenges rather than avoiding them.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to show that life's obstacles are designed to teach us resilience and climbing skills instead of being removed.

illustrations.title: Habakkuk's Hind Feet Retelling
illustrations.text: Habakkuk wanted God to destroy the enemy and prevent them from coming into the land, but God said He wouldn't do that. Instead, God promised to give Habakkuk hinds' feet on high places, meaning the ability to climb over difficult terrain. This retelling emphasizes that God equips us to handle mountains rather than always removing them.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that God may not fulfill our exact requests but will provide the strength to overcome challenges.

illustrations.title: Paul's Rejoice in Hard Times
illustrations.text: We're here to celebrate that you are Lord, even if we're in circumstances we don't want to be in, like what Paul said: we are to rejoice in the Lord always because you are on your throne. You can change it anytime you want, and you will change it if it's best for us. But if you don't, then change us to the glory of God.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses Paul's quote to emphasize rejoicing in God regardless of difficult circumstances, highlighting God's sovereignty and timing.

illustrations.title: John Weeps in Heaven
illustrations.text: In case you don't know, this comes right out of Revelation 5 where John is in heaven. Nobody in all of heaven and earth is worthy to open this scroll, which we believe is the title deed to redeem the earth. The Bible says that John, realizing what that would mean, just begins to weep.
illustrations.context: To illustrate the profound significance of the word 'worthy' in the context of heavenly redemption.

illustrations.title: COVID Worship Challenges
illustrations.text: I remember when COVID began and we couldn't come to church. That was the first time I heard that song, sung on Zoom by a church with pictures of people at home. It broke my heart to see God's people scattered, but they came together to celebrate the truth. We sang it out in the parking lot during services when we couldn't gather inside, reminding us to praise God in the hardest moments.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that God is worthy of praise even during times of separation and hardship.

illustrations.title: Jesus Last Supper Moment
illustrations.text: Jesus gathered his disciples and they had no idea what was going to happen that night. He knew fully what they were going to do but didn't hold it against them. Jesus took the unleavened bread of Passover and said, 'This is my body,' telling them it would represent his sacrifice from now on. As often as they ate it, they were to remember him, emphasizing his love and upcoming death for their sins.
illustrations.context: This retelling highlights Jesus' foreknowledge, grace, and the call to remember his sacrifice.

illustrations.title: Veteran's Blank Check
illustrations.text: A veteran is someone who at one point in their life wrote a blank check made payable to the United States of America for an amount up to and including their life. We don't know them all, but we owe them all. Today, remind them you are grateful for benefiting from their service by the life that God has provided for us.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize honoring veterans for their sacrifices and expressing gratitude for their service.

illustrations.title: Balaam's Rebuke Story
illustrations.text: They have followed the way of Balaam, the son of Beor, who loved the wages of unrighteousness. He received a rebuke for his own transgression when a mute donkey spoke with a human voice, restraining the madness of the prophet. This shows how even a dumb animal can intervene in divine judgment.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob retells this to illustrate that false teachers will face judgment for their actions, just as Balaam did.

illustrations.title: Designated Decoy Deception
illustrations.text: Listen to this true story from Wisconsin, where drinking and driving is jokingly called a sport. A police officer observed a man leaving a bar, appearing extremely intoxicated as he stumbled and tried his keys in several cars. The man finally got into his vehicle, turned on the wipers, hazard lights, and horn on a dry night, then drove slowly before the officer pulled him over for a breathalyzer. To the officer's surprise, the test showed no alcohol, and the man revealed he was the designated decoy to expose drunk drivers. This highlights how even the well-trained can be tricked if they're not careful.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate how false teachers can subtly deceive people, just as the decoy misled the officer.

illustrations.title: Shoop Shoop Song Critique
illustrations.text: In 1963, there was a song on the radio written by Rudy Clark, and it was done by many people over the years. I was only six at the time, but I remember hearing it as a young boy, as my brother and sisters, being older, would listen to the radio. The song is known as the Shoop Shoop song, and the lyrics say: 'Does he love me? I want to know how can I tell if he loves me so. Is it in his eyes? Oh no, you'll be deceived. If you want to know if he loves you so, it's in his kiss.' That's one of the dumbest songs I've ever heard, because the Bible says husbands should love their wives as Christ loved the church, so true love is about christ-likeness, kindness, and consideration, not superficial things like a kiss.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this song to show that worldly ideas about love are misleading and must be evaluated against biblical truth to avoid false teaching.

illustrations.title: Sons of Sceva's Demonic Encounter
illustrations.text: Like the seven sons of Sceva, who thought they could cast out demons in the name of Jesus that Paul preaches, they tried to use spiritual authority without true submission. They found out it doesn't work that way when the demons overpowered them. Peter uses this to show the dangers of arrogance and despising true authority.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that false teachers who despise authority, like the sons of Sceva, face severe consequences when they misuse spiritual power.

illustrations.title: Halloween Costume Warning
illustrations.text: That's one of the reasons I don't think we should dress up our children in Halloween as little demons, little devils, and little witches. We don't mock those things that are real, as that's a big mistake many Christians make. They think it's just a bunch of fun, but the fact is God says don't mess with that stuff because there really is dark authority in this world.
illustrations.context: This example shows that mocking demonic forces demonstrates a lack of respect for spiritual authorities, similar to the attitude of false teachers.

illustrations.title: Check Yourself Phrase
illustrations.text: The next time you're tempted to criticize the president or your boss or your parents or any authority God has placed over you, you need to check yourself before you wreck yourself. This phrase, as my grandson would say, serves as a reminder to control your words and actions. It's about exercising self-restraint under imperfect authority.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to illustrate the importance of respecting and submitting to authorities, even when they are flawed, as a test of faith.

illustrations.title: Michael and Devil's Dispute
illustrations.text: Remember, Moses lost his chance to enter the Holy Land because he dishonored the Lord by striking the rock for water. As a result, God allowed him to see the Promised Land from Mount Nebo but not enter it, and he died there. The Bible says God buried him, but according to Jewish tradition, the Devil appeared to try to take or desecrate Moses' body. God sent Michael the Archangel, the powerful warrior angel who represents Israel, to dispute with the Devil. Michael, despite his supreme power, did not rebuke the Devil himself but said, 'The Lord rebuke you.'
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that one should not directly rebuke the Devil but let the Lord handle it.

illustrations.title: Devil Knocking on Door
illustrations.text: The idea is this: when the devil knocks on your door with temptation or condemnation, let Jesus answer it. I never rebuke the devil myself, and I don't recommend that Christians do it because it's not biblical. Instead, follow the pattern and say, 'The Lord rebuke you,' as Michael did.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates that believers should not confront the Devil directly but rely on the Lord for rebuke.

illustrations.title: Son's Neurotic Dog Story
illustrations.text: I don't know if you have a dog, but I've had many, and right now we're dog-free and fine with that. My middle son has a beautiful but neurotic dog that acts as a good watchman. No matter how many times this dog meets me or anyone else, it freaks out and has a barking attack every single time someone knocks on the door.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how false teachers make noise about things they know nothing about, much like the dog's excessive barking.

illustrations.title: Empty Barrels Analogy
illustrations.text: It's like that teacher who said to her noisy class, 'You remind me, kids, that empty barrels make the most noise.' These false teachers are empty and pride-filled, making a lot of noise without real knowledge. This analogy shows how those lacking substance are the loudest.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to point out that false teachers, like empty barrels, are noisy and full of pride despite their ignorance.

illustrations.title: Jesus Seminar Example
illustrations.text: Some of you may have heard of the Jesus Seminar, a group of 200 supposed scholars who studied the New Testament and decided to vote on which sayings of Jesus were authentic. They waded in to officially determine the validity of red-letter words in the Bible. This serves as an example of modern false teaching that questions scriptural truth.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the problem of false teachers who arrogantly challenge biblical authority without true understanding.

illustrations.title: MacArthur's Quote Rejection
illustrations.text: John MacArthur said this: Please don't think that I believe the conclusions of the Jesus Seminar should be discarded lightly; on the contrary, I think they should be thrown away with as much force as possible. The problem is that people want to sit in judgment of God's word with their own intellect, which is a mistake. This highlights the arrogance of rejecting biblical truth based on human wisdom.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that false scholarly conclusions about Jesus should be firmly rejected, underscoring the danger of intellectual pride over God's word.

illustrations.title: Minds Like Cement Analogy
illustrations.text: Somebody said that a lot of people's minds are a lot like cement—thoroughly mixed up and permanently set. Don't be that way when approaching the Bible. This means having a closed mind prevents true understanding, contrasting with the need to remain open to God's truth.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to warn against approaching the Bible with a preconceived, unchangeable mindset, encouraging listeners to be open rather than rigid.

illustrations.title: Movie of Indian Chief's Death
illustrations.text: It was an old movie from the 80s, I think it was a Dustin Hoffman movie where he was raised by Indians. In this movie, an old Indian chief kept thinking it was his day to die, but it wasn't. He would say, 'I'm ready to die,' lay down expecting to go, and yet he would still be there, repeating the line throughout the movie: 'It's a Good Day to Die.' I have that as a meme on my phone and remind myself of it daily.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate the need to daily die to self and follow Jesus by denying oneself.

illustrations.title: Hidden Reefs in Feasts
illustrations.text: These men are hidden reefs in your love feasts when they feast with you without fear, caring for themselves. What a description and metaphor—they are hidden reefs. How do you discover a hidden reef? In two ways: one, you run into it and get damaged on your boat, or two, you see the damage of others strewn about.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show how false teachers are dangers that can cause harm in the church, similar to hidden reefs in social gatherings.

illustrations.title: Man in the Church Story
illustrations.text: Years ago, there was this man, and we had to ask him to leave the church. He was a good-looking young guy who clearly felt called to minister to hurting wives that weren't his own, always there to help them with their trials. I don't know why they fall in love with me, you know, but it happens.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how false teachers can take advantage of vulnerable people in the body of Christ.

illustrations.title: Wolves Preying on Sheep
illustrations.text: Jesus said these false teachers are like wolves in sheep's clothing, but inside they are ravenous wolves. A wolf preys on the young, the weak, the hurting, and the lonely sheep. It's what they do, and we need to be aware of that in our church.
illustrations.context: This analogy shows how false teachers target and exploit vulnerable individuals in the church.

illustrations.title: Yosemite Bear Watch Experience
illustrations.text: Growing up, we would go to Yosemite and take all the food for 120 people in a truck. We couldn't fit everything into the bear boxes, so every guy was on bear watch patrol every night. We were out there to scare the bears away because they would show up looking for food.
illustrations.context: This personal story emphasizes the need for vigilance against those who might harm the church body.

illustrations.title: Lucy's Essay Deception
illustrations.text: Students were told to write an essay about returning to class. Lucy wrote that vacations are nice, but it's good to get back to school, as there's nothing more satisfying or challenging than education, and she looked forward to expanding her knowledge. The teacher was pleased with Lucy and complimented her in front of the class. In the final frame, Lucy leaned over and whispered to Charlie Brown, 'After a while, you learn what sells well.' This shows how people know what to say to please others.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate how some people, like Lucy, know how to say what Christians want to hear to take advantage of their vulnerability.

illustrations.title: Lemon Squeezing Challenge
illustrations.text: A strong man at a circus sideshow demonstrated his power and squeezed juice from a lemon, then offered $500 to anyone who could squeeze out more. Several big, husky men tried and failed to get any more drops. Then, a thin, scholarly-looking man came forward, strained hard, and managed to get a few more drops, amazing the strong man. The strong man paid him and asked for the secret, to which the man replied, 'I've been the treasurer of a Southern Baptist Church for years and I do this all the time.' Pastor Bob shares this as a quote from Billy Graham to highlight how some people are skilled at handling finances in ways that might involve deceit.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to show how some individuals, especially in church settings, know how to exploit situations for personal gain, much like those who take advantage of Christians.

illustrations.title: Balaam and the Donkey
illustrations.text: This story is from the Book of Numbers chapter 22, where the children of Israel had come out of Egypt and were wandering in the wilderness.
