Balaam, the prophet, went astray by following the way of unrighteousness and loved the wages of wickedness. He received a rebuke for his transgression when a mute donkey spoke with a human voice to restrain his madness. The story illustrates how even a prophet can be led off the right path for personal gain. Pastor Bob retells it to emphasize the dangers of straying from God's way.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to point out that false teachers, like Balaam, speak God's word but pursue selfish interests, warning believers to be cautious.

illustrations.title: Balaam and Balak's Deception
illustrations.text: In the Book of Numbers, the king of Moab named Balak saw the huge crowd of Israelites in the wilderness and was terrified by rumors of their military victories, so he decided to hire a prophet named Balaam to curse them. Balaam, who lived hundreds of miles away and had a reputation for effective blessings and curses, was approached by Balak's representatives. They offered him payment, but Balaam consulted the Lord and was told not to go because the Israelites were blessed by God. When the king sent more distinguished envoys with a blank check, Balaam hinted at his greed by saying he couldn't go unless God allowed it, essentially bargaining for riches. Despite this, he promised to ask God again, showing his double-mindedness.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate how people reacted to the Israelites in the wilderness, highlighting attempts to deceive or curse them through a hired prophet.

illustrations.title: Balaam's Donkey and the Angel
illustrations.text: Balaam is riding his donkey, excited about the money he's going to earn. The angel of the Lord stands in the way with a sword drawn, visible to the donkey but not to Balaam. The donkey veers off the road into a field, and Balaam beats it to get back on track. Then, in a narrow path, the donkey crushes Balaam's foot against a wall to avoid the angel, leading to more beating. Finally, in a tight spot, the donkey lies down, and Balaam beats it again until the donkey speaks, revealing the angel and saving Balaam's life.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how greed and spiritual blindness can make someone oblivious to God's warnings and interventions.

illustrations.title: Grade School Spanish Ditty
illustrations.text: When I was in grade school at Van Buren Elementary School, they introduced Spanish on Fridays with a teacher who showed us movies and taught the alphabet and vowels. To learn the vowels, we repeated a little ditty called 'bird,' which translates to the vowels a-i-e-o-u my donkey knows more than you. We would point at someone next to us and make them say it as part of the lesson.
illustrations.context: This anecdote connects to the Balaam story by humorously referencing a talking donkey to emphasize that even simple things can teach profound lessons.

illustrations.title: Monkey Trap for Greed
illustrations.text: I read about these tribes in North Africa where they hunt monkeys by tying a coconut to a tree, drilling a hole, and putting in nuts that monkeys love. The monkeys come along, put their hand in for the nuts, and when they grab the nuts, their fist is too big to pull out. They refuse to let go, trapping themselves due to their own greed, making them easy to capture.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how false teachers, like Balaam, are trapped by their impure motives and greed.

illustrations.title: Balaam and the Talking Donkey
illustrations.text: Balaam is so angry when his donkey speaks, and he starts having a conversation with it, which is bizarre—like forgetting the money Balak offered and just going to the circus with a talking donkey. The point is, Balaam's donkey knew more than he did, revealing his blindness. This highlights how God used even a mute donkey to speak truth to him.
illustrations.context: This story shows that we must examine the character and motives behind someone's words, not just the content.

illustrations.title: Balaam's Deceptive Advice
illustrations.text: In chapter 24 of Numbers, since Balaam cannot curse God's people, he tells King Balak how to compromise them by having his young women invite the Israelite men to parties and feasts. This leads the men to bow down to Baal and engage in sexual sin and intermarriage. As a result, God sends a plague that kills 24,000 Jews until Phineas intervenes and stops it.
illustrations.context: This demonstrates how Balaam's bad motives led to destruction for God's people, emphasizing the need to check the heart behind actions.

illustrations.title: Neighbor's Coconut Story
illustrations.text: We had a neighbor for about 17 years in our first home in Placentia, and it was a wonderful Hispanic family. We've shared before that we took them to the Harvest Crusade and led many of them to the Lord. One of them, Ronald, would say he was a 'coconut'—brown on the outside but white on the inside, meaning he didn't know traditional cultural practices.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how false teachers might appear one way on the outside but be different within, just like Ronald's self-description.

illustrations.title: Tree by Its Fruit
illustrations.text: My wife can point out any tree and tell me its name, while I can only say if it's green or dead, which is a little embarrassing. Jesus said you can tell what a tree is by the fruit it produces, like an orange tree by its oranges or a peach tree by its peaches. This helps us recognize true character in people.
illustrations.context: This analogy shows that we should judge people by their actions and fruits, not just their outward appearance.

illustrations.title: Little Shop of Horrors Analogy
illustrations.text: There was a science fiction B movie from the 1960s, later made into a play, called Little Shop of Horrors. It's about a guy named Seymour who has a strange plant that starts dying, so he feeds it his own blood after accidentally pricking his finger. As the plant grows, he has to kill people to keep it alive, and it eventually becomes huge, develops a voice, and starts demanding more, controlling his life entirely.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate how feeding the flesh leads to corruption and eventual control, emphasizing the need to deal with sinful desires.

illustrations.title: Laodicea Church Deception
illustrations.text: Jesus said to the church at Laodicea, you say you're rich and have become wealthy and have need of nothing, but you don't even know that you're wretched, miserable, poor, blind, and naked. This shows how people can think they're fine spiritually when they're not. Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize the danger of self-deception and the need for God's true judgment.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that Christians should not rely on their own assessment of being 'good' but seek God's verdict to avoid spiritual blindness.

illustrations.title: Lamp as Guidance Analogy
illustrations.text: Are you familiar with the lamps in that passage? They were little oil lamps that people tied to their feet, and it only lit the next step. Sometimes, it's so dark that you only have enough light for the next step, so you have to trust the Lord for that next step.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate how God's word provides just enough guidance for the immediate next step in life.

illustrations.title: Singing for Memory Example
illustrations.text: Here's an example: 1877 Kars for Kids. When you sing something, you remember it a little bit easier. These songs are full of scripture and truth, helping us commit God's word to memory.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show how singing makes it easier to remember and apply God's word.

illustrations.title: California School Pride Debate
illustrations.text: I watched something on the news that I thought was important to show you, so I recorded a brief video on my phone this morning. It covers the violence that erupted over the Glendale school board's decision to make June Pride Month, with progressive protesters clashing with conservative Armenian and Hispanic parents who argue school should focus on academics, not sexual orientation. Parents are upset because elementary students are being asked to choose pronouns, taught about sexual orientation, and required to share bathrooms with transgender students, all due to state laws mandating LGBTQ+ instruction without opt-out options.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this real-world event to highlight cultural conflicts over education and values.

illustrations.title: Church Members in School Board
illustrations.text: We have a couple of people in our church who decided to run for school board because they care about cultural issues and the influence in public schools. Todd Frazier is with the Placentia Unified School District, and Madison Miner is with the Orange Unified School District. Madison got elected by just a few votes, shifting the balance from liberal to conservative and leading to significant changes. Now, there's a recall effort against her this weekend, based on lies, as liberals try to unelect her. We laid hands on her last week to pray and encourage her, and we don't want her to stand alone.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is showing how Christians can actively influence culture by running for school board positions.

illustrations.title: Oracles of God Teaching
illustrations.text: The Bible says let him who speaks for God speak as it were the Oracles of God. Do you know what that means? The word 'Oracle' means let him speak as it were the very revelation of God. We're not just reading an ancient book of history; we're talking about God's inspired word. And I need you to know what I believe: I am not seeking to deliver the word of God to you tonight; I am seeking to deliver you to the word of God. I'm asking you to say, 'Lord, speak to me.'
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that teaching the Bible is about presenting it as God's direct revelation to personally engage the audience.

illustrations.title: Psalm 91 on Protection
illustrations.text: Jot down Psalm 91 verses 11 through 13. Here's what the psalmist said: For he, the Lord, will give his angels charge concerning you to guard you in all your ways. They'll bear you up in their hands so you won't strike your foot against a stone. You will tread upon the lion and the cobra, the young lion and the serpent; you will trample them down. In other words, everything that the enemy tries to use to discourage you, tempt you, destroy you, or deceive you, God will help you to overcome.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to show that God protects His people from spiritual enemies like the lion and serpent, enabling them to overcome deception and destruction.

illustrations.title: Remember Lot's Wife Warning
illustrations.text: Jesus, when talking about being ready for his return, said to remember Lot's wife. She didn't make it because she tried to go with her husband but left her heart in Sodom. It's a sobering reminder of what happens when you're not fully committed.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate the danger of incomplete commitment in faith, as a warning about apostasy.

illustrations.title: Enemy Fears God's People
illustrations.text: The sons of Israel were on their way to the promised land and camped in the plains of Moab between the Jordan River opposite Jericho. Balak, the son of Zippor, saw all of Israel, a huge group of about a million and a half people, and heard what they had done to their enemies in those battles. Moab was in great fear because of the people, for they were numerous, and Moab was in dread of the sons of Israel. Moab said to the Elders of Midian, another country next to it, that this horde would lick up all that is around us as the ox licks up the grass of the field. Balak, the son of Zippor, was king of Moab at that time.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that the enemy fears the presence of God's people.

illustrations.title: Demons Fear Jesus
illustrations.text: Remember when Jesus goes to Gadara on the other side of the Sea of Galilee? There were two men possessed by a legion of demons. They cried out, saying, 'What do we have to do with you, Son of God? Have you come to torment us before the time?' This shows the terror in the demonic realm when Jesus shows up.
illustrations.context: To illustrate that the demonic realm fears the presence of Jesus or his people.

illustrations.title: Herod Fears Baby Jesus
illustrations.text: Jesus is born as a little baby, and King Herod is troubled, along with all Jerusalem. They're afraid even though Jesus hasn't done anything yet and poses no threat. Herod thinks his throne is in danger because Jesus is called the King of the Jews, but Jesus later says his kingdom is not of this world.
illustrations.context: To show that the enemy fears the presence of God's people even when they are no immediate threat.

illustrations.title: Enemies Unite Against Jesus
illustrations.text: The Pharisees and the Sadducees, who hated each other and were deeply polarized, came together out of fear and envy of Jesus. Similarly, Herod and Pilate, who didn't like each other before, became friends during the process of arresting Jesus. This shows how Jesus can bring even his enemies together, sometimes against him, as the enemy unites forces against God's people.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate how fear of Jesus can unite unlikely enemies, emphasizing spiritual opposition to God's work.

illustrations.title: Balaam's Curse Attempt
illustrations.text: A king sent messengers to Balaam, a known spiritual mercenary near the river in Pethor, to curse the people who had come out of Egypt because they were too mighty to defeat physically. The king believed in a spiritual attack, hiring Balaam for his reputation in cursing and blessing people. This story highlights how the enemy seeks spiritual forces to drive God's people away.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that the enemy wants God's people to leave and uses spiritual attacks, as seen in this biblical narrative.

illustrations.title: Tavern Struck by Lightning
illustrations.text: In a town that had been dry with no alcohol, a tavern was being built, prompting a group of Christians to hold an all-night prayer meeting asking God to intervene. Lightning then struck the tavern and burned it down. The tavern owner sued the church, claiming responsibility, and the Christians hired an attorney to deny it.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate the reality of spiritual battles and the unexpected outcomes when people seek spiritual intervention.

illustrations.title: Jesus and the Demon-Possessed Man
illustrations.text: When Jesus casts the demons out of a man possessed by a legion of them into the pigs, the pigs rushed down the hill and into the Sea of Galilee, getting rid of the demons. The people of that area, who had been troubled by this dangerous man who lived in the tombs and harmed himself, didn't thank Jesus; instead, they told him to go away because they were freaked out by his presence. He leaves and sends the healed man back home to share what the Lord has done for him.
illustrations.context: This story illustrates how the enemy and those influenced by demons reject God's presence, similar to how the people told Jesus to leave after he performed a miracle.

illustrations.title: Police Officer and Boss Encounter
illustrations.text: When I was a police officer in the city of Placentia, I worked for some really good sergeants and lieutenants, and one lieutenant I loved working for called me into his office because I was new on the shift. He didn't know that the chief had hired me as a Christian and an ordained minister to start a chaplain program; he just knew I was on his team. He shut the door and said he didn't like the new chief, and I thought to myself that the chief was actually a nice guy.
illustrations.context: This personal story shows how people can have preconceived notions or rejections towards authority figures, paralleling the earlier point about rejection of Jesus.

illustrations.title: Lieutenant's Dislike of Chief
illustrations.text: There was a lieutenant who said he didn't like the Chief at all. I asked why, and he explained that the Chief shoves God down everyone's throat. He showed me the police manual, which had a dedication page with the Chief's name and a quote from Romans 13:1, stating that no authority exists except that given by God. The lieutenant was deeply offended by this simple inclusion, seeing it as forcing religion on people, even though it was within the Chief's rights. I thought to myself that this man needed the Lord, and years later I learned he had been a Christian as a kid but had backslidden and become bitter toward faith. He eventually got right with the Lord again, which highlighted to me how people often resist God's presence.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to illustrate how people, like the enemies in the sermon, react negatively and are triggered by any mention of God.

illustrations.title: Balaam Seeks God's Permission
illustrations.text: Balaam asks permission of the Lord and receives God's clear answer. God came to Balaam and said, 'Who are these men?' Balaam explained that Balak has a problem and wants him to curse the people. God told Balaam not to go with them and not to curse the people because they are blessed.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that God prohibits cursing those He has blessed and commands obedience.

illustrations.title: Responding to Curses Fearlessly
illustrations.text: As a believer, you don't ever have to fear somebody who says they're going to put a curse on you. I would just smile and say, 'Well, good luck with that.' It doesn't work because God protects His people.
illustrations.context: This shows that believers are protected from curses and should not fear them.

illustrations.title: Pilate's Authority from God
illustrations.text: Pontius Pilate said to Jesus, 'Do you not know I have power to crucify you?' Jesus replied that Pilate had zero authority except what was given by his Father. This means that no one has power over us except what God allows for His purposes.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that all authority comes from God, and believers should not fear human power.

illustrations.title: Satan Targets Job's Weakness
illustrations.text: You know in the Book of Job, Satan is standing before God, and God is bragging about Job, saying he's a righteous man who walks with Him and shuns evil. Satan responds that Job only lives that way because God has blessed him so much, and he asks to test Job. It's interesting that when God said to the devil, 'Have you considered my servant Job?' the word 'considered' in Hebrew refers to evaluating the weakness of an enemy fortress, like in the Book of Joshua. What God meant was, have you really looked at Job to see where you might attack him, and Satan said yes, he had.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how Satan identifies and exploits weaknesses, similar to how Balak increases temptation for Balaam.

illustrations.title: Preacher Pretends to Pray
illustrations.text: Honey, said the preacher, we just got an invitation to go to a bigger church in a bigger city with a bigger salary, so I'm going to go upstairs and pray about it. She asked, 'Do you want me to pray with you?' He replied, 'No, you stay down here and start packing.' This story highlights how someone might claim to seek God's will while already having decided.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the danger of using prayer as an excuse to do what we want instead of truly seeking God's will.

illustrations.title: Young Prophet in 1 Kings 13
illustrations.text: In the book of 1 Kings chapter 13, a young prophet speaks a word from God against Jeroboam and refuses to eat or drink as commanded. An older prophet from the area lies to him, saying an angel told him it's okay to come and eat. The young prophet, tempted and hungry, decides to go along with it anyway. This story warns about the consequences of not obeying God's direct commands.
illustrations.context: This retelling emphasizes that we should obey God's instructions directly and not be swayed by false words from others.

illustrations.title: Disobedient Prophet's Doom
illustrations.text: A man of God goes to another prophet's house, they start eating, and then God gives the old prophet a word that the man will die for not obeying the first command. The man is told he won't be buried with his family and will die on the way. Sure enough, on his way home, a lion kills him and stands next to his body, with his donkey nearby, creating a bizarre scene that underscores the consequences of disobedience.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize that when God speaks clearly, you shouldn't seek another answer, as disobedience leads to severe consequences.

illustrations.title: Woman with the Divining Stick
illustrations.text: I heard about a guy who saw a woman throwing a stick up in the air to decide which path to take. She explained she was at a fork in the road and trying to discern God's direction, but the stick kept falling on the wrong path. The guy realized she was pretending to seek God's will while really wanting her own way, showing how some people go through the motions but ignore true guidance.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the danger of pretending to seek God's direction while actually pursuing personal desires, leading to poor decisions.

illustrations.title: Balaam and the Donkey
illustrations.text: Balaam was riding his donkey with his servants when the angel of the Lord stood in the way as an adversary. The donkey saw the angel with a drawn sword and turned into the field, but Balaam struck her to get back on the road. The angel blocked the path again, squeezing Balaam against a wall and later forcing the donkey to lie down, until God opened the donkey's mouth to speak and question Balaam's anger.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that if you're going the wrong way, God will send signs to stop you, emphasizing the need to heed divine warnings.

illustrations.title: Moses' Near Death on Mission
illustrations.text: When God called Moses to go to Egypt and tell Pharaoh to let His people go, Moses agreed but then faced God's anger on the way. Despite being on a mission for God, He was going to kill Moses because of his disobedience. This shows that even if you're on God's mission, you must obey Him fully, or it won't go as planned.
illustrations.context: This highlights that partial obedience isn't enough; God requires full compliance, even from those He calls.

illustrations.title: Donkey as Broken Car
illustrations.text: Balaam doesn't stop and ask God; he assumes his donkey is rebellious. He doesn't call AAA, saying I have a problem with this donkey like the steering is going out and the brakes are off, and then it's full-on road rage. This illustrates how people react without seeking wisdom.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to show that Balaam fails to seek God's wisdom during his trial, assuming the problem is with the donkey instead.

illustrations.title: Righteous Care for Animals
illustrations.text: Jot down Proverbs 12 and verse 10: a righteous man has regard for the life of his beast, maybe your beast is a Doberman or a puppy, but a righteous person has regard for the life of their beast, whereas the compassion of the wicked is cruel. Pastor Bob connects this to Balaam's character, showing how he mistreats the donkey that is actually saving his life.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to illustrate that a righteous person values and cares for their animals, contrasting it with Balaam's cruelty to highlight spiritual awareness.

illustrations.title: Balaam and the Donkey
illustrations.text: Balaam said to the angel of the Lord, 'I've sinned, for I did not know that you were standing in the way against me. Now if it is displeasing to you, I'll turn back.' But the angel said, 'Go with the men, but speak only the word which I tell you.' So Balaam went along with the leaders of Balak. The point is, Balaam was hired to speak for God but couldn't see into the spiritual realm and was actually fighting God, much like how God used a mute, stubborn, and unclean donkey to rebuke this supposed man of God.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how someone might unknowingly fight against God, emphasizing the need for spiritual awareness.

illustrations.title: Jacob Wrestling God
illustrations.text: Jacob fought with a figure on the Jabbok River, thinking it was an enemy, only to discover it was the Lord. This story shows how one might mistakenly battle against God himself. Pastor Bob uses it to warn that we could be doing the same in our lives.
illustrations.context: It highlights the danger of opposing God's plans without realizing it, urging listeners to open their eyes to spiritual realities.

illustrations.title: Abraham and Pharaoh's Rebuke
illustrations.text: In the Old Testament, God used Pharaoh to reprove Abraham. Remember, Abraham passed off his wife Sarah as his sister because she was strikingly beautiful, even at 90 years old. When Pharaoh discovered the truth, he confronted Abraham, saying, 'What is this you have done to me? Why didn't you tell me she was your wife?' This shows how God employed a godless leader like Pharaoh to correct Abraham's deception.
illustrations.context: This demonstrates that God can use unlikely or ungodly sources to rebuke and correct His people, reinforcing the theme of unexpected divine intervention.

illustrations.title: Grade School Spanish Game
illustrations.text: When I was in grade school, they tried to teach us Spanish one day a week with a teacher who came in to cover basic words like the alphabet and vowels. To review the vowels, we played a little game where we said, 'My donkey knows more than you,' and then pointed to someone else to continue the phrase. It was a silly game, but it's the same idea as saying, 'My dog is smarter than you.' Pastor Bob uses this to connect to the Balaam story, showing how God humbles someone by using something lowly.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating how God humbles Balaam by using a donkey, just as the game highlights someone's lack of knowledge.

illustrations.title: Woman's Divorce Decision
illustrations.text: I remember a gal who was divorcing her husband; I had performed their wedding, and they were both Christians and friends of mine. I met with her and asked what she was doing, and she said he hadn't been unfaithful, but she wasn't happy. I expressed sympathy and tried to understand, but she insisted she had prayed about it and felt peace because God wants His daughter to be happy. She quoted the Bible saying, 'Happy are the people whose God is the Lord,' and decided to go through with the divorce. And she did, convincing herself it was God's will.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate how people can deceive themselves into thinking they're following God's will based on their own desires rather than His clear commands.

illustrations.title: Insincere Prayer for Signs
illustrations.text: It's easy to pray something like, 'God, should I go out with this person? Just show me a sign, like make the sky blue—hey, it's blue today.' But you're just saying it to yourself, and that's not truly hearing from God. Don't do it; let God be God in your life.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating how people manipulate God's will through insincere prayers instead of genuinely seeking His guidance.

illustrations.title: Balaam's Covetousness and Repentance
illustrations.text: This man, Balaam, was driven by covetousness, valuing it more than honoring God. He was blinded to the obstacles God put in his way, blaming circumstances and even beating his donkey as he fought against God's will. Eventually, Balaam repented and said he was sorry, asking God to show him what to do.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is using this to warn against making decisions based on greed rather than God's unchanging will.

illustrations.title: Jesus' Garden Prayer
illustrations.text: Jesus prayed three times in the garden, saying, 'Father, if it be possible, let this cup pass from me.' Nevertheless, he added, 'Not my will, but yours be done,' emphasizing the need to truly mean it when submitting to God's will. Make sure that when you pray like this, you're sincere and ready to accept whatever God decides.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that it's okay to pray repeatedly for something but must ultimately submit to God's will.

illustrations.title: Paul's Thorn in the Flesh
illustrations.text: Paul prayed three times for his thorn in the flesh—a messenger of Satan sent to torment him—to be removed, believing it was best for him. He discovered that God responded by saying no, teaching him that God's ways are higher. Through this, Paul learned to accept God's decision even when it wasn't what he wanted.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates that persistent prayer is fine, but one must recognize when God clearly says no and let it go.

illustrations.title: Bible College Seminary Advice
illustrations.text: When I finished Bible College as a Bible major, my pastor son asked me if I was thinking about going to seminary. I told him I was praying about it, as it was a big decision for three more years. He said, 'Why do you want to go? You've already studied the Bible,' and I thought that was funny because I knew there was so much more to learn from God's Word.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that there's always more depth and truth in the Scriptures than one might initially realize.

illustrations.title: Jesus and the Donkey Colt
illustrations.text: On Palm Sunday, Jesus rode into Jerusalem on a donkey to fulfill a prophecy from Zechariah 9:9. He sent two disciples ahead to a village where they would find a colt tied up, one that no one had ever sat on, and told them to untie it and bring it. If anyone asked why, they were to say the Lord has need of it, and that's exactly what happened when they went. This fascinated me because of the detailed way Jesus knew and predicted these events.
illustrations.context: This retelling shows that even familiar Bible stories contain deeper details that reveal more about God's Word and its truths.

illustrations.title: The Donkey's Untying
illustrations.text: I want you to go and untie the donkey. If anybody troubles you about it, tell them the secret phrase: the Lord has need of it, and they'll let it go. Then it tells us what Jesus said might happen: while they were untying it, someone might ask what you're doing. I always wonder why there's so much detail about it being tied. It's fascinating how this connects to deeper meanings.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this retelling to highlight the significance of the donkey being tied, linking it to prophetic fulfillment in the Messiah's story.

illustrations.title: Judah's Prophetic Donkey
illustrations.text: In Genesis 49, there's a prophecy about Judah, the tribe from which the Messiah will come. It says Judah is a lion's whelp, and he will lie down as a lion with the scepter not departing until Shiloh comes, meaning the Messiah. To him shall be the obedience of the people, and don't miss verse 11: he will tie his donkey's colt to the choice vine. This connects to the Gospel story, showing how the Messiah fulfills ancient promises. It's interesting how this ties into the idea of untying in Jesus' entry.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate how the Old Testament prophecy about the donkey foreshadows Jesus' actions, emphasizing the fulfillment of Scripture.

illustrations.title: Isaiah's Vineyard Parable
illustrations.text: In Isaiah 5, God tells us that He planted His choice vine, Israel, and did everything to make it produce fruit, but it yielded worthless grapes. This parable shows how God expected fruit from His people but found none. Jesus later picks up this idea in His own teachings, emphasizing the need for repentance and fruitfulness.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that Israel, as God's vine, failed to produce the expected fruit of repentance, foreshadowing Jesus' ministry.

illustrations.title: Jesus' Fig Tree Story
illustrations.text: Remember the parable that Jesus told about a fig tree that bore no fruit after three years of care. In this story, the owner looks for fruit as a symbol of repentance but finds none, leading to a decision about its future. It highlights the urgency of producing spiritual fruit in response to God's call.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that Jesus sought the fruit of repentance from Israel during His ministry but found none.

illustrations.title: Donkey as Humility Symbol
illustrations.text: The donkey represents humility and service, as described in Zechariah 9:9, where the King comes gently riding on a donkey. This analogy shows Jesus as the humble servant who bears burdens, just like in Isaiah 53. It contrasts with expectations of a powerful king, emphasizing His gentle nature.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that the Messiah, Jesus, embodies humility and service in His ministry.

illustrations.title: Jerusalem's Destruction in 70 AD
illustrations.text: Jesus wept over Jerusalem because He knew that despite the shouts on Palm Sunday, the people would reject Him and shout for His crucifixion by Friday. He foresaw their 'funeral' in the historical destruction of the city in 70 AD, when it was devastated as a consequence of that rejection. This event underscores the tragic outcome of turning away from God.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate the spiritual truth that rejecting Jesus leads to judgment, as seen in the real historical event.

illustrations.title: John's Rejection of Messiah
illustrations.text: Do you remember what it says in John when he came to his own, which is Israel? He came to his own and his own received him not, but to as many as received him, he'll give them the right to become children of God. So Jesus' ministry is not tied only to Israel, allowing Gentiles to be grafted in through this rejection.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating how Jesus' rejection by Israel opened salvation to Gentiles.

illustrations.title: Joseph's Sin Redemption Analogy
illustrations.text: Just like Joseph's brothers' sin was redeemed to be their own salvation, so God has redeemed even the rejection of Israel to be the richest wealth for Gentiles. This shows how what was meant for harm was turned for good. Through this, we as Gentiles can see God's overarching plan of grace.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that God's redemption turns Israel's rejection into a blessing for Gentiles, similar to Joseph's story.

illustrations.title: Genesis Creation Retelling
illustrations.text: God translated the land or earth, and the gathering of the waters He called seas, and God saw that it was good. Then God said, 'Let the earth sprout vegetation, plants yielding seed, and fruit trees on the earth bearing fruit after their kind with seed in them.' And it was so; the earth brought forth vegetation, plants yielding seed after their kind, and trees bearing fruit with seed in them after their kind. And God saw that it was good. And there was evening and morning, the third day. You guys, it's a brand new day when the first star comes out, which is considered the new day.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is using the Genesis creation story to highlight God's creative order and set the foundation for studying the Bible.

illustrations.title: Road to Emmaus Retelling
illustrations.text: The two men on the road to Emmaus were walking with a stranger who was Jesus in disguise, but they didn't recognize him. They didn't believe that Jesus was the Messiah because he had been killed, and Jesus reproved them for being slow to believe all that God had written in the Old Testament. He pointed out the prophecies about the Messiah, including those about his suffering and death in passages like Daniel 9, Psalm 22, and Isaiah 53, which the Jews often overlooked. Jesus explained that they hadn't believed all the Scriptures that were written about the Messiah. Then, he went through the entire Old Testament, starting from Moses, and explained everything concerning himself.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to show that Jesus is throughout the Old Testament and that we should expect to find him there, as Jesus himself taught.

illustrations.title: Pangaea and Earth's Division
illustrations.text: Science tells us that the original earth was one land mass, called Pangaea, a Greek word meaning all earth, where all continents were once joined. The Bible describes this in Genesis, and in Genesis 10:25, it mentions that during Peleg's days, the earth was divided, possibly referring to when the continents separated. This illustrates how the biblical account aligns with scientific understanding of Earth's history.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is using this to show that the Bible's description of land emerging is consistent with historical and scientific views of Earth's formation, supporting the theme of resurrection and new creation.

illustrations.title: Jonah's Experience in the Depths
illustrations.text: In Jonah chapter 2 verses 2 and 3, Jonah said he called out of his distress while in the belly of the fish, which Pastor Bob describes as like being submerged in water. He notes that Jonah was having a hard day, underscoring how water symbolizes death in the Bible. This story illustrates the concept of emerging from death to new life, much like the land rising from water on day three of creation.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is using this retelling to explain that water represents death, contrasting it with the resurrection and new life in God's creation.

illustrations.title: Red Sea as Salvation Metaphor
illustrations.text: Psalm 66 verses 5 and 6 come and see the works of God who is awesome in his deeds towards the sons of men he turned the sea into dry land they passed through the river on foot there let us rejoice in him. This is a reference to the salvation of Israel coming out of Egypt coming through the Red Sea which was a type or a metaphor a picture of death. They were saved they came through and the Egyptian army the power of Pharaoh was broken it's a picture of salvation through water.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that the Red Sea crossing represents salvation through a death-like experience, symbolizing deliverance from the old life.

illustrations.title: Noah's Ark and Baptism Example
illustrations.text: Corresponding to that experience of Noah during the flood baptism now saves you not the removal of dirt from the flesh but rather an appeal to God for a good conscience through the resurrection of Jesus Christ. He is talking about Noah and he does corresponding to that experience. Was Noah and his family saved because they were in the water or because they were in the ark obviously because they were in the ark.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that salvation comes through faith and God's provision, like the ark, rather than the water itself, paralleling baptism.

illustrations.title: Hosea Third Day Prophecy
illustrations.text: Jot down Hosea 6 and verse 2. Here's what it says: After two days he will revive us; on the third day he will raise us up. Just like on the third day of creation when the land came out of the water, so the Messiah is raised on the third day that we may live before him. This connects the creation story to the resurrection, showing God's pattern of renewal.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that Jesus' resurrection on the third day fulfills Old Testament prophecy, mirroring the third day of creation.

illustrations.title: Psalm Creation Separation
illustrations.text: Some verses from Psalm 104 verses 6 through 9 talk about this very day of creation. The psalmist says: You covered it with the deep as with a garment; the waters were standing above the mountains. At your rebuke they fled; at the sound of your thunder they hurried away. This describes God separating the waters from the land, highlighting His power and the clear division in creation.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is using this to show God's authority in creating order from chaos, paralleling it to spiritual separation and new life.

illustrations.title: Waves Obeying Boundaries
illustrations.text: Well, let's talk about it. We've all been to the beach, and you know, except for tsunamis, the waves pretty much stay where they're supposed to. We're glad for that because it shows how things are kept in order.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate God's established boundaries for the sea, preventing it from overwhelming the land.

illustrations.title: Carol's Passing and God's Timing
illustrations.text: Today, just this afternoon, we said goodbye to one of the 17 people who started this church in my home in 1985 with her husband, because Carol Necessary went to heaven. It comforted us, with Fred and his daughter there, to know that God decided this day a long time ago. Psalm 139 tells us that God knew our days before we were born, and He's known us from the foundation of the world.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob shares this to emphasize God's control over the limits of human life, just as He sets boundaries for the sea.

illustrations.title: Carol's Hopeful Passing
illustrations.text: Carol Mussoorie was a godly woman who fought cancer with incredible grace and beauty for the last six years, ready to go whenever the Lord called her. Today was her graduation day, and while it's a day of loss, I don't grieve as one without hope because we believe in eternal life. I even told a friend that I know more people in heaven than here, and soon we'll all be together, making the separation very short.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate the hope and lack of ultimate loss in death for believers.

illustrations.title: Houdini's Unfulfilled Promise
illustrations.text: When Houdini died, he promised that if there was any way to come back, he would find it, and people took it seriously. Every year after his death on Halloween, they held seances trying to contact him, with his widow continuing for ten years. After nothing happened, she finally said ten years was long enough to wait for any man, highlighting that Houdini could never return from the dead.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob contrasts Houdini's failure with Jesus' victory over death to emphasize Jesus' power.

illustrations.title: Matthew Henry's Waters Analogy
illustrations.text: I love what Matthew Henry says in the text: all of the waters that God made, all of the pictures of trials and troubles and tragedies, don't miss the fact that they are all under the heavens, not above the heavens. In other words, he is in charge of them all. This reminds us that God rules over every overwhelming circumstance.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that God is sovereign over all trials and troubles, just as He is over the seas.

illustrations.title: Cruise Ship Sea Comparison
illustrations.text: You ever been on a cruise ship? The first time you go on one, they're massive, like a city on water, and you think you could never explore every deck. But once you're out at sea, that huge ship suddenly feels like a tiny dinghy compared to the vast ocean. It doesn't feel all that secure if the sea were to change, because man has no real power over the sea except what God allows.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to illustrate that human power is insignificant compared to God's control over the seas and life's overwhelming challenges.

illustrations.title: Childhood Beach Wave Fight
illustrations.text: I remember as a kid, I was about seven or eight years old, standing in the ocean at the beach. The waves were hitting me hard, and I was pretending to fight them back. Then a big wave knocked me over from behind, leaving me face down in the water, struggling to breathe. A lifeguard ran to save me, which made me feel embarrassed and stupid.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how circumstances can overwhelm and control us, contrasting with Jesus's power over storms.

illustrations.title: Church Seat Preference
illustrations.text: I've mentioned this many times. How many of you sit in the same or nearly the same seat every time you're here? Most of us love consistency and familiarity, and that's just normal. We think you should be psychoanalyzed if you always sit somewhere else, but I'm just kidding.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate how people resist change, drawing a parallel to how living things grow and evolve.

illustrations.title: Restaurant Food Consistency
illustrations.text: We go to a restaurant and take something that's good, and next time we go, I'm having that. Why don't you try something else? You never know, I could save some money or eat something good, but I said I had the other, so I'm sticking with that. For this restaurant, I'm not exploring; I'm trying to anyway, but we're just kind of hard-wired that way.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show how people prefer familiarity and resist change, relating it to the growth and change in living things created by God.

illustrations.title: The Silent Parrot Tale
illustrations.text: A lady went into a pet store looking for a pet and decided on a parrot since she couldn't walk a dog in her small apartment. The store owner assured her the parrot would talk, but once she got it home, it didn't say a word. She returned multiple times, buying accessories like a swing and a ladder to make the parrot happy and encourage it to speak, but it remained silent. Finally, when she came back upset, she said the parrot had died and only then uttered, 'Doesn't that store sell any food?' This story highlights how we sometimes overlook the basics.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to show that believers often neglect the fundamental truths of the Bible, which are essential for spiritual growth, just like the parrot needed basic food to thrive.

illustrations.title: Parrot Seeking Food
illustrations.text: Just like that parrot who's looking for some food, you don't grow just because you go through life. Spiritual life is tied to taking in spiritual food. God has decided to connect spiritual growth to regularly engaging with the Word.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that spiritual growth requires actively seeking and consuming the Word of God, just as a parrot seeks food.

illustrations.title: Baby Delivered to Family
illustrations.text: Just like when a baby is born, you don't deliver a baby to a grocery store where there's food. You deliver a baby to families who feed them. Your relationship to growth involves a connection to God's Word and people, as God delivers believers to the body of Christ for nourishment.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates that spiritual maturity requires being connected to God's people, similar to how a newborn baby needs a family for growth and care.

illustrations.title: Baby Feeding Analogy
illustrations.text: When you're a baby, that's what babies need; they can't handle a filet mignon. If a kid is 18 and still only eating Gerber's, something's wrong—those teeth came in for a reason. Let me extend this analogy: when we have babies, they have to be fed and don't do much more than take it in. They drink it down without chewing; it's very simple. Slowly, they move to stronger food, and eventually, every child is taught how to feed themselves. Can you imagine a 15-year-old still needing to be fed like a baby? That works for a two-year-old, but not for older kids; it's like a failure to launch.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that Christians should grow spiritually and learn to feed themselves from the Bible, rather than remaining dependent like spiritual babies.

illustrations.title: Dog Analogy in Preaching
illustrations.text: I preach a sermon about something and use an analogy about my dog to teach a spiritual truth of obedience. Someone comes because they have a dog too, but they just talk about my dog and don't even understand the principle. We don't want to be people who are just spoon-fed and only look at the pictures without grasping the content.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the importance of understanding the spiritual principle behind illustrations rather than focusing on superficial details.

illustrations.title: Grain of Wheat Parable
illustrations.text: Jesus said that if a grain of wheat falls to the earth and dies, it remains alone, but if it dies, it bears much fruit. This means that through death, there is reproduction and abundance. Jesus calls us to follow his example by denying ourselves and taking up our cross.
illustrations.context: This shows that spiritual maturity and fruitfulness come through suffering and self-denial.

illustrations.title: Isaiah's Suffering Servant
illustrations.text: In Isaiah 53, Jesus sells himself out and gives himself to God's will, and he's put to death with the transgressors. But God raises him up and satisfies him with the results of his sacrifice. This demonstrates that through his suffering, Christ achieves great fruitfulness and glory.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that following Jesus involves embracing suffering as a path to spiritual fruitfulness.

illustrations.title: Vine and Branches Analogy
illustrations.text: Jesus said that I am the vine, you are the branches, and my Father is the vine dresser. A branch cannot bear fruit unless it stays attached to the vine. If you have a fruit tree at home, just snip off the branch, and it won't produce fruit anymore, emphasizing the need to abide in Christ.
illustrations.context: This teaches that spiritual growth and fruitfulness require remaining connected to Jesus.

illustrations.title: Guy's Morning Prayer
illustrations.text: Don't be like the guy who said, 'Lord, so far it's been a good day. I haven't lost my temper, haven't coveted my neighbor's stuff, and haven't cursed or gossiped. But in a moment, I'm going to get out of bed and start the day, so I'm going to need more help.' This shows the need for ongoing connection to God throughout the day. Staying connected is essential to bear fruit in life.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize the importance of moment-by-moment connection to God to live out Christ's character.

illustrations.title: Fruit as Seed System
illustrations.text: The seed that reproduces life is inside the fruit, and this is biologically true. For example, the big pit in an avocado wasn't a mistake, and fruits like apples, oranges, lemons, and grapes are designed as delicious seed distribution systems. Animals eat the fruit, including the seeds, and then distribute the seeds elsewhere, ensuring reproduction. This illustrates how spiritual fruit works to spread life.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that the fruit of the righteous contains seeds for reproducing spiritual life, just as physical fruit does.

illustrations.title: Fruit Trees and Seeds Analogy
illustrations.text: God designed fruit trees to produce fruit with their seed in it, so that it reproduces after its kind. We are to bear fruit, which is the character of Christ like love, joy, peace, patience, kindness, goodness, gentleness, and faithfulness. When we abide in Him, His life pours through us, and people can taste and see that God is good through the life of Christ in you, which carries the seed that reproduces spiritual life.
illustrations.context: This analogy shows how believers bearing spiritual fruit naturally includes the seed of God's Word, leading others to experience and desire Christ's life.

illustrations.title: Inherited Lack of Patience Story
illustrations.text: Patience didn't just come naturally to me because my father and grandfather weren't particularly patient, and I'm not either. People know I wasn't patient growing up, and it's nothing genetic. But when you're born again of the Spirit of God, His life inside you can change your character and produce fruit like patience.
illustrations.context: This personal story emphasizes that spiritual fruits like patience come from God through the Holy Spirit, not from family genetics.

illustrations.title: Helping Son with Pull-Up
illustrations.text: I was doing some work around the house, and my daughter bought a pull-up bar that I installed. My son, who's about six years old and doesn't have much strength, wanted to try it, so I lifted him up by grabbing his legs to help him pull himself up. He thought he was doing it all on his own, but I was actually bearing the weight for him.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates that just as he helped his son succeed, Jesus helps us in our daily lives and successes, even when we don't realize it.

illustrations.title: Disciples' Return in Luke 10
illustrations.text: In Luke 10, when the 72 disciples returned, they joyfully reported to Jesus that even the demons obey us when we use your name. Jesus told them, 'I saw Satan fall like lightning. I have given you authority over the enemy's power, and you can walk among snakes and scorpions and crush them without being injured, but don't rejoice because evil spirits obey you; rejoice because your names are registered in heaven.'
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize that our true joy and authority come from God, not from our own efforts or successes.

illustrations.title: Canadian Conversion Therapy Ban
illustrations.text: Something that has just happened in Canada is the passing of legislation known as C4, which unanimously passed their parliament. This is a ban on any use of conversion therapy, making it a crime for Christian pastors and counselors to counsel anyone away from any form of sexuality, even if the person seeks help. It's a five-year prison term for doing so and a two-year term for referring someone, and it even includes sharing what God's Word says about homosexuality and sin.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this real event to illustrate the growing threats of cancel culture to Christians' ability to speak biblical truth.

illustrations.title: Jesus on Truth and Condemnation
illustrations.text: Jesus said, 'I didn't come to condemn but to save,' meaning we shouldn't condemn the lost world but instead offer salvation. He also said, 'The world hates me because I testify that its deeds are evil,' showing that speaking truth will invite opposition. Pastor Bob connects this to the need for Christians to speak truth in love without falling into condemnation.
illustrations.context: This illustrates why Christians must speak biblical truth lovingly, even when faced with hate, as Jesus did.

illustrations.title: Rave or Cave Response
illustrations.text: Joe Dallas says the problem with many Christians is we make the wrong response to cultural pressures, stating, 'You can rave or you can cave.' This means we either get upset and angry, which doesn't achieve God's righteousness, or we give in and stay silent. Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize that neither reaction is appropriate for believers.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob employs this quote to warn Christians against improper reactions to cancel culture, urging a balanced, truthful approach.

illustrations.title: Elizabeth Nash's Abortion Quote
illustrations.text: This is a quote from Elizabeth Nash, who works for the Guttmacher Institute, a pro-abortion group. She said just this last week, 'If the Supreme Court uses the Mississippi case to further undermine abortion rights and access, the effect will be devastating nationwide.' Well, devastating for her is celebrating for me, as it highlights the potential positive change for life advocates.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to contrast perspectives on abortion laws and emphasize the need to pray for a favorable Supreme Court decision.

illustrations.title: Roe v. Wade Overturn Scenario
illustrations.text: They put an image of the United States showing that if the Supreme Court weakens or overturns Roe versus Wade, 26 states are certain or likely to ban abortion, the ones in red. We are at the precipice of a momentous decision potentially. This illustrates the nationwide impact and calls us to be aware and pray for our Supreme Court justices.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this reference to highlight the potential reversal of abortion laws and urge Christians to pray for righteousness in the nation.

illustrations.title: Man Insists on Healing Despite Blindness
illustrations.text: I knew a guy who was going blind and he had us pray for him. He said, 'I don't know what the future holds for me, but if 10 or 20 years from now you see me walking around bumping into trees, just know this: I'm healed.' This illustrates how people can misinterpret scripture to deny their reality. It's a common issue with passages on healing.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to show how misinterpretations of the passage lead people to deny their sickness or blame their faith.

illustrations.title: Jonah's Desperate Prayer
illustrations.text: While I was fainting away, this is when Jonah says I'm dying, as he's in the belly of the great fish at the bottom of the ocean. Everything is over; it's his deathbed, even though he's in a fish. While I'm about to die, I remember the Lord and my prayer came to thee into thy holy temple. It takes significant dramatic things to get us where we should have been all along, which is trusting God and talking to God about our problems.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that significant trials can lead us back to trusting and praying to God.

illustrations.title: Pastor's Marriage Advice
illustrations.text: Pastor said to a man he had met just a couple weeks before in his church, and he met the man and his wife. In private, he said to the man, I know you're having trouble in your marriage. The man said, How could you possibly know such an intimate detail about me? He said, Because I know you're married, and that's exactly what Paul says in First Corinthians seven—if you marry, you will have tribulation in this world.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that suffering, such as marital troubles, is common and should lead to prayer.

illustrations.title: Joshua's Defeat at Ai
illustrations.text: Joshua leads the children of Israel across the Jordan River and they fight by faith at Jericho, where the walls come down and they achieve a great victory. But in the next battle at the small town of Ai, they are totally defeated, with 36 men killed and families left grieving. Joshua is clueless about the reason for the defeat, which was the sin of Achan, and he turns to God in prayer for revelation.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate that we often don't understand suffering and need to pray for revelation from God.

illustrations.title: Joseph Scriven's Personal Loss
illustrations.text: Joseph Scriven was no stranger to hurt and loss; at 25 years old, his fiancée accidentally drowned on the night they were to be married. Instead of becoming bitter, he gave his life to Christ and moved from Ireland to Canada, changing his way of living. Some years later, he became engaged again, showing his resilience through faith.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this example to emphasize that prayer is the antidote to discouragement, even in the face of personal tragedy.

illustrations.title: Hymn Writers Personal Loss
illustrations.text: Shortly before the couple was to marry, the girl became ill and died. He is the one who penned the words to 'What a Friend We Have in Jesus,' which says, 'All our sins and griefs to bear, what a privilege to carry everything to God in prayer. What peace we often forfeit, oh what needless pain we bear, just because we don't carry everything to God in prayer.' This hymn highlights the comfort found in bringing burdens to God.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate how prayer helps in times of grief and loss.

illustrations.title: Prayer as Weapon of War
illustrations.text: Charles Spurgeon said, 'Prayers are the believers' weapons of war.' When the battle is too hard for us, we call in our great ally who lies in ambush until faith gives the signal by crying out, 'Arise, O Lord.' Even if our cause seems all but lost, it shall be won if the Almighty bestirs himself. This quote emphasizes prayer's role in spiritual battles.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show how prayer summons divine help in overwhelming situations.

illustrations.title: Pastors Prayer Transformation
illustrations.text: One pastor talked about being so heavily burdened because of things going on in his ministry, family, and life. He said he could be a wreck and go to pray, and by the time he left his knees, the mountain was smaller, God was bigger, and he was ready to keep going forward. He described it as going in as a kid and coming out as a lion. This experience shows how prayer changes our inner strength.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to demonstrate how prayer alters our perspective and equips us for challenges.

illustrations.title: Daniels Faithful Prayer
illustrations.text: In Daniel 6:10, when Daniel knew that the law was signed that would mean his death if he prayed, he entered his house and went to his roof chamber. He had windows open toward Jerusalem and continued kneeling on his knees three times a day, praying and giving thanks before his God, as he had been doing previously. Despite the law against it, he maintained his prayer habit. This story underscores the importance of consistent prayer even under threat.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize the need for a habitual prayer life regardless of circumstances.

illustrations.title: Police Training Habits
illustrations.text: When I started out as a police officer, I wound up in training where we scrutinized incidents from our department and others to learn from what was done right and wrong, especially when officers were killed. One of the greatest tragedies for the highway patrol in California was in the early 1970s in New Hall, where four officers were shot dead during a car stop by two heavily armed ex-cons. In their training, which was among the best in the country, officers were instructed to pick up their spent brass casings after shooting to keep the range clean. This habit carried over into real emergencies, as evidenced at the scene where some officers had brass in their pockets or stacked neatly during the firefight. The point is that what you practice habitually, you will likely do in an emergency, just as we should practice prayer daily.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that daily habits, like prayer, determine our responses in crises, just as police training habits influenced officers' actions.

illustrations.title: Man with Demons Redemption
illustrations.text: The man with a legion of demons gets saved and wants to leave with Jesus, but Jesus has to leave and sends this guy back. We call him Legion, though he didn't have those demons anymore. Jesus said to him, 'Return to your house, go home, and describe the great things God has done for you.' He went away proclaiming throughout the whole city what great things Jesus had done for him. In other words, when God blesses you, give Him glory, sing His praise, and let other people know what He's done.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to emphasize that when God blesses you, you should give Him glory and share it with others.

illustrations.title: The Ten Lepers Lesson
illustrations.text: We learned that with the lepers, only one got into the very presence of Jesus. The others cried out for mercy and received it, but nine never got close to Him. The one who said thank you fell down at His feet and gave glory to God. Praise brings you closer to the Lord and opens doors for God to give you more than He's already given. We discover that with that leper, who was not just healed but whose faith saved him.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates that praise and thanksgiving draw you nearer to God and can lead to greater blessings.

illustrations.title: Pentecost Praise Power
illustrations.text: Think on the day of Pentecost, we often talk about how they spoke in tongues and there was this great miracle. The people who heard them weren't just focused on that miracle; it was the content that mattered—they were all praising God. The filling of the Holy Spirit caused them to give thanks to God. Praise and thanksgiving are the fuel and power for witness.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob shows that praise, empowered by the Holy Spirit, is essential for effective witnessing.

illustrations.title: Paul and Silas in Prison
illustrations.text: Paul was in prison at midnight after being beaten and arrested for preaching the gospel. He and Silas were praying and praising God, and the prisoners were listening to them, having never seen anyone like that. The joy of the Lord turned that dark dungeon into a place of singing, showing how praise can transform difficult circumstances.
illustrations.context: To demonstrate that true joy and praise to God can persist even in severe trials, as Paul experienced.

illustrations.title: Pray in Every Situation
illustrations.text: It's kind of like this: no matter what you're going through, whether your highest high or lowest low, you should pray. In every catastrophe, in every victory, in every sorrow, disappointment, or success, pray. This is similar to a Jeopardy-style question where the answer is always pray, no matter the circumstance.
illustrations.context: To stress the need to pray consistently in all aspects of life, both good and bad.

illustrations.title: Disciples Sleeping in Garden
illustrations.text: Jesus's disciples fell asleep in the garden, not just because it was late, but because their eyes were heavy with sorrow that had filled their hearts. Jesus had told them everything was falling apart that night, and they knew it was a heavy time. They could sense Jesus's heart was heavy to the point of death, and it affected them too, making them sorrowful and wanting to escape into sleep.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how sorrow and discouragement can prevent people from praying, just as it did for the disciples.

illustrations.title: Embarrassment of Surprise Party
illustrations.text: We don't typically like everybody looking at us at the same time because it's embarrassing, like when people shout 'speech, speech' at a surprise party. Some of us might say we don't want one, but deep down we might actually desire it. Nobody wants to be the center of attention in that way, especially when it means admitting weakness or struggles.
illustrations.context: This analogy shows how people avoid asking for prayer because it feels humbling and inconvenient, much like enduring unwanted attention.

illustrations.title: Good Shepherd Analogy
illustrations.text: Shepherds are to love sheep not just by feeding them, not just by knowing where they ought to go, not just by being one step ahead or knowing how to correct them, but Jesus said there's a difference between the good shepherd and the hireling. The hireling can feed, lead, and correct sheep but has no heart to lay down his life for them; he's just in it for the money, perks, and position. But the good shepherd lays down his life, showing the difference between Christ's heart and that of a professional minister.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that true elders must genuinely care for and sacrifice for the flock, rather than serving for personal gain.

illustrations.title: Mark 16 Healing Quote
illustrations.text: In Mark 16, Jesus made this comment: these signs will accompany those who believe; they'll lay hands on the sick and they'll recover. Now, that is not a promise that every time you lay hands on the sick they'll recover; it's not what He said. He said these signs will accompany believers, meaning there will be miraculous signs among them.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is using this quote to explain that miraculous signs like healing may occur with believers, but they are not guaranteed outcomes, tying into the proper role of elders in prayer.

illustrations.title: Ancient Medicinal Use of Oil
illustrations.text: Did you know that Hippocrates, the doctor from 400 BC, used oil as an ancient practice? Herod, when he was dying, took a bath full of oil. We're told in the scriptures that when the Good Samaritan found the Jew who had been beaten half dead on the side of the road, he poured oil and wine into his wounds. It's very interesting; it was a medicine and an anti-inflammatory. This shows how oil was used practically in healing contexts.
illustrations.context: To illustrate that oil had a medicinal purpose in ancient times, supporting the idea that anointing in James includes practical healing.

illustrations.title: John Corson's Anointing Insight
illustrations.text: I love what John Corson wrote on this. He said that the anointing of oil spoken of by James refers to both the symbolic and the medicinal realms. It speaks of a person saying, I'm looking to the Lord for healing, I'm submitted to his will being done in my life, I believe in his power and his presence, and I'm going to use his gift of medicine as well. There are two streams of healing: prayer and medicine, but it's the same God who works through them.
illustrations.context: To explain that anointing with oil involves both spiritual submission and practical medicine, emphasizing God's role in both.

illustrations.title: Jesus Selective Healing
illustrations.text: Jesus went in John 5 where there was a multitude of the ill; he heals one guy. There were other times in Chapter one of Mark where Jesus healed the whole town. He had the power to heal everybody but he doesn't; he chooses that one person to heal.
illustrations.context: To show that God does not always heal everyone miraculously, even when He has the power to do so.

illustrations.title: Paul's Thorn in Flesh
illustrations.text: Paul himself has a thorn in the flesh, whether it was physical or not I don't know, but he prays three times and the Lord says no, I have something better for you. Did Paul lack faith? I don't think so. This shows that even great apostles experienced unhealed conditions despite prayer.
illustrations.context: To illustrate that God may not remove suffering even from faithful people like Paul, emphasizing that healing isn't always instantaneous.

illustrations.title: Spurgeon on Prayer Kindness
illustrations.text: Spurgeon talked about the blessing it is when people pray for him. He said, 'No man can do me a truer kindness in this world than to pray for me.' I think that's true; when somebody actually prays for us, we need to say, 'Lord, thank you.'
illustrations.context: This quote emphasizes the profound blessing and importance of prayer for others, especially in ministry.

illustrations.title: Shepherd Anointing Sheep
illustrations.text: In Psalm 23, the good shepherd anoints the sheep's head with oil. We often picture it as just a nice gesture, but it's actually because the sheep needed oil to protect against bugs that get in their nostrils. Philip Keller's book explains that this was medicinal and purposeful, meant to heal and prevent illness.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the practical and caring nature of a shepherd's role, paralleling spiritual leadership and healing.

illustrations.title: Healing of Lame Man
illustrations.text: When the lame man was healed in the Book of Acts, it created a ruckus, and people came to hear about Jesus. The leaders arrested the apostles for healing this man in Jesus' name. This event shows how acting in God's name can stir controversy and spread the message.
illustrations.context: This story demonstrates what it means to pray or act in the name of the Lord, representing Him and His power.

illustrations.title: David Facing Goliath
illustrations.text: When David walked into the battle in the Elah Valley, after 40 days of the Philistines taunting the Israelite army, Goliath their champion called for someone to fight him, and nobody would. Now David is going out there to face him. This highlights David's courage in standing up against overwhelming odds.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the concept of representing God and acting in faith, similar to praying in His name.

illustrations.title: David Faces Goliath
illustrations.text: It's a kid with a slingshot and no armor facing Goliath, who is mocking him and boasting about feeding his flesh to the birds. David looks up at this giant warrior and says, 'You come to me with a sword and a spear and a shield, but I come to you in the name of the Lord of armies, whose army you have defied.' He doesn't rely on his own strength or past victories like fighting bears and lions; instead, he trusts in God's power.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize that when we pray, we rely on God's power, not our own strength or holiness.

illustrations.title: Everett Storms' Bible Promises
illustrations.text: Everett Storms, on his 27th time reading through the Bible, recorded every promise in the book and came to a total of 8,810 promises. That's an amazing number, equating to about 24 promises a day, one for every hour of existence. This illustrates that no matter what you're going through, there's a promise in the Bible that covers it, and we should know, believe, and claim them.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that God's promises are abundant and applicable to every circumstance in life.

illustrations.title: Stephen's Prayer in Martyrdom
illustrations.text: Stephen, you can read about him in the Book of Acts. He will be executed for his faith in Jesus as he proclaims the gospel to the Sanhedrin; they will stone him to death. So, what does he pray? He doesn't pray, 'Lord, don't let the stones hurt; let them bounce off of me.' Instead, his prayer is, 'Receive my spirit; I'm coming home; I'm ready to go.' You see, sometimes we aren't praying the right prayers.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that true prayer involves accepting God's will, not just seeking deliverance from circumstances.

illustrations.title: Jacob Wrestling as Prayer Analogy
illustrations.text: That's Jacob wrestling with the angels. You know, the Bible says that's a picture of prayer. He's fighting with God, representing how we sometimes resist God's will in our prayers.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that prayer can involve struggling against God instead of surrendering to His sovereignty.

illustrations.title: Old Man on Deathbed
illustrations.text: A believer, this old man who's on his deathbed, has someone visit him and ask how he's doing. He replies, 'I'm almost well,' reflecting his faith in resurrection power. This story shows that even in weakness, God's healing through resurrection applies to our lives.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that God's resurrection power ultimately restores believers, even in the face of death.

illustrations.title: Friend Fred's Memorial
illustrations.text: When I gave the message at my friend's memorial service, Fred, who had died of pancreatic cancer, I told his friends and family that cancer didn't win in Fred's life. I explained that the cancer in his body is totally dead, but Fred is alive with Jesus. This shows that true victory comes through resurrection, not earthly survival.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to emphasize that death does not have the final say, as Jesus' resurrection power ensures eternal life.

illustrations.title: Man Born Blind Retelling
illustrations.text: When Jesus's disciples saw a man born blind, they asked who sinned to cause it—whether the man himself in the womb or his parents. Jews believed sin could occur even in the womb, but Jesus said neither the man nor his parents sinned. This blindness was not caused by sin but for the glory of God, so that the works of God might be displayed. Then Jesus healed him.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate that sickness is not always caused by sin, countering false teachings that link illness directly to personal fault.

illustrations.title: Heroes of Faith Retelling
illustrations.text: We've studied in Hebrews 11 a few months ago about the heroes of the faith. They are men and women from the Old Testament who trusted God with their lives and have now gone to glory, cheering us on in our walk of faith. It's an interesting list because some were delivered through faith, while others were tormented to death yet still died in faith. This shows that it wasn't about some having more faith than others; it was because God's will differed in their circumstances, and the same applies to our situations with sickness.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that God's will for healing varies, just as it did for the biblical heroes of faith, emphasizing that true faith persists regardless.

illustrations.title: Pre-Prayer Personal Inquiry
illustrations.text: Quite often, I'll ask people before we pray for them for healing if there's something in their life that God is dealing with them about. A lot of times, they'll say no, I have no idea, but sometimes they'll admit yes, and then it's like, okay, you might want to deal with that. God wants to deal with that, so the Lord uses sickness to get our attention. Sometimes people have to go through this to realize it.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that God may use sickness to highlight and address personal issues before healing can fully occur.

illustrations.title: Fire Hose Overload
illustrations.text: I know sometimes because some of you have told me it feels like you're coming to get a drink and it's a fire hose. I don't want to overwhelm you with information, but I do want to encourage you to take something that the Lord spoke to you today through the worship and the word. Ask the Lord what He wants you to do with it, so you can apply it in your life.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is emphasizing that he doesn't want to overwhelm the congregation with too much information, encouraging them to focus on what God is saying through the sermon.

illustrations.title: Pull-Up Bar with Son
illustrations.text: I was working over the weekend and put up a pull-up bar at our house. I probably won't use it myself; I'll just hit my head on it. Let's be honest, I lost more calories putting it up than I ever will using it. So I put it up, and my son wanted to try it. He asked me to help him up, so I lifted him and held his legs as he tried, and he said, 'Yeah, I'm doing it!' It made him feel really good, just like some of you might feel when things are going well.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to show that people often think they're succeeding on their own, but Jesus is actually supporting and empowering them.
