illustrations.title: Jesus on Authority and Rejoicing
illustrations.text: He told them, 'I saw Satan fall like lightning. Look, I have given you the authority over the power of the enemy, and you can walk among snakes and scorpions and crush them; nothing will injure you. But don't rejoice because evil spirits obey you; rejoice because your names are registered in heaven.' Jesus says that's all fine and good, as I've given you the authority to do all that, but worship because of what I've done for you—that your names are registered in heaven. It's not of your own work but by the work of the cross and the empty tomb.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this retelling to emphasize that believers should rejoice in their salvation and God's work, not just in personal victories or authority over evil.

illustrations.title: Catholic Extreme Unction Misuse
illustrations.text: This passage has been a source of false teaching for centuries. The Catholic Church practices something called extreme unction, which involves anointing the seriously ill, especially those about to die. They base this on this verse, believing it commands such an action, as seen in their Douay version of the Bible that mentions calling for priests. However, the original Greek text refers to elders, not priests, and Scripture doesn't teach that anointing is specifically for those near death. We'll discuss that more later, but this shows how the passage has been misinterpreted.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate how the passage in James has been historically misinterpreted by the Catholic Church to support a practice not truly in Scripture, emphasizing the need for accurate biblical interpretation.

illustrations.title: Prayer for Man Losing Sight
illustrations.text: I remember years ago praying for a man who had come under this teaching. He asked for prayer because he was losing his eyesight; he could still see somewhat, but he was told it would go out unless a miracle happened, so we prayed for his healing. Afterwards, his eyesight was the same, but I'll never forget what he said: 'You guys may see me a few years from now bumping into things, but I know that I'm healed because by His stripes I am healed. So I don't care that I can't see at all; I know that I'm healed.' Folks, that is not what God is calling you to do—to believe something that's not true as an expression of faith.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to show how false teachings on healing can lead people to deny reality in the name of faith.

illustrations.title: Pastor Spots Marriage Trouble
illustrations.text: I heard of a pastor who had a man start coming to his church. He met him and got to know him a little, but not very well. One day, the pastor said to him, 'I know you're going through some trouble in your marriage.' The man asked, 'Who told you? How do you know that intimate detail of my life?' The pastor replied, 'I just know you're married—say no more. See, it's biblical to have trouble in marriage, as Paul says in 1 Corinthians 7 that if you marry, you will have tribulation in the flesh, guaranteed.'
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that suffering in marriage is a common biblical reality for Christians.

illustrations.title: Joshua's Defeat at Ai
illustrations.text: Joshua leads the nation of Israel after Moses has died. They cross the Jordan by faith in an amazing miracle and achieve a great victory over Jericho where the walls come down. Then they go to the next town, Ai, a tiny town compared to Jericho, but they suffer a defeat and lose the battle, with 36 Israeli soldiers dead on the battlefield. Joshua doesn't understand why they're defeated, so he goes before the Lord complaining about the army's courage. God reveals that the defeat is due to the sin of Achan, and only through prayer does God start to reveal what's going on.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that we often don't understand why we face trials and that prayer helps reveal the truth behind our sufferings.

illustrations.title: Joseph Scriven's Tragic Loss
illustrations.text: You may not have ever heard his name, but you know something of what he's written. Joseph Scriven was no stranger to loss and hurt. At the age of 25, he was engaged to be married, but his fiancée was accidentally drowned on the very night before they were to be married.
illustrations.context: This shows that even those who have experienced deep personal tragedy can relate to the themes of loss and the importance of prayer in times of suffering.

illustrations.title: Hymn Writer's Overcoming Trials
illustrations.text: A man faced great loss when his fiancée died, but he didn't become bitter against God. He gave his life to Christ, moved to Canada, and changed his way of living. A few years later, he became engaged again, but the girl fell ill and died before they married. He wrote a poem to comfort his mother, which became the hymn 'What a Friend We Have in Jesus,' emphasizing the privilege of carrying everything to God in prayer.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how faith and prayer can turn personal tragedy into a source of comfort and spiritual legacy.

illustrations.title: Spurgeon's Prayer as Weapon
illustrations.text: Spurgeon said that prayers are the believer's weapons of war, connecting it to Paul's teaching that we don't war according to the flesh and our weapons are powerful for destroying fortresses. He explained that when battles are too hard, we call on our great ally, God, who can turn the tide. This quote underscores the idea that prayer invites God's intervention in our struggles.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize the power of prayer in spiritual warfare and overcoming challenges.

illustrations.title: Child's Prayer Misunderstanding
illustrations.text: Remember when praying, it's not like the little boy who thought the Lord's Prayer started with 'Our Father who does art in heaven' or 'whose name is art.' This humorous mix-up highlights the importance of understanding the words we use in prayer. Pastor Bob uses it to stress the correct and meaningful way to address God.
illustrations.context: This example points out the significance of properly recognizing God's fatherly affection and sovereignty in prayer.

illustrations.title: Pastor's Prayer Transformation
illustrations.text: One pastor said that regarding prayer and how it changes things, he could be a wreck and go to pray, and by the time he left his knees, the mountain seemed smaller, his God bigger, and he was ready to move forward. He described it as going in like a kitten and coming out like a lion. Pastor Bob affirms this by saying amen, noting that God's intention is to strengthen our faith through prayer.
illustrations.context: This quote illustrates how prayer shifts perspective, making God seem greater and problems more manageable.

illustrations.title: Spare Tire Faith Analogy
illustrations.text: Too many of us treat our prayer life as something to be used only in case of emergency, kind of like what I call spare tire faith. We only resort to it when nothing else works, making it our last option rather than our first response. Is that even a prayer of faith, or are we just worrying on our knees?
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to show that prayer should not be a last resort but a primary response in times of need.

illustrations.title: Israel at the Red Sea Retelling
illustrations.text: When the children of Israel came out of Egypt, they faced the Red Sea in front, mountains on the sides, and Pharaoh's army behind them. There was no way out no matter which direction they looked. God closed them in to draw them near to Him, teaching that He is in charge and uses such circumstances to bring us closer.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob retells this story to illustrate that God intentionally places us in difficult situations to encourage prayer and deepen our relationship with Him.

illustrations.title: Police Training Personal Story
illustrations.text: Years ago when I was a police officer, one of my jobs was training other officers in law enforcement. We evaluated our department's incidents and those from other departments to learn what was done right and what went wrong. This involved examining every detail to improve our practices and avoid mistakes in similar circumstances.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob shares this personal experience to emphasize the importance of learning from past events, drawing a parallel to how we should approach prayer and life's challenges.

illustrations.title: Newhall Shooting Historical Example
illustrations.text: One of the films we used for training was about the Newhall shooting of the highway patrolmen, which happened in the 1970s and was the worst loss for California highway patrol with several officers killed in four and a half minutes during a single car stop. These young officers, in their 20s with just a couple of years on the force, were outgunned by heavily armed ex-convicts. The incident led to changes in training for the highway patrol and other departments, highlighting the need to learn from such tragedies to prevent future errors.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this historical event to illustrate the value of reviewing and learning from mistakes, connecting it to the habit of prayer in difficult times.

illustrations.title: Police Training Failure
illustrations.text: Back then, police officers carried revolvers and had to load bullets slowly without speedy loaders. At the training range, they were told to pocket the expended brass or stack it neatly to avoid mess. However, in a real gunfight, officers didn't have time for that, and some were killed while trying, illustrating that improper training can lead to fatal mistakes.
illustrations.context: The point is that regular habits and training determine how one responds in emergencies, just as Daniel's consistent prayer prepared him.

illustrations.title: Daniel's Consistent Prayer
illustrations.text: A law was passed that would kill Daniel for praying to God, but when he learned of it, he went to his house and knelt in his roof chamber with windows open toward Jerusalem. He continued praying and giving thanks three times a day, just as he had been doing previously. This shows Daniel's unwavering faith in the face of danger.
illustrations.context: The illustration emphasizes that maintaining regular spiritual habits like prayer prepares one for emergencies.

illustrations.title: Church Member's Song Moment
illustrations.text: I got a text from a guy in our church yesterday who said he was listening to a Christian song he'd heard many times before. The words suddenly hit him deeply, making him pull over his car and cry as he reflected on God's goodness in his life. He shared how blessed he felt with his family's health, financial stability, and ministry opportunities, leading to overwhelming gratitude.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the importance of celebrating and praising God during good times to build a strong faith habit.

illustrations.title: Man with Demons Story
illustrations.text: Remember the man with a legion of demons who got them cast out. He wanted to go with Jesus, but Jesus was getting kicked out of Gadara because of the pigs, so the man insisted on going too. Jesus told him no, you're going home instead, and said, 'Return to your house and describe what great things God has done for you.' So he went away proclaiming throughout the whole city the great things Jesus had done for him, telling his family what God had accomplished.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to emphasize that when God does great things, one should go home and share it with family and friends, giving God the credit.

illustrations.title: Jeopardy Prayer Analogy
illustrations.text: It's kind of like that old game show, Jeopardy, where the answer is pray. What's the question? That is what you need to do in every situation, whether high or low. So, for any circumstance, the response is to pray, just like in Jeopardy where you fit the answer to the clue.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to illustrate that prayer is the appropriate response in all life situations, from celebrations to hardships.

illustrations.title: Wife's Hospital Preference
illustrations.text: My wife told me, 'Bob, if I'm ever in the hospital dying, please don't have a bunch of people come see me.' She explained it's not about how she looks, but because she won't feel like dealing with visitors. This story highlights how illness makes people want privacy rather than attention.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the reluctance to ask for help or prayer when sick due to discomfort and embarrassment.

illustrations.title: No Surprise Birthday Parties
illustrations.text: Most of us in this room are not asking for a surprise party on our next birthday because we don't like all the focus on us. We don't want everyone looking at us and making speeches. This example shows how people generally avoid being the center of attention, much like avoiding elders during illness.
illustrations.context: This analogy demonstrates that people dislike unwanted attention, making it hard to humble themselves and call for elders when sick.

illustrations.title: Spurgeon on Prayer Kindness
illustrations.text: Charles Spurgeon said, 'No man can do me a truer kindness than this: to pray for me.' I think that is exactly why the Lord wants elders to pray, as it highlights the vital role of intercession in leadership.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that elders should pray for others, underscoring the importance of their spiritual role.

illustrations.title: True Shepherd vs Hired Hand
illustrations.text: Jesus said the difference between a true shepherd and a guy who watches sheep for pay is that the hired hand just does it for the money and doesn't care about the sheep. But a true shepherd lays down his life for the sheep, lives as an example, and cares about them deeply. This analogy shows the heart required for genuine leadership.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that elders must genuinely care for the flock, not just for personal gain, as true shepherds do.

illustrations.title: God Rebuking Shepherds in Ezekiel
illustrations.text: In the book of Ezekiel, God rebukes the shepherds of Israel, who were the spiritual leaders, for being self-centered and not caring for the people. He says, 'Woe to you shepherds because you don't really care about the sheep; you just want to use their wool and eat them.' Then God declares that He will step in to feed His flock, lead them to rest, seek the lost, bring back the scattered, bind up the broken, and strengthen the sick.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that shepherds, like church elders, must care for their flock or face God's judgment, emphasizing proper leadership.

illustrations.title: Hippocrates and Olive Oil
illustrations.text: Hippocrates in 400 BC was using olive oil to heal people. It has anti-inflammatory properties, and we see that oil was used not just ceremonially in ancient history, especially in the Bible, but also medicinally. This highlights how oil served practical healing purposes beyond symbolism.
illustrations.context: To illustrate the historical medicinal use of oil, emphasizing its anti-inflammatory properties in ancient practices.

illustrations.title: Herod's Oil Bath
illustrations.text: When Herod was dying, he actually took a bath in hot oil to help his inflammation. This example shows how oil was used medicinally in history to treat physical ailments. It's a reminder that ancient people recognized oil's healing benefits.
illustrations.context: To demonstrate the practical, medicinal application of oil in historical contexts, supporting the idea of its dual spiritual and physical roles.

illustrations.title: Good Samaritan's Healing
illustrations.text: When the Good Samaritan found the Jewish man half dead, he poured oil and wine into his wounds because oil has healing properties. This act highlights the medicinal use of oil in the story. The original Greek also refers to elders rubbing oil on someone, connecting it to practical care.
illustrations.context: To show that Biblical stories include the medicinal aspects of oil, beyond just spiritual symbolism.

illustrations.title: Shepherd Anointing Sheep
illustrations.text: In Psalm 23, David says as a sheep, 'He anoints my head with oil.' A shepherd puts oil on the head of a sheep to heal wounds from flies and mosquitoes, not for spiritual anointing. This practical use underscores the everyday healing purpose of oil in Biblical contexts.
illustrations.context: To explain that anointing with oil in the Bible has a medicinal, real-world application, challenging purely spiritual interpretations.

illustrations.title: Hezekiah's Trust in Doctors
illustrations.text: There's a guy in the Old Testament who did that, his name was Hezekiah. He made a bad move by trusting the doctors and not seeking the Lord. It's a warning against relying exclusively on medicine without involving God.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate the danger of ignoring God's role in healing by depending solely on human means.

illustrations.title: Luke the Physician's Role
illustrations.text: Can we remember who God chose to use to write one of the Gospels and the first 30-year history of Acts? That would be Luke, the beloved physician as Paul calls him. Medicine is a gift from God, and we need to see that all healing comes from Him.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob highlights that God uses figures like Luke to show medicine as a divine gift, emphasizing that healing ultimately comes from God.

illustrations.title: David's Psalm on Healing
illustrations.text: Here is what David wrote in Psalm 103: 'Bless the Lord, O my soul, and forget not all His benefits. He pardons all your iniquities and heals all your diseases.' David is saying that every time we've been healed, it was the Lord. This reminds us that all healing is from God.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to connect the idea that God is the source of all healing, including physical restoration.

illustrations.title: Peter and John Heal Lame Man
illustrations.text: When the lame man was by the temple gates, Peter and John said, 'Silver and gold have we none, but such as we have we give you: in the name of Jesus Christ of Nazareth, rise and walk.' They were arrested by the religious leaders for healing him, which seemed absurd. Peter questioned if they were on trial for a good deed and made it clear that the man's healing happened in the name of Jesus.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the authority and power of praying in the name of Jesus.

illustrations.title: David Confronts Goliath
illustrations.text: When David in the valley decided the rest of the nation wouldn't fight Goliath because he seemed too big, David saw him as tiny compared to God and wasn't afraid. He couldn't wear Saul's armor and knew how to use a slingshot from fighting a lion and a bear. Goliath, a massive professional soldier who had spent his life killing, mocked the young David as a mere boy, but David declared he came in the name of the Lord of armies, not relying on his own strength.
illustrations.context: This shows that acting in the name of the Lord unleashes God's power against overwhelming odds.

illustrations.title: Everett Storm's Promise Study
illustrations.text: Everett Storm did a study of the Bible on his 27th reading through it, enumerating every promise in Scripture and writing them down. He found 8,810 promises, which means there's basically one promise per hour of every day, 24 hours a day. In other words, whatever you're going through in this hour, there's a promise of God for it, so find it, know it, believe it, and claim it.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that God has abundant promises for every situation in life, encouraging believers to apply them through prayer.

illustrations.title: Jesus in Nazareth's Unbelief
illustrations.text: Jesus couldn't do many great works in Nazareth because of their unbelief, though he did heal a few. This shows that faith plays a key role in what God can accomplish. Jesus often said things like 'be it done unto you according to your faith,' emphasizing the importance of belief.
illustrations.context: This retelling highlights that a lack of faith can limit God's miracles, stressing the need for genuine belief in prayer.

illustrations.title: Abraham's Faithful Obedience
illustrations.text: The men and women of Hebrews 11 were champions of faith because they obeyed God when He revealed His will to them. For example, God told Abraham to leave his home, and by faith, he went out as instructed. This demonstrates that true faith is always a response to God's clear direction.
illustrations.context: This story explains that faith must be based on God's revealed will, not just personal desire, to be effective in prayer.

illustrations.title: Paul's Healing in Lystra
illustrations.text: In Lystra, Paul saw a man who was lame, and the Lord showed him that the man had faith to be healed, so Paul performed the healing. This event illustrates how faith aligns with God's intentions for miracles. Peter and John, in contrast, had walked by a similar lame man many times without acting until the right moment.
illustrations.context: This retelling underscores that healing through prayer requires faith that responds to God's specific revelation.

illustrations.title: Jacob's Wrestling Prayer
illustrations.text: Jacob wrestled with the angel on the bank of the Jabbok River, which is a picture of prayer. The Bible says he wrestled because he thought it was an enemy coming to fight him, as he tried to protect his family and relied on his own strength to outwit enemies like his dad and brother. But that night, his tricks failed him. Jacob became victorious only as he was defeated and surrendered, even though he was crippled. As he held on to the Lord, he realized that it didn't matter how many men Esau had; he wasn't worried anymore because he had wrestled with God.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that prayer involves wrestling with God, leading to surrender and strengthened faith, even if circumstances don't change.

illustrations.title: Stephen's Martyrdom Prayer
illustrations.text: When Stephen was stoned to death, he prayed, not for the stones to bounce off or for his enemies to be harmed, but he said, 'Lord, receive my spirit. It's my time to go.' He was ready to surrender to God's will, accepting that God would use this moment to bring him into His presence, come what may.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that prayer involves surrendering to God's will rather than changing circumstances.

illustrations.title: Dying Man's Final Words
illustrations.text: A man was dying on his deathbed, and a friend came to see him for the last time, knowing he was in pain. The friend asked how he was doing, and despite the pain, the man whispered, 'I'm almost well.' This shows a perspective of hope beyond earthly suffering.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize that true hope lies in the assurance of heaven, making even the hardest days ultimately good.

illustrations.title: Friends' Memorial Services
illustrations.text: My friend Fred died, and I did the memorial service; his wife Carol had also died, and I handled hers as well. In Carol's service, I said that cancer didn't win, even though she died of it, because her salvation and heaven were secure. This reminds us that no matter what happens, our eternal hope prevails.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to reinforce that salvation and the promise of resurrection mean that earthly losses do not define the ultimate victory.

illustrations.title: Gospel Sharing Analogy
illustrations.text: That's like saying I shared the gospel and it didn't work. There's no guarantee that the person will receive Christ. If your brother says to go and reprove them in private, and you don't because it doesn't usually work or they get mad at you, then you weren't faithful to what God asked.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is emphasizing that victory comes from obeying God in prayer and actions, regardless of immediate results.

illustrations.title: Man Born Blind Retelling
illustrations.text: The disciples asked Jesus, 'Who sinned, this man or his parents, that he was born blind?' Jesus replied, 'Neither, but this happened so that the works of God might be displayed in him.' Then Jesus healed him to show God's purposes.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that not every illness is directly tied to personal sin, as God has other purposes in allowing it.

illustrations.title: Prescription Ignored Analogy
illustrations.text: It's like having a prescription from the doctor. You thank the doctor, glad they know what's wrong and that it will help. You plan to get it filled and take it twice a day, but then you find it in your desk drawer six months later, never even got the prescription filled. You're wondering why you're still struggling with your symptoms, and it's because you didn't bother to do it.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that ignoring God's command to pray is like not using a prescribed medicine, which leads to ongoing problems.

illustrations.title: First Century Cancel Culture
illustrations.text: I just remind you that canceled culture is not new. In the first century, they tried to cancel Christians from sharing their faith. They told them to stop talking about Jesus and bringing his blood upon us, and they said you can't preach. But the Christians replied that God told us to, so we ought to obey God rather than man, and we can't stop speaking what we've seen and heard.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that cancel culture has historical roots in early Christian persecution, encouraging believers to prioritize obedience to God over human opposition.

illustrations.title: Canadian Anti-Counseling Law
illustrations.text: By the way, Canada just passed legislation making it a five-year prison sentence if any pastor or counselor counsels someone who's homosexual and doesn't want to live that lifestyle. This shows how modern laws are attempting to silence those sharing faith-based guidance. It's a real-world example of efforts to restrict Christian expression.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is using this to highlight how contemporary society is trying to cancel and silence Christians from standing up for their beliefs.

illustrations.title: Roe v. Wade Tragedy
illustrations.text: Today is Sanctity of Life Sunday in many churches because it was 49 years ago in 1973 that the Supreme Court decision in Roe versus Wade made abortion on demand legal. For 49 years, millions of American babies have died at the hands of doctors and their own mothers, a tragedy that calls for God's justice. Right now, the Supreme Court has a case before it from Mississippi, and it appears the conservative balance of the court is ready to possibly overturn Roe versus Wade, which could make abortion illegal or very hard to obtain in 26 states.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this historical event to highlight the ongoing tragedy of abortion and the need for God's justice and revival in America.

illustrations.title: Life Before Marriage Reflection
illustrations.text: I was thinking the other day, I can't vaguely remember a time before I was married. I've been married 15 years now, so I was like 12 when I got married. It's hard for me to remember life before my wife because life with my wife is so great. She's watching, so... And the same goes for my kids; I can't remember a time when I had an opportunity to sleep. It's these monumental moments in your life that happen, and then you think, man, what was life like back then? It doesn't matter because it's great now.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to illustrate how life-transforming events, like marriage and accepting Jesus, make the past seem distant and undesirable.

illustrations.title: Sunday Night Faith Stories
illustrations.text: We've seen roughly 16 people make professions of faith in Jesus through these Sunday nights that we've been doing. Now, they can come and say that's when death was arrested and their life began, on that one Sunday night when someone brought them to church, and they're so happy they did. The Lord is creating these stories for a lot of people, just like the ones being created at Jfest.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is highlighting how God is actively transforming lives through church events, encouraging attendance and sharing.

illustrations.title: Body of Christ Unity
illustrations.text: We're allowing some folks in the body here to exercise their spiritual gifts. Not everybody's a hand, not everybody's a foot, an eye, or a mouth, but we can work together to be the body of Christ. This shows how everyone has a unique role in the church.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating how different people in the church have unique spiritual gifts but must work together as one body.

illustrations.title: Visitors Seeking a Priest
illustrations.text: Every once in a while, somebody will come to our church who's never been to a Bible-teaching or evangelical church. They're used to more formal churches and will ask, 'Where's the priest? Where's the beef?' because we don't have robes and candles and don't look like a typical Catholic or Episcopal church. Sometimes people mistakenly think that I am the priest, but I want to clarify that misunderstanding.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that modern evangelical churches differ from traditional ones without a formal priest, emphasizing that all Christians are called to ministry.

illustrations.title: Martin Luther's Reformation
illustrations.text: This was one of the issues in the Reformation under Martin Luther, the teaching of the priesthood of believers which was contrary to the Catholic Church. It happened in the 16th century, 1600 years after the church was born. One of the Catholic monks, in this case Martin Luther, tried to reform the Catholic Church back to what the Bible taught, emphasizing that all believers are priests and there is no special priesthood.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that the idea of the priesthood of all believers was a key biblical truth rediscovered during the Reformation, challenging church traditions.

illustrations.title: Picture of Church Ministers
illustrations.text: Becky, could you hear me? I was thinking that a lot of you don't know all the ministers at our church because you don't know everybody who's a minister here. I just wanted you to see a picture we have of all of our ministers right here. Oh yeah, I think that's funny.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that every member of the church is a minister, emphasizing the universal call to ministry.

illustrations.title: Son with Police Badge
illustrations.text: It reminds me of this old picture I have of my son. He was about four or five years old, wearing one of my police uniform shirts, with my badge hanging off his chest and my hat on his head. The shirt was huge on him, and it's funny because people just laugh at it since nobody gets nervous around a little kid dressed as a cop, even with a real badge. What if that badge was on my dog in a little police uniform, or on a cat, or even attached to a rat or a worm? The more ridiculous it gets, the less we think any real authority could be given to something so small and powerless.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that God confers authority to believers, even if they feel unworthy or insignificant, just as a badge on a child seems powerless.

illustrations.title: Neighbors as Ministry Field
illustrations.text: Your non-Christian neighbors aren't going to come to my house or to church, but they are your neighbors and you work with them every day. Satan would love it if the only time we shine our lights is at church and we don't do any ministry outside of that. Maybe we sign up for a ministry here, which is great, but that's not all there is—God wants to do more through you if you accept your role.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is emphasizing that everyday Christians must engage in ministry outside of church to counter Satan's deception and live out their faith.

illustrations.title: Rejecting Reverend Title
illustrations.text: I always know when someone new writes to me because they address it as 'Reverend Bob Copeny,' which has a nice ring to it, but I throw it straight in the trash. You know why? Because the Bible only uses the word 'reverend' once, and it's referring to God, not any human. I'm not big into titles like that, as they can hype us up to think we're something we're not.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that ministry roles should not be self-conferred or based on inflated titles, but accepted humbly from God.

illustrations.title: Jesus on Avoiding Titles
illustrations.text: Jesus said, 'Don't get into titles; call no man your father, you're all brothers.' This means we should stop trying to hype ourselves up like we're something special that we're not. Pastor Bob connects this to the idea that ministry isn't about self-conferred status but about accepting what God gives us. It's a reminder to keep things simple and focused on service rather than elevation.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to show that Christians should avoid seeking or using titles that elevate themselves, as true ministry comes from God.

illustrations.title: Pastor's Desert Seeking Experience
illustrations.text: I often share the story of when I felt called into the ministry, which wasn't a pleasant experience for me. I was seeking the Lord, unsure of my path in life, so I decided to go to the desert to fast for a week and pray for guidance. There, I listened to worship music, read the Bible, and spent time alone with God, but things got challenging when my car got stuck in the sand. At night, the winds made my car shake wildly, and I worried about an escapee from the nearby prison, adding to the discomfort and fear. Despite it all, it was a time of earnestly seeking God's direction.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that God's call to minister comes before our own efforts or desires to seek Him.

illustrations.title: Desert Retreat Experience
illustrations.text: I went out alone with a loaded rifle, trying to be at peace with God, but for three days, I felt terrible, lonely, cold, and afraid. When I decided to leave and drove back, I suddenly felt God's presence in my car and questioned where He had been. God impressed on my heart to remember how I felt, because most people on this planet feel that way every day without knowing Him or having the hope of eternal life. This experience revealed my calling to share the treasure of faith with as many people as possible.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to illustrate how his feelings of isolation helped him understand and respond to God's call to evangelism, emphasizing the daily struggles of those without faith.

illustrations.title: Mother's Hospital Reflection
illustrations.text: When I was born, my mom was in the hospital preparing for induced labor in the 1950s, and she had to fill out a form asking about live births. She realized she had four healthy children and had never lost one, which made her grateful to God for that blessing. This moment of reflection highlighted how many women in her time faced loss in childbirth, prompting her to thank the Lord.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob shares this family story to underscore themes of gratitude and God's faithfulness, connecting it to his own life and calling.

illustrations.title: Mom's Early Dedication
illustrations.text: My mom knew I would be her last child, so in the hospital room, she made a dedication to the Lord, saying that if He gave her a healthy child, she would give this one completely to Him. Years later, when I announced I felt called into ministry, she told me about her promise. I realized God was working in her heart long before He worked in mine, showing His plan was in motion even before I was born.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that God calls individuals to ministry before they are even aware of it.

illustrations.title: Amos's Unlikely Prophecy
illustrations.text: Amos was a prophet in the Old Testament, one of the minor prophets, and he told King Amaziah that he was not a prophet by calling or family tradition. He explained that he was just a herdsman and a grower of sycamore figs. But the Lord took him from following the flock and commanded him to go prophesy to His people, showing how God calls ordinary individuals to extraordinary tasks.
illustrations.context: This retelling demonstrates that God selects people for ministry regardless of their background or qualifications.

illustrations.title: Superstar Song Critique
illustrations.text: In the blasphemous movie and play 'Jesus Christ Superstar,' which I recommend you avoid, the disciples sing a song with these words: 'I always hoped that I'd be an apostle, knew that I could make it if I tried, so when I retire I could write the gospel, and they'll all talk about us when we die.' This portrayal is completely wrong because it suggests the apostles sought their roles for personal gain, whereas in reality, they didn't choose it—God did. I use this to highlight the error in thinking we can decide our own calling.
illustrations.context: This quote emphasizes that God initiates calling, not human ambition.

illustrations.title: Moody Refuses Ordination
illustrations.text: Did you know that D.L. Moody refused ordination? The church wanted to ordain him because he was clearly gifted and being used greatly by God. They said, 'We want to ordain you into the ministry,' but he said no, because his understanding of Scripture was that God is the only one who can ordain, not man.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that God alone ordains ministers, emphasizing divine sovereignty over human actions.

illustrations.title: Spurgeon's Quote on Ordination
illustrations.text: In fact, you know what C.H. Spurgeon called ordination? He called it 'the placing of idle hands on empty heads.' This quote highlights the folly of human attempts to ordain, stressing that true ministry comes from God alone.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to underscore that ordination is a divine act, not a human one, connecting it to the biblical truth of God's role in ministry.

illustrations.title: Sacrificing Egyptian Idols
illustrations.text: It's interesting because bulls and rams were worshiped in ancient Egypt. Remember, these people had just come out of Egypt, so sacrificing a bull and ram is a picture of serving the Lord by being willing to sacrifice all the other gods that have been in your life as an act of worship.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that true worship requires giving up former idols and false gods to fully serve God.

illustrations.title: Paul's Leaven Analogy
illustrations.text: Leaven is a symbol of that which permeates thoroughly and yet invisibly, corrupting and causing things to inflate, like yeast. Remember, in the New Testament, Paul uses this to address evil influence in the church of Corinth, saying a little leaven leavens the whole lump of dough. We must get the evil out, otherwise it will spread, as in the situation where a man was involved with his stepmother sexually and nobody was confronting him for it.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate how sin corrupts and must be removed to keep the community pure.

illustrations.title: Jesus as Unleavened Bread
illustrations.text: The offering that God receives has no leaven, symbolizing purity, as Christ had no sin of his own. Remember, Jesus identified himself with the unleavened bread at Passover when he said, 'This is my body given for you.' This connects to the idea that Christ's sacrifice was completely sinless and pure.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob emphasizes that Christ's offering was perfect and without sin, mirroring the unleavened bread.

illustrations.title: Eggs in One Basket Contrast
illustrations.text: We have this expression in English: don't put all your eggs in one basket. It's usually used with regard to having limited resources and putting them in a place that's vulnerable, because if you drop the basket, you'll break all your eggs. So, for more security and less liability, people advise not putting all your hopes in one stock or asset; you want to diversify. But interestingly, in the biblical context, all of what is being offered to God is put in one basket. This highlights the difference between worldly wisdom and God's instructions.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to contrast everyday advice on risk management with the biblical requirement to consolidate offerings to God, emphasizing trust in divine provision.

illustrations.title: Matzah as Jesus' Symbol
illustrations.text: Let's take a look at a Matzah cracker to remind you what they look like. For hundreds of years, this is how Matzah has been made; they poke holes in it in rows, resulting in unleavened bread with puncture marks all through it, done in lines like stripes. The Bible says that Christ is our Passover lamb and He is the bread, and we know from Isaiah 53 that He was pierced for our iniquities and by His stripes we are healed. This is a fascinating picture of Jesus' sacrifice as described in the text.
illustrations.context: This analogy illustrates that Jesus is a sinless sacrifice, pierced and striped for our healing and redemption.

illustrations.title: Jesus as the Door
illustrations.text: In verse 4, it says you shall bring Aaron and his sons to the doorway of the tent of meeting, which speaks of the work of the Savior. Jesus said, 'I am the door; if anyone enters through Me, he shall be saved and shall go in and out and find pasture.' This connects to the idea of being brought to the door for salvation, as referenced in John 10:9 and reinforced by First Peter 3:18, where Christ died for sins once for all.
illustrations.context: This quote emphasizes that Jesus is the exclusive way to salvation and eternal security.

illustrations.title: Jesus' Baptism Explanation
illustrations.text: When we're baptized, we're admitting we're sinners that need to be washed, but Jesus went for baptism even though he did not need to be washed. John the Baptist said to him, 'I need to be baptized by you, and do you come to me?' Jesus replied, 'Permit it now to fulfill all righteousness.' He wasn't saying he needed washing for sin; instead, he was accepting the mission God had for him on earth. That day, his whole ministry began as the Holy Spirit descended on him like a dove, and John proclaimed him as the Lamb of God who takes away the sin of the world. Christ's ministry continued for three and a half years with the empowering of the Holy Spirit, leading to his death on the cross in our place.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this retelling to illustrate that Jesus' baptism symbolized the start of his mission and ministry, contrasting it with believers' baptism as a symbol of repentance.

illustrations.title: Aaron's Robe of Righteousness
illustrations.text: Aaron didn't buy the robe; he didn't make the robe. Actually, he didn't even put on the robe. If you read the text, it was all done to him; it was all done for him. He just had to allow it to be done. Folks, this is what the Bible teaches about me and you—I'm righteous not because I put it on, but because it was put on me the moment I believed.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that righteousness and salvation are gifts from God, not something we achieve ourselves.

illustrations.title: John's Glorified Vision of Jesus
illustrations.text: John was super close to Jesus in the upper room, where he leaned on his breast, and he was the only disciple at the crucifixion besides Mary. John is known as the disciple whom Jesus loved, showing their deep bond. But when John sees Jesus in his glorified state in Revelation 1, everything changes; he falls on his face as a dead man because Jesus is now crowned with glory, clothed in a robe reaching to his feet and girded with a golden girdle, resembling the high priest from the Old Testament.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate how Jesus' glorification demands reverence and highlights the transformation from earthly closeness to heavenly awe.

illustrations.title: Boy's Baptism Misunderstanding
illustrations.text: I heard of a little boy who went to a baptism with his parents for the first time down by the river in New Hampshire. He got dirty at the event, so his mom gave him a bath, and he started baptizing his little army men in the tub. As he did, he said, 'I baptize you in the name of the Father and the Son and the whole East Coast,' because that's what he thought the minister was saying. We often laugh at such stories, but they highlight how many people truly misunderstand the work of the Spirit.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that people often misunderstand the Holy Spirit's ministry, similar to the boy's confusion about baptism.

illustrations.title: Eldad and Medad's Anointing
illustrations.text: In Numbers 11:29, God took the Spirit that was on Moses and placed it on 70 elders of Israel to help him lead. Two men, Eldad and Medad, didn't show up for the anointing ceremony, perhaps because they were sick or missed it for some reason. Yet, the Spirit still came upon them in the camp, and they began prophesying just like the others. Joshua was offended and reported it to Moses, but this story reveals how the Spirit works in unexpected ways beyond human plans.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate the Holy Spirit's ministry and how it operates freely, even outside formal settings.

illustrations.title: Grandson as Mini Me
illustrations.text: Some of you have never met my grandson, but you'll hear about him because I can't help but talk about him. There's a picture I wanted to show you of me and my grandson—it's not just about how cute he is. People call him my mini me because he looks like me, and I like to dress him up in outfits like mine; he enjoys it right now. When we go out to a restaurant, everyone knows we're related because we look and dress so much alike. This shows how connected we are, just like Aaron and his sons.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to illustrate that believers, like Aaron and his sons, share the same anointing and are visibly connected to Christ.

illustrations.title: Paul as Chief Sinner
illustrations.text: That's why Paul said, 'I'm the chief sinner, but he chose me. I was ignorant, and He's doing great things through me, even though I'm the worst.' So if you feel like you're the worst, you're not; God can use the worst in a radical way. The more we fail, the more His grace is magnified.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to encourage listeners that God can powerfully use even the greatest failures.

illustrations.title: Paul's Weakness in Corinth
illustrations.text: Paul said I wasn't really impressive in Corinth; I was weak and trembling. He explained that it was so people would depend not on the wisdom of man but on the power of God. I didn't impress anybody, but I just told the truth, and God's Spirit moved as a result.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that God works through human weakness to demonstrate His power.

illustrations.title: Chuck Smith's Surrender Prayer
illustrations.text: Pastor Chuck Smith said that if in the morning you say, 'Lord, my life is yours. I want to be your servant today. I want you to lead me by your Spirit and overrule any wrong decisions I may make. Take control of my life.' If you yield yourself to the Lord, your life becomes a progressive revelation of God's will as the day unfolds. This means God reveals His purposes step by step.
illustrations.context: This quote illustrates how daily surrender through prayer leads to being filled with the knowledge of God's will.

illustrations.title: Holy Spirit Influence Analogy
illustrations.text: Don't get drunk with wine, as that's a waste and leads to dissipation, but instead be filled with the Spirit, meaning be controlled by the Spirit. I've often said that Christians need to learn to drive under the influence of the Holy Spirit, whether on the way to work or church. This also means having conversations under the Holy Spirit's control, so you're guided in daily life.
illustrations.context: This analogy emphasizes being controlled by the Holy Spirit rather than negative influences to understand and live out God's will.

illustrations.title: Philip's Obedience to God's Call
illustrations.text: Philip was in Samaria preaching the gospel, with people getting saved and miracles like healings happening—it was an amazing revival. In the midst of this, God told him to go down to the desert in Gaza. Philip obeyed and went, even though it seemed confusing. There, he encountered an Ethiopian eunuch in a chariot reading Isaiah, and God directed him to approach. Philip explained the Scriptures, preached Jesus, and the eunuch was saved that day. As a result, the eunuch took the gospel back to Africa. God revealed the next step only after Philip obeyed the first.
illustrations.context: This shows that God reveals His will one step at a time, requiring obedience to the initial directive before showing the next.

illustrations.title: Flower Garden Analogy
illustrations.text: A neighbor had a huge, beautiful flower garden that attracted visitors. One day, he saw a butterfly flitting from flower to flower, enjoying them without much depth. Then, a botanist arrived, sat with a notebook and magnifying glass, studying the flowers intensely and taking notes, but it never affected his life. Later, the neighbor observed a bee diving into the flowers, getting covered in pollen, and flying off to make honey for the colony. Someone said Christians are like one of these: Bible butterflies who skim the surface, Bible botanists who study deeply but don't apply it, or Bible bees who dive in and take action to benefit others.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to show that Christians should not just skim or study the Bible superficially but actively apply it in their lives.

illustrations.title: Doers of the Word Quote
illustrations.text: Be doers of the word and not just hearers who deceive themselves. We need to be like Bible bees who enthusiastically dive into the Word of God, let it fill us personally, and carry it out to others. This means taking action with what we learn, not just taking notes, to bless our families and communities. Pastor Bob connects this quote to emphasize that true faith involves applying Scripture in everyday life.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to stress the importance of not only hearing the Word but actively living it out to avoid self-deception.

illustrations.title: David's Faithful Journey
illustrations.text: Think of this: David was anointed to be king by the prophet Samuel, who was famous, while David was just a nobody. Not long after, he fought Goliath and won, married into King Saul's family, and became best friends with Jonathan, the heir to the throne, who knew David would be king. He even played music for Saul and led Israel's armies in battle, making it seem like God's plan was unfolding smoothly with everyone in the palace loving him. However, a popular song boasting 'Saul has slain his thousands, but David his tens of thousands' irritated Saul, leading him to try to kill David twice. David had to flee Israel, and Saul pursued him with the entire army, but David gathered 400 distressed and bitter men around him. These damaged men were transformed over time into a formidable army that fought the Philistines alongside David, even though he wasn't yet king and lacked official support.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses David's story to illustrate that having a heart after God means being sincere, humble, and passionate despite facing discouragement, as part of walking worthy by pleasing God.

illustrations.title: Adino's Epic Battle
illustrations.text: One of David's men was named Adino, and he killed 800 enemy men in a single day. That's incredible, especially when you compare it to Samson who killed a thousand with a donkey's jawbone. The Bible highlights this to show the extraordinary feats of these warriors.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate the exceptional fighting skills and bravery of David's mighty men.

illustrations.title: Benaiah's Lion Hunt
illustrations.text: Another warrior, Benaiah, killed several enemy champions, including a huge Egyptian, and even went into a pit on a snowy day to kill a lion. This act shows his determination to stay sharp in his skills, even when it wasn't directly related to the main battle. The Bible records this as an example of his fearless nature.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob shares this to emphasize the unique and bold characteristics of David's elite fighters.

illustrations.title: Asahel's Speed
illustrations.text: One of the men, Asahel, was incredibly fast, fleet of foot like a gazelle that can run about 30 miles an hour, faster even than Usain Bolt who ran about 22 miles an hour. This made him stand out among the warriors in battle. The Bible uses this detail to highlight his exceptional abilities.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob employs this description to showcase the extraordinary physical gifts of David's top soldiers.

illustrations.title: David's Thirst for Water
illustrations.text: One day in the heat, David was in a cave thinking about the cold, delicious water from the well in his hometown of Bethlehem, which was then controlled by the Philistines. He wasn't going to go get it himself, but his three top men heard him mention it and decided to act. This story reveals their loyalty and willingness to risk everything for their leader.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to point out the deep commitment and bravery of David's closest warriors.

illustrations.title: David's Men Fetch Water
illustrations.text: We're not told exactly, but David's men looked at each other and decided to go for it. They sneaked away without telling David, heading to Bethlehem where Philistines guarded the city and the well. They fought through, took down a couple of enemies, and one got the water quickly. They brought it back to David, who was shocked and honored by their effort. He poured the water on the ground, saying it was too precious to drink and must be offered to God. Frankly, if I were one of those men, I'm not sure how I'd react, but they seemed to understand.
illustrations.context: This story illustrates the ambition to please God through voluntary acts of sacrifice and love, not just obedience to commands.

illustrations.title: Boasting in God's Knowledge
illustrations.text: Jeremiah God says let not the rich man brag about how rich you are, let not the wise man tell us about all the degrees you got, let not the mighty man do a bench press demonstration. You want to boast in one thing: boast that you know and understand me. Not just that you know me, but you understand me, and he goes on to describe the kind of God he is. That you understand God's character, as it's being revealed in you because you're becoming like him.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is emphasizing that true value lies in knowing and understanding God's character, not in worldly achievements like wealth, wisdom, or strength.

illustrations.title: Knowing God for Eternal Life
illustrations.text: Jesus said this is eternal life that you may know the only true God and Jesus Christ whom he has sent. It means knowing God personally and experientially. Even if you've prayed to receive Christ and your life was changed, you must continue growing in this knowledge. So, go beyond just initial faith to deepen your understanding of God.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is stressing that eternal life involves a personal, experiential knowledge of God through Jesus, beyond mere agreement with doctrine or church attendance.

illustrations.title: Meeting vs Deep Friendship
illustrations.text: Now, Mike, imagine 20 years from now you never come back to our church and we never see each other again. Then, someone walks up to you and says, 'Hey, Mike, do you know Pastor Bob Kopeny?' You'd probably say, 'Pastor who? Bob Kopeny? I saw him at Calvary Chapel once, 20 years ago. I was there, I think.' You'd shake his hand, but you don't really know him; you'd say, 'That gray-haired guy? Yeah, I met him, but I don't really know him.' Now, what if things were different? What if we met today, hit it off, started getting together for breakfast every day, found out we had families with kids the same age, started hanging out and vacationing together, and became best friends for 20 years? Then, if someone asked, 'Do you know Pastor Bob Kopeny?' You'd say, 'Of course! He's my best friend; we finish each other's sentences.' What's the difference? Both start with meeting me the same day, but one is just a meeting while the other builds a deep relationship.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to illustrate the difference between simply accepting Christ and developing a deep, ongoing relationship with Him.

illustrations.title: Tozer's Holy Spirit Warning
illustrations.text: Maybe you've heard the name A.W. Tozer; he was influential in the founding of my alma mater, Biola. Tozer once said that if the Holy Spirit was withdrawn from the church today, in his opinion, 95% of what the church is doing would go on and no one would know the difference. However, if the Holy Spirit had been withdrawn from the New Testament church in the book of Acts, 95% of what they did would stop and everybody would know the difference.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the critical role of the Holy Spirit in the church's effectiveness, emphasizing the need to pray for the Spirit's work in believers.

illustrations.title: Spurgeon's Call for Spirit Baptism
illustrations.text: C.H. Spurgeon, the Prince of Preachers, admonished the thousands of his parishioners with these words: Let us not be satisfied with the sip that saves, but let us go on to the baptism which buries the flesh and raises us in the likeness of the risen Lord, even the baptism of the Holy Ghost and onto the fire which makes us spiritual and sets us aflame with the zeal for the glory of God.
illustrations.context: This quote highlights the importance of seeking a deeper experience of the Holy Spirit for spiritual transformation and zeal.

illustrations.title: Cancer Healing Miracle
illustrations.text: Last night, a couple was here and the woman had been diagnosed with cancer. They were preparing for a biopsy to get genetic material for treatment. We prayed for healing, and when they went in, the tumor was completely gone, leaving everyone amazed at God's power.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the power of the Holy Spirit in performing miracles like healing.

illustrations.title: Praying in German for Tests
illustrations.text: I used to pray for the gift of tongues in German during junior high school on test days. I would ask the Lord to help me miraculously, but it never happened that way. Instead, I learned that God's timing and methods are different.
illustrations.context: This shows that the Holy Spirit's gifts don't always manifest as we expect.

illustrations.title: Chuck Smith Tongues Experience
illustrations.text: Mr. Chuck Smith was speaking in tongues and had no idea what he was saying. Someone who knew French listened and confirmed he was speaking perfect French. This is a clear example of the miraculous gifts of the Spirit in action.
illustrations.context: This demonstrates the reality of the gift of tongues as part of the Holy Spirit's power.

illustrations.title: Word of Knowledge in Marriage
illustrations.text: Some of you know my story; I wouldn't be married to Becky if it wasn't for a word of knowledge that God gave me. That miracle directly influenced our relationship. It's a personal testament to how the Holy Spirit works in everyday life.
illustrations.context: This highlights how the Holy Spirit's power can guide personal decisions like marriage.

illustrations.title: Moses and Pharaoh's Patience
illustrations.text: Moses was very patient with Pharaoh, who kept changing his mind about letting the people go, over and over again, and Moses handled it well. Later, when God's people wanted water, Moses struck the rock in anger instead of following God's instructions, and water came forth. As a result, God told Moses he would not enter the Promised Land, showing how much he lost because of his temper.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate the importance of patience and the severe consequences of losing one's temper.

illustrations.title: Alexander's Unconquered Anger
illustrations.text: Alexander the Great, in the fourth century BC, conquered the known world and wept because there were no more worlds to conquer; he was a military genius with totally loyal troops, even ordering them to march off a cliff to demonstrate his authority. One night, while drunk with his men, he argued with his close friend Cleitus, who had saved his life in battle years earlier by cutting down an attacker. In a rage, Alexander threw a spear that killed Cleitus instantly, and he regretted it for the rest of his life, proving that he conquered the world but never his own anger.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that one can achieve great victories in life but still fail to control personal flaws like anger.

illustrations.title: David's Temper Victory
illustrations.text: I think of David. We all know it was a great victory of faith when he conquered Goliath, but there's a greater victory: when David conquered his own temper. Let me tell you the backstory: David had been king for a while when his son Absalom rebelled, stole the hearts of the men of Israel, and declared himself king, forcing David to flee for his life. As David was leaving Jerusalem with a few loyal mighty men, a man named Shimei from Saul's family started throwing rocks at him and cursing him, claiming God was punishing David. David's men wanted to kill Shimei, but David stopped them, saying the Lord might have sent him to curse and that enduring it could bring blessing. They continued on and were refreshed in the next town.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that controlling one's anger is a greater victory than physical battles.

illustrations.title: US Citizenship Analogy
illustrations.text: Every year in our country, six million foreigners apply to be citizens, with an average of that number, and in 2016, for example, 750,000 were qualified to become US citizens. You can become a US citizen in two ways: by being born to Americans, like my wife who was born in Brazil to American missionaries, making her an American from birth. But in God's kingdom, being born to Christians doesn't make you a Christian—that's different. The second way is naturalization, which involves applying and fulfilling the necessary requirements for citizenship. Similarly, God has qualified us to share in the inheritance of the saints in light, so we should be thankful for that.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to explain that just as one must meet requirements for US citizenship, God qualifies believers for His kingdom.

illustrations.title: Senate Hearing Example
illustrations.text: There was a Senate hearing for a position on a budgetary committee, not the chief role but second-in-command. One candidate, Russell Vought, was questioned by Senator Bernie Sanders about a blog he wrote, where he stated that Muslims stand condemned before God because they reject Jesus Christ. Vought confirmed he wrote it and denied being Islamophobic, explaining that he believes God created all men in His image with dignity and that Jesus Christ died for the sins of all. Sanders pressed him, pointing out that this view means two million Muslims in America and a billion worldwide stand condemned for not believing in Jesus. Vought responded by saying he was defending his alma mater, Wheaton College, which upholds the centrality of faith in Jesus Christ for salvation. This illustrates the challenges of standing for biblical truth in public forums.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this example to highlight the real-world controversy and importance of affirming faith in Jesus Christ for salvation.

illustrations.title: Burning Building Analogy
illustrations.text: If you're in a burning building and there's one exit, you don't say there should be two; you take it. You take that one way out because it's your only chance. This illustrates the urgency and gratitude for salvation.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize thankfulness for the one way to salvation rather than demanding more options.

illustrations.title: Thief on the Cross Retelling
illustrations.text: To that thief who didn't deserve another breath because he had killed people, Jesus said, 'Today you'll be with me in paradise.' He didn't do anything to qualify himself; only Jesus Christ can do that. This shows that salvation comes through grace alone.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob highlights that salvation is not earned by personal qualification but through Jesus' finished work.

illustrations.title: God's Pursuit of the Lost
illustrations.text: You came after us like that lost sheep wandering far from the fold of God. You pursued us even when we were far away. You brought us home, just as a shepherd would.
illustrations.context: This analogy emphasizes God's active pursuit and redemption of those who are lost, mirroring His promises and character.

illustrations.title: Survey on Life Desires
illustrations.text: They did a survey of people in the United States asking what they would like to see changed in their life. People mentioned various things, like their looks, career, marriage, or owning a house. Most responses indicated they were waiting for something to change, and this longing is common among many.
illustrations.context: To illustrate that people often long for changes in their lives, reflecting a deeper dissatisfaction.

illustrations.title: President's Kids and Walnuts
illustrations.text: A man asked the president, 'What's wrong with your kids?' The president replied, 'The same thing that's wrong with the rest of the world.' He explained, 'I have two walnuts, and each of them wants both of them. We want something we can't have, and so we cry about it.' This illustrates how human desire often leads to dissatisfaction.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to show that people are never satisfied and always crave more, tying into the theme of discontentment.

illustrations.title: Black Hole in the Soul
illustrations.text: Pastor Bob describes a black hole in your soul that no thing can ever fill. He relates it to things like the grave, a barren womb, earth never satisfied with water, and fire that never says enough from Proverbs. This analogy shows that worldly desires create an endless void. Only something from God can truly satisfy it.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that material things cannot fulfill deep spiritual needs, emphasizing the need for divine satisfaction.

illustrations.title: Woman at the Well
illustrations.text: Jesus told the woman at the well in John 4 that anyone who drinks from this physical well will thirst again. He explained that physical water only satisfies temporarily, but the water he gives will ensure you'll never be thirsty again. This retelling highlights that true satisfaction comes from spiritual sources, not worldly ones.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to convey that only Jesus can provide lasting contentment, unlike temporary physical pleasures.

illustrations.title: Weaned Child Analogy
illustrations.text: The psalmist says, 'Surely I have composed and quieted my soul like a weaned child rests against his mother, my soul is like a weaned child within me.' Every mother of a newborn or nursing baby knows that when that baby wakes up hungry and frantic to eat, but the psalmist means something deeper: I've calmed my soul like a weaned child who isn't seeking just nourishment but simple rest and relationship. This illustrates not coming to the Lord only for what we need, but for a deeper connection beyond emergencies.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that true contentment means relating to God for who He is, not just for what He provides.

illustrations.title: Noah's Dove Retelling
illustrations.text: Noah is trying to find a place to land the ark, unsure if there's dry land, so he sends out birds for reconnaissance. The dove he sends out finds no resting place for the sole of her foot because the water covers everything, so she returns to him into the ark. Noah puts out his hand, takes her, and brings her back to himself. Matthew Henry comments that this pictures man, like the dove sent out searching but finding no rest, ultimately returning to the one who sent it.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate that we must return to God for true rest when the world offers none.

illustrations.title: Augustine's Rest Quote
illustrations.text: Augustine says we have no rest until we find our rest in the Lord, and this paints a perfect picture of how God wants us to discover a rest we've never known. It's about returning to the one who sent us. So, in this life, we run around seeking peace but find it only in God.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that true rest is found only in God, not in worldly pursuits.

illustrations.title: Hearse Without U-Haul
illustrations.text: I've never done a lot of funerals, but I've never seen a hearse pull up with a U-Haul. This illustrates that we bring nothing into the world and take nothing out. It's a simple reminder of our empty-handed arrival and departure from life.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that material possessions don't last beyond death, urging focus on eternal things.

illustrations.title: Spanish Proverb on Shrouds
illustrations.text: The Spanish have a proverb that there's no pockets in burial shrouds, meaning we can't take our belongings with us when we die. This ties into the idea that we enter the world empty-handed and leave the same way. Pastor Bob connects it to living with the end in view.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this proverb to reinforce that earthly wealth is temporary and we should seek eternal contentment.

illustrations.title: Job's Loss and Faith
illustrations.text: In Job chapter 1 verse 21, on the worst day of his life when he lost everything—his wealth and children—Job said, 'Naked I came from my mother's womb and naked I shall return; the Lord gave and the Lord has taken away, but I will still bless the name of the Lord.' This shows Job's unwavering faith despite immense loss. Pastor Bob uses it to illustrate maintaining trust in God amid trials.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob retells this to demonstrate that true contentment comes from blessing God regardless of life's losses.

illustrations.title: Money Booth Experience
illustrations.text: About 20 years ago, I was at a local mall with my children during a store's grand opening, and they had this setup that looked like a phone booth, called a money booth. Inside, air blew money around, and people could grab as much as they could in a short time, but it was hard to catch and made them look foolish chasing it. I use this to show how futile it is to pursue temporary riches, just like grabbing at floating money.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob shares this personal story to illustrate that chasing after worldly wealth is ultimately pointless and unfulfilling.

illustrations.title: Lot's Wife Warning
illustrations.text: Jesus used three words to warn us about getting too attached to things: 'Remember Lot's wife.' Sodom and Gomorrah were about to be destroyed by fire, and Lot and his family were being led out. But Lot's wife turned back, showing she was still clinging in her heart to the things God was going to destroy.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate the danger of being too attached to material possessions that God intends to destroy.

illustrations.title: Titanic Woman's Survival Choice
illustrations.text: A true story from the sinking of the Titanic involves a wealthy woman who boarded a lifeboat but ran back to her cabin despite the urgency. She ignored her expensive furs and jewelry, instead grabbing three small oranges for survival. This happened because the presence of death completely changed her perspective, making basic needs more important than material wealth.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show how facing imminent death shifts one's value system away from possessions toward survival.

illustrations.title: Monopoly Money Analogy
illustrations.text: Imagine we get together for a game night at the church, like we did at New Year's, and play Monopoly. You're good at it, buying everything in sight and wiping us all out with all that money. But if we saw you around town flashing your Monopoly money, you'd look like a fool because it's worthless; it's just pretend, like a test. Jesus said that if you're not faithful with earthly wealth, God won't give you true eternal riches, because that's the real stuff.
illustrations.context: This analogy shows that earthly wealth is like pretend Monopoly money compared to eternal riches, emphasizing the need to be faithful with what we have.

illustrations.title: Spoiled by Luxuries Quote
illustrations.text: Someone has said that we aren't satisfied with necessities because we're so spoiled with luxuries. That's true, and it's a symptom of being spoiled, as seen in how our need lists have grown too long. For example, we might say we need the latest iPhone or worry about where to eat, rather than being content with basics like food and clothing.
illustrations.context: This quote illustrates why people are not content with necessities and have overly long need lists, pointing to the need for revising our desires.

illustrations.title: Hunger Changes Desires
illustrations.text: You ever gone without food for a while, maybe on a diet where you stop eating meat or carbs? It's funny how when you're really hungry, things that used to seem worthless look delicious, like a simple cracker appearing as a filet mignon. That's because you've spoiled your appetite with excess, and the same thing happens with what we've been given—we don't appreciate the basics anymore.
illustrations.context: This analogy shows how excess, like affluenza, makes people overlook the value of simple things.

illustrations.title: Epidemic of Affluenza
illustrations.text: Somebody said our problem in our nation is not an epidemic of influenza but an epidemic of affluenza, which convinces people that money and material things will make them happy. I live in Yorba Linda, where the sign says welcome to the land of gracious living, but it should say it's a place where your kids will never afford to buy a house. This sickness masks our true needs and leads to dissatisfaction.
illustrations.context: This quote illustrates how affluenza promotes materialism and hides the real need for spiritual fulfillment.

illustrations.title: Rich Young Ruler's Choice
illustrations.text: We think of the rich young ruler who wanted to follow Jesus but went away sorrowful when Jesus told him to sell his possessions, give to the poor, and come follow Him, because his money had become like a god to him. This story shows how attachment to wealth can block true commitment. It's a clear example of how affluenza ruins one's spiritual path.
illustrations.context: This retelling demonstrates how love of money can prevent someone from fully committing to Christ.

illustrations.title: Wealth's Hidden Toll
illustrations.text: Studies reveal that children raised in wealth show many symptoms similar to those raised in abject poverty, including depression, anxiety, despair, and even suicide attempts, often leading them to alcohol and drugs. One article I read was entitled 'Don't Envy the Super-Rich; They're Miserable,' highlighting the emptiness of material pursuit. This reveals that chasing more doesn't bring joy but instead fosters discontent.
illustrations.context: This example illustrates the negative effects of affluenza on mental and emotional well-being.

illustrations.title: Junk Yard Treasures
illustrations.text: Your family meanders through and stops to look at all the piles of treasure that were formerly Christmas and birthday presents. You see things that once cost hundreds of dollars, things that children quarreled over, things that caused friendships to be lost, honesty to be sacrificed, and even marriages to break up. It's a startling picture of how what the world values will one day end up in the junk yard.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to show that worldly possessions and values are temporary and ultimately worthless, emphasizing the need for contentment.

illustrations.title: What Money Can't Buy
illustrations.text: We've all heard that money can buy a house but cannot buy a home, can buy a bed but can't buy rest, can buy a clock but can't buy more time, and can buy medicine but cannot buy health. For example, Steve Jobs was 56 when he died of pancreatic cancer, and his ten billion dollars couldn't save him. Money can buy connections but will never buy love or respect.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates that while money has its uses, it fails to provide true fulfillment or security, highlighting the dangers of valuing it too highly.

illustrations.title: Author's Satirical Quote
illustrations.text: This author said that money is in everything and often causes pain and suffering, then added, 'I tell you all this because I am your friend and as your friend I want to take away your pain, so send me all your money and I'll suffer for you.' It's a humorous way to point out how money can lead to exploitation and misery.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to warn about the deceptive nature of money and how it can cause pain, connecting it to the greater test of prosperity over adversity.

illustrations.title: Happiness Through Relationships
illustrations.text: Studies I read, not even written by Christians, show that happiness measures from surveys of thousands of people across different cultures always come down to relationships as the key factor. The bottom line is that happiness is tied to relationships, whether with God or family.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this real-world example to support that true happiness comes from relationships, not material wealth, tying it to faith and family blessings.

illustrations.title: Evacuation During Fires
