illustrations.text: During the fires we had several years ago in 2008, some of us had to evacuate, and it was such an interesting thing that highlighted what truly matters. It showed how family and relationships become the real blessing when everything else is at risk.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob shares this real-world example to illustrate that happiness and blessings are found in family and faith, especially in times of crisis.

illustrations.title: Fire Loss and Priorities
illustrations.text: When our home was affected, they told us to take whatever we need. I said I just need my wife and kids; that's it. If I have them, burn the rest—it's okay. The real valuable things are your faith, your relationship with God, your family, and your friends—these are the eternal values.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to illustrate that true contentment comes from relationships and faith, not material possessions.

illustrations.title: Baja Locals' Complaint
illustrations.text: True story: There was a tour in Baja, Mexico, where the locals washed their clothes using natural hot and cold springs. A tourist remarked that they must be thankful for the water, but the guide said they just complain about not having soap. This shows our nature to focus on what we lack rather than what we have.
illustrations.context: This real-world example demonstrates that contentment is not automatic, as people often complain about missing things despite having basics.

illustrations.title: Paul's Secret to Contentment
illustrations.text: Paul says in Philippians 4:11-13, 'Not that I speak from want, for I have learned to be content in whatever circumstances I am. I know how to get along with humble means and live in prosperity. I can do all things through Christ who strengthens me.' Pastor Bob explains that this reveals contentment as a learned secret through faith in Christ.
illustrations.context: This quote illustrates that contentment is a skill that must be learned, empowered by Christ, regardless of circumstances.

illustrations.title: Farmer's Farm Regret
illustrations.text: There was a man who had a farm and had been raising crops for some time, with his family owning it for a long time. He grew tired of living out in the middle of nowhere, so he decided to sell it and called a realtor. The realtor asked him to write down all the best parts about the farm for the advertisement. When the realtor read the description back to him, the man realized it was exactly the place he'd been looking for his whole life and decided not to sell. This story shows that we often don't need more or different things; we just need a different perspective on what we already have.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate that contentment comes from appreciating what you already have, rather than seeking more.

illustrations.title: Childhood Christmas Overabundance
illustrations.text: I'm the youngest of five, and as Christmas approached, we bought presents for each other—my brother, three sisters, mom, and me. Our small house's living room would fill up with presents under the tree, making it seem like two-thirds of the room was packed. As a little boy, I'd dive through them, excited to find which ones were mine, and it was always overwhelming to see all those gifts.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that as believers, we should feel overwhelmed by God's blessings, like a room full of presents with our name on them.

illustrations.title: Jacob's Return and Gratitude
illustrations.text: Jacob said as he crossed the river the second time, remembering when he crossed it first with just his staff, now he had wives, children, flocks, and wealth. He looked back and declared to God that he wasn't worthy of the least of His mercies, amazed at what God had given him. This retelling shows Jacob's perspective of being blown away by God's provision.
illustrations.context: This highlights the idea of recognizing and being thankful for God's overflowing blessings in our lives.

illustrations.title: Israel's Promised Land Gifts
illustrations.text: Remember, the children of Israel came out of Egypt and were brought into Canaan 40 years later, where God gave them houses they didn't build and vineyards they didn't plant. He blessed them abundantly, spoiling them with His gifts. But God warned them to take heed not to forget Him amidst these blessings.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that prosperity and blessings from God are not sinful, but one must be careful not to forget God in the midst of them.

illustrations.title: Guilty Rich Christians Example
illustrations.text: I always feel bad for these rich Christians I meet sometimes who feel so guilty about having a boat. It's like, can I go? Yeah, what's your problem? Well, I just feel funny about it, but people that don't care for this, something's wrong there. The Lord has blessed you with it, so use it for His glory and enjoy it.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that Christians should enjoy God's blessings without guilt.

illustrations.title: Forensic Files Crime Example
illustrations.text: Love of money leads people many times to steal money or to compromise their integrity, and it can even lead to murder. How many of these shows like Forensic Files that we all watch show it's usually either a relationship or follow the money? We're probably seeing the person who wants to be rich.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is showing how the love of money roots various evils, like crime and murder.

illustrations.title: Millionaire Shows and Lotteries
illustrations.text: Doesn't that almost describe everybody who wants to be a millionaire? That show would not exist if people didn't want to be rich. You know how much money is spent on lottery tickets every year, especially on sports. This highlights a common desire for wealth.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is pointing out that many people crave riches, which ties into the dangers of loving money.

illustrations.title: Tevye's Rich Man Fantasy
illustrations.text: Pastor Bob references a classic scene from Fiddler on the Roof where Tevye, a poor Jewish man, prays to God about being poor and imagines what life would be like if he were rich. He quotes Tevye saying that if he were rich, important men in town would seek his advice like they did with Solomon, and it wouldn't matter if his answers were right or wrong because people assume the rich are wise. Tevye also mentions he would have more time to pray, reasoning with God about why he should be wealthy. This illustrates the common human desire for riches and the misconceptions that come with it.
illustrations.context: To show how people often fantasize about wealth and believe it brings wisdom and status.

illustrations.title: Richness Like Aging
illustrations.text: Pastor Bob uses an analogy comparing being rich to being old, explaining that just as you always think of someone else as old because old people are older than you, richness is relative since there's always someone richer. He points out that this mindset makes it hard for people to recognize their own wealth. This extended comparison highlights how perceptions of wealth are subjective and comparative. Ultimately, it challenges listeners to reevaluate their own status.
illustrations.context: To emphasize that wealth is relative and people often fail to see their own riches.

illustrations.title: Wealth in Haiti and Cuba
illustrations.text: Pastor Bob gives a real-world example by inviting listeners to visit Haiti or Cuba, where people live in extreme poverty and would consider anyone in the room rich, even if they're between jobs or don't own a home. He explains that in those places, having a car or motorcycle is a distant dream, and basic necessities like food are not guaranteed. This example contrasts American lifestyles with global realities to show how skewed our value systems can be. It urges self-reflection on true wealth.
illustrations.context: To demonstrate that Americans are rich by global standards and need to adjust their perceptions of wealth.

illustrations.title: Salt Water Thirst Analogy
illustrations.text: It's like trying to quench your thirst with salt water. The more you drink, the thirstier you get. And the more money you get, typically the more money you want.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that pursuing money leads to greater dissatisfaction rather than fulfillment.

illustrations.title: Ant's Preparation Lesson
illustrations.text: Go to the ant, you sluggard, talking about the lazy guy who won't work. Hey, go to the ant that stores up during the summer for the winter. That's the way God's made them.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is showing that saving for the future is wise and aligns with God's design, as seen in the Proverbs example.

illustrations.title: Joseph's Famine Wisdom
illustrations.text: Joseph's wisdom from God was that during the good years, you better save for the years ahead because they're not going to be so good. This highlights the importance of preparation. Nothing sinful about saving that way.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is using Joseph's story to demonstrate that planning and saving for the future is not only acceptable but honorable.

illustrations.title: Wealthy Man Seeks Rabbi
illustrations.text: There was a very wealthy man who went to visit a well-known Jewish rabbi because he was depressed despite his wealth. The rabbi, who lived simply, asked the man to look out the window and describe what he saw, which was people enjoying themselves in the park. Then, the rabbi had him look in the mirror and notice that he only saw himself, explaining that adding silver to glass, like amassing money, makes one self-focused.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how wealth naturally draws attention to oneself and can lead to misery.

illustrations.title: Civil War Spy Story
illustrations.text: During the Civil War, the Confederates had spies just like the Union did, and one of them was a woman named Rose Greenhow who passed on information. This example ties into how success or involvement in such activities can lead to ruin due to harmful desires. It's presented as a historical instance of the dangers of ambition and espionage.
illustrations.context: This shows how pursuing success, like in spying, can plunge people into ruin and destruction.

illustrations.title: Spy Drowns with Gold
illustrations.text: There was a woman who was a spy during the war, passing information to foreign nations. She was on a boat chased by the Union Navy, and in bad weather, her boat ran aground and sank. She had sewn gold into her garment's seams from payments for her espionage, and the weight of the gold caused her to drown.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that money can lead to one's downfall, just as Paul describes drowning in greed.

illustrations.title: Woman Drinks Liquor at Airport
illustrations.text: A few years ago, a woman in Shanghai was getting on a plane and went through security with expensive cognac that exceeded the limit. When told she couldn't take it, she drank the entire bottle on the spot. Half an hour later, she was on the floor, too drunk to board the plane, showing how holding onto things can lead to self-destruction.
illustrations.context: This example demonstrates that clinging to material things God wants us to release can bring destructive consequences in life.

illustrations.title: Corrie ten Boom on Money
illustrations.text: Corrie ten Boom once said that whenever she gets money, she holds it lightly in her grasp so God doesn't have to hurt her by prying it out of her fingers. This quote emphasizes the importance of not gripping possessions too tightly. Pastor Bob uses it to connect with the idea of avoiding the pain that comes from material attachment.
illustrations.context: The quote highlights the need to hold money lightly to prevent God from forcibly taking it, avoiding personal harm.

illustrations.title: Regrets of the Dying
illustrations.text: I have had the opportunity to sit with many people as they were dying and talk to them about their lives. Some had a lot of regrets, even if they were Christians. I've never had a man say he wished he had spent more time at the office or made more money. Instead, many told me they wished they had spent more time with their family, wives, kids, or grandkids. It's a painful regret that highlights the emptiness of greed.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that loving money leads to regrets, emphasizing the importance of prioritizing relationships over wealth.

illustrations.title: Man Seeking Inheritance
illustrations.text: Greed can hide behind a sense of justice, like that man who came to Jesus and said, 'Lord, tell my brother to divide the inheritance with me.' That seems reasonable, but Jesus replied, 'Who made me a judge or an arbiter over you?' and warned, 'Beware of covetousness.' This illustrates how pursuing money can stem from hidden greed, even in matters of justice.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to caution against covetousness and the dangers of letting greed drive actions like lawsuits.

illustrations.title: John's Advice to Soldiers
illustrations.text: I think of what John the Baptist said to the soldiers who were getting baptized; they asked what they should do, and he told them to be content with their wages. This advice is a good starting point for fighting greed. John connects contentment to avoiding the pitfalls of loving money, urging people to be thankful for what they have.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that being content with wages is key to overcoming greed and living right.

illustrations.title: Content with Cop Wages
illustrations.text: When I became a cop at my first department, they were taking a strike vote a week after I joined. They wanted better wages, and I suppose they deserved it, but I was just so blessed to be getting so much more money than my prior job. It was really hard for me to complain; I had a big smile on my face just to show up to work. Be content with your wages.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate the importance of being content with what you have.

illustrations.title: Desiring Nothing on Earth
illustrations.text: The last verse of Psalm 73:25 says, 'Whom have I in heaven but You? And besides You, I desire nothing on earth.' Did you hear that? I don't need anything else. Isn't that the testimony you want, showing complete satisfaction in God?
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize finding full satisfaction in Christ alone.

illustrations.title: Holding Adopted Daughter
illustrations.text: I was holding my newborn baby daughter, who was plucked out of a crack house, and I got a notification on my phone. I thought about how she could have been just another statistic, but now she's my daughter. God turns what was lost and broken into something beautiful, giving us moments of profound grace. This personal experience reminds us that God is actively working in our lives.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate how God redeems and transforms lives, turning potential tragedies into testimonies of His goodness.

illustrations.title: Shadrach Meshach and Abednego in Fire
illustrations.text: Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego went willingly into the fire because they refused to bow down to the things of this world. It wasn't an accidental trial; they chose faithfulness despite the threat. They stood firm in their conviction, knowing God would be with them, and indeed, another was in the fire standing with them. This story shows that enduring hardship for God's truth brings His presence and protection.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize that the church must not bow to worldly pressures, as God remains with His people in trials.

illustrations.title: Supreme Court Prayer Endurance
illustrations.text: I am super encouraged for all of you who have prayed for years asking God to end this in our nation, to bring some relief, and to turn things around, yet didn't see any results for almost 50 years. Now, we are grateful for this turn of events with the Supreme Court's decision. We know this isn't the end of the battle or the spiritual warfare, but it is encouraging, and we give God the glory for any move in the right direction.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that persisting in doing good and praying faithfully will eventually yield results, as echoed in the Bible verse about not losing heart.

illustrations.title: Kingdom as Banquet Analogy
illustrations.text: The kingdom of God is pictured in the Bible as a banquet but never as a picnic. This means we should realize there are going to be difficult times ahead. So, we need to prepare ourselves for challenges as we live in God's kingdom.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to emphasize that following God involves enduring hardships rather than expecting an easy life.

illustrations.title: Accused Falsely Experience
illustrations.text: I don't know if you've ever been accused falsely. I have been in a lawsuit where someone claimed I did something I did not do. It's very difficult to keep your mouth shut in that moment, as it's natural to want to defend yourself.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob shares this personal story to illustrate the challenge of patiently enduring wrongful accusation, just as Jesus did.

illustrations.title: Dentist Pain Analogy
illustrations.text: It's like that dentist who says, 'Oh, there's going to be a slight pinch.' Yeah, it's like a horse kicking you. It's not slight at all, but anyway, as long as there's purpose in the pain, I can handle that.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to explain the difference between hurting and injuring, emphasizing that pain with purpose is acceptable.

illustrations.title: Police Officer Ticket Story
illustrations.text: I remember many years ago when I was still a police officer in the city of Placentia and we were at Calvary Chapel of Placentia. I announced the next week I was going to be doing a message on how to avoid getting tickets. People thought I was going to share tricks like where we hide with radar or which stop signs we watch, but I disappointed them by teaching from Romans 13 instead. I said if you want to avoid tickets, just don't speed, don't roll through stop signs, and use your signals properly. By the way, I'll give you this word of advice: if you realize you're being followed by a police officer and know you've messed up, just pull over and say, 'I deserve it.'
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate the principle that doing good, like obeying laws, helps avoid harm or consequences.

illustrations.title: Admitting Fault to Cop
illustrations.text: If you say 'I deserve it' when a cop pulls you over, it's not a trick, but it might get you out of a ticket because officers can decide if you're the right person to ticket. If you argue or question them, you're just digging a deeper hole, so it's wiser to keep quiet or admit fault. This approach makes you the exception where they might give a warning instead.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that accepting responsibility can lead to better outcomes and reduce stress in conflicts.

illustrations.title: Jesus on Popularity
illustrations.text: Jesus said in Luke 6:26, 'Woe to you when all men speak well of you, for in the same way their fathers used to treat the false prophets.' He warns that if everything is going positively for you, it may indicate something is compromised in your life. This quote highlights the danger of seeking universal approval.
illustrations.context: This quote emphasizes that suffering for righteousness is a blessing, as being universally praised might mean you've compromised your faith.

illustrations.title: John Wesley's Reflection
illustrations.text: John Wesley, who began the Methodist Church and preached conversion theology, was kicked out of the Anglican Church for insisting people needed to be born again and saved. He preached on the streets, leading hundreds of thousands to faith, and the Methodist Church was originally biblical in doctrine. One day, while riding along a road, it dawned on him that three whole days had passed without any apparent hardship or opposition.
illustrations.context: This story shows that a lack of opposition might indicate compromise, aligning with the idea that suffering for righteousness is a rare blessing.

illustrations.title: John Wesley's Persecution Story
illustrations.text: John Wesley was severely persecuted by the church and unbelievers, but for three whole days, no brick or egg was thrown at him. Alarmed, he stopped his horse and exclaimed that he might have sinned and backslidden. He slipped off his horse, knelt down, and began praying to ask God if there was fault in his life. A man nearby heard him, recognized him as that Methodist preacher, picked up a brick, and threw it at him, but it missed and fell harmlessly beside John. Upon noticing, John leapt to his feet, joyfully exclaiming, 'Thank God, it's all right; I still have His presence.'
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that the absence of persecution might make one question their faith, but true faith endures opposition as a sign of God's presence.

illustrations.title: Church as Advancing Army
illustrations.text: Remember what Jesus said: upon this rock I will build my church and the gates of Hades will not prevail against her. Now think about it; that pictures the church as an army marching on the gates of death. This means the world around us is spiritually dead, and there's a battle to be fought for men's and women's souls.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to emphasize that the church is actively fighting in a spiritual battle against spiritual death and for souls.

illustrations.title: Hell's Post Office Quote
illustrations.text: Someone said it this way: If hell has a post office, don't you want your picture on the wall as a believer? I hope so. That's something from the last millennium, probably, but the idea is to be actively engaged in faith.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to encourage believers to be actively involved in spiritual battles, making them worth Satan's attention.

illustrations.title: MRI Claustrophobia Story
illustrations.text: For years, I told myself I wasn't claustrophobic, but then I got an MRI and it detected I was lying. It's a real phobia, like the word phobos in the Bible. Maybe you have some kind of fear too, but the Lord says not to react with irrational fear when facing intimidation.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob shares this to show that irrational fears can be overcome with God's help, as commanded in Scripture.

illustrations.title: Oswald Chambers on Fearing God
illustrations.text: Oswald Chambers said, 'The remarkable thing about God is that when you fear God, you fear nothing else.' So, if I'm fearing something else, whereas if you do not fear God, you'll fear everything else. This means that true reverence for God eliminates all other fears.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that fearing God is the key to overcoming fear of circumstances.

illustrations.title: The Three R's of Rejoicing
illustrations.text: I've often said that there are three reasons to rejoice every day for believers: He is risen, He's ruling right now, and He's returning. These deal with the problems I face; His resurrection addresses my past sins, His ruling brings peace in the present, and His return offers hope for the future. You see, those three R's help us recognize Christ's control over our circumstances.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to illustrate how focusing on Christ's resurrection, rule, and return helps believers overcome fear and find peace.

illustrations.title: Young Man Seeks Hope
illustrations.text: People can see hope in us, otherwise they wouldn't ask about it. For example, a young man in our church came to me last week on Sunday morning or Wednesday night. This shows that our hope is evident and draws questions from others.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that people notice the hope in Christians and inquire about it during challenging circumstances.

illustrations.title: Peace Amid Cancer Diagnosis
illustrations.text: I hadn't seen him in a while, and he shared that he had been diagnosed with cancer and had been fighting it. He went through a rough time and wasn't sure what would happen when they wheeled him in for surgery. Suddenly, he felt the Lord's presence and an incredible peace that he couldn't explain, which made others ask how he was managing.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that believers can experience the peace of God that others don't understand, providing an opportunity to share their hope.

illustrations.title: Hope Like an Anchor
illustrations.text: The Bible describes hope as an anchor in the book of Hebrews. An anchor works under the surface; you don't see it, but it produces results on the ship. So, our hope is unseen by others yet effective in our lives, giving us a chance to explain it.
illustrations.context: This analogy shows that hope is an unseen but powerful force that stabilizes believers, allowing them to share its source with others.

illustrations.title: Paul and Silas in Macedonia
illustrations.text: Remember, Paul and Silas were called on a missionary journey to Macedonia. They went to Philippi, shared the gospel, and encountered a slave girl with a demon, whom Paul cast out. This led to their arrest on false charges because her owners lost their profit, turning the situation into an opportunity for testimony.
illustrations.context: This retelling demonstrates that persecution can create unexpected opportunities for sharing the gospel.

illustrations.title: Paul and Silas in Prison
illustrations.text: Paul and Silas were beaten and thrown into prison, where they were put in stocks, a form of torture that stretched their feet after beating them bloody. About midnight, they were praying and singing hymns to God, and the prisoners were listening to them. This demonstrated how their praise in hardship caught the attention of others, leading to an opportunity for sharing the gospel.
illustrations.context: To illustrate how praising God in difficult circumstances can lead unbelievers to seek salvation.

illustrations.title: Son and Santa Claus Encounter
illustrations.text: I can remember it like it was yesterday when my son was about five years old, right before Christmas, and we were in the store checking out. A big, jovial man behind us asked my son if he was ready for Christmas and what Santa Claus was going to bring him. We had taught our children that Christmas is about Jesus being born, not Santa Claus, so my son looked unsure and glanced at me for guidance before responding.
illustrations.context: To show the importance of standing firm in teaching children about true faith when faced with external influences.

illustrations.title: Son's Dick Tracy Belief
illustrations.text: A man asked me what I believe in, and my son looked up and said, 'I believe in Dick Tracy.' This drew laughter and made me scratch my head, realizing we need to work on explaining faith better. It shows how unexpected moments can highlight opportunities for teaching.
illustrations.context: This personal story illustrates how everyday circumstances can create opportunities for discussing and sharing faith.

illustrations.title: Hard to Argue with Experience
illustrations.text: It's an old expression that it's hard to argue with experience. When you share what happened to you, people may think you're deceived or that it's not for them, but they're not likely to argue against your personal story. This makes sharing your testimony a great starting point for evangelism.
illustrations.context: This quote emphasizes that personal experiences are effective for sharing faith because they are difficult for others to dispute.

illustrations.title: Paul's Defense Before Festus
illustrations.text: While Paul was defending himself, Festus interrupted in a loud voice, saying Paul was out of his mind due to his great learning. Paul replied that he was speaking words of sober truth, especially to the king who knew about these matters. He emphasized that the resurrection of Jesus wasn't done in secret and asked King Agrippa if he believed the prophets, knowing Agrippa did, and Agrippa responded that Paul almost persuaded him to become a Christian.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show how Paul effectively combined history and prophecy when sharing his faith.

illustrations.title: Josephus on Jesus' Historicity
illustrations.text: Pastor Bob suggests steering people to read what Josephus, a first-century Jewish historian who was not a Christian, wrote in his work 'The Antiquities of the Jews,' where he describes Jesus as being followed as the Messiah and mentions accounts of his rising from the dead. He also references other historians like Suetonius and Tacitus, who wrote about Jesus as a real historical figure. This highlights how non-Christian sources confirm Jesus' existence and events of his life.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that Jesus is a verified figure from history, strengthening the credibility of Christian testimony.

illustrations.title: Peter Stoner's Prophecy Calculation
illustrations.text: In the 20th century, there was a class at Pasadena City College taught by Professor Peter Stoner, a mathematician who wrote the book Science Speaks and taught at several universities. They conducted a semester project to conservatively estimate the chances of someone fulfilling the messianic prophecies throughout history. For example, to claim to be the Messiah, one had to be born in the right city, like Bethlehem as Micah 5:2 states, and from the right tribe, making the odds extremely low. They calculated that about 1 in 280,000 people were born in Bethlehem during that time, showing how improbable it is for anyone to meet these criteria by chance.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize the reliability of biblical prophecies about Jesus, arguing that their fulfillment is not coincidental but evidence of divine truth.

illustrations.title: Compound Probability Analogy
illustrations.text: Compound probability works like this: If one in ten people are left-handed, then lining up ten people on average will find one left-handed person. If one in ten people are colorblind, lining up ten people might find one colorblind person. But to find someone who is both colorblind and left-handed, you have to line up 100 people. This shows how probabilities multiply when combining events.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to explain how compound probability makes it extremely unlikely for someone to fulfill multiple prophecies by chance.

illustrations.title: Silver Dollars Probability
illustrations.text: To illustrate the odds, imagine you had 10 to the 17th power silver dollars, enough to cover the landmass of Texas two feet deep. Mark one silver dollar, blindfold a cowboy, and let him wander through the state to pick one at random. The chances of him picking the marked one are the same as someone accidentally fulfilling eight prophecies. This highlights the astronomical improbability involved.
illustrations.context: This analogy demonstrates the near-impossibility of fulfilling multiple biblical prophecies by random chance, supporting the uniqueness of Jesus as the Messiah.

illustrations.title: Silver Dollars Probability
illustrations.text: Make a ball of silver dollars the distance between the Earth and the Sun times 30, which would reach out to the orbit of Neptune. That's how many silver dollars you have if you have 10 to the 45th power. Now, mark one of those silver dollars, get Luke Skywalker with a blindfold on, and have him reach out with the Millennium Falcon to pick one—the chance of him picking the right one by chance is the same as someone fulfilling just 16 of the prophecies that Jesus fulfilled.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to illustrate the extreme improbability of Jesus fulfilling prophecies by chance.

illustrations.title: Electron Size Analogy
illustrations.text: An electron is 2.5 quadrillionths of an inch, and if you laid them end to end at 250 a minute, it would take 19 million years to get one inch. Making a solid cube of them would take 19 million years times 19 million years times 19 million years—they're incredibly small. Now, imagine making a giant ball of electrons the size of our observable universe, and even after making more for four billion years at 100 a minute, you'd still have 10 to the 32nd power left over, and mark one of those for the 48 prophecies Jesus fulfilled.
illustrations.context: This analogy emphasizes the astronomical scale of improbability for Jesus fulfilling multiple prophecies.

illustrations.title: Peter Stoner Quote
illustrations.text: Peter Stoner says in his book, 'To the extent then that we know this blindfolded man cannot pick the marked electron, to that extent we know that Christ could not have fulfilled the prophecies by chance.' This quote connects to the idea of vast improbabilities in prophecy fulfillment. Pastor Bob uses it to reinforce the point about Jesus' life not being accidental.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob employs this quote to underscore that the fulfillment of prophecies by Jesus was not by chance but divinely orchestrated.

illustrations.title: Stoner's Quote on Faith
illustrations.text: Professor Stoner made this comment: 'Any man who rejects Christ as the Son of God is rejecting a fact proved perhaps more absolutely than any other fact in the world.' I say to that, amen. This highlights the overwhelming evidence for the Bible's inspiration.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to encourage believers not to fear facts when sharing their faith.

illustrations.title: Zacharias' Unbelief Story
illustrations.text: Remember, Zacharias, the father of John the Baptist, didn't believe he was going to be part of God's plan and that his wife was going to get pregnant. As a result of his unbelief, he couldn't talk. This shows how unbelief can close your mouth when it needs to be open.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates that unbelief or fear of man hinders sharing faith.

illustrations.title: Conscience as a Dirty Window
illustrations.text: The conscience has been described as like a window to your soul, but it can get dirty. It's your perception of things both inwardly and outwardly, and your own judgment about what you think, feel, and do. This window can become defiled by your behavior and the choices you make.
illustrations.context: This analogy illustrates how the conscience can become clouded and distorted by sin and poor choices.

illustrations.title: Man's Guilt After Murder
illustrations.text: True story: Over in Chester, England, there was a man who killed his wife, buried her body in a nearby peat bog, and got away with it for years. Nobody knew what happened to his wife, and 22 years went by until he read about peat diggers unearthing a skull in his area. He immediately drove to the police department, confessed to everything, only to find out the skull was from ancient Roman times. See, he could cover his crime, but he couldn't silence his conscience.
illustrations.context: This story demonstrates that a person's conscience will eventually compel them to confront their wrongdoing, no matter how long they try to hide it.

illustrations.title: Peter and John Healed Man
illustrations.text: Peter and John healed a lame man on their way into the temple, and he went leaping and praising God with them. They got arrested for preaching Jesus and healing in His name, so they were on trial. Peter boldly declared that the man was healed by the name of Jesus Christ, whom they crucified but God raised from the dead, and by that name, the man stood before them in good health.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the importance of living with a clean conscience, as Peter and John faced persecution but stood firm in their actions.

illustrations.title: Spurgeon's Blackmail Defiance
illustrations.text: Charles Haddon Spurgeon, the Prince of Preachers, late in his ministry, had some evil men approach him and demand money, threatening to write all they knew about him in the papers. He responded by telling them to write all they know about me across the heavens, as he had absolutely nothing to conceal. This story highlights the freedom that comes from a life of integrity.
illustrations.context: This shows the power of a clean conscience, allowing one to face accusations without fear.

illustrations.title: Mark Twain's Telegram Joke
illustrations.text: Mark Twain once said that he sent a dozen of his friends a telegram saying, 'Flee at once, all is discovered.' They all left town immediately, revealing their own guilty consciences. This quote connects to the idea that people with unclean consciences react quickly to perceived exposure.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how a lack of a clean conscience makes people vulnerable and quick to flee from truth.

illustrations.title: Reagan's Prophetic Quote
illustrations.text: Ronald Reagan wrote a book called 'Abortion and the Conscience of the Nation' in 1983, where he said it is possible that the Supreme Court itself may overturn its abortion rulings. He drew a parallel to Brown v. Board of Education, where the court reversed its own earlier decision, and believed that if the court reconsidered the real issue between the sanctity of life ethic and the quality of life ethic, it would change its mind once again. Reagan described the Roe v. Wade decision as an act of raw judicial power that has not settled the debate but instead prods the nation's conscience.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to show that Supreme Court decisions can be reversed, emphasizing the ongoing moral debate over abortion and the potential for change.

illustrations.title: Friend's Social Media Attack
illustrations.text: I have a friend who called me, thrilled with a decision they made, but immediately faced attacks on Facebook with people saying it was sick and evil. I advised them to be very careful in how they respond, warning that reacting in kind is what the attackers expect and what Satan wants. Instead, let the Lord be your defense and share your views with reverence and meekness.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize responding to criticism with care and not escalating conflicts online.

illustrations.title: House Painting Analogy
illustrations.text: It's kind of like this: if somebody wants to paint their house some weird color, that's their choice, but they have no right to come over to my house and paint it that color. Similarly, someone can put a sign in their front yard about who they support politically, but they don't have the right to tear one out of my yard. They are welcome to say whatever they want on their own Facebook page, not on mine.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates that people should respect personal boundaries and express their views without imposing on others.

illustrations.title: Holding Newborn During News
illustrations.text: So, two things occurred to me when I received the news. It was a kind of poetic moment because I was holding my newborn baby. I know every time I say that, the women go 'oh,' and so do I. So, I'm holding my newborn baby who was literally plucked.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to illustrate how God brings gratitude and meaning in the midst of overwhelming circumstances.

illustrations.title: Daughter's Redemption Story
illustrations.text: Then I got news on my phone that Roe v. Wade was overturned, and it was a very poetic moment. I thought, she could have easily been a statistic, but instead she's my daughter. I get a little emotional—I even cried during a Geico commercial—so everything makes me cry now, but that's our story. We were lost in the darkness, but God plucked us out, made us His children, and redeemed us.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to illustrate how God redeems and saves individuals from difficult circumstances.

illustrations.title: Shadrach Meshach and Abednego Retelling
illustrations.text: Sometimes the actions of being a Christian and living a righteous life put us into fiery situations, and that was true for Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego. They said they would not bow to this world, so they were thrown into the fire, but then Christ was with them. We see this playing out beautifully in the church today as we refuse to bow down to the things of this world.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob retells this story to show that God is present with believers during trials and that standing firm in faith leads to His protection.

illustrations.title: Dr. Sackett as Tour Guide
illustrations.text: Dr. Sackett teaches in a way that is very engaging and charismatic, capturing your attention. He uses straight interviews, expert interviews, illustrations, and animations. He's really a great tour guide, bringing us along this journey to gaze upon the face of God.
illustrations.context: This analogy shows how Dr. Sackett makes learning about God interactive and guided.

illustrations.title: Personal Transformation Testimony
illustrations.text: It just stirred us and stirred me; I really found it to be beneficial to be in a room with individuals that know me, who can continue the challenge when the video turns off. The content changed me because I can't love the same; I need to love sacrificially and with zeal. I called my wife and said things are going to change; we need to talk. It's been exactly what I needed to hear when I needed to hear it, in the environment I needed.
illustrations.context: This example demonstrates how the Engagement Project leads to personal change and relational growth.

illustrations.title: Truth Project History
illustrations.text: Dr. Del Tackett did the Truth Project, which was a biblical worldview engagement series that over 20 million people viewed in 130 countries and trained us in what the Bible says and how we should live. This is his next project, called the Engagement Project, as part two in the worldview series. It builds on the original by focusing on how to apply those truths in daily life.
illustrations.context: This reference illustrates the progression from biblical knowledge to practical application in life.

illustrations.title: Del Tackett Encounter
illustrations.text: Our men had Del Tackett come and do a men's retreat a few years ago, and it was phenomenal. We did the Truth Project here, and I had the privilege of running into him in Israel on one of the tours at the Dead Sea. We talked for a while about the style of ministry and how, after a lot of research, their real preference is to do it in homes in small groups, as it's far more effective. So, we're excited about doing that this time, as it provides an opportunity to be trained to apply God's Word specifically in your life, where you live and work.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this example to encourage participation in small groups for effective cultural engagement and practical application of faith.

illustrations.title: Mary as Church Analogy
illustrations.text: Many of you have heard me say I think that Mary is a picture of the Christian or the church. Mary, Jesus's mother, was engaged and expecting, and we are to be expecting Christ's return. We are engaged to Christ, our bridegroom, and we're to be engaged in the mission He gave us. He said, 'Occupy until I come,' so we have a mission to be involved in, growing and applying our faith practically.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to illustrate that Christians should actively await Christ's return and engage in their mission.

illustrations.title: Jesus Hated for Truth
illustrations.text: This is John 7 and verse 7: the world cannot hate you but it hates me because I testify of it that its deeds are evil. In other words, Jesus called people to repent of their sin and told them they weren't ready for the coming judgment. Remember his message was repent for the kingdom of heaven is at hand.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to illustrate that Christians suffer because, like Jesus, they testify to the evil in the world and call for repentance, leading to hatred from those who reject it.

illustrations.title: Sued for Righteous Actions
illustrations.text: I have been sued more than once, and it's not fun to be accused of something in front of a judge when you are totally guiltless. For example, when I was a police officer, I arrested a man for drunk driving, which was completely legal since his blood alcohol was over the limit. He got hurt on his own later and named me in the lawsuit, even though I did nothing wrong. Instead of going to trial, they paid him off with thirty thousand dollars because it was cheaper than the court costs, which is frustrating when people doing wrong accuse you and get away with it.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to illustrate that suffering for doing what is right can be unjust and frustrating, emphasizing the need to endure for the right reasons.

illustrations.title: Kingdom as Banquet Not Picnic
illustrations.text: The kingdom of God is often pictured as a banquet, symbolizing a grand and fulfilling experience, but it's never pictured as a picnic, which implies something casual and easy. This means that in this life, as Christians, we will face struggles and challenges. It's a way to understand that living with the King inside us puts us at odds with a fallen world.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to show that the Christian life involves hardships and is not a carefree experience, preparing believers for suffering.

illustrations.title: Police Officer Sermon Story
illustrations.text: Years ago, when I was still a police officer in Placentia, I was the pastor of Calvary Chapel Ascension, which is what this church was back then. I told the congregation I was going to give a message next Sunday on how to avoid tickets, and our church doubled in size in one week as all kinds of people showed up—people I hadn't seen in years or ever. They thought I was going to share secrets like where cops hide with their radar guns or how to get out of a ticket. I didn't, and most of those people were disappointed and didn't come back.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate that people often seek easy ways out of consequences rather than doing what is good, connecting to the principle of suffering for righteousness and avoiding harm by doing right.

illustrations.title: Alexander's Spread of Greek
illustrations.text: Alexander the Great spread Hellenism and Greek culture throughout the world, making Greek the common language of the time. This is why the New Testament was written in Koine Greek, the everyday Greek spoken in the 2nd century, rather than classical or modern Greek. As a result, people in that era could easily read and understand the Bible, since it wasn't originally written in Latin.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this historical reference to explain why the New Testament was written in Koine Greek, emphasizing its rarity and relevance to understanding the conditional word in the biblical text.

illustrations.title: John Wesley's Persecution
illustrations.text: John Wesley was riding along on a horse one day when he realized that three whole days had passed without any persecution, like bricks or eggs being thrown at him. Alarmed, he stopped his horse, got off, and knelt down to pray, asking God if he had sinned or backslidden. As he prayed, a man on the other side of a hedge heard him, recognized Wesley, and threw a brick at him, which thankfully missed. Wesley jumped up and thanked God, seeing it as confirmation that he was still on the right path.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to show that true faith and righteousness often attract persecution, and its absence might indicate a lack of bold living.

illustrations.title: Hippies Preaching Naked
illustrations.text: True story: back in the 70s, a couple of hippies who got saved decided to preach the gospel by taking off all their clothes and covering themselves in mustard in a park. They got arrested for indecent exposure and claimed they were being persecuted for righteousness. But Pastor Bob points out that they were actually being persecuted for being foolish, not for their faith.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that Christians should not mistake suffering for weird behavior as true persecution for righteousness.

illustrations.title: Preacher at Fullerton College
illustrations.text: When I was at Fullerton College, there was a guy who came on campus and started preaching without getting the required permit. The school told him he couldn't do that, but he insisted because he was preaching the gospel. Eventually, the police came and took him away, and he claimed it was persecution for righteousness, which Pastor Bob says was ridiculous because he broke the rules.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to warn that Christians shouldn't label rule-breaking or foolish actions as genuine persecution.

illustrations.title: Sons of Sceva Demon Encounter
illustrations.text: Remember when those seven sons of Sceva were casting out demons in Jesus' name? They weren't even Christians, but they tried it because they thought it would work, saying, 'We adjure you by the Jesus that Paul preaches.' The demon-possessed man jumped on them and beat them, first saying, 'I know who Jesus is, and I know Paul, but who are you?' This shows that demons recognize true authority and those who are a real threat.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate that the enemy recognizes and fears those who are genuine threats to his kingdom.

illustrations.title: Wanted in Hell Analogy
illustrations.text: It's kind of like this: if hell has a post office, don't you want your picture on the wall? We want to be a threat to the kingdom of Satan, making every day count for the kingdom of God. After all, we have one life to live, and it's going to be over soon.
illustrations.context: This analogy encourages listeners to live boldly for Christ so that they become a recognized threat to evil forces.

illustrations.title: Personal Reflection on Life's Length
illustrations.text: I just realized yesterday that I've lived twice as long as Jesus did on this earth in this human body. I don't know how many more days, months, or years I have, but I want every one of them to count for the kingdom. We have one chance to affect the people around us and stand up for Christ.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob shares this to emphasize the urgency of living purposefully for God's kingdom before time runs out.

illustrations.title: Family Member's Social Media Stand
illustrations.text: A friend of mine, who is actually a family member and a Christian that comes to this church, posted on her Facebook page when the Roe v. Wade decision came out. This shows how standing up for biblical truths can lead to offense, even among those close to us. It's an example of how sharing Christ can provoke strong reactions.
illustrations.context: This real-world example illustrates that standing for righteousness will often result in people being offended, as predicted in scripture.

illustrations.title: Woman's Righteous Stand Criticism
illustrations.text: She was celebrating something righteous and was very happy about it, but immediately faced criticism from people who aren't believers. One person even said, 'You people make me sick,' and others started to badmouth her. This shows that when you take a stand for what's right, you'll evoke negative responses from those who disagree.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that standing for righteousness often leads to opposition, tempting one to react in anger or fear.

illustrations.title: Pastor's Claustrophobia Experience
illustrations.text: For years, I told everybody and myself that I wasn't claustrophobic, but the MRI I had revealed I was lying. A phobia is an irrational fear not tied to anything legitimate. This personal experience highlights how such fears can be deceptive and hard to admit.
illustrations.context: This shows that irrational fears like phobias are common and contrast with biblical commands to not fear.

illustrations.title: Fear Not Bible Commands
illustrations.text: People often say that the command 'fear not' is used 365 times in the Bible, one for every day of the year. Lloyd Ogilvy pointed out it's actually 366 to include leap year, and in fact, it's about 500 if you add up all the related verses about not worrying or fearing God. This emphasizes how the Bible is full of encouragement to overcome fear by trusting in God.
illustrations.context: This quote reinforces that the Bible repeatedly addresses fear, providing daily reassurance to not be afraid.

illustrations.title: Isaiah's Vision of God
illustrations.text: Remember the issue there in Isaiah: it was in the year King Uzziah died, a great king who ruled for 54 years and brought many good changes, and suddenly he dies. Then Isaiah sees the Lord on His throne, showing that even though Israel's earthly throne is unoccupied and uncertainty looms, God is still ruling over the universe and hasn't left His throne. This illustrates that in times of loss or change, we must remember God's sovereignty.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize that Jesus rules over circumstances, even in times of uncertainty like after a king's death.

illustrations.title: John's Exile on Patmos
illustrations.text: That's the idea there in the Book of Revelation: John is on the island of Patmos for his faith in Jesus, not knowing if he'll stay there forever; he was the pastor of the church at Ephesus and an old man who didn't want to be exiled. It looks like he's going to die there, but God gives him a vision, one of the greatest ever, and in Revelation 4 and 5, he sees heaven with a throne and the Lord on it. This shows that even in isolation and suffering, God reveals His presence and control.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to point out that believers should see God on the throne during their trials, providing assurance of His rule.

illustrations.title: Paul's Joy in Prison
illustrations.text: Remember Paul said rejoice in the Lord always, and he wrote these words while in prison, explaining that his circumstances of being arrested have turned out for the greater progress of the gospel, with even the elite Praetorian Guard hearing about Jesus because of it. Paul never called himself the prisoner of Rome; he saw himself as the prisoner of the Lord, recognizing God's hand in his suffering. This example highlights how difficult situations can advance God's purposes.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that recognizing Christ's rule means rejoicing in trials, as Paul did, turning suffering into opportunities for the gospel.

illustrations.title: Jesus Calms the Storm
illustrations.text: The Hebrew word is the same one Jesus used when the storm raged on the Sea of Galilee. He turned to the storm and said, 'Hush, be still,' like you'd say to a little dog or someone making noise. Literally in the original language, it's 'shh,' and suddenly everything became calm.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that the Lord is in control and we should be silent before Him, emphasizing His sovereignty.

illustrations.title: Jesus at Lazarus's Funeral
illustrations.text: Remember, Jesus goes to the funeral of Lazarus where everybody is upset, not just because Lazarus has died, but because Jesus didn't come sooner when they called for help. He waited until Lazarus was dead, but then He shows up and talks to Martha while Mary is crying in the house. Martha says, 'The teacher is here and He's calling for you,' showing His presence in the midst of suffering.
illustrations.context: This demonstrates that Jesus is with us during our suffering and in charge, helping us avoid fear and worry.

illustrations.title: Anchor of Hope Analogy
illustrations.text: You can't see my hope, but you can see its effects, just like an anchor of a ship that's below the surface yet affects the ship in the storm. Our hope is the resurrection, Christ coming, the rapture, going to heaven, and our sins being forgiven—it's the blessed hope of the believer. So, people should detect in you something they lack or don't understand, which causes them to ask questions.
illustrations.context: This analogy shows how unseen hope influences visible behavior, prompting others to inquire about faith.

illustrations.title: Paul and Silas Persecution Story
illustrations.text: Paul and Silas were arrested basically for being Christians and were falsely accused in Philippi. Paul had a vision in Troas of a Macedonian man calling for help, so he went to Europe expecting to find that man, but instead, a woman named Lydia received Christ and a church was planted. Before more ministry could happen, Paul cast a demon out of a slave girl who was making money for her masters through fortune-telling, which angered them and led to Paul and Silas being falsely accused, beaten, and thrown into the Philippian jail in stocks—a form of torture.
illustrations.context: This retelling illustrates how persecution can create opportunities for testimony and sharing faith.

illustrations.title: Missed Christmas Sharing Opportunity
illustrations.text: I have three sons who are now in their 30s, but when they were little boys, I was with one of them in a local store before Christmas. The store was all decked out for the holidays, and a total stranger behind me asked my four or five-year-old son if he was excited about Christmas and if Santa Claus was going to bring him something. You need to understand that we taught our sons that Christmas is about Jesus being born and God sending us the greatest gift, which is why we give gifts. The man assumed my son believed in Santa, so when my son said he didn't, the man asked what he believed in. My son looked at me for approval and replied, 'I believe in Dick Tracy.' The man looked at me, and I thought we needed to leave and work on making the most of opportunities, but he was only five.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how we sometimes miss opportunities to share our faith effectively.

illustrations.title: Paul's Defense in Prison
illustrations.text: In the book of Acts, Paul is in prison in chapter 26 and has the opportunity to stand before a governor to explain why he's in jail and what he believes. As he's talking about Christ's resurrection, the governor interrupts him. Festus said in a loud voice, 'Paul, you are out of your mind; your great learning is driving you mad.' But Paul responded graciously, saying, 'I'm not out of my mind, most excellent Festus, but I utter words of sober truth.'
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to show that sharing faith should be done reasonably and with gentleness, as Paul defends his beliefs calmly and confidently.

illustrations.title: Seminary Hymn Experience
illustrations.text: I shared this before when I was in seminary, we would go into chapel called Calvary Chapel, and we'd sing the great hymns of the faith. One day, we were singing the hymn 'He Lives,' with the chorus 'You ask me how I know He lives, He lives within my heart.' My professor, Dr. Rigsby, a Hebrew professor with a big voice, sat behind us and sang louder than everyone, changing the words to 'You ask me how I know He lives, the Bible tells me so.' He was making a point about relying on Scripture, not just personal experience.
illustrations.context: Personal experience alone isn't enough; faith must be validated by the Word of God.

illustrations.title: Josephus on Jesus
illustrations.text: Jesus's life, ministry, and even his resurrection are testified outside of New Testament documents. For instance, if you've not read Josephus, who was the historian of the first-century Jewish people and not a Christian, he wrote in 'The Antiquities of the Jews' and 'The Wars of the Jews' about Jesus and the belief that he rose from the dead due to the circumstances. This shows that these events were well-known and documented beyond Christian circles.
illustrations.context: Evidence for Jesus's resurrection comes from historical sources outside the Bible, strengthening the validity of Christian claims.

illustrations.title: Unfalsifiable Prophecies Fulfilled
illustrations.text: There are those who say Jesus came and purposely fulfilled those prophecies. I agree with you when he rode the donkey into Jerusalem, fulfilling Zechariah 9:9. But let's talk about choosing where you're going to be born before you're born—that's a lot tougher to pull off. The Messiah had to be betrayed by a friend, with the betrayal money being exactly 30 pieces of silver, thrown into the house of the Lord, and used to buy a potter's field—all of that was predicted. And by the way, he needed to be born of a virgin. How do you govern and control all those things?
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to show that Jesus couldn't have faked fulfilling all the prophecies, emphasizing the authenticity of his Messiahship.

illustrations.title: Peter Stoner's Probability Example
illustrations.text: Back in the 1950s, there was a man named Peter Stoner, a mathematics professor who wrote a book called Science Speaks. He used compound probability to calculate the chances of biblical prophecies about Jesus being fulfilled by random occurrence. For instance, for eight prophecies, the odds are one in 10 to the 17th power, which is like covering the entire landmass of Texas with silver dollars two feet deep, marking one coin, mixing them, and having a blindfolded cowboy randomly pick the marked one. This shows the extreme rarity of such an event, and for more prophecies, the number grows even larger, requiring comparisons to vast distances like that between Earth and the Sun.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the extreme improbability of Jesus fulfilling multiple prophecies by chance, emphasizing divine intervention.

illustrations.title: Silver Dollars Analogy
illustrations.text: You have to picture a silver ball the size of the distance from Earth to the Sun times 30, extending out to Neptune's orbit. That's a massive ball of 10 to the 45th power silver dollars. If you mark one silver dollar and someone tries to pick it blindfolded, the chance is like fulfilling 16 prophecies by accident. For 48 prophecies, the odds reach 1 in 10 to the 157th power, which is so vast that we switch to electrons. An electron is incredibly small, about 2.5 quadrillionths of an inch, and even counting them at 250 per minute would take 19 million years to make one inch.
illustrations.context: This analogy illustrates the extreme improbability of someone fulfilling Bible prophecies by chance, emphasizing the divine inspiration behind them.

illustrations.title: Peter Stoner Quote on Inspiration
illustrations.text: Peter Stoner said in the conclusion of his book that to the extent we know a blindfolded man cannot pick out the marked electron, we know the Bible is inspired. This is not merely evidence but proof of the Bible's inspiration by God, so definite that the universe isn't large enough to hold the evidence. Professor Stoner then commented that any man who rejects Christ as the Son of God is rejecting a fact proved more absolutely than any other.
illustrations.context: This quote reinforces the proof of the Bible's divine inspiration through the impossibility of fulfilling prophecies by chance.

illustrations.title: The Murderer's Guilty Conscience
illustrations.text: True story: In England in Chester, a man named Peter had problems with his wife and murdered her. He buried her in a local peat bog, and for 22 years, no one knew what happened. Then, he read in the paper about peat diggers uncovering a skull, which prompted him to drive to the police department and confess the entire crime. It turned out the skull was from something else, but his conscience drove him to come forward. This shows how guilt can linger and force confession even after years.
illustrations.context: To illustrate how even unbelievers have a conscience that accuses them and can lead to shame or confession.

illustrations.title: Roman Skull Conscience Tale
illustrations.text: In the 400s A.D., it was a Roman skull from when the Romans were still in Great Britain, and it was not his wife at all. He could cover his crime but he could not keep his conscience silent. This story shows that even in ancient times, guilt reveals itself.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that living right means a clear conscience will eventually reprove others, even if they don't see it immediately.

illustrations.title: Peter and John Arrested
illustrations.text: Peter and John were arrested for healing a lame man in the name of Jesus, as recorded in Acts chapter 4. They boldly declared that by the name of Jesus Christ, whom the people crucified but God raised, the man was made well. Peter used this opportunity to preach the gospel, saying it was absurd to be tried for such a good deed.
illustrations.context: This retelling emphasizes that suffering for righteousness provides a chance to share the gospel and maintain a clear conscience.

illustrations.title: Schumer Abortion Quote
illustrations.text: Leader Chuck Schumer recently said in the Washington Post that millions upon millions of American women are having their rights taken away from them. Pastor Bob responds by noting it amazes him when people call wrongs rights, and he highlights the 67 million babies who had their right to live taken away. He expresses gratitude for the Supreme Court's decision that the abortion issue shouldn't be based on constitutional law.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to point out the inconsistency in defining rights, connecting it to the moral issue of abortion.

illustrations.title: Reagan's Abortion Insight
illustrations.text: Ronald Reagan wrote in 1983 in his book Abortion and the Conscience of a Nation that as an act of raw judicial power, the Supreme Court's decision in Roe versus Wade has so far been made to stick, but it has not settled the debate. Instead, it has become a continuing prod to the conscience of the nation. He noted that the Supreme Court might overturn its rulings, just as it did in Brown versus Board of Education when it reversed the separate but equal decision.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to illustrate that controversial court decisions can be reversed, encouraging persistence in the fight against abortion.

illustrations.title: Supreme Court Reversal History
illustrations.text: Ronald Reagan pointed out that in Brown versus Board of Education, the Supreme Court reversed its own earlier separate but equal decision. This example shows that judicial rulings can change over time. Pastor Bob connects this to the possibility that the Supreme Court could revisit and overturn Roe versus Wade.
illustrations.context: This historical reference emphasizes that past court decisions have been reversed, offering hope for change in abortion laws.

illustrations.title: Persistent Prayer Example
illustrations.text: Pastor Bob encourages that if you are married to an unsaved husband or have a prodigal son and feel like giving up, don't give up but keep praying. He explains that in due time, you will reap the benefits if you persist. This ties into the broader point that changes, like the recent ones on abortion, come from God's intervention through prayer.
illustrations.context: This real-world example urges believers to remain faithful in prayer for seemingly hopeless situations, as God can bring about change.

illustrations.title: Joy in Children's Faith
illustrations.text: I was thinking about that this morning, as you may not know, but this was one of our youth worship teams. They normally minister upstairs, but we invited them to come. I know many of them, and their parents attend here, and I see the joy on their parents' faces as their children lead the congregation. It is a thrill, and anyone with kids knows what a blessing it is to see your children walking with the Lord, serving Him, and teaching others about Him. John is saying that very thing in his letter.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this example to illustrate the profound joy parents feel when their children walk in faith, mirroring John's sentiment.

illustrations.title: Grandson's Development Stages
illustrations.text: I have grandchildren who live with me, and one of them, my youngest, is Jeffrey. I talk a lot about him; he's my cute little sermon illustration. He's not walking yet, but he's starting to sit and stand, and that's usually the order for a baby—they sit, then stand, and then walk. We're all excited, waiting for him to take his first steps and say our names first. Of course, he's already saying 'dad,' and we're wondering if 'pop' will come next.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to illustrate the stages of spiritual development, contrasting a baby's physical progression with the biblical sequence of sitting, walking, and standing in faith.

illustrations.title: Crusades Conversion Uncertainty
illustrations.text: You know, when Billy Graham does a crusade or Greg Laurie holds one, people come forward, and in our church, somebody prays a prayer to receive Christ. But you don't know if it's going to stick—are they just professing or truly converted? Time will tell, as it reveals the genuineness of their faith.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the uncertainty of true conversion in evangelistic events, emphasizing that professions of faith need time to prove genuine.

illustrations.title: Paul's Orphaned Heart
illustrations.text: Paul described how he felt when he had to leave town quickly without saying goodbye to everybody—he said he felt orphaned, like there was a death in his family, because of how much he loved them and couldn't even say goodbye. I talked about this last week, noting that Paul really hurt from the separation. This shows that such emotional pain should be normal for Christians deeply involved in a church.
illustrations.context: This retelling highlights that genuine care for believers involves deep emotional attachment, even feeling orphaned upon separation.

illustrations.title: Paul's Journey to Berea
illustrations.text: Paul left Thessalonica and went to Berea, where the Bible says the people were more noble than those in Thessalonica. Even though he was away, Paul said he was still with them in spirit and couldn't stop thinking about the church. I mentioned how this is like leaving your heart behind, with the Bereans being notably eager and thoughtful, even starting something like a Christian bookstore chain as a humorous note.
illustrations.context: This story underscores that true spiritual care persists despite physical distance, keeping the believers always on one's mind.

illustrations.title: Theodore Roosevelt's State Dinner
illustrations.text: The reason I tell you this is that too often we have great opportunities to minister to one another but we miss them. We allow ourselves to come and go without strengthening anyone's faith or encouraging them in the Lord. True story: Theodore Roosevelt had a state dinner, a ball, and all these dignitaries were coming all dressed up.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to show how people often miss opportunities to minister and encourage others in their faith.

illustrations.title: Man's Shocking Party Confession
illustrations.text: Everybody was treating each other with the usual pleasantries, saying things like 'hello, how are you?' But one man was tired of the superficiality and leaned over to each guest, saying, 'I murdered my grandmother last night,' just to see their reactions. Most ignored him and continued with their niceties, like 'good job, keep up the good work.' One diplomat even responded, 'I'm sure she deserved it.' This illustrates how people often miss the truth when it's right in front of them.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show how people go through social motions without truly engaging or hearing the truth.

illustrations.title: Jonathan Strengthens David
illustrations.text: David had been anointed as king, killed Goliath, and led Israel's armies to victory, but this made King Saul jealous and determined to kill him. Jonathan, Saul's son and a more mature believer, met David in the woods to encourage him despite the bad news that he couldn't return home. Jonathan strengthened David's hand in God, reminding him of God's promises by saying, 'Fear not, for Saul shall not find you, and you will be king over Israel.' He affirmed that God's plan would stand no matter what Saul did. This shows how to encourage others by pointing them to God's word and promises.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates how true encouragement involves reminding others of God's promises, even in difficult circumstances.

illustrations.title: Memorial for Pastor Mike
illustrations.text: Some of you attended the memorial service for Pastor Mike Swanson almost a year ago, and it was a hard one. He was in his thirties, leaving a young widow and little children, and he was a beloved pastor with the place packed and standing room only, plus 350 people watching online. To me, the most radical moment was when Aaron, Mike's widow, got up to speak with great poise and wisdom, showing peace in God's decision to take her husband. Her calmness made all of us feel okay, just as Paul was reassuring the Thessalonians.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that seeing someone at peace in trials, like Aaron, helps others find comfort and not be disturbed by afflictions, mirroring Paul's message.

illustrations.title: Paul's Suffering Foretold
illustrations.text: From the beginning of Paul's salvation in Acts 9, Ananias was told by the Lord that Paul was going to suffer greatly as part of God's mission for him. Ananias took his girdle and was instructed that bonds and afflictions awaited Paul. This prophecy came true, showing that Paul knew trials were appointed for him and he accepted them. Paul shared this in advance so others wouldn't be disturbed.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob retells this to explain that Paul expected suffering, which helped comfort others by showing it was part of God's plan.

illustrations.title: Forewarned Family Scare
illustrations.text: Look, if you have somebody in your family who likes to freak people out by jumping out of closets, you know how it goes. If you walk into a room and see them sneaking in the closet, then when they jump out, you're not going to be freaked out. In fact, you might even turn the tables and freak them instead because you knew ahead of time.
illustrations.context: This analogy shows that being forewarned about trials, like Jesus warned his disciples, prepares us so we won't be surprised or stumble.

illustrations.title: Fiery Furnace Faith
illustrations.text: You remember Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego, who refused to bow to the image and compromise their faith, so they were thrown into the fiery furnace. They declared that God could save them even if He didn't, and they had already resolved not to bow down. As a result, they were supposedly executed by being cast into the furnace, but the king saw not three but four figures in the flames.
illustrations.context: This retelling illustrates that believers should not be surprised by fiery trials and should rejoice in sharing Christ's sufferings, standing firm in faith.

illustrations.title: Stephen's Martyrdom Vision
illustrations.text: Look at Stephen, the New Testament's first martyr. They rose up to kill him, and as he's being stoned, he sees heaven open and Jesus standing at the right hand of the Father. Jesus isn't sitting as expected; he's standing, perhaps saying, 'I'm ready, Stephen, that's my boy.' When you stand for the Lord on earth, he'll stand for you in heaven.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how Jesus is manifested and stands with believers during trials and suffering.

illustrations.title: Spilled Coffee Analogy
illustrations.text: You're on your way to work and stop at Starbucks like you do every day, buying a cup of hot coffee. You're in a hurry and forget to put the lid on fully, then hit a speed bump in the parking lot, and the coffee spills all over your car. The natural question is, did the bump create the coffee? No, it was there all along; it just displayed what was in the cup, showing that circumstances bring out what's already in your human nature so it can be dealt with.
illustrations.context: This analogy explains that trials reveal and purify inner flaws like anger or unkindness, rather than creating them.

illustrations.title: Bible Autographing Tradition
illustrations.text: Every once in a while, someone will get a new Bible or come to Christ and receive one, and they'll ask me to autograph it. I always remind them that I didn't write it, but I'm happy to add a note. What I always write is what Susanna Wesley reportedly wrote in her son John's Bible: 'This book will keep you from sin or sin will keep you from this book.' This quote underscores the power of Scripture in a believer's life, as I share it to emphasize its importance.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate the vital role of God's Word in helping believers stand firm and resist sin.

illustrations.title: Conversion at Age Thirteen
illustrations.text: I received Christ when I was 13 years old, and Jesus truly came into my heart and saved me. Even though I was saved, I didn't immediately gain all these spiritual qualities; I still talked and acted much the way I used to. It's like the Lord came down my street in 1971, saw my life which was red-tagged and slated for condemnation, and decided to buy it, just as you might in Monopoly when you land on a prime property and say, 'I'll buy it.'
illustrations.context: This illustrates how God can enter and redeem a person's life even when they are young and unchanged at first.

illustrations.title: Fred and Phil's Bible Study
illustrations.text: I didn't have many spiritual appetites, but I had a friend named Fred who brought me to his church where I gave my life to Christ. Fred's youth pastor, Phil Lewis, suggested a Tuesday night Bible study after hearing about my conversion. When Fred invited me, I refused because I was watching TV and told him to say I was sick. That Tuesday night, there was a knock at the door—it was Phil and Fred, who had decided to bring the Bible study to my house. We sat down and had the study right there, even though I don't remember the details of what was said. I'll never forget Phil's creative and caring approach. This showed me the importance of going the extra mile in faith.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the need to be creative and persistent in sharing God's Word and showing His heart to strengthen others' faith.

illustrations.title: Meeting Becky and Hidden Feelings
illustrations.text: Some of you don't know this, but when I first met Becky, she was engaged to be married, so we were just friends.
