I encouraged her spiritually, and we spent time together talking about the Lord and life. Feelings started to grow inside me, but I was scared to ask how she felt because I didn't want to hear it might be over. One day, I walked in and saw her writing on a piece of paper, which she quickly tried to hide by grabbing it and even putting it in her mouth. Finally, I got hold of it and saw she had written my last name with hers repeatedly, realizing she liked me too.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how Paul wanted to know if the church in Thessalonica cared about him as deeply as he cared about them.

illustrations.title: Joseph's Reunion in Egypt
illustrations.text: Jot down Genesis 44 verses 30 and 31; you know the background of this story. Joseph is in Egypt, and everybody thinks he's dead. His brothers don't recognize him because it's been many years and he's changed, even joking about his Egyptian nose and glasses. They come to Egypt for food during the famine.
illustrations.context: This shows the importance of reciprocal care and recognition in relationships, mirroring Paul's concern for the church.

illustrations.title: Joseph's Demand for Benjamin
illustrations.text: Jacob is old and back in Canaan, and Joseph is messing with his brothers during their trips. They tell him about their younger brother Benjamin, who is Joseph's only full brother from their mother Rachel. Joseph demands they bring Benjamin to prove they're telling the truth, or no more business, and the brothers worry about how this will devastate their father Jacob, whose life is bound up in the boy's life.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to show how one person's situation deeply affects another's emotional and spiritual life.

illustrations.title: Paul's Concern for the Weak
illustrations.text: Paul says to the church at Corinth that whoever is weak means he is weak, and whoever is led into sin causes him intense concern and offense. He emphasizes his deep emotional connection to the churches, showing how their struggles become his own. This illustrates Paul's burning passion for the spiritual health of believers.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob connects this quote to demonstrate how leaders and believers are personally affected by each other's weaknesses and sins.

illustrations.title: God Defending Israel
illustrations.text: God says of Israel that whoever touches you touches the apple of my eye, meaning an attack on His people is like poking Him directly. This highlights God's intense personal protection and identification with Israel. Pastor Bob uses it to show how God takes offenses against His people personally.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates that harming God's people is equivalent to harming God Himself, emphasizing divine protection and unity.

illustrations.title: Jesus and Saul's Persecution
illustrations.text: Jesus said to Saul, who was persecuting the church, 'Saul, Saul, why are you persecuting me?' even though Saul was targeting the believers, not Jesus directly. This shows that the church is the body of Christ, so an attack on it is an attack on Him. Pastor Bob explains that Jesus takes persecution of the church personally, as if it were against Himself.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to convey that the church is so united with Christ that harming it harms Him directly.

illustrations.title: Offending Through Criticism
illustrations.text: If you want to offend me, just say something negative about my wife, because that's how personal it gets for me. This analogy shows that criticizing or harming something dear to someone is like attacking them directly. Pastor Bob connects it to how God views attacks on the church, His bride.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates the deep personal connection God has with the church by comparing it to a husband's reaction to insults against his wife.

illustrations.title: Unreciprocated Parental Love
illustrations.text: Let me be really honest when it comes to parents and children: Paul said to the Church of Corinth, 'If I love you the more, should I be loved by you the less?' It's not always reciprocal. Every parent knows that our children don't usually return the same level of love and care that we have for them. Think back to when you were a kid and had parents—it was probably the same. You're older and more mature now, and your love is more mature; when that child says, 'I hate you,' you might say, 'Go to your room, I'll help you, but I still love you—I know you don't really hate me.'
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that loving others deeply, like Paul did, involves risk because love isn't always returned, encouraging people to express care anyway.

illustrations.title: Mother's Concern for Struggling Child
illustrations.text: Someone said a mother is only doing as well as her child who is doing the worst—that's true. You could have five kids, and if one is really blowing it in life, your focus and attention is on that one. That's the nature of the heart, but be careful—you have four other ones that need to know you're proud of them and excited if they're walking with the Lord. Make sure they know this was a good report. The application includes ministering to the one who's not doing well, like Paul said, 'If anyone is weak, I'm weak; if anybody's hurting, I'm hurting.'
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to illustrate the deep emotional investment parents have in their children's struggles, emphasizing the need to care for and affirm those who are doing well while supporting those who are not.

illustrations.title: Pearl of Great Price Analogy
illustrations.text: Lord, you have pulled us as the pearl of great price. You have called us the treasure for which you were willing to sell out and buy the whole field. Lord, you were willing to endure the shame and the separation from your father, as well as the weight of sin and its punishment that you had never known, all for each of us.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to emphasize that God sees believers as highly valuable, just as in the biblical parables, encouraging them to recognize their worth and persist in faith.

illustrations.title: Jesus' Crucifixion Example
illustrations.text: It's interesting to look at the example of Jesus Christ on the cross. Nobody has ever suffered as much as Jesus did, physically and spiritually, being separated from God and enduring the torture of the cross. Yet, we see him ministering through the seven words of the cross. We can't use pain as an excuse for why we can't minister, as Jesus did even in his suffering.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that even in immense suffering, one can still minister and bless others through the power of the Holy Spirit.

illustrations.title: Stephen's Martyrdom Prayer
illustrations.text: For Stephen, as the rocks were coming in, he said, 'Lord, don't lay this to their charge,' just like Christ. He wasn't acting on his own but was filled with the Spirit of God. This shows how the Holy Spirit enables one to forgive and minister even in persecution.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates that with the Holy Spirit, individuals can respond to suffering with grace and ministry, mirroring Jesus.

illustrations.title: Jacob's Final Blessing
illustrations.text: Jacob, of all people, wasn't the most spiritual throughout his life, but at the end, as he was dying from some disease, he ministered to his family and blessed them. He spoke from his heart and reflected a changed character before he died. This example shows how one can leave a legacy of faith even in their final moments.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to encourage blessing children by faith as one approaches death, demonstrating spiritual growth.

illustrations.title: God of the Living Retelling
illustrations.text: Jesus proved from the Sadducees' own scriptures that God is the God of the living. He referenced Exodus 3:14, where God introduces himself to Moses as 'I am' and as the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, who had died centuries earlier. Jesus explained that if God is still their God, then they must be alive in some way, showing an afterlife exists.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this retelling to illustrate that the Sadducees erred by not believing in the resurrection, as the scriptures they accepted prove God is the God of the living.

illustrations.title: Pastor Chuck's Death Analogy
illustrations.text: Pastor Chuck said that one day, people might read in the newspaper that Chuck Smith died last night, but don't believe it—that's fake news. He explained that accurate reporting would say he moved out of an old, worn-out tent into a new, glorious body like Jesus has, with no more pain or suffering, just perfect fellowship with the Lord forever. Pastor Bob shares this to emphasize that death for believers is not an end but a transition.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to show that death is the soul's relocation for believers, not termination, providing hope and perspective on the afterlife.

illustrations.title: Paul's Thessalonians Hope
illustrations.text: Paul writes in 1st Thessalonians 4:13-18 that we shouldn't grieve like those without hope, because if we believe Jesus died and rose again, God will bring with Him those who have died in Jesus. He explains that the Lord will descend from heaven with a shout, and the dead in Christ will rise first. Pastor Bob highlights this to assure believers of the resurrection and future reunion.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to reinforce that believers have hope beyond death, contrasting it with the grief of unbelievers.

illustrations.title: Jacob's Gathering to Father
illustrations.text: Jacob said, 'I am going to be gathered to my father.' He could have said, 'I'm going to die' or 'kick the bucket,' but instead, he saw death as being reunited with his family. This perspective highlights how believers view death positively.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that death means reunion with loved ones in heaven.

illustrations.title: Jesus' Departure to the Father
illustrations.text: In John 13:1, before the Feast of the Passover, Jesus knew his hour had come to depart out of this world to the Father. Having loved his own who were in the world, he loved them to the end. This occurred right before he washed their feet, illustrating his deep love and impending relocation.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize that death for believers is a loving relocation to the Father.

illustrations.title: Job's Assurance of Afterlife
illustrations.text: They called him about his speculations on life after death because they knew he was a believer, and his answer was that he knew nothing about speculations; he was resting on certainties. He said, 'I know that my redeemer lives, and because he lives, I shall live also, and I see that in Jacob.' I've got a life to live after I leave here, and I love that. So, when you're dying, you need to know where you're going to help those who love you let you go.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize the certainty of eternal life through faith, encouraging believers to have assurance about the afterlife.

illustrations.title: Doctor and Dog's Faith
illustrations.text: A sick man turned to his doctor as he was preparing to leave the examination room and said, 'Doctor, I'm afraid to die. Tell me what lies on the other side.' The doctor quietly replied, 'I don't know,' even though he was a Christian man. As the doctor held the door handle, a scratching and whining sound came from the other side, and when he opened it, his dog sprang into the room and leaped on him with eager gladness. The doctor turned to the patient and said, 'Did you notice my dog? He's never been in this room before; he didn't know what was inside, but he knew his master was here and sprang in without fear.' I know little of what is on the other side of death, but I do know my Master is there, and that's enough.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to show that faith in God provides confidence in the afterlife despite uncertainties, much like a dog's trust in its master.

illustrations.title: Johnny's Heaven Reluctance
illustrations.text: A teacher asked if everyone wanted to go to heaven, and everybody raised their hand except one little boy named Johnny. The teacher asked Johnny why he didn't raise his hand, and he said he thought they were planning to go right then. This story highlights that just because someone says they're ready doesn't mean they truly are. Poor Johnny always seems to be in these kinds of stories, showing how assumptions about faith can be misleading.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to question if people are truly ready for heaven, emphasizing that being a Christian doesn't automatically mean living in that assurance.

illustrations.title: Pastor Chuck's Legacy Advice
illustrations.text: Praying Pastor Chuck used to say that after he's gone, no one should name buildings after him, like Smith Hall. He didn't want memorials focused on his name or remains. Pastor Bob connects this to Jacob's priorities, showing that what's truly important is the record of one's faith, not physical monuments. This illustrates that faith and God's promises matter more than earthly legacy.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that Jacob cared more about his faith and God's promises than about a grand burial site.

illustrations.title: Seed Analogy for Burial
illustrations.text: Paul the Apostle in 1st Corinthians 15 says we bury our dead in faith, explaining that the burial of a body is like burying a seed. We put a seed in the ground not to get rid of it, but with full intentions that something better will come up. Paul goes into great detail about how what comes up is way better than what was put in the ground, and so the glorified body will be far superior to the one we bury, all in the hope of the resurrection from the dead.
illustrations.context: This analogy illustrates that we should bury our dead in faith, expecting a resurrection and a better future as promised by God.

illustrations.title: Jacob and Joseph's Final Faith
illustrations.text: By faith, Jacob, as he was dying, blessed each of the sons of Joseph, worshiped while leaning on the top of his staff, and showed his commitment to God's promises. Then, by faith, Joseph, when he was dying, made mention of the Exodus of the sons of Israel, which would happen hundreds of years later, and gave orders for his bones to be taken to the promised land. This demonstrated their unwavering belief that God would fulfill His promises, even beyond their lifetimes.
illustrations.context: This retelling emphasizes that we are called to live, walk, and die in faith, remaining committed to God's promises.

illustrations.title: John Denver's Forest Lawn Parody
illustrations.text: John Denver wrote a parody song about Forest Lawn burials, highlighting the absurdity of extravagant funerals. In the song, he sings about being laid in a silver casket with golden flowers, accompanied by a drum and bugle corps, cannons, and even 16 liveried employees handing out souvenirs. He contrasts this with a desire for a simple funeral, mentioning piped-in tapes and a likeness cast in brass that tips its hat, all while poking fun at the commercialization of death. Pastor Bob shares these lyrics to emphasize how people often plan overly elaborate burials. Ultimately, the song underscores that true rest doesn't require such fuss.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses the quote to contrast elaborate, commercialized burials with Jacob's simple desires, illustrating that true peace comes from simplicity and what's already prepared.

illustrations.title: Jacob's Marriage Deception
illustrations.text: Jacob went to find a bride among his relatives in Paddan-Aram and met Rachel at a well, where he was immediately smitten and kissed her on their first meeting. He agreed to work seven years for her uncle Laban to marry her, but on the wedding night, he discovered Laban had substituted his older daughter Leah. Jacob ended up marrying both sisters, but he never loved Leah, leading to her bitterness as she tried to win his affection through their children.
illustrations.context: To illustrate the pain of unrequited love and the consequences of deception in relationships.

illustrations.title: Jacob's Tricked Marriage Redemption
illustrations.text: You see, at first Jacob felt tricked and trapped in that marriage. He didn't realize that God's greatest gift to him and to all mankind was going to come through Leah. For a long time, he didn't know that. I think sometimes in marriages, we think, 'That's not the person I married; that's not who I thought I was given.' We wake up one day and realize we're tricked and trapped. May I suggest you remember this—not just about marriage, but about anything God has put you in—hang in there, because you don't know what God is going to do in that situation or how He might redeem it.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses Jacob's story to illustrate that God can redeem disappointing situations, like feeling tricked in marriage, and turn them into something profound.

illustrations.title: Paul's Ship in Storm
illustrations.text: A prisoner was going to Rome, and on the way, the ship encountered a storm and was about to sink. The soldiers and sailors were panicking and considering abandoning ship. Paul told them the Lord had spoken to him, advising them to stay with the ship or they wouldn't make it to shore. They followed his words, cut the ropes to the lifeboats, and stayed on board, ultimately surviving the ordeal. If they had abandoned ship, they would have perished.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that we should not abandon situations God calls us into, as He can bring survival and redemption through perseverance.

illustrations.title: Joseph's Redemption Story
illustrations.text: Joseph said to his brothers, 'You sold me into slavery; it was for evil, but God meant it for good.' He explained that what they intended for harm, God used for his ultimate blessing. Despite being tricked and trapped, Joseph stayed in the situation and saw God redeem it for good in his life.
illustrations.context: This shows that God can turn even sinful actions into blessings if we persevere and trust Him.

illustrations.title: 80-Year-Old's Wedding
illustrations.text: I think of a woman who was getting married at 80 years old, which was a big deal in her community. The local paper sent a journalist to interview her about the wedding. She shared that it was her fourth marriage, as her previous husbands had all died, and she spoke about her experiences.
illustrations.context: This illustrates being ready for new beginnings or the end of life, connecting to the idea of being prepared as Jacob was.

illustrations.title: Woman's Varied Marriages
illustrations.text: A woman shared that she married her first husband at 20, a wealthy banker who later died. Her second husband was a movie director, an interesting man who also passed away. She then married a pastor in her 60s and was about to marry a mortician, explaining her choices were for money, show, readiness, and to go. This story highlights different life stages and preparations.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate the idea of preparing for the end of life, leading into the concept of saying 'it is finished' before death.

illustrations.title: Jacob's Final Moments
illustrations.text: Jacob finishes blessing his sons and then climbs into bed, feeling complete and ready to go. He buckles himself in and passes away, symbolizing that he has no unfinished business. This retelling shows Jacob's sense of accomplishment at the end of his life. Pastor Bob connects this to the idea of being done with one's tasks.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the spiritual truth of completing one's life work before death, much like Jacob did.

illustrations.title: Unbelievers' Hell Party Myth
illustrations.text: You often hear unbelievers say they don't want to go to heaven; they'd rather go to hell and party with their friends who they know will be there, than go to heaven and play a harp and be good. But that's ridiculous on every level because there is no community in hell; it's a place of complete isolation. Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize that hell isn't a gathering spot for friends.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that hell lacks any sense of community, countering the misconception that it could be a place to be with friends.

illustrations.title: C.S. Lewis on Hell's Isolation
illustrations.text: Have any of you ever read The Great Divorce by C.S. Lewis? Lewis describes hell in a poetic way, saying that at the end of time, there will be those who say to God, 'Thy will be done,' and those to whom God says, 'Thy will be done,' referring to damnation. If you're in hell, it's because you've chosen to be there, but it's a place where everyone is moving farther and farther apart, as no one wants to be near anybody—it's solitude and being on your own. Pastor Bob connects this to show that hell is defined by eternal separation.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that hell is a place of solitude and separation, not community, based on Lewis's depiction.

illustrations.title: Chaff Analogy for the Wicked
illustrations.text: The wicked are described as chaff, which the wind blows away, while the righteous are like a tree planted by the river, bringing forth its fruit in season. The wicked do not abide and are scattered, as chaff doesn't blow away together but apart from itself. This illustrates that there is no community in hell, emphasizing the separation of the wicked. Pastor Bob uses this to highlight the contrast between the gathered righteous and the scattered wicked.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that the wicked are separated and lack community, just as chaff is blown apart by the wind.

illustrations.title: Jeremiah's Precious from Worthless
illustrations.text: You find what's praiseworthy about them, you extract what's precious from what's worthless. It's Jeremiah 15:19, where God said, 'Therefore, thus says the Lord, if you extract the precious from the worthless, then you will become my mouth.' You want to speak for God and like God, so you have to learn to do that, because there might be a ton of worthless things, but you go looking for what's precious. I'm not saying you make it up and lie to them about something that's not there; you find something commendable and unique about them that you can praise.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize finding and praising positive attributes in children, even if they have flaws, to speak blessings like God.

illustrations.title: Bema Seat Judgment Analogy
illustrations.text: Can I tell you something? It sounds like the Bema seat judgment, where it's exactly what the Lord is going to do with us. He's going to look through our entire life, and if there's anything worthy of praise, he's going to find it. He's going to burn away everything that will perish, but if he can find one thing that won't, he will find it so that he can reward you for it on that day. This illustrates how we should focus on the positive in others, just as God will in judgment.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to show that, like God will reward the worthy parts of our lives at judgment, we should praise the commendable aspects in our children and others.

illustrations.title: Woman's Pallbearer Refusal
illustrations.text: I heard about this woman who said she didn't want any men as pallbearers at her funeral. When asked why, she explained that since no men took her out when she was alive, she didn't want them taking her out when she was dead. She was single and never married, adding a humorous twist to her point. This story highlights how people can express their unfulfilled desires even in death.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize the importance of specifying personal funeral wishes to reflect one's life experiences.

illustrations.title: Becky's Flower Instructions
illustrations.text: Becky has told me for many years that she's sure she'll die before me, and she doesn't want people bringing flowers to her funeral. Instead, she wants flowers given to her while she's alive and to other women she knows. She specifically said not to put flowers on the grave, emphasizing to give them when it matters. This personal story shows how to bless others in advance.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that we should plan our funerals to reflect our values and bless our loved ones.

illustrations.title: Matterhorn Childhood Fear
illustrations.text: I remember going on the Matterhorn as a kid, seeing people go off and hearing them scream, which made me terrified but curious since they all came out alive. It's like facing death—it's fearful because it's unknown, even if you're not afraid of the end itself. I've never experienced it before, so it's natural to hesitate.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the fear and uncertainty surrounding death, emphasizing that it's a common human experience.

illustrations.title: Words for the Dying
illustrations.text: When talking to people who are dying, I like to say things like, 'When you get there, look up these people for me, like my dad or my friend Fred, and tell them hi from me—I'll see them soon.' This reassures them that there's real life after death, and it's a place where they can connect with loved ones. I do this because I'm confident in the afterlife, and it helps both them and me realize heaven is real.
illustrations.context: This example shows how to comfort the dying by affirming the reality of heaven and eternal life.

illustrations.title: Funeral Video Tribute
illustrations.text: At Michael Swanson's funeral, we played a clip of his last sermon where he talked about how heaven is better than anything else. This was more powerful than any words I could say, as it let Mike share his own view of heaven. I also recorded a short video myself, saying things like, 'I hope you miss me, and I love you— you can be with us in heaven by surrendering to the Lord.'
illustrations.context: This illustrates the importance of preparing and sharing personal messages about heaven to comfort those left behind.

illustrations.title: Jim Elliot's Diary Quote
illustrations.text: Like with Jim Elliot, the martyr and young Christian missionary who died for his faith when the Auca Indians killed him, he had written in his diary: 'When the time comes to die, make sure that all you have to do is die.' This means you should take care of your unfinished business and ensure that all your family is willing to be around you and one another on the day you die. If you're at odds with someone, do what you can to forgive, because you can control your own actions to make that happen.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to stress the importance of resolving conflicts and unfinished business before death to ensure peace in relationships.

illustrations.title: Worship Chaos and True Joy
illustrations.text: As soon as I walked into the hall for our worship service, I was instantly stressed because none of our cords were working and the speakers had problems—it was basically a disaster. I was wearing a shirt that says 'I've still got joy and chaos' and a hat that says 'Be glad,' but inside, I felt the complete opposite of what I was presenting. After the worship, I talked to Dion, who played drums, and he pointed out that all that matters is the kids were up front worshiping, which helped me regain perspective.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to illustrate the importance of maintaining joy and focusing on true worship despite stressful and chaotic circumstances.

illustrations.title: Baptism Mindset Example
illustrations.text: Pastor Bob mentioned an example from someone who shared that they were stoned during their baptism. They just went along with the crowd because everyone else was doing it and didn't think much of it at the time. He pointed out that if you weren't in the right mindset, it's worth considering being baptized again to make it meaningful. This highlights the importance of being spiritually prepared for such a step.
illustrations.context: This illustrates when someone might need to be re-baptized if they weren't in the proper spiritual state during their original baptism.

illustrations.title: Skating with Grandchildren Adventure
illustrations.text: I went with my grandchildren recently and intended to do nothing but watch them and videotape them. But my grandson begged me to go out there and asked if I was afraid. He said, 'What do you mean? Are you afraid I'll run over you?' We had the time of our life, and I didn't fall at all. I'm not hoping that will happen next time, but it was great.
illustrations.context: To encourage participation in the skate night by showing that it's enjoyable even if one is hesitant.

illustrations.title: Physical Laws Example
illustrations.text: We all know physical laws; we grow up learning them, sometimes the hard way. If I poke around an electric socket, I shouldn't be shocked if I find myself fried. If I jump off a 10-story building, I might wake up in a hospital broken and battered. These examples show how the laws of electricity and gravity are consistent, just as God created them.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that just as physical laws govern the universe consistently, spiritual laws do the same, leading to blessings or burdens based on obedience.

illustrations.title: Biblical Tribes Retelling
illustrations.text: Before the children of Israel enter the Promised Land, God tells Moses to separate the tribes into six and six. They will recite all the blessings of God's law, and the other six tribes will recite all the curses. In other words, God lays it out clearly: if you live according to my laws, you'll be blessed; if not, you'll be burdened. This story emphasizes that God sets before us life and death, urging us to choose life.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that God presents clear choices of blessings for obedience and curses for disobedience.

illustrations.title: Choose Life Quote
illustrations.text: God said at the end of it, 'I've set before you life and death.' He then urges, 'Choose life.' In other words, this means your future direction isn't controlled by fate but by the choices you make, leading to God's blessings or burdens. Pastor Bob connects this to emphasize that we can grow in blessings through good choices or suffer from bad ones.
illustrations.context: This quote illustrates the point that individuals must actively choose obedience to God's laws for blessings.

illustrations.title: Trust and Obey Hymn
illustrations.text: We have that great hymn, 'Trust and obey, for there's no other way to be happy in Jesus but to trust and obey.' It's true, as the hymn says, when we walk with the Lord. Pastor Bob explains that this hymn reinforces the idea that trusting and obeying God is the path to happiness and blessings in Christ.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize that trusting and obeying God's word is essential for experiencing happiness and blessings.

illustrations.title: Idolatry from Romans 1
illustrations.text: In Romans 1, it says though man knows there's a God and He's worthy to be honored as God, he refuses to acknowledge God or give thanks. But he became corrupt in his thinking and instead of worshiping the unseen God, starts to make images of God. There's something uniquely innately religious about man; he wants to find something to worship even though God has revealed Himself, and so man historically and still to this day finds other things to give credit to that really belong to God.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to illustrate how idolatry stems from man's refusal to honor God, leading to a reduction of God's true nature.

illustrations.title: Peanut-Sized God Quote
illustrations.text: My professor at Biola used to say, 'You have a peanut-sized god.' This means we often view God as small and powerless, as if nothing is too difficult for Him, yet we act like He won't intervene. God asked Abram, 'Is there something too difficult for me?' but we doubt His ability to heal or answer prayers.
illustrations.context: To illustrate that people have a diminished view of God's power and fail to expect much from Him.

illustrations.title: Expect Great Things Quote
illustrations.text: William Carey said, 'Expect great things from God; attempt great things for God.' This quote reminds us that the Lord is honored when we believe He will show up and act, even if the results differ from our expectations. By having high expectations, we avoid dishonoring God by assuming He won't do anything.
illustrations.context: To encourage believers to have bold expectations of God and actively trust in His ability to work.

illustrations.title: Saul Among Prophets
illustrations.text: I say, is this Saul among the prophets? If you don't know what that question means, go back and read why it became a proverb in Israel. It was the last thing you'd expect from Saul in the Old Testament that he would be prophesying, but he did. The point is, if that can happen, then who knows what God wants to do next.
illustrations.context: To illustrate that God can bring about unexpected changes in people, emphasizing living by faith.

illustrations.title: Roe v Wade Example
illustrations.text: Maybe it's a little closer to home, like Roe versus Wade that'll never be overturned. You think something isn't going to happen because you haven't seen it yet. This shows that what seems impossible can actually occur.
illustrations.context: To demonstrate that events thought impossible can happen, encouraging faith in God's possibilities.

illustrations.title: Police Work Schedules
illustrations.text: When I started as a police officer, I remember they worked four tens, which is 40 hours but with three days off every week—it felt like a three-day weekend. Then another department did 3-12s, and I thought it was even better because it didn't add up to 40 hours exactly, but we made it work. From our perspective, an extra day off wouldn't be a big deal, just like observing the Sabbath.
illustrations.context: To contrast modern work attitudes with ancient ones, showing how keeping the Sabbath requires faith and trust in God's provision.

illustrations.title: Young Christian Music Experience
illustrations.text: Years ago, when I was a young Christian around 16 or 17, I went to a concert in the tent with groups like Love Song and Children of the Day, who were out doing ministry. I had never heard Christian rock and roll before, and it was exciting to see people my age sharing their faith through music and personal testimonies. They had a song called 'Silver Packages' that talked about silver packages all tied with string, sitting in heaven ready to send, but held up because there's no address label, illustrating how God wants to bless us with the power of the Holy Spirit, yet our unbelief and disobedience can quench it.
illustrations.context: This story shows how God is ready to provide blessings and the Holy Spirit, but unbelief and disobedience can hinder them.

illustrations.title: J Vernon McGee on Iffy Chapter
illustrations.text: J. Vernon McGee calls chapter 26 an 'iffy' chapter, describing it as an iffy section of the Bible where the word 'if' is used 43 times, 'then' 27 times, and 'I will' (God speaking) 25 times. He emphasizes that 'if' is one of the smallest yet biggest words in the Bible, highlighting its significance in conditional promises. This connects to how such words reflect God's readiness to act based on our response.
illustrations.context: This quote underscores the importance of conditional language in the Bible, illustrating how small words like 'if' carry weight in understanding God's promises.

illustrations.title: Israel's Conditional Promised Land
illustrations.text: See the children of Israel were given the Promised Land, it was theirs, but God said that depending on how they behaved, they would or would not get to enjoy it. It's not that God would take it away, it's still theirs, but they might not enjoy it. We're seeing these conditional promises in the same way that God tells us there are things that are ours as believers that we can enjoy, but just being a Christian doesn't automatically mean we're enjoying them.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that God's blessings are conditional and can be possessed without being enjoyed, emphasizing the need to follow God's statutes.

illustrations.title: Overwhelming Abundance of Blessings
illustrations.text: He uses this illustration in verse five that men, you're not going to be able to catch up with the way I'm going to bless you. You get done with one thing and there will be another provision. This shows perpetual provision from God, like an endless cycle of blessings.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that God's blessings will be so abundant that people won't be able to keep up, highlighting His generous provision.

illustrations.title: Chasing the Elusive Butterfly
illustrations.text: A lot of people don't have a clue why they're on the planet, so they pursue happiness like it's a right, but they haven't found it yet. It's kind of like that elusive butterfly of love that just keeps flying around. You keep trying to chase it down, but it never works, showing that true fulfillment isn't found in chasing happiness.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that pursuing happiness alone leads to frustration, as people were designed to bring glory to God, not just seek personal fulfillment.

illustrations.title: Short-Lived Toy Excitement
illustrations.text: It's pretty exciting on Christmas Eve when you're seven, until you open the box and find underwear, or it's the Whammo Rock'em Sock'em Robot you wanted. You get that BB gun or Barbie doll, and it's cool and awesome for a while, but then you see a new model or your friend's isn't broken like yours, and the joy fades quickly. These kinds of fulfillments are very short-lived, just like seeking pleasure in life.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that worldly pleasures are temporary and lead to frustration.

illustrations.title: God-Shaped Void Quote
illustrations.text: Pascal said God made man with a God-shaped void in him, like a puzzle piece missing inside of you. You may not know or believe it, but until you discover Christ and give your life to Him, you'll never know why you were made. You can go through life looking for fulfillment, but it's right there in front of you.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob explains that only God can fill the inner void, emphasizing that true purpose comes from Christ.

illustrations.title: Life as a Prison Sentence
illustrations.text: Some people don't like their life and wish it were over, as I know people right now who would like to check out, even some Christians. A long life feels like a prison sentence if you hate it. This highlights the sadness of living without true purpose.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates that a long life without meaning is undesirable, underscoring the need for abundant life in Christ.

illustrations.title: Pastor Bob's Fruit Discovery
illustrations.text: I don't know much about fruit, but I've learned more about it this year by actually eating it. For years, I didn't particularly love fruit; I respected it, and if you did, good for you—have some celery with it for fiber. But my lifestyle has changed, and I actually started really enjoying fruit, particularly apples and navel oranges. They're one of my main staples now.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses his personal experience to relate to the concept of fruit, leading into a discussion about spiritual fruit and abiding in Christ.

illustrations.title: Tree Producing Fruit Analogy
illustrations.text: A tree does not produce fruit and then eat it. If you have an orange tree at home, it's producing fruit, but the tree doesn't say, 'I'm hungry, let me eat that fruit.' Get that on video if you see it happening. We are to produce fruit because fruit is the life of the tree, the vine.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates that Christians should produce spiritual fruit for others through abiding in Christ, not for their own consumption.

illustrations.title: Fear's Contagious Impact
illustrations.text: I know people, believers who struggle with anxiety and fear, and it's not always a spiritual thing, but fear can be contagious. You can breed fear, and anyone who's gone to scary movies knows that you've paid to be scared. If you're not sure that fear is contagious, just ask Penny.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating how fear can bind people and affect believers, making it a tragic force even without real threats.

illustrations.title: Roof Collapse Insurance Tale
illustrations.text: I remember when our roof over the gymnasium collapsed after we bought and started rehabbing the building. The entire roof caved in, shearing off the fire sprinkler system, which flooded the 52,000 square foot building—the elevator was underwater, and water destroyed the drywall everywhere; it was a sight to behold. I was on a big cherry picker high above, looking at the damage while a news helicopter hovered overhead, and I was on the phone with our new insurance company. The agent said roof collapses are almost never covered, but as I explained what happened, he checked the subsections and found it qualified under 'improper workmanship,' so it was totally covered.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to illustrate how God's provisions for peace, like insurance conditions, ensure coverage for believers.

illustrations.title: Jesus in the Storm
illustrations.text: Listen, who's at total rest in the storm in the Gospels? That's Jesus. The disciples were freaking out because the boat was filling with water and they thought they were going to die, so they woke Jesus up and said, 'Don't you care that we're perishing?' Jesus rebuked the storm, calming the wind and waves, and then He rebuked them for their lack of faith. After that, the disciples were even more amazed, wondering who this man was that could control the weather.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show how Jesus had perfect peace in chaos, illustrating that believers can experience the peace of God by focusing on Him.

illustrations.title: Abraham's Test of Faith
illustrations.text: Kind of like Abraham, how could he possibly kill his son when God asked him? I mean, I'm sorry, I can't do that—God hasn't called me to it, and my sons would be happy to hear that. Abraham had to trust God completely, even in something that seemed impossible, knowing God's plan was greater. God provided a way out for Abraham, just as He did with His own Son.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize unwavering faith and peace in God's promises, similar to how Jesus knew His purpose.

illustrations.title: Scary Ride Analogy
illustrations.text: When I go on a scary ride, which I rarely do, it's not because I don't like them, but because I get sick easily on things like the teacups or the Tilt-A-Whirl—some maniac created that ride without considering motion sickness. If I do go on a first-time scary ride, I don't really think I'm going to die, even though I joke that a few people might be buried at the end. I know it's designed and checked by humans who aren't perfect, but I'm okay with it because it's just meant to scare me and it's under control, much like trusting God in tough situations.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that we can have peace and trust in God during scary circumstances, knowing things are under control.

illustrations.title: TV Test Pattern Example
illustrations.text: Remember when we were growing up, the test pattern would come on TV in the middle of a show, before DVRs existed, with a beeping sound for the emergency broadcast system. They announced it was a test, and if it had been real, you'd already be dead, though they suggested hiding under the couch for safety. The point is, we need to hear that old test pattern every time we're in an unexpected circumstance we don't know how to handle, as the Lord is saying He's testing our faith right now, so relax.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that God tests our faith in unexpected situations, encouraging us to remain calm.

illustrations.title: Max Lucado Storm Quote
illustrations.text: I think it's Max Lucado who has a book or article that says Jesus stills storms, and He does. But more often than not, when we're in the midst of the storm, the Lord is willing to still the storm inside of His child and let the storm outside rage. This highlights how God provides internal peace even when external chaos continues.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that God often calms our inner turmoil rather than stopping external storms.

illustrations.title: Adam and Eve's Fall
illustrations.text: We know this; we've studied it before. Adam is with Eve in the garden, with one tree they can't eat from. The serpent beguiles Eve into seeing the fruit from the tree of the knowledge of good and evil. The Bible never calls it an apple; it doesn't specify what fruit it is—some think it's a pomegranate, I have no idea, I don't think it was a navel orange anyway. Whatever it was, it was off limits, the forbidden fruit. She sees that it's a delight to the eyes, desirable to make one wise, and good for food, covering the three areas of temptation.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show how the enemy tempts through the lust of the flesh, eyes, and pride, leading to Adam's failure.

illustrations.title: Jesus' Wilderness Temptation
illustrations.text: Adam and Eve failed in the Garden of Eden, where every provision and pleasure was available, with no reason they couldn't have their needs met in other ways. Then Jesus, called the last Adam, comes on the scene and faces every temptation in those three spheres, but not in a garden—in the wilderness. It's interesting how the settings differ, yet the temptations are the same. What does Jesus use to overcome them? The sword of the Spirit with three precision responses: 'It is written,' 'It is written,' 'It is written.'
illustrations.context: This illustrates that believers can achieve victorious battles against temptation using the Word of God, as Jesus did.

illustrations.title: Jonathan's Faith in Battle
illustrations.text: Then Jonathan climbed up on his hands and feet with his armor bearer behind him, and they fell before Jonathan. His armor bearer put some to death after him, and that first slaughter which Jonathan and his armor bearer made was about twenty. It's interesting that one guy decides to go up against this unbeatable army, the Philistines, who had held them in bondage for years. Just by faith, one guy up there brings the Philistine army down like a hot knife through butter, wiping them out. It's an incredible passage of what God does by faith.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate how faith in God can lead to overwhelming victory against overwhelming odds.

illustrations.title: Israel's Modern Wars
illustrations.text: Both the Independence Day War and the Six-Day War, but especially the Yom Kippur War in 1973, show God's hand in the affairs of men. Yom Kippur is the holiest day in Israel, and the nation is more shut down than on any other day, making the attack by eight Arab nations a shock. These nations, especially Egypt and Syria, were committed to destroying Israel, with other Arab nations joining them. It's a real event that highlights how God protects and forms the nation of Israel against great odds.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to demonstrate God's ongoing involvement in Israel's conflicts as an encouragement of divine providence.

illustrations.title: Israel's Yom Kippur Victory
illustrations.text: The Arab nations, including Iraq, Jordan, Algeria, Morocco, Kuwait, and Saudi Arabia, attacked Israel with overwhelming force and support from Russia, facing a 12 to 1 ratio in armaments. Israel was unprepared and suffered initial losses, but they repaired and reused 600 of their 1,000 damaged tanks while destroying 400 enemy tanks and capturing others for their own use. In the end, Israel had no net loss of tanks, shot down 514 Arab aircraft with only five losses, and sank 19 enemy naval vessels without losing any ships, all while facing 2,800 Israeli soldier deaths compared to 18,000 enemy casualties. This demonstrates how Israel overcame impossible odds.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate God's faithfulness and protection for His people even when they are unprepared and outnumbered.

illustrations.title: One Tank Hero's Defense
illustrations.text: There's a fascinating story about a man named Zavika Greengold, a tank operator for Israel during the war in Galilee. He held off the entire Syrian army using just one tank by constantly moving positions among the hills, appearing in different spots to attack and confuse the enemy. Reports say he took out 20 to 60 enemy tanks, making the Syrians believe they were facing a much larger force. This shows how one individual can stand against overwhelming aggression.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to highlight God's ability to empower individuals to defend His people against great odds.

illustrations.title: God Speaking Through Pastor
illustrations.text: People have told me over the years that the Lord was speaking to them through me, and just this last week, men came to me asking if their wives had called me because I seemed to know their personal thoughts. I don't confirm or deny it, but I know that God's Spirit searches everyone's heart and knows what they're thinking and going through. It's no surprise that He loves you enough to prompt me to say something unplanned, whether in my notes or off the cuff, because He wants to speak directly to you and make His presence felt.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how God actively speaks through believers to reveal truths and convict people, emphasizing the importance of allowing the Holy Spirit to work in relationships and gatherings.

illustrations.title: Joshua and the Promised Land
illustrations.text: In Joshua chapter one and verse three, Moses is gone and Joshua is taking the leadership role of the children of Israel into the Promised Land and across the Jordan. God said to him, every place on which the sole of your foot treads, I've given it to you just as I spoke to Moses. It's not just about geography or drawing lines on a map; if you're going to actually have the land, you have to walk in it. Until you walk in God's promise, it's just a possibility, not a reality.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize that God's promises require active obedience and walking in them to be fully realized.

illustrations.title: Walking in the Promise
illustrations.text: God doesn't just say we're going to divide up the land and here's your map with lines around your territory. It's not just about geography; if you're going to actually possess it, you have to walk in it. Many of God's promises could have been for Christians but remain unrealized because they don't take that step. God's will involves not just delighting in or discussing His word, but actually doing it.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that merely knowing God's promises, like having a map, isn't enough; one must actively engage and walk in them to experience the blessings.

illustrations.title: Fountain of Truth Quote
illustrations.text: There's an old saying that few people drink from the fountain of truth; most only gargle. In other words, people can talk about truth, get excited about it, and say things like 'I learned a new truth I never heard before,' but that doesn't mean they're fully engaging with it. This highlights that merely hearing or discussing truth isn't enough; you need to internalize and act on it for real benefit.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that simply hearing God's word without doing it leads to self-deception and no real blessing.

illustrations.title: Sheep and Goats Judgment
illustrations.text: Someone once said it this way: God's Christ is going to come back and God is going to separate the nations as the sheep and the goats. It's going to be based on what we did, not on how much we read. I think that's a good point because it shows that faith is about actions, not just knowledge.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is emphasizing that faith is measured by actions and deeds, not by intellectual knowledge.

illustrations.title: Pastor's Time Passing Story
illustrations.text: I remember when I turned 30, I was in the ministry and thought this is when Jesus began his ministry. It seemed like right away I was turning 33, and I realized how quickly time passes. I've hardly started, but time goes by fast, and things change when we least expect it.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how quickly time passes and how change comes unexpectedly, relating to the disciples' brief time with Jesus.

illustrations.title: Raymond's Leadership Growth Analogy
illustrations.text: If you're not careful, the first thing you're great at will be the only thing you're good for, because you get so accustomed to being good at something that you think that's all God wants to use you for. Over the years, God has gifted me in raising up other leaders, and I've learned through attending seminary and serving under Pastor Bob that He equips us for more. It's really about discipleship and pouring into others in daily life.
illustrations.context: This analogy emphasizes the importance of growing beyond one's initial gifts and embracing new areas of ministry as part of God's calling.

illustrations.title: Aircraft Carrier Analogy
illustrations.text: Rocky said it's like we're an aircraft carrier with all these fighter jets just sitting there ready to go, and anytime we want, we can send one out and still have plenty in reserve. I thought that was really cool. This illustrates the church's potential and readiness.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating the church's abundant resources and ability to send out members for ministry.

illustrations.title: Church Vote Confirmation Story
illustrations.text: We visited a church in Carlinville, Illinois, that has been without a pastor for over a year and has faced some hurt and hardships. I took my dad there to convince me not to go, but he failed. That morning, I felt the Lord saying we needed at least 90% approval in their vote, and they came back with 99%, which was a clear confirmation.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is showing how God provides clear signs and confirmation when following His call.

illustrations.title: Healthy Church Quote
illustrations.text: Somebody from our worship team texted me saying, 'You're at a healthy church when there are people going out planting and pastoring other flocks.' This connects to our situation with Pastor Mike leaving and us preparing to go, showing that a thriving church sends out leaders. Pastor Bob uses this to highlight the strength and outreach of their fellowship.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is emphasizing that a healthy church actively sends out members to start new ministries.

illustrations.title: Young Woman's Marriage Quote
illustrations.text: Pastor Bob shares the story of a young woman who said that when she got married, she was looking for the ideal, but instead found an ordeal, and now she wants a new deal. This illustrates the disappointment when commitments are not upheld. He uses it to emphasize that many people make vows like 'I do' but fail to live them out, as shown by divorce statistics. The point is to avoid such regret by maintaining integrity in promises.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to show the consequences of not keeping marriage vows, highlighting how initial commitments can lead to regret if not followed through.

illustrations.title: Reagan's No-Fault Divorce Law
illustrations.text: Pastor Bob explains that no-fault divorce began in California in 1969 when Governor Ronald Reagan signed it into law as the first state in the Union. Reagan later called it the worst piece of legislation he ever signed, even though he had been divorced himself. This historical event spread across the country, making it easier to end marriages without proving fault. Pastor Bob connects it to the importance of keeping vows before God, warning against treating commitments lightly.
illustrations.context: This reference underscores the seriousness of vows and how societal changes, like no-fault divorce, reflect a decline in honoring commitments, which God values.

illustrations.title: Counting Bible Promises
illustrations.text: A man took a year and a half of his life to read through the Bible meticulously, keeping track of every single promise in it. This was later written up in a book by Herbert Lockyer, who referenced this Canadian guy named Stone on his 27th reading of the Bible. Stone identified a total of 7487 promises from God to man, highlighting the abundance of God's commitments in Scripture. Pastor Bob notes that this number is impressive and suggests that one could focus on about 20 promises a day to understand and claim them.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this example to emphasize the vast number of God's promises in the Bible, illustrating God's reliability as the original promise keeper.

illustrations.title: Job's Desire for Permanent Words
illustrations.text: I think of what Job said. I love this passage from Job 19 verses 23 and 24. He said, 'Oh that my words were written, oh that they were inscribed in a book.' Well, he got that wish, that with an iron stylus and lead they were engraved in the rock forever.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize the trustworthiness and permanence of commitments, contrasting human words with God's unchanging promises.

illustrations.title: Jephthah's Costly Vow
illustrations.text: Jephthah prayed to God, saying that if God gave him victory over the enemy, he would sacrifice the first thing that came out of his house. God granted the victory, and to his horror, his daughter emerged first. Jephthah had intended to sacrifice an animal, but instead, he had to dedicate his daughter to the Lord, meaning she would never marry or have children. This was a huge sacrifice for both of them, as he fulfilled his vow despite the pain. It's a story that shows the consequences of rash promises.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize the importance of keeping vows, even when they cause personal hurt, as Jephthah did.

illustrations.title: Joshua's Deceived Covenant
illustrations.text: Joshua made a commitment to the Gibeonites without seeking God's guidance first. The Gibeonites deceived him by pretending to come from a distant land, using moldy bread and worn-out clothes as props. Joshua examined their provisions and entered into a protective covenant with them, only to later discover they were local inhabitants who should have been driven out. This story highlights how even a godly man like Joshua can err by not consulting God. The consequences of that decision affected Israel greatly.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate the need to seek God's counsel before making important decisions, as failing to do so led to unintended outcomes.

illustrations.title: Disappearing Ink Analogy
illustrations.text: I remember as a kid being told about invisible ink or disappearing ink, and how cool it was because you could write something and it would just go away, though it never really worked well. We had those little pads where you could write and then lift it up, like an Etch A Sketch, and it would erase. Now with technology, apps like Signal and WhatsApp let you send messages that disappear after five seconds to a week, so you can send a message and have it self-destruct. I think about how our spoken words seem to disappear into thin air. But according to the Bible, they become part of God's permanent record.
illustrations.context: To show that words have eternal consequences despite seeming temporary.

illustrations.title: Mildred the Church Gossip
illustrations.text: Mildred was the church gossip who appointed herself the monitor of church morals, making sure people behaved. She accused a newer member named George of being an alcoholic after seeing his pickup truck parked outside a bar. George didn't deny or debate; he simply waited for his truck to be fixed and then parked it in front of her house overnight as a quiet response. This story illustrates how assumptions can lead to misunderstandings. Pastor Bob shared it to highlight the impact of words, even if it's not directly about vows.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to emphasize the consequences of gossip and hasty judgments, connecting it to the broader theme of words having lasting effects.

illustrations.title: Recorded Phone Conversations
illustrations.text: Every one of us has called a company and heard the message that the conversation may be recorded for training purposes. I did it just yesterday, and we often don't think much about it. But Pastor Bob points out that this is a reminder of how words can be captured and preserved. This leads into the idea that our spoken words have eternal significance, much like those recordings.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal experience to illustrate that every word we speak has eternal consequences, similar to how phone conversations are recorded permanently.

illustrations.title: Sound Waves and Voyager
illustrations.text: Sound waves go out beyond our atmosphere and never stop; they continue infinitely. For example, we still receive radio transmissions from the Voyager spacecraft, which has left our solar system, and it takes hours for the messages to reach us. This shows how words and broadcasts persist forever, just like the impact of our speech. Pastor Bob connects this to the idea that our words have lasting, eternal effects on people's lives.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to demonstrate that words we speak, like sound waves or radio signals, have an infinite and eternal impact.

illustrations.title: Rescission Rights for Purchases
illustrations.text: If you get a mortgage, there's a three-day right of rescission in California, allowing you to undo it if you have buyer's remorse. Similarly, if you buy a new car, you have 48 hours to return it and change your mind. This protection exists because it's easy to make a hasty decision and later regret it.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how laws provide safeguards for impulsive decisions, mirroring God's provisions for protecting vulnerable people from rash vows.

illustrations.title: Minors' Legal Restrictions in California
illustrations.text: In California, a minor cannot legally sign a contract until they are 18, get a tattoo, get married, have their ears pierced, or skydive without parental consent. However, laws allow minors to get an abortion or birth control without their parents' knowledge. This contrast highlights inconsistencies in how society protects vulnerable individuals.
illustrations.context: This example shows the inconsistency in modern laws regarding child protection, emphasizing the need for parental involvement as per biblical principles.

illustrations.title: California Lawsuit on Gender Notification
illustrations.text: Recently, the state of California is suing a school in Chino Valley because the school requires parents to be notified if a child wants to identify as a different gender. The state claims this protects children from telling their parents, which the pastor finds tragic and misguided. This event illustrates the ongoing cultural battle over parental rights and child protection.
illustrations.context: This references a real event to highlight how current laws undermine the biblical role of fathers and husbands in safeguarding their families.

illustrations.title: Husband Challenging Vow
illustrations.text: If a wife makes commitments, like buying something on credit, and the husband hears about it, he can step in and say no, tearing up the credit card and returning the items. They're not going through with buying that condominium or whatever was signed up for. This shows how authority figures can intervene to prevent harm.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that those in authority, like husbands or fathers, must speak up to protect against harmful decisions.

illustrations.title: Pastor's Confession on Silence
illustrations.text: I have noticed that I tend to speak when I should be silent and be silent when I should speak. This is just a confession about my own struggles. It's something I deal with, highlighting the challenge of knowing the right times to talk or stay quiet.
illustrations.context: This personal admission emphasizes the importance of speaking up when necessary and remaining silent at other times.

illustrations.title: Job's Friends and Silence
illustrations.text: When you read the book of Job, he suffered horrible losses, including his children, wealth, health, and reputation. His friends came from a long distance after hearing about his troubles and initially said nothing; they just sat with him for seven days, weeping in silence. Then, they started speaking, filling chapters with accusations about why this happened to him, insisting he needed to get right with God even though he hadn't done anything wrong. Job called them miserable comforters, as their words made him feel worthless and forced him to defend himself. It's interesting how they were helpful when silent but harmful when they spoke, showing that sometimes just being present is enough for someone in pain.
illustrations.context: This story underscores that God holds us accountable for our silence when we should speak up to protect others from harm.

illustrations.title: Break It You Bought It Analogy
illustrations.text: You ever been in a store that had one of those signs on the stuff that says you break it, you bought it? It's like if you don't speak up when the opportunity is there, you're actually giving credence to the decision. Even if you have a right to remain silent, it's never right to remain silent if your silence causes people to be bound by something they shouldn't be or destruction comes into their life. This principle applies broadly. God expects timely action in such matters.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to illustrate that failing to speak up in time means accepting responsibility for the consequences, just as breaking an item in a store obligates you to buy it.

illustrations.title: Ezekiel Watchman Quote
illustrations.text: In Ezekiel 33, the first seven verses, God speaks to Ezekiel, saying son of man, speak to the sons of your people and say to them if I bring a sword upon the land and the people take one man as their watchman, and he sees the sword coming and blows the trumpet to warn the people, then if someone hears and doesn't take warning, their blood is on their own head. But if the watchman sees the danger and doesn't blow the trumpet, the people aren't warned, and blood is required from the watchman's hand. God appoints Ezekiel as a watchman for Israel, emphasizing the need to deliver warnings from God. This teaches that failing to speak up leads to accountability.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to show that God expects people to warn others of danger, just as a watchman must sound the alarm, or they bear responsibility for the outcome.

illustrations.title: Parents and Tattoos Example
illustrations.text: We don't want to tell a child who wants to do something no, so it's easier to let them do it even if it's not best. For instance, when you agree to let a child get a tattoo, I know people who take their kids out of state to make it happen. This illustrates how avoiding confrontation can lead to poor decisions. God expects us to love each other enough to speak the truth.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this example to emphasize that remaining silent when we should speak up can allow destructive choices, like getting a tattoo, and we must intervene out of love.

illustrations.title: Watchman Analogy
illustrations.text: As a believer, you're the watchman. Every unbeliever is asleep, and you're the one who realizes the enemy's coming for them. So, are you willing to warn them that judgment is coming and they need to get right with the Lord? Because if we're silent, we become complicit in their decision not to prepare for the Lord's coming.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to emphasize the responsibility of believers to warn unbelievers about impending judgment.

illustrations.title: Judas and Peter Contrast
illustrations.text: Jesus will say to people, 'I never knew you,' as evidenced by their sinful lives. Judas appeared to be one of Jesus' followers; he betrayed him, admitted his sin by returning the money, and showed worldly sorrow that led to his death. In contrast, Peter also betrayed Jesus but experienced godly sorrow, leading to repentance and restoration, making Peter and Judas a study in opposites, like Saul and David.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob retells these stories to illustrate the difference between worldly sorrow that leads to death and godly sorrow that leads to repentance.

illustrations.title: Heart and Mouth Duet Quote
illustrations.text: I like what Jay Vernon McGee says: God expects the heart and the mouth to sing a duet to prove that there's integrity and authenticity to our commitment to the Lord. This quote highlights how our inner beliefs and outward words must align. Pastor Bob uses it to connect to the idea of living out faith genuinely.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that true commitment to the Lord requires both heartfelt belief and verbal confession to demonstrate authenticity.

illustrations.title: Marriage Vows as Commitment
illustrations.text: If you are married or ever get married, you probably said vows like promising to love and cherish your spouse for better or worse, for richer or poorer, in sickness and in health, till death do you part. I do weddings, and people often ask if they can include unique elements, like entering on a trapeze—I tell them as long as they're making a lifetime commitment of fidelity before God, I'm willing to be part of it, and everything else is just tradition. This example shows how vows are a serious promise that should be lived out, much like our commitment to the Lord.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that just as marriage vows require ongoing faithfulness, a commitment to the Lord must be lived out in real life.

illustrations.title: Lord's Prayer Reminder
illustrations.text: Jesus said when you pray, pray like this. Do you remember what he said? It's the Lord's Prayer: Our Father Who Art in Heaven, let your name be holy. That's a prayer request, but it's interesting because when I'm aware of my sin, I want to start by confessing. However, the prayer doesn't begin with that; it gets to forgiveness later. God wants you to recognize Him as your Father first, assuring you of His love.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses the Lord's Prayer to illustrate that one should start prayer by acknowledging God as Father, not immediately focusing on sins, to emphasize God's prior forgiveness.

illustrations.title: Jonah Name Blunder
illustrations.text: Some of you have heard me tell this story: my daughter-in-law was pregnant and showed me the ultrasound picture, saying I was going to be a grandpa again. She told me it was a boy named Jonah, and I responded, 'Wow, like Jonah and the whale.' I didn't mean it that way, and she was very forgiving. Have you ever said something you instantly regretted?
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate how he unintentionally offends people with his words, showing that everyone struggles with speech and needs forgiveness.

illustrations.title: TV Commercials Excusing Fault
illustrations.text: I can't tell you how many commercials I've seen on TV where it's not your fault. They don't say it outright, but basically, they make it seem like nothing is ever your fault—it's because of how you were brought up, society, or your hormones. Listen, just own it.
illustrations.context: To demonstrate how society often shifts blame away from personal responsibility, preventing true confession of sin.

illustrations.title: Fonzie's Apology Struggle
illustrations.text: You remember how Fonzie couldn't say sorry? There was an episode where he needed to apologize for something that had happened, but as a prideful cool guy who thought he was perfect, he kept trying to say 'I'm sorry' and couldn't get the words out. Finally, someone told him it was okay not to, which illustrates how pride blocks true repentance.
illustrations.context: To show that pride and reluctance to admit wrongdoing, like Fonzie's, prevent people from confessing sin and receiving forgiveness.

illustrations.title: Peter's Denial and Jesus' Intercession
illustrations.text: I mentioned how Peter made this big commitment to Jesus, remembering that Jesus prophesied all of his disciples would betray him because scripture said the shepherd would be struck and the sheep scattered. Peter insisted it wouldn't happen to him, saying the others might deny Jesus but not him, even claiming he'd die for him. Jesus responded by revealing that Satan had requested permission to sift Peter like wheat, but Jesus had prayed for him. This shows Peter as part of the bride, with Jesus speaking up for him despite his failure, just as he does for us today. So, our bridegroom takes the responsibility and intercedes when we can't live up to our commitments.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that Jesus always speaks up for us and intercedes during our failures, emphasizing his role as the bridegroom.

illustrations.title: Hymn of Jesus' Intercession
illustrations.text: I love that hymn that says, 'And now for me he stands before the Father's throne, he shows his wounded hands and names me for his own. For me he died, for me he lived an everlasting life, and in life and light he freely gives.' This hymn illustrates Jesus speaking up for us, emphasizing his sacrifice and advocacy. Amen, it's a powerful reminder of his love.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this hymn to show how Jesus intercedes for believers, speaking up on their behalf before God.

illustrations.title: Jesus' Departure as Advantage
illustrations.text: Father, we love this man and his family; he is a gift to us, but not just to us. Jesus, when you said to your disciples it's to your advantage that I go away, I'm sure not one of them could understand that as being a good thing, but you know best. We are grateful for these five years that Raymond and his family have been here, loving and serving people with their gifts for God's glory. This connects to how God's plans often bring greater blessings despite initial confusion.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to show that saying goodbye to Raymond is difficult but ultimately for the greater good, mirroring Jesus' words about His own departure.

illustrations.title: Prescription Analogy for Diligence
illustrations.text: Whether it's a diet or a recipe or a prescription, it's so important that you do it right. You can't mess with the ingredients of a recipe and expect it to come out right. You can't do a diet halfway and expect it to work. This illustrates how something like a prescription requires diligence to follow exactly as presented.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to emphasize the need to follow instructions precisely for achieving the desired outcome, just as in spiritual matters.

illustrations.title: Antidepressant Statistics Example
illustrations.text: A recent survey shows 15% of men in the United States and 20% of women, that's one out of five, are currently on antidepressants. These statistics are likely reflected in the congregation as well. Pastor Bob notes that while being on antidepressants isn't necessarily a sin, it could be a symptom of deeper issues, tying into the need for God's peace.
illustrations.context: This real-world example highlights the prevalence of anxiety and depression, underscoring the relevance of the biblical prescription for peace.

illustrations.title: Mary and Martha's Worry
illustrations.text: Remember when Jesus was with Mary and Martha in the home of Lazarus in Bethany? Mary sat at Jesus's feet listening to his word, while Martha was serving and noticed she was alone. She went to Jesus, asking him to tell Mary to help her, assuming he would be upset like she was. Jesus responded to Martha, saying she was worried and troubled about many things, and only one thing was necessary.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate how worry pulls us in different directions and distracts from what truly matters.

illustrations.title: Man and the Inheritance
illustrations.text: It's like that guy who came to Jesus and said, 'Tell my brother to divide the inheritance with me,' assuming Jesus would side with him. Jesus replied, 'Who made me a judge or an arbiter over you?' and warned him about greed. By the way, Jesus rebuked the man, not his brother, showing how we often project our feelings onto God.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that we shouldn't assume God shares our frustrations or judgments, especially regarding greed and worry.

illustrations.title: Worry as Misused Imagination
illustrations.text: Someone once said that worry is the wrong use of the imagination, like a dark room where our fears are developed. This means regretting your past won't change it, and getting ahead to the future only robs you of today's peace. Pastor Bob connects this to Jesus's teaching, emphasizing that worry strangles joy and peace.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to show how worry misuses our imagination and prevents us from experiencing God's peace in the present.

illustrations.title: Air India Rat Incident
illustrations.text: This happened about a year and a half ago. It was in the paper, and I found this article. An Air India plane, a national airline, was forced to turn back after a rat was spotted on board a flight from somewhere. This real event shows how even a small issue can disrupt plans, much like how we need to bring our concerns to God. Remember, just as the plane had to address the problem immediately, we should turn to our Father in prayer.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this real-world example to illustrate the importance of addressing fears and problems through prayer, emphasizing faith in God's sovereignty.

illustrations.title: Handley Page's Rat Encounter
illustrations.text: Frederick Handley Page, a pioneer in early aviation, took off in a plane over North Africa after refueling and heard a noise behind his head, realizing a rat had boarded.
