He knew the rat could chew through a hydraulic line, putting his life at risk, so he panicked at first but remembered that rats can't survive at high altitudes. He flew higher and higher until the rat died, allowing him to land safely. This story shows how facing fear requires rising above it.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this historical event to illustrate that just as Handley Page overcame the rat by going higher, we must rise to faith and prayer to defeat fear and worry.

illustrations.title: Fear as a Rodent Analogy
illustrations.text: Fear is like a rat and worry is a rodent that will eat away at you until it brings you down. However, it cannot survive in the high altitudes of faith and prayer, just as the rat in the plane couldn't breathe at higher elevations. By taking things higher spiritually, like getting on your knees before God, you can eliminate worry's grip.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to show that fear and worry lose their power in an atmosphere of faith and prayer, encouraging listeners to actively rise above them.

illustrations.title: Grandmother's Family Trials
illustrations.text: There was a Christian grandmother whose family was going through a lot of trials, and she herself was facing health problems. For many people, prayer becomes a last resort in such situations. Pastor Bob highlights this to stress that prayer should be the first response to worry and fear.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this real-world example to point out that people often treat prayer as a last resort, but it is essential for overcoming worry by remembering God's presence.

illustrations.title: Woman's Prayer as Last Resort
illustrations.text: A woman faced financial problems and all kinds of worries, and finally her son said, 'Mom, there's nothing left to do but pray about it.' She turned to me and asked, 'Has it really come to that?' I responded that it always comes to that, so why not start with prayer.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that prayer should be the first response to problems, not the last resort.

illustrations.title: Parable of Persistent Widow
illustrations.text: Jesus told a parable about a widow who needed justice and kept showing up at the courthouse of an unrighteous judge who didn't care about God, justice, or her. She persisted every day until he finally decided her case just to get rid of her. Jesus used this to teach that if even an unrighteous judge responds to persistence, how much more will your heavenly Father respond to your prayers.
illustrations.context: This story encourages believers to pray persistently and not lose heart.

illustrations.title: Watchmen Interceding Analogy
illustrations.text: It's an analogy of people who are willing to intercede and pray on your walls, O Jerusalem. I have appointed watchmen all day and all night; they will never keep silent. You who remind the Lord, take no rest for yourselves and give Him no rest until He establishes and makes Jerusalem a praise in the earth. In other words, God's promise is to do that, so now you go after Him for it.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to emphasize the need for persistent intercession and prayer to pursue God's promises.

illustrations.title: Jesus Praying in Agony
illustrations.text: Here's what the Bible says of Jesus: being in agony, He prayed more fervently. We need to learn to turn our pain into prayer and our fears into faith, as Jesus did in His moment of agony.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob retells this to illustrate how to transform pain and fears into faithful prayer.

illustrations.title: Daniel in Heathen Society
illustrations.text: Remember in the Book of Daniel, Daniel was a godly man living in pagan Babylon, a very heathen society, but God honored him because he honored God. God raised him up and put him in a position of high authority; he was loved by the king but hated and jealousied by the people around him, so they got together against him.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to show that there is always room to praise and thank God, even in challenging circumstances like Daniel's.

illustrations.title: Daniel's Faith in the Lions' Den
illustrations.text: The only way to trap Daniel was through his faith in God, so his enemies tricked the king into passing a law that anyone praying to anyone but the king would be thrown into the lions' den. Daniel knew about the law but continued his routine, kneeling three times a day to pray and give thanks to God as he always had. When his enemies caught him praying, he was arrested and thrown into the den, but God sent an angel to shut the lions' mouths, and Daniel emerged unharmed the next morning. Meanwhile, the king spent a sleepless night worrying about Daniel's fate.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate that believers can experience God's peace amid trials, rather than only when problems are solved.

illustrations.title: Jesus Rebukes Galilee Cities
illustrations.text: When Jesus was preaching in Galilee, most of his ministry in the north, he looked at the work he had done in those cities and realized people were not repenting despite his preaching and miracles. He rebuked those cities, pronouncing judgment with words like 'Woe to you, Capernaum,' and compared them to Tyre, Sidon, Sodom, and Gomorrah, saying that if those places had seen his miracles, they would have repented long ago. From Jesus' perspective, he came to seek and save the lost, teaching the gospel and performing miracles, but it wasn't working, so he praised God, saying, 'I thank you, Father, Lord of heaven and earth, that you have hidden these things from the wise and revealed them to little children.'
illustrations.context: To illustrate that even when ministry fails, one should trust in God's sovereignty and thank Him for His plan.

illustrations.title: Jesus Controls Life Storms
illustrations.text: Jesus is in charge of everything, including every storm, and he still calms storms, but more often than not, he calms the storm within his child while letting the external storm rage. This means God brings problems into your life to help you find a different kind of peace, one that surpasses understanding and isn't based on resolving circumstances. He wants to create inner peace in you, even as outer trials continue.
illustrations.context: To show that true peace comes from God calming internal turmoil rather than stopping external problems.

illustrations.title: Sued as a Pastor
illustrations.text: I was only a pastor for a few years when it happened. I had been a police officer for the first three and a half years of our church's existence and worked for Placentia PD. My chief, who was a devout Christian and elder with Pastor Chuck, and I often met for lunch to discuss church matters. When I was a cop, I was sued, which wasn't surprising, but I never expected to be sued as a pastor. It involved lies about things I hadn't done, and it hurt the church, causing confusion among people. My wife and I were praying and felt discouraged, so I called my chief for help. When we met, I hoped he'd suggest consulting Pastor Chuck, but instead, he shared a story from his own life.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate how God's peace guides and directs us through personal challenges and discouragement.

illustrations.title: Chief's Trust in God
illustrations.text: A chief of police received a call at night from one of his officers who had arrested a drunk driver, the son of the county sheriff. The chief instructed them to book him despite potential repercussions. The next day, the sheriff called and threatened his career, leaving him worried. His wife, Sharon, advised him with Proverbs 3:5-6, urging him to trust in the Lord. Later, the situation resolved when the sheriff apologized, affirming the chief's decision.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to emphasize trusting in God and not leaning on one's own understanding, as illustrated by Proverbs 3:5-6.

illustrations.title: Garbage In Garbage Out
illustrations.text: You ever heard the expression GIGO, that old computer term, garbage in garbage out? What are you putting into your brain? As a man thinketh in his heart, so is he, meaning that the input affects the output of your thoughts and emotions.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to show that what you input into your mind determines your thoughts and behavior.

illustrations.title: Horror Movie Mind Control
illustrations.text: If you've ever gone to a horror movie, you went to pay money to be freaked out. In the theater, there's no real threat; it's just actors on a screen with fake blood, yet you still get scared because of the intense music and scenes that fill your mind. Your fears and worries are directly tied to what you allow to play on the screen of your mind, and you have control over that.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates that your emotions follow what you choose to think about, emphasizing control over your thoughts.

illustrations.title: Worry Survey Results
illustrations.text: They did a survey and found that out of people worrying, only eight percent of their concerns were legitimate; ninety-two percent were completely imaginary, would never happen, or were beyond their control. This shows how most worries are unfounded. Pastor Bob uses this to remind us to focus on what's true.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob points out that most worries are not based on reality, encouraging people to think about true things instead.

illustrations.title: Feeding Anxiety Like Fire
illustrations.text: For lack of wood the fire goes out, so if you don't put firewood on the fire, it just goes out. We feed that fire of anxiety just like you go to the movie theater to be scared—you do that to yourself and even pay money for it. This shows how we voluntarily fuel our worries by choosing to think about or talk about them.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating how anxiety can be extinguished by not feeding it, similar to a fire dying without wood.

illustrations.title: Peter's Warning from Jesus
illustrations.text: Your spouse or a friend might mean well when they ask about your problems, just like Peter did when he told Jesus, 'You will surely not go to the cross.' Jesus rebuked Peter sharply, saying 'Get behind me, Satan,' because Peter was focusing on human thoughts rather than God's. This story shows how even loving intentions can distract from God's plan if they pull us away from trusting Him.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to point out that well-meaning people can unintentionally encourage worry, and we must guard our minds against such influences.

illustrations.title: THAAD Missile Defense Analogy
illustrations.text: I don't know if you know much about the THAAD system, which stands for Terminal High Altitude Area Defense, a missile defense system designed to shoot down incoming ballistic missiles. It's an amazing technology that involves firing a missile at Mach 8.3, over six thousand miles an hour, to hit another bullet-like projectile out of the sky. This illustrates how focusing on the right things gives you a built-in radar to detect and reject stray thoughts in real time.
illustrations.context: This analogy shows how guarding your thoughts is like a defense system that identifies and stops wrong ideas.

illustrations.title: Simon Says Game Example
illustrations.text: Remember playing Simon Says when you were a kid? In the game, you follow commands only if they're prefaced with 'Simon Says,' like touch your nose or chin, but if you don't, you're out. Paul is like Simon, giving an example to follow, as he says to practice the things you've learned from him. This playful reference emphasizes the importance of imitating godly examples in your life.
illustrations.context: This example illustrates the need to follow Paul's instructions and examples for living rightly.

illustrations.title: Jesus' Suffering Retelling
illustrations.text: In 1 Peter 2, Peter describes how Jesus himself suffered unjustly during his trial, when he was beaten and crucified, yet he didn't respond with anger or retaliation. Instead, Jesus remained silent like a lamb led to slaughter and entrusted himself to God, who judges righteously. This story serves as an example for us to follow in his steps, enduring hardship with faith and trust.
illustrations.context: This retelling emphasizes following Jesus' example of patient suffering and trust in God for peace.

illustrations.title: Pastor Chuck's Advice
illustrations.text: Pastor Chuck Smith said while he was alive that we shouldn't just do what he did or try to replicate everything exactly, like getting a tent and starting something like Maranatha, because the Spirit of God is always doing something new and fresh. He encouraged singing a new song to the Lord and not turning into a denomination that just copies the past. Pastor Bob uses this to warn against becoming stagnant and to emphasize that while Chuck left important principles, we must let the Spirit work in fresh ways.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to illustrate the importance of following godly patterns without blindly imitating the past, encouraging spiritual growth and innovation.

illustrations.title: Doctor Prescription Analogy
illustrations.text: Some of us in this room don't go to the doctor even when we need to, like getting an annual exam every five years or avoiding the dentist. I was a cop and I understand that reluctance, as it was similar in my experience. But if you're sick or have a problem, you go to the doctor, they diagnose it, and write a prescription—yet some people take it home and never get it filled, just keeping it around for years. This illustrates how we might receive spiritual guidance but fail to act on it.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to show that just as people ignore medical prescriptions, we must actively follow spiritual prescriptions like imitating faith to live out God's will.

illustrations.title: Prescription Analogy
illustrations.text: It's kind of like a prescription; it's not enough to get one, it also requires filling and following. I had a prescription filled but never took the pills fully, even though it was for a seven or ten-day course and I only took it for three days. Just as that medicine sat unused in my cabinet, spiritual peace requires us to actively fill and follow through.
illustrations.context: Illustrates that receiving God's peace, as part of the fruit of the Spirit, requires not just obtaining it but actively following through, like properly taking a prescription.

illustrations.title: Freeway Police Story
illustrations.text: Look, I've been in the car and seen it happen on the freeway when a police officer is driving down the highway. Everyone suddenly drives the speed limit, puts on seatbelts, and puts down cell phones, driving at or just below the limit. It's amazing how people make those choices when authority is present. I even gave a message years ago in Placentia, where our church met and many people came from, announcing I'd teach on how to avoid getting a ticket, and the place was packed with folks I'd never seen before.
illustrations.context: Demonstrates that making right choices, like obeying the law when a police officer is around, helps maintain peace, paralleling the decisions needed for spiritual peace.

illustrations.title: Speeding Ticket Consequences
illustrations.text: There are people who get a ticket but don't have time, money, or care, so they don't show up for court, lose the ticket, or throw it away. When they fail to appear, a warrant is issued for their arrest, turning a simple infraction into a misdemeanor that costs far more. They then face issues like not being able to renew their car registration at the DMV because of the warrant, forcing them to drive around out of date and in constant fear of being pulled over. This lack of peace comes from not doing the right thing, much like how God's peace requires honoring Him.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that disobeying authority leads to escalating consequences and a lack of peace, emphasizing that God's peace comes from making right decisions.

illustrations.title: Elf on the Shelf Heartbreak
illustrations.text: We started doing Elf on the Shelf when it came out, and my wife thought it was cute, though I found it a bit terrifying. We used it to teach our kids lessons, like being kind and praying for others. One Christmas, when my daughter was six, she loved it so much and was heartbroken when it left; I read her a letter from the elf saying how blessed it was by her. As she cried, I started crying too, but for a different reason—I was empathizing with her pain as a parent.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to illustrate the depth of parental empathy and connect it to Jesus' suffering and grief in Isaiah 53.

illustrations.title: Hymn Quote on Sacrifice
illustrations.text: This song that we're about to sing is my favorite worship song, and it's the greatest set of lyrics that I've read and pondered all the time. There's a moment in the song that says, 'Mild He lays His glory by, born that man no more may die.' He was born with that purpose to lay down His life for us, and that should drive us to want to worship Him and glorify Him. Don't rob these lyrics of their value to sing back to the King of Kings and the King of Glory here tonight.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses the quote to emphasize that Jesus' birth and sacrifice should inspire genuine worship and prevent limiting the song to just Christmas traditions.

illustrations.title: Bless Fest Event Testimony
illustrations.text: I want to show you a little video from Bless Fest because some of you weren't able to attend. In the video, people share that it was one of the most organized events they've ever been to, they felt spiritual, loved, and blessed, and it was a miracle for them. We had about 400 people and seven buses going to different shelters, making it an incredible experience. We're grateful to God for your prayers, donations, and participation, and it highlights the positive impact of our community efforts.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is using the Bless Fest event to illustrate the success and spiritual value of community outreach and thanksgiving activities.

illustrations.title: Sheep of Bethlehem's Purpose
illustrations.text: Alfred Edersheim points out something that many people miss: it wasn't just to fulfill the prophecy in Micah 5, but Jesus was born in Bethlehem where shepherds watched sheep destined for sacrifice in Jerusalem. These sheep were not typical; they were specifically kept in the fields around Bethlehem for use as sacrificial lambs. We're studying Leviticus and see how fascinating it is that Jesus was born in Bethlehem to be our sacrificial lamb, connecting to the offerings we've been discussing.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that Jesus' birth in Bethlehem signifies his role as the ultimate sacrificial lamb, linking it to the sin offering in Leviticus.

illustrations.title: Benjamin's Skilled Slingers
illustrations.text: Benjamin was the smallest tribe with the smallest army of 26,000 men, but among them were 700 left-handed special forces. These men could sling a stone so accurately that they never missed their target, even hitting a hair's breadth. The word for 'miss' in this context is the same as the word for 'sin', illustrating that sin means failing to hit what God intended.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to explain that sin means missing God's intended mark.

illustrations.title: Peter's Garden Slumber
illustrations.text: When Peter fell asleep in the Garden of Gethsemane, Jesus had asked him and the others to stay awake and pray to avoid temptation. Peter was tired and overcome with sorrow from Jesus' words about what would happen that night, so he dozed off. Jesus then said, 'The spirit is willing, but the flesh is weak,' showing that sin can stem from human weakness rather than willful disobedience.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that sin isn't always intentional but can result from the frailty of human nature.

illustrations.title: Fish Don't Feel Wet
illustrations.text: Most people don't feel very guilty about sin for the same reason that fish don't feel wet—they're so immersed in it that they don't notice. I've talked to fish, and they don't feel wet at all. This analogy highlights how sin surrounds us without us realizing its impact.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to explain why people often don't feel guilty about their sins.

illustrations.title: Supreme Court on Life
illustrations.text: The Supreme Court is debating the possibility of overturning Roe v. Wade, a historic case that's happening right now. I listened to some of it today, and our justices say they can't deal with the philosophical question of when life begins because it's above their pay grade. Instead, they focus on things like the viability of the fetus and historical factors.
illustrations.context: To illustrate the limitations of human courts in addressing when life begins, contrasting it with the Bible's clear perspective.

illustrations.title: Lincoln's Call to Repentance
illustrations.text: I'll just remind you, because we didn't cover it on Thanksgiving, so I should do it now. We often think of Abraham Lincoln as giving the proclamation for Thanksgiving, and he did. But before that, in the same year, 1863, he made this statement and called the whole nation to fast and to repent. It's been a long time since we had a president of the United States call us to repent, and when was the last time we heard a pastor do the same?
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that nations can sin and need to repent, contrasting it with how American Christians might mistakenly view their blessings as self-earned rather than from God.

illustrations.title: Lincoln's Call for National Repentance
illustrations.text: Listen to this, here's what he said: We have been the recipients of the choicest bounties of heaven. We have been preserved these many years in peace and prosperity. We have grown in numbers, wealth, and power as no other nation has ever grown. What was our sin? We have forgotten God. We have forgotten the gracious hand which preserved us in peace and multiplied and enriched and strengthened us, and we have vainly imagined in the deceitfulness of our hearts that all these blessings were produced by some superior wisdom and virtue of our own. Abraham Lincoln was convinced the reason we were in a Civil War is because we weren't a people honoring God, blessing God, and thanking God. He calls the nation of the United States back to a repentant relationship with the Lord.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that forgetting God leads to national judgment, as seen in the Civil War, urging modern repentance.

illustrations.title: Adam and Eve's Sacrifice
illustrations.text: God tells us in Genesis that He killed an animal, possibly a lamb, and provided skins to cover both Adam and Eve after they sinned. They both needed this sin offering because Eve was deceived and Adam also fell, showing that sin affects everyone. This story illustrates that God made a sacrifice from the beginning to cover our shame and separation from Him.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize that sin requires a divine sacrifice and separates us from God, just as it did for Adam and Eve.

illustrations.title: People Magazine Sin Survey
illustrations.text: I saw a People Magazine article years ago that I clipped out because they surveyed a thousand people about how often they sin. They asked these people directly about their views on sin, which I found revealing. Back then, magazines like that addressed such topics, but it seems they wouldn't do it anymore.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that people often fail to deal with sin properly or recognize it, highlighting a common problem in modern society.

illustrations.title: Fonzie's Apology Struggle
illustrations.text: In Happy Days, Fonzie could never say he's sorry because of his pride. He struggled to humble himself and admit he was wrong, even to his friend Richie. In one episode, he needed to apologize for something he did but couldn't bring himself to do it, and Richie eventually told him it was okay. This shows how people often avoid admitting their faults. I think many go through life like that, never humbling themselves to others or to God.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate how pride prevents people from humbling themselves and admitting sin, even to God.

illustrations.title: King Saul's Compromise
illustrations.text: King Saul was sent on a mission to wipe out the Amalekites, but instead, he brought home King Agag as a war trophy and spared their livestock, which he wasn't supposed to do. He claimed to have obeyed God by mostly following orders, but God saw this as rebellion and insubordination. Samuel confronted him, and God declared that even a small compromise is as serious as divination. In Saul's mind, he had done enough, thinking he should be commended despite his partial obedience.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that even small compromises in obeying God are viewed as major rebellion with serious consequences.

illustrations.title: Saul's Excuses for Disobedience
illustrations.text: King Saul claims he's blessed because he has obeyed the Lord fully, but Samuel points out that Saul didn't obey by sparing animals that should have been destroyed. Saul blames his people, saying he was afraid they wouldn't wipe them out completely. Even when confronted, Saul shifts blame and tries to justify keeping the animals for sacrifice to God.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate how people deny and excuse their sins instead of admitting them.

illustrations.title: Adam and Eve's Blame Game
illustrations.text: The first effect of sin in the Garden was shame, as their eyes were opened and they saw they were naked. The second was blame, when God asked Adam if he had eaten from the tree, and Adam pointed fingers at Eve, saying it was her fault and even implying God gave her to him. This shows how sin leads people to shift responsibility.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob connects this to demonstrate that blaming others is a common response to sin, just like Saul did.

illustrations.title: Norman Greenbaum's Denial Song
illustrations.text: Back in the 70s, there was a song by Norman Greenbaum called 'Spirit in the Sky,' where he claims he's never been a sinner and has a friend in Jesus who will take care of him when he dies. Pastor Bob points out the poor theology in this, as it denies the reality of sin and misunderstands biblical truth. This example shows how denying sin prevents people from understanding the need for forgiveness.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize that denying one's sin, as in the song, blocks the truth of Scripture about confession and redemption.

illustrations.title: Jesus on True Goodness
illustrations.text: When a man called Jesus 'good master' or 'good teacher,' Jesus responded, 'Why do you call me good? There is none good but God.' Oh wow, that's a whole different kind of good than we use the term. We often use 'good' relatively, like good, better, or best, but the Bible means a goodness that's acceptable to God, which no one achieves on their own.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize that no one is truly good in God's eyes except God Himself, highlighting the inadequacy of human efforts for salvation.

illustrations.title: Genetic Excuse for Infidelity
illustrations.text: This was an Insider magazine cover story a while back about people involved with infidelity, claiming that cheating might be genetic and explaining what you need to know. It suggests that if you're unfaithful, it's just the way God made you with the unfaithful gene. Sin is part of our DNA, but this article tries to provide a unique excuse for behaviors like gambling or infidelity by blaming genetics.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate how people make excuses for sin, renaming it as a genetic issue instead of calling it what it is.

illustrations.title: Jesus and Adulterous Woman
illustrations.text: I'm not talking about lacking compassion; you won't find a more compassionate person in history than Jesus Christ. He says and does things I wish I could, but I wouldn't, like in the case of the woman caught in adultery. Even in that situation, Jesus showed incredible mercy and understanding.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that true compassion exists in Jesus, even toward sinners, while urging people not to avoid calling sin by its name.

illustrations.title: Woman Caught in Adultery
illustrations.text: Remember, they brought this woman caught in the act, which was utterly embarrassing, and questioned Jesus about stoning her as the law demanded. Jesus didn't answer immediately; instead, he wrote something on the ground that convicted her accusers, from the oldest to the youngest, until they all left. Then Jesus turned to her and said, 'Woman, where are your accusers? Neither do I condemn you—go and sin no more.'
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to emphasize that Jesus forgives sin directly and that renaming sins as mere habits or diseases removes the need for Christ's forgiveness.

illustrations.title: David's Sin with Bathsheba
illustrations.text: After David sinned with Bathsheba, it led to all kinds of problems as he tried to cover it up. He brought Uriah, her husband and a faithful soldier, back from the battlefield hoping he'd sleep with her to hide the pregnancy, but Uriah refused. David then arranged for Uriah to be killed by ordering the troops to retreat and leave him exposed in battle. Bathsheba became pregnant, their child died, and David faced severe consequences, living with the guilt of adultery and murder. These sins violated the Ten Commandments and showed how one sin can spiral into more.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show how sin leads to further sins and severe consequences, emphasizing that all sin is ultimately against God.

illustrations.title: Hating Family Analogy
illustrations.text: It's kind of like when Jesus said, 'Unless you are willing to hate your mother and father, you're not worthy of me.' We struggle in relationships, but He's not asking you to hate your mom and dad. The idea is to be so in love with the Lord that by comparison, it's an overstatement to show how much your love for God should be, even if it means losing your parents or facing enemies in your own household.
illustrations.context: To emphasize that the offense of sin to God is in its own category and incomparable, similar to the required devotion to God over all else.

illustrations.title: Stench of Death Quote
illustrations.text: One writer said, 'The stench of death surrounds everything sin touches.' Thus, it was literally our sin placed upon Christ that killed Him, showing how sin brings about death physically, mentally, morally, and spiritually.
illustrations.context: To illustrate that sin inevitably leads to death in all its forms, as connected to Christ's sacrifice.

illustrations.title: Jesus on the Cross Example
illustrations.text: If you wish to see the results of sin, just look at Jesus on the cross. The Bible says God made Him who knew no sin to be sin on our behalf, and He cried out, 'My God, my God, why have you forsaken me?' He was alone, stripped of His possessions, beaten, tortured, separated from humanity, and mocked by people, showing the full consequences of sin.
illustrations.context: To demonstrate that sin leads to death, separation, and suffering, as seen in Jesus' crucifixion.

illustrations.title: Passover Lamb Application
illustrations.text: Remember, the Passover lamb had to be slain for the children of Israel so that the angel of death would pass over. It wasn't enough to just kill the animal; the blood had to be applied to each of the doorposts. It wasn't enough that it died or that it was an acceptable sacrifice; it had to be personally applied to their lives.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that knowing about Jesus' death is not enough; one must personally apply His blood to their life for redemption.

illustrations.title: Veil as Christs Flesh
illustrations.text: Christ is pictured in these sacrifices, and here we have that altar that stood before the veil. Christ ultimately will rend the veil as a result of Himself being torn on the cross. This shows the connection between the sacrificial system and Jesus' own body.
illustrations.context: This analogy demonstrates that Jesus' death tore the veil, providing a new way to access God.

illustrations.title: Hymn on Blood Atonement
illustrations.text: What does that old hymn say? My hope is built on nothing less than Jesus' blood and righteousness. It's Robert Lowry, a pastor who wrote 500 hymns, but he's remembered for this one that asks two simple questions: What can wash away my sin? Nothing but the blood of Jesus. What can make me whole again? Nothing but the blood of Jesus.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that atonement and forgiveness are founded solely on Jesus' blood.

illustrations.title: Childhood Room Cleaning
illustrations.text: When I was little, my mom would say I couldn't go out to play until I cleaned my room. I'd shove all the toys and clothes into the closet and under the bed to make it look clean. But moms are too smart for that; it was just covered up, not actually clean.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how Old Testament atonement only covers sin, while New Testament reconciliation truly removes it.

illustrations.title: Cat in the Hat Mess
illustrations.text: Do you remember the story of The Cat in the Hat Comes Back? In it, the cat tries to clean a pink ring in the bathtub but only spreads the mess to other things, like their mother's dress, the wall, their father's shoes, a rug, and even their parents' bed. They keep calling for help as the stain transfers from one object to another.
illustrations.context: This shows that attempts to cover up sin or mess don't truly eliminate it, much like the limitations of Old Testament sacrifices.

illustrations.title: Cats Cleaning Snow Spot
illustrations.text: A big cat lifts his hat to reveal little cats who try to clean a spot in the snow by transferring it to various places like a television, a pan, and outside with a fan, but this only spreads the spot. More little cats join in, waging war on the snow spots with pop guns, which makes the problem worse until all the snow turns pink. Finally, the last little cat unleashes a voom that cleans up the spot, clears the snow, and puts everything back. I like that story because it shows how we often make the mistake of dealing with sin by covering it up or ignoring it, thinking that's enough.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate that people mistakenly try to hide or cover up sin temporarily, whereas God forgives by cleansing it permanently.

illustrations.title: David's Struggle with Sin
illustrations.text: David went about his life as king, still attending the temple and doing his duties, but he was struggling internally after being away from the Lord for a long time. From the outside, people might not have noticed his inner turmoil. In Psalm 32, David describes how blessed it is when transgressions are forgiven and sin is not imputed, sharing his experience of how keeping silent about his sin caused his body to waste away and his strength to drain. He then confesses his sin to the Lord, who forgives the guilt, emphasizing the relief that comes from being honest with God.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses David's story to show that even if someone appears fine on the outside, unconfessed sin leads to inner suffering, and true forgiveness comes through confession.

illustrations.title: Forgiving Tombstone Story
illustrations.text: There is a tombstone in a cemetery outside New York City with just one word on it, and no mention of the person's name, birth, or death. Pastor Bob reflects that this word is the greatest that could be written on any gravestone, emphasizing its profound meaning. He questions whether listeners can honestly say they have been forgiven, tying it to the core issue of forgiveness between man and God.
illustrations.context: To illustrate that true forgiveness is essential for one's spiritual legacy and relationship with God.

illustrations.title: Becky Pippert's Confession Story
illustrations.text: Becky Pippert, a Christian author, shared an experience from her book about being a woman who was once a youth worker in a conservative church. She and her fiancé had premarital sex, leading to a pregnancy, and they chose abortion to avoid the humiliation of confession. On her wedding day, she was overwhelmed with guilt, thinking of herself as a murderer and struggling with the shame before God.
illustrations.context: To demonstrate the torment of hidden sin and the necessity of dealing with it through forgiveness.

illustrations.title: Woman's Confession to Becky
illustrations.text: A woman confessed to Becky Pippert about her abortion, expressing deep shame and inability to forgive herself. Becky responded by pointing out that all people are responsible for Christ's death on the cross, using the woman's sin as an example. She explained that just as the woman's pride led to her actions, it also contributed to crucifying Jesus, and thus, forgiveness is available for all sins through the cross.
illustrations.context: To illustrate that every person's sin contributed to Christ's death, making full forgiveness possible for any wrongdoing.

illustrations.title: Luther's Nails Analogy
illustrations.text: Martin Luther said that we carry his very nails in our pockets, meaning we all bear responsibility for Christ's crucifixion. This quote was used to show that everyone, regardless of their specific sins, sent Jesus to the cross. Becky connected it to the woman's situation, emphasizing that her sins are no different from those that led to Christ's death, making forgiveness complete.
illustrations.context: To emphasize that all individuals share in the guilt of Christ's death, highlighting the universality of sin and grace.

illustrations.title: Sin as Cancer Analogy
illustrations.text: When it comes to cancer, early detection and early treatment are some of the most important ways to treat it. The Bible says sin is like cancer; when you don't deal with it, it goes on to affect other things in your life, in your marriage, and in your family. Just as untreated cancer spreads, sin unchecked will cause more harm.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to emphasize the importance of dealing with sin immediately before it affects other areas of life.

illustrations.title: Being Offended Example
illustrations.text: When somebody offends you and you become offensive in return, I've noticed that when I'm offended, I feel a right to be offensive. You're never in more trouble than when you've been done wrong, because then you think you have a right to lose your temper or say mean things. This often escalates the situation rather than resolving it.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates how responding to offense with more offense leads to further sin and trouble.

illustrations.title: Bumping into Reconciliation
illustrations.text: Ideally, two Christians that hurt each other should bump into each other on the way to getting right with each other, you know, before they go to church. This means they're both actively seeking to make amends. It's a picture of mutual obedience to God's call for reconciliation.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is emphasizing the importance of taking initiative in reconciliation, as it leads to potential mutual forgiveness and restoration.

illustrations.title: Christmas Gifts Analogy
illustrations.text: With Christmas coming, I think about gifts and buying them for my family, and that's a joyous time. When I buy gifts, I hide them and put them away, and I eventually wrap them—I'm not great at wrapping, but I get them ready. I look forward to giving them to my wife, my children, and my grandchildren. It's hard to think of it this way, but sin has been paid for two thousand years ago, and the Lord is anxious to give you the gift of forgiveness that He paid for.
illustrations.context: This analogy shows that just as Pastor Bob prepares and eagerly gives gifts to his family, God has already paid for sins and is waiting to offer forgiveness.

illustrations.title: Alliances Fulfilling End Times
illustrations.text: There are things happening day-to-day that make it clear we're in the end times regarding geopolitical events predicted in the Bible. In Ezekiel 37, it predicts the resurrection of the nation of Israel, which has happened. Ezekiel 38 and 39 predict the Battle of Gog and Magog, and the enemies listed are already in alliance today: Russia, Turkey, and Persia, which is modern-day Iran, against Israel. I've been following the news, and Iran has threatened that if the United States attacks them, they will obliterate Israel within half an hour. They're committed to destroying Israel if we attack, and we know from the Bible how that turns out, but these events are unfolding.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is showing that current geopolitical alliances and threats are signs of biblical end times prophecies being fulfilled.

illustrations.title: God's Sacrificial Love
illustrations.text: God proves that he is loving by sending his son to die for sinful man, even those who will reject him. Romans 5:8 states that he demonstrates his own love toward us in that while we were yet sinners, Christ died for us. This shows the epitome of love, which contrasts with the unloving character of the church in the last days.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to illustrate that true love is sacrificial, as demonstrated by God, and to highlight how the church in the last days fails to reflect this.

illustrations.title: Opposite of Love Explained
illustrations.text: You know, the opposite of love isn't hate; it's selfishness. Read in 1 Corinthians 13, which describes the nature of love, and it says in verse 5 that love does not seek its own. This means the exact opposite of love is selfishness, and it becomes the character even of God's people in the last days.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to explain that selfishness, not hate, is the true opposite of love, connecting it to the prophecy that the church will lack love in the end times.

illustrations.title: ACR 99 Legislation
illustrations.text: I mentioned some legislation that you should be aware of called ACR 99 here in California. This legislation is aimed at the church, primarily trying to get pastors to stop denouncing homosexuality as sin because it discourages people living that lifestyle. The end goal is to cause people who are living a homosexual lifestyle to feel accepted in their homosexuality.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how unnatural affection is expressed in modern culture through legislation targeting the church.

illustrations.title: Jesus Accepts Sinners
illustrations.text: Jesus Christ accepts sinners; he doesn't condemn the woman caught in adultery. He was called a friend of sinners, a wine-bibber and glutton, and I'm glad because I need him. The Bible says that he receives sinners, and that means sinners can receive Christ.
illustrations.context: This shows that we should love and accept sinners while denouncing their sin, following Jesus' example.

illustrations.title: John Corson on Abortion
illustrations.text: John Corson talked about unnatural affection in the context of abortion, saying that in our culture, we see this through the prevalence of abortion. He noted how many people, even within the church, are involved with it, and how tragic that is. This example highlights the lack of natural family affection in modern society.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to illustrate how unnatural affection manifests in contemporary culture through abortion, pointing to a breakdown in family love.

illustrations.title: Old Testament Family Failures
illustrations.text: In the Old Testament, God raised up judges and priests like Eli, who was a priest but not a good father; his sons were ungodly and in the ministry yet not godly. Then there's Samuel, a man of God who started the battle against the Philistines and anointed David, but his own sons were not godly, showing problems in the family. David, the model king, had issues as a father with problems in his home, and Solomon followed with his own family troubles.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses these biblical stories to show that God's judgment is linked to the breakdown of family structures.

illustrations.title: Solomon's Idolatry and Compromise
illustrations.text: Solomon had hundreds of wives and nearly 700 concubines, but the Bible only records one son, which seems statistically impossible. It's been suggested that his foreign wives turned his heart away from God, leading him to build high places for idols like Molech. Molech was a god to whom people offered their infant children in sacrifice by placing them in searing hot metal hands until they were consumed. Solomon even built a temple to Molech near Jerusalem that stood for four hundred years, promoting practices like ancient infanticide. This may explain why many of his children were never mentioned in the records.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate how compromise with the world, like Solomon's, can lead to severe sin and turning away from God.

illustrations.title: Lot's Encounter in Sodom
illustrations.text: You know the account of Lot in Sodom and Gomorrah, where angels came and the men of the city surrounded the house, demanding to have relations with them. Lot pleaded, 'Don't do this evil thing,' but then offered his own daughters instead to protect the angels. I have a problem with that; he's the man God chose to save, yet he made such a compromising choice. The men refused, saying they wanted the men, not the women, and God struck them with blindness as judgment. Eventually, God destroyed Sodom and Gomorrah with fire and brimstone.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to show how even God's chosen people, like Lot, can act like the sinful world around them.

illustrations.title: Judges Story Comparison
illustrations.text: The writer of Judges shows what happened in Genesis 19 happening again, but now among God's people. In Judges 19 and 20, a Levite's wife is given to the men of the town of Gibeah in the tribe of Benjamin, and she is raped to death. This leads to a civil war that almost destroys the Benjamites, just as God judged Sodom and Gomorrah for their wickedness.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate how God's people are acting like the wicked world, mirroring the sins of Sodom and signaling the need for judgment.

illustrations.title: Jeremiah Quote on Wickedness
illustrations.text: In Jeremiah 23:14, God declares among the prophets of Jerusalem, I have seen a horrible thing: the committing of adultery and walking in falsehood, as they strengthen the hands of evildoers so that no one turns back from wickedness. God compares all of them to Sodom and Gomorrah, indicating that His people have become just like the wicked world. Pastor Bob explains that this means God is ready to judge not just the world, but His own people for their resemblance to it.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to show that God's judgment comes when His people act like the world, failing to be a light and instead embracing wickedness.

illustrations.title: Burma-Shave Signs Reference
illustrations.text: There's this stubborn self-will in just about every man, and to illustrate that, I recall the old Burma-Shave signs from years ago along the roads, like on the way into LA near the Grapevine. These signs had little sayings every half mile or so, and one I never forget said over several signs: 'Famous last words of lights that shine: if he won't dim his.' It's a humorous way to point out stubbornness that leads to downfall.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate the irreconcilable nature of people who refuse to yield or forgive, much like the unyielding behavior he warns against.

illustrations.title: Divorce Statistics Example
illustrations.text: Do you know the most common reason listed for divorce? Orange County is the divorce capital of the world, way higher than the national average, with about 74% of marriages ending in divorce due to irreconcilable differences. This started with California being the first state to have no-fault divorce in 1970, and even Ronald Reagan admitted it was the worst law he ever signed. Pastor Bob uses this to show that in God's eyes, there are no truly irreconcilable differences—just people unwilling to reconcile.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that what society calls irreconcilable differences is really about unwillingness to forgive, emphasizing God's power to reconcile.

illustrations.title: Oglethorpe-Wesley Quote
illustrations.text: General Oglethorpe once said to John Wesley, 'I never forgive and I never forget.' Wesley replied, 'Then sir, I hope you never sinned.' Pastor Bob connects this to remind us that unforgiveness is dangerous because we all need forgiveness ourselves.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to highlight the importance of forgiveness, showing that refusing to forgive reveals a lack of understanding of our own need for it.

illustrations.title: Gods Big Eraser Analogy
illustrations.text: You might say it this way: God has a big eraser, and He's put it in your hand. This means God gives us the power to forgive others just as He has forgiven us. Through this analogy, Pastor Bob emphasizes that forgiveness is possible because of the forgiveness we've received from God.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that we can forgive others because God has equipped us with the ability to do so through His own forgiveness.

illustrations.title: Guy's Wife Gets Historical
illustrations.text: You've heard me say that a guy was telling his friend, 'My wife whenever she gets upset with me, she gets totally historical.' And he said, 'You mean hysterical?' No, she gets historical; she starts telling me everything I've ever done wrong. Well, that's the nature of man.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how people hold onto past wrongs and bring up history when upset, instead of forgiving.

illustrations.title: Little Johnny Buries Goldfish
illustrations.text: Listen to this: Little Johnny was filling a hole in the garden when his neighbor looked over the fence and said, 'What are you doing there, son?' 'I've just buried my goldfish that died,' Little Johnny said. 'Well, that's a mighty large hole you dug for a goldfish,' said the neighbor. Patting down the last bit of earth, Little Johnny said, 'That's because my goldfish is inside your stupid cat.' Yeah, it just comes naturally to us to want to see people pay.
illustrations.context: This shows our natural inclination to seek revenge rather than forgiveness.

illustrations.title: Proverb on Enemy Revenge
illustrations.text: There's an old proverb that says, 'If your enemy offends thee, make a drum out of the skin of each of his children.' We don't want to forgive; we want to get even. That's the nature of man.
illustrations.context: This quote highlights the human desire for revenge over reconciliation, emphasizing the need to choose forgiveness.

illustrations.title: Jesus as Fruit-Seeking Gardener
illustrations.text: I think of Jesus describing himself in the parables, and in one of the parables, he describes himself as a gardener. He said, 'I come these three years seeking fruit from my fig tree; there's no fruit.' Now, he's talking about the nation of Israel, representing the length of his ministry, as he had come seeking the fruit, which is repentance. Just think about that as the character of Christ; he comes looking for fruit, that's who he is.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that Jesus seeks repentance and good fruit in people, contrasting with those who focus on faults.

illustrations.title: Fruit Finders vs Fault Finders
illustrations.text: There are fruit finders and there are fault finders. You need to ask yourself which one you are: when you are around people, do you look for that which you can commend, do you look for that which is Christ-like, or do you immediately notice and comment on the faults you see? It's an extended comparison to show how we should focus on the positive qualities in others rather than their shortcomings.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that people should strive to be like Christ by seeking and affirming good in others instead of gossiping or criticizing.

illustrations.title: Bee's Honey and Sting
illustrations.text: It's been said that a bee is seldom complimented for making honey but more often criticized for its sting. Think about it: just as bees provide something valuable like honey yet get criticized for their sting, people often overlook the good in others and focus on negatives. This illustrates how we should appreciate positive contributions rather than dwell on flaws.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that, like Jesus who overlooked disciples' faults, we should look for and commend good qualities in people instead of criticizing.

illustrations.title: Excitement Over Grandson's Progress
illustrations.text: I see my grandson and all the things he can't do, but I'm blessed by anything he can do. Every new thing he does, like putting three words together into almost a sentence, excites me. I want to videotape it and make you watch it because I'm genuinely excited about his growth.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how God is excited about our progress despite our immaturity and lovingly corrects us.

illustrations.title: Three Pastors Sharing Struggles
illustrations.text: The story of three pastors who were struggling in their lives led them to form a group to share honestly and pray together. They were from different churches, and in their first meeting, the first pastor admitted he has a problem with alcohol and sometimes gets drunk. The second confessed his gambling habit on vacations, where he wins and loses but knows it's wrong. The third said his problem is gossip and he can't wait to leave to spread the word.
illustrations.context: This shows that gossip is a common issue even among church leaders and highlights its destructive nature.

illustrations.title: Quote on Spreading Lies
illustrations.text: Mark Twain is supposedly quoted as saying that a lie will travel halfway around the world while the truth is putting on its boots, but that's inaccurate because he didn't say it—it was said over a hundred years ago by someone else. The point remains true: people are anxious to believe and repeat lies. This happens all the time, especially in the context of gossip.
illustrations.context: This emphasizes how quickly and eagerly lies spread, connecting to the dangers of gossip.

illustrations.title: German Statue of Jesus
illustrations.text: I've shared before about a great story of a statue in Germany. It was a statue of Jesus with his arms outstretched, and during the war, this church was bombed, and a rafter knocked the arms off the statue. After the war, they tried to put the statue back together, but some students decided not to replace the arms and instead put a sign on it that says, 'Jesus has no hands but ours.' I was thinking about that in relation to this verse, because if you think about it, Satan has no mouth but ours.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate that Satan uses people's mouths to accuse others, just as the statue shows Jesus relies on us.

illustrations.title: Job's Wife Temptation
illustrations.text: It is Job's wife who is enticing Job to do what Satan has bragged he will get Job to do: curse God and die. That wasn't her idea; she hadn't been thinking a lot about it, and it really came directly from the devil, though she didn't know it. Unwittingly, she's the mouthpiece of the devil to her husband.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show how Satan influences people, like Job's wife, to spread accusations without realizing it.

illustrations.title: Peter Rebukes Jesus
illustrations.text: Peter, after being told that upon this rock I'll build my church and making the great confession, heard Jesus say he was going to Jerusalem to be turned over to the Gentiles and crucified. Peter rebuked Jesus, saying that's never going to happen. Jesus responded sharply, telling Peter to get behind him, Satan, because Peter was being influenced to say thoughts directly from hell, even though he was a believer.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to demonstrate how Satan can influence believers to speak against God's plan.

illustrations.title: Ahab and Lying Spirits
illustrations.text: When King Ahab was going to war and wanted his prophets to tell him whether he should, the Bible tells us that behind the scenes, a lying spirit was put into the mouths of those prophets. Demons don't come out and talk except through people, so this spirit influenced them to deceive. This shows how satanic influences can operate through human speech.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that in the last days, people in the church might unwittingly spread satanic lies through gossip.

illustrations.title: Police Officer on New Year's Eve
illustrations.text: When I was a police officer in two cities in North Orange County, I worked the graveyard shift on New Year's Eve. The cops not on calls would drive to an underpass and wait under it at midnight because gunfire was everywhere. People shoot guns randomly into the air, not thinking about the danger, and every year, bullets come down and hurt or kill people. This careless act mirrors how words can cause unintended harm.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how rash words, like bullets fired carelessly, can cause great damage and harm to others.

illustrations.title: Man at Choir Performance
illustrations.text: I heard of a man who went to a choir ensemble performance and listened to a woman sing a solo. He turned to the guy next to him and said it was terrible. When he learned she was the guy's wife, he awkwardly tried to backtrack, blaming the song or the words instead of his rash judgment.
illustrations.context: This shows how speaking rashly can hurt people deeply and lead to immediate regret.

illustrations.title: Fred Rogers' Critical Experience
illustrations.text: Fred Rogers, an ordained pastor and believer, once shared that years ago, his wife and he were at a church service with friends. During the sermon, he critically noted every mistake he thought the preacher was making. After it ended, he turned to his friend and realized his judgmental attitude, which connected to the harm of rash words.
illustrations.context: This quote highlights the danger of being overly critical and sarcastic, showing how it reflects poorly on one's own character.

illustrations.title: Judging the Sermon
illustrations.text: I was intending to say something critical about the sermon, but I stopped myself when I saw tears running down her face. She whispered to me that he said exactly what she needed to hear. That was a seminal experience for me—I was judging while she was needing, and the Holy Spirit responded to need, not judgment. It showed me how out of sync I was, ready to criticize unjustly.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate the importance of responding to spiritual needs rather than judgment.

illustrations.title: Elderly Women Driving
illustrations.text: This true story involves two elderly women out driving in a large car, both barely able to see over the dashboard. They ran through three red lights in a row without stopping. The passenger realized what was happening and confronted the driver, saying they could have been killed, highlighting a lack of self-control.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate what happens when people are without self-control, as mentioned in the verse.

illustrations.title: City Walls Analogy
illustrations.text: Like a city that is broken into and without walls, a man who has no control over his spirit is totally vulnerable. Your home's security system is only as strong as its weakest link; you can have bars on every window and door, but if one window is cracked, intruders can get in. It doesn't matter how strong the rest is—an ancient city is only as secure as its walls, and if breached, it's defenseless. This describes how a person lacking self-control is easy to take down.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to show that a person without self-control is defenseless and vulnerable, just like a breached city.

illustrations.title: Street Games Story
illustrations.text: I remember playing street football and street baseball as kids growing up, and kids weren't always kind to each other. When it was time for a batter, we'd try to distract them or say things like 'easy out' to psych them out. It was a psychological approach to make the other kid think they were an easy target. This illustrates how demons might treat some Christians facing temptation.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to explain how temptations can make people feel like easy targets, just as kids did in games.

illustrations.title: Esau Birthright Retelling
illustrations.text: The writer in Hebrews warns against being an immoral or godless person like Esau, who sold his own birthright for a single meal. Esau chose that bowl of porridge over his birthright because he cared more about satisfying his physical desires than valuing the things of God. This shows how giving in to fleshly drives can lead to regret and loss. In the church, we must not be driven by such impulses.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob retells Esau's story to emphasize that people should not be controlled by fleshly desires, as it leads to spiritual destruction.

illustrations.title: Bird Trapped Over Falls
illustrations.text: Over the falls, a large bird like a raven came down on some dead meat floating in the river upstream and started feasting on the carcass. It knew it could fly away and saw the falls coming, but it kept eating until the end. Its talons had frozen into the dead meat, and screaming, it went down to its death. Someone has pictured sin that way, where you think you can stop anytime, but the longer you're engaged in sin, the more you become a slave to it.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how sin can trap and enslave a person, making it hard to let go despite the consequences.

illustrations.title: Moses' Lost Opportunity
illustrations.text: Think about Moses, who was an example of Christ, the savior of the people of Israel, face to face with God and the meekest man in the world. When the children of Israel were upset because there was no water a second time, Moses got angry and said, 'Shall I bring water for you out of this rock?' Instead of just speaking to the rock as God commanded, he struck it twice with his staff, breaking the type that the rock represents Christ, who is smitten once. As a result, God was upset with Moses for not treating Him as holy before the people, and Moses lost his chance to enter the promised land, disqualifying him from what God had for his life.
illustrations.context: This story shows that lacking self-control can lead to disqualification from God's purposes.

illustrations.title: Demon-Possessed Man Healed
illustrations.text: A man was possessed by thousands of demons, making him completely out of control—he tore off his clothes, broke shackles, cut himself with rocks, and screamed constantly. No one could handle him, and he lived isolated in the tombs. Jesus arrived, and the demons recognized Him immediately, begging not to be tormented. Jesus cast the demons into a herd of pigs, which then ran into the water and drowned. The townspeople, frightened, asked Jesus to leave, but the man was left clothed and in his right mind, experiencing self-control for the first time.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate that Jesus can give self-control to anyone, even those who seem beyond help.

illustrations.title: Hercules and the Stables
illustrations.text: Hercules was given twelve labors in Greek mythology, one of which was to clean the stables of King Augeas. The king had 30,000 oxen, and the stables hadn't been cleaned in ten years, making the task overwhelming. Hercules had to complete it in just one day, and realizing his strength alone wasn't enough, he diverted two nearby rivers to flood and clean the stables quickly.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this reference to show that self-control is a work of the Holy Spirit, not something achieved through human effort alone.

illustrations.title: Rivers Cleaning Stables Analogy
illustrations.text: Someone dug a ditch from two rivers into the stables, removed the fencing, and diverted the power of these two rivers to clean out the stables all in one day. May I suggest that's a picture of what happens in our lives when we say, 'Lord, I can't do it with just my little shovel.' We need the power of God, the Holy Spirit, to cleanse and change us rather than relying on our own efforts.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that we need divine power from the Holy Spirit to achieve spiritual cleansing and self-control, not just human effort.

illustrations.title: Archimedes Lever Quote
illustrations.text: Archimedes, the one who invented the lever, said, 'Give me a lever long enough and a place to stand outside the earth and I'll move the world.' That's what we need—a power outside of ourselves, the power of God's Spirit, to come in and cleanse us, move us, and change us.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is using this quote to emphasize the necessity of external divine power for personal transformation and self-control.

illustrations.title: Jesus on Praying for Worthiness
illustrations.text: Jesus said pray always that you would be accounted worthy to escape these things that are coming on the earth. I don't believe we're saved because we've done something that makes us worthy; Jesus Christ is the only one who can do that. But if you have a question whether or not the rapture were to happen that you would go, that's a good indication that you need to get your life right with the Lord.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to stress the importance of self-examination and readiness for the rapture, emphasizing that uncertainty about salvation signals a need for repentance.

illustrations.title: Paul on Cleansing for Readiness
illustrations.text: Remember Paul said if you cleanse yourself from these things, you'll be a vessel ready for the Master's use. So we need to get cleansed even as Christians. This means actively purifying our lives to be prepared for God's work.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to illustrate the necessity of personal cleansing for Christians to be ready for Christ's return and useful to God.

illustrations.title: Paul's Eyes Opening Quote
illustrations.text: Paul in the New Testament says, 'I want your eyes to be open so that you might see what is the greatness of his inheritance in the Saints.' This isn't just about the inheritance of the Saints in heaven, but about seeing how precious you are to Him. This book is really all about that in a wonderful way, emphasizing how the bridegroom helps the bride see herself through his eyes.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to show how the Song of Solomon helps believers see their value and preciousness to God, just as Paul describes.

illustrations.title: True Love Waits Verse
illustrations.text: We have this expression used twice before in the book: 'Daughters of Jerusalem, do not arouse or awaken my love until she pleases.' We need to remember that true love waits, and this reflects the Lord's love being passionately patient. We can think about that in different ways as it relates to relationships.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that God's love is patiently waiting, illustrating the importance of timing in true love.

illustrations.title: CS Lewis's Reluctant Conversion
illustrations.text: I know CS Lewis said, 'I came kicking and screaming into the kingdom of God,' because he was an intellectual who had to give up all of that intellect and humble himself, but nonetheless, he chose to do so. This shows that even someone as smart as Lewis resisted at first. No one is forced into the kingdom; it's a personal choice.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that God invites people into the kingdom without forcing them, as seen in Lewis's voluntary decision despite his resistance.

illustrations.title: Jesus Cleansing the Temple
illustrations.text: When Jesus repossesses the temple, that's what I call it, when he came in and overturned the money changers' tables, kicked them out, and said, 'My house shall be called a house of prayer, but you've made it a den of thieves.' Then Jesus started healing and people praised God, making it an incredible day as that's what the temple was made for. Jesus asserted his authority as the Lord of the house, but when challenged by the religious leaders, he left and went to Bethany where Mary, Martha, and Lazarus were. This illustrates that Jesus won't force his way into situations.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to show that Jesus exercises his authority without forcing people, respecting their willingness to follow him.

illustrations.title: Robert Ingersoll's Challenge
illustrations.text: You ever heard the name Robert Ingersoll? He was an atheist intellectual who spoke about philosophy and was anti-God, drawing big crowds as a good speaker. On one occasion, he said to the audience, 'There is no God, and I'll prove it right now—I will give God five minutes to strike me dead.' He took out his watch, and everyone waited, but nothing happened at the end of the five minutes. He claimed it proved there was no God, but someone replied that it just showed sinful man cannot exhaust the patience of Almighty God in five minutes.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that God's patience cannot be exhausted even by direct challenges or mockery.

illustrations.title: Methuselah's Long Life
illustrations.text: You want to see the patience of God? Read in Genesis when God says He's going to destroy the earth, and Enoch names his son Methuselah, which means 'when he dies, it will come,' referring to the flood. Methuselah lived to be 969 years old, the oldest person recorded, showing how God waited a long time before judgment. It's hard to picture such an old age, but it highlights God's incredible patience toward humanity.
illustrations.context: This story demonstrates God's extensive patience before bringing judgment, as seen in the time before the flood.

illustrations.title: Jesus as Type of Israel
illustrations.text: By the way, it's interesting you see parallels in the scripture. Jesus is taken by his mother and Joseph into Egypt when Herod is going to slaughter the babies, and then he comes back from Egypt as a child, fulfilling the prophecy 'Out of Egypt I called my son.' This prophecy was originally about Israel, but it applies to Jesus, showing him as a type of the Messiah. Jesus also goes into the wilderness for 40 days to be tested after his baptism, similar to Israel's experiences. Additionally, Israel crossed the Red Sea, which can be seen as a baptism of sorts.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating how the bride's journey in Song of Solomon parallels the bridegroom's glory and biblical events like Jesus' life and Israel's exodus to emphasize spiritual dependence.

illustrations.title: Song on Wilderness Journey
illustrations.text: Years ago, I heard a song called 'Take Another Lap Around Mount Sinai.' The chorus says: 'Go on and take another lap around Mount Sinai until you learn your lesson, until you stop your whining and quit rebelling, until you learn to stand in your day of testing by trusting and obeying the Lord.' I often wonder if it really needed to be 40 years, since it doesn't take that long to walk from there. This song highlights the idea of enduring trials until we grow spiritually.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this song to illustrate that every believer goes through a personal wilderness journey of testing and learning to trust God.

illustrations.title: High School Trust Walk
illustrations.text: I have a friend who is a pastor of a Calvary Chapel in Orange County, but before that, he was a high school teacher at Maranatha Christian Academy in Costa Mesa. One day, he wanted to teach his Christian high school students a lesson, so he took about 30 kids outside the classroom and instructed them to keep their eyes closed and hold onto the shoulder of the person in front. As they walked, the students started complaining—they didn't understand, they got tired, and some even wanted to go home—but he kept saying, 'Follow me,' no matter what they said. This experience showed how people react in the wilderness, mirroring our responses to God's leading.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how believers often complain and question during wilderness experiences but must learn to follow God faithfully.

illustrations.title: Moses' Desert Degree
illustrations.text: It's been said that Moses had to graduate before God could really use him by getting his 'backside of the desert degree.' This means that in the wilderness, while shepherding Jethro's sheep, Moses learned to humbly meet God, give up his own sense of identity, and discover how God could work through him. This idea emphasizes the purpose of wilderness seasons in spiritual growth.
illustrations.context: This quote shows that time in the wilderness is necessary for believers to be prepared and transformed for God's purposes.

illustrations.title: Chuck Smith's Wilderness Years
illustrations.text: We all know Pastor Chuck Smith for his great ministry, but he spent 17 years before Calvary Costa Mesa in a wilderness period where he struggled and God's blessing wasn't on it yet. He described those years as tough, full of challenges. This illustrates that even great leaders face hard times.
illustrations.context: This shows that believers may go through prolonged wilderness periods before experiencing God's full blessing.

illustrations.title: Jacob's Personal Encounter with God
illustrations.text: Jacob wrestled in Genesis 32, and his name means heel-catcher, implying a con man who takes advantage of others. He was born holding his brother's heel and grew up in a family of believers like Abraham and Isaac, but he never personally met God until his own moment. Although he was surrounded by faith, it wasn't enough; he had to have a direct encounter with the Lord, just like many of us who grow up in Christian homes but haven't truly met God ourselves.
illustrations.context: This retelling emphasizes that growing up in a family of faith is not enough; a personal encounter with God is essential.

illustrations.title: Jacob's Wrestling with Angel
illustrations.text: In Genesis 32, Jacob wrestles with an angel by the river at night as he prepares to meet Esau, whom he fears will kill him. The angel engages him with just enough effort to resist without defeating him immediately, allowing the struggle to continue until the angel touches Jacob's hip socket, crippling him instantly. This injury opens Jacob's eyes, making him realize he has been fighting against God, and he emerges transformed, learning to lean on God rather than rely on himself. God gives him a new name, from Jacob to Israel, symbolizing his change, though he still has to grow into it.
illustrations.context: God allows us to wrestle with Him until we recognize our resistance, potentially injuring us to teach dependence and transformation.

illustrations.title: Gibeonites Deceive Israel
illustrations.text: The Gibeonites were deceitful characters who lived nearby but pretended to come from far away to avoid destruction. They tricked Joshua and the Israelite leaders by showing moldy bread and old clothes, claiming they were from a distant land and posed no threat. They made a covenant with Israel without consulting God, thinking it was an obvious decision. As a result, they regretted it because they leaned on their own understanding instead of seeking divine guidance.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate the danger of relying on one's own understanding rather than seeking God, leading to regretful decisions.

illustrations.title: Jesus Asleep in Storm
illustrations.text: By the way, we only have one occasion in the Bible where Jesus is sleeping. He slept every night as the God-man, though as God he never slumbers. We find Jesus asleep on the boat while a storm was raging, and the disciples woke him up, just like in the story.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate Jesus' humanity as the bridegroom who can be awakened, contrasting with God's unchanging nature.

illustrations.title: Jesus Calms the Storm
illustrations.text: The disciples are in a boat during a fierce storm, bailing water frantically while Jesus sleeps peacefully. They wake him, crying out, 'Lord, don't you care that we're going to perish?' Jesus rises, rebukes the storm with a simple command, 'Hush, be still,' and the wind and waves obey instantly, turning the raging sea into perfect calm. The disciples, who were terrified of drowning, become even more frightened by Jesus' power, wondering, 'Who is this that even the wind and the waves obey him?'
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate how Jesus can bring peace in the midst of life's storms, showing his care and authority.

illustrations.title: Jonah Asleep on the Ship
illustrations.text: Jonah is asleep in the ship's hold during a violent storm caused by his disobedience to God. The sailors, desperate to stop the storm, wake him and urge him to pray to his God. Jonah admits his God is the one who made the sea and that he's fleeing from Him, realizing they've angered the sea God by having him on board. The sailors are horrified, thinking, 'Oh great, you've ticked off the sea God, and now we're in trouble.'
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to contrast with the disciples' faith, highlighting how avoidance of God can lead to chaos in one's life.

illustrations.title: Hushing the Storm Like a Pet
illustrations.text: Jesus rebukes the storm with words like 'Hush, be still,' similar to how you might calm a noisy child or a small dog. For example, if you have a little Chihuahua or Dachshund that's barking or causing a fuss, you say, 'Shh, be still,' to quiet it down. This command implies a gentle yet authoritative control, as if the storm were a unruly pet under Jesus' command. Pastor Bob connects this to show the personal, intimate way Jesus handles chaos.
