illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to emphasize Jesus' effortless authority over nature, making his power relatable and immediate.

illustrations.title: Friend at Midnight Parable
illustrations.text: Jesus uses illustrations in the New Testament of going to your neighbor when you have friends who came to your house and you run out of food, and they're hungry at midnight. So you go to your neighbor's home and say, 'Hey, I have friends over; do you have any food?' The neighbor says, 'Go away, we're in bed.' But Jesus says that even though they won't get up because you're a friend, if you keep persisting and won't leave, they'll eventually give you food just to get rid of you.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate the importance of persistent prayer, showing that God will respond to our persistence even if it annoys others.

illustrations.title: Persistent Widow Parable
illustrations.text: Jesus makes this point that if someone bugs another person enough, like the unrighteous judge who decides the case of the widow, it's not because he cares about justice, but because he wants to be rid of her. The judge finally gives in just to stop her persistence. Jesus then asks if God, who truly loves us, would delay in answering our prayers.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that persistent prayer leads to answers from God, who cares deeply for us.

illustrations.title: Bride Awakening Bridegroom
illustrations.text: The bride awakens the bridegroom because she needs him, showing a picture of urgent and persistent seeking. This draws from the idea of deep relationship and necessity, where one doesn't give up until the other responds. It's used to emphasize how we should approach God in prayer.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that God's love is unstoppable and that we should persist in prayer like a bride seeking her bridegroom.

illustrations.title: High Priest's Breastplate
illustrations.text: The high priest wore the names of the children of Israel on his breastplate, called the ephod, with jewels for each of the twelve tribes right over his heart. This wasn't in his pocket but on his chest to symbolize how God carries His people close to His heart. It illustrates that God keeps us near and handles our burdens.
illustrations.context: This reference shows that God's love is unstoppable and that He holds His people close, like a seal over His heart.

illustrations.title: Marriage Vows Analogy
illustrations.text: When Becky and I got married, we wrote our own vows. Can you imagine if she said, 'Bob, I promise that I will love you before all the other guys that I'm going to love'? We had to revise those because the wedding wouldn't go through unless it was no other guys at all. Okay, no other gods before me means God isn't willing to share your deepest affection.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that God's jealous love means He doesn't want to share your affection, just as exclusive vows are required in marriage.

illustrations.title: Desert Motorcycle Adventure
illustrations.text: I remember as a young man going with a friend on a motorcycle ride. We were in 8th grade and went with his parents in the middle of the night. We ended up in the middle of the desert somewhere and got lost, but I wasn't really lost—I was just in the camper. This experience shows how unexpected challenges can arise, much like the trials in life. It's a simple story from my past that ties into bigger truths.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to illustrate that love or faith can endure through challenges, connecting to the idea that love cannot be quenched.

illustrations.title: The Military Flare Mishap
illustrations.text: We were out in the middle of nowhere on a deserted road around 3 a.m., and my friend and I got out of the car near a building. He grabbed an old military flare from the Korean War, and we lit it behind the building so no one would see, but it created a massive smoke and light show visible for miles. We panicked and tried desperately to put it out, but flares aren't designed to extinguish easily, making it a chaotic adventure. It was a good memory from the trouble we got into, and now I can share it years later.
illustrations.context: This story illustrates that just as waters cannot quench a military flare, God's love cannot be drowned out by overwhelming circumstances.

illustrations.title: Noah's Ark and God's Justice
illustrations.text: Our sins called for justice, and we deserved to die because humanity became wicked in its imaginations. God decided to flood the earth, but His love prepared an ark to save the remnant—Noah and his family—through the waters. God's wrath had to be poured out on sin since He is just, yet He sent His Son to die on Calvary so we could be saved. This shows that God's love endures despite destructive floods of problems.
illustrations.context: This retelling emphasizes that God's love persists through judgment, just as it did in the flood story, connecting to the unquenchable nature of divine love.

illustrations.title: George Mathewson's Unwavering Faith
illustrations.text: Listen to this: His name was George Mathewson, born with poor vision that gradually worsened until he was almost totally blind. However, he was academically gifted, and his devoted sister learned Latin, Greek, and Hebrew to help him study. He graduated from the University of Edinburgh in 1862 and became a minister in the Church of Scotland, memorizing sermons and Bible sections so well that his congregation didn't realize he was blind. Years before, he had been engaged, but his fiancée broke it off when she learned he was going blind and couldn't face life with him. His sister, who had cared for him all those years, was now getting married, leaving him at 40 years old with fresh remembrance of his own heartbreak.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to show that human love can fail and disappoint, serving as a mere foretaste of God's unchanging and enduring love.

illustrations.title: Hymn of Unfailing Love
illustrations.text: It says that in the midst of losing somebody he loved and intense sadness, the Lord inspired him to write 'O Love That Will Not Let Me Go'. I love the title of it. This story shows that even when human love fails, God's love endures forever.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that God's love remains constant despite personal loss and heartbreak.

illustrations.title: Beatles Quote on Priceless Love
illustrations.text: As the Bible says, if a man were to give all the riches of his house for love, it would be utterly despised, or as the Beatles said, 'Can't Buy Me Love'. This quote emphasizes that love, especially God's love, cannot be purchased with material wealth. It connects to the idea that God's love is a priceless treasure.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that God's love is invaluable and cannot be bought, highlighting its eternal nature.

illustrations.title: Worship Song of Divine Treasure
illustrations.text: There's an older song that some of you might remember: it says, 'Lord, you are more precious than silver, Lord you are more costly than gold, Lord you are more beautiful than diamonds, and nothing I desire compares to you.' The song goes on to say, 'Who can weigh the value of knowing you? Who can judge the worth of who you are?' This highlights that God's love surpasses all earthly values.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is using this to show that God's love is the ultimate treasure, more valuable than any material possession.

illustrations.title: Lamentations on God's Faithfulness
illustrations.text: It's interesting that the verse is taken from the book of Lamentations, where Jeremiah is lamenting many things. In that book, he gains a heavenly perspective amid suffering. For example, Lamentations 3:22 says, 'The faithful love of the Lord never ends; his mercies never cease. Great is his faithfulness.' This shows we can praise God even in difficult times, as his mercies are new every morning. So, when we sing about praising from the rising sun to the setting sun, we have reason to do so despite our laments.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to illustrate that God's unchanging faithfulness provides hope and a reason to praise even during suffering.

illustrations.title: Son at Prayer Night
illustrations.text: About a week and a half ago, my four-year-old son was standing right here during prayer night. We were praying for the election, and many of you were here but hadn't arrived yet. It was just me, him, and a couple of other people; he was walking around like this, looking this way, and he kept walking until he went off.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to share a relatable moment from a recent prayer gathering, likely emphasizing the simplicity and presence of family in spiritual activities.

illustrations.title: Distracted Child Incident
illustrations.text: There was a kid at the front of the stage with a nice red thing, and he walked into it, hitting his face directly. His hands barely caught him, but it was mostly on the face. As a dad or mom with kids, or just as a human, seeing this makes you hurt inside and think, 'Please look forward when walking forward.' If you're going backwards, look backwards, but if you're walking forwards, don't let things distract you.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the importance of keeping your eyes on the Lord and not letting distractions pull you away, as faith comes from hearing and focusing on His word.

illustrations.title: Shy Kid at McDonald's
illustrations.text: I was talking with my dad the other night, and he reminded me of a time we went to McDonald's. I was too afraid to order my own food, even though he urged me to just ask for a hamburger. I kept saying, 'Dad, you tell them; I can't.' This story shows how incredibly shy I was back then.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate his past shyness and how God has helped him overcome it to serve in ministry.

illustrations.title: Homiletics Class Pressure
illustrations.text: Many years ago, when I was just starting out in ministry, I attended Life Bible College and took a homiletics class on preaching. My professor was my former youth pastor, who I thought would go easy on me since he knew me well. I quickly realized it wouldn't be easy, and I worried that if I didn't get an A, I'd get fired from my ministry role. So, I worked hard and still ended up getting fired anyway.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to highlight how his journey in ministry involved overcoming fears and working diligently, attributing his progress to God.

illustrations.title: Preaching as Bus or Plane Pilot
illustrations.text: He shared an illustration about what preaching is. He explained it as being like a bus driver, trying to get everyone on the bus to the same destination. Or like a pilot of an airplane, where everyone wants to land at the same place, such as LA or Houston. There might be some turbulence along the way, but the goal is to land the plane safely. So, my goal today is to guide you to that destination through this message.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to show that preaching is about guiding people to a spiritual destination despite challenges.

illustrations.title: Matthew Henry's Quote on Jesus
illustrations.text: Matthew Henry said that our griefs and sorrows were allotted to him, and he bore them without blaming his lot. He carried them without shrinking from or sinking under them, even though the load was heavy and the way was long. Yet he did not tire but persevered to the end until he said, 'It is finished.' That's Jesus, that's our Lord and Savior, no doubt about it.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to illustrate that Jesus willingly took on our griefs and sorrows, enduring them fully.

illustrations.title: Jesus' Betrayal and Grief
illustrations.text: Remember in Mark 14:50, he was betrayed, he was arrested, and where were the disciples? They forsook him, as he was acquainted with grief. Peter denied him three times, Judas betrayed him, and his own people crucified him. This shows the depth of Jesus' sorrows as described in Isaiah.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that Jesus was a Man of Sorrows, acquainted with grief as prophesied.

illustrations.title: Sins Loaded on Jesus' Back
illustrations.text: You need to get the image: he loaded our sins on his back so that we wouldn't have to. This comes from Paul explaining in 2 Corinthians 5:21 that God made him who knew no sin to be sin on our behalf. By this, Jesus took the crushing burden of our iniquities upon himself, allowing us to live in righteousness.
illustrations.context: This analogy shows how Jesus bore the weight of our sins to free us from them.

illustrations.title: Women at the Empty Tomb
illustrations.text: Remember when the women went to the tomb to look for Jesus and he wasn't there. They wondered, where is he, where did he go? The angel of the Lord answered and said to them, indicating that Jesus had conquered death. This event highlights the resurrection as a pivotal truth.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that Jesus triumphed over death, fulfilling the prophecy.

illustrations.title: Jesus Heals the Leper
illustrations.text: A leper came to Jesus, and Jesus healed him. Leprosy was a horrible disease, and in the Old Testament, God commanded that lepers be quarantined and cry out 'unclean' to warn others, making their lives isolated and miserable. People often felt disgust rather than compassion toward lepers, especially when the disease was advanced, as in Luke's account where the man was full of leprosy, meaning his body was rotting away. Jesus, however, chose to heal this man with a touch, showing profound kindness. This story highlights how Jesus brought restoration to the outcast.
illustrations.context: This illustrates Jesus' compassion and ability to recognize and heal those society rejects.

illustrations.title: Compassion for Abused Animals
illustrations.text: We're often moved to compassion when we see sick or hurting people, like when I see commercials about abused dogs and my wife wants to adopt all of them. I usually say that two dogs are enough, but it shows how these images stir our hearts. This personal experience highlights how everyday suffering can evoke empathy, even if it's not always practical.
illustrations.context: This shows that people naturally feel compassion for those in pain, contrasting it with the rejection lepers faced.

illustrations.title: First Touch at Summer Camp
illustrations.text: I remember the first time Jesus touched my life. I was eight years old at summer camp in the San Bernardino mountains, sitting in a chapel on a wooden pew. I can still see the preacher's face; he wasn't a great preacher, but he talked about Jesus and what He did for me, how He died for me, and how I could come to Him for forgiveness and a changed life. As he spoke, the Holy Spirit touched my life for the first time, just like Jesus changed the life of the leper. I don't ever want to forget that, just like He's touched your life as well.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize that people should remember how Jesus has personally touched their lives and not forget His impact.

illustrations.title: Parental Love Analogy
illustrations.text: Think about how much you love your kids. You do anything for your kids. Think about that love for a moment and know that it doesn't even compare to how much Jesus loves us. This shows that God's love far exceeds our deepest human affections.
illustrations.context: To illustrate that God's love for us is infinitely greater than a parent's love for their children.

illustrations.title: Shadrach and Furnace Story
illustrations.text: One of my favorites is the story of Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego. These young Jewish men refused to bow down to King Nebuchadnezzar's golden image. As a result, he threw them into a fiery furnace. I have great memories of this story because it shows how God was with his people in their time of trial.
illustrations.context: To demonstrate that God cares for and protects his people, even in the midst of severe trials.

illustrations.title: Childhood Church Musicals
illustrations.text: I grew up in the church where my mom was the music director, and we did many musicals for Christmas and Easter. My sister and I were in every one, even when we didn't want to be, like when I played a camel in high school. In one musical about Shadrach, Meshach, Abednego, and Daniel, I played one of the young boys in a fake furnace built by church members, and we danced around while the music played, illustrating how Jesus was with them in the furnace.
illustrations.context: To illustrate that God is always present with His people, even in challenging situations, as experienced in the biblical story.

illustrations.title: Disciples in the Storm
illustrations.text: Remember the disciples in the storm; they were struggling against the wind and felt alone. Jesus knew their situation and was watching them all the time. He cares deeply for His people, even when they don't feel it.
illustrations.context: To show that Jesus is always watching over and caring for His followers, despite their feelings of isolation.

illustrations.title: Isaiah's Promise of Hearing
illustrations.text: Isaiah says in Isaiah 65:24 that before they call, I will answer, and while they are still speaking, I will hear. This is amazing because it shows God hears our cries even before we voice them. He connects this to His care for grief, sickness, anxiety, worry, sorrows, sadness, pain, and suffering, proving they are all covered.
illustrations.context: To emphasize that God hears and responds to His people's prayers immediately, demonstrating His constant attentiveness.

illustrations.title: African Pastor Carries Bags
illustrations.text: A pastor from the States was arriving for an important meeting with the general superintendent of a National Church in Africa. He and his driver met me curbside as I came out of the terminal with my bags. I was expecting the driver to help, but the elder leader greeted me and took my bags, carrying them to the waiting car. In his culture, such tasks were done by servants or those of lower status as a sign of respect. He was communicating that I was his guest, and he was taking full responsibility for my needs during my stay.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate how a leader humbly serves others, mirroring Jesus's servanthood.

illustrations.title: Isaiah on Bearing Sorrows
illustrations.text: The pastor reflects that we should be stunned by Jesus becoming the suffering servant, stooping low to meet us at our point of need. He carries our weaknesses, diseases, and sorrows that we are powerless to handle alone. Surely he has borne our griefs and carried our sorrows; it is on the cross that he took full responsibility for our sin, weaknesses, diseases, and pains by dying in our place.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob connects this quote to emphasize that Jesus takes on our burdens, urging us to release our pains to him.

illustrations.title: Israel at the Red Sea
illustrations.text: I wonder how Israel felt, God's people with their backs to the Red Sea and their faces toward the Egyptians. They were trapped and facing their enemies. But the Lord was with Israel, just as He is with us today.
illustrations.context: To show that God is with His people even in the midst of suffering and danger.

illustrations.title: Elijah on Mount Carmel
illustrations.text: What about Elijah? He might have been intimidated, being outnumbered 850 gods to his one on Mount Carmel. Yet, the Lord was with Elijah, supporting him against overwhelming odds. This demonstrates God's faithfulness in difficult situations.
illustrations.context: To illustrate that God stands with us even when we feel outnumbered and afraid.

illustrations.title: Martha and Mary's Grief
illustrations.text: What about Martha and Mary when Lazarus died? They wondered where Jesus was; He should have been there days ago, and their brother was dead. But God raised Lazarus up, showing He was with them in their pain. This highlights God's power over death and His presence in loss.
illustrations.context: To emphasize that God is present and active even in times of grief and loss.

illustrations.title: Personal Moments of Doubt
illustrations.text: One of the things I've learned is never count God out. There have been times in my life when I've almost given up, thinking God won't come through. But then, He does, showing up just when I need Him most. This reinforces the idea that God is reliable in every situation.
illustrations.context: To teach that we should never give up on God, as He always comes through.

illustrations.title: Psalm 30s Promise of Joy
illustrations.text: David says in Psalm 30:5, 'For his anger is but for a moment, his favor is for a lifetime. Weeping may last for the night, but a shout of joy comes in the morning.' This reminds us that no matter how dark the night, God's favor endures and joy will follow. It's a great reminder of God's enduring care.
illustrations.context: To illustrate that God's favor lasts a lifetime and joy follows periods of weeping.

illustrations.title: Joseph's Dark Nights to Dawn
illustrations.text: Remember Joseph? He had some dark nights; his brothers hated him and wanted to kill him, so they sold him into slavery. He found favor in Potiphar's house, but then he was falsely accused and thrown into prison. He lived there day after day, month after month, year after year. Then one morning, everything changed, and he became the second most powerful man in Egypt. No matter how dark the night looks, remember the morning is coming, and with it comes rejoicing.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses Joseph's story to illustrate that even in the darkest times, God brings eventual joy and turnaround.

illustrations.title: Jesus's Acquaintance with Grief
illustrations.text: Remember, Isaiah 53:3 says that we have a Savior who feels our hurts and is acquainted with grief. He wept at Lazarus's funeral; Jesus wept. We know this, but we don't always live in it, so we should remember that the Lord is always there to help us when we need him. He never leaves us to carry our loads alone.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote and story to emphasize that God empathizes with our struggles and always helps us bear our burdens.

illustrations.title: Mosaic Song on Burdens
illustrations.text: I love to worship and listening to worship music. If you come into my office at the church, I'm always playing worship music when I'm not studying. I love a song by the group Mosaic called Everlasting Light, and one of the lines says that even the darkest days are temporary, for you Lord are the Everlasting Light. This reminds us that our burdens and loads won't last forever. It's a powerful way to see that tough times pass.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this song quote to illustrate that life's burdens are temporary compared to God's eternal light, encouraging listeners that their struggles won't last forever.

illustrations.title: Paul's Thorn in the Flesh
illustrations.text: Paul knew about suffering, as mentioned in Romans 8:18, where he says that the sufferings of this present time are not worthy to be compared with the glory that is to be revealed. Remember his thorn in the flesh; Paul asked God to take it away three times. The Lord didn't remove it, but He did answer Paul in some way. This story shows that even great apostles faced ongoing trials.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob retells Paul's experience to emphasize that present sufferings are temporary and incomparable to future glory, offering hope in times of need.

illustrations.title: Raised in Church Anecdote
illustrations.text: I was raised in church and feel like I was born in church. I've heard this teaching my whole life about casting your cares on the Lord and giving your worries to God. It's nothing new, but the important question is whether we truly live it out by embracing and applying this promise in our daily lives.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to challenge listeners on whether they actively live out the promise of giving burdens to God, rather than just knowing it.

illustrations.title: Quote on Releasing Burdens
illustrations.text: Someone said this: Lord, I'm so discouraged, I don't know what to do. I have so many burdens and I gave them all to you, but you didn't take them. Jesus, will you tell me why? The answer is simple, little one, it's because you just won't let go. This quote emphasizes the need to fully surrender burdens to God.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to illustrate that God won't take our burdens if we don't truly release them.

illustrations.title: Man with Bundle of Sticks
illustrations.text: There's a photograph on one of the old Lead Zeppelin album jackets that shows an old man carrying a huge bundle of sticks. It's so heavy that he's bent over at the waist, overwhelmed by the load. I wonder if there are many people today carrying similar crushing burdens, not literal sticks but emotional or spiritual ones. Maybe that's you, carrying a heavy burden when you could give it to God.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to show that people often carry unnecessary burdens themselves instead of letting God help.

illustrations.title: Carrying Heavy Load
illustrations.text: I'm carrying my load and walking through life, and the burdens come and the cares come, making it heavier and harder and more painful until I feel like I can't take another step. What do I have to do? I have to take it off and put it at the foot of the cross at the feet of Jesus and say, Lord, help me shoulder the load. Then, I'm always tempted to take it back, saying, God, I need to get back in there, but He says no, we have to release it.
illustrations.context: This analogy illustrates the struggle of holding onto life's burdens and the need to fully surrender them to Jesus for relief.

illustrations.title: Jesus' Yoke Quote
illustrations.text: Jesus is teaching the crowds in Matthew 11:28-30, saying, 'Come to me, all who are weary and heavy laden, and I'll give you rest. Take my yoke upon you and learn from me, for I am gentle and humble in heart, and you will find rest for your souls, for my yoke is easy and my burden is light.' Here, Jesus emphasizes that His yoke is easy and light compared to others, as long as we don't rebel against it.
illustrations.context: This quote explains why Jesus' burden is lighter than worldly ones, encouraging listeners to accept His yoke for true rest.

illustrations.title: Yoke for Oxen Analogy
illustrations.text: A yoke is a wooden bar placed over the neck of a pair of animals to help them pull together. When training a new animal like an ox, ancient farmers often yoked it to an older, stronger, more experienced animal that bore the burden and guided the young one through the learning process. Just as we are yoked to Christ, the yoke is tailor-made to fit perfectly, like it was adjusted for the ox so it wouldn't irritate its neck.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that Jesus' yoke is easy, well-fitting, and provides guidance and rest for our souls.

illustrations.title: Cinderella Slipper Analogy
illustrations.text: Jesus' yoke is a perfect fit, just like when Prince Charming slipped that glass slipper on Cinderella's foot. It's tailor-made for you and me, so it doesn't irritate or hurt. If our yoke feels hard and heavy, it's not truly his.
illustrations.context: This shows that Jesus' burden is perfectly suited and easy, emphasizing personal comfort and fit.

illustrations.title: Spurgeon on Coming to Jesus
illustrations.text: Charles Haden Spurgeon said this about this passage: 'Come, he drives no one away.' He calls them to himself, and his favorite word is 'come'—not 'go.' To Moses, come; to Jesus himself, we must come. Sometimes we go to our knees of our own volition, and Jesus says plainly, 'My yoke is easy and my burden is light,' promising to bear our load with us.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that Jesus invites everyone to come to him without driving anyone away.

illustrations.title: Strongmen and Jesus's Strength
illustrations.text: I used to like to watch these strongman shows with huge bodybuilder guys, some of the strongest in the world, pulling semi-trucks, lifting cars, and carrying huge stones. It's amazing how strong they were, and I watched because I could never do that myself. But Jesus, though not a big muscular guy, has strong shoulders—stronger than anyone else's, as he bore the sins of the entire world and can handle our loads.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to illustrate that Jesus has the strength to bear our burdens, just as strongmen handle heavy weights.

illustrations.title: Mother Caring for Comatose Son
illustrations.text: In 1972, two-year-old Huin Schwan fell from a table and went into a coma, waking up after six days unable to talk or move. His mother was terribly distressed, especially since she couldn't afford a nursing home for his care. Instead, she cared for her son herself, showing remarkable dedication in the face of overwhelming burden.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to highlight how Jesus helps bear heavy loads, like the mother's distress and care.

illustrations.title: Mother's Burden of Love
illustrations.text: You see, because he's unable to move, he's liable to get terrible bed sores. For the past 30 years, his mother has done the unbelievable; she has carried her son on her back. As of 2002, Lee Q Lon was 65 years old and weighed 88 lbs, while her son, a grown man, weighed 180 lbs. On many occasions, Lee has fallen and fractured bones while carrying her son, yet she continues. When asked how she can do this, her reply is simple: 'He Ain't Heavy, He's My Son.'
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate that Jesus can easily bear our burdens, just as the mother carries her son without complaint.

illustrations.title: Teaching Church History Class
illustrations.text: I recently taught a church history class, and a big theme of that class was that church history hasn't stopped. We're still in church history, and in this portion, we know that He is ruling, reigning, and returning. This serves as a reminder that the same God who worked in the past is active today.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that God's work continues unbroken from the past into the present.

illustrations.title: Hope as an Anchor
illustrations.text: I will put my hope in Jesus, my anchor to the ground, as it's right out of Hebrews. We have a hope that is an anchor for the soul, and it isn't going anywhere. Even when storms and tumultuous times surround you, you can put your faith in Jesus and know that he will anchor you firmly, because he is faithful and true.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to illustrate that faith in Jesus provides steadfast stability during life's challenges.

illustrations.title: Son's Face-Plant Story
illustrations.text: About two weeks ago, I was in this room about to start a prayer for the nation before the elections on a Monday night. My four-year-old son was with me, and he loves to scare me by climbing on the stage and jumping off, so I told him to stop. Then, as he was walking, he looked away and face-planted right there. Even if I didn't know him, that would hurt, but as his dad, it was especially concerning. I often remind him to look forward when walking because he's always distracted by what's around him.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how we get distracted in our faith walk and need to keep our eyes on Jesus.

illustrations.title: Eyes on Jesus Analogy
illustrations.text: I think that's often us with our walks with the Lord; He's saying, come this direction, trust me, keep your eyes right here. But we're like, what about all the stuff going on, like the election and other concerns? He's just saying, keep your eyes on me, the author and perfector of your faith. We come back to get reset because our faith isn't always strong, and Jesus only asks for a mustard seed of faith, which grows by hearing the Word of God.
illustrations.context: This analogy emphasizes the need to focus on Jesus amidst life's distractions to strengthen faith.

illustrations.title: Overcoming Childhood Shyness
illustrations.text: I was thinking about this because every time I stand up here, I always ask myself one question: how did I get here? If you knew me when I was young, I was very shy as a little boy and didn't like to talk. I wouldn't even order my own food in a restaurant or at the Little League field snack bar. My dad would say, 'Go order a hot dog,' but I'd refuse and make him do it for me. So, I was really shy back then, and now I wonder how in the world I ended up here.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating how God has transformed his life from extreme shyness to confidently sharing God's word.

illustrations.title: Class with Senior Pastor
illustrations.text: I was taking a class because my professor was actually my senior pastor, who had been my youth pastor years ago. I thought it would be great and easy, like a kickback experience. But then I realized he was a tough teacher and wouldn't let me slide by. I even worried that if I didn't get an A, he might fire me from my youth pastor role. In the end, I got an A and kept my job, but it was all just a joke.
illustrations.context: This story highlights the personal dynamics and expectations in learning from a mentor, leading into a discussion on preaching.

illustrations.title: Preaching as Piloting a Plane
illustrations.text: He gave an example of preaching and said it's like being a bus driver where you want to get everyone to the same destination. Or like a pilot of an airplane with one goal in mind, whether it's to LA, San Antonio, Houston, or New York. Your aim in homiletics is to land the plane safely, getting everybody there despite any turbulence along the way. That means navigating through potential confusion to deliver the message effectively.
illustrations.context: This analogy emphasizes that the goal of preaching is to guide the audience to a clear destination or understanding.

illustrations.title: Matthew Henry's Jesus Quote
illustrations.text: Pastor Bob refers to Matthew Henry the great commentator who said this about the verse: our griefs and sorrows were allotted to him, he bore them and blamed not his lot, he carried them and did not shrink from or sink under them, the load was heavy and the way long, yet he did not tire but persevered to the end until he said it is finished. That's Jesus, there's no doubt about it. Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize that Jesus endured suffering without complaint. This quote highlights how Jesus fulfilled the prophecy by bearing the weight of human sins.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses the quote to illustrate that Jesus bore griefs and sorrows without blame or fatigue, connecting it to the prophecy about the Messiah.

illustrations.title: Jesus Carrying Sins Burden
illustrations.text: You have to get the image that he loaded our sins on his back, why so that you and I wouldn't have to carry them. That's the powerful picture from the scriptures. It shows the weight Jesus took upon himself for our sake.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating how Jesus took our sins upon himself so that we don't have to bear them, emphasizing redemption through Christ's sacrifice.

illustrations.title: Jesus Healing the Blind Man
illustrations.text: Remember in John, Jesus heals a blind man, and when they ask who touched you, he simply says a man named Jesus. Those who know Jesus have no trouble recognizing his footprint as they walk through life. They have no trouble recognizing the touch of Jesus Christ; there's no mistaking it.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that people who truly know Jesus can easily recognize His influence and work in their lives.

illustrations.title: Jesus Healing the Leper
illustrations.text: In Mark 1:40 and 41, Jesus heals a leper who came to him. Leprosy was a horrible disease, and the worst part was how people treated those afflicted, forcing them to quarantine and cry out 'unclean' to warn others away. We're often moved to compassion for sick or hurting people, like when seeing commercials about abused dogs—my wife wants to rescue them all, but I say two dogs are enough—yet lepers didn't usually arouse such compassion.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is using this story to highlight how Jesus shows compassion to the outcast and to contrast societal treatment of the afflicted with modern reactions to suffering.

illustrations.title: Jesus Heals the Leper
illustrations.text: In chapter 5 of the Gospel of Luke, verse 12, Luke shares this account of a man full of leprosy, meaning his disease was advanced and his body was rotting away. Jesus chose to heal him with a touch, stretching out his hand even though he didn't have to. People were forbidden to touch lepers, especially one in such a severe state, so this act showed immense compassion. Jesus touched him, reminding us that a life truly touched by Jesus remembers it forever.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate how Jesus's touch brings healing and compassion, emphasizing that it changes lives forever.

illustrations.title: Pastor Bob's Camp Conversion
illustrations.text: I remember the first time Jesus touched my life; I was eight years old at summer church camp, sitting in a little chapel with wooden pews. The preacher shared about how Jesus loved me, died for me, and had a plan for my life, offering forgiveness and a relationship with him. As he spoke, the Spirit of God touched me and changed my life forever; I committed to Christ right there. That moment transformed me, just as it has for so many others.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob shares this to remind listeners of the lasting impact of Jesus's touch in their lives and to encourage them not to forget how he has changed them.

illustrations.title: Encouraging Struggling Youth
illustrations.text: I talk to many young people who are bogged down with the cares of life and don't feel special at all, and I always tell them that God loves you. Do we really understand how much He does though? I wonder sometimes if we truly understand how special we are to God.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that even when young people feel overwhelmed and unimportant, God's love for them is real and profound.

illustrations.title: Parental Love Comparison
illustrations.text: Moms and dads, think about how much you love your children. You would do anything for your child, and know that love does not even come close to the love that God has for you and for me. God's love is unbelievable and intrinsic to who He is.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is using parental love to show that God's love far exceeds even the deepest human affection.

illustrations.title: Dimensions of Divine Love
illustrations.text: God's love is so wide, it's wide enough to include every person, for God so loved the world. It's so long, it's long enough to last for all eternity. It's deep, it's deep enough to reach the worst sinner. And it's high, it's high enough to take us to heaven.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is emphasizing the immeasurable and all-encompassing nature of God's love as revealed at the cross.

illustrations.title: Childhood Church Play Memory
illustrations.text: I was raised in the church, and my mother was our music director, so we did a lot of musicals around holidays. I even played a camel in a manger scene once, which was fun. In one musical about Daniel and the three young Jewish men, I got to play one of those characters. Our senior pastor played King Nebuchadnezzar, yelling at us, while we danced in a furnace made of plywood by men from our church. I was about 10 years old, and I'll never forget when Jesus appeared in the play, just like in the story.
illustrations.context: To show how the story of Shadrach, Meshach, and Abednego has a special place in his heart, illustrating God's intervention and presence.

illustrations.title: Disciples Facing the Storm
illustrations.text: Remember the disciples in the storm; they were struggling against the wind and felt alone. Jesus knew their situation and was watching all the time. Even though they felt isolated, he cared for them deeply.
illustrations.context: To emphasize that God is always watching over his people, even in difficult situations.

illustrations.title: Pastor Carries Visitor's Bags
illustrations.text: There was a pastor sharing this, and he says I was arriving for an important meeting with a general superintendent of a National Church in Africa. He and his driver met me curbside as I came out of the terminal with my bags. I was expecting the driver to help me with my luggage, but instead, the Elder leader greeted me and took up my bags and carried them to the waiting car. I was stunned because in his culture, things were carried by servants or those of lower status as a sign of respect. He was taking full responsibility for me during my stay, communicating his desire to see my needs while I was in his care and under his authority.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate how Jesus, as the greater one, serves the lesser by carrying our burdens and sorrows, just as the pastor did for his guest.

illustrations.title: Israel Trapped by Egyptians
illustrations.text: I wonder how Israel felt with their backs to the Red Sea and their faces towards the Egyptians. It was a desperate situation, seeming impossible. Yet, we know God was with them and delivered them.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that God is always with us in our suffering, just as He was with Israel.

illustrations.title: Elijah Outnumbered on Mount Carmel
illustrations.text: You think Elijah may have felt intimidated, being outnumbered 850 to one on Mount Carmel. He faced overwhelming odds against false gods. But God showed His power through Elijah.
illustrations.context: This story emphasizes that God is with us even when we feel outnumbered or alone.

illustrations.title: Martha and Mary Lose Lazarus
illustrations.text: Martha and Mary wondered where Jesus was when Lazarus died, saying, 'You should have been here; our brother is dead.' They felt abandoned in their grief. But we know God raised Lazarus, showing His presence and power.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob highlights that God is with us in loss and grief, just as He was with Martha and Mary.

illustrations.title: Pastor's Moments of Doubt
illustrations.text: There have been times in my life when I've been on the brink of saying, 'Okay God, I guess I can't count on you in this situation.' We used to sing that song in children's ministry, 'I'm counting on God.' But every time, God comes through unexpectedly.
illustrations.context: This personal story encourages listeners not to count God out, even in uncertainty, as He has always proven faithful.

illustrations.title: David's Psalm on Joy
illustrations.text: Psalm 30 verse 5 is a beautiful prayer from David: 'For his anger is but for a moment; his favor is for a lifetime. Weeping may last for the night, but a shout of joy comes in the morning.' David reminds us that no matter how tough things get, God's favor endures and brings rejoicing.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to convey that God's favor outlasts temporary suffering, encouraging perseverance.

illustrations.title: Joseph's Dark Nights Turnaround
illustrations.text: Think about Joseph. He had some dark nights because his brothers hated him and wanted to kill him, so they sold him into slavery. It was okay for a while as he found favor in Potiphar's house, but then he was falsely accused of a crime and thrown in prison, facing really dark nights day after day. Then one morning, everything changed for Joseph as he became the second most powerful man in all of Egypt. This shows that even in the darkest times, God can bring about a complete transformation.
illustrations.context: Even in dark nights, God can bring morning and rejoicing, as seen in Joseph's life.

illustrations.title: Hospital Fear and Dad's Comfort
illustrations.text: I remember when I was in the hospital one time years ago. I was pretty scared, and my dad knew I was having a hard time. He simply said to me, 'Daryl, things are going to get better. Things are going to get better.' And that's how I know these burdens don't last forever.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate that burdens and difficult seasons are temporary and will improve, encouraging listeners to hold on during tough times.

illustrations.title: Paul's Thorn in the Flesh
illustrations.text: Boy, Paul knew a lot about suffering. He had this thorn in the flesh and asked God three times to take it away. God didn't remove it but answered him, saying, 'My grace is sufficient for you.' Paul even considered this burden a strength, as mentioned in 2 Corinthians 12:10.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize that God's grace is enough to handle sufferings and burdens.

illustrations.title: Pastor's Personal Burden
illustrations.text: I think about a burden I'm carrying and I'm trying to let the Lord bear the load with me. It's hard, but God's grace is sufficient for me. This reminds us that even though burdens are part of life, they don't last forever.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob shares this to show that we can embrace God's promise to lighten our loads despite difficulties.

illustrations.title: Burden Release Quote
illustrations.text: Someone said, 'Lord, I'm so discouraged. I don't know what to do. I have so many burdens, and I thought I gave them all to you, but you didn't take them. Jesus, will you tell me why that's so?' The answer's simple, little one: it's because you just won't let go.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that people must actively release their burdens to God rather than holding onto them.

illustrations.title: Led Zeppelin Photograph Analogy
illustrations.text: There's a photograph on one of Led Zeppelin's albums. It's a photograph of an old man carrying a large bundle of sticks on his back, and on his back, there's this bird. This image illustrates the weight of burdens people carry unnecessarily.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to show that people often refuse to let go of their burdens, much like the man in the photo.

illustrations.title: Burden Carrying Analogy
illustrations.text: If I've got my load of burdens and I'm walking through life, life's good at first, it's not that heavy yet, but they start to get heavier and heavier, and pretty soon I'm weighed down. What do I have to do? I can't take it anymore. Jesus isn't going to come and take this load off my back; I have to take it off and put it at the feet of Jesus at the foot of the cross. But if you're like me, I hold on and say, 'Lord, I just need to get back in there; there's one thing, one burden I just have to have back; I have to carry this by myself.' And He says, 'No, Daryl, zip that up and get out of here.' We all do that; we have to totally give it to Him and leave it at the foot of the cross, whatever it is.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating how people must fully surrender their burdens to Jesus instead of holding onto them.

illustrations.title: Yoke of Oxen Analogy
illustrations.text: A yoke is a wooden bar placed over the neck of a pair of animals to help them pull together, not apart. When training an ox, ancient farmers would yoke a strong, experienced animal to a new, weaker one, so the stronger animal could bear the burden and guide the younger through the process. Just as that happens with animals, when we're yoked to Jesus Christ, He guides us. The word 'easy' in Greek means well-fitting, like how in Palestine, ox yokes were carefully adjusted to not irritate the animal's neck and cause pain. In other words, Jesus' yoke is tailor-made to fit us perfectly.
illustrations.context: To illustrate that Jesus' yoke is easy, well-fitting, and provides guidance like a stronger animal helps a weaker one.

illustrations.title: Cinderella's Perfect Slipper Fit
illustrations.text: It's like when Prince Charming goes down and slips that glass slipper on Cinderella's foot; it's a perfect fit. This illustrates how Jesus' yoke fits us perfectly. If our yoke feels hard and our burden heavy, it means we're not letting Jesus bear it with us.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to show that Jesus' yoke is a perfect fit, making burdens easier to bear.

illustrations.title: Lincoln Driven to His Knees
illustrations.text: Abe Lincoln was one of my favorite people in history, and during the Civil War, he told a friend how he was often driven to his knees because there was nowhere else to go. Sometimes that's how it is with us; there's just no place we can go other than the Lord, and it takes us a while to figure that out. He was sharing this to highlight our need to turn to God in desperation.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob references Lincoln to illustrate that in overwhelming times, we must turn to the Lord as our only refuge.

illustrations.title: Spurgeon on Jesus' Call
illustrations.text: Charles Spurgeon says this about the passage: 'Come, he drives none; he calls them to himself. His favorite word is come, not go—to Moses, come unto me; to us, we must come to Jesus himself.' This quote emphasizes that Jesus invites us gently, and sometimes we go to our knees willingly or because our load is too much.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to explain that Jesus' invitation is welcoming and urges us to come to Him for rest.

illustrations.title: World's Strongest Man Feats
illustrations.text: I used to like to watch this TV show called the World's Strongest Man competition, where these big guys pull semi-trucks, lift cars, carry huge Atlas stones, and perform incredible feats of strength. This illustrates the limits of human strength compared to Jesus, who promises to carry our burdens. It's a fun way to see how Jesus' strength surpasses even the mightiest efforts.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this example to contrast human strength with Jesus' promise to bear our loads easily.

illustrations.title: Mother's Burden of Love
illustrations.text: In 1972, two-year-old Hu Jin Schwan fell from a table and went into a coma. When he woke up after six days, he was unable to talk or move, leaving his mother terribly distressed because she couldn't afford a nursing home. Instead, she cared for him herself, showing the unfathomable depth of her love. Because he was unable to move, he was prone to terrible bed sores, so for the past 30 years, she has carried him on her back. As of 2002, she was 65 years old and weighed 88 pounds, while her grown son weighed 180 pounds. On many occasions, she has fallen and fractured bones while carrying him, yet she continues. When asked how she can do this, her reply is simple: 'He ain't heavy, he's my son.'
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate that Jesus has strong shoulders and can bear our griefs and sorrows, just as the mother faithfully carries her son.

illustrations.title: Groceries and Son's Help
illustrations.text: It's actually a dad law that if you get to the house with groceries, you have to carry them all in one trip, otherwise you're not a man. That's just the way it is, so I try to grab all the bags. I can't do it, and it gets too heavy, so I have to call my five-year-old son to come help, which is embarrassing for me. But sometimes, you just need a little bit of help to carry your load to the Lord.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate that it's okay to seek help with burdens, just as he needs assistance with heavy groceries, encouraging people to bring their loads to Jesus.

illustrations.title: Isaiah Prophecy of Emmanuel
illustrations.text: You know the verse Isaiah 7:14, which is usually quoted around Christmastime and rightly so as a prophecy of the coming Messiah to be born of a virgin. It says, therefore the Lord Himself will give you a sign: behold, a virgin will be with child and bear a son, and he will be called Emmanuel, which means God with us. Jesus is God with us, not just a teacher about God, but actually God come to dwell among us, fulfilling this prophecy.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that Jesus is God incarnate, directly connecting to the theme of God's presence with people like Joseph.

illustrations.title: Hark the Herald Angels Sing Lyrics
illustrations.text: We have that great hymn 'Hark! The Herald Angels Sing,' which includes the lines: veiled in flesh the Godhead see, hail Incarnate deity, pleased as man with men to dwell, Jesus our Emmanuel. This hymn highlights the Incarnation, where deity becomes man, showing God dwelling among us. Pastor Bob connects this to the idea that Jesus reveals God's character and nature.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to illustrate the concept of the Incarnation, reinforcing that Jesus is God with us in human form.

illustrations.title: John 1 on Word Becoming Flesh
illustrations.text: John writes in Chapter 1 of John that no man has ever seen God, but the only begotten God, who is in the bosom of the Father, has revealed Him. The Word became flesh and literally tabernacled among us, as God in the Old Testament revealed Himself in the tabernacle as the Shekinah glory. This shows Jesus as God in a body, revealing the very character and nature of God. Pastor Bob explains this to connect the idea of God's presence with Joseph to Jesus' revelation of God.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to demonstrate how Jesus reveals God, linking it to the theme of God's presence in Joseph's life and beyond.

illustrations.title: Blessing Spout Analogy
illustrations.text: We all want to be under the spout where the blessings come out, but I want to praise God to make me the vehicle of His blessing. Lord, I want to be the spout in other people's lives. This means being a channel so that others can experience God's goodness through me.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that we should be channels of God's blessings to others, not just recipients.

illustrations.title: Fruit of the Spirit Analogy
illustrations.text: We've talked about the fruit of the Holy Spirit, which we all want—like love, joy, peace, patience, kindness, and goodness. A tree produces fruit and never eats it itself, so if we're to produce this fruit, it's not for our own sake but always for the benefit of somebody else. This way, others can taste and see that the Lord is good through the kindness and love coming from us.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that the fruit of the Holy Spirit is meant to bless and impact others, showing God's character through our lives.

illustrations.title: Tree Not Hoarding Blessings
illustrations.text: Pastor Bob points out that you've never seen a tree say it's hungry or complain about giving away its fruit. This simple analogy shows that trees naturally share what they produce without holding back. He uses it to illustrate that God's blessings, like fruit on a tree, are meant to be given away rather than kept for ourselves.
illustrations.context: To emphasize that blessings from God are intended for sharing and not for personal hoarding.

illustrations.title: Blind Men in Jericho
illustrations.text: Pastor Bob retells the story of the blind men in Jericho who sat by the road, begging as Jesus and his group passed by on their way to Jerusalem. When the blind man heard the crowd and learned it was Jesus of Nazareth, he cried out for mercy, recognizing the opportunity for healing. This biblical account highlights how blessings follow where Jesus goes, turning ordinary moments into divine encounters.
illustrations.context: To show that Jesus brings blessings and that we can become vehicles of those blessings to others.

illustrations.title: Song of Impending Blessing
illustrations.text: Pastor Bob shares an old song he loves, quoting the lines: 'Something good is going to happen to you this very day, something good is going to happen to you, Jesus of Nazareth is passing your way.' He explains that this song draws from the biblical story and underscores how blessings naturally follow Jesus. By connecting it to his message, he emphasizes that we should expect and share these blessings as followers of Christ.
illustrations.context: To illustrate that blessings accompany Jesus' presence and encourage us to be channels of blessing to others.

illustrations.title: Boy Trusts Stranger at Beach
illustrations.text: I shared a story with this group about a little boy who went to the beach with his sister. He wanted to go out in the water but had his stuff with him and wasn't sure what to do. So he walked up to a total stranger, an older lady sitting there with her sunglasses on, and said, 'Excuse me, ma'am, are you a Christian?' She said, 'Yes, as a matter of fact, I am.' This showed how he trusted her based on that.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate that trustworthy people, especially Christians, can be relied upon in everyday situations.

illustrations.title: Faith Test with Quarter
illustrations.text: A person asked another if they believed in the Bible, and she affirmed every word. He then asked her to hold his quarter while he walked on the water to test her faith. This quick story illustrates the importance of genuine belief and how it's tested in real life.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show how faith is tested through simple, everyday challenges.

illustrations.title: Life as Preparation Quote
illustrations.text: Pastor Chuck said in his autobiography that everything in your life is preparation for something else, meaning what you're going through right now is important but serves as preparation for future events. The things God gives you are opportunities that act as tests. Pastor Bob emphasizes that we should hear this repeatedly because it connects our daily experiences to greater purposes.
illustrations.context: This quote illustrates that life's challenges and opportunities are tests from God to prepare us for bigger responsibilities.

illustrations.title: Joseph's Faithfulness Journey
illustrations.text: Joseph was found to be faithful quickly by Potiphar and the chief jailer, even in small tasks like handling money, time, property, skills, and opportunities. This led to greater responsibilities, as God was testing him for larger roles, such as becoming Pharaoh's right-hand man and a savior to Egypt and Israel. The story parallels Jesus, who went from prison to palace, showing how faithfulness in little things leads to authority over much.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize that God tests our faithfulness in small matters to determine if we're ready for greater responsibilities.

illustrations.title: Drone Shot Perspective
illustrations.text: When I read Revelation 19:11, I look at it from an earthly standpoint, but we're going to see it from a different standpoint, more like a drone shot. This helps us understand the scene from a broader, heavenly view rather than just our limited perspective. It's a way to visualize the second coming with greater clarity.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating how biblical events can be viewed from different perspectives to emphasize a heavenly viewpoint.

illustrations.title: Personal Worry Example
illustrations.text: When something's going wrong in your life, the natural reaction is to get upset, worried, or angry and try to fix it. Here's the truth: when I start worrying about something, which I'm tempted to all the time, I know I'm not reflecting God's character. God wants us to trust Him instead of letting worry take over.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that worrying hinders us from reflecting God's character and that we should trust God in our reactions.

illustrations.title: Joseph Resists Temptation
illustrations.text: Now it came about after these events that his master's wife, Potiphar, looked with desire at Joseph, a good-looking young man about 17 years old. We don't know how old Mrs. Potiphar is or her name, so we'll call her Mrs. Potiphar. She could have been a cougar or just a young woman; we don't know, but Joseph had gone through an extremely difficult time, from a place of honor with his father to being betrayed by his brothers, sold into slavery in a foreign country with no believers around him. Despite this, he remained faithful in his job day in and day out. Suddenly, there was a problem: his master's wife wanted him to sleep with her, saying 'lie with me,' but he refused. He explained to her that his master trusted him completely, putting all that he owns in his charge, and withheld nothing from him.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate that with God, one can conquer temptation, as Joseph did despite his hardships.

illustrations.title: Resisting Temptation Casually
illustrations.text: If Joseph wasn't tempted, I don't think he'd have to run away; he'd just say talk to the hand, I'm not interested. It wouldn't be a big deal for him. But the point is, he was tempted and had to take action.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to show that Joseph faced real temptation and had to flee, rather than dismiss it easily.

illustrations.title: Biblical View of Marriage
illustrations.text: The Bible says in Hebrews 13 that marriage is honorable to God, but the adulterer will be judged, and the marriage bed is honorable too. We need to have a high view of marriage in our culture, based on Scripture, especially when facing sexual temptation. This helps us understand the importance of fidelity as Joseph did.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize the need for a scriptural perspective on marriage to resist temptation and honor God.

illustrations.title: David and Bathsheba Story
illustrations.text: David slept with Bathsheba, and she became pregnant. He called Uriah back from the battlefield, hoping to trick him into sleeping with his wife to cover up the affair, but Uriah refused out of honor for his fellow soldiers. David then conspired to have Uriah killed in battle and took Bathsheba as his wife. It took over a year for David to confess his sin, and he wrote Psalm 51 as a result.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that all sin is ultimately and supremely against God.

illustrations.title: Psalm 51 Confession Quote
illustrations.text: In Psalm 51, David prays, 'Against you, you only, have I sinned and done what is evil in your sight, so that you are justified when you speak and blameless when you judge.' Pastor Bob explains that David is emphasizing his sin is ultimately against God, even though it affected others like Uriah. This highlights the profound nature of true repentance and accountability to God.
illustrations.context: This quote shows that sin is most wretchedly against God, as David confesses.

illustrations.title: God's Bragging on Job
illustrations.text: Jot down Job 1:8. Remember, God is bragging on Job in front of the devil. It's interesting how God, like a parent bragging about their child, sees and is impressed with what we do for Him. In Job 1:8, God said to Satan, 'Have you considered my servant Job? There is no one like him on earth, a blameless and upright man, fearing God and turning away from evil.' Those two go together—he fears God and turns from evil.
illustrations.context: To illustrate that fearing God means being blameless and turning from evil, as God praised Job.

illustrations.title: The Diligent Craftsman
illustrations.text: I remember hearing about a craftsman who was a talented carpenter, uniquely gifted in making things like sculptures. He was building something and asked his assistant to finish a part that would be covered over with wood. The assistant wondered why spend time on it since no one would see it. The craftsman replied that he would, because it's about knowing that God sees everything, and it's not about how you look to others but about integrity before God.
illustrations.context: To show that we should maintain high standards even in unseen areas because God is always watching.

illustrations.title: Joseph Flees Temptation
illustrations.text: Now it happened one day that he went into the house to do his work and none of the men were around. She caught him by the garment, saying, 'Lie with me,' and he left his garment in her hand and fled outside. She's pursuing him, and he doesn't say things like, 'You've got a problem; maybe we should talk about it or have coffee.'
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating how Joseph actively fled from sexual temptation, showing that sometimes one must run rather than engage.

illustrations.title: Resisting vs Running Temptation
illustrations.text: If you're choosing to resist a sexual temptation when the Bible says you should be running, you are in trouble. It's not enough to be on the right track if you aren't moving fast enough. This emphasizes the need to flee from certain sins rather than just resist them.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that for sexual temptation, fleeing is required, not merely resisting, to avoid falling into sin.

illustrations.title: Joseph's Trials and Betrayal
illustrations.text: Think about what Joseph has gone through: he had dreams from God that he would rule his family and the world, with stars bowing down to him. His father loved him uniquely as the son of his favorite wife, giving him a place of honor. But he was betrayed by his brothers, sold into slavery, and torn from his family and the land of Canaan. In Egypt, God's favor promoted him in Potiphar's house, but then Potiphar's wife falsely accused him of attempted rape after he refused her advances. She took his garment and told everyone, shifting blame to Joseph, leading to his imprisonment despite his innocence.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this retelling to draw parallels between Joseph's suffering and Jesus' experiences, emphasizing themes of innocence and divine faithfulness.

illustrations.title: Fury of a Scorned Woman
illustrations.text: There's an old saying that hell hath no fury like a woman scorned, and it applies to Potiphar's wife who sought to punish Joseph for rejecting her. She accused him of trying to rape her, hoping it would cost him his life, and even manipulated the situation by taking his garment and telling the household. This led to Joseph being falsely accused and imprisoned, highlighting how her anger escalated the injustice against him. Pastor Bob connects this to show the depth of human deceit and its consequences.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to illustrate the intensity of Potiphar's wife's revenge and how it mirrors the unjust suffering Joseph endured.

illustrations.title: Silent Suffering Like a Lamb
illustrations.text: Joseph is innocent yet falsely accused and does not utter a single word in his defense, which parallels Isaiah 53:7 that says he was oppressed and afflicted yet did not open his mouth, like a lamb led to the slaughter. Pastor Bob explains this to show the similarity to Jesus, who suffered silently for others' sins. This quote underscores the theme of quiet endurance in the face of injustice, connecting Joseph's story to Christ's.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to highlight how Joseph's silence mirrors Jesus' innocent suffering, emphasizing spiritual parallels in handling accusation.

illustrations.title: Pontius Pilate Parallel
illustrations.text: There's some manipulation that's being used to get Potiphar to do something he doesn't want to do, similar to Pontius Pilate who finds that Jesus is innocent and would like to release him, but if he does, he's no friend of Caesar. This shows how external pressures can force unjust decisions. It's very interesting to me the parallels here between Joseph's situation and Pilate's.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate how manipulation influenced Potiphar's actions, drawing a parallel to Pilate's dilemma in the Bible.

illustrations.title: Resilient Toy Analogy
illustrations.text: I don't know how many of you grew up with one of these, but I had one when I was a little boy, and I don't even know if they're sold much anymore. It's like this toy that you can hit as hard as you want, and it always comes right back up smiling. That's how I picture Joseph, who remains faithful and in a good mood no matter what trials hit him. Just like the toy, Joseph bounces back from adversity.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that Joseph maintained faithfulness and a positive attitude despite worsening circumstances.

illustrations.title: Pressure Reveals Inner Leaks
illustrations.text: If there's stress on the hose, pressure makes it leak. A pinhole might not show without pressure, but when you turn it on, leaks display themselves. You go and get a big cup of coffee, forget the lid, and you're late for work; you hit a speed bump and the coffee spills everywhere. The bump didn't create the coffee; it just displayed it. Pressures in life are like that—they reveal what's inside us.
illustrations.context: Pressures in life reveal hidden flaws or true character, just as physical pressure exposes leaks or spills.

illustrations.title: Joseph's Story of Testing
illustrations.text: God sent Joseph ahead as a man who was sold as a slave. They afflicted his feet with fetters and laid him in irons until the time that his word came to pass. This refers to the dream he had, and the word of the Lord tested him. It's about how God tests us to see if we can believe His promise even when we can't see it coming to pass.
illustrations.context: God uses testing and trials to prepare and prove faithfulness, as seen in Joseph's life leading to the fulfillment of God's promises.

illustrations.title: Emergency Broadcast System Test
illustrations.text: I don't think they do it much on TV anymore, but when I was a kid, the Emergency Broadcast System on TV and radio would interrupt programming. They would say, 'This is a test. This is just a test. If this had been an actual emergency, you would have been instructed on what to do.' Every time we go through something difficult, we need to hear God say, 'This is a test. I'm still God and I'm in charge.'
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is using this analogy to show that life's trials are like tests, reminding us that God is in control and working things for good.

illustrations.title: Hippies Share Christian Songs
illustrations.text: Back in 1970, when we were in the little chapel and the Lord was working with many young people, these hippies with long hair and beards came in and said they were musicians who had just gotten saved. They wanted to share the Christian songs the Lord had given them with the young people. I was cautious since they were new believers, so I asked them to play something for me first. They brought in their guitars from their old Volkswagen van and started playing, and we discussed performing at our Monday night young people's gathering. They mentioned one of their guys was in jail for a marijuana charge and would get out at noon, so they could likely play that night. That marked the beginning of their music ministry, and the song they played that touched my heart was 'Welcome Back,' making me feel truly welcome even though I hadn't gone anywhere.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate the welcoming and transformative power of faith for new believers.

illustrations.title: My Calvary Chapel Conversion
illustrations.text: There was a Bible study going on, and I didn't have anything better to do, so I went. That was the beginnings of Calvary Chapel, with about 30 or 40 of us sitting there. Chuck Smith came out and taught the Bible study, and when it was over, he asked if anybody wanted to come forward. I thought about it all night and couldn't wait to get back. Then, I accepted the Lord, with Love Song and Children of the Day playing. I remember Chuck Gerrard asking if anyone wanted to raise their hand and accept the Lord, and I did. Everyone was excited that I had invited the Lord into my life.
illustrations.context: This illustration shows how attending a simple Bible study led to the pastor's personal acceptance of faith.

illustrations.title: Accidental Start of Music Ministry
illustrations.text: We met the Lord through an accidental Bible study when I went down there. Marcia had just written a song called 'For Those Tears I Died' and taught it to us, and we added harmonies as we practiced. We performed it at the study with her guitar, and someone invited our group to sing elsewhere the next month, so we quickly prepared five or six songs. This led to us never stopping, as it was contagious and new, especially since we were acoustic in an era when drums and electric guitars weren't allowed in churches. By the first year, we borrowed money, recorded our first album, and saw it become hugely popular with God's clear blessings.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating how God unexpectedly guides and blesses beginnings in ministry.

illustrations.title: Hawaii Revival Experience
illustrations.text: I remember a wonderful time we went to Hawaii and Greg was going to minister. We parked ourselves in front of the Rainbow Hotel, set up our speakers, played music, and Greg gave the message. All these people started coming out of the water and accepting the Lord; it was just amazing.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the powerful and visible impact of God's work during the revival, showing how people responded with emotion and faith.

illustrations.title: Conversion Through Testimony
illustrations.text: It reminds me of a story about Ernie and Debbie Retino; they met and fell in love, and became their own worship group. They came and spoke in the classroom, giving their testimonies and saying things like 'Praise God, Praise the Lord, Hallelujah.' I thought, wow, their eyes were shining, and I wondered what this was all about. I went to talk with them afterwards, said hi, I'm Jewish, and this guy handed me Isaiah 53. I read the scripture and clearly saw how it foretold Jesus' death, resurrection, and what he did for us in taking our sin. A week later, I knelt by my bed and asked Jesus to be the Lord of my life.
illustrations.context: To illustrate how encountering a testimony of faith led to personal conversion and embracing God's love.

illustrations.title: Answered Prayer for Money
illustrations.text: I needed 300 dollars after spending all the money my dad had left. I heard that when you pray, you should be specific to Jesus if your motive is pure, so I looked up and prayed, 'Lord, I need 300 bucks; it's not for me, it's for my dad.' Then I went to pick up my check, which was supposed to be for 100 bucks, but it was for 300, and I smiled knowing God had answered. When asked why I was smiling, I didn't explain because I was remembering this miracle.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that God answers specific prayers when motives are pure.

illustrations.title: Commitment Through Hymn Vision
illustrations.text: Not long after that, I went to Calvary Chapel and formally accepted Christ, becoming aware of my vocation. I found a hymnal at my house and opened it to the song 'Take my life and let it be consecrated, Lord, to Thee; take my life and let me sing always only for my King.' I sang it through once, realizing it was my prayer of consecration, so I sang it again and felt there was no turning back. Then I had a vision of two hands: one with my voice and the other with Jesus, who said I could only choose one, and I chose Him, deciding that even if I never sing again, I just want Him.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating his full commitment to Jesus over personal talents and worldly pursuits.

illustrations.title: Singing and God's Presence
illustrations.text: We were harmonizing backstage and started singing together, then we went to a camp in the mountains where we put a couple of songs together. When we sang, the power and presence of God filled the room and anointed it. I remember being obedient and doing what God asked; I was in a dormitory at UC Riverside, singing in the stairwell, and girls from the floors above gathered to listen. I prayed for a song for them and sang about knowing a Savior in Jesus. Later, on stage, I felt Jesus' presence and heard that worship is the attitude of the heart in fellowship.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to show how obedience and heartfelt worship lead to encountering God's presence.

illustrations.title: Parent's Joy in Gifts
illustrations.text: I was thinking as I sat here watching everyone use their gifts for the Lord, and my daughter was playing the guitar. I felt privileged to be in the group with her, enjoying her gift of leadership and music. When a parent gives a child a gift and the child tosses it aside and never uses it, it makes the parent sad, but seeing children play with and use the gift brings the parent great joy. Our Heavenly Father feels that same joy tonight as He sees all of you using your gifts on stage, in the art, sound, and singing.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating how God experiences joy when people use the spiritual gifts He has given them, similar to a parent's joy in seeing a child use a gift.

illustrations.title: Childhood Friendship with Debbie
illustrations.text: I'm especially blessed because my friend Debbie is here tonight; I've known her since she was 11, and I was 11 too. We grew up together and went to school together, and I didn't know she was coming, so hi Debbie. It's a beautiful thing to have someone who's known me for practically all my life.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is emphasizing the blessing and joy of long-term friendships and community in the context of shared faith and service.

illustrations.title: Jesus Revolution Memories
illustrations.text: We were part of the Jesus Revolution in the early 1970s, and Debbie and I were at Campus Crusade together. We'd drive in my blue Corvair from San Bernardino to Arrowhead Springs for concerts every Saturday, enjoying the music and community. Our first date was at a Children of the Day concert, and we spent weeks attending events like that, including the Thief in the Night movie. As a senior in high school, I visited the Philadelphia House, a Christian commune near the ocean, where I sat on the floor surrounded by music and people writing songs from Scripture. We drove around with cars covered in bumper stickers like 'One Way Jesus,' reflecting the era's spiritual enthusiasm. Back then, people were searching for meaning through various paths, including protests, drugs, and the Vietnam War, but many found it in the Holy Spirit's movement.
