illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to highlight the authentic and freeing experience of following Jesus during the Jesus Movement, contrasting it with traditional religion and other cultural searches.

illustrations.title: Revival Wave Experience
illustrations.text: It just took us like a wave, and it seemed like thousands of people were coming to Christ. Then Glenn and I got married at Calvary Costa Mesa with Pastor Chuck in 1976, and we started serving the Lord right away. That generation was ready for revival, just as this one is now.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to illustrate that past generations experienced revival and that the current one is also primed for it despite challenges.

illustrations.title: Prison Analogy for Freedom
illustrations.text: It would almost be like visiting somebody in prison and bringing them a pillow and cookies to make their stay a little better, when Jesus wants to open the prison door and let them out. We don't want to make you feel better and prop you up in your current state. Instead, He has freedom for each one of us tonight through the exchanged life.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to show that true salvation offers complete freedom from sin, rather than just temporary comfort in bondage.

illustrations.title: Galatians 2:20 Explained
illustrations.text: One of my favorite verses is Galatians 2:20, which says: 'I am crucified with Christ: nevertheless I live; yet not I, but Christ liveth in me: and the life which I now live in the flesh I live by the faith of the Son of God, who loved me, and gave himself for me.' This means that when Jesus died on the cross, He died as me, so I no longer live, but Christ lives in me. The good news is that I don't have to live by my own faith, which is never enough, but by the faith of the Son of God who lives in me.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that Christians should rely on Christ's faith and power for living, not their own efforts.

illustrations.title: Childhood Concert Experiences
illustrations.text: I was around then. I was tiny, but I was there, and I remember my older brother and sister were old enough to go to all these concerts, and I went with them. I didn't know what was going on, but I loved this music; it was the soundtrack of my childhood. Someone asked me at one of the concerts we did how many of these songs I know, and I said all of them, even though they thought I wasn't old enough. According to my mom, I was the first kid dedicated in the tent, which is cool. Because I was around and growing up in all of this, I met the folks I interviewed, like Peter and Hannah Jacobs, and Ernie and Debbie Routino; they're friends I've known since I was a kid.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob shares his personal background to connect with the audience and establish his familiarity with the people and events discussed.

illustrations.title: Jesus Knocking for Revival
illustrations.text: Behold, I stand at the door and knock, and if anyone hears my voice and opens the door, I will come in and sup with them and they with me. Is this just for non-believers? No, it's for believers who might be in a dry patch. Open the door; behold, He stands at the door and knocks, wanting to ignite your fire once again.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to show that Jesus seeks to revive and renew believers experiencing spiritual dryness.

illustrations.title: Noah's Trust Analogy
illustrations.text: Take an umbrella when there wasn't a cloud in the sky. Just keep building and doing your best and pray. Hey Noah, I'll take care of the rest because I'm the weather man. He'll take care of the rest.
illustrations.context: God will handle the results if we faithfully obey Him, as in Noah's story.

illustrations.title: Jesus Revolution History
illustrations.text: The Jesus Revolution changed the world and began a whole new genre of music that shared the gospel truth in a special way. We loved sharing the music of the 60s and 70s with you. We need to keep that momentum going today.
illustrations.context: The Jesus Movement demonstrates how music and cultural shifts can spread the gospel, encouraging continued efforts today.

illustrations.title: Victor's Missionary Story
illustrations.text: Victor and Nicole are our missionaries to Costa Rica, sent out by us years ago. Victor originally came from Costa Rica, moved to the United States, and attended a school of ministry for Spanish speakers that Pastor Chuck used to run at Costa Mesa. He excelled there and has been serving in Costa Rica for several years, offering the same free school to pastors, lay leaders, and church staff. This school teaches verse-by-verse Bible study, a style we value in Calvary Chapel, and it's completely free. During their time away due to government issues, the school went online and grew to include students from 14 different countries and nearly 80 students.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate how the church raises and sends missionaries who expand ministry, such as teaching Bible study methods globally.

illustrations.title: Missionaries as Body Fingertips
illustrations.text: They're the fingertips of the body of Christ here at Calvary Chapel East Anaheim. They are the ones out there doing the work in another country, representing Jesus and ministering to churches, pastors, and leaders that influence hundreds and thousands of people. Now, they have the privilege of touching people all over the world.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating how missionaries extend the church's reach and actively serve in spreading the faith.

illustrations.title: Hunting for Jesus in Scripture
illustrations.text: As I like to tell the congregation that comes on Wednesday night, we're on a hunt for Jesus—that's what we're looking for in the Old Testament. The Old Testament is the Bible of Jesus and Paul, and Jesus is all through it. We're studying through the Old Testament, starting with the book of Deuteronomy, to discover these truths.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is encouraging people to engage in Bible study to find and understand Jesus in the Old Testament.

illustrations.title: Wednesday Night Origins Story
illustrations.text: A lot of you don't know that Wednesday night started as my home Bible study with just 20 people in my home. The church grew, and we didn't fit anymore, so now we have it here. This shows how our fellowship has expanded over time.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is encouraging attendees to join Wednesday night services to build deeper connections and become part of the body of Christ rather than just a crowd.

illustrations.title: Pastors with Warning Signs
illustrations.text: Two pastors from local churches stood by the side of the road holding up signs. One sign said 'The end is near,' and the other said 'Turn before it's too late.' They held up the signs as each passing car went by, and the first driver that sped by saw the sign and yelled out.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating the urgency of heeding spiritual warnings, as discussed in the context of Jude's message about contending for the faith.

illustrations.title: Pastors Warn of Bridge
illustrations.text: There was a story about pastors who were warning drivers that a bridge was out, but the drivers yelled from their window, 'Leave us alone, you religious nuts!' As the car went around the curve, they heard screeching tires and a big splash. One pastor then said to the others, 'We should just put up a sign that says bridge out, the end is near, turn before it's too late.'
illustrations.context: This illustrates how Christians who talk about end times and judgment are often seen as alarmists by the world.

illustrations.title: Sunday School Kid on Heaven
illustrations.text: It's like that Sunday school teacher who asked the kids, 'How many of you want to go to heaven?' They all raised their hand except one little boy, who I call Johnny because that's always the name in my stories. When the teacher asked Johnny why he didn't raise his hand, he said, 'Well, when you die.' The teacher clarified, and Johnny responded that he wanted to go to heaven, but not if he had to die to get there.
illustrations.context: This shows that people may want the benefits of heaven but are reluctant to face the reality of death and judgment.

illustrations.title: Revelation's Second Coming Scene
illustrations.text: In Revelation 19, the heavens will roll back like a scroll, and we will see Jesus on a white horse, faithful and true, judging in righteousness and waging war. He's coming back to earth with the armies of heaven, which I believe means we should start practicing horseback riding because we're going to be in that army. We're coming back with him after he's caught us up in the air, as the Bible teaches.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate the reality of God's judgment and the excitement of Christ's return, urging preparation for the end times.

illustrations.title: Steering a Parked Car
illustrations.text: I often tell people it's very hard to steer a parked car if you want the Lord's leading and you're just waiting for it. That's a mistake because many times, if we seek, we'll find; if we knock, it'll be opened. We have a part to play—do what you know, and you'll know what to do. Too many of us suffer from the paralysis of analysis, doing nothing and wondering why God isn't guiding us.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to emphasize that believers must take action to receive God's guidance rather than waiting passively.

illustrations.title: Paul and Barnabas's Guidance
illustrations.text: Go read how Paul and Barnabas were guided by the Holy Spirit; they were called by God into ministry as described in Acts 13, where the Lord said to set them apart for the work. God didn't give them a map of their journeys, even though we have one in our Bibles today. They went out, discovered their path through closed doors, and found they couldn't go into Bithynia and Pamphylia because the Holy Spirit prevented it. They learned their direction on the road, not in advance.
illustrations.context: This retelling illustrates that God guides believers through action and circumstances, not by providing a complete plan upfront.

illustrations.title: 9/11 Etched in Memory
illustrations.text: 911 will be etched into the minds of the generation that lived through it, serving as a profound warning and pivotal moment. Just as Jude shifted from encouragement to a word of warning in his letter, this event reminds us how certain moments change our perspective forever. It's a real historical reference that highlights how warnings can deeply impact and linger in collective memory.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses the 9/11 event to parallel Jude's shift to a warning, emphasizing how such moments make spiritual truths unforgettable.

illustrations.title: 9/11 and October 7th Failures
illustrations.text: When I see a digital clock showing 9:11, it has a different significance for me than for my grandchildren who didn't experience it. There's a new date, October 7th, that will live in infamy. Both 9/11 and October 7th were incredible failures of intelligence: 9/11 for the United States and October 7th for Israel. They admit as much; Netanyahu and others didn't know what the enemy was planning beforehand. Perhaps they could have or should have known.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses these historical events to illustrate how failures in awareness mirror spiritual threats that people often miss.

illustrations.title: Benhadad's Thwarted Attacks
illustrations.text: In the book of Second Kings, the enemy of Israel is the king of Syria, named Benhadad, who repeatedly tries to attack Israel. Every time he plans an assault, Israel seems to know in advance and thwarts him, frustrating him after at least three attempts. He becomes convinced he has a mole on his staff and calls his officials together to find out who's leaking information. They tell him no one is betraying him, but that Israel has a secret weapon: the prophet Elisha, who hears from God and knows everything, even exaggerating that Elisha knows what he says in his bedroom. This leads Benhadad to realize God's omniscience is at play, preparing Israel for every attack.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob retells this story to show that God sees enemies and threats that people often fail to notice, emphasizing the need for spiritual awareness.

illustrations.title: Advice from Early Ministry
illustrations.text: Before this church started, I called Calvary Coast of Mes, and Pastor Chuck had given me permission to start Calvary Chapel of Placentia in my home. I remember the advice of one of the pastors helping new Calvaries; they said to make those people who have come the best loved, best fed sheep in town. That's the best counsel I could give to anyone called into ministry: make the people your ministry, whether there are two or two thousand, ensuring they are the best fed and best loved people because that's what Jesus, the Good Shepherd, does.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the importance of loving and caring for church members as a shepherd does for the sheep.

illustrations.title: Shepherd Protecting the Flock
illustrations.text: A Good Shepherd loves to feed the sheep, but if a shepherd only feeds the sheep and never warns them, they're just fattening them for the wolf. Part of the shepherd's job is to protect the sheep from things they don't see or understand. This means not only nurturing but also safeguarding the flock from dangers.
illustrations.context: This analogy emphasizes that pastors must protect their congregation from spiritual threats, not just teach them.

illustrations.title: Old Mountain Man Faith
illustrations.text: I'm kind of like that old guy who lived up in the mountains. He said, 'I believe the Bible from cover to cover, I even believe the cover which says Holy Bible.' This shows his unwavering commitment to the scriptures. It's a simple way to emphasize complete trust in God's word.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the importance of fully believing the Bible as the complete word of God without seeking new revelation.

illustrations.title: Police Briefing Experience
illustrations.text: I remember when Assistant Chief Bob Vernon came and spoke to us. He was talking about his first day on the job with the LAPD and said he was a little nervous out on the streets, but he had been trained and was excited to be there. They discussed assignments and updates, including being on the lookout for wanted individuals, just like how Jude describes false teachers.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the concept of a 'bolo' or being on the lookout for false teachers, similar to police briefings that prepare officers for potential dangers.

illustrations.title: Police Officer's First Arrest
illustrations.text: On his beat, there was a guy wanted for murder who had been seen, so they issued a picture of him to identify him. The officer didn't want to take the picture out of his pocket all day, so he put it inside his hat. All day, he'd walk down the street, see a guy, take off his hat to look at the picture, and everyone thought he was the most polite cop in the world. Later that day, he spotted the suspect in a bar, got nervous, pulled out his gun while shaking, and showed the picture asking, 'Is this you?' The suspect admitted it, and the officer handcuffed him quickly because he was afraid of accidentally shooting.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the need to be aware of dangerous people creeping into the church, just as the officer had to watch for the murderer.

illustrations.title: Personal Prophecy Study Impact
illustrations.text: I've shared before that while I'm excited about studying prophecy, it really changed my life as a Christian from a young man in the 70s. I read books like The Late Great Planet Earth and many others, and listened to Pastor Chuck. This study transformed my faith, and I can't wait to study Revelation with you. It's a personal experience that highlights the importance of prophecy in my spiritual growth.
illustrations.context: This personal story emphasizes how studying prophecy can deeply affect a believer's life and urges focus on overlooked aspects of the last days.

illustrations.title: Police Training Theft Spotting
illustrations.text: My training officer, Kevin, an experienced police officer, was training me, and I'll never forget. It was a Friday afternoon, and we were driving down Lambert in Laab when suddenly he said, 'Put on the brake, stop!' He made me back up because he saw something I didn't—a group of guys loading lumber into a truck after remodeling a house. We pulled up, and he started questioning them about what they were doing, who the owner was, and if they had permission. At first, it seemed innocent, but soon it was clear they were strangers stealing the lumber, and I would have missed it entirely if I were alone.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the need to be suspicious and test for hidden wrongdoing, just as we must detect false teachers among us.

illustrations.title: Harry Houdinis Deceptive Strength
illustrations.text: You know, Harry Houdini was one of the greatest magicians or illusionists ever; he was really an escape artist and a contortionist, extremely strong. In his shows, he would let strong men punch him in the stomach as hard as they could, and it didn't hurt him. But if you're not aware, Houdini died of a ruptured appendix after a show backstage, showing how even his impressive feats had vulnerabilities.
illustrations.context: This highlights how false prophets can deceive like Houdini's illusions, emphasizing the importance of testing spirits.

illustrations.title: Performer Ignores Warning
illustrations.text: A college student watched a performer in his shows and unexpectedly hit him as hard as he could in the stomach. The performer played it off like it wasn't a big deal, even though his appendix ruptured and he needed medical help. He didn't seek treatment, thinking it was just a minor issue, and ultimately died from the ruptured appendix.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the danger of ignoring warnings, emphasizing that Biblical warnings about false teachers must be heeded to avoid spiritual harm.

illustrations.title: Forewarned is Forearmed Quote
illustrations.text: There's an old saying: to be forewarned is to be forearmed. This means that when the Bible gives us warnings, we need to be aware and prepare for potential attacks, rather than dismissing them. Pastor Bob connects this to the idea that false teachers don't always announce themselves, so we must stay vigilant.
illustrations.context: This quote underscores the importance of preparing for and recognizing false teachers as warned in the Bible.

illustrations.title: Wolves in Sheep's Clothing
illustrations.text: Jesus said that false teachers come in as wolves in sheep's clothing, meaning they disguise themselves to appear harmless and trustworthy. This analogy shows how they can deceive people without raising suspicion, potentially pulling the wool over your eyes. By using this image, Pastor Bob highlights the subtle nature of spiritual threats.
illustrations.context: This analogy points out how false teachers hide their true intentions, making it hard to detect them.

illustrations.title: Wanted Posters Analogy
illustrations.text: Jude is going to erect a virtual post office wall, like the ones where they used to put up wanted posters for the bad guys, such as the FBI's Most Wanted list. This wall will display the characteristics of false teachers so we can recognize them. Pastor Bob uses this to explain how studying the Old Testament helps identify these intruders who have crept in unnoticed.
illustrations.context: This analogy helps explain how Jude's letter provides clear descriptions to identify false teachers, much like wanted posters identify criminals.

illustrations.title: Movie Hero's Victory Shout
illustrations.text: C Scott winning this battle in the movie and shouting out at General Raml, saying, 'I read your book Raml,' in other words, I know your techniques and understand what you're doing. This shows knowing the enemy's strategies. Paul the Apostle echoes this idea in the New Testament.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate the importance of understanding Satan's devices, just as the movie character knows his opponent's tactics.

illustrations.title: Forgiving the Repented Sinner
illustrations.text: Paul the Apostle says in 2 Corinthians that he's talking about the need to forgive a guy who had sinned, been kicked out of the church, and now repented. He said we need to forgive the guy and accept him back in, why? Lest Satan gain an advantage over us, for we are not ignorant of his devices. In other words, Satan works through unforgiveness, and we must become aware of it.
illustrations.context: This retelling emphasizes that unforgiveness allows Satan to work, urging believers to forgive to avoid his schemes.

illustrations.title: Israel's Exodus and Judgment
illustrations.text: The saved from Egypt, that was Israel, the children of God, where the Passover happened as a picture of the Cross; blood was applied to their homes and they were released from the death penalty. They were set free from bondage and slavery, just like we were set free from sin and Satan. They went through the Red Sea, a picture of baptism, but with most of them God was not pleased because of their unbelief, and they perished in the wilderness.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to warn about the dangers of unbelief leading to judgment, as seen in the groups God judged in the Old Testament.

illustrations.title: Cicadas as Empty Shells
illustrations.text: Any of you ever lived in the South? Then you know what a cicada is. Cicadas will keep you up at night if you keep your windows open because they are noisy, and they're not locusts. We have a picture of one; if you've never seen one, here's what they look like—they're beautiful, though people often say they're locusts, but they're not. By the way, this particular one is the shell they leave after they shed, and it just crunches into nothing.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses the cicada's empty shell to illustrate people who maintain a form of godliness but lack its true power.

illustrations.title: Woman's Divorce Justification
illustrations.text: Like that woman who was only married about a year and said to me, 'Pastor, I know God hates divorce, but God doesn't want me to be unhappy. I'm His daughter, and He wants me to be happy. I prayed about it and have a peace about it, so I'm going to divorce. I know God will forgive me afterwards.' This example shows how people misuse grace as an excuse. It's a real conversation that highlights the danger of twisting God's forgiveness.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how people turn grace into a license to sin by assuming forgiveness for intentional wrongdoing.

illustrations.title: Milk Turning Sour Analogy
illustrations.text: It's interesting how they talk about turning grace; I think it's kind of like milk that turns and becomes sour. There are those who turn grace into disgrace, perverting the doctrine of grace into a permission to satisfy the flesh. This comparison shows how something good can become corrupted.
illustrations.context: This analogy demonstrates how grace can be twisted from a pure gift into an excuse for sin.

illustrations.title: Ray Comfort's Evangelism Example
illustrations.text: Just watch any of Ray Comfort's videos; the average person feels like if there's a God, they're going to heaven because they're a pretty good person. Until they listen to Ray share the scriptures, he uses the law of God, the Ten Commandments, to help people see that they're sinners and might not go to heaven. This real-world approach challenges common misconceptions about salvation.
illustrations.context: This example shows how the law reveals sin and convicts people of their need for true repentance.

illustrations.title: Hymn of Abundant Grace
illustrations.text: Like that old hymn says, 'Grace, Grace, God's Grace, Grace that can pardon and cleanse within, Grace, Grace, God's Grace, Grace that is greater than all my sin.' We teach that because it's true; you've never out-sinned the grace of God and you never will. This highlights how grace abounds even where sin is great.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this hymn to illustrate that God's grace is greater than any sin, emphasizing the unlimited forgiveness available through Christ.

illustrations.title: Demons Recognizing Jesus
illustrations.text: You go through the Gospels and find that when the demons speak about Jesus, they get it right, saying things like, 'We know who you are, you're the Holy One of Israel.' They have A+ on their theology test, as James says, the demons believe in God and they tremble, but they don't surrender to His lordship. This shows that mere intellectual belief is not enough for true faith.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this biblical example to demonstrate that knowing Jesus intellectually, as the demons do, is insufficient without surrendering to His authority and lordship.

illustrations.title: Christians Defying Caesar
illustrations.text: If you worked for the Roman government, once a year you were required by law to demonstrate your allegiance by burning incense to Caesar as a God and saying the words 'Caesar is Lord,' meaning he is the Supreme Master of your life. Believers who worked for the Roman government refused to do that and died for their refusal. They didn't say things like 'Caesar's a nice guy' or 'Caesar's the boss'; instead, they declared 'Jesus is Lord' even at the cost of their lives.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that true allegiance to Jesus as Lord requires unwavering commitment, even facing death, rather than submitting to any earthly authority.

illustrations.title: Business Under New Management
illustrations.text: I like to use that illustration of the restaurant or that business that puts up the big sign 'Now Open Under New Management.' That should be true of you when you become a Christian; you're saying not only do I want to go to heaven and be forgiven, but from now on, I am surrendered to a new master. It's no longer about me or anyone else being in charge.
illustrations.context: This analogy shows that becoming a Christian means fully surrendering control to Jesus as the new master of one's life.

illustrations.title: Alexander's Demand for Surrender
illustrations.text: In 331 BC, Alexander the Great was marching his armies towards India and had already conquered much of the known world. He came upon a particular city that was a fortress with an army inside. He only had a small contingent of men, far too small to fight them on the open field. So, he went to the wall of the city where the king was standing. As history records, Alexander the Great demanded that the king immediately surrender.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate how obedience impacts our witness to God.

illustrations.title: King's Allegiance Demonstration
illustrations.text: A general approached a king with only 100 men, and the king laughed, confident in his larger army. The general then commanded his men to march toward a cliff, and one by one, 11 of them marched off to their deaths, showing absolute obedience. The king, seeing this level of allegiance, surrendered the city, realizing he couldn't match such loyalty.
illustrations.context: This story illustrates the power of unwavering obedience to God, showing how it can lead to victory and influence others.

illustrations.title: Lord of All Quote
illustrations.text: Pastor Bob shares the old saying, 'if he's not Lord of all he's not Lord at all,' explaining that it means Jesus must have complete control over every area of our lives. He connects it by saying this might highlight areas we need to surrender, and it's not about guilt but about true lordship. Ultimately, he challenges listeners to make 2024 a year of full commitment to Christ.
illustrations.context: This quote emphasizes that Jesus' lordship requires total surrender, not partial, to truly live for eternity.

illustrations.title: Christmas Eve Conversions
illustrations.text: On Christmas Eve, I had people raise their hands and many received Christ in this room. Maybe you were one of them, or perhaps you were next to someone who did, or you were aware of it happening. This event shows that salvation can occur in everyday church settings.
illustrations.context: To challenge listeners who may not have accepted Christ to do so immediately.

illustrations.title: Recent Personal Evangelism
illustrations.text: I had the privilege of leading a guy last week to Christ out in the courtyard; he'd come with his friend, and I prayed with him. I was overjoyed to do that, and then the friend, who was a Christian, asked about the prayer we used. This experience demonstrates that leading someone to Christ can happen casually and anywhere.
illustrations.context: To emphasize that people should not wait for a formal altar call to share the gospel.

illustrations.title: Beggar Sharing Gospel Quote
illustrations.text: Many have said that sharing our faith and the gospel is like one beggar telling another beggar where to find bread. But you already found it, so now it's our privilege to share it with others.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is emphasizing that sharing the gospel is a humble privilege for those who have already received it, encouraging everyone to evangelize.

illustrations.title: Personal Focus on Jesus
illustrations.text: I'll be honest with you, I don't want my year to be focused on a future election. I want to live out the election I already got and have Jesus as Lord today and every day. I'm not so concerned about a new person in the White House; that's where my focus is.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is urging listeners to prioritize their spiritual life and focus on Jesus rather than worldly concerns like elections.

illustrations.title: Forgetting to Pray for Others
illustrations.text: I can't tell you how many times I've told somebody I'll pray for them and then forgot. So please don't come up and say, 'Pastor Bob, will you pray for me,' because I don't want to lie—I want to pray for you right now. It's in part because there are too many times in my history that I've said to somebody, 'I'll pray for you,' or they asked me to pray and I said sure, then I completely forgot. Later, they thanked me, saying God moved when you prayed, and I had to think, oh no, I didn't pray for you—it must have been someone else.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to emphasize the importance of praying immediately for others to avoid forgetting and to encourage genuine ministry in church relationships.

illustrations.title: Eric Liddell's Surrender
illustrations.text: When Eric Liddell was dying, some of you may remember him as the star of the true story Chariots of Fire. He was a Christian Olympic runner who trusted God, believing that honoring God's Sabbath was more important than winning a gold medal, so he gave up that dream to accept whatever God had for him. It turned out God provided another gold medal for him in a different way. On his dying breath, he said these three words: 'It's all surrender.' He died as a prisoner of war in China and impacted the prisoners and guards there.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that the victorious Christian life is about complete surrender to God.

illustrations.title: Parents Awaiting Child's Birth
illustrations.text: Your parents probably couldn't wait for the day you were born because they got to see you for the first time, hold you, love you, and start a brand new life with you. Well, guess what? The God of eternity has waited for you until the moment you die, because that's when you'll be face to face with the God who has loved you from all eternity and waited for you. And that's why I believe to the Lord that is the most precious day in your existence—the day you move from this life into eternity with Him.
illustrations.context: To show that God eagerly anticipates our entry into eternity, just as parents look forward to a child's birth.

illustrations.title: Jesus as the Spiritual Rock
illustrations.text: The children of Israel all drank the same spiritual drink, for they were drinking from a spiritual rock that followed them. And that rock was Jesus. He was with the children of Israel as they came out, revealing God in his various manifestations. This shows Jesus' role in their journey. It's a clear biblical example of his presence and guidance.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that Jesus was present with the Israelites, emphasizing his role as the creator and revealer of God.

illustrations.title: Peter's Fishing Obedience
illustrations.text: Peter's out there not catching any fish, and Jesus says to throw the net on the right side. Peter, the fisherman, wonders who's in charge, but decides to follow Jesus anyway. Every time he tells me to do something, it works out better than my own plans, like how Peter caught fish when he obeyed.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that following Jesus' guidance leads to better results than relying on our own efforts.

illustrations.title: Front Seat Back Seat Surrender
illustrations.text: I was sitting in the front seat, trying really hard to be the driver, thinking I was making good time but always ending up late. That old song about front seat and back seat reminds me of that struggle. Now I'm sitting in the back seat, letting Jesus Christ run my life, and that's the reality of true surrender.
illustrations.context: This analogy emphasizes the need to let Jesus guide our lives instead of trying to control everything ourselves.

illustrations.title: Pastor's Judas Reaction
illustrations.text: I've often said, if I came to Judas knowing what he knew, I would have had a really hard time. I would have either skipped him or said, 'Here, wash and wait, let me get some Brillo.' I would not have been a happy camper about Judas, but Jesus was loving Judas right to the end.
illustrations.context: To show that Jesus exemplified perfect love and servanthood by washing Judas's feet despite knowing his betrayal.

illustrations.title: Ira Sankey's Civil War Encounter
illustrations.text: The story is told of Ira Sankey, the famous singer with D.L. Moody, who was on a Mississippi riverboat around Christmas time. People recognized him and asked him to sing, so he performed the hymn 'Savior, Like a Shepherd Lead Us,' which spoke of needing God's tender care. After finishing, a stranger approached him and revealed that he was a Confederate soldier during the Civil War. The stranger confessed that he had once snuck into Sankey's Union camp on a moonlit night and seen him on picket duty, even deciding to kill him, but evidently did not follow through. This encounter highlights a moment of potential danger that Sankey survived, illustrating divine protection.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate how God guards and protects His people, much like the angel mentioned earlier.

illustrations.title: Assassin's Reluctance to Kill
illustrations.text: I was hidden in the brush, took up my rifle, and pulled the hammer back, about to shoot you and slip away into the night. I knew I could get away, but just before I shot, you sang that song, 'Savior like a shepherd lead us, much we need thy tender care.' It was beautiful, and I recognized it as the song my mother used to sing to me as a child. By the time you finished, I realized you must know Jesus, just as I did, and I couldn't kill you, so I quietly put the hammer down and snuck away.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how God protects His people in unexpected ways.

illustrations.title: Shepherd's Prepared Table
illustrations.text: The sheep says of the shepherd in Psalm 23, 'You prepare a table for me in the presence of my enemies.' This refers to sheep being fed on the tablelands, even with wolves and enemies nearby in the hills. The shepherd has gone ahead and prepared the place, ensuring their safety. It's a picture of being protected while being provided for.
illustrations.context: This shows that God prepares a safe place for us despite surrounding dangers.

illustrations.title: Jesus and the Fishing Miracle
illustrations.text: After Jesus rises from the dead, the disciples decide to go out fishing, and Jesus meets them at dawn on the shore of the Sea of Galilee. They don't recognize Him at first, and He asks if they've caught anything; they say no, so He tells them to throw the net on the right side, resulting in a huge catch. This moment reminds Peter of when he first followed Jesus, and when they reach the shore, Jesus already has breakfast prepared—fish and bread frying. It's a scene of provision and recognition.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how Jesus prepares and provides for His followers, just as He did in the past.

illustrations.title: Teenage Song Revelation
illustrations.text: When I was about 15 or 16, I heard a song for the first time by the group Children of the Day during the Jesus movement. The lyrics said there's a life of joy and happiness waiting just for you, a life you've been searching for with a perfect ending, and it's all been planned to stand the hardest trial. It struck me even as a young Christian that God had a life prepared for me to live in, not just a place to go when I die.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that God has a prepared life for believers to live now, as emphasized in Ephesians 2:10.

illustrations.title: Preparation for Heaven Analogy
illustrations.text: Jesus said He goes to prepare a place for you, but it's like He's also preparing you for that place until He returns. He acts as your guide to direct you, your guard to protect you, and your God to perfect you, ensuring the work He started is completed. This means God is actively shaping us for our eternal home.
illustrations.context: This analogy shows that Jesus not only prepares a heavenly place but also prepares believers for it through guidance and perfection.

illustrations.title: Sheep Recognizing Shepherd's Voice
illustrations.text: There's a true story of a guy who went to Israel, where sheep shepherds and shepherdesses still watch flocks in places like Bethlehem fields, making you feel like you're in the ancient world. He saw a large herd of sheep and, not knowing the shepherds, decided to call out to the sheep as if they were his own. One sheep left the herd and came straight to him, which surprised everyone. The actual shepherd noticed and approached the stranger, asking if he could help. The man was puzzled, thinking it strange because he believed the Bible described how sheep know their shepherd's voice.
illustrations.context: This story illustrates that true followers of Jesus recognize and respond to His voice, just as sheep know their shepherd.

illustrations.title: Sick Sheep Follows Stranger
illustrations.text: He said to me, I thought they didn't do that. Well, normally they don't. He explained that a sheep won't follow the voice of a stranger, but that particular sheep is sick, and sick sheep will follow anyone. And that's true.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that just as a sick sheep follows anyone, people who are spiritually unwell might not discern true guidance.

illustrations.title: Lady Meets Author on Train
illustrations.text: I love that story. It's a true story about a lady who was on a train. She was single and met this young man, and they started talking and getting to know each other. They were attracted to one another, and she discovered he was an author who had written a book and had it with him.
illustrations.context: This story shows how genuine attraction and connection, like falling in love with God, changes one's desires and draws them closer.

illustrations.title: Womans Book Experience
illustrations.text: A woman had read a book before and hated it, finding it the most boring she'd ever read. When someone gave her the same book again, she politely accepted it but was unenthusiastic. After meeting the author and learning about him, she reread it and found it exciting, every line making sense as she fell in love with the content.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how meeting Christ transforms the Bible from boring to exciting and meaningful.

illustrations.title: Presidential Pardons Example
illustrations.text: The idea of a pardon comes up when presidents leave office; for instance, Trump pardoned over 200 people, Truman over 2,000, and Jimmy Carter pardoned over 200,000, including those who avoided the draft. This shows how presidents use their authority to forgive large numbers. Pastor Bob uses this to contrast with God's pardon, which is based on personal payment rather than mere prerogative.
illustrations.context: This explains that God's pardon differs from presidential pardons because it stems from Christ's own sacrifice, not arbitrary forgiveness.

illustrations.title: Hymn on Divine Pardon
illustrations.text: What is the old song we used to sing: 'I'm forgiven because you were forsaken, I'm accepted you were condemned.' In other words, the pardon of God is not like just telling somebody they're forgiven because you have the authority to do so. Sin has to be paid for; there is no pardon except somebody gets punished, as Christ was punished for our sins.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that God's forgiveness requires sin to be paid for through Christ's sacrifice, not through arbitrary pardon.

illustrations.title: Call about suicide
illustrations.text: Pastor Bob received a call yesterday from someone at church about their friend, a Christian who took their own life. The caller was struggling with whether this person could still go to heaven. This real-life situation led Pastor Bob to emphasize not judging others' salvation.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that we should not judge whether a Christian goes to heaven based on their final actions.

illustrations.title: Thief on the cross
illustrations.text: Pastor Bob retells the story of the thief on the cross, noting that his family might have assumed he was going to hell. However, Jesus promised him paradise that very day. This biblical example shows that salvation comes through faith in Jesus, not human judgment.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that we should leave judgment of others' eternal fate to God, as seen in Jesus' grace to the thief.

illustrations.title: Speeding crash analogy
illustrations.text: Pastor Bob compares dying in sin to speeding at 110 mph and crashing, saying it's not the way anyone should go. He explains that this is similar to other sins at death, emphasizing that salvation isn't about the severity of the sin. Ultimately, he stresses that faith in Jesus secures heaven, not one's final moments.
illustrations.context: This analogy shows that all sins don't equally affect salvation, which depends on Jesus' work, not how one dies.

illustrations.title: Ananias and Sapphira story
illustrations.text: Pastor Bob references the biblical story of Ananias and Sapphira, who lied and faced God's judgment. He suggests they might still be in heaven despite their sin, as God sometimes removes people due to destructive behavior. This illustrates that God handles sin and judgment, not us.
illustrations.context: This retelling emphasizes that God takes people in their sin sometimes, but salvation is based on faith, not perfect endings.

illustrations.title: Peter's Denial Contrast
illustrations.text: You say, well, wait a minute, didn't Peter deny the Lord? Yes, three times. Those were three instances of denial, but he didn't live in denial or persist in denial. When the Bible says if you deny Him, it's in the future tense, meaning if you live in ongoing denial, He will continue to deny you. But that wasn't true for Peter; it wasn't a persistence in denial.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses Peter's denial to illustrate that temporary denial is forgivable, but persistent rejection of Christ leads to unforgiveness.

illustrations.title: God's Names as Character
illustrations.text: Whenever you read something like this, you realize the word 'name' refers to the whole character of somebody. That's why the Bible says the righteous run into the name of the Lord, meaning they put their trust in the character of who God is. If you are sick, you put your confidence in the fact that He is Jehovah Rapha, the Lord who heals you. If you feel alone, He is Jehovah Shalom, the Lord who is there for you.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses analogies of God's names to show that God's character provides exactly what people need in their struggles.

illustrations.title: Jesus Claims Before Abraham
illustrations.text: Do you remember what Jesus said in the Gospel of John? He told the people that Abraham rejoiced to see His day and was glad. They were confused and challenged Him, saying He wasn't even 50 years old, so how could He have seen Abraham? This led Jesus to declare, 'Before Abraham was, I am,' which provoked them to pick up stones to kill Him right there.
illustrations.context: To illustrate Jesus' divine identity and authority as the eternal God.

illustrations.title: Sensitive Eye with Contacts
illustrations.text: You know what the apple of your eye is—your pupil. I wear contacts; I just got some new ones on Monday, and I've been doing it for years. Even after 20 years, my body reminds me to be careful when putting them in, because my eye is very sensitive and hesitant, even with my own hand. God uses this to say that whoever messes with you, Israel, is like poking Him in the eye, meaning He will respond fiercely.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how God is deeply protective of His people, comparing it to the sensitivity of the eye.

illustrations.title: Jesus Confronts Saul
illustrations.text: What does Jesus say to Saul on the road to Damascus when He introduces Himself in power? He says, 'Saul, Saul, why are you persecuting me?' Jesus explains that persecuting the church is persecuting Him, because the church is His body and His bride. This means that touching His people is like touching Him directly.
illustrations.context: This shows that criticizing or harming God's people is equivalent to offending God Himself.

illustrations.title: Pharaoh Pursues Israelites
illustrations.text: When the children of Israel were led out of Egypt, a pillar of cloud by day and fire by night guided them. Pharaoh changed his mind after his grief over the death of the firstborn and sent his powerful army—horses, chariots, and swords—after the unarmed slaves. This great empire advanced to bring them back or kill them if necessary, but it highlights God's promise to fight for His people.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that God will actively fight the enemies of His people, as promised.

illustrations.title: Exodus God Fights for Israel
illustrations.text: Moses said the Lord will fight for you while you keep silent. Then God caused the Egyptians' chariot wheels to swerve, making them drive with difficulty, so the Egyptians said, 'Let us flee from Israel, for the Lord is fighting for them.' As the Egyptians approached the children of Israel, God performed a deity blocking maneuver by moving the pillar that represented the Lord from in front of them to behind them, protecting His people from the enemy.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that God promises to fight battles and protect His people, just as He did for the Israelites.

illustrations.title: Yom Kippur War Divine Intervention
illustrations.text: There was a general in Israel during the Yom Kippur War named General Hezi Ezekiel. He testified that he commanded a small force of 32 men against five Egyptian companies, about a thousand men, and they were vastly outnumbered with only two rifles and two grenades per ten men. Suddenly, the Egyptians retreated for no apparent reason, allowing the Israelis to chase and fire, and later the Egyptian general admitted that thousands of Jews in white uniforms backed by tanks appeared behind the Israeli lines, implying a miraculous intervention.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that God still fights for His people today, just as in biblical times, showing modern examples of divine protection.

illustrations.title: Modern Testimony of Angelic Victory
illustrations.text: He told me that across the desert, we were outnumbered, not you. My heart filled with joy because I knew our victory came not from our fighting skills, but because God sent His angels to fight for us. This doesn't just happen in the Bible; that man later became a Christian, came to the United States, got saved, and is now with the Lord. What an incredible testimony of this verse lived out in modern days.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that God actively intervenes with angels to defeat enemies in real life, just as in biblical times.

illustrations.title: Sheep Fighting Analogy
illustrations.text: We are sheep, not fighting animals. If you want a laugh, go Google videos of fighting sheep; they're mostly a joke, showing sheep bumping heads a little bit. We're not goats that get into real fights; we're sheep called to battle, but we're outclassed. We have to be strong in the Lord and in the strength of His might, as in Ephesians 6:10-13. Ultimately, we're brought to the armory of God and come out equipped like steel wool.
illustrations.context: This analogy emphasizes that humans are not naturally equipped for spiritual warfare but must rely on God's strength to fight and win.

illustrations.title: David and Goliath Retelling
illustrations.text: David runs into the battle against this monster of a guy, Goliath, who is offended that he's even fighting a little kid. David's attitude is amazing; he says, 'You come to me with a sword and a spear and a shield, but I come to you in the name of the Lord of hosts, the God of Israel, whom you have defied.' It's not about who has bigger weapons; it's about who has a bigger problem, since God is way bigger than you and your battle is with Him. All David has to do is show up, and Goliath is going down.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that God fights our battles and defeats enemies stronger than us, emphasizing reliance on God's power over human strength.

illustrations.title: Jacob's Reunion with Esau
illustrations.text: Before I read, I want to tell you the background: Jacob finally meets his brother, who twenty years before had wanted to kill him. He hasn't seen Esau in 20 years, and Esau had vowed that Jacob was dead if he ever got his hands on him, which is why Jacob ran away. But now, as a broken man, Jacob can't run or fight; he has to trust God with what happens as Esau approaches with 400 men. He can't fight back, and we discover that Esau's heart has been changed by the Lord—he no longer wants to kill Jacob, now called Israel; he just wants to be with him. It's a pretty amazing passage that shows transformation through surrender.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how God brings about surrender and transformation through pain and trust, changing hearts and relationships.

illustrations.title: Jacob Escapes from Laban
illustrations.text: Jacob had been living with Laban for 20 years, where Laban was an unfair employer, changing his wages and exerting heavy control. God told Jacob to leave, so he fled at night without telling Laban while Laban was away. When Laban pursued him, God protected Jacob through a dream, warning Laban not to harm him, allowing Jacob to escape safely.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the experience of victory over the tyranny of the old man's control, representing freedom from the old nature in a believer's life.

illustrations.title: Jacob Reunites with Esau
illustrations.text: Jacob was terrified that his twin brother Esau was coming to kill him and his family after their past conflicts. However, when they finally met, Esau was not angry or threatening at all; instead, he was very friendly. This shows how God had intervened and changed Esau's heart during Jacob's journey back to the promised land.
illustrations.context: This illustrates separation from the influence of the world and God's role in reconciling relationships.

illustrations.title: Disciples in the Storm
illustrations.text: The disciples on the boat in the storm were sure they were going down, but they weren't going down because Jesus was going to make sure they got to the other side. Some of us right now are terrified of something in our life, and the Lord is saying, just relax, trust me, I'm in charge of your life and I will see you through. This story shows how God protects us even in our fears.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that God protects and cares for us, encouraging trust in difficult times.

illustrations.title: Jacob's Flight and Bethel
illustrations.text: I think of Jacob how he ran from fear of his brother because of the sin he had committed against his brother, and remember the Bible says when he ran 20 years before, he stumbled in the dark down into a place called Bethel and used a rock for a pillow. Now, I've never fully understood that passage, but it highlights how God was with Jacob even in his desperation. This retelling emphasizes God's faithfulness amid human mistakes.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that God protects and provides for us, even when we don't realize it, just as He did for Jacob.

illustrations.title: Jacob's Rock and Grace
illustrations.text: Jacob used a rock for a pillow, which must have been a hard night's sleep. He had a dream where God showed him grace, promising blessings without mentioning his sins. After the dream, Jacob took that same rock and turned it into a pillar, anointing it with oil and calling the place Bethel. This illustrates how God can transform hard times into opportunities for praise and glory.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that God turns the consequences of sin and hard experiences into chances to glorify Him.

illustrations.title: Prodigal Son Misery
illustrations.text: The prodigal son enjoyed himself for a little while; sin is pleasurable for a season, but then it becomes rotten. He ended up feeding pigs and wishing he could eat their food. This is a good picture of people who are truly children of God but are in the world and miserable, feeling out of place until they return home.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that Christians who try to live with one foot in the world and one in God's kingdom will be miserable and ineffective.

illustrations.title: Forgiveness Stabbing Analogy
illustrations.text: If you stab me by accident or on purpose, I might forgive you, but I might still have a hole or pain in my shoulder for the rest of my life. Forgiveness is not the same as being healed. Treating someone who's not trustworthy isn't unforgiveness; it's wisdom, and Christians often confuse these concepts.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob explains that forgiving someone doesn't mean the relationship is fully restored or that pain disappears, emphasizing the difference between forgiveness and trust.

illustrations.title: Caterpillars Marching in Circles
illustrations.text: Biologists have done experiments with processional caterpillars on the rim of a clay pot that held a plant. They lined the caterpillars up so the leader was head-to-head with the last one all around. The tiny creatures circled the rim for a full week, just marching around without any breaking away to eat the plant right there. Eventually, all the caterpillars died from exhaustion and starvation.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how unbelievers walk in circles spiritually, leading to their own demise without guidance from the Lord.

illustrations.title: Israelites Wandering in Wilderness
illustrations.text: Something that's supposed to take days takes decades because of unbelief. In fact, that whole generation died in the wilderness and never entered the Promised Land. They wandered in circles for 40 years, going nowhere despite God's provision. This shows how unbelief can trap even believers, preventing them from reaching God's intended destination.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate how unbelief can cause believers to go in circles and miss out on God's promises.

illustrations.title: Jacob's Slow Pace with Family
illustrations.text: Jacob said to Esau that his children are frail and his flocks are nursing, so they must go at a slower pace. If driven hard, the flocks and family would die, so Jacob chose to proceed at his leisure according to the pace of the children and cattle. This highlights the difference between being driven like Esau's group and being led gently. Pastor Bob connects it to the idea of trusting God without haste.
illustrations.context: This story illustrates that believers should move at God's patient pace to protect what matters, rather than rushing.

illustrations.title: Shepherd's Gentle Leading Quote
illustrations.text: The Bible says he who believes will not make haste, meaning true faith involves patience. In Isaiah 40:11, it describes the Messiah as a shepherd who tends his flock, gathers the lambs in his arms, and gently leads the nursing ewes. This verse shows God's caring and slow guidance, especially for the vulnerable. Pastor Bob uses it to emphasize trusting God's timing over hurried efforts.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob connects this quote to the point that believers should trust in God's gentle leading rather than rushing ahead.

illustrations.title: Unequal Yoking with Animals
illustrations.text: The physical illustration is of two different kinds of animals in the Old Testament. You don't take an ox and a donkey and put a yoke on them because they have completely different steps and heights. This would make it impossible to plow a field correctly, frustrating one animal or injuring the other, so it simply does not work.
illustrations.context: This analogy shows that believers should not be unequally yoked with unbelievers, as it leads to frustration and ineffectiveness in their shared endeavors.

illustrations.title: Jacob and Esau's Different Paths
illustrations.text: That's exactly how Jacob represents himself, saying he can't move at Esau's pace or it would harm his family, so he'll proceed at the pace of his children until he comes to his Lord at Seir. Esau is going home to Seir, which is Edom down south, while Jacob is heading north to completely different directions. Essentially, Jacob is indicating that he's going up while Esau is going down, highlighting their divergent destinies.
illustrations.context: This retelling illustrates that believers and unbelievers have different goals and destinies, underscoring the importance of following a faith-guided path.

illustrations.title: Abraham and Lot's Separation
illustrations.text: There was strife between the herdsmen of Abraham's livestock and the herdsmen of Lot's livestock, as the Canaanite and the Perizzite were dwelling in the land. So Abram said to Lot, 'Please let there be no strife between you and me, nor between my herdsmen and your herdsmen, for we are brothers.' This shows another time when two relatives could not stay together, as Abraham was a man of faith while Lot lived for worldly things.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to draw a parallel between Abraham and Lot's separation and Jacob's decision to part from Esau, highlighting conflicts arising from differing priorities.

illustrations.title: Rahab and Midwives' Imperfect Faith
illustrations.text: It's possible that Jacob is heading in the right direction but doing it the wrong way, kind of like Rahab who lied about hiding the spies because she believed God would destroy Jericho, and God saved her through faith even though she wasn't fully mature. Similarly, the midwives lied to Pharaoh, claiming the Jewish women were too hearty and gave birth before they arrived, thus saving the babies instead of killing them as ordered. They were doing the right thing but not entirely in total faith in God.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that even after surrendering to God, people might still sin or act imperfectly, as seen in Jacob's situation.

illustrations.title: Esau Offers Protection to Jacob
illustrations.text: Esau said, okay we're not going together, so let me leave some of my people with you for the journey. Jacob replied, I don't need that; please let me find favor in the sight of my Lord. Esau accepted and returned with his men to Syria. It's interesting that Esau, for good reasons, wanted to leave some men for protection to help his brother stay safe. But Jacob was not willing to allow unbelievers on the journey with his family, as he knew bad company corrupts good morals.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that believers should avoid close association with unbelievers to prevent negative influence.

illustrations.title: Mixed Multitude Influences Israelites
illustrations.text: In Numbers 11:4, the children of Israel had come out of Egypt, but among them was a mixed multitude of people who were not Jews. This rabble had greedy desires and began to complain, saying, who will give us meat to eat. The sons of Israel were influenced by this group, leading them into carnality and away from fully following the Lord. Even though the Israelites were already prone to weakness, the presence of these unbelievers exacerbated their problems.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how allowing unbelievers into one's life can pull believers down and lead them astray.

illustrations.title: Rotten Apple Spoils Bunch
illustrations.text: I think of that old song about one bad apple not spoiling the whole bunch, but actually, it does. If you have a barrel of apples and put a rotten one on top, the good apples will never turn the rotten one good. Instead, the rot from that apple will spread to everything around it. We need to remember that bad influences work the same way in our lives.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize that bad company corrupts good morals, just like a rotten apple ruins the others.

illustrations.title: Doctor as Physician Analogy
illustrations.text: When I go to the doctor, I know who the doctor is and I know that I'm the patient. Not only does my doctor know who's sick and who's not, but he makes sure that while he has contact with me if I'm sick, he doesn't get contaminated by me. In other words, our relationship is all about healing. So if you're going to be like a physician to the sick, be very clear about who you are and why you're there, both in your mind and hopefully in theirs.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to emphasize that Christians should influence non-believers without being spiritually contaminated, clearly understanding their roles as healers.

illustrations.title: Man's Airplane Home
illustrations.text: This guy said recently I boarded a plane, walked down the aisle, found my seat, and sat down next to a strange sight. The man seated next to me was in a robe and slippers, dressed for the living room, not for a journey. His seat was fine leather that he bought in Argentina and installed himself, complete with a mahogany fold-down table, a portable TV, a tiny ceiling fan, and a globe light above us. I had never seen anything like it, so I asked why he spent so much time and expense on an airline seat. He replied, 'Because I live here; I make my home on the plane.'
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that believers should not settle permanently in this world, as it distracts from walking by faith and following God's direction.

illustrations.title: Life as Plane Journey
illustrations.text: Incredible, a man made a home out of a mode of transportation, turning a journey into a residence. You might think I'm stretching the truth, but I've seen such foolishness in life where people treat this world like a permanent home, pouring time and energy into it as if it will last forever. We are all in transit; someday the plane will stop, and deboarding will begin, so wise people stay ready to get off when they reach the city.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to emphasize that life is temporary and people should not cling to worldly things as if they will last forever.

illustrations.title: Jacob's Journey to Shechem
illustrations.text: Now Jacob came safely to the city of Shechem, which is in the land of Canaan, and he camped before the city. He bought the piece of land where he had pitched his tent from the sons of Hamor for a hundred pieces of money, and then he erected an altar there and called it El-Elohe-Israel. Some translations say he came to the place of peace before Shechem where he pitched his tent, showing he's living in a tent as a picture of walking by faith and experiencing peace as a byproduct of that faith.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob retells this story to illustrate that walking by faith leads to peace and safety, contrasting with detours that can occur in one's spiritual journey.

illustrations.title: Jacob's Vow Fulfilled
illustrations.text: Then Jacob made a vow saying if God will be with me and keep me on this journey that I take and will give me food to eat and garments to wear and I return to my father's house in safety, then the Lord will be my God. This was back at Bethel, 20 years ago. And now, 20 years later, he is finally doing what he had said he would do by building this altar and declaring God as his God.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that Jacob is now living by faith and fulfilling his earlier promise of dedication to God.

illustrations.title: Thomas's Doubt and Faith
illustrations.text: I think of Thomas after the resurrection; he wasn't sure Jesus was really alive because he didn't see him like the other disciples did. That's what happens when you miss church on Sundays; Jesus shows up and you're not there. Maybe he was homesick or watching a football game, but he wasn't there when they gathered, so the next Sunday Thomas came to church and got together with the disciples. When they gathered, Jesus showed up as promised and addressed Thomas's doubt directly, proving he hears and responds to our faith struggles.
illustrations.context: This shows that true faith and peace come from being with believers and trusting God's presence, even after doubt.

illustrations.title: Right Track Analogy
illustrations.text: It's been said like this: It's possible that you're on the right track, but if you're not moving, even being on the right track can be a problem when the train comes. Jacob was on the right track by entering the Promised Land, but he stayed in Shechem too long, leading to troubles. This illustrates the need to keep progressing in faith.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to show that being in the right place spiritually isn't enough if you're not continuing to move forward as God intends.

illustrations.title: Shechem Tragedy Retelling
illustrations.text: Jacob stays in Shechem, where his daughter Dinah is raped by Shechem. Then, Jacob's sons Simeon and Levi commit the first serial murder in the Bible by slaughtering an entire village through deception. This event mirrors Jacob's own flaws, as the apples don't fall far from the tree, showing the consequences of lingering where God wants you to pass through.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob retells this story to illustrate the dangers of not fully obeying God's direction, leading to sin and family tragedy.

illustrations.title: Abraham's Servant Seeks Wife
illustrations.text: Abraham was old and advanced in age, and the Lord had blessed him in every way. He instructed his servant, the oldest of his household, to swear not to take a wife for Isaac from the Canaanites, but to go to his relatives and find a suitable woman. The servant prayed to God for success, asking for a sign at the spring where women drew water. Rebekah appeared, offered him water, and even watered his camels, confirming she was the one God had chosen. The servant watched in silence, marveling at how God had made his journey successful.
illustrations.context: To demonstrate God's guidance and provision through faithful obedience and prayer.

illustrations.title: Isaac's Sacrifice Retelling
illustrations.text: We saw the father being willing to sacrifice his son, remember up there on Mount Moriah, which is the place we call Calvary where Jesus was crucified over 2,000 years later. This is an incredible picture of the sacrifice the father was willing to make of his own beloved son, his only son. Then he was restored back to him on the third day, mirroring resurrection.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating how Abraham's willingness to sacrifice Isaac prefigures God's sacrifice of Jesus and the theme of restoration.

illustrations.title: Isaac's Miraculous Birth
illustrations.text: In Genesis 21, we see Isaac finally born, the long-awaited, promised son, supernaturally born with no way possible except by a miracle of God because of Abraham and Sarah's age. It was just not possible, making him a type of Christ as he was named before he was born. There are all kinds of types in Isaac's life, but one key aspect is this supernatural birth.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is showing how Isaac's birth serves as a foreshadowing of Jesus' miraculous birth.

illustrations.title: Wedding Rehearsal Shadow
illustrations.text: It's kind of like a wedding rehearsal. It's not the actual wedding, but it's here to go over the major points so you can get a feel for what it's going to be like soon. That's the sense of what's happening here in the text.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating how the Old Testament events are shadows or previews of good things to come, similar to a wedding rehearsal preparing for the real event.

illustrations.title: Servant as Holy Spirit Analogy
illustrations.text: This servant becomes a beautiful picture and type of the Holy Spirit in many ways. He's the oldest of Abraham's household, who had charge over all that he owned, and his name is left out of the text, just as the Holy Spirit doesn't speak of himself. For example, in John 16, Jesus describes the Spirit as one who will guide into truth and glorify Jesus by disclosing what is his. This mirrors how the servant carries out his mission without seeking glory for himself.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to show how Abraham's servant represents the Holy Spirit's role in guiding and preparing for the Son's bride without drawing attention to himself.

illustrations.title: John 16 Quote on Holy Spirit
illustrations.text: Jesus said in John 16:13-14, 'When he, the Spirit of truth, comes, he will guide you into all the truth; he will not speak on his own initiative, but whatever he hears he will speak, and he will disclose to you what is to come. He will glorify me, for he will take of mine and disclose it to you.' Pastor Bob explains that this shows the Holy Spirit's character of not speaking of himself, much like how Paul's salutations never include the Holy Spirit's name. This connects to the idea that the Holy Spirit's role is to point to Jesus and the Father.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to illustrate how the Holy Spirit operates selflessly, mirroring the unnamed servant's mission.

illustrations.title: Personal Decision for Jesus
illustrations.text: You might feel like I remember the day I decided to follow Jesus. Praise God for that moment, but guess what? If you had that experience, according to John 6:44, the Father started the work. He's the author and perfecter of your faith, showing that salvation begins with God.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that while people may feel they chose Jesus, it was actually God who initiated their salvation.

illustrations.title: Abraham's Servant and Bride
illustrations.text: Abraham gave a great mission to an unnamed servant to find a wife for his son Isaac. He instructed the servant to swear by the Lord not to take a wife from the Canaanites, but instead to go to Abraham's country and relatives. The servant asked what to do if the woman wasn't willing to leave her home, and Abraham replied that under no circumstances should Isaac go back there—she must be willing to come. This story shows the bride must leave her home to marry the son.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is using this to show that the church, as the bride of Christ, must come from God's family and be willing to leave their old life.

illustrations.title: Destination Wedding Analogy
illustrations.text: You might say this was to be a destination wedding and so is ours. It's interesting that Jesus Christ will not step foot back on earth until after his wedding. Read Revelation 19; you'll find in verse 9 there's the wedding supper of the Lamb in heaven with the bride, and after that in verse 11, John says he beheld the heavens opened and a white horse, and two verses later, Jesus is coming back to earth, but not before the wedding.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to illustrate that the rapture and wedding of the Lamb occur before Jesus returns to earth.

illustrations.title: Angels as Ministering Spirits Quote
illustrations.text: Jot it down, Hebrews 1:14. Here's what the writer to Hebrews says: Are they not all ministering spirits sent out to render service for the sake of those who will inherit salvation, as in you? If angels are ministering spirits sent out to render assistance for those who are going to be saved, this shows God's provision in our lives.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that angels assist believers, connecting it to God's role in important missions like finding a bride for Isaac.

illustrations.title: Peter's Angelic Release
illustrations.text: Remember when Peter was put in prison in the Book of Acts? They were going to kill him the next morning, but God released him with an angel, and he came back to the prayer meeting where people were praying all night for his release. He knocked on the door, and Rhoda answered, saw him, and ran back to tell the others that Peter was there, but they thought it was his angel.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that Christians have angels assigned to them as ministering spirits.

illustrations.title: Angels Baseball Analogy
illustrations.text: I know people are excited about this guy from Japan, Shohei Ohtani, who plays for the Angels; he doesn't throw 100-mile-an-hour fastballs, but every pitch is unbelievable. The real question isn't who is on the Angels team, but whose team the angels are on. The good news is that if you're a Christian, the angels are on your team.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is using this to emphasize that spiritual angels are on the side of believers.

illustrations.title: Ancient Oath Tradition
illustrations.text: You've probably never shaken on a deal quite like that, where you put your hand under someone's thigh instead of signing a contract or placing a hand on the Bible. This was a cultural practice related to covenants and promises of descendants, involving the loins and reproductive area, which has ancient connotations in many cultures. The rabbi explained it as a way to ensure attention, and it's connected to words like 'testify'.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is explaining the cultural significance of the oath in the biblical story to highlight the seriousness of covenants.

illustrations.title: Jesus at the Door Analogy
illustrations.text: Remember Jesus said, 'Behold I stand at the door,' not 'I kicked down the door.' I mean, God is our Father, not the Godfather. The Holy Spirit never makes anybody bark, roar, laugh, or fall down out of control. The Holy Spirit doesn't force people to do something beyond what they're willing to do. It's not the nature of the Spirit of God.
illustrations.context: This analogy emphasizes that God does not force people to believe or act, highlighting the importance of voluntary choice in faith.

illustrations.title: 1 Peter 1:8 Quote with Context
illustrations.text: Jotted down First Peter 1:8: Though you have not seen Him—this is Jesus—you love Him. Though you have never seen Him, you already love Him, and though you do not see Him now, you believe in Him and rejoice with joy inexpressible and full of glory. In other words, we're on our way to a wedding we've never seen the groom for, but we're already in love with Him. This connects to the bride willingly going to marry someone she's never met.
illustrations.context: This quote illustrates that believers can love and trust Jesus without seeing Him, paralleling the bride's willingness in the story.

illustrations.title: Camels as Ancient Semis Analogy
illustrations.text: Camels were kind of like the ancient semis in terms of carrying loads, so it's like this guy drives up to your neighborhood with ten semi trucks full of presents for you, which might get your attention. He was loaded down with gifts from his master. By the way, I want to suggest that the camels can and probably do represent the law of God in this analogy.
illustrations.context: This analogy shows how the Father's goodness is revealed through abundant gifts, symbolizing God's provision and the law.

illustrations.title: Mirror Reveals Imperfections
illustrations.text: If I look in the mirror in the morning and see flaws, I don't throw out the mirror because it's doing its job well. That's what the law of God does; it reflects our imperfect character while showing God's perfect character. The law acts like a mirror that faithfully shares our flaws without being bad itself.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that the law of God reveals our imperfections, just as a mirror shows flaws without being at fault.

illustrations.title: Camels in Abraham's Story
illustrations.text: I think we often hear this story and forget there were ten camels, not just one, with drivers and maybe others, making it an entourage from the Father. This group carried the good things to testify to the bride about the son's wealth. It's a detailed picture of how God sends witnesses to reveal His provision.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is using the biblical story to show that the camels represent the good things from God that testify to His character and provision.

illustrations.title: Adopted Kid's Witty Response
illustrations.text: Remember this story of a kid who was talking to his friends about being adopted. They tried to make him feel bad by saying, 'You're adopted!' He shot back, 'Well, at least my parents got to choose me. Your parents were stuck with you.' This anecdote highlights the positive aspect of being chosen.
illustrations.context: To illustrate that being adopted means being purposefully chosen by God, emphasizing grace and selection over obligation.

illustrations.title: Ancient Roman Adoption Custom
illustrations.text: We think of adoption in terms of babies, but in ancient Roman culture, it was usually adults who were adopted to become heirs, granting them rights and privileges they didn't originally have.
