This was bestowed purely by grace, not by birthright. Adoption in this context speaks to our legal standing before God, where we are given a new role through His choice.
illustrations.context: To explain that spiritual adoption is a gracious act that provides believers with new rights and status as heirs of God.

illustrations.title: Jesus and Samaritan Woman
illustrations.text: There came a woman of Samaria to draw water at this well, and Jesus said to her, 'Give me a drink.' This woman had been married five times and was not fulfilled by her relationships, as Jesus showed her that those who drink from this well will thirst again. He offered her living water that truly satisfies, and she went back and brought her whole village to meet Jesus, the bridegroom. It's amazing how Jesus reveals himself and meets deeper needs.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to show that people often seek fulfillment in relationships but find true satisfaction only in Jesus.

illustrations.title: Jesus Borrowing a Boat
illustrations.text: I think of Jesus when a big crowd comes up and he asks, 'Can I borrow a boat?' Even though he could walk on water or create food if he wanted, he borrows a boat and asks for extra lunch to feed the people. This shows that the one who turned water into wine and multiplied bread and fish doesn't really need these things. Instead, he uses these moments to connect with people and perform miracles.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates that God often presents needs He doesn't have to draw people closer and reveal His power.

illustrations.title: Rebekah's Well Drawing Effort
illustrations.text: Ancient wells in the Middle East were large, deep holes with steps leading down to the spring, requiring substantial effort for each draw. A camel can consume 40 to 50 gallons of water in about 10 minutes, so ten camels would need 400 to 500 gallons if they were dry. That meant Rebekah had to make over a hundred trips to the well, each with a jar holding about 3 gallons, taking two to three hours to fill them all, and she did it quickly without hesitation.
illustrations.context: This illustrates Rebekah's spectacular generosity and servant-hearted willingness to help, even at great personal cost.

illustrations.title: Camels as Ten Commandments
illustrations.text: Pastor Bob suggests that the ten camels might picture the law, perhaps the Ten Commandments, as a symbol of burdens or requirements. Rebekah's willingness to draw water for all the camels represents the bride's readiness to satisfy these spiritual demands. This extended comparison highlights how she went beyond just helping one person to serving the entire group fully.
illustrations.context: This analogy shows that true servanthood involves fully addressing spiritual laws or obligations, just as Rebekah did for the camels.

illustrations.title: Servant Gives Gifts to Rebekah
illustrations.text: When the camels had finished drinking, hours later, the man took a gold ring, which in Hebrew is a nose ring, weighing a half shekel, and two bracelets for her wrists weighing ten shekels in gold. Of course, the servant, the unnamed servant, is a type of the Spirit giving gifts to the bride. These gifts were given to beautify the bride and testify to the wealth of the person she's going to marry, showing his ability to meet her needs.
illustrations.context: This retelling illustrates how the Holy Spirit provides gifts to believers to equip and adorn the church.

illustrations.title: Servant as Holy Spirit Type
illustrations.text: The unnamed servant is a type of the Spirit giving gifts to the bride, just as in the New Testament, after Jesus ascended, he gave gifts to men as described in Ephesians 4 and 1 Corinthians 12. These gifts are for the bride while still on earth, before the wedding in heaven, and they beautify her while testifying to the wealth and ability of her future husband. They are real, nothing man-made, and intended for different parts of the body.
illustrations.context: This analogy demonstrates how the Holy Spirit gives spiritual gifts to the church to prepare and enrich believers.

illustrations.title: Dad's Obedience Lesson
illustrations.text: My dad made that really clear when I was young. He said, 'I brought you into this world,' and you know that whole story. It was his way of emphasizing the importance of honoring parents for a long life.
illustrations.context: To illustrate that honoring parents leads to blessings like a long life.

illustrations.title: Caleb's Faith in Old Age
illustrations.text: I think of Caleb in the Old Testament. He was one of the two spies who said we can take on the Canaanites, while the others wanted to go back to Egypt. Even at 85, he was as strong as he was 40 years ago and ready to conquer new territory, serving as an example to others.
illustrations.context: To demonstrate that faith enables new ventures and strength even in advanced age.

illustrations.title: Jacob's Abundant Blessings
illustrations.text: What did Jacob say when he crossed the river 20 years ago? He had nothing, just his staff, running from his brother who wanted to kill him. But now, he's coming back so blessed with flocks, wives, and kids. He said, 'I am not worthy of the least of your favors, Lord. I don't deserve any of this, but you keep blessing me no matter what I do.'
illustrations.context: This illustrates that God blesses people abundantly, even when they feel unworthy, emphasizing faith and divine favor.

illustrations.title: Waking to Overflowing Blessings
illustrations.text: I remember waking up one day and thinking about all the things God has done in my life, every prayer answered and every desire of my heart. I felt like I was the youngest of five in my family at Christmas, where we didn't spend much the rest of the year, but at Christmas, there were presents from wall to wall covering the entire living room. As kids, we'd excitedly look for our gifts, and as an adult Christian, I realized I feel like I've awakened to a room full of presents all with my name on them—God keeps blessing me even though I don't deserve it.
illustrations.context: This personal story shows that walking with God means experiencing continuous blessings, encouraging a perspective of gratitude and abundance.

illustrations.title: 2014 Unmarried Milestone
illustrations.text: In 2014, a milestone was reached in this nation; for the first time in our history, the census showed there were more unmarried people than married ones. This reflects a significant shift in societal trends regarding marriage. Pastor Bob uses this to connect to the idea that marriage is God's design, highlighting how cultural changes might challenge biblical views.
illustrations.context: This historical reference illustrates the decline in marriage rates, underscoring that marriage remains God's intended plan despite modern shifts.

illustrations.title: Unequally Yoked Warning
illustrations.text: If you're a Christian and you marry a non-Christian, you will have in-law problems. Your father-in-law will be the devil. I'm not kidding; it's what the Bible clearly teaches. Don't be unequally yoked with unbelievers, for what partnership has light with darkness?
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that Christians should not marry non-Christians to avoid spiritual conflicts and misalignment.

illustrations.title: Adam's Single Mate
illustrations.text: Remember when God made Adam, how many women did he make? It was just one for Adam, not a dozen to choose from. That's the model and example God intended—one partner for you to be with. Many Christians today overlook this and date freely, but God has appointed a specific one for you if you're meant to be married.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob retells this story to illustrate that God appoints a specific spouse, encouraging singles to trust in God's plan rather than pursuing multiple options.

illustrations.title: Mr. Right Joke
illustrations.text: It's like that girl who said she was sure when she married him he was Mr. Right, until she learned his first name was Always. After that, he's the one that God has appointed. This shows that the person God chooses for you might not be perfect, but they are perfectly imperfect for you.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that the ideal spouse may have unexpected flaws, emphasizing that God's appointed partner is still the right one.

illustrations.title: Biblical Wells of Meeting
illustrations.text: In the Bible, Jacob meets his bride at the well. Moses also finds his bride while she is working as a porter at a well. These stories show that many people in Scripture find their mates at places of refreshment and fellowship, like the wells.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to point out that seeking a spouse in the right places, such as environments of worship and refreshment, aligns with God's design.

illustrations.title: Adam's Trust in God
illustrations.text: Adam didn't specify what he wanted in a partner, like looking for a brunette or something less hairy. Instead, he went to sleep, trusting God to provide. God gave to his beloved even in their sleep, creating Eve as the perfect match. This highlights the need to rest and let God handle what we can't.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize that to know God's choice, one must hear God's voice and trust Him fully, rather than relying on personal preferences.

illustrations.title: Chuck's Moving Quote
illustrations.text: Let me just read you what Chuck said I loved: one of the most important steps in being led of the Lord is to get moving. It's hard to guide a stationary object. If you're just sitting around, it's hard to get the leading of the Lord; God leads us as we're moving, so we have to step out in faith and the Lord is able to lead us.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that God guides us when we actively step out in faith rather than waiting passively.

illustrations.title: Servant's Biblical Discovery
illustrations.text: This servant says when he hears whose daughter she is and knows the name Nahor—that's my Master's brother—that's exactly where we're supposed to go out of all this whole village. It was like hitting bingo or a Yahweh moment; that was the one I was looking for. God's will was all lining up and his prayers were being answered because he was walking in the way that he should have been, so God was able to reveal his will to him.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob retells this story to show that God reveals His will when we step out in faith and follow His path.

illustrations.title: Trust and Obey Song
illustrations.text: What is the old song say: when we walk with the Lord in the light of his word, what a glory he sheds on our way. And when we do his good will, he abides with us still, and with all who will trust and obey. This illustrates that God wants to guide us as we walk in His way.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this song quote to reinforce that following God's will through obedience allows Him to provide guidance.

illustrations.title: Bless Fest Service Event
illustrations.text: Many of you were at Bless Fest, our Thanksgiving outreach where we invite shelters in Orange County to bring the homeless. We send out buses and had over 800 volunteers from our church who gave up part of their Thanksgiving Day to serve in any way God might use them. We served 850 to 900 guests, providing medical, dental, and other services, which was more than ever before.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the church members' commitment to serving and being available for God's work.

illustrations.title: Prescription for Peace Analogy
illustrations.text: I think about it like this: Sometimes people go to the doctor with a problem, get diagnosed, and receive a prescription. They fill it at the pharmacy but then don't take it, leaving unused medicine in their cabinet because they decide they don't need it or save it for later. As a result, they continue to live with the same condition, ignoring the doctor's advice.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to show that just as people should follow a doctor's prescription to address their health issues, believers should follow Paul's instructions to achieve peace and avoid worry.

illustrations.title: Voluntary Thanks Analogy
illustrations.text: God's not really excited about forcing you to say thank you to him, any more than you are when telling your kids to say thank you. It doesn't really bless me when they say it just because I told them to; you want someone to be truly thankful. So does God—it's a voluntary thing that makes it meaningful.
illustrations.context: This analogy emphasizes that genuine thanksgiving in prayer is voluntary and more effective, just as forced thanks from children lacks sincerity.

illustrations.title: Bread and Yeast Analogy
illustrations.text: I think of bread: if you leave out yeast, it won't rise. In the same way, if you leave out thanksgiving and praise in your prayers, they won't be effective. This ingredient is essential for the full result, just as yeast is for bread.
illustrations.context: This analogy illustrates that thanksgiving is a crucial part of prayer for experiencing God's peace, similar to how yeast is necessary for bread to rise.

illustrations.title: Michelangelo's Creation of Adam
illustrations.text: Most everyone here has seen the picture, though maybe most of us have never been to the Sistine Chapel. It's an amazing poetic picture of God and Adam in that moment when Adam comes to life. The only problem is it's totally unbiblical because it didn't happen by a touch; it happened by a breath. God formed man out of the dust of the earth, breathed into his nostrils the breath of life, and man became a living soul. There was a moment he was mud, and then he was animated and became living man.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that spiritual life begins through God's breath, not a mere touch, contrasting it with the biblical account of creation.

illustrations.title: God's Breath into Adam
illustrations.text: God formed man out of the dust of the earth and breathed into his nostrils the breath of life, and man became a living soul. There was a moment he was mud, and then he was animated and became living man. Life began by the breath of God, marking the start of human existence.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob retells this to emphasize that spiritual life, like physical life, begins with God's direct intervention.

illustrations.title: Zinc Fireworks in Fertilization
illustrations.text: When you were conceived in your womb, you were there, though you don't remember it. Scientists have photographed what happens when life begins at fertilization: there's this explosion of zinc in a cell they call the zinc fireworks. In that moment, life wasn't present one second before, and then suddenly it is. This illustrates the sudden start of life, which parallels the spiritual sense of salvation.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this real-world scientific example to show that spiritual life begins suddenly, just as physical life does at conception.

illustrations.title: Peter's Angelic Rescue
illustrations.text: In the book of Acts, Peter was arrested by Herod, who had already killed James and planned to kill Peter. On the night before his trial, Peter was sleeping between two soldiers, bound with chains, and guards watched the prison door. Suddenly, an angel of the Lord appeared, a light shone in the cell, the angel struck Peter and woke him, saying get up quickly. The chains fell off his hands, and the angel told him to dress and follow. Peter did so and escaped, illustrating a miraculous deliverance.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show how Peter's physical rescue mirrors the spiritual freedom experienced in salvation.

illustrations.title: Charles Wesley's Hymn Quote
illustrations.text: Charles Wesley, the brother of John Wesley, described his own salvation in his famous hymn by drawing from the Bible's account of Peter's escape. In the hymn, he wrote, 'Long my imprisoned spirit lay fast bound in sin and nature's night; thine eye diffused a quickening ray, I woke, the dungeon flamed with light. My chains fell off, my heart was free, I rose, went forth, and followed thee.' Pastor Bob explains that this poetic language captures the radical change when someone experiences spiritual rebirth, much like Peter's chains falling off.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to illustrate the moment of personal salvation and the awareness of radical life change.

illustrations.title: Jacob's Ladder Dream
illustrations.text: In Genesis 28, Jacob had a dream where he saw a ladder between Earth and Heaven with angels ascending and descending. God spoke to him from above, saying He wanted a relationship with Jacob and promising to never leave him or forsake him, while also giving promises of land and blessings. Even though Jacob was in a place in his life that didn't deserve blessing, God introduced Himself and likely brought Jacob to a saving knowledge of God that day.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate how God initiates a saving relationship with people, even when they don't deserve it.

illustrations.title: Blessfest Salvation Stories
illustrations.text: Joe Maguire, who was part of our Prayer Ministry during Blessfest, wrote to me saying that at least three dozen people prayed to receive Christ at this event on Thursday. We praise God for this, as it's the ultimate reason we're here. This highlights the excitement and importance of people coming to faith.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob emphasizes the joy and praiseworthiness of people getting saved.

illustrations.title: Gaza Dreams of Jesus
illustrations.text: It's a miracle that Muslim men in Gaza sought Christ after over 200 of them dreamed of Jesus on the same night. These guys doing ministry in Palestine have been trying to lead people to Christ, and this event shows God's powerful work. We prayed for such awakenings amid the conflict, hoping people would come to a saving knowledge of Jesus Christ.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates how God uses dreams to draw people to salvation, even in dire situations.

illustrations.title: Harvest Anniversary Testimony
illustrations.text: I was last Sunday afternoon with Ryan Raymond and his wife, along with Becky and I, out at Harvest for their 50th Anniversary celebration. We sang old songs and heard Greg share about the blessing of sharing the gospel through Harvest Crusades and the church over 50 years. They calculated that a million people have professed faith in Christ through their altar calls, which is incredibly exciting and shows God's work in evangelism.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to highlight the excitement and impact of people coming to faith over time.

illustrations.title: Horatio Spafford's Tragic Loss
illustrations.text: Some of you know the story; perhaps you've never heard it. His name is Horatio Spafford, a businessman in Chicago during D.L. Moody's ministry. He was a wealthy Christian who supported Moody, but after the Chicago Fire, he suffered great financial losses. He sent his wife and daughters to England for a vacation, planning to join them later. Unfortunately, their ship sank, and his wife survived but sent a telegram with two words: 'saved alone.' So, he got on board a ship himself to go to her.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate that we should praise God for salvation and forgiveness, even in the midst of personal tragedy and loss.

illustrations.title: Hymn Writers Heartbreak
illustrations.text: I can only imagine the heartbreak in this man's life. On the way over the ship he was on stopped in the same area where the other ship had gone down. There in his state room, he wrote the words of that famous hymn, It Is Well with My Soul. The hymn starts with 'When peace like a river attendeth my way, or when sorrows like sea billows roll,' reflecting his own loss. His daughters—Annie who was 12, Maggie who was seven, Bessie who was four, and Tanetta who was 18 months old—had all died, yet he praised God, saying his sin was nailed to the cross and he bore it no more.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that even in profound sorrow, a Christian can find peace and praise through faith in salvation.

illustrations.title: Thanksgiving Talk with Son
illustrations.text: One of my sons and I were having our Thanksgiving meal yesterday, and I asked him what the most familiar thing is that I've shared from the pulpit throughout his life. He immediately said it's when I say, 'If you are what you always have been, you're not a Christian.' I told him that's a good one, and it's not original—it's biblical. This highlights the need for true conversion and a new birth in one's life.
illustrations.context: This personal anecdote emphasizes that genuine conversion is essential for salvation and being a Christian.

illustrations.title: Jesus on Conversion
illustrations.text: Jesus said, 'Except you be converted and become as little children, you shall not enter the kingdom of heaven.' This means that if you are what you always have been, you're not a Christian, as it requires a new birth and true change. I share this to underline that biblical conversion is necessary for salvation. It's a foundational truth that makes one's calling sure.
illustrations.context: This quote illustrates the point that personal transformation through conversion is required to enter heaven.

illustrations.title: Jacob's Surrender to God
illustrations.text: For instance, we read of Jacob who was saved in Genesis 28 and met the Lord 20 years later in chapter 32, where he wrestled with God without knowing it at first. He thought it was an enemy, but in reality, it represented his opposition to God's will because he was living for himself. Jacob was saved but not surrendered, leaning on his own understanding, which is typical of many Christians. On that night by the Jabbok River, an angel representing the Lord touched him, crippled him, and he stopped fighting and started clinging. The Bible says God changed his name that very night from Jacob, meaning a heel-catcher who grabs for himself, to Israel, meaning governed by God, signifying a transformation in his life.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this illustration to show that believers must move beyond initial salvation to full surrender to God, as Jacob did.

illustrations.title: The Drowning Discipleship Lesson
illustrations.text: I heard a story from many years ago, perhaps over a hundred years ago, about a young man who had become a Christian and heard about a godly wise man living in the hills who deeply loved the Lord and profoundly changed everyone he met. The young man went to him and said, 'I want you to disciple me; I want a relationship with God like yours.' The wise man agreed and told him to meet at the beach the next day. They went into the water, and the wise man held the young man under until he passed out. When the young man regained consciousness and confronted him angrily, accusing him of trying to kill him, the wise man asked, 'When you were under the water, what did you want more than anything?' The young man replied, 'I wanted to breathe,' and the wise man said, 'When you want to live for Christ as much as you wanted to breathe, then come back, and you'll be ready.'
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to show that true surrender to God requires desperation and letting go of one's old life.

illustrations.title: Crucifixion Analogy
illustrations.text: Think about this: Jesus didn't crucify himself; he allowed himself to be crucified. Just imagine putting down the cross, hammer, and nails. You'll come to a point where you can't complete the job yourself, because it's impossible to die to self in your own strength.
illustrations.context: Illustrates that one cannot achieve the Crucified Life through personal effort alone and must rely on God.

illustrations.title: Pastor's Personal Surrender
illustrations.text: I came to a place where I didn't want to live this life anymore as a Christian, because I felt like such a failure. I told God I feel like giving up, and I could hear Him say, 'It's about time. I've been waiting for you to stop thinking you're going to do it on your own, Bob, because you never were.' This led me to realize the need to fully surrender.
illustrations.context: Emphasizes the frustration of trying to live the Christian life without surrender and the relief in relying on God.

illustrations.title: Paul's Early Ministry Struggles
illustrations.text: Paul was clearly converted on the road to Damascus, where he was blinded and didn't know which way was up, but he knew Jesus was alive. Ananias prayed over him, healed his blindness, and baptized him, and Paul was filled with the Holy Spirit. He started preaching the gospel boldly, like a bull in a china shop, causing problems wherever he went because he wasn't completely Spirit-led. The church sent him away, and they enjoyed peace when he was gone. He was full of faith but not yet faithful in the way the Holy Spirit produces.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that Paul was saved and surrendered but not always Spirit-filled, emphasizing that faithfulness comes from the Holy Spirit.

illustrations.title: Visiting George Washington's Home
illustrations.text: Becky and I years ago went to Washington DC and visited where George Washington lived. We saw his house and the quill that he used to write with. Those items would be priceless at auction now, nothing compared to what they were brand new, because their value changes depending on who is using them. This illustrates that something used can gain immense value if it's in the hands of someone significant, like Washington. In the same way, our lives gain true value when God uses us.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to explain that being used by God increases our value, contrasting with the idea that used things typically lose worth.

illustrations.title: Jonah's Story of Rebellion
illustrations.text: Jonah was on a ship with pagans during a storm, and he admitted that the storm was his fault because he wasn't obeying God. He told them to throw him overboard to stop it, and they did, leading him to be swallowed by a fish where he faced death and rebellion. After three days, Jonah repented and cried out to God, who saved him and gave him a second chance to go to Nineveh. He delivered God's message of destruction, but when the people repented, Jonah became angry because he couldn't see them as victims like God did. This illustrates the difference between salvation, surrender, and being filled with the Spirit.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses Jonah's story to show that one can experience salvation and surrender but still lack being filled with the Holy Spirit, as seen in Jonah's anger towards Nineveh's repentance.

illustrations.title: Jonah's Compassion Lesson
illustrations.text: Jonah said he had good reason to be angry even to death and wanted to die. The Lord responded, asking if Jonah had compassion on a plant for which he did not work or cause to grow, which came up overnight and perished overnight. Shouldn't I have compassion on the great city with more than 120,000 persons who don't know their right hand from their left, as well as many animals?
illustrations.context: This illustrates that Jonah was saved and surrendered but not Spirit-filled, lacking God's character of compassion.

illustrations.title: Rush Hour Compassion Analogy
illustrations.text: When you get on the 91 freeway at rush hour, is compassion what comes over you? Most of us, let's be honest, don't feel quite compassionate; we see the multitudes as just in our way. Jesus, on the other hand, sees the multitudes and is moved with compassion because he views them as sheep without a shepherd.
illustrations.context: This shows that without the Holy Spirit, people lack the compassion that Jesus has for others.

illustrations.title: Police Car Out of Service
illustrations.text: Many of you know I was a police officer for about 10 years in Orange County, in La Habra and then in Placentia. In small departments, they use police cars for non-sworn officers like community service officers, but they cover the light bar with 'out of service' to ensure they're not mistaken for active duty. I wonder how many Christians are like that police car—saved but not fully Spirit-filled and thus not fully usable for God's work.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that some Christians may be saved and even consecrated but are not Spirit-filled, limiting their reflection of God's character.

illustrations.title: John the Baptist's Proclamation
illustrations.text: In the Gospel of John, we read about Jesus's baptism where John the Baptist saw Jesus walking and said, 'Behold the Lamb of God who takes away the sin of the world,' meaning he's the one everyone has been waiting for. John explained that he's just preparing the way for someone mightier than him. Then, two of John's disciples heard this and started following Jesus, not knowing what would happen next. When Jesus turned and saw them, he asked, 'What do you seek?'
illustrations.context: To illustrate that people must actively seek and respond to Jesus's call, rather than just going through the motions.

illustrations.title: Heaven's Gate for Husbands
illustrations.text: I heard a story of a couple who were saved, died, and went to heaven where the Gate of Heaven had two lines: one for husbands who were henpecked and another for those who were not. The husband had to choose which line to go to, showing that even in the afterlife, our choices and behaviors matter. This anecdote highlights that simply being in the right place doesn't guarantee everything.
illustrations.context: To emphasize that attending church or following Jesus outwardly isn't enough without genuine seeking and commitment.

illustrations.title: Husband in Short Line
illustrations.text: There's a very short line with only two guys in it, while the other line for husbands is packed as far as the eye can see. This man gets into the short line, and the two guys in front of him ask what he's doing there. He replies that his wife told him to stand here. Jesus asks a similar question: what do you seek? Are you following just because someone else told you to?
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to question if people are seeking Jesus genuinely or just following others' instructions.

illustrations.title: Prodigal Son's True Need
illustrations.text: In the story of the prodigal son, after his money was gone, so were his friends. He's working a dead-end job feeding pigs, which is unfit for a Jewish boy, and he's so hungry he's hoping to eat the pig food. He thought his biggest problem was a lack of money, but that was just a result of his choices driving him to his real need. His greatest need wasn't relief or food, but repentance and returning to the father.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates that people's greatest need is often spiritual repentance, not just fixing immediate circumstances.

illustrations.title: Demons in Synagogue
illustrations.text: Some of the exorcisms Jesus did were in church in synagogue. Jesus would show up and the demons didn't like it. They said, 'Have you come to torture us before our time?' And Jesus would cast them out, delivering the person.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that even demons believe in God but are not saved, emphasizing that true faith goes beyond belief.

illustrations.title: Become as a Child
illustrations.text: Jesus said you must become as a child or you'll never enter the kingdom of God. This means humbling yourself completely. Sometimes religious people are the hardest to be saved because they think they're doing better than others.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to show that humility is essential for salvation, countering self-righteousness.

illustrations.title: New Creation in Christ
illustrations.text: The Bible says people mostly don't change until they meet the Living God, and when they do, if anyone is in Christ, he is a new creation; the old things pass away and new things come. This means your past doesn't define you forever. God can transform anyone who turns to Him.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that genuine change comes only through a personal relationship with Christ, urging listeners to accept salvation.

illustrations.title: Praying with Friend for Salvation
illustrations.text: I prayed many years ago with a friend of mine who had been in the church longer than I had. We were in college and in a college-age group together, and I was teaching about being born again. She came up to me after the message and said she didn't think she was a Christian, even though I argued that she had been saved longer than I had. We prayed together for her to receive Christ, and years later, she confirmed that her relationship with God truly started that day.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that someone can attend church for years without truly being born again and that genuine salvation can happen at any time.

illustrations.title: Old Song on Unexpected Salvation
illustrations.text: There's an old song that says a funny thing happened on the way to heaven: I got saved. This connects to people who might be unsure of their standing with God, much like the folks in the story who realized their faith later. Pastor Bob uses this to encourage those who feel they haven't truly committed.
illustrations.context: This quote emphasizes that salvation can be a surprising or belated realization for some.

illustrations.title: Paul's Conversion Struggle
illustrations.text: Can you imagine how messed up Paul the Apostle's mind was when he thought Jesus was a false prophet and suddenly realized he was God? He had to rethink all those verses and his past actions. This example shows that even someone with major doubts and misconceptions can be transformed by Jesus.
illustrations.context: This reference highlights that Jesus accepts and transforms people regardless of their past errors or doubts.

illustrations.title: Childhood Prayer Experience
illustrations.text: I might have prayed a hundred prayers, a thousand prayers, not insincere but not with much faith because I had never seen prayer change anything. But I will never forget the prayer I prayed 52 years ago as a little 13-year-old boy. That prayer is one I'm about to reproduce for you because I believe what Scripture says: whoever calls on the name of the Lord will be saved. This is the prayer He wants you to pray, and we're excited to see what God will do in your life.
illustrations.context: To show the transformative power of a sincere prayer for salvation based on personal experience.

illustrations.title: Jesus' Assurance of Acceptance
illustrations.text: Jesus said these words: no one who comes to me will I in any wise cast out. What that means is, if you come to the Lord as you just have, you don't have to worry that He accepted everyone but you. He accepts you on the authority of the Scriptures, and your sins are forgiven if you receive Him.
illustrations.context: To reassure listeners that Jesus will accept anyone who comes to Him, emphasizing forgiveness and salvation.

illustrations.title: Pastor's Personal Surrender Prayer
illustrations.text: I can tell you that as a Christian, I prayed a prayer for surrender. It wasn't the sinner's prayer for salvation, but it was still a prayer acknowledging my need to surrender. I didn't do it at an altar call or go forward; nobody even knew I prayed it. It's not about being seen by others; God sees your heart. This shows that true surrender is a private matter between you and God.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to illustrate that surrendering to God can be a private, heartfelt act rather than a public display.

illustrations.title: Jesus' Feed My Lambs Quote
illustrations.text: Remember what Jesus said to Peter: if you love me, feed my little lambs. They need to be fed the word of God and encouraged in their faith. So, get to know them, pray for them, and love them as new believers.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize the importance of nurturing and encouraging new believers in their faith.

illustrations.title: David's Enthusiastic Worship
illustrations.text: In the Old Testament, the Bible says that David danced before the Lord with all his might. His wife, the queen and daughter of a king, despised him for stripping down to dance freely, thinking it unbecoming of royalty. David responded that he didn't care about her criticism, as he was fully honoring God, even if it damaged their marriage.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that true worship involves giving everything to God without holding back, regardless of others' opinions.

illustrations.title: Sports Fans' Excitement
illustrations.text: When I see football players and fans at games, they paint themselves up and go wild with passion for their team. They show extreme enthusiasm for something temporary, like a sports event. Yet, it's puzzling that people often care more about that than expressing devotion to God, who is eternal.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to highlight how people get overly excited about worldly things like sports while failing to show the same fervor for worshiping Jesus.

illustrations.title: Moses' Plea to Edom
illustrations.text: Moses sent messengers to the king of Edom, saying, 'Your brother Israel has suffered greatly. Our fathers went down to Egypt and lived there for a long time, where the Egyptians mistreated us and our ancestors. But when we cried out to the Lord, he heard our voice and sent an angel to bring us out of Egypt.' They shared their history of hardship and salvation, turning a potential closed door into an opportunity to testify about God's deliverance. This retelling highlights how God uses such moments for greater purpose.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this biblical story to illustrate how closed doors can provide opportunities to share personal testimony and history.

illustrations.title: Jesus in Samaritan Village
illustrations.text: Jesus sent messengers ahead of him, and they entered a village of the Samaritans to make arrangements for him. We know the Samaritans were not receptive and would say he couldn't come, but nonetheless, Jesus wanted to go there and gave them an opportunity to receive him. You and I need to see that there are times we're in situations that make no sense, but God has a purpose for allowing us to have a relationship with someone who might not benefit us, so we can share how we got saved.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that we should share our testimonies even in unreceptive situations, as Jesus did.

illustrations.title: Paul's Redirected Journey
illustrations.text: Paul was on a missionary journey, led by the Holy Spirit, but even though he was Spirit-filled and called by God, not every place he wanted to go was permitted. They passed through the Phrygian and Galatian region, having been forbidden by the Holy Spirit to speak the word in Asia. When they came to Mysia, they tried to go into Bithynia, but the Spirit of Jesus did not permit them, so they passed by Mysia and came down to Troas. God often uses closed doors to redirect us, just as He did with Paul.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that God uses closed doors to redirect our paths, even when we are following His call.

illustrations.title: Paul's Trials Before Leaders
illustrations.text: You read through in the Book of Acts and Paul gets hauled before two governors and a king. He's in Caesarea by the sea, standing in front of Governor Felix, Agrippa, and Governor Festus. Paul shares his faith and his testimony about what happened on the road to Damascus before these kings, and none of them received Jesus, at least in the text, but the message was delivered to them.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that sharing testimony during persecution can provide opportunities for witness, even if it doesn't always result in conversion.

illustrations.title: Sharing Testimony in Idaho
illustrations.text: I shared my testimony two days ago with a guy while Becky and I were up in Idaho, and we spent some time with him. I had a great opportunity to share my story, but he did not receive Christ. That doesn't mean he's rejected Christ—I don't know for sure, and I'm looking forward to the next time I see him.
illustrations.context: This shows that when you share your testimony, some people may reject it, but that's okay because God uses multiple people over time for salvation.

illustrations.title: New Believer's Gospel Poem
illustrations.text: Somebody got saved and was given a New Testament to read, and since they had never read it before, they started with the Gospel of Matthew. They noticed that the next books were The Gospel According to Mark, Luke, and John, realizing it was the same story about Jesus but from different perspectives with slight variations and details. As a result, they wrote a little poem: 'You're writing a gospel, a chapter each day by the things that you do and the things that you say.'
illustrations.context: This demonstrates that as Christians, our daily actions and words write the gospel for others to see.

illustrations.title: Esau and Jacob Birthright Story
illustrations.text: Esau and Jacob were twins, brothers of Israel, but they were very different from each other. Esau was a rugged hunter, like a caveman kind of guy, while Jacob was more of a mommy's boy who worked in the kitchen. God chose Jacob through His Sovereign Grace, even though neither was seeking God. Esau cared more about earthly things and sold his birthright for a bowl of soup because he was so hungry. Jacob took advantage of him, and later pretended to be Esau to get the blessing from their blind father. Esau becomes a picture in Scripture of a person who's not saved, driven by fleshly desires. This story shows how the flesh is self-centered and opposed to the spirit.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate that the flesh lacks compassion on a neighbor in need and represents people driven by worldly, self-centered desires.

illustrations.title: Lyndon Johnson's Selfish Quote
illustrations.text: Lyndon Johnson in 1964 said in a speech to troops, 'Don't forget, we are just 200 million in the United States, and there are three billion opposed to us. They want what we have, but they won't get it from us.' In my opinion, this is a good picture of selfishness, like saying, 'I have what I have, and I'm going to keep it.' It illustrates how people naturally want to hold onto their possessions.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to show how selfishness manifests in protecting one's own resources and fearing others.

illustrations.title: Pastor Bob's Suspicion Confession
illustrations.text: I'll be honest with you, I find myself very suspicious of people, especially salespeople. When they call me up, I know better than to answer, but sometimes I do and then realize it's not someone I should talk to. I need to be more loving and share Jesus with them instead of hanging up. This shows my own struggles with selfishness.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob shares this to illustrate the natural human tendency toward suspicion and self-protection.

illustrations.title: Good Samaritan Retelling
illustrations.text: Remember the story of the Good Samaritan, where a man was going down from Jerusalem to Jericho and fell among thieves who beat him almost to death. A priest and a Levite saw him and walked by on the other side, ignoring him. But a Samaritan, who wasn't even a Jew, stopped to tend to his wounds, care for him, and pay for his needs. This is a picture of Christ, who owes us nothing but still helps us, highlighting a lack of compassion in others.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to demonstrate true compassion and contrast it with selfish avoidance.

illustrations.title: Hugging Enemy Analogy
illustrations.text: It's really hard to fight with somebody who's trying to hug you. It's hard to stay angry at somebody who's trying to love you. And we're to be those people who respond with love instead of anger.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that showing love to enemies can disarm their anger and lead to conviction.

illustrations.title: Romans 12 Enemy Love Quote
illustrations.text: In Romans 12, it says to take no revenge and leave room for God's wrath. If your enemy is hungry, give him something to eat; if he's thirsty, give him something to drink. In doing so, you'll heap burning coals on his head, which means to convict him, not to harm him.
illustrations.context: This quote emphasizes that Christians should respond to enemies with kindness to convict them and avoid seeking revenge.

illustrations.title: Death Clock App Example
illustrations.text: Pastor Bob talks about apps like Death Clock, where you enter your lifestyle details such as weight and exercise habits, and it predicts a specific date for your death. He dismisses it as stupid and unreliable, comparing it to something foolish. This illustrates that human attempts to forecast death are misguided and not to be taken seriously.
illustrations.context: This example highlights that we cannot predict or control our death date, as it is ultimately in God's hands.

illustrations.title: Fortune Cookie Personal Story
illustrations.text: Pastor Bob shares a light-hearted story about a fortune cookie he once received, which said something like 'You're a fool who gets things out of cookies.' He uses this to poke fun at the idea of seeking wisdom from such trivial sources. This anecdote emphasizes the absurdity of relying on fortune cookies for any real insight into life or death.
illustrations.context: This story underscores that predicting or controlling life's events, like death, through superstitions is foolish and unreliable.

illustrations.title: Wanted Poster Analogy
illustrations.text: God is like a poster with your face on it saying 'Wanted: Dead or Alive' because the Rapture means the dead in Christ rise first. So whether you die or are raptured, you'll be gathered to your people. This illustrates that death isn't the end but a transition to being with God and your loved ones.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to explain that Christians will be with God whether through death or the Rapture, emphasizing the certainty of eternal reunion.

illustrations.title: Theater Kid Analogy
illustrations.text: It's kind of like the theater where a lost kid goes down and asks, 'Does anybody know who I am?' because if you're lost, you're not going to heaven. This means that in heaven, you'll recognize people just as you do on earth, and you won't be dumber there than here. People worry about not knowing loved ones, but the point is that family ties remain stronger than ever after death.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to reassure that relationships and recognition persist in the afterlife, countering fears about heaven.

illustrations.title: Creating Heaven People List
illustrations.text: In 2019, I started thinking about people I knew who were believers already in heaven, and I made a list that has grown since then. I shared it on a Facebook post with a picture of me and Pastor Chuck, including my chief of police, father, mom, and others like the baby from our miscarriage. People emailed me reminding me of those I forgot, which made me realize how many loved ones are waiting there.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is emphasizing the joy and anticipation of being gathered to one's people in heaven, highlighting the personal connections awaiting believers.

illustrations.title: Motorcycle Reflection on Fred
illustrations.text: While on a motorcycle ride with Becky the other day, I suddenly thought about Fred, the young man who led me to Christ in eighth grade and was part of our church's ministry. I wondered what Fred is doing in heaven today, and Becky agreed he's having a great day with his wife Carol, who died before him. This moment illustrates how those in heaven are enjoying themselves, giving us something to look forward to.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating the comforting truth that believers who have passed are in a glorious state, reinforcing the hope of reunion.

illustrations.title: Job's Nakedness Quote
illustrations.text: Here's what Job said: 'Naked I came from my mother's womb and naked I shall return.' What he meant was I came into this world with no clothes and no possessions, and when I leave, I'm not taking anything with me. There's no titles, no honors, no money, no glory—I'm going out empty-handed.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to illustrate that people enter and leave the world without possessions, emphasizing the futility of material attachments.

illustrations.title: Hearse Without U-Haul
illustrations.text: I've been to a lot of funerals and done a lot of funerals, and I've watched a lot of hurts. I've never seen a hearse pull up with a U-Haul, because you can't take your stuff with you. This highlights that no one carries their possessions beyond death.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this real-world example to show that material possessions cannot be taken after death, reinforcing the idea of leaving everything behind.

illustrations.title: Paul's Heavenly Garments
illustrations.text: Jot it down: Second Corinthians 5 verses one through five. Paul says, 'For we know that if this earthly tent, which is our body, is torn down, we have a building from God, a house not made with hands, eternal in the heavens.' He explains that we long to be clothed with our dwelling from heaven, so that what is mortal may be swallowed up by life, and God prepared us for this with His spirit as a pledge.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob connects this quote to illustrate the heavenly side of death, where believers receive new garments or bodies, contrasting the earthly removal of Aaron's garments.

illustrations.title: College Student Mission Example
illustrations.text: Just last week, our elders prayed over a college-age student who's going on a three-week medical mission in Africa. She has grown up in this church with parents who have a heart for the mission field. Their daughter has caught that passion from seeing it in her mom and dad, which shows how children can be influenced by their parents' faith.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that children learn and adopt a heart for God's work by observing their parents' godly lives.

illustrations.title: Psalm on Divine Promotion
illustrations.text: Jot down Psalm 75 verses 6 and 7: For promotion comes neither from the East nor from the West nor from the South; it comes from above us. God is the judge; He puts down one and sets up another. This quote shows that God is the one who ultimately chooses and promotes in ministry.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is emphasizing that God, not parents or humans, is the source of promotion in ministry, as seen in the selection of Eleazar.

illustrations.title: Famous Quote on Legacy
illustrations.text: Someone said it this way: when you were born, you cried but your mama was happy; make sure that when you die, you're happy and everybody else is crying. In other words, for 30 days the children of Israel remembered the gift that Aaron had been to them. This illustrates that the value of your life is often reflected in how people mourn for you.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that a meaningful life is one that leaves others grieving and appreciating your impact, as seen in the mourning for Aaron.

illustrations.title: Black Preacher's Mortality Story
illustrations.text: I heard about this one sermon years ago from a black preacher that a guy talked about. He said that at this black church, they had graduation Sunday for kids who were the first in their families to graduate from universities like MIT and Harvard, and the parents and grandparents would weep with pride. The preacher would tell these graduates, 'Children, you're all going to die; we'll bury you in a hole, throw dirt on your face, and then eat potato salad back at the church—just remember, you're going to die.' This story highlights the contrast between earthly honors and the inevitability of death.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob shares this to stress that despite achievements, everyone faces death, underscoring the importance of a lasting spiritual legacy like Aaron's.

illustrations.title: Tombstone Legacy Choice
illustrations.text: He talked about what you will have when you die, saying some of you have great honors and will become famous, but what's going to be on your tombstone—just a title like president or entrepreneur. He warned not to live for that, but instead to live for testimonies where people stand around your grave, weeping and sharing how God used you in their lives. You have to make a choice in how you live so that you're remembered for your impact, not just your titles.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is emphasizing the importance of living for eternal testimonies rather than temporary honors or titles.

illustrations.title: Israel Weeping for Aaron
illustrations.text: Here you have the nation of Israel weeping, saying there'll never be another Aaron and what a gift he was to them. This illustrates how Aaron was mourned and remembered for his role. Pastor Bob uses this to encourage living a life that leaves a lasting positive impact, like Aaron did.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that we should strive to be remembered and valued by others, just as Aaron was by Israel.

illustrations.title: Cloud of Witnesses Stadium
illustrations.text: Pastor Bob described how Christians never say goodbye for the last time because there's a reunion waiting in heaven, with a cloud of witnesses—our relatives and past believers—who are like friends in a grand stadium cheering us on now, and soon we'll join them there if the Rapture doesn't come first. This analogy paints heaven as an ongoing encouragement from those who've gone before. It connects to the idea that we're not alone in our faith journey.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating the comfort of eternal reunion and ongoing support from believers who have passed, motivating readiness for heaven.

illustrations.title: Elder's Worship Endorsement
illustrations.text: One of our elders, when we first did this on Wednesday night, said to me, 'Man, Bob, I wouldn't mind if we did this every Wednesday and every Sunday.' I responded, 'Me too.' This shows how much we appreciate this practice and want it to be a regular part of our gatherings.
illustrations.context: To encourage people to feel free and welcome to come forward for worship.

illustrations.title: Jewish Exorcists' Demonic Encounter
illustrations.text: There were some Jewish exorcists who were Christians, but they couldn't cast demons out. So, they decided to start casting demons out the way the Apostle Paul did, by using the name of Jesus. They tried to command the demons to come out of a possessed man. The demons spoke and said, 'We know who Jesus is, and we know who Paul is, but who are you?' The Bible says that this demon-possessed man beat these guys up, and they all ran out of the house naked and wounded.
illustrations.context: This story illustrates that demons recognize true spiritual authority in Jesus and Paul, but not in unauthorized individuals.

illustrations.title: Authority from Knowing Jesus
illustrations.text: Jesus I know, and Paul I know, they knew Paul because Paul knew Jesus. If you know Jesus, then the forces of hell are afraid of Jesus in you. This shows that true spiritual authority comes from a genuine relationship with Him.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that believers have real authority over spiritual forces only if they have a personal relationship with Jesus.

illustrations.title: Singing in Church Evolution
illustrations.text: I used to not sing in church even though I was saved. Then, I would just move my lips without any sound coming out. Now, I feel so much freer to worship God without caring about what others think.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is emphasizing the freedom and joy of heartfelt worship without self-consciousness.

illustrations.title: Shower Worship Analogy
illustrations.text: You should be able to worship the Lord like you do in the shower. That means don't think you're ready for American Idol just because you sound good alone. Don't wait until heaven to praise freely.
illustrations.context: The analogy illustrates that worship should be uninhibited and natural, just like singing carefree in private.

illustrations.title: Sister's Singing Comment
illustrations.text: I used to have people look at me strangely when I sang. My sister once said it was almost like harmony, but I was trying to sing the melody and it wasn't quite right. Who cares, because God values what's in your heart.
illustrations.context: This story shows that external judgments don't matter as much as genuine heart worship.

illustrations.title: Becky's Distraction Story
illustrations.text: Sometimes my wife Becky will look at me and say, could you tone it down a little because you're distracting and I can't focus. I don't mean to show off or be weird; that's not my heart. I just want to worship the Lord without inhibitions.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to highlight the importance of prioritizing God's opinion over others' discomfort in worship.

illustrations.title: Pimple in Junior High Example
illustrations.text: It's like when you get your first pimple in junior high school and you think everyone will notice, so you might even put a Band-Aid on it to hide it. But no one is really thinking about you; they're worried about their own issues like their hair or bad breath. The truth is, people are focused on themselves, not you.
illustrations.context: This example teaches that worrying about others' opinions is unnecessary because people are preoccupied with their own lives.

illustrations.title: Off-Key Worship Analogy
illustrations.text: I'd rather you be off-key and free than on-key and dead spiritually. Start singing with your voice; we'll love you even if we don't like the way it sounds. God wants to hear you worship Him genuinely, and He'll appreciate your effort.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is emphasizing that authentic and free worship is more valuable than perfect execution.

illustrations.title: Psalmist on God's Presence
illustrations.text: I like what the psalmist said: 'When I awake, you are still with me.' He'll be with you all through the night. If He wakes you up, you know what to do: pray and rest in His presence.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is reassuring the audience that God remains with them constantly, encouraging them to find peace and pray.

illustrations.title: Royal Rangers Campout Story
illustrations.text: I just got back from our Royal Rangers campout. There was a bunch of dads and sons going up into the mountains and getting really dirty. We had a moment where the speaker shared something meaningful.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal experience to emphasize honoring God in everyday activities, as referenced from 1 Corinthians 10:31.

illustrations.title: Father-Son God Listening
illustrations.text: We were challenged to be quiet for a whole minute and listen for the voice of God in his creation, so my son and I did that. We sat there, and after the minute was up, as we walked back to our tent, my son asked if I heard God. I said I think I did because I didn't hear him; he's seven and expecting audible words from the Lord. Everyone else went back for s'mores, but he wanted to try again, so we returned to our tent and sat once more. When I asked if he heard God, he said he just couldn't, so I told him it was okay and tried to explain it to him.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to show that people, like his son, may struggle to hear God audibly but can still encounter Him through other means.

illustrations.title: Loving Past Park Days
illustrations.text: I've been to most of our Park days in the past years and I have loved every one of them. I get to meet people I don't know before, have some great food, and enjoy great times. It's a wonderful opportunity to connect and build relationships.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is encouraging attendance at the Park day to foster community and enjoyment.

illustrations.title: Men's Retreat Bonding Experience
illustrations.text: For my men's retreat experiences, I got to have conversations and do activities I would never do apart from being at a retreat with fellow believers. I remember this past men's retreat we had right here at the church; we played basketball in the afternoon, which I would never do with those guys otherwise. Because of that, we built relationships and even serve together in the youth ministry today; it's really a cool thing.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is encouraging women to attend the women's retreat to build relationships and connect with the Lord through shared activities.

illustrations.title: High School Catalina Trip
illustrations.text: When I was in high school, I had a friend who wanted to go to Catalina, and I hesitated because the boat ride was long. We ended up flying on a seaplane, which took just 20 minutes, and then we rented a small motorboat with our limited money. We decided to anchor and enjoy the scenery, but when we threw out the anchor, the rope wasn't attached, so we lost it completely. That mishap left us in trouble, as we had to report it and realize our mistake. It was a fun yet eye-opening experience that highlighted the importance of a secure anchor.
illustrations.context: This story illustrates the need for a reliable anchor in life, paralleling it to the anchor of the soul provided by faith in Christ's return.

illustrations.title: Niagara River Boat Rentals
illustrations.text: Remember that true story of the place upstream on the Niagara River where they rented boats in a safe area. They had a bridge you go under, and there's a sign that asks if you have an anchor and if you know how to use it. This is crucial because the river can become dangerous further downstream. The story serves as a warning about the importance of preparation and proper equipment. It's a real-world reminder of what can happen without readiness.
illustrations.context: This example emphasizes the importance of having and knowing how to use an anchor, symbolizing how faith in Christ's return anchors us through life's storms.

illustrations.title: Joshua and Rahab's Protection
illustrations.text: Remember in the Old Testament, Joshua led the charge into the Promised Land after Moses passed away and God buried him on Mount Nebo. Joshua took the children of Israel across the Jordan River, and their first battle was Jericho. God had already terrified the people of Jericho with news of His victories, so when spies came to the house of Rahab, who lived in the wall of Jericho, she hid them and protected them. She told them that they were terrified and begged for mercy. In return, the spies made a deal that if she and her family stayed in the house and put a red cord outside, they would be safe.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate that abiding in Christ is the only safe place for a Christian, similar to how Rahab and her family were protected.

illustrations.title: Jericho as Safe Haven
illustrations.text: Jericho was a picture in the Bible of a type of the world, and there's only one safe place to be, which was in that house where that promise was made. In other words, there was only one safe place when God's judgment came on Jericho. It shall come about that anyone who goes out of the doors of your house onto the street, his blood shall be on his own head, and we shall be free.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that there is only one safe place from God's judgment, which is in His promise.

illustrations.title: Ark of Noah as Christ
illustrations.text: I think it's an important analogy because the ark is a type of Christ. It did not matter if you were male or female, your annual income, or which deck you were on; it just mattered if you were on board. If you were in the ark, you were safe, but if you were not, it didn't matter how close you were as a neighbor or if you had visited the ark.
illustrations.context: This emphasizes that salvation requires being in Christ and remaining there to be safe from judgment.

illustrations.title: Katharina Luther's Final Words
illustrations.text: Many of you know Martin Luther's name, but do you know his wife, Katharina? She was a nun who married Luther, defying church traditions because celibacy isn't commanded in Scripture. Her last words were, 'I will cling to Christ as a burr to a top coat,' spoken as a true wife and mother, meaning she decided to stay with him no matter what because of what he did for her.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the importance of remaining steadfast in faith and clinging to the Lord.

illustrations.title: Tree Firmly Planted Analogy
illustrations.text: The Bible says we're to be like a tree in Psalm 1, not like the expression 'be like a tree and leave.' The righteous person meditates on God's word day and night, and as a result, they are like a tree firmly planted by rivers of water. This means they stay rooted and steadfast, rather than being moved away.
illustrations.context: This analogy emphasizes that true believers remain firmly established in their faith and do not drift away.

illustrations.title: Childhood Peach Tree Story
illustrations.text: Growing up, my parents had a peach tree that produced a lot of fruit, way more than we needed or I wanted, because I had to mow the lawn and the peach pits would get into the lawnmower. But that tree never decided in the middle of the night that it was bored and wanted to move to the front yard. Trees don't do that, and the whole idea is that as believers, we are to stay planted and put our roots down deep with the Lord.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that true believers stay with the Lord and produce fruit without wandering away.

illustrations.title: Rocky Soil Parable Retelling
illustrations.text: In the parable of the sower, the seeds that fell on the rocky soil are those who hear the word of God with joy but have no firm root. They believe for a while, but in times of temptation or trial, they fall away. This shows that true faith not only comes to the Lord but continues to stay with Him.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that genuine faith endures through trials, unlike superficial belief that fades away.

illustrations.title: Bride Waiting for Groom
illustrations.text: Remember the old song 'How Beautiful' by Twila Paris. In that song, she describes how beautiful the radiant bride who waits for her groom with his light in her eyes. She's ready; the bride has made herself ready as God says in the Book of Revelation. It's the wedding day, too late to diet or get a new dress; you're walking up the aisle fully ready because your whole life has prepared you for this moment. The ready bride has nothing to hide.
illustrations.context: This analogy illustrates that believers should live confidently and prepared for Christ's return, having nothing to hide due to His righteousness.

illustrations.title: Pastor Visits Unresponsive Visitor
illustrations.text: A pastor called to visit a new visitor to his church. He knocked on the door and got no answer, knocked a second time with still no response, but saw the curtain move and knew someone was home. He took out his card and wrote Revelation 3:20 on it, which says, 'Behold, I stand at the door and knock; if anyone opens the door.' The following Sunday, the visitor handed him a piece of paper with Genesis 3:10, which says, 'I heard you in the garden, and I was afraid because I was naked, so I hid myself.'
illustrations.context: This story highlights the shame and unpreparedness of not being ready for Christ's coming, emphasizing the need to live without fear or hiding.

illustrations.title: Guilty Dog Behavior
illustrations.text: Have you ever come home and your dog communicated clearly that something was wrong, like not looking at you and walking into another room instead of greeting you? Dogs talk without words and show guilt very clearly. We're taking care of my sister's dog right now, and it's cute, but dogs definitely communicate their feelings, unlike cats who couldn't care less.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how we should be ready for the Lord's return, not acting guilty or avoiding Him.

illustrations.title: Reverse Surprise Party
illustrations.text: I don't know how many of you have been to a surprise party, but I've been to a couple of reverse surprise parties where everyone is waiting for the person, who doesn't arrive as soon as expected. We start enjoying the food, hanging out, and talking, and nobody's watching anymore. Then the person just walks in, and they're the ones surprised.
illustrations.context: This shows that we need to stay alert for Jesus' return, not get distracted and be caught off guard.

illustrations.title: Master's Journey Parable
illustrations.text: It's like a man away on a journey who left his house and put his slaves in charge, assigning each one their tasks and commanding the doorkeeper to stay alert. He told them to be on the alert because they don't know when the master of the house is coming, whether in the evening, at midnight, or in the morning, lest he come suddenly and find them asleep. What he says to them, he says to all: be on the alert.
illustrations.context: This retelling emphasizes the need to stay watchful and prepared for the Lord's unexpected return.

illustrations.title: Waiting for the Master
illustrations.text: Be like men who are waiting for their master when he returns from the wedding feast so that they may immediately open the door to him when he comes. This means being ready at any moment, just as servants should be for their master's arrival. It's about constant vigilance and preparedness for his return.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how believers should always be ready to welcome Jesus upon His return without delay.

illustrations.title: Shackleton's Antarctic Readiness
illustrations.text: On an expedition to the Antarctic, Sir Ernest Shackleton was forced to leave 21 of his men on Elephant Island. He intended to return but was unavoidably delayed, and after four months of waiting, he finally reached them and found his men alive and well with their belongings packed. When asked how they could leave on a moment's notice, they explained that every morning their leader would roll up his sleeping bag and shout, 'Get your things together, boys, the boss may come today.' Every single day, they lived as if it could be the day he returned.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the importance of always being prepared for Jesus's return, just as Shackleton's men were ready for his arrival.

illustrations.title: Last-Minute Car Belt Analogy
illustrations.text: It's like saying, if I'm about to be in a car accident, I'll go ahead and put my seat belt on as we're slamming into something. But you can't do that; it's too late. This highlights the futility of waiting until the very last moment.
illustrations.context: This analogy emphasizes that you cannot wait until the last second to get right with Jesus; preparation must happen now.

illustrations.title: Elevator Fall Jump Analogy
illustrations.text: It's like the person who says, if the elevator is falling, at the last second I'll jump up right before it hits. But that won't work because you're moving too fast and it will be ineffective. This shows the danger of relying on last-minute actions.
illustrations.context: This analogy stresses that last-minute efforts won't prepare you for Jesus's return; you must be ready in advance.

illustrations.title: Conference Speaker Resembles Father
illustrations.text: I was at a pastor's conference many years ago when we came back from lunch and guys were talking. Some guy got up and started speaking, and I didn't know who he was at first, thinking he might just be giving announcements. But then, the room quieted down as we realized he sounded exactly like John Courson. It turned out to be John's son, and the speaker even said, 'I know the apple doesn't fall far from the tree.' This story shows how a son naturally resembles his father.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that believers, as children of God, should resemble Him in their lives as evidence of their spiritual birth.

illustrations.title: Jesus on Spiritual Fathers
illustrations.text: Remember what Jesus said to the Jews in the Gospel of John: 'You are of your father the devil, and you want to do the deeds of your father. He was a liar and a murderer from the beginning, and you want to murder me.' This quote matters because it highlights how people resemble their spiritual father through their actions, just as believers should resemble God. Pastor Bob uses it to connect the idea that godly living proves our spiritual heritage.
illustrations.context: This quote emphasizes that one of the evidences of being born of God is resembling Him, in contrast to those who resemble the devil.

illustrations.title: Sounding Like Chuck Smith
illustrations.text: I've had people tell me that from time to time, but last week someone came up to me in the courtyard and said, 'I can't help it, but I've attended near Mesa for years, and you sound just like Chuck Smith.' I replied, 'Well, I could do worse, but as much as I love and appreciate Pastor Chuck Smith, my goal is not to sound like him; it's to live like Jesus Christ.' And I think that's got to be your goal too.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to emphasize that believers should aim to live like Jesus rather than imitate other people.

illustrations.title: Jesus' Ascension Retelling
illustrations.text: Remember, he led them out as far as Bethany, was lifted up before their eyes, and disappeared. Then the angel said he's coming back the same way. Jesus said the Spirit of God will use my going into heaven bodily to convince this world there's something called righteousness.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to explain how the Ascension demonstrates God's standard of righteousness.

illustrations.title: Righteousness Beyond Pharisees
illustrations.text: Jesus said it this way to the Jews: except your righteousness exceed that of the scribes and the Pharisees, you will in no wise enter the Kingdom of Heaven. That blew them away because these guys were living their lives for the righteousness of God, studying the word every minute of their day. They realized there's no hope for them if their righteousness doesn't exceed that.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to show that human efforts cannot achieve God's perfect standard of righteousness.

illustrations.title: Train Track Standards Analogy
illustrations.text: You see, he said there are two rails and that second rail has to be exactly the right distance from the other; it conforms to a standard. Did you know that rails on trains are four feet eight and a half inches apart all over the United States? That's the standard because it originated from Great Britain, based on the width of old Roman roads, which was the distance of chariot wheels, actually the size of two horse rear ends, and ever since that original standard, all rails have had to conform to that.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to show that truth is absolute and must conform to a fixed standard, contrasting it with modern cultural views on truth.

illustrations.title: Eve's Temptation Retelling
illustrations.text: Do you know when the very first temptation happened in the Book of Genesis to Eve? Satan said that God lied to you and that you won't die if you eat the fruit. He promised that your eyes would be opened, knowing good and evil, and you would be like God. This meant experiencing evil in a way God never does, and it involved declaring what is good and evil yourself.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how Satan tempted Eve to rely on her own understanding and decide truth for herself, contrary to God's word.

illustrations.title: Solipsism Philosophy Explained
illustrations.text: There's an ancient philosophy called solipsism, derived from Latin words meaning alone and self. It basically claims that the only reality is what exists in my mind, so if I say something is true, then it is. This philosophy is more modern than most people realize and promotes the idea of personal truth over external reality.
illustrations.context: This reference shows how solipsism reflects the temptation to define one's own reality and truth, similar to Satan's deception.

illustrations.title: Henley Quote on Self-Mastery
illustrations.text: Remember what Henley said: 'It matters not how straight the gate, how charged with punishment the scroll, I am the master of my fate, I am the captain of my soul.' This quote means that I decide what reality and truth are, rejecting any external authority. Henley expresses the idea that personal will overrides all else, even divine judgment.
illustrations.context: This quote highlights the dangerous mindset of self-determination that exalts human understanding above God's truth.

illustrations.title: Train Derailment Tragedy
illustrations.text: When trains go off the rails or crash, it's a horrible tragedy. You've likely heard about the one in India where three trains crashed, killing 300 people and injuring a thousand. We've seen many derailments in the United States, which are common but usually don't result in loss of life; the real tragedy occurs when people are on board or hazardous materials are involved, affecting entire cities. It's all about what's on board, just like with truth.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that the content or stakes involved determine the impact, paralleling it to how truth stumbling affects society.

illustrations.title: Isaiah on Stumbling Truth
illustrations.text: Listen to what Isaiah said: Justice is turned back and righteousness stands far away, for truth has stumbled in the street and uprightness cannot enter. This quote speaks to the confusion in society, like debates over sex and gender, where people think they can define themselves apart from truth. Pastor Bob connects this to how truth is essential and can't be easily dismissed.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that societal confusion about identity reflects a deeper issue where truth has fallen, leading to injustice.

illustrations.title: Car Thieves and Hidden VINs
illustrations.text: When a person steals a car, thieves often deface the VIN, the vehicle identification number that shows who manufactured it and who it belongs to, by getting rid of it or replacing it. What they don't know is that manufacturers put hidden VINs in places like the frame, engine, and transmission, making it impossible to change the car's true identity completely.
