This illustrates how people might try to alter their own identity, like in gender discussions, but the Creator has marked every cell in the body with the truth of what you are—there are 37.2 trillion cells confirming it.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is showing that just as hidden VINs reveal a car's true origin despite attempts to change it, human DNA and cells reveal one's true identity set by the Creator.

illustrations.title: Burger King Truth Analogy
illustrations.text: This idea that I'm going to make the world like Burger King, where I can have it my way, or like Baskin Robbins, where I choose something different today than yesterday, is completely foreign to truth. Truth doesn't change, and you don't make it up for yourself. God declares what is true, and we must live in light of it.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that attempting to redefine truth or identity arbitrarily is contrary to God's unchanging truth.

illustrations.title: Tampering with Word Analogy
illustrations.text: When man tries to redefine what God has created, he doesn't define it; he defiles it, just like with the Word of God when you add to it or subtract from it. This damages and destroys it. We need to believe what God says and stop trying to make our own rules.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is showing that redefining God's creations, like gender or marriage, corrupts them in the same way altering Scripture does.

illustrations.title: Combat Shooting Example
illustrations.text: Anybody involved with weapons for a profession knows that you're trained in combat shooting to shoot for the body mass. People often ask why police don't shoot the gun out of someone's hands or aim for the head, but that's from movies like The Rifleman. The goal isn't to kill but to stop someone, and shooting for the body mass is more effective than trying to wing them. In the same way, Satan targets your vital areas of righteousness.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how Satan aims to attack the core areas of a person's spiritual life, like righteousness, to cause damage.

illustrations.title: Breastplate Armor Analogy
illustrations.text: The breastplate in ancient warfare was the part of your armor that protected your vital organs. Satan knows this, so he targets areas of your righteousness and obedience to God. Even if no one else sees your secret sins like cheating on taxes or viewing pornography, it damages your conscience and makes you vulnerable. This shows why he hits hard in these motivational areas.
illustrations.context: This analogy emphasizes that Satan focuses on attacking the essential parts of spiritual protection, just as enemies in battle target vital spots.

illustrations.title: John Baptist's Warning
illustrations.text: The Jews thought that because they were sons of Abraham biologically, they were surely going to heaven. John the Baptist corrected them, saying that God could raise up children to Abraham from these stones and calling them a brood of vipers. He warned them to flee from the wrath to come and get right with God. This story highlights that true salvation requires genuine repentance, not just heritage.
illustrations.context: This retelling stresses that one must live as a true child of God, not rely on rituals or lineage for salvation.

illustrations.title: Boy Waiting for Gum
illustrations.text: I was just in the mall yesterday, looking for something for my grandson, and I had to go up and down the escalator multiple times at Nordstrom. While I was there, I was thinking about a story I heard last night about a little boy. It was Christmas time, and everyone was rushing around when this four-year-old boy was standing in front of the escalator, staring at it with no parents around. Someone from the store asked if he was lost, and he said no, explaining that he had put his gum on the escalator rail and was waiting for it to come back. He wouldn't take his eyes off it, illustrating that things will return, ready or not. The question is, will you be ready for Jesus' return?
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to emphasize that Jesus will return unexpectedly, and people must be prepared spiritually.

illustrations.title: Isaiah's Feet of Good News
illustrations.text: In Isaiah, it says how lovely on the mountains are the feet of those who bring good news, and the good news is they're announcing peace, declaring God's righteousness, and proclaiming that our God reigns. I know this verse well, and I preach it because I have to believe it for myself. So do you; you need to know right now that God reigns, even if you're not fully living in that reality yet, so absorb it and say to God that you're okay and don't have to worry about your problems at work or home.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that God reigns and encourages listeners to internalize this truth to overcome worries in daily life.

illustrations.title: Explaining the Bema Seat
illustrations.text: The Bema Seat is a Greek word referring to a place in the first-century Greek-Roman world where judges passed judgment in civil and criminal cases. It was an open place in various cities, something well-known in their culture. It's like us talking about a courthouse today, helping us understand the biblical concept of standing before Christ.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate the idea that every Christian will stand before the Judgment Seat of Christ to be recompensed for their deeds.

illustrations.title: Church as Hospital Analogy
illustrations.text: How many of you have ever known somebody who got sick, was hospitalized, and then got sicker because of something they caught at the hospital? It's called a healthcare-acquired illness, and it's not hard to figure out why that happens. Hospitals are places of healing, but that means they're full of sick people, so there's a risk of catching what others have. My wife and I have just spent some time at several hospitals, and there are a lot of sick people there. The church is a hospital, which is why it doesn't surprise me when people get upset about others at church who aren't completely well.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that the church, like a hospital, contains spiritually sick people who might spread negative influences, emphasizing the need for caution among God's people.

illustrations.title: Grapes of Wrath Quote
illustrations.text: In the Book of Revelation, you find this picture during the Great Tribulation, a metaphor familiar from the American song Battle Hymn of the Republic. We sing the phrase, 'He is trampling out the Vintage where the Grapes of Wrath are stored.' This comes from Revelation, illustrating how the wrath of God accumulates from the sin of man who has rejected Christ and hates God. Eventually, that wrath pours out as judgment when God says enough.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to explain how God's judgment accumulates over time due to persistent sin, leading to inevitable divine wrath.

illustrations.title: Greg Laurie Church Story
illustrations.text: Years ago, there was a group of churches gathering for prayer. Greg Laurie was fairly new, and they were introducing themselves. One guy stood up and said, 'I'm Pastor so and so, I pastor such and such a church, and I'm a prophet.' In contrast, Greg said, 'I'm Pastor Greg Laurie, Calvary Chapel of Riverside, a nonprofit organization.' This humorous exchange highlights the difference in humility and self-proclamation.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate the need to be wary of self-proclaimed spiritual leaders who might not be genuine.

illustrations.title: Personal Salvation Experience
illustrations.text: When I first got saved, I was 13 years old, and I didn't have much spiritual discernment. Most brand new Christians are like that; it's not surprising. You're not born with discernment, much like a baby who doesn't know what to eat and needs a house that's baby-proofed. As a new believer, you have to learn and grow in these areas.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob shares this to emphasize that new Christians lack initial discernment and must develop it over time.

illustrations.title: Baby Proofing Analogy
illustrations.text: We hadn't had a baby at our house in a while, so when one came, we realized our cabinets didn't have those childproof locks to keep them from opening. There were things like Comet cleaner that a baby could get into and put in their mouth, which is dangerous because babies naturally put stuff in their mouths and it can be serious or even life-threatening. You don't have to protect a 30-year-old the same way, but for babies, it's crucial. That analogy isn't too far off for a baby Christian, who might take in unhealthy spiritual things without realizing it.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to show how new Christians, like babies, can easily absorb harmful influences.

illustrations.title: TV Show and Magazine Story
illustrations.text: I remember when I became a Christian, there was this TV show I wouldn't have watched before, about a good-looking man talking about the Bible and the Holy Land. I was intrigued by his discussion of prophecy and subscribed to their free magazine, thinking it was generous. It was from Garner Ted Armstrong and the Worldwide Church of God, and I didn't read much of it, just looked at the pictures to show I was interested in growing spiritually. When a youth pastor came to my house for a Bible study, he noticed the magazine on the coffee table and told me it was from a cult. I didn't even know what a cult was, so I threw it away immediately, realizing it was a well-disguised lie. This illustrates how we can innocently get involved in unhealthy things without knowing better.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob shares this story to warn about how new believers might unintentionally engage with deceptive spiritual content.

illustrations.title: Flight Path Deviation
illustrations.text: You've probably heard this illustration before if you've been here any length of time. They say that for every degree you fly off course, you'll miss your target landing spot by 92 feet for every mile flown. That amounts to about one mile off target for every 60 miles flown. For example, if you're flying from LAX to Hawaii, which is 2,542 miles, being one degree off will make you miss the islands by 42 miles. At 35,000 feet, you won't even see them at all. It doesn't take much to be off course to end up way off target, and not that much time.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate how small deviations in spiritual teaching can lead to significant errors in discernment.

illustrations.title: Bible as Truth App
illustrations.text: Wouldn't it be great if there was an app for everything, like a portable light detector to find out if someone is telling the truth? For example, when talking to your teenage kids about where they were, you could use it to check. That would be handy for verifying the truth. Well, guess what? You already have an app for that—it's right here, the Bible, which helps you detect spiritual error.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that the Bible is the essential tool for discerning and testing spiritual truth.

illustrations.title: Warning on Door-to-Door False Teachers
illustrations.text: Sometimes people wonder about those who come to their door, really into their religion like Mormonism. They want to leave their material and suggest a deal where they'll read your Bible if you read their Book of Mormon or Watchtower material. Be really careful; some people say they bring them into their house just to keep them busy so they can't talk to neighbors. They take all the literature, say sure I'll take it, and then throw it away. This illustrates the need to avoid giving place to the enemy.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is warning against engaging with false teachers to prevent becoming spiritually infected and partnering in their evil deeds.

illustrations.title: Peter Following at Distance
illustrations.text: We often point out that when Peter was following the Lord Jesus at a distance, remember Jesus was under arrest and Peter didn't want to associate with him, so he was following at a distance. That's always a dangerous place to be. That's when sheep tend to wander away from the shepherd.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that following God closely is essential to avoid spiritual danger.

illustrations.title: Sheep's Lack of Defenses
illustrations.text: Sheep are natural followers, which can be good or bad because they have absolutely no natural defenses. They don't have sharp teeth to bite, claws to fight, can't run very fast, or kick hard. Really, the only true defense a sheep has is to stay close to the shepherd.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that Christians must stay near to God for protection, as sheep rely on the shepherd.

illustrations.title: Psalms on God's Nearness
illustrations.text: Remember what David writes in Psalm 23: 'Thy rod and thy staff, they comfort me.' It's what he has; that's where my safety is. Then in Psalm 73:28, 'But as for me, the nearness of God is my good; I have made the Lord God my refuge that I may tell of all Thy works.' This emphasizes that safety comes from being close to God.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is showing that God's nearness provides safety and goodness, connecting it to the importance of following God closely.

illustrations.title: Boy Runs Away Limited
illustrations.text: It's like that story I heard about a little boy who was upset with his mom and decided to run away from home. He kept riding his tricycle around the cul-de-sac back and forth. When someone asked what he was doing, he replied that he wasn't allowed to cross the street. So, yeah, obedience will keep you close to the Lord even in your struggles.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that obedience keeps you close to the Lord during struggles, just as the boy's limits kept him safe.

illustrations.title: Saul's Rebellion and Silence
illustrations.text: Remember what happened with Saul: because of his rebellion, he stopped hearing from God. He desperately wanted to hear from God but got nothing, which is why he decided to try bringing Samuel back from the dead. This shows that rebellion can lead to spiritual isolation, making it hard to connect with God.
illustrations.context: This retelling emphasizes that rebellion against God can result in losing the ability to hear from Him.

illustrations.title: AM Radio Signal Blockage
illustrations.text: I remember it used to be AM radio where you'd go under an overpass and couldn't hear anything because those radio waves don't go through it. Well, sin does that—it blocks you from hearing God even though He's still there and has plenty to say. If you're holding onto sin, you won't expect to hear from God because it creates a separation.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how sin acts as a barrier that prevents people from hearing God's voice, just like an overpass blocks radio signals.

illustrations.title: Chinese Man and Bible
illustrations.text: Remember the Chinese man that gave the Bible back to the missionary. He said he didn't want it because every time he read it, it kicked him and convicted him. It's like God speaking through the Word, telling us to repent and not turn it off.
illustrations.context: This shows that God's Word convicts people of their sins and encourages them to listen rather than avoid it.

illustrations.title: Sick Sheep in Israel
illustrations.text: I heard the story once of a man who went over to Israel on a tour and saw a big flock of sheep. He tried to get one sheep to follow him out of the herd, and it did, but the shepherd explained that the sheep was sick, which is why it followed a stranger. A sick sheep will follow anyone, highlighting the danger of spiritual vulnerability where one might stray from the true Shepherd.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that spiritually weak or 'sick' individuals are more likely to follow the wrong influences instead of God's voice.

illustrations.title: Elderly Man's Loyalty Joke
illustrations.text: So, this elderly man lay in a hospital with his wife sitting at his bedside. He whispered, 'Is that you, Ethel, at my side again?' She answered yes, and he said, 'Remember years ago when I was in the VA Hospital, you were there with me then. You were with me when we lost everything in the fire, and when we were poor, you were with me then too.' The man sighed and said, 'I tell you, Ethel, you are bad luck.'
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to question who deserves lifelong loyalty, emphasizing the need to cling faithfully to God as He has been faithful to us.

illustrations.title: Persecution of Early Christians
illustrations.text: For about the first 300 years, there was severe persecution of believers by Jewish people and the Roman Empire, with wave after wave of emperors trying to annihilate Christians. During this time, emperors like Domitian arrested and killed Christians, and many were buried in the catacombs in Rome. It's been said that the blood of the martyrs is the seed of the church because when people saw Christians willing to die for their Savior, it attracted them and led to more conversions, even though six million Christians died during these persecutions. Then, in the beginning of the 4th century, the conversion of Constantine in 313 AD marked a turning point when he had an appearance of the cross and became a Christian.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this historical reference to illustrate that attempts to destroy the church through force, like the persecution in the early centuries, ultimately failed and even led to its growth.

illustrations.title: Constantine and Church Corruption
illustrations.text: His mom Helena became a Christian and made pilgrimages to the Middle East, where churches like the Church of the Holy Sepulchre were established toward the end of the 4th century because of her faith. Christianity went from being an illegal religion to the official religion of Rome, leading to the Holy Roman Empire. The church became corrupt, wealthy, and politically powerful for centuries, with the pope often at odds with the emperor, compromising scriptural teachings. Satan couldn't destroy the church through violence, so evil infiltrated it instead. This historical shift shows how the church can become a breeding ground for compromise.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate how the church transitioned from persecution to corruption, showing that external success can lead to internal compromise.

illustrations.title: Parable of Wheat and Tares
illustrations.text: Jesus talks about the parables of the kingdom in Matthew 13, including the one about wheat and tares. There will be false believers within the church who mix in for various reasons, like social status, business advantages, or family benefits. You won't be able to easily tell them apart from true believers. This parable highlights how motivations can vary and lead to insincere faith. It's a warning about the presence of hypocrisy in the church.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to point out that false believers will exist alongside true ones in the church, making it hard to distinguish them.

illustrations.title: Parable of the Mustard Seed
illustrations.text: Jesus describes the parable of the mustard seed, a small seed that grows into a large tree. When fully grown, the birds of the air nest in it, and birds often symbolize demonic or evil forces. This represents the church starting small but growing so large that evil elements can infiltrate and thrive within it. Even though the church expands, not everything connected to it is pure or organic. It's a vivid picture of how corruption can enter a growing institution.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that the church will grow massively but may harbor evil influences that aren't truly part of it.

illustrations.title: Parable of the Leaven
illustrations.text: Jesus mentions the woman with the three measures of meal who puts leaven into each one until they are all fully leavened. Meal is a type and picture of something in scripture, often representing the spread of influence. In this context, leaven symbolizes corruption or sin that permeates thoroughly. This parable warns about how negative elements can spread through the church undetected.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show how evil or false teachings can fully infiltrate and affect the entire church.

illustrations.title: Loose Cannon Danger
illustrations.text: Victor Hugo, a famous author, wrote a book called 93, which is where the idea of the danger of a loose cannon comes from. It's about a cannon on a ship that becomes untied, rolling from side to side with its weight and wheels. The men try to stop it, but it's too heavy and starts killing them as the ship lists. Eventually, it could go through the deck and sink the ship. So, the expression is that a loose cannon within is more dangerous than an enemy from without, illustrating internal threats.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that spiritual infection from within the church is far more dangerous than external persecution.

illustrations.title: Phone Call About Judgmental Church
illustrations.text: Somebody called me the other day because a church was being judgmental. They said the church was wrong, but I told them to slow down, as the church might be trying to honor God's word. There may be a way they're doing it that's not biblical, but we should be careful about judging.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that people should not quickly dismiss others for upholding God's word.

illustrations.title: Eve Tempting Adam to Sin
illustrations.text: The devil tempted the very first man to sin through his wife, who tried to get Adam to disobey God. It's like how the devil used Eve in the garden. This shows Satan's method of using those closest to us.
illustrations.context: This points out that Satan often uses spouses to lead people into sin.

illustrations.title: Job's Wife Encouraging Cursing
illustrations.text: Job's wife tried to get her husband to curse God after their suffering. The devil was behind it, using her to tempt Job. This demonstrates how Satan can manipulate family members.
illustrations.context: This highlights that the devil uses close relationships to promote sin.

illustrations.title: Eli Honoring Sons Over God
illustrations.text: Eli, the high priest, honored his sons above God and wouldn't deal with their sins. God judged him and his sons for it. This shows the consequences of prioritizing family over obedience to God.
illustrations.context: This warns that failing to address sin in loved ones can lead to judgment.

illustrations.title: Peter Deterred Jesus from the Cross
illustrations.text: Peter, one of Jesus' closest disciples, tried to deter him from going to the cross, and Jesus called him Satan for it. Even best friends can be used by the devil. This reveals how Satan works through trusted people.
illustrations.context: This emphasizes that Satan can use even faithful friends to obstruct God's plan.

illustrations.title: Jezebel Encouraging Ahab's Murder
illustrations.text: Jezebel, Ahab's wife, encouraged him to murder a citizen and steal their vineyard. This is an example of how the devil uses spouses for evil deeds. It shows Satan's influence through marriage.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that the devil can use wives or close partners to promote wickedness.

illustrations.title: Ananias and Sapphira's Deception
illustrations.text: Ananias and Sapphira decided to lie about giving all their money to the Lord, and they were both struck down for it. Great fear came upon the whole church and all who heard about it, just as God said in the Old Testament. This story shows how the devil can involve couples in sin and the severe consequences that follow.
illustrations.context: This demonstrates that Satan uses even believers in partnerships to lie and face God's judgment.

illustrations.title: LA Riots Temptation Story
illustrations.text: There was a guy who got saved out of the gangs in Fullerton and started coming to our church during the LA riots. He came to me and said his old friends invited him to go see the chaos, even though he knew he shouldn't. He admitted he went anyway, and I told him it was a bad idea. That day, I had a Newsweek magazine on my desk with a picture of guys turning, which tied into the events.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how easy it is to get sucked into mob mentality and follow a crowd into wrongdoing.

illustrations.title: Police Car Bad Decision
illustrations.text: Over an LAPD or Highway Patrol police car flipping it over with fires all around, he said, 'I'm in the picture.' I replied, 'What? That's me right there.' It doesn't take but a moment of a bad decision to get yourself with the wrong group and get sucked back into stuff you shouldn't have been there.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how a single bad decision can lead to being in the wrong group and facing consequences, emphasizing that God defines right and wrong.

illustrations.title: Silence as Complicity Quote
illustrations.text: Somebody has said that silence in the face of oppression is complicity with the oppressor. This means that when sin is happening around you, staying quiet makes you part of the problem. In the church, you do not have the right to remain silent; you're called to reprove a person in sin.
illustrations.context: This quote underscores the point that failing to speak up against sin in the community makes one complicit, urging active participation in addressing wrongdoing.

illustrations.title: Achan's Hidden Sin Consequences
illustrations.text: Jericho fell and the walls came tumbling down after Joshua's victory, but one man named Achan took forbidden items like silver, gold, and Babylonian garments, hiding them under his tent. No one knew except God, and when Israel attacked the next town, Ai, they were utterly defeated, with 36 men dying in the battle. This defeat led to mourning families and revealed how Achan's secret sin affected the entire community, as God refused to go with them until the sin was addressed.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that individual sin has far-reaching consequences, affecting the whole group and leading to defeat.

illustrations.title: Israeli Destruction of Terrorist Homes
illustrations.text: In Israel today, the military completely destroys the homes of terrorists using bulldozers, ensuring no one can live there again as a severe form of punishment. This practice reflects a modern expression of how sin is dealt with decisively. It parallels God's command to utterly destroy cities like Jericho, making a permanent heap as a lasting reminder.
illustrations.context: This example shows that sin requires total eradication to prevent further harm, just as in biblical times.

illustrations.title: Cancer Treatment Analogy
illustrations.text: If your doctor says you have an aggressive melanoma skin cancer, you can't defeat it with your diet or arrest it with an antibiotic. You have to cut it out, and they must remove margins of healthy tissue beyond it to ensure it's all gone. You have to get more radical, or it's coming back, and that's exactly what scripture means about dealing with sin.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to emphasize the need to deal radically with sin to prevent it from returning.

illustrations.title: Quote on Root of Sin
illustrations.text: Someone once said that for every individual striking at the root of sin, there are a thousand who are only hacking at its branches. This quote highlights the importance of addressing sin deeply rather than superficially. As I read the scripture, I ask myself where I'm not dealing radically with sin in my life.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to stress the need for thorough action against sin rather than partial efforts.

illustrations.title: Israel's Disobedience Warning
illustrations.text: God is warning his people that if you don't deal with sin as radically as you should, you will be dealing with it again later. To be honest, the nation of Israel really didn't obey this command and they did lose the kingdom as a result. This serves as a severe warning about the consequences of ignoring such instructions.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob references Israel's failure to illustrate the severe consequences of not dealing radically with sin.

illustrations.title: Abraham's Sacrifice Test
illustrations.text: God told Abraham to offer Isaac up. Isaac wasn't stumbling him; God was testing Abram and would give him that back. If that relationship is something that will glorify God, He'll give it back to you.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that God may ask believers to end relationships as a test, but if they honor God, He will restore them.

illustrations.title: Grace in Weakness Quote
illustrations.text: Paul pleaded to the Lord for him to take away something, an ailment he mentioned three times. The Lord responded, 'My grace is sufficient for you, for my power is made perfect in weakness.' This world does not celebrate weakness but celebrates what it perceives to be power, yet God's power is made perfect in weakness.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that God's strength is revealed through human weakness, encouraging praise in difficult times.

illustrations.title: Jesus in the Storm Analogy
illustrations.text: Christ is the cornerstone and is in effect during this storm, not worried as he's sleeping in the bottom of the boat. The fact that he's in your boat should give you full confidence that no matter what you face, the Lord has the power to speak and calm the storm. This illustrates God's presence and control in life's challenges.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that God's presence provides confidence and peace during life's storms, just as Jesus was in the boat with his disciples.

illustrations.title: Humorous Mother Lessons
illustrations.text: I read an article some time ago about life lessons my mother taught me, and I wonder what you would put down if you had to make a list of those. This person said their mother taught them to appreciate a job well done by saying, 'If you're going to kill each other, do it outside. I just finished cleaning.' Then, their mother taught them about prayer: 'You better pray that will come out of the carpet.' Their mother also taught them logic: 'Because I said so, that's why,' and foresight: 'Make sure you wear clean underwear in case you're in an accident.' Now, I don't assume a new generation is telling their kids that, but some of us grew up with our parents like that.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses these quotes to connect with the audience about life lessons from parents, leading into the discussion of honoring father and mother from Exodus 20:12.

illustrations.title: Mother's Hypocrisy Teaching
illustrations.text: This one, my mother taught me about hypocrisy: 'If I've told you once, I've told you a million times, don't exaggerate.' Then she taught me about genetics: 'You're just like your father.' It's kind of humorous and serves as a light-hearted example. This personal anecdote highlights the irony in parental advice.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to humorously introduce the fifth commandment and transition into discussing relationships.

illustrations.title: Isaiah on God's Love
illustrations.text: Listen to what God says in Isaiah 46:3-4: 'Listen to me, O house of Jacob, and all the remnant of the house of Israel, you who have been borne by me from birth and have been carried from the womb; even to your old age I will be the same, and even to your graying years I will bear you; I have done it, and I will carry you and I will bear you and I will deliver you.' In other words, this quote shows God's enduring love for His people from birth to old age. Pastor Bob connects it to parents' sacrificial love, illustrating how parents mirror God's character. This helps emphasize the command's focus on relationships.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to show that parents preview God's personal character through their sacrificial and enduring love.

illustrations.title: Jesus as Protective Hen
illustrations.text: I think of what Jesus said to Jerusalem: how many times I would have gathered you as a hen gathers her chicks. That's a picture of a mother protecting her young. It's God's attitude toward us, and that's how our parents wanted to protect us, even when we didn't want to be protected from the things they saw as dangers.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to illustrate how parents protect their children, just as God desired to protect Jerusalem.

illustrations.title: Pastor Bob's Career Change
illustrations.text: I've shared many times before that originally I had thought I would be in law enforcement, so I pursued a career in that. But God called me into the ministry, and I wasn't sure how my parents would feel about that. I was 17 or 18 years of age when this happened, and it shows how parents can encourage and influence our life directions.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob shares this personal story to demonstrate how parents encourage and direct their children in personal life choices.

illustrations.title: Mom's Dedication to Ministry
illustrations.text: My mom said, 'Bob, I'm so proud of you that my son is going to be in the ministry.' She told me a story about something that happened before I was born, where she had dedicated me to the Lord for full-time ministry but never mentioned it to me for 18 years and waited for God's calling on my life. What a blessing that was, as it shows how parents can encourage us in unique ways.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how parents can dedicate and encourage their children in faith, waiting for God's timing.

illustrations.title: Boy's Church Play Mix-Up
illustrations.text: I remember hearing about a little boy who was in a church play and was totally nervous because he had never been in a play before. He only had one line: 'I am the light of the world.' When it came to his moment, he couldn't remember his line, but his mom was in the front row prompting him by saying, 'I am the light of the world,' and finally he smiled and said, 'My mom is the light of the world.' This story highlights how parents can reflect God's character to their children.
illustrations.context: This shows how parents might unintentionally reveal God's character to their children, even in everyday moments.

illustrations.title: Sunset Painting Analogy
illustrations.text: Listen, if someone paints a beautiful life-like picture of a sunset, it's not a sunset but it reminds you of what the real deal is like. That's the best parents can do; we're not God, but God uses parents to give a preview of His character. Parents are kind of our spiritual training wheels to help us learn about and honor God's authority in our lives.
illustrations.context: This analogy explains how parents provide a preliminary glimpse of God's character and help children understand spiritual truths.

illustrations.title: Sons of Rechab Obey Ancestor
illustrations.text: It's interesting in the book of Jeremiah that God tells Jeremiah to go and call a particular man and his family, the sons of Jonadab who lived in Judah, to come to the temple. He brings them in and sets down pitchers of wine in front of all these men and says, 'Drink it.' They reply, 'We're not allowed to drink wine; we don't drink wine because our forefather commanded us not to, and we've been obeying that ever since.' They explain that their ancestor also told them not to live in cities but in tents, and they've always followed his instructions. God then uses this as an example, saying that these sons have obeyed their father's command, even though His own people haven't listened to Him.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate that honoring parents through obedience is commendable, even when God's people fail to obey Him.

illustrations.title: 60s Slang for Heavy Meaning
illustrations.text: The word honor in Hebrew is kaboth, which means heavy or weighty. Maybe some of you grew up in the 60s and 70s where the slang term was 'that's heavy,' meaning something amazing or significant. This expression shows that weighty things are awesome and impactful. Pastor Bob connects this to treating parents as having significant value.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to explain that honoring parents means treating them as weighty and significant in our lives.

illustrations.title: Boomerang Beach Mishap
illustrations.text: I don't know if you've ever thrown a real boomerang, but a lot of us as kids had those plastic ones that just fly away like a baseball. One time on a family vacation at the beach, I splurged and bought a real wooden one from a shop. I took my kids down to the beach to show them how it works, even though I hadn't thrown one before, and I threw it as hard as I could. It went way out there and then came flying back at us fast, so we had to run to avoid it.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that dishonoring parents has a boomerang effect, meaning negative actions come back as consequences.

illustrations.title: Noah's Curse on Ham
illustrations.text: Noah told his son Ham, who disrespected him by going out and telling his brothers that Noah was naked and drunk in the tent. As a result, Noah pronounced that the consequences of this disrespect would be seen in Ham's son. This shows how such actions can lead to ongoing effects in future generations.
illustrations.context: This retelling demonstrates that dishonoring parents leads to consequences that extend to one's descendants.

illustrations.title: Adam and Jesus Comparison
illustrations.text: Think of Adam, who lived to be 930 years old according to the Book of Genesis. Jesus lived to be about 33. But no one could argue that Adam honored his parents or God more than Jesus did, showing that physical longevity isn't the key measure.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that honoring parents doesn't guarantee a long physical life but a fuller one.

illustrations.title: Tree of Life Analogy
illustrations.text: In fact, this word 'to prolong' is used in the Book of Ezekiel, picturing a tree that is blossoming and growing, planted by water with its branches extending. The idea is that the tree's life is stronger and more healthy, not necessarily longer. So, it represents a full and vibrant life rather than extended years.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob explains that living long in the land means having a healthier, more abundant life through God's blessing.

illustrations.title: Inmates from Broken Families
illustrations.text: Statistics are tragic: about 70% of inmates in our prisons right now come from broken and dysfunctional families. This shows that where there's a breakdown in the family, there's a breakdown in the culture and society. It's a clear indicator of how family issues lead to broader societal problems.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this statistic to illustrate that the breakdown of the nuclear family leads to societal collapse and judgment by God.

illustrations.title: Amazon's Hand Payment Technology
illustrations.text: Did you just read that Amazon is coming out with Amazon One where you're going to buy stuff with your hand? It's already available; you're just going to use your hand to make purchases. This is basically a plug for a system where you'll have to use your hand as a mark to buy and sell, aligning with end-times prophecies.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this real-world technological advancement to show how it's fulfilling biblical prophecies about the mark of the beast in the last days.

illustrations.title: Legal Loophole in Jesus's Day
illustrations.text: In Jesus's day, there was a legal loophole to avoid helping aging parents or a widowed mother. People could dedicate money to God, which meant that money came back to them, and their family had no claim to it. The rabbis allowed this practice, likely for their own benefit, even though it violated God's command. Jesus confronted this by saying it invalidated the word of God for the sake of traditions, emphasizing the importance of financially caring for family.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate how religious traditions can lead people to neglect God's command to honor and care for parents.

illustrations.title: Personal Parenting Error
illustrations.text: I'm kind of defending Joseph and Mary because, as a dad, I once left one of my young sons somewhere and I know how it happens. We don't know the details of their situation, but these things can occur in the midst of travel and distraction. This personal experience helps me relate to their mistake and understand it wasn't out of carelessness.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that parents can make unintentional mistakes, just like Joseph and Mary did.

illustrations.title: Jesus at the Temple
illustrations.text: Jesus's parents took him to Jerusalem for the feast when he was 12, the age of becoming responsible. They left him there accidentally, probably in a caravan, and when they realized their error, they searched everywhere and found him in the temple talking to the teachers. He was asking impressive questions that amazed the teachers, but Mary was upset and said, 'Didn't you care about us?' Jesus responded, 'Did you not know that I must be about my Father's business?' This revealed his deeper knowledge beyond his years.
illustrations.context: This story shows that even though Jesus knew more than his parents, he still honored and submitted to them as an example for others.

illustrations.title: Wedding at Cana Miracle
illustrations.text: Jesus performed his first miracle at a wedding in Cana. Mary came to him saying they had run out of wine, and Jesus responded by saying, 'What is that to me and to you, woman? My hour has not yet come.' This showed a shift in their relationship as he began his ministry, but he still honored her by turning water into wine. Mary trusted him and told the servants to do whatever he said, demonstrating her faith in her son.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how Jesus honored his mother while establishing his role as the Messiah.

illustrations.title: Jesus on the Cross
illustrations.text: When Jesus was dying on the cross for our sins, he was focused on others despite his immense suffering. He thought about his mother's future and said to her, 'Woman, behold your son,' referring to John, and to John, 'Behold your mother.' This act ensured Mary was cared for, showing Jesus' commitment to honoring his parents even in his final moments. Throughout his life, he exemplified this command fully.
illustrations.context: This highlights Jesus as a perfect example of honoring one's father and mother.

illustrations.title: Extracting Precious from Garbage
illustrations.text: If you want to honor me and speak for me, you're going to have to learn to take that which is precious out of a huge pile of garbage. A lot of us have more precious things than we know. Remember when God judges us, He's going to look at our lives and even if a man's life had nothing but wood, hay, and stubble that's all going to be burned, He's going to have a foundation that can't be destroyed and will extract what is rewardable and worthy of honor.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to illustrate that we must focus on the positive, praiseworthy aspects of our parents or memories, even if mixed with negatives, to honor them as God commands.

illustrations.title: Pastor Chuck's Mother's Faith
illustrations.text: I used to love to listen to Pastor Chuck in his 80s talk about his mother's faith; he would get emotional, even though he didn't like to show emotion and said he didn't want to cry in the pulpit. When he talked about his mom, he couldn't stop because of the impact she had on him. This shows how deeply her faith affected him, making him emotional in a way that was unusual for him.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob shares this to emphasize that honoring parents through memories of their positive qualities, like faith, has no expiration date.

illustrations.title: Aretha Franklin's Respect Song
illustrations.text: I think we need to remember the tune from 1967 by Aretha Franklin, R-E-S-P-E-C-T, and find out what it means to me. How can you show respect for your mother and father, whether they're alive or have passed on? This song reminds us that respect involves understanding and valuing others, especially in family relationships.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to challenge listeners to actively show respect to their parents regardless of their flaws or circumstances.

illustrations.title: China's Law on Visits
illustrations.text: Do you know in China not long ago they passed a law that requires adult children to visit their elderly parents often or risk being sued by them. Now, I'm not recommending we have a law like that. You say, man, who legislates respect for parents? That would be God.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that while human laws try to enforce respect for parents, it's God who truly establishes it through the fifth commandment for our blessing.

illustrations.title: Cloud of Witnesses Analogy
illustrations.text: The Bible says those who have passed away in faith, from the book of Hebrews, are like a giant auditorium or arena filled with people of faith who have lived and died and are now cheering us on. We are surrounded by so great a cloud of witnesses who are telling us to live with endurance and live out our faith. Those who have died in faith are in that auditorium, so it's possible your parents can see you.
illustrations.context: This analogy emphasizes that honoring parents can bring blessings, as those who have passed on in faith might be watching and encouraging us.

illustrations.title: Silver Packages Song Quote
illustrations.text: There's an old song by Children of the Day that I remind myself of when I read passages like this, called 'Silver Packages.' It says the silver packages are all tied with string, waiting in heaven all ready to send. There's only one thing holding them up: there's no address label to put on the top. When God makes promises, He's waiting for you to take advantage of them. God is saying I want it to go well with you and for you to be long and strong in faith on this earth, but it's tied to your decision to honor your parents.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to show that God's blessings are ready but require action, like honoring parents, to be received.

illustrations.title: Michigan Rock Discovery Example
illustrations.text: True story: just two years ago, a man in Michigan took a big rock he'd used as a door stop for 30 years. He got it when he bought the farm and never thought much of it until one day he decided to have it checked by a geology professor, wondering if it was a meteorite. It turned out to be the first meteorite that professor had ever seen, weighing 22.5 pounds and worth a hundred thousand dollars. All that value had been sitting there unused for years. Could it be that God's blessings in your life have been sitting there all along, neglected until you honor your parents?
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates that valuable blessings, like those from honoring parents, might be overlooked and unused in life.

illustrations.title: Pastor's Parents Reflection
illustrations.text: For me, it took starting to see my mom and dad in a different light. I began thinking about the positive impacts they had on my life instead of focusing on what I didn't like or understand. For example, my mom would get up before anyone else, make coffee for my dad, read her Bible, and pray—I never once got up before her without her already praying. She reflected Jesus to me before I ever met Him. This shift helped me appreciate the true influence of honoring parents.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob shares his personal experience to emphasize that honoring parents involves focusing on their positive legacy to unlock God's blessings.

illustrations.title: Childhood Church Reluctance
illustrations.text: My mom and dad made me go to church, and I hated it. I didn't feel close to God; it was just religion. But by the time I received Christ, my theology was completely orthodox because every week I recited the Apostles' Creed and the Nicene Creed, so I knew it inside out. That right theology allowed me to receive Christ easily, even though I didn't appreciate it at the time.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate how parental insistence on church attendance shaped his faith positively, despite his initial resistance.

illustrations.title: Letter of Gratitude to Mom
illustrations.text: In 1998, ten years before my mother died, I wrote her a letter and read it to her. Some of you have heard me share it before, but it was my way of thanking her for things I hadn't appreciated earlier. I presented it to her as an expression of honor, reminding others not to miss opportunities to honor their parents while they can.
illustrations.context: This story emphasizes the importance of expressing appreciation to parents before it's too late.

illustrations.title: Mother's Daily Sacrifices
illustrations.text: I thanked my mom not just for birthing me, but for carrying me physically as the youngest of five while managing other little kids. I didn't appreciate it until I had my own children and grandchildren, realizing the effort involved in carrying them around and changing their diapers. It's a simple way to honor the precious things parents do that we often overlook.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates how everyday parental efforts deserve recognition and honor, drawing from his personal experience.

illustrations.title: Remembering Dad's Private Faith
illustrations.text: It impacted me, and I still remember it at this moment because there was something about my dad's faith. Though it was very private, it was very real. I need to tell you that, and I need to tell my children and grandchildren because it's true and right, and God commands it so He can bless me.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating the importance of honoring and sharing about parents' faith to obey God and receive His blessing.

illustrations.title: Childhood TV Show Anticipation
illustrations.text: When I was a kid, I used to watch a cartoon show on Saturday hosted by Hobo Kelly. She would wear big sunglasses and call out names, saying things like, 'Johnny, it's your birthday today, go check under your parents' bed for a present.' I couldn't wait for my birthday and when she finally said, 'Bobby, happy birthday, go to the laundry room for your gift,' I ran to check excitedly. It turned out that thousands of Bobbies across the US probably did the same, but I didn't find anything, and it failed my expectations.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to express his appreciation for online viewers and his desire to personally connect with them, mirroring his childhood excitement of being noticed.

illustrations.title: God Breathes Life into Man
illustrations.text: I think about what the scripture says concerning when God made man. The Bible says in the Book of Genesis, God formed man out of the dust of the earth and then breathed into his nostrils the breath of life, and he became a living soul. He was inanimate, and God breathed life into him. It's like mouth-to-mouth resuscitation, where God animated what was lifeless. Before God's breath, man was physically formed but dead, with no life. This is an interesting picture that God in a breath brings the inanimate to life.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this retelling to illustrate that Scripture is God-breathed and alive, just as God brought life to man.

illustrations.title: Israel's Departure from Sinai
illustrations.text: The nation of Israel has been camped out at Mount Sinai for a year. They've received the Ten Commandments, the law, built the Tabernacle, and started doing sacrifices. Now they've come to the point where they start to move, heading out from that time with the Lord at Mount Sinai after a year to get on the march to the promised land. In verse 11, it was the second year, and the cloud lifted over the Tabernacle of the testimony, signaling the time to go. This cloud represented the Shekinah presence of God, a visible manifestation guiding them forward.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that there is a time to move out and on in one's spiritual journey, just as Israel did after their time at Sinai.

illustrations.title: Israelites at Mount Sinai
illustrations.text: They've been at Mount Sinai for a year, discovering God's presence and collecting manna every day as a sign of his provision. They've enjoyed his blessings, but Sinai was not their inheritance—Canaan was. Now it's time to move on, even though it's comfortable, because staying leads to settling rather than progressing.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that believers must embrace change and not settle in comfortable seasons, as God calls them to new journeys.

illustrations.title: Preference for Familiar Habits
illustrations.text: People often prefer what's comfortable and familiar, like sitting in the same seat at church or parking in the same spot. For example, many admit to eating at restaurants they've visited before or even at home. This tendency shows how humans naturally resist change, which can lead to complacency.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to point out that seeking comfort can hinder spiritual growth and lead to stagnation.

illustrations.title: Pastor's Reluctance to Move
illustrations.text: I once lived somewhere for a relatively short time and became very comfortable there, but I had to move and I resisted it, even crying about it. This happened because from my mother's womb, that was my first place of familiarity. It's embarrassing to admit, but it shows how deeply we cling to what's known.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob shares this to emphasize that everyone resists change due to comfort, and it's important to overcome this for spiritual progress.

illustrations.title: Israelites as Spiritual Soldiers
illustrations.text: This chapter over and over again describes the nation of Israel. Not long ago, a little over a year ago, they were slaves, and then as of Passover, they became saved and were released from slavery. So they were slaves, then they were saved, and now the saved are becoming soldiers; this chapter describes them all as an army, suddenly going from sojourners to soldier sojourners.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this retelling to illustrate that believers, like the Israelites, must transition from being saved to becoming spiritual soldiers on their journey of faith.

illustrations.title: Promised Land as Christian Life
illustrations.text: The journey to the promised land is not what a lot of people think it is; typically, people see it as heaven, like in the spirituals, but actually, the victorious Christian life is the promised land. When they get to Canaan, there are still enemies that have to be fought, unlike heaven where there are none. It's about entering into the full promises of God, experiencing the fruitfulness of the Christian life while facing tests and hardships on the way.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to show that the Christian life involves ongoing challenges and battles, even after salvation, as believers strive to inherit God's promises.

illustrations.title: Jesus on Worldly Tribulation
illustrations.text: Jesus said in the world you will have tribulation, and I wish he said celebration, but you might have some of that too. This highlights that as believers, we must accept hardships and attacks on the way to the promised land.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob connects this quote to emphasize that hardships are inevitable in the Christian journey, urging acceptance as part of spiritual growth.

illustrations.title: Hands as Pressure Analogy
illustrations.text: Put your hands together; it's the space in between your hands, being pressed on both sides, stressed and under pressure. That's what the word for tribulation means. In the world, you're going to have this pressure in your life and you can't avoid it.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating the meaning of tribulation to emphasize that pressure and stress are inevitable in a fallen world.

illustrations.title: Christian Life as War
illustrations.text: Paul uses this analogy that the Christian life is a war. He said to suffer hardship as a good soldier of Christ Jesus. No soldier in active service entangles himself in the affairs of everyday life, so that he may please the one who enlisted him.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is using this analogy to show that Christians must endure hardship and avoid distractions to stay focused on their spiritual battle.

illustrations.title: Shield of Faith Analogy
illustrations.text: Take up the shield of faith; I try to remember every day to go over each piece of armor, which talks about the character of Christ. Whenever I talk to the Lord about taking up the shield of faith, I remind myself that a soldier picks up a shield because they're expecting incoming attacks. It's not the Frisbee of faith; we should live expecting to be attacked and be ready for it.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating the shield of faith to emphasize that Christians should anticipate spiritual attacks and prepare accordingly.

illustrations.title: Soldier in Battle Analogy
illustrations.text: Peter says don't be surprised by this testing that comes among you as though something strange were happening. It's like a soldier in battle—they're shooting at us, and it's not surprising because that's what you signed up for. We should expect these trials as part of the Christian journey.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is using this analogy to convey that Christians should not be shocked by trials, as they are inherent to following Christ.

illustrations.title: Spurgeon's Sword and Trowel
illustrations.text: It was Spurgeon who had a publication with various thoughts from the word of God, and it was called The Sword and the Trowel. This title symbolizes the balance of fighting spiritual battles and building up faith. Pastor Bob connects it to the idea that as Christians, we're in a fight with hard times ahead while pursuing our inheritance.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is using this historical reference to illustrate that Christians face ongoing spiritual battles while advancing toward their promised inheritance.

illustrations.title: Nehemiah's Sword and Trowel
illustrations.text: When Nehemiah was rebuilding the destroyed walls of Jerusalem, he called the nation to help family by family, with each group working on a portion of the wall. They built with a trowel in one hand while carrying a sword in the other because of their enemies. This setup illustrates that believers must balance building their faith and engaging in spiritual warfare.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that believers, like Nehemiah's people, must build spiritually while fighting against enemies.

illustrations.title: Spiritual War Casualties
illustrations.text: As believers, we face victories and defeats in our lives, along with casualties who are not walking with the Lord. For example, a believer might be a casualty, having denied the Lord entirely, or someone might be M.I.A., missing and not connected to God anymore. Others could be like POWs, imprisoned by their sin or deception, emphasizing that this is a real war we must fight for one another.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to illustrate that spiritual life involves real battles with potential losses among believers.

illustrations.title: Genesis Judah Prophecy
illustrations.text: In Genesis 49:10-11, Jacob prophesied over his sons, saying the scepter shall not depart from Judah, nor the ruler's staff from between his feet until Shiloh comes, and to him shall be the obedience of the peoples. He also described tying a foal to the vine and washing garments in wine, which points to future events like the Messiah's coming. Pastor Bob connects this to Judah leading the tribes, explaining its significance in God's plan and how it relates to biblical leadership and prophecy.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to explain why Judah is chosen to lead, highlighting God's prophetic intention for the tribe.

illustrations.title: Leah's Praise for Judah
illustrations.text: Remember when Mom gave birth to Judah she said this time I'm just going to praise the Lord. Before that, she was hoping each one of her sons would get her husband's attention and affection, and finally she said, you know this time that didn't work, those other times I'm just going to praise the Lord. And then she stopped bearing; it was kind of like she finally realized I need the right motives in my heart, I'm just going to praise God for this child. It's a beautiful story.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how praise leads us as God's people and emphasizes the importance of having the right motives in our hearts.

illustrations.title: Yom Kippur Atonement Ceremony
illustrations.text: On Yom Kippur, the Day of Atonement, the blood of the goat that had the sins of the nation confessed on it was shed. The high priest, after performing rituals for his own forgiveness, entered the Holy of Holies representing the nation. He sprinkled the blood on the Mercy Seat on top of the Ark of the Covenant, which averted God's wrath and forgave the sins of the nation. This pictures how Jesus, as our high priest, covers our sins with His blood.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating how the Yom Kippur ritual symbolizes Christ's role in atoning for sins and providing mercy.

illustrations.title: Boy's Heart Transplant Story
illustrations.text: I heard a true story of a little boy who had a heart transplant. He came from a Christian family, and after the procedure, he asked his mom if he needed to ask Jesus to come into this new heart. That's a cute story that highlights a deeper truth.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to emphasize that one must personally receive Christ into their heart, not just intellectually agree with doctrine.

illustrations.title: Soldiers' Duty Analogy
illustrations.text: Modern soldiers often say they have a job to do, knowing their specific role in a larger mission without worrying about the big picture. Just like the Israelites marching to Canaan, where each tribe had an assigned place and it wasn't optional, soldiers focus on their part in invading enemy territory. This illustrates how everyone in God's army has a designated responsibility.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to show that, like soldiers, individuals in God's plan must fulfill their assigned roles without choosing based on personal preference.

illustrations.title: Marching in Gods Army
illustrations.text: Picture yourself marching in an army, where some people are ahead of you and some are behind you. You've been placed where God wants you, and those ahead have been where you're going, so they can guide you through your troubles. There are also people behind you who will need to learn from your experiences, so you have a role to play right where you are.
illustrations.context: Everyone has a specific role in God's family, with others to learn from and to teach.

illustrations.title: Imitate Pauls Following
illustrations.text: Paul said, 'Imitate me as I follow the Lord.' I used to think that was bold, like he was perfect, but it's not what he meant; it's about following Jesus to whatever degree we can. So, if I imitate Jesus even a little, you can imitate me in that way, because we're all called to follow Him first.
illustrations.context: Good leadership requires being a good follower of Jesus.

illustrations.title: Follow Jesus Fishers of Men
illustrations.text: Jesus said, 'Follow me and I'll make you Fishers of Men.' If you're good at fishing for fish, imagine being transformed to fish for people, which is what Jesus does for us. It's about committing to follow Him so He can make us more like Him for His purposes.
illustrations.context: Following Jesus leads to personal transformation and purposeful living.

illustrations.title: Police Support Services Story
illustrations.text: When I was a police officer, I worked on the streets in patrol until I became a detective. Most cops start there, but there was a whole division called Support Services in the police departments I worked for. These weren't officers on the street; they handled things inside, like working evidence, hiring new people, doing record checks, and managing the radio. We couldn't do our job without them; there's no way.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that support roles in the body of Christ are essential, just as support services are crucial for police work.

illustrations.title: Spurgeon on Guidance
illustrations.text: Spurgeon said that while we don't lean on our own understanding, we don't ignore it either. He explained that we should always seek the Lord's guidance through Providence, yet we can find direction through our own common sense and discretion, which God has given us. God will guide us supernaturally, and sometimes He will guide us naturally.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that believers should use their God-given common sense alongside seeking divine guidance without ignoring personal discernment.

illustrations.title: John Corson on Evangelism
illustrations.text: John Corson said that to those who say they're not interested in church and don't care much about heaven, we need to follow the example of Moses and say we need you, such as pointing out how they can help with a softball team or their skills like painting a mural. Such is the course Moses took, and Hobab responded by choosing to travel to the promised land when told he was valuable and could enrich them. Thus, we should make unbelievers feel needed to draw them in, as seen in the Book of Judges.
illustrations.context: This shows how to engage unbelievers by highlighting their value and contributions to the community, following biblical examples.

illustrations.title: Jesus Needing Others
illustrations.text: Jesus needed the woman at the well to give him water to drink, and He needed the owner of the colt in Jerusalem to release it to Him. This demonstrates how Jesus made people feel essential in His ministry. By doing so, it illustrates a way to approach unbelievers by showing they are needed.
illustrations.context: This retelling emphasizes that Jesus modeled making people feel valued to build relationships and share the gospel.

illustrations.title: C.S. Lewis on Eternity
illustrations.text: C.S. Lewis was right when he said, 'If Heaven and Hell are true, nothing else matters. If Heaven and Hell aren't true, then nothing matters at all.' He uses this quote to emphasize the high stakes of evangelism, urging us not to give up on inviting people to faith because eternal consequences are real.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is stressing the urgency of sharing the gospel and not giving up on loved ones, as heaven and hell make everything else insignificant.

illustrations.title: Jethro and Beverly Hillbillies
illustrations.text: Jethro is a hard name for those of us who have lived since the 60s because we picture a guy from The Beverly Hillbillies, who graduated the sixth grade and is living in Beverly Hills. This cultural reference shows how modern perceptions can twist our understanding of biblical figures. It's a light-hearted way to explain that Jethro was actually a title meaning 'esteemed one,' referring to Moses's father-in-law as a priest of Midian.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating how cultural associations can mislead our view of biblical names, emphasizing that Jethro represents an honored role.

illustrations.title: Moses and Jethro's Bond
illustrations.text: Ruel is one of Jethro's names, which means cherished, and I suggest that Moses really liked his father-in-law because he was both his boss and family. Moses had been watching Jethro's sheep for 40 years, showing respect and likely affection despite the long service. He had already listened to Jethro's counsel on appointing leaders, proving their close relationship, and Moses wanted him to be saved.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate the importance of valuing and evangelizing those closest to us, like family or mentors.

illustrations.title: Andrew Brings Peter to Jesus
illustrations.text: Andrew meets Jesus and becomes the first to lead someone to the Lord—his brother Peter, who was originally named Simon. Andrew didn't go to strangers; he simply told his brother, 'You have to meet him.' Similarly, Philip brought Nathaniel, showing how friendships and family ties make sharing faith natural.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob emphasizes that new believers should start sharing their faith with those they know and love, like family or close friends.

illustrations.title: Pastor's Early Evangelism Zeal
illustrations.text: After I got saved, I was concerned for my family because they weren't saved, and as a new believer, I had a lot of zeal to share the Lord but also immaturity that led to judgment. I didn't know much about witnessing, so I made mistakes like telling people they were going to hell as a lead-in. This experience shows that while enthusiasm is good, new Christians need to approach evangelism with wisdom to avoid pushing people away.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob highlights that new believers often feel compelled to share with family but must balance zeal with maturity to be effective.

illustrations.title: Prayer Changes Family Dynamics
illustrations.text: This is a true story; about six months after I started praying for my family in a new way, God changed my relationship with them through prayer. I began praying for them by name every day while living at home, and as I did, God softened my heart, making me less judgmental and more loving. Out of the blue, my mom and dad asked me to lead a family Bible study, which included my grandma and grandpa who had never attended church. They even invited my sister, brother-in-law, and niece, turning it into a full gathering. We studied the book of Matthew together, and it was a miraculous experience that brought us closer.
illustrations.context: Persistent prayer can transform personal attitudes and lead to unexpected spiritual breakthroughs in family relationships.

illustrations.title: Grandfather's Deathbed Conversion
illustrations.text: My grandfather, for a year, I kept hoping he might come to faith, but I wasn't sure. A few years later, I got a call that he was dying, so I went to say goodbye. He was in a lot of pain and couldn't open his eyes, but he could hear me. I asked if he was ready to die, and he shook his head no. I reminded him of the Bible study we did and asked if he wanted to pray to receive Christ right then, and he said yes. We prayed together, and those were my last words with him before he passed.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the importance of persistent invitation and sharing faith, even when it seems unlikely, leading to someone's salvation.

illustrations.title: Brother-in-Law's Phone Prayer
illustrations.text: About a year later, I got a call from my brother-in-law, who was Catholic and had been coming to the Bible study. He wasn't very interested in what I was saying at first, but then he called and said he remembered how we'd have people pray to receive Christ. He wanted to do it right then over the phone. I agreed, and we prayed together for him to receive Christ. Now, he's in heaven with the others from that study.
illustrations.context: This shows that God can use ongoing exposure to the gospel to bring about sudden decisions for faith.

illustrations.title: Dishes on Thanksgiving Reluctance
illustrations.text: Sometimes I can be very lazy and don't feel like doing anything, but once I get going, I don't want to stop. For example, I only do dishes once a year on Thanksgiving—that's my day. I start doing the dishes, and then someone says, 'Okay, stop and come be with us or play,' but I don't want to because I really want to finish. I thought I hated it, but now I actually kind of enjoy it and certainly don't want to stop in the middle.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to illustrate how people can be reluctant to stop activities even when rest is needed, paralleling it to following God's timing for rest in the Christian life.

illustrations.title: Undercover Police Experiences
illustrations.text: When I was a police officer, if somebody was undercover, that meant they were in disguise. We had cops that looked like bikers, smelled like bikers, and fit right into the biker community. We had cops that looked like high school sophomores, going on campus to sell drugs or catch people who did. We had gang member cops and druggies that looked the part, all to fit in and infiltrate. This illustrates how people disguise themselves for a purpose, but many Christians do it just to blend in without real intent.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to contrast worldly undercover work with Christians who try to fit in without spiritual purpose, emphasizing God's true covering.

illustrations.title: Lunch with Church Brother
illustrations.text: I used to go out to lunch once a week with a brother from church. He was older than me, a successful businessman and usher who loved the Lord deeply. Our church had about 150 people, and he always wanted to bless me, so he'd say, 'Can I take you to lunch?' We'd go to places like Fiddler's Three, and he had one of the first mobile phones, making reservations on the drive, which impressed me. The first time he paid, it was nice, but the second time I felt guilty and offered to pay, yet he'd grab the check and say, 'No, it's covered.' No matter what I suggested, like paying the tip, he'd insist it was completely covered, and that became his expression for it.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate that just as his friend covered the lunch expenses, God fully covers believers' sins, journeys, and challenges.

illustrations.title: Headstones False Advertising
illustrations.text: I believe the greatest form of false advertising this world has ever known is on headstones. One of the most common things to put on a headstone are three letters, RIP, which stands for Rest in Peace, as if it doesn't matter what they believed about God or Jesus. That is not what my Bible teaches at all. Putting rest and peace on someone's headstone does not make them rest in peace; the rest is in Christ for those who believe.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that true eternal rest comes only through faith in Christ, not through cultural traditions like inscriptions on headstones.

illustrations.title: Scott's Early Ministry Dedication
illustrations.text: Sometimes I'm akin to this man right here, Scott Cunningham, who some of you know has been the worship leader and assistant pastor at Calvary Chapel Costa Mesa for 22 years. He started when he was just 11 years old, which is incredible as the youngest person ever hired there. This example shows the depth of commitment in ministry.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses Scott's story to illustrate the concept of kindred spirits and lasting connections within the church community.

illustrations.title: Childhood in Worship Ministry
illustrations.text: I grew up at Calvary Chapel Costa Mesa where my mom worked and we attended as kids. You might remember Salty the singing songbook, which was a big part of my childhood. My mom was a worship leader who got us singing and teaching the Bible young, and looking back, I see God's faithfulness and grace in my life through that experience.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how early exposure to worship and Scripture shapes a lifelong commitment to serving God.

illustrations.title: Steadfast Love from Psalms
illustrations.text: There's this old song called Steadfast Love, with lyrics from the Word of God: the steadfast love of the Lord never ceases, his mercies never come to an end, they're new every morning. As a worship leader, I'm always drawn to the Psalms, which provide language for lament and praise, helping me connect with what the authors felt and express my own experiences to God. This word 'loving kindness' appears throughout the Psalms and resonates deeply in times of reflection.
illustrations.context: This quote highlights the enduring nature of God's love and mercy, encouraging reliance on Scripture for personal expression.

illustrations.title: Timeless Psalm of Steadfast Love
illustrations.text: David would say your steadfast love oh Lord extends to the heavens, your faithfulness to the clouds, your righteousness is like the mountains of God. How precious is your steadfast love oh God, children of mankind take refuge in the shadow of your ways, o continue your steadfast love to those who know you. David thousands of years ago would say what we say today, Lord your steadfast love is unbelievable, it's amazing, and so we get to join with the Saints of old singing something that's so true about the Lord.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses the Psalm quote to illustrate the enduring and awe-inspiring nature of God's steadfast love, showing how it connects ancient expressions of faith to modern experiences.

illustrations.title: Song Written at Conference
illustrations.text: I wrote this song about 15 years ago at a conference. It was inspired by a pastor teaching on living for the glory of God. This experience shaped the song as a reflection of that lesson.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to show how he was inspired to create a song about dedicating life to God's glory.

illustrations.title: Glorifying as Full Display
illustrations.text: When you think about what it means to glorify something, it means to put something on full display. For example, we want to glorify God by highlighting His attributes and beauty in our lives. This comparison shows how our actions can showcase God's qualities to others.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to explain that living for God's glory involves openly displaying His character through our daily lives.

illustrations.title: Pastor's Life Transition Story
illustrations.text: I just learned this song recently when I attended a worship service at another church a few months back. It was called 'Comfort' and it really ministered to me in my current season of life. I've been on staff at Harvest Temple Coast for about 22 years and just transitioned off in February. My wife and I are praying for what's next and dealing with anxieties about the future, like how it will all work out.
