I have five daughters, so I'm thinking about five weddings and five son-in-laws; I've got one son-in-law already, and he's great, imagining the rest will be too. As we get older, these worries grow bigger, from vocational concerns to bigger life questions. We have to learn to truly trust the Lord with all our heart and not lean on our own understanding.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates the importance of trusting God amidst personal anxieties about the future.

illustrations.title: God's Creation Rest Example
illustrations.text: God created the world in six days and then God rested. Why did God rest on the seventh day? He did not rest because he was tired, since God neither sleeps nor slumbers. God rested as an example to us, showing that we should enter into Sabbath rest, even though we humans get tired and need renewal.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this retelling to illustrate that God's rest was not from fatigue but as a model for humanity to trust and rest in Him.

illustrations.title: Isaiah on God's Strength
illustrations.text: This is Isaiah 40: even young men get tired and grow weary, but the Lord does not. We all get tired as human beings, but God doesn't tire and will renew your strength. God didn't rest because He needed to; He did it as an example for us to follow.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that God's rest is about providing an example, highlighting His unending strength compared to human weakness.

illustrations.title: Police Academy Burdens
illustrations.text: When I started out as a police officer, one of the things you do in the police academy is study and memorize the penal code and the vehicle code. You need to know all the elements of the crimes so you can apply them out in the field. Well, you learn these different codes, but sometimes you're not exactly sure how they apply because there are so many of them and lots of ways to break the law, and one of those is in the traffic code about unsafe loads.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate that people are carrying more burdens than God intends, similar to an unsafe load.

illustrations.title: Unsafe Load Story
illustrations.text: I was working with a traffic officer who was my training officer when I started out, and I asked him how to know when a load is unsafe. He explained it with an example of a commercial truck where something fell out, saying that if something falls out, it's unsafe. I thought it was a perfect example for how some of us carry unsafe loads in our lives, with things falling apart, and that's why the Bible tells us to cast our cares on Him because He cares for us.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that carrying worries and burdens alone is like having an unsafe load, and we should trust God instead.

illustrations.title: Romaine's Worry Quote
illustrations.text: As the assistant pastor under Pastor Chuck, Romaine was a drill instructor who ran the staff and was effective in his ministry. Whenever he saw someone on staff who was upset, worried, or frustrated, he would yell out of his door, 'If you're worrying, you're not trusting.' This quote reminds us that worrying means we're not truly trusting the Lord and trying to carry more than He intended.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that worrying is a sign of not trusting God fully.

illustrations.title: Israel's Captivity Reference
illustrations.text: God's people Israel rejected His Sabbath rest by not observing the sabbatical years for 490 years, leading to the southern Kingdom of Judah going into Babylonian captivity for 70 years. This happened because they owed God 70 Sabbath years for the land, as detailed in Second Chronicles 36:21, which says the land enjoyed its Sabbaths during its desolation. It illustrates how God ensures rest is honored even through consequences of disobedience.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate the consequences of not trusting God and obeying His commands for rest.

illustrations.title: Jesus Announces Favorable Year
illustrations.text: When Jesus went into that synagogue, the Book of the Prophet Isaiah was handed to him. He opened the book and found the place where it was written in Isaiah 61: 'The Spirit of the Lord is upon me, because he has anointed me to preach the good news to the poor. He has sent me to proclaim release to the captives and recovery of sight to the blind, to set free those who are downtrodden, and to proclaim the favorable year of the Lord.' Isaiah was referring to the Messiah bringing spiritual restoration, not just the physical Jubilee, giving a picture of rest and freedom that happens when Christ rules and reigns on earth.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that Jesus fulfills the spiritual essence of the Jubilee, bringing rest and restoration.

illustrations.title: Abraham and the Ram's Sacrifice
illustrations.text: If you go back to the Book of Genesis, you find a ram and its horns in a very important moment. Abraham was told to sacrifice his own son Isaac, and he was willing to do so. Isaac even asked about the sacrifice, and Abraham said God would provide it. As Abraham raised the knife, an angel stopped him, and he saw a ram caught in a thicket by its horns. Abraham took the ram and offered it as a burnt offering in place of his son. This ram is a type of Christ, symbolizing God providing the sacrifice. The horn represents the animal's strength, and it's interesting that the ram was caught in a thornbush.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate that the shofar, made from a ram's horn, symbolizes repentance and God's provision of a substitute sacrifice like Christ.

illustrations.title: Burning Bush Typology
illustrations.text: Remember when God revealed himself to Moses in Exodus 3 through a burning bush. We talked about this before; the thorn bush typifies Israel, which is not a fruitful plant and worthy to be burned, but Israel was in bondage in Egypt with nothing to commend itself except God's promises to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob. Though in persecution and fire, Israel was not consumed, showing it's a miracle that Moses witnessed, testifying that God protected his people amid the fire.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how God protects and preserves His people, like Israel in the burning bush, even in the midst of persecution.

illustrations.title: Jesus' Apparent Weakness
illustrations.text: Remember when Jesus was about to be arrested and Peter took out his sword to help, but Jesus said he didn't need it because he could call angels to wipe them out and just saying 'I am' made them fall back. Or when he was on the cross and people mocked him, saying if he saved others, he should save himself. Jesus appeared weak and couldn't free himself, but the Bible says he was crucified because of weakness, not real weakness— he could have freed himself but chose not to, showing his commitment.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that Christ, like the ram entangled in the thorn bush, appeared weak and trapped but was actually strong and dedicated to saving his people.

illustrations.title: Unforgiving Servant Parable
illustrations.text: Jesus told the story of a man who was forgiven by his master a huge amount of debt that he could never pay back. But then, that same man was unwilling to forgive a petty debt that his brother owed him. When the master heard about it, he became angry and had the man arrested, thrown in jail, and ordered to pay back everything he originally owed. This suggests that true forgiveness from God changes how we treat others.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that if someone is unwilling to forgive others, they may not have truly experienced God's forgiveness.

illustrations.title: Mercy Reservoir Analogy
illustrations.text: God pours so much mercy into your life for all the sins you've ever committed, like a massive reservoir. Then he asks you to give a cup of forgiveness to somebody. If you say you don't have any or don't want to, it means you obviously didn't receive it, because you don't have it to give.
illustrations.context: This analogy illustrates that receiving God's forgiveness should naturally lead to forgiving others, as evidence of having truly received it.

illustrations.title: Withered Hand Healing
illustrations.text: When a man has a withered arm and hasn't been able to use it, he can't stretch it out on his own. But when the Lord God of the universe stands before him and says stretch forth your hand, He enables that which He commands. This shows that God provides the ability for what He asks, just as He enables us to forgive.
illustrations.context: This retelling emphasizes that God gives the power to forgive when He commands it, requiring our participation and faith.

illustrations.title: Prodigal Son and Grace Quote
illustrations.text: Robert Farrar wrote a book called 'Between Noon and Three' about the cross, and he discussed the prodigal son's story. He pointed out that we're worried about permissiveness in preaching grace, as if it allows terrible things as long as forgiveness follows. But Jesus wasn't afraid, giving the prodigal son a kiss instead of a lecture and a party instead of probation. In the story, the elder brother raises objections, complaining that the father is lowering standards, and the father responds that it's about resurrection, not bookkeeping.
illustrations.context: This quote illustrates that God's grace emphasizes restoration and resurrection over judgment or moral accounting.

illustrations.title: Restored Classic Car Example
illustrations.text: I have a friend from our church who had us over for dinner the other night and took us out to the garage. He has a 1957 Chevy that looks even better than it did back in 1957—it's pristine and beautifully restored. I hope he never takes it out because one little mishap could ruin it, but it's amazing work to behold. The psalmist says of the Lord, 'He restores my soul,' just like Jesus restores us. This illustrates how God brings renewal to damaged lives.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to show how God restores souls, similar to restoring a vintage car.

illustrations.title: Locusts Plague in Joel
illustrations.text: God says in the Book of Joel, 'I will restore to you the years that the locusts have eaten.' We often quote this verse, but it's based on a real event: wave after wave of actual locust calamities that stripped the entire nation of its agriculture, leaving them with nothing. God sent these locusts as a judgment on their sin. This historical event shows that what seems like a metaphor was a tangible punishment, emphasizing God's promise of restoration after loss.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to explain how God judges sin through real events and promises to restore what was lost.

illustrations.title: Son's Humpty Dumpty Misunderstanding
illustrations.text: I think I shared this before, but when my son was little, he heard the nursery rhyme Humpty Dumpty and misunderstood it. He thought the words were 'Humpty Dumpty was sad on the wall' and asked me why Humpty was sad. Well, if you think about it, mankind is like the original Humpty Dumpty who had a great fall in Genesis 3, and everything broke from then on. The rhyme says all the king's horses and all the king's men couldn't put Humpty together again, but God, the King of Kings, can restore us and put us back together. That's what Jesus does through His word and His people.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to illustrate how God can restore what sin has broken, unlike human efforts that fail.

illustrations.title: Retirement as Jubilee Analogy
illustrations.text: It's kind of like retirement. You work your whole life and hopefully there's something you can live on. You just gotta die soon, as the guy said, the trick in life is to have your money and your life end about the same time. If I could arrange to die next Tuesday after lunch, I'd be good.
illustrations.context: This analogy shows that provision during Jubilee comes from past work, similar to how retirement provides from lifelong efforts.

illustrations.title: Baxter on Free Grace
illustrations.text: I like what Richard Baxter wrote in the free gift: As we paid nothing for God's eternal love and nothing for the Son of his love and nothing for his Spirit and our grace and our faith and nothing for our eternal rest, what an astonishing thought it will be to think of the unmeasurable difference between our deservings and our receivings. Oh how free was all this love and how free is this enjoyed glory. So then let 'deserved' be written on the floor of hell but 'grace' on the doors of heaven. And I just say Amen to that.
illustrations.context: This quote emphasizes that eternal rewards come from grace, not our own deservings, tying into the idea of provision from past faithfulness.

illustrations.title: Jubilee House Value Analogy
illustrations.text: For instance, if you buy a house on day one after the Jubilee, you get 49 years to enjoy it, so it's full value. But if you're buying a house a year before Jubilee and you'll only have it for a year because it's going back, you pay a lot less—it's worth a lot less. Why? Because Jubilee is almost here. What's the picture? It's this: the closer we get to the coming of the kingdom of God, the more we realize He's coming, and things of this earth get less and less valuable because the Jubilee is coming.
illustrations.context: This analogy shows that earthly possessions lose value as God's kingdom approaches, just as property diminishes in worth before the Year of Jubilee.

illustrations.title: Monopoly Money Analogy
illustrations.text: Our culture makes money supremely important, yet in the end, you can't take it with you—it's just like Monopoly money when you're dead and can't spend it. It doesn't work; it's worthless where you're going. Whether in heaven or elsewhere, money has no value beyond this life.
illustrations.context: This analogy illustrates that worldly wealth is ultimately insignificant and unusable after death, emphasizing the futility of prioritizing it.

illustrations.title: Solomon's Wealth Reference
illustrations.text: Do you remember when Solomon, the wisest and wealthiest king who ever lived, made silver as common as stones in Jerusalem? You know how common stones are in Jerusalem—if you come with us, you'll see it's wow-worthy. What does that do? When you have a huge supply of anything, it makes it less valuable.
illustrations.context: This reference shows that abundance, like Solomon's wealth, diminishes the perceived value of material things, teaching us not to overvalue earthly riches.

illustrations.title: Joseph's Famine Preparation
illustrations.text: Think of Joseph and Pharaoh. Joseph tells Pharaoh what his dreams meant, predicting seven years of plenty followed by seven years of famine. Because they believed and saved up during the abundant years, they had enough to survive the need. In the same way, God is saying that He has the ability to provide for you in advance where He guides, just as He did through Joseph for the Egyptians.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that God provides abundantly in advance when people obey and trust Him, ensuring provision during times of need.

illustrations.title: Money Devoured by Costs
illustrations.text: Somebody might say, 'Yeah, I get a raise, but it's just eaten up by costs. You know, coffee costs more, and everything is so expensive it's ridiculous. Then other expenses like car repairs or dentist visits come up and take it all away.'
illustrations.context: This illustrates how failing to trust God with finances leads to money being consumed by everyday expenses.

illustrations.title: Money Makes Wings
illustrations.text: The Bible says in Proverbs that if your riches increase, don't set your eyes on them, for surely your money will make itself wings and fly away. We all know that happens—you get more money, and suddenly your car breaks down or you need a dentist, and it's gone. Instead of planning for luxuries like a trip to Hawaii, you're fixing what's broken, showing how God provides but we often miss it.
illustrations.context: This quote emphasizes that wealth is fleeting and encourages trusting God rather than relying on money.

illustrations.title: Money Says Goodbye
illustrations.text: Like the guy said, money talks, I can't deny I heard it once, and it said goodbye. This shows how quickly money disappears despite our plans.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the transient nature of money, reinforcing the need to trust God with finances.

illustrations.title: Israel Ignores Jubilee
illustrations.text: The tragedy is that God sent His people into Babylon for 70 years because they never celebrated the Jubilee or even the Sabbath year. There's no record in the Bible or history of Israel ever obeying the Jubilee, showing a pattern of disobedience. This serves as a warning about the consequences of ignoring God's commands.
illustrations.context: This highlights the dangers of persistent disobedience to God, paralleling it with issues like tithing.

illustrations.title: Frozen Lake Story
illustrations.text: Remember the story of the guy on the frozen lake. He has a horse and is worried about falling in, so he's inching his way across because he thinks he's going to die. He's about halfway and thinks he might not make it. Then, a big stagecoach with six horses comes over the bluff and crosses the whole lake easily. Despite seeing that, he continues inching across the lake.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how some people live in fear and fail to embrace God's peace, even when evidence shows it's possible.

illustrations.title: Difference Between Exhaustion and Being Spent
illustrations.text: I want to challenge you not to be exhausted but to be spent. There's a difference between being exhausted and being spent. In 2 Corinthians 12:15, it says, 'I will gladly spend and be spent for you, though the more abundantly I love you, the less I am loved by you, beloved.' This verse shows Paul's willingness to give everything for others despite potential lack of reciprocation. So, embrace being spent as a positive act of devotion.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is challenging the audience to fully commit and expend themselves in service rather than merely feeling tired.

illustrations.title: Energized by Talent Camp
illustrations.text: Sometimes you're doing things and you feel like you're not being filled up by them, but sometimes you are energized by it, like with Talent Camp—I'm energized by it. It's really cool to see. I want to encourage you to spend and be spent for the sake of the Gospel, even if you're exhausted.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses his personal experience with Talent Camp to show how certain activities can energize you, encouraging listeners to give their all for the Gospel despite exhaustion.

illustrations.title: Psalmist's Worship Encouragement
illustrations.text: I like what the psalmist said: 'Oh magnify the Lord with me, let us exalt his name together. I sought the Lord and he heard me and delivered me from all my fears.' There's things that happen when we spend time dwelling on who God is, and it's a profound truth that we just need to believe what we already know. This reminds us that worship transforms our perspective and delivers us from fears.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that dwelling on God's character brings deliverance from fears and strengthens faith.

illustrations.title: Grandkids Question Music Choice
illustrations.text: I was with my grandkids after Talent Camp, and we were going to one of the complexes here. I was putting on Christian music, and she said, 'How come you always listen to Christian music?' She doesn't think it's just because I'm a pastor; it's about living out faith naturally. This moment highlights how everyday interactions can reflect our commitment to God.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to illustrate the simplicity and everyday application of believing in God's truths.

illustrations.title: Personal Music Choice Story
illustrations.text: Someone asked me why I always listen to Christian music, and I explained that I didn't always do that. When I was 17, I became a Christian and reached a point where I decided to only listen to music that encourages me spiritually. I used to listen to a lot of junk and chose to stop it, and as I get older, I'm more motivated to make choices that honor God with my time.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is emphasizing the importance of making deliberate choices to honor God in daily life.

illustrations.title: Recent Baptism Example
illustrations.text: I was looking on my way to church and saw an image of a baptism from this past Saturday at Harvest Christian Fellowship, where Pastor Greg Laurie was out in the water baptizing people. He's featured in the movie The Jesus Revolution, which is where he got baptized himself. This event highlights the significance of baptism in our faith community.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is using this to encourage church members to sign up for their upcoming baptism event.

illustrations.title: Teenage Song Revelation
illustrations.text: When I was a young Christian, just a teenager, I didn't know much of the Bible, but I knew songs. One song by the group Children of the Day said, 'There's a joy, a life of joy and happiness waiting for you. A life of love you've been longing for, with a perfect ending too. It's all been planned and thought about; it can stand the hardest trial. You can start this life today, so why wait? But you must become as a child,' referring to Jesus' words about entering the Kingdom of Heaven. They used this song for sharing the gospel, and I remember thinking how cool it was that God has a perfect life planned for me.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that God has a plan for our future by sharing his personal experience with a song that highlighted this truth.

illustrations.title: Unimaginable Heavenly Plans
illustrations.text: Sometimes people quote that verse saying heaven is better than you can imagine, and that's true because the Bible in 1 Corinthians 2:9 says that no eye has seen, no ear has heard, nor has entered into the heart of man what God has prepared. It's not just about heaven; if you read the context in 1 Corinthians 2, it's about your future here on Earth as well. God who loves you has plans that are better than you could imagine, applying to both your eternal and earthly life.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that God's plans for believers include an unimaginable future on Earth as well as in heaven, encouraging those who feel discouraged.

illustrations.title: Paul in Prison Example
illustrations.text: Remember when Paul is in prison and there are people preaching the gospel? He says they're not doing it for the right motives, but he's going to praise God because the gospel is going out anyway. In other words, some people aren't really led by the Lord to do what they're doing, but they are sharing the gospel and the word of God won't return void.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that God can use people with wrong motives to spread the gospel, just as He used Balaam.

illustrations.title: Slave Girl with Demon
illustrations.text: When Paul and Silas were in Philippi, the little slave girl possessed by a demon kept saying these are men, servants of the most high God. What she said was absolutely true, even though it came from a demon. This shows that demons can speak truth about God despite not being believers.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates that God can use even demonic forces to proclaim truth, emphasizing how Balaam, who didn't know God, could still speak His word.

illustrations.title: Demons in Gadara
illustrations.text: The demon-possessed men in Gadara yelled, We know who you are, Holy One of Israel, have you come to torment us before the time? They were speaking truth about Jesus, showing that demons have great theology even though they're not saved. This highlights how supernatural beings can acknowledge God's truth.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob points out that just as demons spoke truth, Balaam could prophesy without knowing God, proving God uses various means to reveal His word.

illustrations.title: Cyrus Decree Example
illustrations.text: Cyrus in Ezra chapter one was used by God to release His people and gave an edict recorded in the Bible that describes true things about God. Although Cyrus did not know the Lord, God still used him for this purpose. This shows that God can work through non-believers to fulfill His plans.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to explain how Balaam, not being one of God's people, could still speak God's word, as God has historically used outsiders like Cyrus.

illustrations.title: Mission Trip Healing
illustrations.text: I once had a guy ask me, 'Bob, I don't understand it. I was on a mission trip in a foreign country, and God used me in a powerful way. I laid hands on a person who was blind, and God restored their sight—it was amazing.' He said, 'But what I don't understand is how God could use me, because I wasn't in a right place with the Lord and was doing things I knew were wrong just the night before.' I explained to him, 'It's not about what you were doing; it has to do with God's compassion for the man you prayed for. God wanted to heal him, so He used you, regardless of your worthiness.'
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to show that God can use imperfect people for His purposes, emphasizing that divine use does not guarantee someone's salvation.

illustrations.title: Childhood TV Show Memory
illustrations.text: When I was a young child, there was a TV show called Please Don't Eat the Daisies. It's about Doris Day, who sings the theme song Que Sera Sera. In the song, a little girl asks her mother about the future—will I be pretty, will I be rich—and her mother replies, 'Que Sera Sera, whatever will be will be, the future's not ours to see.' As the song progresses, the girl grows older and asks the same of her sweetheart, and later, as a mother, she tells her own children the same thing—we can't know the future.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to contrast human uncertainty about the future with God's complete knowledge of it.

illustrations.title: Blimp View Analogy
illustrations.text: God has that blimp view of the Rose Parade, where He can see everything happening simultaneously. From this eternal perspective, He dwells in eternity and sees the beginning and the end all at once. This means He knows the future completely, unlike us who are limited to our linear experience of time.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to explain how God can declare the future because He has a comprehensive, timeless viewpoint.

illustrations.title: Jesus Reverses Adam's Curse
illustrations.text: Jesus Christ was nailed to the cross because Galatians says everyone who hangs on a tree is cursed. He took the curse for us, the curse of sin that affects every one of us. That's why he died naked, just as Adam and Eve were when their eyes opened as sinners. That's why Jesus wore a crown of thorns, symbolizing the curse God pronounced on Adam: from dust you came, to dust you will return, and the ground would yield thorns and thistles. Jesus became a curse for us, reversing the effects of sin.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate how God reverses the curse of sin through Jesus.

illustrations.title: Simeon and Levi's Curse Reversed
illustrations.text: At the end of Genesis, Simeon and Levi were supposed to be blessed by their father Jacob as he neared death and spoke to his sons about their future. Jacob pronounced a curse on them for their sins, saying they would not receive an inheritance like their brothers and would be scattered throughout Israel. Yet, God turned this curse into a blessing: Levi became the priesthood, scattered among the tribes but drawn closer to God, receiving cities in every territory. Simeon was absorbed into the tribe of Judah, the kingly tribe from which Jesus came. This shows how God fulfills and reverses curses for good.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that God is in the business of reversing curses, turning negative consequences into blessings.

illustrations.title: John as Burning Lamp
illustrations.text: Jesus said about John the Baptist, you have sent to John and he has become a witness to the truth. In John 5:35, Jesus said he John was the lamp that was burning and shining and you were willing to rejoice for a while in his light. Even though Balaam isn't the same man, what he's going to say is valuable because it connects to this idea of being a light.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to show that those who speak God's truth, like Balaam, act as lights guiding others, just as John the Baptist did.

illustrations.title: Bible as Lightsaber
illustrations.text: God's word is our light to see, as it reveals the Lord and helps us grow in our relationship with him. It's also described in Ephesians as the sword of the Spirit, the word of God. So you might say the Bible is your lightsaber, a powerful tool for both illumination and defense.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob makes this analogy to emphasize that the Bible serves as both a guide for living and a weapon in spiritual battles.

illustrations.title: Gehazi's Spiritual Vision
illustrations.text: I think of Gehazi, that servant of Elisha, who didn't have the spiritual insight his master had. He was holed up with armies surrounding him and was freaking out, but Elisha prayed, 'Lord, open his eyes.' When God opened his eyes, Gehazi saw the armies of heaven surrounding the enemy. This shows that God can give spiritual vision even to someone like Gehazi, who wasn't a godly believer.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate that God can grant spiritual insight to unbelievers or less spiritual people.

illustrations.title: Prayer for Open Eyes
illustrations.text: I like to pray a simple prayer from the Old Testament, which is, 'Lord, open my eyes that I might behold wonderful things from your Word.' I commend this prayer to you because it's essential for understanding God's revelation. Even after studying the Bible for years, I know that without the Holy Spirit's work, I might miss what God is saying. This prayer reminds us that the Spirit interprets and applies God's Word to our lives.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize the need for the Holy Spirit to reveal and apply God's Word personally.

illustrations.title: Samuel Hears God's Call
illustrations.text: Little Samuel was taught to listen as he sat in his bed in Shiloh during the time of the Tabernacle. He heard a voice calling his name, 'Samuel, Samuel,' and thought it was Eli. Eli, the high priest, wasn't walking with the Lord and wasn't hearing from God anymore. This story shows that even a young boy like Samuel could hear God, contrasting with Eli's spiritual dullness.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate the importance of being attuned to God's voice through the Holy Spirit.

illustrations.title: Samuel's Call to Listen
illustrations.text: Samuel comes when called, thinking it's Eli, and says you called me, but Eli replies I didn't call you, go back to bed. God calls Samuel again, and the same thing happens. Then Eli realizes it might be God and instructs Samuel to say, Speak Lord, your servant is listening, the next time he hears the voice. Eli, who isn't hearing from God himself anymore, knows exactly what to do in this situation. This shows the importance of being ready to respond to God.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize that one must be willing to listen and obey God to hear from Him.

illustrations.title: God Using Balaam's Donkey
illustrations.text: We often wonder how God could use Balaam, but the real question is how could God use a donkey. God used a mute, unclean donkey to speak His rebuke to the prophet Balaam. This is humbling because it shows God can use anyone, even the most unlikely. We should ask ourselves, Lord, how could you use me, despite my impurities. It's all about God's grace, not our qualifications.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates that God can use imperfect people through grace, encouraging humility and availability.

illustrations.title: Jeremiah on Boasting in God
illustrations.text: Shot down Jeremiah 9:24: Let the person who's going to boast or have something to be glad about in their life boast of this that God says that he knows and understands me that I am the Lord who executes loving kindness and justice and righteousness on Earth for I delight in these things declares Lord. If you want to have something to go after in your life, be a person who not just reads the Bible but knows the Lord. This means seeking a deeper understanding of God beyond mere knowledge.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that true value in life comes from knowing and understanding God, rather than worldly achievements.

illustrations.title: Moses Seeking God's Presence
illustrations.text: Remember what Moses's goal was; he found favor in God's eyes so God says ask me what you like, and Moses wanted to know God better. He said, I just want to know you more, I want to see your face, I want to be face to face with you God. This shows Moses desiring a closer, intimate relationship with God than he had ever experienced.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate that seeking a deeper personal knowledge of God is essential for being used by Him.

illustrations.title: Solomon Asking for Wisdom
illustrations.text: God said that to Solomon too; God said Solomon what do you want, and Solomon wanted wisdom not for personal gain but to be the king and to honor you Lord. He recognized he couldn't fill his father's sandals and needed wisdom to lead according to God's will. God blessed him because he asked for something aligned with God's desires.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to show that asking for wisdom and things that honor God leads to His favor and effective service.

illustrations.title: Mezuzah on Jewish Doors
illustrations.text: If you ever see a Jewish home, especially Orthodox ones, they have this little metal thing on their door called a mezuzah. It's their way of obeying the command in Deuteronomy 6, where God said to write His words on the doorposts of your house. Inside these mezuzahs are pieces of scripture, like the Shema, and many have the letter Shin on them, which stands for Shaddai, meaning Almighty God.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate how people honor God's commands and recognize Him as Almighty.

illustrations.title: Abram's Promise from God
illustrations.text: Remember when Abram thought he couldn't have kids and considered Hagar as a solution? God asked him, 'Is there anything too difficult for me?' This story shows God's power to overcome impossibility, reminding us that He is Almighty and can handle any situation.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is emphasizing that nothing is too hard for God, encouraging trust in His power.

illustrations.title: Moses' Reluctance to Speak
illustrations.text: Remember when Moses said he couldn't speak well and wasn't fit to go to Pharaoh? God responded by asking, 'Who made your mouth?' This retelling highlights that God equips us for His purposes, showing His sovereignty over our weaknesses.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that God is big enough to handle personal limitations and fears.

illustrations.title: Sculpture of Humble Viewing
illustrations.text: There's a life-sized granite sculpture of Jesus by a Danish artist named Thorvaldsen. He sculpted the body of Christ so that you can't see his face from a standing position. Next to the statue is a sign that reads: 'If you want to see the face of Jesus, you must sit at his feet.' And sure enough, if you get down at the foot of the statue, you can look up and clearly see the face of Jesus. What an awesome idea, as it shows how humility reveals deeper truths.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize that humility is essential for God to reveal His will, word, and wisdom.

illustrations.title: Bar Kokhba Revolt and Prophecy
illustrations.text: Many of you have heard of the Jewish Revolt around 68 A.D., when the Romans destroyed the temple and persecuted the Jews, as Jesus had predicted when he wept over Jerusalem. However, not many are familiar with the later revolt in 135 A.D., led by Simon Ben Kosiba, who was nicknamed Bar Kokhba because people believed he was the Messiah. The Jews followed him in a massive uprising, regaining autonomy for three years until the Romans slaughtered them all. This event relates back to the biblical prophecy of the star, illustrating how it was misapplied to a false messiah.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this historical reference to show how the prophecy of the star and scepter pointed to the true Messiah, Jesus, and was misunderstood in historical events.

illustrations.title: Moses' Prayer Against Amalekites
illustrations.text: The Amalekites were the first nation to fight against Israel. Remember, Moses told Joshua to go down and fight them while he went up to pray. As long as Moses held his hands up, Israel prevailed, but he got tired, so Aaron and Hur helped hold his hands up. Because of his intercession, Israel defeated the Amalekites. God declared that there would be ongoing war with Amalek.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating how God ensures victory for Israel over their enemies through prayer and intercession, connecting it to the historical enmity with Amalek.

illustrations.title: Queen Elizabeth's Evidence of God
illustrations.text: Queen Elizabeth is said to have asked her Secretary of State, Prime Minister Disraeli, for one evidence of the existence of God. He replied that it was easy: the Jew, because they have survived all attempts by great empires and nations to obliterate them, and yet they still exist. God is keeping his promise, which is proof that there is a God and that this nation and these people still exist on the earth. That is exactly what Balaam is saying here: all these kingdoms are going to come and go.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to show that the survival of the Jews despite attacks from empires proves God's enduring promise to Israel, as prophesied by Balaam.

illustrations.title: Defeat of Ancient Empires
illustrations.text: Friends, I have yet to meet an Amalekite or a Hittite; basically, all these nations are gone, wiped out, and destroyed. They were massive, huge, powerful empires that came against God's people, and God predicted that no matter who comes against you, I will destroy them. It seemed impossible for God's people to survive, but they did because God was with them. This shows that even when you're up against overwhelming odds, God's promise ensures you will come through it.
illustrations.context: God will destroy any enemies opposing His people, ensuring their survival and protection.

illustrations.title: Psalm 91 Divine Protection
illustrations.text: What does it say in Psalm 91? A thousand may fall at your side and ten thousand at your right hand, but it won't come near you or destroy you. God will give His angels charge concerning you, lest you dash your foot against a stone. You're going to get some bumps here and there, but you're going to come through this just fine because God's watching over you. This promise means that if you make God your shelter, the Most High your dwelling place, He will protect you.
illustrations.context: God promises to protect His people from harm, even in the face of great dangers.

illustrations.title: Wedding Statue Anecdote
illustrations.text: Becky and I were at a wedding some years ago when I was much more immature. It was in a beautiful Lutheran church, and we were waiting for the ceremony to start. There was a large statue of Jesus with his hands outstretched, and it struck me that it looked like he was playing volleyball. I made the joke to Becky, saying it looked like that, and I knew right away I shouldn't have because it made it hard for us to stay serious. I'm sure I'd never be invited back, as it might seem irreverent, but it just resembled a volleyball pose to me.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to humorously introduce the idea of Jesus preparing a place, connecting it to biblical themes of guidance and paths.

illustrations.title: Thought Leads to Destiny
illustrations.text: There's an old saying that a thought leads to an action. If you keep thinking a thought, it reaps an action, which is why the Bible teaches that lust is like committing adultery, coveting is like stealing, and hatred is like murder. A thought reaps an action, an action reaps a habit, and a habit reaps a destiny.
illustrations.context: This shows how thoughts and behaviors demonstrate and validate one's faith and assurance of salvation.

illustrations.title: Balaam's Misguided Faith
illustrations.text: Lord tonight we're realizing that a person like Balaam can hear from you speak for you and it's recorded in here. He wasn't a man who was motivated by the right things and he wasn't living out a Godly life. From what we can tell, he's not an example to us and quite likely not going to be in heaven.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses Balaam's story to illustrate the danger of hearing from God without living a godly life and the risk of self-deception.

illustrations.title: Parable of Wheat and Tares
illustrations.text: Jesus presented another parable to them, saying the kingdom of heaven may be compared to a man who sowed good seed in his field. While his men were sleeping, the enemy came and sowed tares among the wheat and went away. When the wheat sprouted and bore grain, the tares became evident. The slaves of the landowner said to him, 'Sir, did you not sow good seed in your field? How then does it have tares?' He replied, 'An enemy has done this.' They asked, 'Do you want us to go and gather them up?' But he said, 'No, for while you're gathering up the tares, you may uproot the wheat with them. Allow both to grow together until the harvest, which is the end of the age and the judgment.'
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this parable to show that in the visible church before Christ's return, good and evil will coexist until the final judgment.

illustrations.title: Judas as False Believer
illustrations.text: Just think of Judas, who was fully involved in ministry and thought he was saved, but he wasn't. He was a make-believe believer among the true ones, showing how imitation can occur even in close circles. This example highlights the insecurity of those who aren't genuine.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that Satan uses imitation through false believers who appear saved but are not.

illustrations.title: Roman Empire's Church Shift
illustrations.text: The Roman Empire tried to destroy the church for 300 years, but then they changed gears and became the Holy Roman Church when Constantine got converted. By the end of the fourth century, it was no longer an outlawed religion but the state church, bringing all sorts of problems with it. This historical event shows how the church's growth led to unintended influences.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that the church grew so large that evil could infest it organizationally.

illustrations.title: Mustard Seed Growth Analogy
illustrations.text: The kingdom of heaven is like a mustard seed, which a man took and sowed in his field; it's smaller than all other seeds, but when it grows, it becomes a large tree where birds of the air come and nest in its branches. This represents how the church started tiny but grew into something massive, affecting culture and history worldwide. However, this expansion means that evil, symbolized by the birds, can infest and become part of it.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that the church's growth makes it vulnerable to evil forces infiltrating it.

illustrations.title: Leaven as Sin Analogy
illustrations.text: Leaven is yeast, it's a type and a picture of sin in the Bible that which corrupts but utterly corrupts. It hid in three pecks of flour until it was all leavened. This is the progression Jesus is giving to us of the church on earth: there will be imitation, then infestation, and ultimately it will be fully permeated or invaded by evil.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating how sin gradually corrupts and invades the church completely.

illustrations.title: Demon-Possessed Men in Gadara
illustrations.text: This word difficult is only used one other time in the New Testament in Matthew chapter 8, where Jesus went to Gadara, the capital city of the Decapolis. Those ten Greek cities weren't Jewish, though some Jews lived there. When Jesus got out of the boat, he was met by two demon-possessed men who would tear their clothes off, lived in the tombs, cut themselves, and everyone was afraid of them. The word difficult means dangerous and menacing, just like these men.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is using this story to explain that the last days will bring dangerous and menacing times for believers.

illustrations.title: Parable of the Ten Bridesmaids
illustrations.text: Remember there were ten bridesmaids, five of them while they were all waiting for the bridegroom to come, but only five were ready. I'm sure all ten thought they were going into the wedding feast, but they didn't all go. He's not talking about the world there; he's talking about his followers.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is warning that not all church members or followers will be prepared for Christ's return, emphasizing the risk of apostasy.

illustrations.title: Pentecost and the Last Days
illustrations.text: With the advent of the outpouring of the Holy Spirit, the Jews said these guys are drunk. Peter responded that they're not drunk; it's too early for that, which is an interesting statement. He then explained that this is what was spoken by Joel: in the last days, God says, I will pour out my Spirit upon all flesh, and this happened at Pentecost.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this illustration to show that the last days began with the outpouring of the Holy Spirit at Pentecost.

illustrations.title: Jesus and Samaritan Woman
illustrations.text: In John 4, Jesus spoke to a Samaritan woman who hadn't been converted or born again. She had a wrong belief system and lifestyle. Jesus told her to call her husband, and she said she didn't have one, but Jesus replied that she had five husbands before and the man she's with now isn't her husband. She then tried to change the subject, saying, 'Sir, I perceive you're a prophet, let's talk about something else.'
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate that the church today may not blush at sin like the Samaritan woman did, showing how Christians are resembling the world culturally.

illustrations.title: Magazine Titles Show Self-Focus
illustrations.text: I remember growing up getting copies of Life magazine. The number one magazine in the 50s and 60s was Life, then it became People magazine in the next decade, followed by Us, and then Self. Does anybody else notice a progression here? It's from life to people to us to self, illustrating a cultural shift towards individualism. Someone said that if you want a successful magazine today, just call it 'Me' and include a big mirror inside.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the cultural progression towards self-centeredness in society.

illustrations.title: WI FM Analogy for Self-Interest
illustrations.text: Every single person that's born is hardwired and tuned into WI FM, which stands for What's In It For Me. That is the nature of the human soul, desperately wicked and deceitful above all else. We may not like to hear it, but it's a fundamental truth about human nature.
illustrations.context: This analogy demonstrates that people are naturally self-centered, as part of their inherent sinful nature.

illustrations.title: Commercials Promoting Self-Worth
illustrations.text: You've seen the commercials that have been around for a while, advertising some product, and they say something like, 'Yes, it costs more, but after all, you're worth it.' This promotes self-love by suggesting that we deserve the best for ourselves. We are meant to worship God and love people, using things for His glory, but these ads shift the focus to ourselves.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate how media encourages self-love, leading people to prioritize themselves over God.

illustrations.title: CS Lewis on Selflessness
illustrations.text: CS Lewis once wrote, 'I haven't had a selfless thought since the day I was born.' This highlights our natural tendency toward self-love and why we should pray for ourselves. It shows how self-love infects biblical teaching and pollutes true worship.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that self-love is a universal issue that corrupts genuine worship and biblical understanding.

illustrations.title: Prosperity Gospel in Mega-Churches
illustrations.text: The largest church in the world was in Korea with a million people, led by Paul Cho who committed to the prosperity gospel. The largest church in America also teaches this gospel, focusing on what God can do for you. This popularity draws crowds but shifts the message away from holiness, sin, and judgment toward self-help.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show how the prosperity gospel's emphasis on personal gain has made it the most popular message, distorting true worship.

illustrations.title: Personal Salvation Story
illustrations.text: When I came to Jesus, He washed away my sins with His blood, not just the ones I had committed up until I was 13, but for the rest of my life as well. I'm so grateful for that. Love covers a multitude of sins, and it's something we should all appreciate.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how God's love completely covers our sins.

illustrations.title: Self-Forgiveness with Spills
illustrations.text: I am very self-forgiving; if I knock a glass of milk on the ground, I just say that's okay, I'll clean it up, and I don't get upset with myself. I hope I don't get mad at anybody else, but I'm just saying, I'm very forgiving to myself in these situations. This shows how self-love operates in everyday life.
illustrations.context: This demonstrates how self-love excuses our own mistakes.

illustrations.title: Driving Double Standards
illustrations.text: Have you ever been at a light and stopped for the red, and somebody blew right through it, thinking where's a cop when you need one? But if you accidentally run a red light, thinking it was yellow and it wasn't, you don't get mad at yourself; you just say that's okay. This highlights how we treat our own errors differently from others'.
illustrations.context: This shows how self-love leads us to excuse our sins while holding others accountable.

illustrations.title: Deathbed Regrets Story
illustrations.text: I've shared this before. I've talked to a lot of people who are dying; it comes with the territory, and I don't always know what to say, just to be there, grieve with them, and help if they don't know the Lord or have unfinished business. But I have never, never, never sat with a man on his deathbed who said, 'I wish I had made more money' or 'I wish I had spent more time at the office.' Suddenly, it's all worthless in terms of eternity.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate that people on their deathbeds do not regret not making more money, emphasizing that the love of money leads to pointless pain.

illustrations.title: Childhood Spy Fascination
illustrations.text: When I was in grade school, I had a fascination with all things law enforcement, especially international spies. I used to watch a show on TV called The Man From UNCLE, where U.N.C.L.E. stood for the United Network Command for Law and Enforcement, fighting evil forces. I saw myself as one of them, like Napoleon Solo and Illya Kuryakin. I collected cards from bubble gum that were pieces of a 52-piece puzzle of the Man From UNCLE, and I had six sets that I put together and kept in a little black box near the trash cans. I also had a double-oh-seven spy pen, which was really a squirt gun, and a decoder pad that was secret and classified. When I wanted to feel important, I'd check my little black box and ride around the neighborhood on my bicycle at night, looking for evildoers to keep the neighbors safe.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to illustrate how chasing toys or status, like his childhood obsession, reflects the deceitfulness of riches and the immature pursuit of feeling like a winner.

illustrations.title: Bumper Sticker on Riches
illustrations.text: What did the old bumper-sticker say? 'He who dies with the most toys wins.' I like the other one that came out: 'He who dies with the most toys wins nothing.' They should have had one that just makes you the biggest kid ever, as it proves you're still a big kid. This phrase highlights the lie that riches make you a winner, a deception that can choke out spiritual growth just like in the parable of the sower.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to show how the cultural lie of riches promising victory or status misleads people, connecting it to the deceitfulness that chokes the Word of God.

illustrations.title: Childhood Treasure Obsession
illustrations.text: I know that it's just a child's imagination, worthless kids' stuff, but it made me feel important to have my stuff. I don't sneak out anymore to our trash area and have my little black box. As a child, I valued these things, but now as an adult, I've moved beyond that childish way of thinking.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to illustrate the need for believers to mature and change their value system from worldly possessions to spiritual priorities.

illustrations.title: American Debt and Spending
illustrations.text: The old commercials say, and we all agree, that there are a few things that money can't buy, but for everything else there's MasterCard. Americans spend way more than we have; the current credit card debt for Americans is over 1.02 trillion dollars. The average American household carries 137 thousand dollars in debt, according to the Federal Reserve's latest numbers, yet the median household income is only fifty-nine thousand dollars.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this real-world example to show the deceitfulness of riches and how an unhealthy relationship with money leads to insecurity and poor financial habits.

illustrations.title: Quack Seller Analogy
illustrations.text: The word for boaster is from Greek, meaning a quack who goes around selling potions that claim to cure everything, making all sorts of false claims. We all know people like that who boast about all the things they can do. It's an example of someone strutting around like a peacock with exaggerated stories.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to explain that a boaster is someone who makes false or inflated claims to appear superior.

illustrations.title: Quote on Boastful People
illustrations.text: Someone once said, 'Why is it that all the people who really know how to run the world are so busy cutting hair and driving taxis?' This highlights how those who boast often think they have all the answers, but in reality, true capability is found in humble positions. Pastor Bob connects it to the nature of man and the tendency toward arrogance.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to illustrate that boasters falsely believe they are superior, while humble people quietly excel.

illustrations.title: Jesus' Humility Retelling
illustrations.text: In Philippians, Jesus is our example who did not regard equality with God as something to be grasped, but emptied himself and took on the form of a servant. He washed his disciples' feet, taking the place of the lowest servant, even though he was their master. If Jesus could humble himself like that, certainly we can do the same for one another.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob retells this story to emphasize that believers should humble themselves as Jesus did, rather than being arrogant.

illustrations.title: Cat Claims God's Throne
illustrations.text: A cat, a German Shepherd, and a Doberman all died and went to heaven. God asked the German Shepherd what he believed, and he said, 'I believe in discipline, training, and loyalty to my master,' so God told him to sit on his right hand. God then asked the Doberman, who said, 'I believe in the love, care, and protection of my master,' so he was told to sit on God's left. But when God asked the cat, the cat replied, 'I believe you're sitting in my seat,' which Pastor Bob uses to highlight audacious pride like Satan's.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to show how pride leads people to try to usurp God's position, just as Satan claimed he would ascend to the Most High.

illustrations.title: Wise Men and Herod's Rivalry
illustrations.text: Jesus was born in Bethlehem, as prophesied in Micah 5:2. The wise men saw his star in the east and traveled to Jerusalem to worship him as the King of the Jews. They asked King Herod for help in finding the child, but Herod was troubled because he saw Jesus as a threat to his own throne. Herod wore a name tag claiming 'King of the Jews' and refused to share his position, illustrating how people cling to power instead of acknowledging God's authority. This story shows the conflict when someone tries to hold onto what belongs to God.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob retells this biblical story to demonstrate how refusing to acknowledge God leads to futile attempts to maintain personal control, mirroring the earlier point about pride.

illustrations.title: Boastful Ball Player
illustrations.text: There was a guy with a ball and a bat, practicing by throwing the ball up and swinging, but he kept missing. Every time he threw it up, he would boast, 'I'm the best hitter in the world,' only to miss again. Then he'd say, 'I'm the best pitcher in the world.' This story shows how pride manifests in self-deception.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the ongoing battle with pride in the lives of Christians.

illustrations.title: Ingrained Pride in Fools
illustrations.text: The Proverbs say that even if you take a fool and put him into a mortar and grind him with a pestle, pride would still remain there, as it's ingrained in his very nature. You can't grind it out of him; it's in the DNA. This highlights how deeply rooted pride is in those who reject wisdom.
illustrations.context: This shows that pride is an inherent part of a fool's character and cannot be easily removed.

illustrations.title: James and Johns Ambition
illustrations.text: James and John, followers of Jesus, didn't ask him directly about positions of honor; instead, they had their mom approach him, saying she was glad for what he'd done with her sons and asking if they could sit at his right and left in his kingdom. Jesus told them he couldn't grant that, as it wasn't his to give. This desire for prominence exemplifies selfish ambition.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how arrogance and selfish ambition appear in relationships and the church.

illustrations.title: Christians Arguing Online
illustrations.text: Can we remember how some Christians got into heated arguments online during the last election cycle? They were at each other's throats over differences, not just sharing opinions. The things I've seen Christians say to each other on the internet have troubled me deeply, and I want us to be aware as a new cycle begins.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how arrogance leads to disunity and putting others down among Christians.

illustrations.title: Grandson's Hawaiian Shirt Excitement
illustrations.text: I got a Hawaiian shirt and bought a little one for my grandsons. The other day, my grandson was about to leave for school, all dressed, but when he saw his little shirt, he wanted to wear it instead. It was a bit of a battle because he wanted to put it on himself, but he couldn't, so I helped him. Once it was on, the first thing he did was run down the hall to show his mother how his shorts matched the shirt.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating how children naturally seek recognition, connecting it to the broader point about avoiding arrogant attention-seeking in adulthood.

illustrations.title: Boy Seeking Praise in Darts
illustrations.text: I thought of a little boy who said to his dad, let's go play darts. The dad asked how he wanted to play, and the little boy said, well I'll throw and you say wonderful. This shows how children naturally like to be recognized for their actions.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is using this to show that seeking attention is a natural human trait from childhood, warning against letting it lead to arrogance.

illustrations.title: Child at Pool for Attention
illustrations.text: A little kid at the pool does something on the diving board and calls out for his mom or someone to watch. He jumps in, even if it's nothing spectacular, and as soon as he's back, he wants everyone to watch again. This highlights how built into us is the desire for recognition.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that the human desire for recognition starts young and becomes more sophisticated with age, tying into the need to avoid misuse of platforms like social media.

illustrations.title: Delight in Grandson Jeffy
illustrations.text: You know this because I often talk about my youngest grandson, who lives with us. His name is Jeffrey, but we call him Jeffy since he can't say it yet. I want to show you a picture of him—that's the delight on his face when I dangled my car keys to make him smile. Becky and I wonder why a two-year-old brings us such joy every day; we wake up, have coffee, and wait for him to come downstairs. He calls out for us, making sure we're there, and just his presence makes us happy—he doesn't have to do anything, just show up. And I love it when he asks for things, even if I can't understand or give them to him.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate that just as he delights in his grandson's presence and simple requests, God delights in His people's prayers.

illustrations.title: Cyprien's Letter to Donatists
illustrations.text: In the 3rd century, Cyprien sent a letter to his friend Donatists and said it's a bad world, an incredibly bad world, but I have discovered in the midst of it a quiet and good people who have learned the great secret of life. They have found a joy and wisdom which is a thousand times better than any of the pleasures of this sinful life. They are despised and persecuted, but they don't care; they are masters of their souls and have overcome the world. These people, Donatists, are Christians, and I am one of them.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that Christians can find joy and overcome a bad world despite persecution, encouraging believers to be exceptions in a declining church.

illustrations.title: Sower and the Seed Parable
illustrations.text: The Word of God goes out like the sower goes out to sow seed. Some of the Word is stolen away by the birds of the air, which represent demonic forces. When people don't understand it, the Word never comes to fruition.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating how demonic forces try to steal the Word of God before it takes root.

illustrations.title: Abraham's Sacrifice and Birds
illustrations.text: Remember, Abraham prepared to sacrifice and was waiting for God to show up. God hesitated, and then the birds of the air came to eat the sacrifice. Abraham had to shoo them away, showing the need to protect what God has given.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is using this to emphasize the importance of driving away distractions or demonic influences before engaging with God's Word.

illustrations.title: Roman Soldier's Boots
illustrations.text: Remember, Paul was looking at armor on a Roman soldier, no doubt tied to him as he was writing or dictating it. A Roman soldier's shoes, which we might call sandals, were actually boots made of tough leather to cover their feet. What was most significant was the hobnails on the bottom that provided traction for standing firm in battle and even using them as a weapon against the enemy. This preparation symbolizes our readiness and confidence in spiritual conflict through the gospel of peace.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses the historical description of Roman soldiers' shoes to illustrate how the gospel equips believers for spiritual battles with readiness and peace.

illustrations.title: Jesus' Synagogue Reading
illustrations.text: Jesus went into the synagogue, took the scroll of Isaiah, opened it to the place we know as chapter 61, and read aloud. He declared that the Spirit of the Lord was upon him because he was anointed to preach the gospel to the poor, proclaim release to the captives, recovery of sight to the blind, and freedom for the oppressed. This reading showed that he was fulfilling the prophecy that very day as part of his mission.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate Jesus' mission to proclaim the good news of salvation.

illustrations.title: The Marathon Messenger
illustrations.text: The Persians in about 590 BC decided to destroy their opposition among the Greeks and landed to battle outside Athens at a place called Marathon. They first demolished nearby Eritrea and then fought the Athenians in a severe battle, ultimately losing to the Greeks. A courier named Pheidippides ran over 26 miles from Marathon to Athens to announce the victory, declared the good news upon arrival, and then collapsed and died. This historical event inspired the modern marathon and serves as a picture of delivering important news.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob compares this to Jesus' role in declaring the good news of salvation.

illustrations.title: US Coast Guard Motto
illustrations.text: I believe you know the motto of the US Coast Guard is semper paratus, which simply means always ready from the Latin. It's great that it's theirs, but before it was theirs, it was ours according to the scripture. This motto emphasizes being prepared at all times, just as we should be in our faith.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this real-world example to illustrate the importance of always being ready to share the gospel.

illustrations.title: 1 Peter 3:15 Scripture Quote
illustrations.text: According to the scripture in 1 Peter 3:15, sanctify the Lord God in your heart and be ready always to give an answer to every man that asks you for a reason of the hope that is in you, but with meekness and fear. This means we need to know what we believe and why, so we can explain it confidently. Paul Little wrote two books on this: Know What You Believe and Know Why You Believe, highlighting the need for biblical knowledge today.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob explains this quote to stress the necessity of being prepared to defend and share one's faith with others.

illustrations.title: Bible's Unique Structure
illustrations.text: The Bible is unique in all literature of the whole world. There are 66 separate books written by over 40 authors over a period of fifteen hundred plus years, written in three different languages on three different continents. Yet, while there's all that difference, it fits together into one cohesive story with an appropriate beginning, a logical ending, a central character in the Lord Jesus Christ, and a consistent theme.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate the miraculous unity and character of the Bible, emphasizing why believers should have confidence in its inspiration.

illustrations.title: Quote on Bible's Impact
illustrations.text: Like the guy said, I have read many books but I only have one book that reads me. This highlights how the Bible is unique because it comes from God himself, penetrating and revealing truths about us in a way no other book does.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to show that the Bible's uniqueness lies in its divine origin and personal transformative power, supporting the need to understand why we believe in it.

illustrations.title: Persecutions of Early Church
illustrations.text: During the first three centuries of the church, there were wave after wave of persecution, ten successive waves starting from the book of Acts and worsening over time. You might be familiar with Nero, under whom Paul the Apostle and Peter were executed, but the persecution under later emperors like Diocletian was even more severe. This demonstrates the indestructibility of the Bible, as attempts to destroy it and the faith have failed.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate the Bible's indestructibility as evidence of its divine origin, reinforcing why believers should trust in its authority.

illustrations.title: Diocletian's Persecution of Christians
illustrations.text: Diocletian was the emperor of Rome at the end of the 3rd century and beginning of the 4th century. He declared Christianity illegal, ordering all Bibles to be seized and burned, gathering places destroyed, and Christians slaughtered in horrific ways. Christians went underground, but after Diocletian's death, his wife and daughter became Christians, and the new emperor Constantine also converted, making Christianity legal and eventually the state religion. This story highlights the resilience of the faith despite severe opposition.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that attempts to eradicate Christianity and the Bible ultimately fail, emphasizing the enduring nature of God's Word.

illustrations.title: Spurgeon's Warning on Distractions
illustrations.text: Here's what Spurgeon said: More and more I am jealous lest any views upon prophecy, church government, politics, or even systematic theology should withdraw one of us from glorying in the main message. Pastor Bob shares this to stress the importance of not letting secondary issues overshadow the core of the gospel. It's a reminder to stay focused on what truly matters in faith and evangelism.
illustrations.context: This quote encourages believers to prioritize sharing the gospel and avoid distractions from other topics.

illustrations.title: Veteran Marine Example
illustrations.text: A veteran came up to a pastor some years ago and said, 'I was a good marine but I never had a chance to prove it.' He explained that he served between the Korean War and the Vietnam War, so he never saw combat. This story shows that while he was ready, he lacked the opportunity, much like some might feel about spiritual battles.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that the Christian spiritual war has no ceasefires and is always ongoing.

illustrations.title: Jesus and Peter Retelling
illustrations.text: Jesus said to Peter, who had answered correctly when Jesus asked, 'Who do you say that I am?' Peter replied, 'Thou art the Christ, the Son of the Living God.' Jesus blessed him, saying, 'Flesh and blood has not revealed this to you, but my Father in heaven, and upon this rock I will build my church, and the gates of Hell will not prevail against it.'
illustrations.context: This retelling emphasizes that the church will victoriously advance against evil and rescue souls.

illustrations.title: Imelda Marcos Shoes
illustrations.text: Imelda Marcos, the wife of the dictator of the Philippines, reportedly had three thousand pairs of shoes. When she fled into exile in 1986, she left her huge collection behind. As a result of floods and termites, most of them were destroyed, leaving little behind.
illustrations.context: This references the impermanence of material possessions, contrasting with the need for spiritual readiness like 'gospel shoes'.

illustrations.title: Believers as Missionaries Reminder
illustrations.text: I remember years ago we were talking about the importance of believers, every believer not just those going on mission trips. We have missionaries in remote parts of the world and local ones doing evangelism, but every believer is called to be a missionary. We encouraged people to put up a sign above their front door to remind them as they go to work or school that they are entering their mission field, representing Jesus and making disciples.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is emphasizing that every Christian is called to be a missionary in daily life.

illustrations.title: Missionary or Impostor Quote
illustrations.text: Aspersion once said that if you're a Christian, you're either a missionary or an impostor, highlighting the mindset that every believer is called to share the gospel. Pastor Bob uses this to stress that all Christians must actively engage in evangelism. This quote serves as a challenge to live out one's faith purposefully.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that every believer must act as a missionary or risk being an impostor in their faith.

illustrations.title: Jim Elliot's Crisis Man Prayer
illustrations.text: Jim Elliot was a young martyr who died at age 28 while bringing the gospel to a primitive tribal people. He lived for that purpose and had prayed in his diary, Lord, make me a crisis man, meaning he wanted to be a fork in the road so that people must decide about Christ when they encounter him. This prayer reflects a heart fully dedicated to impacting others for Jesus.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating the need for believers to actively influence others for Christ, not just exist passively.

illustrations.title: Grandkids Squiggle Activity
illustrations.text: We do this sometimes with our grandkids; it's an inexpensive fun thing to do. We'll take a piece of paper and make a squiggle, just a meaningless shape, then hand it to them and say, 'Now make something out of it.' Their job is to look at that squiggle and draw something with it without lifting the pen, creating something that makes sense. We've all done this kind of fun activity.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how believers are called to redeem their circumstances in the world to share Jesus Christ.

illustrations.title: Jesus at the Well
illustrations.text: Think of what Jesus did in John 4 at the well. It was hot, in a Jewish town, and these people had a corrupt understanding of the Bible. Jesus's disciples thought there was no point in sharing the gospel there and wanted to leave quickly, but Jesus spoke to the Samaritan woman, saying, 'Give me a drink.' He quickly turned the conversation from water to witnessing about himself, and that woman came to faith in Christ.
illustrations.context: This shows that people around us are ready to hear the gospel, even if they don't seem like it, urging believers to be prepared to share Christ.

illustrations.title: Cindy Ricketson's Outreach Example
illustrations.text: I think of Cindy Ricketson, who has asked and you have responded so well. They come out and share the vision of reaching into our elementary schools with the Chapel on Wheels. It's one thing to take the Great Commission seriously; it's another to take it personally.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating the difference between merely acknowledging the Great Commission and personally acting on it through community efforts.

illustrations.title: Junior High Evangelism Impact
illustrations.text: I'm so glad at districts we see the junior highers and the high schoolers going out to the malls and the public square to share Christ. Literally, over 200 people have come to Christ just through our junior high ministry as they've gone out and witnessed to people. This shows the real results of taking evangelism seriously in everyday life.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is highlighting how young people actively sharing the gospel leads to many conversions, emphasizing everyone's role in witnessing.

illustrations.title: Two Buttons Analogy
illustrations.text: If you have something in your life that's really a problem, like a situation, relationship, financial issue, or health concern that you'd like to be resolved, imagine if there was a button you could push to change it right now. But I want to suggest there are two buttons you could choose: one to change the circumstance, and another related to experiencing the peace of God. Think about which one truly brings lasting peace in the midst of challenges.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is using this analogy to show that while we might want to fix problems immediately, embracing the peace of God is more important than altering circumstances.

illustrations.title: Thanksgiving Like Yeast
illustrations.text: With thanksgiving, it's kind of like the yeast that makes the bread rise. A lot of our prayers don't rise for this very reason. We need to add this element, as it makes our prayers effective and complete.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating how thanksgiving is essential for prayers to be effective, much like yeast makes bread rise.

illustrations.title: Peace as Sentinel Guard
illustrations.text: The word guard means to stand as a sentinel to prevent the enemy from invading. God promises his peace to you so that what the enemy wants to do in your mind and heart will not be able to get in. This peace acts as a protective barrier in times of anxiety.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is showing how God's peace protects hearts and minds from external threats, like a sentinel on watch.

illustrations.title: Pagers as God's Signal
illustrations.text: You remember back in the day when we had pagers, and they were so cool—originally just for doctors and lawyers, but then everyone got one. Someone would call, and your beeper would go off, meaning you had to rush to a phone booth because somebody needed you, even if you didn't know who. It was the hot technology of the 80s. Now, when you lack peace or are struggling, it's like your beeper is going off—God is paging you to pray and respond.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that a lack of peace in your life is a call from God, similar to how a pager alerted people in the past.

illustrations.title: Peace as Baseball Referee
illustrations.text: Picture it this way: in a baseball game, a player hits the ball to the shortstop, runs to first base, and slides in as the ball arrives, kicking up dust. Everyone waits for the referee to make the call—whether it's safe or out. The referee's job is to decide based on what he sees, just like God's peace in your life acts as a referee in certain circumstances. It tells you when you're safe or when you need to get out of a situation.
illustrations.context: This shows how the peace of Christ serves as a referee in a believer's life, guiding decisions by indicating what's right or wrong.

illustrations.title: Painting of Satan in Louvre
