illustrations.text: Years ago, there was a painting in the Louvre in Paris, France. A famous painter had created it, and it was a picture depicting Satan. Let's consider putting it on the board to illustrate the point.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this reference to connect the idea of God's peace and reign with the presence of evil, emphasizing spiritual truths.

illustrations.title: Chess Painting Deception
illustrations.text: In the painting, a man is playing chess against Satan, with the setup suggesting Satan is about to deliver checkmate and claim the man's soul. A chess expert studied the painting closely, even recreating the board, and discovered that the man actually has another move that would lead to his victory. This revelation shows that the painting's portrayal is a lie, as the man isn't truly defeated.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that even when life seems like a hopeless checkmate, God provides another move for victory.

illustrations.title: Joseph's Prison Hope
illustrations.text: When Joseph was forsaken by his family and forgotten in prison, he likely heard whispers that he would be there for the rest of his life, feeling like checkmate. However, God had another move for him, turning his situation around for ultimate victory. This story highlights God's ability to redeem even the most hopeless circumstances.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that God can provide a way out when people feel trapped and defeated.

illustrations.title: David's Ziklag Victory
illustrations.text: When David arrived at Ziklag and found it burned to the ground, with his family and his men's families taken by enemies, his men were ready to stone him in their despair. David sought the Lord in prayer, asking for guidance, and discovered that God had another move for him, leading to recovery and triumph. This event underscores God's intervention in moments of utter loss.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that prayer and trust in God can reveal unseen paths to victory in desperate situations.

illustrations.title: Disciples' Resurrection Hope
illustrations.text: The disciples were depressed and defeated after their master Jesus was crucified and buried in a sealed tomb, feeling like all was lost. However, praise God, the King had another move, as Jesus rose from the dead, bringing ultimate victory. This story emphasizes the power of resurrection and new beginnings.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to remind listeners that God's power overcomes death and despair, providing hope beyond human limits.

illustrations.title: Miriam and Paul Silas Praise
illustrations.text: It's been said that when Miriam took up the timbrel and led the women of Israel in dance after the Red Sea had opened for the children of Israel and destroyed their enemies, there was the song of Moses, a celebration song, and Miriam's song to worship the Lord and praise Him for what He's done. He cast the horse and rider into the sea and destroyed them. But would it have been better if she had taken up that tambourine on the other side? Isn't that what Paul and Silas were doing in the Philippian jail when they were still in prison, their wounds fresh, in the dark with bad company, but at midnight they sang praises?
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that believers should praise God in the midst of trials, just as Paul and Silas did, turning present problems into future praise.

illustrations.title: Paul and Silas in Prison
illustrations.text: I love that it's at midnight they begin to pray and to sing praises to God. You can turn your darkest dungeon into a place of praise if you decide that God is in charge. Wasn't Paul and Silas in prison, they sang, and the walls fell down? He didn't know that would happen, but it wouldn't have changed his tune one bit.
illustrations.context: To illustrate that praising God in adversity leads to deliverance and strengthens faith.

illustrations.title: Job's Unwavering Trust
illustrations.text: As Job said, 'Though he should slay me, yet I will trust in him.' If I'm going out with this, then I'm going out for him, because after he has tried me, I will come forth as gold. I accept your refining work, Lord.
illustrations.context: To emphasize that true faith endures even in the face of potential death or suffering from God.

illustrations.title: Gospel as Cinderella's Slipper
illustrations.text: The gospel that brings peace to others through us and brings peace to us as well is kind of like Cinderella's slipper; it perfectly fits us if we'll put it on. Put it on today and say, Jesus, I want to get back to the mission.
illustrations.context: To show that the gospel is perfectly suited for believers and equips them for their spiritual mission.

illustrations.title: David and Samson's Defeats
illustrations.text: We talked about David never losing a battle until he was home when he should have been in the battle. Samson was the same way; undefeated among the enemies, but he got defeated in the bedroom, not on the battlefield. The idea is that if we refuse to wear these shoes, we refuse to have the mindset of why we're here and what we're doing, we will be defeated.
illustrations.context: To warn that believers will face defeat if they abandon their God-given mission.

illustrations.title: Marriage Exposes Sinfulness
illustrations.text: If you're not sure if you're a sinner, get married and you will have plenty of opportunity to discover how much of a sinner you are in ways you wouldn't have otherwise. But if you get married and you're still not sure, have children because that will make it clear. See, children by nature challenge us, and this reveals our imperfections.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that family life, particularly marriage and parenthood, humbles us by exposing our sinfulness.

illustrations.title: Childhood Memory of Moving
illustrations.text: I was a little boy, the youngest of five, and I remember when my parents moved us into our home in Yorba Linda in 1963. It was quite a while ago, and as a child, I looked up to my parents. This experience highlights the natural dynamic of children admiring their parents.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate the challenges and joys of family relationships, tying into the broader theme of fatherhood.

illustrations.title: Childhood Dad Comparison
illustrations.text: I remember the first day we were playing together. We didn't have fences between our yards, so we were hanging out and playing. One of us said, 'My dad is stronger than your dad.' I'd never met his dad, and he hadn't met mine, but we debated it all day. Then his dad came home from work—a huge guy, like a Neanderthal—and he lumbered into the house. Kenny said, 'My dad could beat up your dad.' When my dad got out of his car, he was five foot seven, wearing glasses, and I replied, 'My dad's smarter than your dad.'
illustrations.context: This story illustrates the natural pride children have in their parents, leading to the importance of honoring them as commanded.

illustrations.title: Franklin on Holidays vs. Commandments
illustrations.text: I think it was Benjamin Franklin who wrote that it's easier to keep holidays than commandments. For example, it's easier to have a Thanksgiving Day than to be thankful all the time. It's also easier to honor mom or dad one day of the year and say we've done it. But no, honoring them is supposed to be a regular, ongoing part of our life.
illustrations.context: This quote emphasizes that honoring parents should be a daily practice, not limited to special occasions like Father's Day.

illustrations.title: Jesus and Nicodemus Encounter
illustrations.text: Do you remember what Jesus said to Nicodemus in John 3? Nicodemus was a teacher, a religious leader, a well-respected man whom we would all like and learn from. But Jesus shocked him by saying, 'Nicodemus, you're not going to see the kingdom of God unless you're born again.' He meant you have to be born a second time, born of the Spirit. That was something Nicodemus didn't understand, and it applies to some of us here who haven't had that spiritual birth—we respect God, revere Him, and call Him Father, but we're not true children of God.
illustrations.context: To illustrate that one must be spiritually born again to be a true child of God.

illustrations.title: Jesus' Parable to the Jews
illustrations.text: Remember, Jesus told this parable to the Jews who thought they were already going to heaven just because they were born into the family of God as Jews. They believed their lineage guaranteed their place, like members of the Auto Club who think they're automatically covered. This story highlights how they were mistaken in assuming birthright alone sufficed for true relationship with God.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this retelling to illustrate that simply being born into a religious family does not mean one truly honors God as a child should.

illustrations.title: Parable of Two Sons
illustrations.text: Jesus told them a parable about those who were self-righteous. He said there was a father with two sons, and he told the first son to go work in the field. That son said, 'I will, sir,' but he didn't go. The father told the second son the same, and he initially said, 'I'm not going,' but later changed his mind and went to work. Jesus asked which son honored the father, making the point that it's the one who obeyed.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize that true obedience matters more than words or claims in having a real relationship with God.

illustrations.title: Counterfeit Money Training
illustrations.text: The Banking Association held a two-week training on detecting counterfeit money. During the training, they didn't show or handle any counterfeit money at all. Instead, they only handled real money so participants could become familiar with the genuine article. This makes it easier to spot fakes because knowing the real thing helps identify what's false.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that understanding biblical truth is essential for detecting false teaching.

illustrations.title: Bereans Examine Scriptures
illustrations.text: You remember the Bereans from the Book of Acts. After Paul left Thessalonica, he went to Berea and shared the gospel, claiming Jesus of Nazareth was their Messiah. He reasoned with them from the Scriptures, showing how Jesus fulfilled prophecies like Isaiah 53, Psalm 22, and Psalm 16. The Bereans were more noble than those in Thessalonica because they examined the Scriptures daily to see if what Paul said was true.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize the importance of checking teachings against the Bible.

illustrations.title: Bible as Lie Detector
illustrations.text: I've said this before: your Bible is kind of like a lie detector, like a polygraph. When somebody tells you something, check it out and hook it up to the Word of God. This helps you verify if what you're hearing is true or not.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates how the Bible can detect and expose false teachings.

illustrations.title: Demon Possession Claim
illustrations.text: Somebody might come and say that even if you've accepted Jesus and are saved, you might still be demon-possessed. That's not true; the Bible says in 1 John that greater is He who is in you than he who is in the world, and Satan cannot possess a Christian. This shows how to use Scripture to counter false ideas about spiritual oppression.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to demonstrate how to judge and refute incorrect teachings on demon possession.

illustrations.title: Living Together Before Marriage
illustrations.text: Somebody might suggest that it's okay to live together before marriage to see if you're compatible. That's not true; the Bible is clear in Hebrews that the marriage bed is undefiled, but God will judge fornicators and adulterers. This example shows how worldly ideas contradict Scripture on purity.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates the need to align actions with Biblical standards on relationships.

illustrations.title: Losing Salvation Myth
illustrations.text: Somebody might suggest to you that if you've fallen away from the Lord or been sinning, you've lost your salvation. That's not true; Romans 8:1 says there is no condemnation for those in Christ, and God will complete the work He started. This helps clarify that salvation is a gift that can't be lost through actions.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize the security of salvation based on Scripture.

illustrations.title: Philo's Added Genealogies
illustrations.text: There was a man named Philo who wrote the book of Jubilees and took the genealogies in the book of Genesis, adding a bunch of names that aren't in the Bible. He would tell you names for Adam and Eve, and for Noah and others, creating stories not found in Scripture. They didn't just add to the genealogies; they made all kinds of crazy spiritualizations from things in the Bible that aren't really there, which excited early Christians but led to speculation.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to warn against adding to Scripture and seeking secret knowledge that distorts biblical truth.

illustrations.title: New Ideas Are Not True
illustrations.text: Can I tell you something: if it's new, it's not true, and if it's true, it's not new. I tell young guys going into the ministry to be careful when they think they've discovered something profound that the Holy Spirit revealed just to them. For example, if you claim a revelation and no one else in 2,000 years has seen it, that's probably not true, so be very careful with speculative things.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob emphasizes the danger of seeking novel teachings over established biblical truths to avoid doubts and errors.

illustrations.title: Creation and God's Light
illustrations.text: Remember when God created the world in Genesis chapter 1, where darkness was over the surface of the waters, and God said, 'Let there be light,' which cleared things up. When God speaks, it brings clarity and order. In contrast, the devil always puts a question mark where God puts a period, introducing doubt where God has made clear declarations.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates how God's word brings clarity, while the devil introduces doubt to challenge divine truth.

illustrations.title: Devil's Question in Eden
illustrations.text: Remember the devil always puts a question mark where God puts a period; for example, God gave clear instructions about which trees Adam and Eve could eat from. Then Satan showed up and said, 'Has God said?' questioning God's clear command and inserting doubts. This shows how the devil loves to undermine God's declarations.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob warns that the devil challenges God's clear instructions, leading to temptation and sin.

illustrations.title: Jesus' Baptism and Temptation
illustrations.text: I'll give you an example: when Jesus was baptized, the heavens opened and God spoke, saying, 'This is my beloved son.' Shortly thereafter, Jesus was led into the wilderness to be tested, and the devil's first words were, 'If you are the son of God,' directly questioning God's declaration. This shows how the devil inserts doubts even after God's clear affirmations.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob demonstrates how the devil challenges God's direct statements, urging believers to stand firm against such tactics.

illustrations.title: False Teaching in Church
illustrations.text: I remember years ago there was a book written by a guy with a radio program, and some people in our small church started listening and reading it. I noticed they stopped singing during certain worship songs, like one asking God for forgiveness, and I couldn't figure out why at first. They finally met with me and explained that they had learned from this teaching that we should never ask God to forgive us because we're already forgiven, and doing so dishonors Him. I was surprised and pointed out it was a beautiful song, but they insisted on forming their own group around this doctrine. As a result, they created their own little church based on this false idea.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to show how false teachings can easily lead believers astray and divide the church.

illustrations.title: Shepherds in Modern Israel
illustrations.text: I remember hearing a story of a guy that went to Israel for the first time and saw real shepherds and sheep, just like in biblical times. If you've been to Israel, as I have 20 times, you'll know that shepherds and sheep are still a common sight, and it's not just for tourists—the Bedouin people still live in tents and care for herds of sheep and goats. This guy, a Christian, observed that it's authentic and not an act. The story highlights how these ancient practices continue today, connecting to spiritual truths.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate the enduring relevance of biblical imagery, emphasizing the need to discern truth in the church like a shepherd cares for sheep.

illustrations.title: Sick Sheep Analogy
illustrations.text: A stranger was leading the flock, and the shepherd noticed and asked what was happening. The stranger said he thought the Bible taught that sheep won't follow a stranger, but this one did. The shepherd explained that normally sheep only follow their shepherd, but a sick sheep will follow anyone, even someone they shouldn't.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to show that spiritually sick or immature believers can be easily led astray by false teachings.

illustrations.title: Young Bob's Cult Encounter
illustrations.text: I was a Christian for less than a year, around 14 or 15 years old, and God was changing me as I began caring about spiritual things and respecting the Bible. I signed up for a free magazine from a TV show that seemed Christian, featuring a pastor teaching about the Bible in Greek and Hebrew. As I read it, my youth pastor Gary visited, saw the magazine, and wisely advised me to throw it away because it was from the Worldwide Church of God, a cult promoting false doctrines like denying Jesus's deity and teaching legalism.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob shares this personal story to illustrate how young or immature Christians can be deceived by cults if they don't know their Bibles well.

illustrations.title: Grandson Imitating Grandma
illustrations.text: My grandson lives at my house, and this is a normal daily experience. Here's a picture from yesterday—his eyesight is fine, even though he wears readers. He loves to put on his grandma Becky's glasses and use her cell phone; he only wants the Apple phone, not Android like me. He doesn't even care if the glasses are around his neck; he just watches and wants to do what he sees his grandma doing. She's on her phone with her glasses on, and he thinks that's cool. If he were imitating me, that might be different, but anyway, children naturally imitate their parents and grandparents.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate that children naturally imitate their parents, just as believers should imitate God.

illustrations.title: Peter's Defense in Gethsemane
illustrations.text: I'm sure Peter was confident he was honoring God as he attempted to defend Jesus in the Garden of Gethsemane. Peter went out defending Jesus and cut off the ear of Malchus, the servant of the high priest. Jesus healed the guy's ear right there, showing he cared about this person Peter had harmed. In a sense, Jesus had to restore the ear so the man could hear, while Peter's actions worked against that purpose.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how defending Jesus in the flesh, even with good intentions, can unintentionally harm those Jesus wants to save.

illustrations.title: Hireling vs. Shepherd Analogy
illustrations.text: Remember, there are two kinds of people that watch sheep: hirelings and shepherds. They both watch sheep and do pretty much the same tasks, but the hireling does it for what he gets out of it, like a paycheck, and runs when danger comes. The shepherd does it because he loves the sheep and is willing to lay down his life for them. When the wolf comes, the hireling says he's out of here, but the shepherd stays and protects.
illustrations.context: This analogy shows that true church leaders are motivated by love and sacrifice, not personal gain or position.

illustrations.title: Jesus' Critique of Pharisees
illustrations.text: Remember what Jesus said to the Pharisees: you search the Scriptures because you think that in them you have eternal life, and it is they that testify about me, but you're not willing to come to me and humble yourself so that you may have life. This shows that being deeply into the Bible isn't enough if you're missing the personal connection. Pastor Bob uses this to highlight the need for love alongside knowledge.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that the goal of instruction is not just biblical accuracy but also a loving relationship with God, as seen in the church at Ephesus.

illustrations.title: Saints in Church Analogy
illustrations.text: There's an old saying: 'To dwell above with the saints we love, that will be glory. But to dwell below with the saints we know, well that's another story.' There's Brother and Sister Sandpaper, Ronald Religion, and Susie Spiritual—these people might be hard to deal with. Guess what? They're in the body of Christ to train us to become more like the Lord, who loved us when we were total sinners.
illustrations.context: This analogy illustrates that being in church with imperfect people helps Christians grow in love, as evidence of true faith.

illustrations.title: Boy Walks to Loving Church
illustrations.text: There was a little boy who would walk a long way, a mile or two, to go to church every Sunday. One of the neighbors saw him and asked where he was going, and he explained he was heading to D.L. Moody's Church. The neighbor pointed out there were closer churches and asked why he bothered. The boy replied, 'They really know how to love a fellow down there; I feel the love of God there.' We don't want to just be experts on theology; remember this story.
illustrations.context: This example shows that genuine love in a church is a key evidence of God's presence and draws people to it.

illustrations.title: Misleading Book on Hugging
illustrations.text: A man thought he needed a book on how to hug, so he bought it, took it home, and made a cup of coffee to read it. But it turned out to be an encyclopedia volume that only listed the words from 'how to' without any real substance. This illustrates how some people go to church expecting to experience God's love but end up with just dry theology.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that attending church for knowledge alone doesn't fulfill the need for genuine love and relationships.

illustrations.title: Service Without Love Example
illustrations.text: If you go to the DMV tomorrow morning, you'll see people serving you without any real care. Or visit a particular restaurant where a waitress serves customers but resents their existence the whole time. This proves that serving others doesn't always come from love.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob emphasizes that true love naturally leads to serving, but serving alone doesn't guarantee love.

illustrations.title: Remembering My Dad's Imperfections
illustrations.text: I remember when my dad died, and he wasn't a perfect man by any means. I thought I'd never get a chance to fix our past issues, but God told me to honor him anyway. God reminded me that while my dad helped with things like my taxes, He is my true eternal Father who has always been there for me. He said that every imperfection in my dad was meant to teach me that I needed a perfect heavenly Father. God has never failed me, watching every step I took and celebrating my achievements.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to show that God is the perfect Father who compensates for the shortcomings of human fathers and desires a close relationship with us.

illustrations.title: Boy's Shame and Redemption
illustrations.text: The white-haired man pointed to a mountain and described a small town at its base where a boy was born out of wedlock, facing stigma in a time when such births were frowned upon. The boy grew up in shame, constantly questioned about his father, and isolated from other children who wouldn't play with him. He avoided social situations and even stayed inside during recess to escape mockery. Eventually, a new, loving preacher arrived in town, drawing the boy to church with his charismatic and non-judgmental message about God's love. The boy began to feel hope and warmth in his heart through the preacher's words about Jesus and the Heavenly Father.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate how God's love can bring hope and acceptance to those feeling shame and isolation.

illustrations.title: Ben Hooper's Transformation Story
illustrations.text: A little boy in church was asked by the preacher, 'Whose son are you?' The entire church gasped and leaned in to hear his answer, as everyone in town wondered about his parentage. The preacher grinned and said, 'Wait a minute, I know whose son you are. You're a child of God,' and patted him on the shoulder, telling him to claim that inheritance. That affirmation changed the boy's life forever; he began telling people, 'I'm a child of God,' and grew up to become the governor of the state. This elderly man later shared how that moment shaped his entire future.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate that anyone can discover and claim their identity as a child of God, regardless of their background or history.

illustrations.title: Paco and Father's Forgiveness
illustrations.text: True story: In Mexico City, with millions of people, a father and son had a falling out, and the son ran away in anger. The desperate father, whose son's name was Paco, searched everywhere, called everyone, and even the police, but couldn't find him. Finally, he placed an ad in the paper saying, 'Paco, all is forgiven. Meet me at the park at noon on Sunday. Signed, Dad.' When the father arrived at the park, 800 men named Paco showed up, revealing how common such pain is.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate how people can bring their damaged relationships with their fathers to God for healing and forgiveness.

illustrations.title: Pastor's Fatherhood Regrets
illustrations.text: Every one of us who's a father has regrets, and we feel like when people say you did the best you can, I say don't lie, I didn't. I need forgiveness for the fact that I didn't do the best that I could. I know I'm not totally responsible for my children's choices, but I'm responsible for mine, so there's a lot of regret, grief, and frustration for many people in this area.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that people need to let go of the imperfections of their fathers or their own failings and seek forgiveness.

illustrations.title: Father Runs to Prodigal Son
illustrations.text: The Bible says that God ran just one time. You know the story: the father ran to receive his rebellious son back home. It doesn't say the son was running home, but when the father saw his son on the horizon, he ran to him. This was undignified in that culture for a man to run, yet he did it anyway.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating God's eagerness to forgive and welcome back those who seek forgiveness, emphasizing healing in family relationships.

illustrations.title: My Dad and Forgiveness Journey
illustrations.text: I have no anger in my heart toward my dad. I realized I failed him as much as he failed me, maybe even more, and my God has shown me that He put me with that man to help me learn to be patient and forgiving as a child. You might say no child should have to learn that from their father, but I think every child needs a father, and I've got a long way to go as a father. I'm a Christian, I'm a pastor, my sons were raised in the church, but I still have an old nature and I still fail and sin. My children can tell you about my sins; I have plenty of failings, and they help me to be humble. That my kids even want to be around me is a shocker.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates that family relationships teach patience and forgiveness, highlighting personal failings and God's role in healing.

illustrations.title: High School Bands Memory
illustrations.text: I remember when I was in high school, all these bands were coming out of Calvary Chapel of Costa Mesa during the Jesus Movement. There was Love Song, Country Faith, Children of the Day, and all these groups. One group got started and they called themselves Sanctified, and I remember they came and performed. This story shows how the word 'sanctified' was used in popular culture. It's a personal reminder of how theological terms can appear in everyday contexts.
illustrations.context: To illustrate that 'sanctified' is a theological word many Christians hear but don't fully understand, connecting it to Paul's teaching on sanctification.

illustrations.title: Band Name Change Story
illustrations.text: I had heard them play at Calvary and they called themselves Sanctified, but they changed their name to The Road Home because hardly anybody knows what the word sanctified means. I remember going up after the concert and asking why they changed their name. They explained that the term was unfamiliar to most people. This story shows how common misunderstandings about spiritual words like sanctification persist even today.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to illustrate that many people, even in his audience, don't understand sanctification, leading into its explanation.

illustrations.title: Pen and Eyeglasses Analogy
illustrations.text: Somebody has defined sanctification as the state of proper functioning, to set a person or thing apart for the use intended by its designer. For instance, a pen is sanctified when it's used to write, not thrown at a barking dog. Eyeglasses are sanctified when they're used to improve sight. In the theological sense, things are sanctified when they're used for the purpose God intends, so a human being is sanctified when living according to God's design and purpose.
illustrations.context: This analogy explains that sanctification means being used for God's intended purpose, just like objects functioning as designed.

illustrations.title: Finger Cutting Analogy
illustrations.text: I cut off a piece of my finger years ago, but I'm still here inside. If you cut off a whole finger, I'd still be inside. If you cut off my arm, I wouldn't like it, but I'd still be inside. If you keep cutting, eventually you'd get to me, but I am not my body. I live in my body, which is part of how I express my spirit and soul.
illustrations.context: To show that a person is more than their physical body and that the body is a temporary dwelling.

illustrations.title: Steak Dinner Analogy
illustrations.text: Let me use this as an illustration. Let's say I decided to have a steak for dinner. This helps explain the idea of full surrender to Christ, as discussed in the Revelation passage about being lukewarm.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating the need for complete surrender to Christ rather than partial commitment.

illustrations.title: Steak Digestion Analogy
illustrations.text: We buy some nice chuck steak, cook it up, and I eat it. It goes down into my stomach where the stomach juices come out to dissolve it, and they say hello Mr. Steak, we're here to dissolve you into Bob Kopeny. Mr. Steak says I don't want to be dissolved; I want to keep my steak identity. The juices explain that it's time for you to become part of Bob Kopeny. If the steak refuses, there's a battle, and eventually, my body will reject it.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the spiritual battle when one refuses to surrender their identity to Christ.

illustrations.title: Losing Life for Christ Quote
illustrations.text: Jesus said that he who saves his life will lose it, but he who loses his life for my sake will find it. This connects to the idea of surrendering one's identity. John the Baptist also said, 'He must increase, I must decrease,' emphasizing the same principle of submission to Christ.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to show that holding onto one's life leads to loss, while surrendering it to Christ brings true life.

illustrations.title: Obey Better Than Sacrifice Song
illustrations.text: Keith Green sang a song about how to obey is better than sacrifice, with the Lord speaking through it. In the song, he says God doesn't want just Sunday and Wednesday nights; He wants every part of your life. This highlights the need for full obedience and surrender in all areas.
illustrations.context: This quote emphasizes that God desires complete obedience in every aspect of life, not just partial commitment.

illustrations.title: Salvation as God's Work
illustrations.text: Someone once said the only contribution that I really make to my salvation are the sins that need to be forgiven, and the only work of man that'll survive in heaven will be the nail prints in Jesus's hands and feet. Well, it's a work of God from start to finish. This emphasizes that God handles everything in our salvation.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to show that salvation is entirely God's work, highlighting His faithfulness and role in sanctification.

illustrations.title: John Carson's Rubberband Theology
illustrations.text: I like what John Carson told his children years ago when they were young. He said, 'You're the Lord's; I dedicated you to Him. You can run as far away from me and the Lord as you want, but I believe in rubberband theology. Because you're the Lord's, you can run, but you're going to come back. It's just a matter of how much you want it to hurt when you come back.' This illustrates that running from God leads to inevitable return with potential pain.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to show that God will complete His work in us, and resisting only causes more suffering.

illustrations.title: Moving a Log with the Spirit
illustrations.text: Picture a big old log that needs to be moved, and you're saying, 'I can't move it.' The Spirit of God says, 'I'm going to help you deal with that sin, that addiction, that problem, that attitude, that past, whatever it is.' You want God to take it away, but He says, 'I won't take it away until you come and take your part, because it's about working together.' This means the Spirit helps us by being on the opposite side, lifting with us as we participate.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that the Holy Spirit helps us in our weaknesses, but we must actively participate in the process.

illustrations.title: Esther's Year of Preparation
illustrations.text: In the book of Esther, Esther, a Jewish woman, was chosen as the most beautiful in the Persian Empire after a massive contest, essentially becoming Miss World, and married the heathen king. It's an incredible story of how God redeems, sanctifies, and beautifies. For a year before her royal wedding, she underwent beauty treatments, not just for weight loss or the dress, but including oils for six months, to prepare herself fully. Can you imagine dedicating a whole year to get ready for such an event? This highlights the effort involved in preparation. Ultimately, it shows God's hand in making her ready.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that believers, like Esther, have a responsibility to prepare themselves as the bride of Christ in the process of sanctification.

illustrations.title: Household Vessels Analogy
illustrations.text: Paul uses an illustration of a household with all kinds of different bowls, just like you have at home with really good stuff that you bring out and shine for holidays or when certain people come. Then you have the daily stuff or paper cups for everyday use. In 2 Timothy 2:21, Paul says if anyone cleanses himself from the things he's been describing, he will be a vessel for honor, sanctified and useful to the master, prepared for every good work.
illustrations.context: This analogy shows how sanctification makes believers more honorable and useful to God, like special household vessels set aside for important occasions.

illustrations.title: Pastor's Prayer Struggle
illustrations.text: I had to come to a place in my Christian life where I admitted to God that I believed in prayer but wasn't good at it. I was called into ministry, loved studying and teaching the Bible all day, and would give a little prayer beforehand, but I didn't pray for anybody afterward. Personal prayer just didn't come naturally to me, and I struggled with it.
illustrations.context: This personal story emphasizes that growing in holiness requires making prayer a priority, even if it's challenging for individuals like the pastor.

illustrations.title: Jesus in Gethsemane Retelling
illustrations.text: I believe if you read about Jesus in the Garden of Gethsemane, you'll discover that Jesus, the perfect sinless Son of God, asked his disciples to pray for him. He told them his soul was sorrowful to the point of death and urged them to pray so they wouldn't enter into temptation. Even though they failed, Jesus invited them to participate in his agony, showing he wanted their involvement in his ministry.
illustrations.context: To emphasize that even Jesus, who needed no help for his mission, asked others to pray, highlighting the importance of requesting prayer from others.

illustrations.title: Prayers as Incense Analogy
illustrations.text: When you see people praying for each other at church, I just inhale and think about what the Bible says—that the prayers of the saints are counted as incense before God. The incense offering was a cloud of fragrant smoke rising from the temple up into the heavens, picturing God receiving and being blessed by it. This shows that our prayers are a pleasing offering to God, like a sweet fragrance.
illustrations.context: To illustrate that God values and is blessed by the prayers of believers, encouraging active participation in prayer.

illustrations.title: James the Just's Devotion
illustrations.text: James, the brother of Jesus, did not believe in him until after the resurrection, as mentioned in First Corinthians 15, where Jesus appeared to him and he got saved. He became the leader of the Jerusalem church, as seen in Acts 15, and was known as James the Just. He was allowed into the holy place because he spent his life in prayer, and his knees were as hard as a camel's from the hours he spent begging God for forgiveness for his people. This paints a picture of how we should intercede for others.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize the importance of persistent intercession and prayer for others.

illustrations.title: Jesus's Intercession for Disciples
illustrations.text: Jesus ever lives to make intercession for us, as the Bible tells us. Throughout the Gospels, he prays for his disciples, like when he sends them out on the boat and goes up on the mountain to pray, seeing them struggle. In the Gospel of John, there's an entire chapter on his high priestly prayer, where he says to Peter, 'Satan desires to sift you like wheat, but I have prayed for you.' This shows how praying for others is key to becoming more like Jesus.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates that true sanctification involves praying beyond ourselves, just as Jesus does.

illustrations.title: Job's Restoration Through Prayer
illustrations.text: In Job 42:10, the Lord restored the fortunes of Job when he prayed for his friends. The Lord then increased all that Job had twofold. This story shows that God waits to bring restoration in our lives until we are willing to pray for others.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to point out that praying for others is necessary for God to work restoration in our lives.

illustrations.title: Children's Letter on Kissing
illustrations.text: Somebody gave me years ago a little book of children's letters to God, called 'Dear God.' In this book, one kid wrote: 'Dear God, I went to a wedding the other day and they kissed right in church. Is that okay?' This illustrates a child's innocent confusion about public displays of affection in church, which Pastor Bob uses to transition into explaining cultural norms. It's a light-hearted way to address the topic without judgment.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to humorously explain the cultural context of the holy kiss, emphasizing that greetings in church vary by culture and should foster fellowship.

illustrations.title: Ancient Greeting Customs
illustrations.text: In that culture, the men would kiss the men, the women would kiss the women, and they would acknowledge one another at the communion service. In our culture, you might say greet one another with a holy handshake or a holy hug. The word 'greet' in Greek means to unfold in the arms, like a hug, symbolizing warm embrace and connection. This historical practice shows how early Christians expressed fellowship physically.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that biblical greetings like the holy kiss were cultural expressions of deeper fellowship, encouraging modern believers to connect more intimately in the church.

illustrations.title: Pearl Parable Retelling
illustrations.text: The kingdom of God is like a merchant seeking fine pearls. Upon finding one of great price, he sells all that he has to obtain it. The pearl represents the church, which is like an impurity accepted into the heart of an oyster, covered with its own life to become precious. That's us, the Bride of Christ, formed from imperfection into something valuable.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that the church, like a pearl, is made precious through God's process despite human flaws.

illustrations.title: Church as Support System
illustrations.text: As a church, we are to be an emergency room for the injured and the wounded and the sick. We are also to be a maternity ward for those yet to be delivered and an incubator for the newborn believer. We're to be a family and a flock, a place to belong, a boot camp for those that are teachable, and a launch pad for those that are empowered and equipped.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that the church should be a multifaceted community providing support, growth, and belonging for people in various spiritual stages.

illustrations.title: God's Word as Wonder Bread
illustrations.text: I like to call it God's Wonder Bread. Remember those old commercials where Wonder Bread builds strong bodies twelve different ways? Well, God's Word is like Wonder Bread; it blesses and burns, convicts and converts, cleanses and constructs, detects and directs, enlightens and encourages, heals and gives hope, inspects and inspires, protects and perfects, restores and renews, revives and reminds, satisfies and sustains, teaches and transforms. Besides all that, it's perfect, permanent, and precious beyond words.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating the comprehensive benefits of God's Word to show how it aids in sanctification and spiritual growth.

illustrations.title: Bible as Greatest Story Never Read
illustrations.text: Someone has called the Bible the greatest story never read. There are so many Christians who have never read their whole Bible, even though they've read many other books, some harder to understand. This highlights that despite its importance, the Bible often goes unread among believers. Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize the need to engage with it fully for spiritual transformation.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that believers must read and share the entire Bible to grow in sanctification and become more like Jesus.

illustrations.title: Billy Graham's Speeding Ticket
illustrations.text: Years ago, Billy Graham told a story about when he was becoming well-known and traveling through the South. He got pulled over by a police officer for speeding and knew he was guilty. He appeared before a judge, pled guilty to the ticket, and that's when the judge realized he had the world-famous evangelist in his courtroom.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate that God's grace involves facing consequences but ultimately offers redemption.

illustrations.title: Billy Graham's Speeding Ticket
illustrations.text: The judge said, 'I have to find you guilty. You are guilty.' Then, he took out his own wallet and paid the speeding ticket for Billy Graham. Afterwards, Billy Graham took the judge out for a steak dinner and explained that the payment was mercy—not getting what he deserved—and the dinner was grace—getting something he didn't deserve.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate the concepts of mercy as not getting what is deserved and grace as receiving what is not deserved.

illustrations.title: Billy Graham's Return Message
illustrations.text: Watch this less than two-minute clip of Billy Graham from Anaheim Stadium in 1969. There's only one hope, expressed by Jesus Christ when he said, 'If I go and prepare a place for you, I will come again.' Blessed is that servant whom his Lord finds so doing when he comes. The temptation for many Christians is to sit back and wait, but you might be left behind, just like the five foolish virgins who let their lamps go out.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize the need to stay active and prepared for Christ's return rather than becoming complacent.

illustrations.title: Five Foolish Virgins Parable
illustrations.text: You remember the five foolish virgins in the story Jesus told. They thought the Lord was delayed, grew tired, and let the oil in their lamps run out. When he finally came, they were left behind. This illustrates the danger of not staying ready for his arrival.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this biblical story to warn that Christians must remain vigilant and active, or they risk being unprepared for Christ's coming.

illustrations.title: Pastor's Early Life Reflection
illustrations.text: When I watched that clip, I realized I was 12 at the time of that crusade. I wasn't there, wasn't saved, and probably wouldn't have gone even if invited. I didn't get saved for another year, but I loved what Billy Graham focused on about having your bags packed and being ready. This reminded me of how messages like that can impact us later in life.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob shares this personal story to highlight the timeless relevance of preparing for Christ's return, even if one isn't ready at first.

illustrations.title: Ignatius's Handball Readiness
illustrations.text: Ignatius lived in the end of the first century into the second century. He was playing a game of handball and asked the other believers with him, 'Suppose you knew Jesus was coming back in 20 minutes, what would you do?' One person said, 'I'd pray,' and another said, 'I'd share the gospel with an unbeliever.' When they asked Ignatius what he would do, he replied, 'I'd finish my game,' meaning he was already ready. In other words, if we think of anything we'd do differently, we should do it to be prepared for Christ's return.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize the need to be always ready for Christ's return by living in a state of preparedness.

illustrations.title: Escaping Home Life Example
illustrations.text: I know many people go away to college to escape their home life. I know a lot of people just leave to escape a bad situation. And so, the idea of a homecoming might be the last thing they want, but it contrasts with God's desire for a spiritual return.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that while some people flee from negative home situations, God offers a welcoming spiritual home through a saving relationship.

illustrations.title: Living Water Analogy
illustrations.text: There's dry and weary lands where there is no water, but God is a spring, a well of living water. If you're in a dry and weary land or a desolate place right now, know that if you put yourself where God is and make yourself available to him by giving him your heart, you'll find that you'll never thirst again.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that even in times of spiritual dryness, surrendering to God provides endless refreshment and joy.

illustrations.title: Memories from Music Listening
illustrations.text: I remember years ago, my family was going out for the evening, but I wasn't feeling well, so I stayed home on the couch. I had a CD player playing just the music of a song our church was going to do at Easter about the Lord, and I listened with my eyes closed. As I listened, memories of the highlights of my whole life started coming to mind, from my childhood to the present, including my wedding day, graduating high school, my sons being born, my grandchildren, and starting this church. I thought it was awesome and didn't want my family to come home too early. I even said that if I'm ever in the hospital without pain, play this song, because it was about choosing to think on praiseworthy things.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show the value of focusing on positive, praiseworthy aspects of life, which reflects entering God's presence and appreciating His love.

illustrations.title: Harvest Crusade Memories
illustrations.text: I used to do them for three nights at the Anaheim Stadium. These are two nights at what I call the pond, the Honda Center, and it's a free evangelistic outreach by Greg Laurie with amazing great Christian artists like Phil Wickham and Chris Tomlin and a whole bunch of others.
illustrations.context: To encourage attendance and participation in the upcoming Harvest Crusade by sharing personal experiences of past events.

illustrations.title: Baptism at Pirates Cove
illustrations.text: If you've seen the Jesus Revolution, you saw Pirates Cove, that's where Greg Laurie got baptized, but we're going back. We used to do them all there, and we've been doing them in the courtyard, but we feel it's time, so we're going to do a beach day picnic day for the church and then a baptism.
illustrations.context: To promote the upcoming baptism event by connecting it to the historical significance of Greg Laurie's baptism as shown in the Jesus Revolution.

illustrations.title: Harvest Crusade Encounter
illustrations.text: I went to a Harvest Crusade years ago with my neighbor who was only coming because we invited his teenage son to hear the gospel. The dad said he was going to check it out, and before the event started, they showed 'agape love' on the big screen. He leaned over to me, his name was Ron, and asked, 'What is a guppy love?' I explained it to him, and that night, he and his son received Christ—it was pretty amazing.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to show that some people are unfamiliar with 'agape love' and how sharing it can lead to life-changing faith.

illustrations.title: Hope as Life's Anchor
illustrations.text: When the Bible speaks of hope in the New Testament, it's not like our casual 'I hope this happens.' The word in Greek means confident expectation, something we know will occur. The hope of a Christian is described in the book of Hebrews as an anchor in the storms of life that holds us steady.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that biblical hope is a reliable and steady force that provides stability during life's challenges.

illustrations.title: Carl Barth's Theology Summary
illustrations.text: Some of you know the name Carl Barth, who was one of the leading theologians of the 20th century. He dedicated his life to writing Church Dogmatics, a massive 14-volume work that spanned over six million words, explaining the theology of the New Testament. Late in his life, when asked to summarize his theology, he simply said it could be reduced to a song his mom taught him as a kid: 'Jesus loves me this I know, for the Bible tells me so.' This shows how the deepest truths boil down to God's love.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize that the core of theology and God's message is the simple truth of His love.

illustrations.title: Jesus on Marriage Origins
illustrations.text: Jesus is talking about divorce and remarriage in Matthew 19, where disciples question him based on the Old Testament. They say Moses allowed a certificate of divorce, but Jesus responds that it was permitted only because of people's hardness of heart. He explains that from the beginning, God created one man and one woman for life, saying what God has joined together, let no one separate, emphasizing the original plan of marriage.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that understanding God's original design requires going back to the beginning, as Jesus did, to grasp foundational truths about marriage and faith.

illustrations.title: Cain and Abel's Murder
illustrations.text: In the Book of Genesis, which means beginnings, we see the first man, the first woman, the first sin, and the first family, leading to Cain as the first murderer and Abel as the first martyr. Cain killed his brother Abel because his deeds were evil while Abel's were righteous, and this act stemmed from hatred as Cain was influenced by the evil one. Pastor Bob uses this story to warn about the dangers of hatred leading to murder.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates that believers should not hate others, as seen in Cain's story, which shows how evil deeds and hatred can result from rejecting righteousness.

illustrations.title: Cain's Envy and Downfall
illustrations.text: You know what Cain does? He starts with envy, which then becomes hatred and depression. God comes in Genesis 4 and says, 'Why is your countenance fallen? Why are you angry? If you do well, will it not be lifted up? But if you don't do well, sin is crouching at the door; it's desirous for you, but you must master it.' Cain refused this warning, allowing envy to spiral into anger and inward depression. This story shows the consequences of not mastering sin.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this retelling to illustrate how envy in Cain's life led to anger and depression, emphasizing the need to respond to God's warnings.

illustrations.title: Chief Priests' Envy of Jesus
illustrations.text: Envy is the key reason why the chief priests delivered Jesus up to Pilate. Even Pontius Pilate knew they had delivered Him up because of envy, as the Bible clearly states. This event parallels Cain's story, showing how envy can lead to betrayal and unjust actions. Pastor Bob highlights this to connect historical envy with spiritual truths.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this reference to show that the chief priests' envy mirrored Cain's, demonstrating how envy drives people to harmful deeds.

illustrations.title: Jesus' Quote on the Devil
illustrations.text: Jesus said to the Jews in John 8, 'You are of your father the devil,' just like Cain who was a murderer and a liar from the beginning. Pastor Bob explains that this quote connects the Jews' envy and actions to Cain's story, showing a spiritual lineage of sin. He uses it to emphasize why envy leads to destructive behavior, linking it directly to his point about faith and sin.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob employs this quote to illustrate that the envy of the Jews, like Cain's, stems from a devilish influence, underscoring the dangers of unfaithfulness.

illustrations.title: Cain's Murder and Deception
illustrations.text: God comes to Cain and asks, 'Where's your brother?' Cain replies, 'I don't know, am I my brother's keeper?' But he knew exactly where Abel was because he had buried him. God says, 'Your brother's blood is crying out to me from the ground,' revealing Cain as not only a murderer but also a liar.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that children of the devil can masquerade as true believers.

illustrations.title: Jesus on Murder and Lies
illustrations.text: Jesus said to the Jews in John 8, 'You are a murderer; your father the Devil is a murderer and a liar from the beginning.' I've been telling you the truth, and you want to kill me, showing you have the same characteristics as your father. This connects to the point that those influenced by evil exhibit murder and lies like Satan.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that individuals like Cain share attributes with the devil, such as murder and lying, to highlight how the children of the devil can pretend to be believers.

illustrations.title: Judas as False Disciple
illustrations.text: Judas was among the believers and even the disciples who were out ministering, but according to the Bible, he was the son of perdition and not saved. He never truly had salvation, serving as an example of someone who masquerades as a believer. This shows that not everyone who appears devoted is genuinely born again.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize that children of the devil can pretend to be true believers, contrasting with the security of genuine faith.

illustrations.title: Cop Patrol Exposes Wrongdoers
illustrations.text: I've shared this before. When I used to be a cop on the graveyard shift, my job was to patrol the parks that closed at 10 pm in La Habra. I'd turn off all my lights and spot a group of guys drinking beers, doing drugs, and other illegal activities. As soon as I turned on my headlights and spotlights, shining them in their eyes, they would scatter like cockroaches in every direction. They didn't thank me or admit guilt; instead, they ran because that's what people do when caught in the act by the light.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to show that people hate the light of Christ because it exposes their evil deeds, just as wrongdoers flee from police lights.

illustrations.title: Dead Fish Analogy
illustrations.text: Remember, any dead fish can go with the flow; it takes a live one to swim upstream. This means that it's easy for people to just follow the crowd without resistance. Pastor Bob uses this to point out that true Christians, like live fish, must actively go against the current of the world.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is emphasizing that Christians should stand against worldly pressures rather than conforming to them.

illustrations.title: John Wesley's Persecution
illustrations.text: I shared it before, but John Wesley was kicked out of the Anglican Church. He and his brother Charles preached revival, emphasizing the need for personal conversion, which wasn't taught in the church he came from. This shows how standing for truth often leads to opposition, as it did for them when they promoted genuine faith over tradition.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that proclaiming biblical truth, like Wesley did, can result in rejection from established systems.

illustrations.title: Wesley's Persecution Anecdote
illustrations.text: He was so used to persecution that on one occasion, he was riding his horse by himself and thought, 'I haven't had a single egg thrown at me in two or three days,' and it bothered him. He worried that he might be watering down the message or not honoring the Lord, so he got off his horse, knelt down, and started praying to search his heart. Unbeknownst to him, a man hiding behind a hedge saw him, picked up a brick, and threw it over the hedge. The brick missed, and Wesley saw it fall nearby, then thanked God, saying, 'Thank you, Lord, I still got it.' This story shows how deeply committed he was to his faith despite the hostility.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that true believers should expect and endure persecution for righteousness without diluting their message.

illustrations.title: Medical Emergency Example
illustrations.text: We had a gal who needed medical attention during first service, and our medics were there. Thankfully, her heart was fine, and they didn't need to use a defibrillator. If someone has no pulse or flatlines, they use a defibrillator to restart the heart, which shows evidence of life, just as spiritual signs show we're alive in Christ.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that physical signs like a pulse confirm life, and similarly, loving others confirms spiritual life.

illustrations.title: Funerals in Church
illustrations.text: It's not uncommon to find dead people in church; they're called funerals. This means that just being in church doesn't prove someone is spiritually alive. In fact, attending church is no guarantee of true faith.
illustrations.context: This shows that physical presence in church isn't evidence of being a true child of God.

illustrations.title: Pharisees and Scriptures Quote
illustrations.text: Jesus said to the Pharisees, who loved the Word of God: 'You search the Scriptures because you think that in them you have eternal life, but it is they that bear witness about me, yet you are not willing to come to me that you may have life.' This quote matters because it reveals that even deep study of the Bible doesn't lead to salvation without personally coming to Jesus. Pastor Bob uses it to emphasize that knowing the right things isn't enough for true faith.
illustrations.context: This quote demonstrates that merely engaging with Scripture, like the Pharisees did, isn't proof of being a disciple of Christ.

illustrations.title: Tertullian's Christian Love Quote
illustrations.text: Tertullian, a third-century church father, wrote in his work Apologeticus, chapter 39. He said that even the heathen, or unsaved people, say of believers, 'Look how they love one another,' because the unsaved hate one another. And how believers are ready to die for each other, while the unsaved are ready to kill each other. This early church father highlighted that there's a clear difference in how believers relate to one another.
illustrations.context: To demonstrate that the love among Christians is evident and distinct, serving as a mark of true discipleship as per Jesus' words.

illustrations.title: Girl's Unrequited Doll Love
illustrations.text: A mom was with her daughter who had her two dolls with her while they were out shopping. The little girl started crying, and when Mom asked what was wrong, she held her dolls tight. The girl said, 'I keep loving them and loving them, but they never love me back.' This story illustrates the frustration of one-sided affection.
illustrations.context: To show the difference between human or worldly relationships and the reciprocal love that comes from being transformed by God's love.

illustrations.title: Gang Member's Redemption Story
illustrations.text: I remember a guy years ago in our Sunday school ministry. We started doing background checks, and he came to me saying he should talk to me before the results came back. He shared his testimony about how he used to be in a gang, and there was a murder that happened where he was charged. He went to jail and got saved afterwards.
illustrations.context: This story illustrates that even those with serious sins like murder can be saved and transformed by faith.

illustrations.title: Jesus on Adultery
illustrations.text: When Jesus said, 'You shall not commit adultery,' but I say to you that everyone who looks on a woman to lust for her has committed adultery with her already in his heart. So Jesus gets to the heart of the sin issue, helping people understand that the commands of God describe the outward expression, while the inward expression is virtually the same sin as far as guilt.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating how Jesus expands the commandments to address internal sins, emphasizing that lust is as guilty as the act itself.

illustrations.title: Don Francisco's Song on Love
illustrations.text: Years ago, Don Francisco wrote a song that I happen to like, although it's convicting because it offers a good look at ourselves. In the song, it's portrayed as though Jesus is saying to his church: I don't care how many buses you own or the size of your sanctuary; it doesn't matter how steep your steeple is if it's sitting on a cemetery. I don't care if you pave your parking lot and put pads on your pews; what good is a picture-perfect stage if it's missing all the cues? The song emphasizes that what we need is love and truth, and it questions whether we've done the things Jesus said, like loving our wife, children, and others as servants.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this song to illustrate that true evidence of salvation is loving others through actions, not just religious activities or knowledge.

illustrations.title: Boy's Sacrificial Blood Donation
illustrations.text: You might remember the story of a little boy who had an older sister in grade school. She needed blood urgently, and they discovered that her little brother had the same blood type. They explained to him that his sister was sick and could die, and asked if they could use his blood to save her. He thought about it because he was scared, but he agreed. They took the blood and gave it to his sister, and she started responding immediately. They told him she was going to live and that he could go home, but he asked, 'When do I die?' because he thought they were taking all his blood.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate that biblical love involves sacrificial giving and willingness to die for others, emphasizing that reconciliation always requires a death.

illustrations.title: Hate as Devouring Food
illustrations.text: You cannot avoid hurt in this life; it's going to happen to you. But hate is the Devil's food; if you're feeding on it, you'll get full of it, and it'll eat you alive. You will hurt yourself and other people, and you need a change of diet.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating how holding onto hate internally destroys a person and harms others, emphasizing the need to let go for healing.

illustrations.title: Strength Through Christ Quote
illustrations.text: You might say you can't forgive, but Paul said, 'I can do all things through Christ who strengthens me.' This means that with Jesus' help, you can overcome any obstacle, including forgiving others. So, say it out loud and believe it for your life.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is showing that true forgiveness is possible only through Christ's empowering strength, countering excuses of inability.

illustrations.title: Man with Withered Arm
illustrations.text: When Jesus said to the man with the withered arm, 'Stretch forth thy hand,' it's not like he could have responded, 'You know how many times I've tried that just yesterday or earlier today.' But the moment Jesus commands it, that command itself provides the enablement to do it. This shows that we shouldn't make excuses based on past failures.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that Christ's command is the enablement needed to obey, overcoming human limitations.

illustrations.title: Peter Walking on Water
illustrations.text: If Peter and his buddies, without Jesus there, said, 'I'm gonna do a little walk on the water like Jesus,' it wasn't going to go over well. It didn't go over well even when Jesus was there, because when Peter got his eyes off of Him, he started to sink. This highlights that true obedience requires keeping our focus on Christ.
illustrations.context: This shows that attempting to follow Jesus without full faith and focus leads to failure, emphasizing the need for His presence.

illustrations.title: Cromwell's Army Deserter
illustrations.text: This is a true story from 1647 during England's Civil War. A deserter in Cromwell's Army had been sentenced to execution when the curfew bell sounded that night. However, the bell never rang because the man's fiancée hid in the bell tower, and when the clapper was pulled, it struck her instead, leaving her bruised and battered. Cromwell, moved by her sacrificial love, spared the deserter's life, declaring that curfew shall not ring because of her sacrifice.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that God's command to forgive and let go is enabled by His help, mirroring sacrificial love and redemption.

illustrations.title: Grace as a Reservoir
illustrations.text: God has placed so much grace in a reservoir for me, forgiving all that I've ever done, all that I'm still doing, and all the things I'll ever do in this life. They're all forgiven. He's asking me for just a couple drops of that reservoir for somebody who didn't defend a holy God or who offended you. If you say you don't have it to give, it's illogical because you do have it, or perhaps you never really received that reservoir to begin with. You can forgive by the forgiveness that he's poured into your life.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that believers have an abundant supply of grace from God to draw from in order to forgive others, just as they have been forgiven.

illustrations.title: Doctor and Great Physician Analogy
illustrations.text: If you go to the doctor and he finds something wrong, it's not a good day, but if that doctor has a cure for it, then it's manageable. I'm not the doctor, but our great physician has already provided the cure for the problem. So, don't get upset about discovering issues in your heart; it's the beginning of a good day if you let God work on it.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that discovering unforgiveness is not discouraging because God, like a great physician, has a cure for spiritual issues.

illustrations.title: Jesus and Stephen's Forgiveness Quotes
illustrations.text: Jesus said, 'Father, forgive them,' even though they were killing him and hadn't repented, showing that he wanted them forgiven. Stephen said, 'Don't lay this to their charge,' as he was being stoned. You can let go of anger and hurt towards someone who won't repent, just as Jesus and Stephen did, without needing reconciliation.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is using these quotes to show that forgiveness can be extended even without repentance or reconciliation, emphasizing the release of personal anger.

illustrations.title: Two Types of Christmas Listeners
illustrations.text: There are two types of people when it comes to Christmas music: those who only listen at 8 p.m. on Christmas Eve, like my father-in-law, and those who start listening in August, which I think is nuts. Then there are people ready for it as soon as Thanksgiving is over. This variety shows how Christmas music excites different people in unique ways.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is using this to engage the audience and transition into viewing Christmas songs as worship songs that convey timeless truths.

illustrations.title: Darkness in December Experience
illustrations.text: I like to watch the sunset as I eat lunch, especially in December when it's really dark. People tend to get a little depressed because of the literal darkness. There are also reasons to be upset and sad when we look at our world and see that it's dark.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show how the literal darkness of winter reflects the spiritual darkness in the world, setting up the contrast with Jesus' light.

illustrations.title: Matthew 2 Biblical Account
illustrations.text: In Matthew chapter two, light shines into the darkness and exposes it, as Herod tries to secure his throne by murdering many firstborns, though the Lord protected Jesus. Before Jesus showed up, there were 400 years of silence with no prophet in the land. The thing that broke God's silence was the cry of a baby, which is profound, and we see in Matthew 2 that there was much reason to cry, as it was not a darker time in history.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate how Jesus' birth breaks through darkness and silence, bringing light and hope into a profoundly dark period.

illustrations.title: Hark the Herald Angels Quote
illustrations.text: There's a moment in the song that says, 'Mild he lay his glory by, born that man no more may die, he broke silence but not just to speak but to save.' He came and was born for a purpose; his entire life he lived in the shadow of the cross. That is praiseworthy and a reason to sing, as it shows how good he is to us.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that Jesus came not just to speak but to save humanity, highlighting his purposeful life leading to the cross.

illustrations.title: Worship of Infant Jesus
illustrations.text: Jesus was worshiped by the wise men who came when he was just born, as a young child perhaps up to two years old. The shepherds also came the night he was born. Jesus didn't give a sermon or heal any of them; he just was there. This illustrates that he was worthy of worship from the start.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that Jesus is worthy of worship even before his death and resurrection.

illustrations.title: Don's Recovery and Visit
illustrations.text: Don has been recovering from open heart surgery for a year, and the Lord has protected his life. He told me he wasn't strong enough for two services on Sunday morning and might only handle a Wednesday night. I encouraged him, saying we'd take him however he could come, and then he texted back that he wanted to go for it, so he's coming to speak on January 1st.
illustrations.context: To illustrate God's protection and encourage attendance at the event featuring Don's prophecy update.

illustrations.title: Cultural Signs of Christmas
illustrations.text: There's that song 'It's Beginning to Look a Lot Like Christmas,' and I was thinking about how we all know the telltale signs in our culture that it's Christmas. Lights go up on the houses, and the malls are packed to the gills. I hope you haven't had to go to the mall; I went the other day, just dropping somebody off and not trying to find a parking space. People will aggressively fight you for their space anyway. Another sign is personally avoiding getting on the scale until the new year because there's no sense in it.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the everyday cultural indicators of Christmas to contrast with the powerful biblical sign of Emmanuel.

illustrations.title: Mountain Range Analogy
illustrations.text: Prophets often describe future events as if they are happening one after the other. It's almost like a mountain range where you see one peak and another peak right next to it. In reality, there's a huge valley of time between them, even though they look close from a distance.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how prophets perceive near and distant events as adjacent in their visions.

illustrations.title: Pentecost and Joel Retelling
illustrations.text: In the book of Acts, on the day of Pentecost, the Holy Spirit came upon the church, and people spoke in tongues and were filled with joy, confusing those watching. Some mocked them, saying they were drunk. Peter stood up, explained they weren't drunk, and quoted the prophet Joel, saying this is what was spoken of: in the last days, God will pour out His Spirit on all people, with young men seeing visions and old men dreaming dreams. However, parts of Joel's prophecy, like blood and fire, point to future events not fully realized then.
illustrations.context: This retelling demonstrates the Law of Double Fulfillment, where a prophecy has both an immediate partial fulfillment and a future complete one.

illustrations.title: Ahaz and the Enemy Alliance
illustrations.text: To briefly bring you into it, the background of this prophecy about Emmanuel is another prophecy given to Ahaz, who was the king of Judah at that time. Isaiah was prophesying during a period when the king of Israel, Pekah, had joined forces with the king of Syria, Rezin, and they conspired to attack the southern kingdom of Judah. Ahaz, the king of Judah, was terrified because of this huge army threatening them. There were many wars between Israel and Judah, contrary to what we might think of as a united family. Isaiah was sent to deliver a word of encouragement to Ahaz, as detailed in the beginning of the chapter.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this retelling to illustrate how biblical prophecies have historical contexts and partial fulfillments leading to greater ones.

illustrations.title: Punks as Firebrands Analogy
illustrations.text: Don't be afraid of these, let's call them punks. I think on Fourth of July, that's kind of like two firebrands that are smoking. Basically, you're not gonna have to worry about these because they're insignificant threats.
illustrations.context: To illustrate that the threatening kings and their armies are not to be feared, as they are weak and fleeting like dying embers.

illustrations.title: Civil War Between Kingdoms
illustrations.text: Actually, 200 years before this, there was another civil war between Israel and Judah. Judah had 400,000 soldiers, and Israel had 800,000 coming against them. King Abijah told King Jeroboam that God established the true kingdom through David and the priesthood through Aaron, accusing them of selling the priesthood for money and calling them fake.
illustrations.context: To demonstrate that God upholds His chosen kings and priesthood, contrasting true authority with illegitimate claims in times of conflict.

illustrations.title: Overlooked Church Sign
illustrations.text: Now, look, our church, Calvary Chapel, has a sign out on the street. It's hard to see, but it's there and lit up at night. You may or may not have ever seen it. People have a hard time finding our church all the time, as some folks I knew drove right by it for years without noticing, even though they knew it was there.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that God's signs, like the one promised in the Bible, can be present but easily overlooked by people.

illustrations.title: City Sign Approval Analogy
illustrations.text: We do have a sign, but it's hard to find; you might need an arrow to spot it. In this city, every sign has to be approved by the government department. They permit it only if it meets their rules and jurisdiction. This illustrates how signs are regulated in the real world.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that just as cities strictly approve signs, God has only approved one sign for Christmas, the Virgin birth.

illustrations.title: Isaiah's Son as Sign
illustrations.text: This is a reference to the child that's going to be born in Isaiah's day, who is Isaiah's son. So, I approached the prophetess—that would be Mrs. Isaiah, by the way—and she conceived and gave birth to a son. Then the Lord said to me, name him. This shows how the prophecy connects to a immediate historical event in Isaiah's life.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to explain that the Isaiah prophecy refers to a child born in Isaiah's time, illustrating the fulfillment of God's promises in the prophet's era.

illustrations.title: Child's Christmas Misunderstanding
illustrations.text: Someone was asking their child, a little kid, 'Do you know why we celebrate Christmas?'
