The child replied, 'Yes, it celebrates when Jesus was born, and it was because Mary had an Immaculate contraption.' We laugh at this, but it highlights how many Christians mistakenly think the miracle was the birth itself. Pastor Bob uses this to clarify that the actual miracle was the conception.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that the miracle of Jesus was the conception, not the birth, correcting common misunderstandings.

illustrations.title: Wife's Instant Name Change
illustrations.text: On June 5th, 1982, it only took a moment for my wife to get her name changed. She just said 'I do' and suddenly, like that, her name was legally changed, her home address was changed, and her net worth was about the same. This illustrates how some changes happen quickly despite others taking time.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to show that significant changes, like God's deliverance, can occur in just a moment.

illustrations.title: Max Lucado's Phrase Reflection
illustrations.text: Max Lucado wrote this in one of his books, 'He Came Near,' which is a great book about the Incarnation and Christmas. He said, 'Ever thought about that phrase just a moment? We use it all the time, we hear it, we say it.' It's interesting to think about it from a deeper perspective, connecting it to how quickly life can shift.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that everything can change in just a moment, linking it to the suddenness of God's deliverance.

illustrations.title: Egg Fertilization Video
illustrations.text: I don't know if you've ever seen the videos of eggs being conceived; they show this flash of energy that happens in an instant. There's a moment when the egg is not fertilized, and suddenly it is, like an electrifying event that pronounces life. It's an amazing thing to witness under the microscope, highlighting how conception occurs in just a moment. Pastor Bob uses this to connect to the Incarnation, showing how quickly God can bring about change.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how God's transformative actions, like the Incarnation, can happen in an instant, mirroring the sudden flash of energy in conception.

illustrations.title: Sudden Answer to Prayer
illustrations.text: Have you noticed how sometimes you pray for things for years and might even give up, whether it's for someone to get saved or for change in your life? Then, suddenly, the Lord moves, and it's like doors fly open and things happen almost overnight. You feel like you're just watching as God swiftly brings about His will. This shows that when God's time is right, nothing can stop Him, encouraging persistence in prayer.
illustrations.context: This example emphasizes that God can change situations quickly, urging listeners not to lose hope and to keep praying.

illustrations.title: Mary's Conception Analogy
illustrations.text: It's very interesting you need to see the analogy: there's a prediction of a birth of a virgin conceiving and giving birth to a child, his name's going to be God With Us, but what happens in Mary is like this biological pattern. Jesus is born in her through the Holy Spirit, but it really is a picture of what has to happen in anybody else's life. The Holy Spirit caused Christ to come alive inside of her, and Jesus says to Nicodemus that the Holy Spirit has to do that with me inside of you.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to show that the Holy Spirit's role in Mary's conception illustrates the spiritual rebirth required for entering the kingdom of heaven.

illustrations.title: Gabriel's Visit to Mary Retelling
illustrations.text: After Gabriel comes to Mary and says you're going to be bearing the Son of God by the power of the Holy Spirit, she says well how, I've never known a man. Gabriel responds, don't worry about that, we got that figured out, and explains that the Spirit of God is going to come upon you. Mary doesn't ask questions or seek more details; she accepts it.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob retells this story to emphasize the miraculous work of the Holy Spirit in conception as a parallel to spiritual birth.

illustrations.title: Mary's Faith in Miracle
illustrations.text: The angel says to help Mary out, your cousin is also pregnant, which isn't a virgin conception but it's a miracle like Sarah's. She's an elderly woman, way past menopause and never expected to get pregnant, yet she's six months along. She's keeping it under wraps and didn't send any save-the-date notices, so Mary decides to visit her cousin first thing.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this retelling to illustrate how God encourages faith by showing another miracle, like Elizabeth's pregnancy, to strengthen Mary's trust in His plan.

illustrations.title: Zacharias Doubts the Angel
illustrations.text: Zacharias, the priest and the most spiritual in his family, had an angel appear to him, promising that his prayers for a son would be answered and that the child would be a forerunner of the Messiah. Instead of thanking God, he doubted and asked for proof, saying, 'How do I know this is really going to happen?' As a result, he was struck mute until the baby was born, teaching a lesson about faith. This story shows that even those close to God can struggle with belief.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to contrast Zacharias's doubt with Mary's faith, emphasizing that believing God's word requires the Holy Spirit.

illustrations.title: Isaiah's Emmanuel Prophecy
illustrations.text: In Isaiah's day, about 200 years before, two kingdoms were threatening with overwhelming odds, making it seem like defeat was certain. Yet, the prophecy of Emmanuel, meaning God is with us, assured the people that God would be present with them. This historical event illustrates that God's presence overcomes fear and destruction, even in the face of battles. It's a recurring theme of divine assurance.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob connects this to show that God's answer to every fear is His presence, just as in the biblical narratives.

illustrations.title: Raising of Widow's Son
illustrations.text: Do you remember when Jesus went to the city of Nain and as he was coming into town, there was a funeral for a widow's only son who had died? Jesus saw the sad procession, had compassion on the widow, touched the coffin, and the young man sat up. It was amazing, as he got out and went home with his mother. We know of Lazarus, but this was one of three times Jesus raised the dead: Jairus's daughter in private, Lazarus for his family, and this public resurrection of a complete stranger. The people were gripped with fear and glorified God, saying a great prophet has arisen and God has visited his people, which means Emmanuel, God with us.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to show that Jesus' miracle demonstrates he is Emmanuel, meaning God with us, as the people recognized God's presence.

illustrations.title: Jesus Calms the Storm
illustrations.text: When the disciples see Jesus calm the storm that they thought would kill them on the Sea of Galilee, he speaks the word 'hush, be still' to the storming winds. Then the Bible says they were more afraid of Jesus than the storm itself. Now the storm's gone and it's quiet, but the disciples are huddled in the boat, wondering, 'What manner of man is this that commands the wind and the sea, and they obey him?' That's an Emmanuel moment, showing God's presence with them.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that Jesus is Emmanuel, God with us, as his miracles reveal his divine authority.

illustrations.title: Jesus Walks on Water
illustrations.text: When Jesus is walking on the water, it's different from his other miracles like changing water to wine or healing the sick. In the Book of Job, it says God treads upon the sea, a thing only God can do. Jesus wasn't showing off but demonstrating that he truly is God with his people. This miracle highlights his divine nature while he serves and ministers to others.
illustrations.context: This shows that Jesus' miracles, like walking on water, prove his identity as God incarnate.

illustrations.title: Jesus at Lazarus' Funeral
illustrations.text: Remember when Jesus comes to Lazarus's funeral, not to his sick bed, even though he was invited earlier. He waits until Lazarus is good and dead, four days later, when no one expects a miracle. Mary and Martha tell him, 'If you had been here, my brother would not have died,' yet they speak with respect and faith, saying, 'Even now, whatever you ask God, He will give you.' This shows Jesus' perfect timing and the depth of their trust.
illustrations.context: This illustrates Jesus' deliberate timing in miracles to deepen faith and reveal his power over death.

illustrations.title: High School Friend's Tragedy
illustrations.text: I had a friend in high school who was Christian; we went to the same church and were in the same youth group. Her brother Joe died in a solo car accident after falling asleep at the wheel; he was a young man in his late teens or early 20s, and it was a terrible tragedy. We attended the funeral and graveside service, where the family was weeping, and the pastor shared some words before someone started singing the chorus 'He is here,' which goes: 'He is here, He is here, He is moving among us.' As we worshiped the Lord in the midst of that grief, the awareness of God's presence with us right then changed everything, and I can say the presence of God truly came upon us.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to emphasize the personal awareness of God's presence in the midst of tragedy, showing how it can transform circumstances.

illustrations.title: Group Worship Moment
illustrations.text: This group of about 50 of us was worshiping the Lord that morning. I can't explain it, but if you know what I'm talking about, you know. The Lord wants to be with you in the midst of your circumstances, even though he doesn't explain himself.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that God is present in our circumstances without needing to explain them.

illustrations.title: Job's Encounter with God
illustrations.text: All through the Book of Job, Job wants to talk to God and ask why he lost his kids, why he's sick, why he's lost his reputation, and why his wife tells him to curse God and die. Then God shows up and asks Job questions like, 'Where were you when I created the Earth?' God has two chapters of questions that Job can't answer. At the end, Job retracts and repents in dust and ashes, realizing he needed to know God was there, not the reasons behind his suffering.
illustrations.context: This retelling shows that in suffering, we need to know God's presence more than the reasons for our trials.

illustrations.title: David's Shadow of Death
illustrations.text: David says, 'Though I walk through the valley of the shadow of death, I will fear no evil.' He explains this is because God is with him. If we know God is with us, we can handle anything, even death or grief. This quote matters because it connects God's presence to overcoming fear in difficult times.
illustrations.context: This quote emphasizes that God's presence eliminates fear in the face of death and hardship.

illustrations.title: Paul's Second Journey Struggles
illustrations.text: Paul the Apostle sets out on his second missionary journey, led by the Holy Spirit through a dream of a Macedonian man calling for help. He travels to Philippi expecting a great revival, but instead faces arrest after casting a demon out of a slave girl, leading to imprisonment and beating. Despite these hardships, Paul continues his travels to places like Thessalonica, Berea, Athens, and Corinth, encountering opposition, riots, and mockery along the way, yet remaining faithful to his calling.
illustrations.context: This retelling shows that following God's call often involves unexpected trials and persecution, emphasizing perseverance in faith.

illustrations.title: Boy and School Bullying
illustrations.text: There's a story of a little boy who goes to school and comes home saying he doesn't want to go anymore. He tells his dad that bigger kids are pushing him around and taking his lunch money, and it's been happening for a week. The dad insists he must go, but says he's not going alone, so he takes the boy's hand and walks with him, ready to face the bullies together. This shows how God's presence changes everything when we face our fears.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that God's presence helps us endure and overcome challenges, just as the dad accompanies his son.

illustrations.title: Kids Bragging About Dads
illustrations.text: I heard another story of some kids sharing about their dads' jobs in class. One kid bragged that his dad is a lawyer and everyone knows him, another said his dad is a bank president in charge of all the money, and the third kid, whose dad was a construction worker, simply said, 'Well, my dad is here right now.' This speaks volumes about our kids' perspectives and reminds us that our Father in heaven is always present. Jesus comes to walk through every moment of your life.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize that Jesus is always with us, like a father who is present in our daily lives.

illustrations.title: Bill's Transformative Testimony
illustrations.text: Bill gave his life to the Lord, and it profoundly impacted him. His life is clearly changing, and he's full of excitement. He now sits on the front row every week when he comes to church. Bill's story encouraged me and made me aware that people are joining us, even amidst challenges.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses Bill's story to illustrate the encouraging impact of faith and church involvement on personal life changes.

illustrations.title: Nebraska Family Sends Picture
illustrations.text: Recently on a Wednesday night, I was sharing how people are watching but I can't see them, and I asked if they'd be willing to send me their information so I could know they're watching. One family did just that; they sent me a picture, and I think they were from Nebraska. I've never met them, but they introduced themselves through it. This shows how simple connections can build our church family.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to encourage online viewers to share their information so the church can connect, pray for them, and feel more united.

illustrations.title: Grandson's Baptism Excitement
illustrations.text: My grandson has told me every time he's around any water, 'Grandpa, can you baptize me?' I said sure, but not right now. He once asked at a pool, but I told him no because his mom and dad weren't there. Another time at Pirate's Cove, he wanted it right then, but I explained we wait for the proper time. He's six and a half, and we're waiting until he's ready.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to emphasize that children may express eagerness for baptism but should wait until they are truly ready, encouraging parents to guide the decision.

illustrations.title: Baptism of a Three-Year-Old
illustrations.text: I remember doing a baptism of a little girl many years ago; she was three, which is pretty young. I'm not saying a three-year-old can't receive Christ, because my wife was three when she received Christ. If someone understands well enough to receive Christ, I can't biblically see why they can't be baptized, though it's fine to wait if needed. This little girl wanted to be baptized, and her dad was very excited; he brought her down. His name was Mark, and I'll never forget it as the water was cold.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob shares this to illustrate that young children can be baptized if they genuinely understand faith, while respecting parental caution.

illustrations.title: Child's Baptism Hesitation
illustrations.text: My child said, 'No, Daddy, I don't want to be baptized.' I responded that I'm not sure if this could cause post-traumatic stress for her, so if she's not ready, we shouldn't push it. Instead, help them get prepared and decide when they're okay with it, but only sign them up if they're ready.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is emphasizing the importance of not forcing baptism on someone who isn't ready, while encouraging gentle preparation.

illustrations.title: Israel's Camp as Cross
illustrations.text: I have a picture I'd like to show you on the screen. This is how the children of Israel camped, in the form of a cross. If you looked at the nation of Israel from a distance, that's what you'd see. It's not that Balaam was thinking about the cross, but we can see it prophetically, as God had his people camp this way to foreshadow his plan.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate how God's arrangement of Israel's camp prophetically foreshadows the cross, showing that God reverses curses through Christ.

illustrations.title: Balaam's Compromise with Moabites
illustrations.text: In essence, what happens is the Moabite women meet the men because they were not far away and invite them to worship their God. That involved feasting, partying, and idolatry, bowing down to their gods, and then it involves sexual sin. This is the first time the children of Israel worship Baal, and it happens because these women are flirting with them and bringing them into this compromise. Idolatry is often connected with immorality in the Bible, as we see here. It's fascinating how this leads to God's judgment.
illustrations.context: To illustrate how the enemy changes strategy to lead God's people into idolatry and immorality, resulting in divine judgment.

illustrations.title: Israel's Golden Calf Worship
illustrations.text: Remember the golden calves when Moses was having a very long quiet time for 40 days on the mountain. We don't know what happened to him; he's probably up there with that angry God. Aaron had to lead us, and they said we need some gods to lead us, so they went after the Egyptian-type god with that golden calf right out of Egypt. This shows the nation of Israel bowing down to an idol even after being saved. It's an early example of their faithlessness.
illustrations.context: To connect the current story of idolatry with Israel's past sin, emphasizing that this is not the first time they turned to idols.

illustrations.title: Early Church Persecution
illustrations.text: For 300 years approximately, the original church was persecuted by 10 successive waves of persecution under the Roman Empire. Emperors like Nero, Hadrian, and Trajan tried to root out and destroy Christians, becoming increasingly ruthless by burning Christians alive and destroying Bibles. Despite their efforts to eradicate Christianity as an illegal religion, it only spread further as believers shared their faith and lived for the Lord.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that attempts to destroy the church through hostility ultimately fail and lead to its growth.

illustrations.title: Blood of Martyrs Quote
illustrations.text: There's an old expression associated with Fox's Book of Martyrs that even though they kept trying to kill Christians, Christianity just spread. The expression is 'the blood of the martyrs is the seed of the church.' This means that as Christians were willing to die for Jesus Christ, their witness inspired others who had never seen such dedication, leading to the faith's expansion.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob connects this quote to illustrate that persecution and martyrdom actually fuel the growth of the church.

illustrations.title: Early Christian's Dedication
illustrations.text: There was an early Christian who wanted to be arrested and killed for his faith, so he planned to turn himself in. His mother took his clothes away, leaving him naked and unable to go, which was the only reason he didn't get killed. This story highlights the intense passion early Christians had for the Lord, showing they were willing to die rather than deny their beliefs.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate the genuine faith of early Christians under persecution, contrasting it with modern counterfeit Christianity.

illustrations.title: Faith in Cuba
illustrations.text: In Cuba, there aren't many fake Christians because following Christ comes at a high cost, including potential persecution. This situation mirrors the early church where no one pretended to be a Christian due to the dangers involved. Pastor Bob points out that the church thrives under such conditions.
illustrations.context: This example shows that genuine faith flourishes in environments of persecution, reducing hypocrisy in the church.

illustrations.title: Constantine's Vision
illustrations.text: Constantine, the Roman Emperor, had a vision of the Cross before a battle and heard the words 'in this sign conquer.' He adopted the symbol, won the battle, and became a Christian, which led to Christianity becoming legal in the Roman Empire. Later, his mother Helen visited the Holy Land and identified sites related to Jesus' life, like his birth and burial places. This marked the shift from Christianity being persecuted to becoming the state religion.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to explain how Satan's strategy changed, turning Christianity from an illegal faith to a powerful, state-endorsed religion that attracted opportunists.

illustrations.title: Aquinas and Pope's Exchange
illustrations.text: In the 13th century, Catholic theologian Thomas Aquinas visited Pope Innocent II, who was counting a huge amount of money and remarked that the church could no longer say 'Silver and gold have I none.' Aquinas responded that neither could the church say 'Rise and walk,' implying it had lost its spiritual power amid material wealth. This interaction highlights the prosperity and corruption of the church over time. Pastor Bob connects this to the broader shift in the church's influence.
illustrations.context: This quote illustrates how the church's pursuit of wealth and power led to a loss of its true spiritual authority and mission.

illustrations.title: Phineas Confronts Sin Boldly
illustrations.text: We have this passage where it's interesting to see the different reactions to what's going on. The people are not only committing idolatry but also immorality, and God starts judging his people with a plague that breaks out and causes people to die. He commands in verse 4 that all the leaders involved are to be brought out and executed so that God might show mercy and stop the judgment. Then in verse 6, one of the sons of Israel brazenly brings a Midianite woman into the camp in the sight of Moses and all the congregation, even while the leaders are weeping at the doorway of the tent of meeting. Phineas, the son of Eleazar and grandson of Aaron the priest, rises up from the midst of the congregation, goes into the tent, and pierces both the Israelite and the woman through, killing them both. This action stops the plague, showing God's response to decisive action against sin.
illustrations.context: This story illustrates the principle that taking bold, decisive action against sin can turn away God's judgment and bring mercy.

illustrations.title: James on Mourning Sin
illustrations.text: Jot down James 4 verses 8 and 9: Draw near to God and He will draw near to you; cleanse your hands, you sinners; purify your hearts, you double-minded. Be miserable, mourn, and weep; let your laughter be turned into mourning and your joy into gloom. He's talking about the person who's in sin needing to grieve their sin, as mourning over sin is biblical. However, mortifying your sin is better than just mourning it, connecting this to the need for active repentance.
illustrations.context: This quote emphasizes that while grieving sin is important, believers must go further by actively putting sin to death for spiritual growth.

illustrations.title: Jesus on Radical Sin Removal
illustrations.text: Jesus said if your hand or your foot causes you to stumble, cut it off and throw it away. It's better for you to enter life crippled or lame than to have two hands or two feet and be thrown into eternal fire. And if your eye causes you to stumble, pluck it out and throw it away. He used these radical words to emphasize getting serious about sin. This teaching shows we must deal with sin decisively.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that people must take extreme measures to deal with their own sin, not just weep over it.

illustrations.title: Saul's Partial Obedience Failure
illustrations.text: God sent King Saul to wipe out the Amalekites, including their livestock and everyone, because they opposed God's people. Saul went on the mission and killed most of them, but he spared King Agag as a trophy and brought back some of the finest animals. When confronted, Saul claimed he had obeyed, but God rejected him for not following instructions fully. This story highlights that partial obedience is still disobedience. God was dealing with sin like removing cancer.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that just like Saul, people must fully obey God to address sin, rather than doing only part of what is required.

illustrations.title: Saul's Disobedience Retelling
illustrations.text: Saul was supposed to destroy everything on the mission, but he wiped out most and kept the best animals. When Samuel confronted him, Saul claimed he was going to sacrifice them to the Lord and that keeping one man wasn't a big deal. Samuel rebuked him, explaining that this compromise was like the sin of rebellion, which is as bad as sorcery, and it brought God's discipline.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating how compromising God's commands leads to severe consequences and divine rejection.

illustrations.title: Obedience Over Sacrifice Quote
illustrations.text: Keith Green drew from this biblical story for his song, saying that to obey is better than to sacrifice. Pastor Bob explains that this highlights how rebellion in the heart is equivalent to sorcery and dishonors God. He connects it to the idea that partial obedience is still sin.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that true obedience to God is more important than religious acts or excuses.

illustrations.title: Doctor Visit Story
illustrations.text: I went to my doctor a few months ago for a checkup, and he noticed a spot on my skin that might be nothing but suggested we check it to be safe. I agreed, and he took a sample to send to the lab for early detection. A week later, he called me early in the morning, stressing the importance of addressing potential issues promptly.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that just as it's crucial to deal with potential health problems early, we must confront and eliminate sin in our lives as God commands.

illustrations.title: Melanoma Personal Experience
illustrations.text: I had a doctor leave a message that I missed, and when I finally got through, he told me it was melanoma. We had to keep cutting until we got clear margins, and thankfully it came back fine. This experience made me think about how sin works in our lives.
illustrations.context: Illustrates that sin, like cancer, must be completely removed to prevent it from growing.

illustrations.title: Sin as Cancer Analogy
illustrations.text: When it comes to sin, you have to think about it like cancer—it has to be cut out or it will grow. We often try to solve sin by changing our diet or taking the wrong medicine, but that doesn't work. God knows it must be dealt with directly, just as cancer requires surgery to get clear margins.
illustrations.context: Emphasizes that sin must be eradicated completely, not just superficially treated.

illustrations.title: Quote on Root of Sin
illustrations.text: Someone put it this way: for every man striking at the root of sin, there's a thousand hacking at the branches. This means we need to address the core of our sinful nature rather than just the symptoms. It's a reminder that true change comes from dealing with the root cause.
illustrations.context: Highlights the importance of tackling the root of sin instead of just the surface issues.

illustrations.title: Misspoken Sin Confession
illustrations.text: I heard the story once of this guy at the end of a service who felt really convicted about the way he was living. He walked up to the pastor for prayer, crying and beside himself with emotion. He meant to say, 'My life is so full of sin,' but instead said, 'My sin is so full of life.' The pastor thought, 'Yeah, that's true too; that's the problem.'
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate how sin remains active and dominant in people's lives, contrary to living dead to sin.

illustrations.title: Oprah's Misunderstanding of God
illustrations.text: According to Oprah Winfrey, the reason she stopped going to church was because a pastor said that God was a jealous God, and she couldn't understand what that meant. She thought it implied God was jealous of her, which led her to stop attending church from that point on. She even stopped believing that Jesus was the only way to heaven, as she shared on national TV, and it's very interesting how this affected her faith.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show how misunderstanding God's jealousy can lead people away from church and true faith.

illustrations.title: Cuba Mission and Family Encounter
illustrations.text: I've told you before that when I went to Cuba, I had the privilege of leading a 16-year-old man to Christ. We wrote letters to encourage him, and I gave him a Bible since he and his friend wanted to grow in their faith. When I returned, his father, a committed communist and atheist, invited me to their home to meet the family, concerned about his son's new beliefs. The whole family gathered, watching as we sat and talked through a translator. Despite the tension, his father welcomed me warmly, saying 'Mi casa es su casa,' which means 'My house is your house.'
illustrations.context: To illustrate God's jealousy for His people through a personal example of sharing faith in a challenging environment.

illustrations.title: Family Conversion Tale
illustrations.text: A joke broke the ice, and long story short, he comes to Christ. He winds up becoming an elder in Richard's later church. It's a fantastic story of the whole family giving their lives to the Lord that day, with the entire family receiving Christ—it was amazing.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the concept of godly jealousy, showing how God desires exclusive devotion without compromise.

illustrations.title: Phineas as Christ Analogy
illustrations.text: Phineas is a type of Christ; he turns away the wrath of God and ushers in a new covenant of peace. Just as Phineas's actions reveal God's mercy, this points to how Christ reconciles us to God. Through this, we see the establishment of peace between sinful people and a righteous God.
illustrations.context: This analogy highlights how Phineas's role foreshadows Christ's atonement and the new covenant of peace.

illustrations.title: Zimri and Cozbi's Deception
illustrations.text: In verse 14, the name of the slain man of Israel who was slain with the Midianite woman was Zimri, the son of Salu, a leader of a father's household among the Simeonites. He was a son of royalty or a tribal leader, and the Midianite woman was Cozbi, the daughter of Zur, who was head of the people of a father's household in Midian. These two from leader families were willful and arrogant; she was involved in sexual sin and idolatry, while he knew better but chose it anyway. Pastor Bob explains that sexual sin is deceitful, noting that Cozbi's name means 'Deceiver' and her father Zur's name means 'Honeycomb,' symbolizing false sweetness. This story highlights how such sin leads to destruction.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this biblical story to illustrate the deceitfulness of sexual sin and the dangers of arrogance.

illustrations.title: Proverbs on Seductive Words
illustrations.text: Jot down Proverbs 5 verses 1 through 4, where Solomon says: 'My son, give attention to my wisdom and incline your ear to my understanding, that you may observe discretion and your lips may reserve knowledge. For the lips of an adulterous drip honey and smoother than oil is her speech, but in the end she is bitter as wormwood, sharp as a two-edged sword.' Pastor Bob connects this to the story, explaining that sexual sin appears sweet and alluring like honeycomb but ultimately brings bitterness and harm. He emphasizes that this quote warns against the deceptive nature of temptation.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to show how sexual sin deceives with initial sweetness but leads to severe consequences.

illustrations.title: Honey Overindulgence Analogy
illustrations.text: Honey is delicious, but if you eat too much of it, it will make you sick. Have you found honey? Eat only what you need, unless you have it in excess and you vomit it. Of course, sexual sin is pleasurable, but it will ultimately destroy you.
illustrations.context: This analogy illustrates that just as overindulging in honey leads to sickness, overindulging in sexual sin leads to destruction.

illustrations.title: House of Rising Sun Quote
illustrations.text: There's an old song: There is a house in New Orleans, and if you know that song, it's been the ruin of many a poor boy—that whorehouse. The fact is, sexual sin will be enjoyable to you but it will destroy you and eat you alive. It's a warning about the destructive nature of such sins.
illustrations.context: This quote emphasizes that sexual sin may seem appealing but ultimately leads to ruin and destruction.

illustrations.title: Midianite War Retelling
illustrations.text: Moses sent them to war, a thousand from each tribe, together with Phinehas the son of Eleazar the priest, with the vessels of the sanctuary and the trumpets for the alarm in his hand. They warred against Midian as the Lord commanded Moses, and they killed every male. They killed the kings of Midian with the rest of their slain, including Evi, Rekem, Zur, Hur, and Reba, the five kings of Midian, and they also killed Balaam the son of Beor with the sword.
illustrations.context: This retelling illustrates the importance of fighting and not fraternizing with enemies, as compromise with the world makes one an enemy of God.

illustrations.title: Farmland Deal Compromise
illustrations.text: I heard a story once about a farmland deal where a guy wanted to buy a thousand acres, but the seller insisted on keeping one acre right in the middle. The buyer thought it wasn't a big deal and almost agreed, but he discovered that allowing that one acre would give the seller legal rights to build a road through the property. As a result, he refused the deal outright.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that giving Satan even a small foothold in your life leads to greater compromise and destruction.

illustrations.title: Samson's Compromise with Delilah
illustrations.text: You remember the story of Samson in Judges where the Philistines couldn't defeat him in battle. But Delilah seduced him and discovered the secret of his strength through deceitful kisses and persistence. Ultimately, his repeated compromises, including sexual sin, led to his downfall despite his godly calling as a Nazarite set apart from birth.
illustrations.context: This warns against being kissed into compromise, showing how seemingly small deceptions can lead to total spiritual defeat.

illustrations.title: Samson's Downfall to Lust
illustrations.text: Delilah weaves his hair and the Philistines are upon him, but he breaks loose and fights back. He keeps lying to her until she wears him down, and he finally tells her that if his hair is cut, he'll become weak. He doesn't realize the Philistines are coming, and when they do, he tries to fight as before but finds God's power has left him. They gouge out his eyes, shackle him, and make a mockery of him by forcing him to grind in the prison. That's what sexual sin and unchecked lust will do to you.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to warn that lust and sexual sin can lead to spiritual weakness and destruction if not addressed.

illustrations.title: Boy and the Rattlesnake
illustrations.text: It's a famous story of a Native American boy up on a mountain where it's cold, and he sees a rattlesnake that begs him to take it down because it's dying from the cold. The boy is hesitant, fearing the snake will bite him, but the snake promises not to. He takes the snake under his shirt to warm it, and as they reach the bottom, the snake bites him after being released. The boy, realizing he's going to die, asks why, illustrating how some dangers can't be trusted despite promises.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize the destructive nature of sin and the need to deal with it before it turns on you.

illustrations.title: Snake Compromise Warning
illustrations.text: A person picks up a snake, and later when it bites them, they ask why it did that. The snake hisses back and says, 'You knew what I was when you picked me up.' This story illustrates that we know the risks of our compromises but choose them anyway.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to warn that continuing in compromise will lead to dishonoring God and ruining aspects of life, urging immediate repentance.

illustrations.title: Sin as Monkey Wrench
illustrations.text: Sin has been called the monkey wrench in the machinery. Picture a big machine humming along smoothly, then a monkey wrench is thrown into it, causing lots of damage. That's exactly what sin does—it disrupts and harms everything.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob emphasizes that sin causes ongoing damage and won't improve without action, encouraging people to remove it from their lives.

illustrations.title: Trojan Horse Deception
illustrations.text: The imagery that kept coming to my mind was the battle against the city of Troy. The Greeks tried for 10 years but couldn't bring the walls down. So, as the story goes, they left a big wooden horse as a gift at the gate. The Trojans took it in, and that night, the Greek soldiers inside got out and conquered the city because they couldn't breach the walls directly.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate how an unexpected strategy can overcome seemingly impenetrable barriers, connecting it to themes of praise and spiritual breakthrough.

illustrations.title: Great Wall Deception Analogy
illustrations.text: The Great Wall of China was one of the Seven Wonders of the World, built to prevent invasions from the Mongols and others from the south. They never managed to break down the walls themselves. However, the invaders succeeded three times in history by bribing the gatekeepers, allowing entry despite the strong defenses.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that people can undermine their own defenses by allowing harmful influences in, just as the Chinese were invaded through betrayal from within.

illustrations.title: Exodus Journey Analogy
illustrations.text: We've been through our quote-unquote Egypt, experiencing good times and bad times in the desert and wilderness. We've been chained up and locked up, but we've been set free because Christ died on the cross for us. This journey has brought us into deliverance, leading us to where we stand now on the powerful name of Jesus Christ.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating how believers' spiritual struggles and deliverance mirror the Israelites' exodus from Egypt to the promised land.

illustrations.title: Car Accident Perspectives
illustrations.text: The idea is that Matthew, Mark, and Luke are looking at many of the exact same events but recording them individually. It's like if there's a car accident and you see it and I see it; we may see things a little differently. So, God has three witnesses providing slightly different angles on the same material.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how the Synoptic Gospels provide slightly different perspectives on the same events to give a fuller picture.

illustrations.title: Puzzle Box Preview
illustrations.text: You have the box of puzzle pieces with a picture on it showing how it's supposed to look. When you take it out, it doesn't look that way at first, and it might not when you're done if pieces are missing or you're tired. But if you have the time and all the pieces are there, that's what it could look like—it's a preview of what it's supposed to be.
illustrations.context: This analogy illustrates how Old Testament prophecies serve as a preview of Jesus' life and fulfillment.

illustrations.title: Road to Emmaus Encounter
illustrations.text: Remember the two on the road to Emmaus in Luke 24; they thought Jesus was the Messiah, but since he died on the cross, he couldn't be, and they were disappointed. As they walked along feeling bummed out, Jesus joined them, but they didn't recognize him. They explained to him about Jesus and their dashed hopes, and Jesus responded, 'Oh, you slow of heart to believe all that the prophets have written. Didn't you know the Messiah had to suffer?'
illustrations.context: This retelling emphasizes that the Old Testament is all about Jesus and highlights the importance of understanding the prophecies about his suffering.

illustrations.title: Emmaus Road Revelation
illustrations.text: They go into Emmaus, and Jesus takes the part of the host and breaks the bread. Their eyes are opened, and they recognize the living Christ. Then he disappears, and they feel a burst of energy, running back to Jerusalem to announce that Jesus is alive and they've seen him. They reflect on how their hearts burned within them when he opened the Scriptures and explained everything concerning himself in the Old Testament. This moment highlights the excitement of encountering Jesus through the Word.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize how hearts burn and come alive when Jesus is revealed in the Scriptures.

illustrations.title: Bezalel as Solomon Type
illustrations.text: Bezalel is actually a type of King Solomon. Moses receives the blueprint for the tabernacle but doesn't build it; instead, he gives it to Bezalel, who is Spirit-filled with understanding and wisdom. Similarly, David receives the blueprint for the temple but doesn't build it due to being a man of bloodshed; his son Solomon, a man of peace filled with wisdom, builds it. This comparison shows how God chooses specific, gifted individuals to construct His house.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates that God intends everyone to know who He chose to build His house, drawing parallels between Bezalel and Solomon.

illustrations.title: First House Buying Experience
illustrations.text: I remember years ago, Becky and I were looking to buy our first house, and it was a nervous time, especially when houses cost just a hundred thousand dollars—which seems laughable now. We couldn't afford anything in Orange County, so a friend who was a police officer invited us to see new homes in Riverside near the Tyler Mall. We toured the model homes, which were gorgeous with bay windows, plush carpeting, a huge master bedroom, and lush grass—it felt like a no-brainer. But when we visited my friend's actual house in the same complex, it was mostly empty with boxes everywhere, and I realized the stark difference between the perfect model and everyday reality.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate the difference between an ideal representation and actual reality, paralleling it to the idea that believers are the true house of God, not a physical building.

illustrations.title: My Poorly Furnished House
illustrations.text: I furnished a house that had some of his old junks, a lot of empty rooms, and it wasn't so good. The neighborhood was full of gang writings and drive-by shootings. As a police officer, I realized it wasn't the right home for us to live in, so I share that to introduce the idea of God's furnished house.
illustrations.context: To contrast a poorly furnished physical house with God's fully furnished spiritual house, emphasizing faith in Christ.

illustrations.title: Jesus and the Furnished Upper Room
illustrations.text: Jesus said to his disciples in Jerusalem, this man will show you a large furnished upper room; prepare the meal there. That's the night that Jesus said, I want to have this special meal with you and I want you to be in a furnished room. This illustrates how God provides a prepared place for significant events.
illustrations.context: To highlight how God furnishes spaces for spiritual purposes, like the Last Supper, connecting to the idea of God's provision in faith.

illustrations.title: Moses Saved in the Ark
illustrations.text: Then, at the beginning of the book of Exodus, we find a mini-ark with Moses on board. His mom, remembering what God did with Noah, makes a little ark when the Jews are supposed to throw their babies in the Nile. She puts him in there with tar, sets it on the water, and he is saved, drawn out of the water—that's where his name comes from. So, once again, salvation happens in the ark.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that the ark represents salvation through Christ, as seen in Moses' rescue.

illustrations.title: Manna as Living Bread
illustrations.text: Remember that the bowl of manna was how God provided supernaturally for His people in the desert during the 40 years. Jesus came and they said their forefathers ate manna in the wilderness, but Jesus replied, 'I am the living bread that came down from heaven to give you eternal life.' While their fathers ate the manna and still died, those who partake of Jesus will live forever.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is using this analogy to show that Jesus is the ultimate spiritual provision, like the manna, leading to eternal life.

illustrations.title: Aaron's Rod Budding Miracle
illustrations.text: There was a conflict between Aaron and the people who were jealous of their leaders in the nation of Israel while they were marching through the wilderness. They accused Aaron of thinking he was something special, as if they were all the same. So God told them to gather all the tribal leaders' rods, symbolic items for their tribes, and place them before the Lord in the tent of meeting. The next day, they returned to find that all the other rods remained unchanged, but Aaron's rod had budded into an almond tree, coming back to life and even producing fresh almonds. It was like a miracle, turning a dead rod into a little almond factory, clearly proving who God had chosen.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to show that just as Aaron's rod budding proved his divine selection, Jesus' resurrection proves He is the Son of God.

illustrations.title: Emmanuel as God With Us
illustrations.text: One of Christ's names comes from Isaiah 7:14, as we usually use it at Christmas. We're told that his name will be called Emmanuel, which means God with us. Therefore, the Lord himself will give you a sign: behold, a virgin shall be with child and bear a son, and his name shall be called Emmanuel. This is fulfilled in the book of Matthew, referring to Jesus. Jesus said, 'I am with you to his own even to the end of the age,' showing that God's presence is always with us.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to illustrate that Jesus, as Emmanuel, makes God's presence portable and enduring among his people.

illustrations.title: Disneyland Happiness Contrast
illustrations.text: You know, if you go to Disneyland, they used to have that sign 'happiest place on earth.' When I was a kid, that was true, but as an adult, you have to pay for it all, and it's not so sure—it's the most expensive place anyway. But if there was a sign in the tabernacle in the holy of holies, it would have been the holiest place in the universe.
illustrations.context: To emphasize that the tabernacle is the holiest place, contrasting it with Disneyland's marketed happiness.

illustrations.title: David's Sin with Bathsheba
illustrations.text: By the way, he sinned with Bathsheba; she got pregnant. He tried to get Uriah to sleep with her to cover it up, but Uriah was too honorable and refused, sleeping on the front patio instead. David couldn't manipulate him, so he had Uriah killed, then married her, thinking he had gotten away with it. From the outside, everything looked fine, but inside, he was dying and miserable.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show the internal torment of unconfessed sin and the importance of confessing to find God's mercy and restoration.

illustrations.title: Israelites Doubt in Wilderness
illustrations.text: This is what the children of Israel said to God after they went into the wilderness and got hungry. In Psalm 78:19, they spoke against God, saying, 'Can God furnish a table in the wilderness?' meaning, can God feed us out here? Of course, we know He fed them for 40 years, and the table of showbread served as evidence of God's ongoing provision for His people.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this retelling to illustrate that the table of showbread symbolizes God's provision, just as He provided for the Israelites in the wilderness.

illustrations.title: Paul on God's Nearness
illustrations.text: Do you remember what Paul said in the Book of Acts to the Athenians? Yeah, God's not that far away. You might not feel close to Him, and you may not have a close idea where He is, but He's right there; He's so close to you. This quote reinforces that God's presence is constant, even when we don't sense it.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that God is always near, connecting it to the idea that His people are continually in His presence.

illustrations.title: Buzz Aldrin's Moon Communion
illustrations.text: Buzz Aldrin, when he landed on the moon in 1969 during the first moon landing, took out a chalice with wine and bread from his personal things. He was an elder in his church, and the first thing he did was take communion, making it the first bread eaten and liquid drunk on the moon. He did this because he wanted to be with the Lord even upon the moon, illustrating that God's presence is everywhere.
illustrations.context: This story shows that God is always present, no matter where you go, as demonstrated by Aldrin seeking communion on the moon.

illustrations.title: Psalm 23 Table in Enemies
illustrations.text: In Psalm 23, it says God prepares a table for me in the presence of my enemies. This means God provides for me all the time, and I'm always right before Him. Pastor Bob connects this to the idea that Christ provides God's protection for all His people, emphasizing the security found in God's presence.
illustrations.context: This quote illustrates that God offers protection and provision even in dangerous or adversarial situations.

illustrations.title: Grandson Jeffrey's Hand Holding
illustrations.text: My grandson Jeffrey is getting pretty big now and doesn't need me to carry him anymore because he's too heavy and I can't due to my back. When we cross the street, I make him stop because he doesn't look both ways and thinks he's immortal. I always hold his hand to keep him safe, not because he's holding mine, but because I'm holding his. Even if he wiggles and doesn't want to, he can't get out of my grasp.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that God securely holds onto believers, ensuring nothing can separate them from His love.

illustrations.title: Peter Sinking in the Sea
illustrations.text: I think of Peter in his unbelief as he starts sinking on the Sea of Galilee; he was known as the big fisherman and was a big guy. He only manages to cry out, 'Lord, save me,' as he's going down, and the Bible says Jesus stretched out His hand and pulled him out of the water. Jesus is mighty to save, no matter what you've done in your unbelief or how far down you've gone.
illustrations.context: This retelling shows that Jesus will rescue believers even in their moments of doubt and failure.

illustrations.title: Police Patrol in the Dark
illustrations.text: I've shared this before. When I was a police officer in La Habra, I worked the graveyard shift and one of my jobs was to check the parks after hours to make sure no one was dealing drugs or engaging in other bad behavior. There was one park where trouble often happened, so I'd drive in with my car completely blacked out—no brake lights, no running lights, and the engine off for total silence. Then, I'd suddenly turn on all the bright spotlights, which were like aircraft landing lights, to catch them off guard and expose what was going on.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how God's light exposes evil deeds, just as the police lights reveal wrongdoing in the darkness.

illustrations.title: Cockroaches Fleeing Light
illustrations.text: I didn't hear me coming and I just like to watch because it was just like cockroaches. I'm not kidding, they would run in every possible direction, terrified. It's like what the Bible describes about people avoiding the light to hide their evil deeds.
illustrations.context: This analogy illustrates how people doing evil flee from the light to avoid exposure of their deeds.

illustrations.title: Lieutenant's Anger at Christian Chief
illustrations.text: I was telling a friend of mine, a police officer I used to work with, and we talked about when we were in the police department. I had a lieutenant, Lieutenant Jones, who was great but angry at the chief because the chief was a Christian. He called me into his office and said he couldn't handle the chief trying to shove God down everyone's throat. I asked what he meant, and he showed me the policy manual, which had Romans 13:1 on the first page inside it.
illustrations.context: This personal story shows how people may feel condemned and react negatively to the presence of light or truth, even without direct words.

illustrations.title: Chief's Manual Encounter
illustrations.text: The new chief is allowed to do whatever he wants with everything, and he decided to include a reference in the manual. He showed it to me and said, 'Do you see this?' I responded, 'That's it—he's trying to shove God down our throats.' This illustrates how people react when confronted with biblical truth, feeling judged and guilty as they suppress the truth in unrighteousness.
illustrations.context: To show how people feel condemned when exposed to God's authority and truth.

illustrations.title: Jeremiah and Almond Branch
illustrations.text: Jeremiah was a young man whom God called to preach, but he protested that he was too young and no one would listen. God assured him that He would put His words in Jeremiah's mouth. Then, in Jeremiah 1:11-12, God asked Jeremiah what he saw, and Jeremiah replied that he saw a rod of an almond tree. God explained that He is watching over His word to perform it, linking the almond tree to the quick fulfillment of His promises, as it's the first tree to blossom in Israel, symbolizing resurrection and renewal.
illustrations.context: To illustrate how God reveals and fulfills His word, providing illumination and assurance.

illustrations.title: Menorah as Bible Analogy
illustrations.text: The almond blossoms on the menorah have three parts each, with seven branches: three on the left, three on the right, and one in the center. Each side branch has three sets of three elements, totaling nine per branch, while the center has four sets, making twelve. Adding them up gives 66, which corresponds to the number of books in the Bible. This structure reveals how the menorah symbolizes the light of God through Scripture.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses the menorah's design to illustrate the Bible's composition and its role in revealing God's light.

illustrations.title: Psalm Quote on Word's Value
illustrations.text: Psalm 19 verse 10 says that God's laws are more desirable than gold, yes, than much fine gold. This connects to the pure gold of the light fixture in the text, emphasizing the purity and value of God's revelation. Pastor Bob explains that this shows how the Bible is like pure gold, providing divine light for our lives.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to highlight that God's word is pure and more valuable than gold, linking it to the idea of divine revelation.

illustrations.title: Business Card Analogy
illustrations.text: If I take out a business card and put it in my Bible and mail the Bible to the other side of the planet to China, where's the business card? It's in the Bible. Wherever the Bible goes, if you're in Christ, everything that's His belongs to you. Everything that He's done is like you've earned it, though you've earned none of it by grace. You have been given it, so Christ's acceptance is yours.
illustrations.context: This analogy illustrates that being in Christ means we share in His acceptance and blessings, making us pleasing to God.

illustrations.title: Peter's Denial Retelling
illustrations.text: When Peter is going to fall, he thinks he'll die for Jesus, though he will later. He boldly says, 'The rest may forsake you, but I'll never forsake you.' Jesus warns him, 'Peter, before the morning you're going to deny me three times.' Then Jesus explains, 'Satan has desired and been given permission to sift you like wheat.'
illustrations.context: This retelling emphasizes that Christ's intercession and acceptance cover our failures, just as it did for Peter.

illustrations.title: Peter's Sifting Story
illustrations.text: It's kind of like in the book where Satan can't do anything to you except God signs off on it. Sorry Peter, God said enough on this one, he's going to sift you like wheat, but then Jesus said, after you've turned back, strengthen your brothers, and I have prayed for you. Those are the most comforting words: Jesus is praying for me, and everything He prays for, God gives, because Jesus always prays according to God's will. So if Jesus is praying for me, that's all I need to know.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that Jesus intercedes for believers during trials, ensuring their restoration.

illustrations.title: Altar of Incense Analogy
illustrations.text: The brazen altar in the courtyard is a picture of the cross, showing Christ suffering for us and receiving our judgment. The mercy seat is a picture of the atoning blood of Christ's offering that was accepted for our pardon. But the altar of incense pictures Christ's current work in heaven, not His past work 2000 years ago, but His ongoing intercession right now.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to explain that Christ's intercession is His present ministry in heaven for believers.

illustrations.title: Hymn of Intercession Quote
illustrations.text: You have that great hymn: My hope is in the Lord who gave Himself for me and paid the price of all my sin at Calvary. For me He died, but for me He lives, and everlasting life and light He freely gives. Now for me He stands before the Father's throne, He shows His wounded hands and names me as His own. This hymn shows that Christ is interceding for us, praying when nobody else is.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob connects this quote to emphasize that Christ's ongoing intercession provides eternal hope and assurance for believers.

illustrations.title: Prayer Song Example
illustrations.text: We used to sing a song, 'Somebody's Praying, I can feel it.' You know, I don't know if anybody else was praying for me, but I know Jesus is. So if you only get one person to pray, let it be Jesus. This means you always have Christ praying for you, even when others aren't.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that Jesus' intercession is reliable and sufficient, regardless of human prayers.

illustrations.title: Jesus Quote on Holy Spirit
illustrations.text: Jesus said it is to your advantage that I go away, for if I do not go away, the Helper will not come. But if I go away, I will ask the Father, and He will send you another Helper, the Holy Spirit of promise. This means that when you come to Christ, you already have the anointing, and He wants to anoint you for the work of living for Him.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to explain how Christ sends the Holy Spirit as an anointing for believers to live for Him.

illustrations.title: Prayer for Scratch-off Ticket
illustrations.text: I know sometimes we want things that God doesn't want for us. For example, oh Lord, please let this scratch-off be the one. Probably not, because He's saying, sorry, I love you too much to ruin your life tonight. This shows that God lovingly withholds answers that aren't in our best interest.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this example to illustrate that prayers should align with God's will, as He answers based on what glorifies Him and benefits us.

illustrations.title: Napoleon's Soldier Reward
illustrations.text: The story is told of Napoleon, after a battle, where one soldier acted valiantly and was promoted. Napoleon asked him what he wanted as a reward, and the soldier requested an island that Napoleon had conquered. Another general thought it was ridiculous, but Napoleon said, 'No, he honors me by the size of his request; he thinks I'm that gracious. Give it to him.' This illustrates how bold requests can honor a generous leader.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that God is honored when we ask boldly in faith, just as Napoleon was by the soldier's large request.

illustrations.title: Christ's Scars as Hope
illustrations.text: You know when John sees Jesus in heaven, it says that he saw him as a lamb that has been slain, and that's interesting because it means that Christ still bore the testimony of his having been killed. He had the wounds still in his resurrected body as he appeared. I was thinking about that this morning, and some of us have had our lives altered forever because of this pandemic, still facing circumstances and consequences from it without knowing what will come out of it. Can I just encourage you that Christ's scars mean that suffering and healing are part of God's plan for your life?
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses Christ's enduring scars to illustrate that suffering and healing are integral to God's plan, especially for those affected by the pandemic.

illustrations.title: Jesus Washing Disciples Feet
illustrations.text: And so when Jesus washed the disciples' feet, I'm sure he enjoyed that. I wonder if he was thinking this may be the last time I do this. But if it is, I want to enter into that. The Bible says having loved his own, he loved them to the end.
illustrations.context: To show that serving others empowers and encourages us, as Jesus demonstrated resolve and love.

illustrations.title: Hezekiah's Desperate Plea
illustrations.text: When Hezekiah realized he was going to die, as God had told him, it's pretty sure when God tells you. He wrote these words recorded in Isaiah 38: 'Like a swallow or a crane, so I twitter; I moan like a dove; my eyes look wistfully to the heights; O Lord, I am oppressed, be my security.' This shows Hezekiah's raw emotion and turning to God in his final moments.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate the importance of turning to God in times of crisis and impending death.

illustrations.title: Upside-Down World Example
illustrations.text: The world is really upside down when the ACLU is defending the president's right to communicate. I'd say this is an amazing time we live in. It highlights the chaos and unexpected events in current society.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show how the world is in political chaos, emphasizing that such strangeness should remind us not to trust in human institutions.

illustrations.title: Refuge in the Lord Quote
illustrations.text: The final verse I want to share is from Psalm 118: It is better to take refuge in the Lord than to trust in man, and better than to trust in princes or presidents or political solutions. Pastor Bob explains that trusting in political parties or leaders leads to disappointment, but trusting in God through Christ ensures no disappointment. This connects to his point about finding true security in faith amid national division.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to encourage trusting in God over human leaders during times of political crisis.

illustrations.title: Random Bible Selection Error
illustrations.text: There was a man some time ago who believed that God is in charge of all circumstances, so he decided to know God's will by randomly opening the Bible and pointing to a passage. One morning, he closed his eyes, opened the Bible, and his finger landed on 'And Judas went and hanged himself.' He thought that couldn't be right, so he tried again and it said, 'Go thou and do likewise.' He tried one more time, and it said, 'What thou doest, do quickly.' That story highlights the real problem with taking a passage out of its context.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show the dangers of interpreting Bible verses without considering their context.

illustrations.title: Falling Back into Works
illustrations.text: It'd be like a person gets saved out of the Roman Catholic Church and they're born again, but they go back to confession because they think they must confess to a priest to be forgiven. Or they keep going forward in an altar call, or keep getting re-baptized because they doubt the last one worked, and they're adding these things to what Christ has already done. You can't do it, and you shouldn't do it, as it undermines God's grace.
illustrations.context: Illustrates the peril of turning back to a lifestyle of performance and works to add to salvation.

illustrations.title: Confession and Denial Quote
illustrations.text: Jesus said, 'If you confess me before men, I'll confess you before my Father; if you deny me before men, I'll deny you before my Father.' Paul echoes this in Timothy, saying if we deny Him, He will deny us, but even if we're faithless, He remains faithful. This quote shows the straightforward truth about faith and denial.
illustrations.context: Emphasizes that denying Christ means losing His advocacy, while highlighting His unchanging faithfulness.

illustrations.title: Peter and Judas Contrast
illustrations.text: Remember when Peter denied the Lord at a campfire in Caiaphas' courtyard? That's where his denial happened, but he was later restored at another campfire on the shore of the Sea of Galilee, where Jesus and the disciples were present, and Peter was made right. In contrast, Judas betrayed Jesus and lived in that rejection without true repentance. Peter had an instance of denial but repented and was restored, while Judas experienced remorse but not godly sorrow, leading to his downfall. This shows that even great sins can be forgiven through repentance.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate the difference between true repentance like Peter's and unrepentant regret like Judas's, emphasizing that Christians can sin but must not reject Christ's work.

illustrations.title: C.S. Lewis on Choosing Hell
illustrations.text: You say Bob I don't believe in a God that would send people to hell. Good, me either I don't believe in a God who would send people to hell because I don't believe God sends people to hell. Listen to what C.S. Lewis said: There are only two kinds of people in the end—those who say to God, 'Thy will be done,' and those to whom God says in the end, 'Thy will be done,' and those are the ones in hell because they've chosen it.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that people choose hell by rejecting God's will, rather than God forcing them there.

illustrations.title: Thomas Misses Church Once
illustrations.text: Remember when Thomas missed church after the resurrection? He only missed it once, and that's when Jesus showed up. Jesus didn't go to Thomas's house; he waited until the next Sunday when they were gathered again. Thomas had doubted, saying he wouldn't believe unless he saw the wounds, and Jesus heard him. So Jesus appeared, showing his hands and saying, 'Be not unbelieving, but believing.'
illustrations.context: This illustrates that Jesus is always present and hears our doubts, emphasizing the importance of faith and gathering with believers.

illustrations.title: George Wilson Refuses Pardon
illustrations.text: An interesting thing happened years ago in the United States; there was a man named George Wilson, a postal clerk who robbed a federal payroll on a train and accidentally killed a guard. He was sentenced to death by hanging, but due to public sentiment against the death penalty, President Jackson pardoned him. Strangely, Wilson refused the pardon, which was unprecedented, and nobody knew how to handle it.
illustrations.context: This story highlights the consequences of rejecting God's grace, paralleling the idea of rejecting Jesus and facing judgment.

illustrations.title: George Wilson's Refused Pardon
illustrations.text: He's pardoned but he said he won't accept it, and it went all the way to the Supreme Court. Chief Justice John Marshall handed down the court's decision, stating that a pardon is a parchment whose only value is determined by the receiver. It has no value apart from what the receiver gives to it, so George Wilson refused to accept the pardon and therefore must die. As a result, he was taken from his cell and hanged to satisfy the requirements of the law.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that God's pardon must be accepted and not forced upon anyone.

illustrations.title: Hugging the Shadow Analogy
illustrations.text: I go on a trip to Israel while Becky stays home, and it's tough because we miss each other. When I return, she's excited to greet me in the daylight but ends up trying to hug my shadow instead of me. This shows how futile it is to cling to something that's not the real thing. Can you imagine doing that when the actual person is right there?
illustrations.context: This analogy demonstrates that one should not return to old rituals or shadows when Christ, the substance, is the true reality.

illustrations.title: Song on Growing Through Storms
illustrations.text: Jamie Owens Collins wrote a song back in the 70s on her album Growing Pains. She asked the question, 'Is the rain falling from the sky keeping you from singing? Is that tear falling from your eye because the wind is stinging?' She says, 'Don't you fret now child, don't you worry, the rain's to help you grow, so don't try to hurry the storm along, the hard times make you strong.' Don't you know a seed would never grow if there were never showers, and though the rain might bring a little pain, just look at all the flowers.
illustrations.context: This quote illustrates that hardships and storms in life help believers grow stronger in faith.

illustrations.title: Trees Strengthened by Winds
illustrations.text: Trees are actually benefited by high winds; they produce something called reaction wood that makes them stronger. Otherwise, they wouldn't stay up and need the strong winds to produce that strength. We know this to be true as it helps trees endure the elements.
illustrations.context: This analogy shows that suffering produces endurance and strength in faith, just as winds make trees stronger.

illustrations.title: Forests Renewed by Fires
illustrations.text: Forests benefit from fires; individual trees might get burned down, but the forest as a whole thrives. For instance, certain kinds of pines like lodgepole only generate their seeds after a fire, which clears out the forest bed and allows sunlight in. This process helps new growth and renewal in the forest.
illustrations.context: This analogy demonstrates that God uses hard times to bring about renewal and strength, similar to how fires benefit forests overall.

illustrations.title: Pearl Formation Analogy
illustrations.text: We all know the pearl starts as an irritation in an animal and forms over time. A diamond takes so long to form from a piece of coal under heat and pressure in the earth. This process illustrates how character is built through trials, not just by resolving problems.
illustrations.context: God uses trials to build character, similar to how pearls and diamonds form under pressure.

illustrations.title: Trials as Physical Therapy
illustrations.text: Every new trial or tragedy is like physical therapy to strengthen our spiritual muscles. When you face something new, hear God whisper, 'Will you trust me now?' God is not shocked by what's happening and uses these moments to build trust.
illustrations.context: Trials strengthen spiritual muscles and encourage trust in God during difficult times.

illustrations.title: Family Mockery Story
illustrations.text: I had somebody in my family once say, 'I thought you came from an educated family.' It's hard to keep my educated mouth shut at times, but this shows how people can mock you for your faith. This experience highlights the reality of being put down for believing.
illustrations.context: Enduring mockery for faith is a way to develop endurance as a believer.

illustrations.title: Beatitudes Persecution Quote
illustrations.text: Blessed are you when people insult you, persecute you, and falsely say all manner of evil against you because of me. Rejoice and be glad, for your reward in heaven is great, for in the same way they persecuted the prophets who were before you. Hey, you're in good company, so see this as a sign you're following in their footsteps.
illustrations.context: When insulted for your faith, remember it's a blessing and puts you in good company with the prophets, leading to heavenly reward.

illustrations.title: Peter's Denial Example
illustrations.text: Just look at Peter following Jesus at a distance in the courtyard around people hostile to Christ. What does he do? He wants to warm his hands at their fire and fit in. He'll cuss, talk just like them, and deny the Lord, saying 'I don't know him,' which is evident by the way he talks and acts.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the danger of blending in with worldly people and compromising faith to avoid conflict.

illustrations.title: Dead Fish Analogy
illustrations.text: You say you just like to go with the flow. Any dead fish can go with the flow; it takes a live one to swim upstream. It is safer to fit in, but God is calling you to stand up, stand out, and shine.
illustrations.context: This analogy emphasizes that following the crowd is easy and lifeless, while standing for faith requires courage and vitality.

illustrations.title: Apostles' Rejoicing Story
illustrations.text: Do you know what it says of the disciples and apostles after they got beaten for standing up and preaching Jesus? They got beaten badly in Acts, and it says they went on their way from the presence of the council rejoicing that they had been considered worthy to suffer shame for the name. I want to be worthy to suffer shame for the name; I'm not looking for it, but it will come if I stand up for Him, and I need to be willing.
illustrations.context: This story shows that enduring mockery and persecution for faith is an honor and a sign of true commitment.

illustrations.title: Joseph's Bold Burial Request
illustrations.text: Remember, it was after Jesus died when Joseph of Arimathea wanted the body of Jesus. Let me tell you, that was not a politically correct move for a Jew on the Sanhedrin to say, 'I'd like to bury this condemned criminal.' He was essentially volunteering to pay for Jesus' funeral, which probably wasn't good for his reputation. Then, old Nicodemus suddenly joined him, going public with his faith despite the risks.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the courage to publicly declare faith even when it endangers one's reputation and status.

illustrations.title: Forty Soldiers' Faithful Stand
illustrations.text: I heard a story when I was at Biola in chapel, and I've never forgotten it from the early days of the church under Nero's persecution. There were some people in the Roman army who became Christians, and word was sent out that any Christian soldiers needed to be executed. The commander of a group in Gaul had elite soldiers, including a distinguished group of forty who used to chant for victory in gladiatorial games. When asked if any named the name of Jesus, those same forty men stepped forward, showing their commitment despite the emperor's decree.
illustrations.context: This demonstrates the importance of standing firm in faith and enduring persecution for the promised reward, as seen in the Hebrews passage.

illustrations.title: Forty Martyrs Story
illustrations.text: I have to follow orders; I'll give you until tonight to make your decision, but if you decide to follow Christ, you will be executed. The next night, the commander asked the question again, and the same 40 stepped forward, saluting that they believed in Jesus. He ordered them stripped naked and marched onto a frozen lake to die from the cold, saying their fellow soldiers wouldn't kill them—they were choosing their own fate. As they marched, they chanted, 'Forty wrestlers wrestling for you, O Christ, wishing to win for you the victory and from you the victor's crown.' One broke ranks and died by the fire after renouncing his faith, so the chant changed to 'Thirty-nine wrestlers,' but then the commander himself stripped and joined them, making it forty again. They continued chanting until they died, showing unwavering commitment. This story highlights choosing to suffer with God's people rather than enjoy the world's comforts.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate the importance of identifying with and suffering for Christ, even in the face of death.

illustrations.title: Pastor Mike's Heaven Message
illustrations.text: When I did the memorial service for Pastor Mike Swanson, who was well-loved at this church and died of cancer, I shared part of his final sermon titled 'Heaven is Better.' Mike started by saying the best day of his life was when he got married, but even that paled in comparison because heaven is better. He emphasized that no matter the best moments in life, heaven is permanent and far superior, making it okay if life ends sooner or differently than expected.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that believers can joyfully accept losses because heaven offers something eternally better.

illustrations.title: Sheik and Stockbroker Tale
illustrations.text: I heard a story of a Saudi Arabian sheik who had a U.S. stockbroker that made him a lot of money in investments, so the sheik wanted to give him something as a reward. The stockbroker said he couldn't receive gifts because it wasn't allowed, but the sheik insisted on showing his gratitude.
illustrations.context: This story reinforces the idea of appreciating greater rewards beyond earthly possessions, tying into the theme of having a better and lasting possession in heaven.

illustrations.title: Stock Broker Golf Example
illustrations.text: Let me just give you something about a stock broker. He tried to say no but couldn't. Finally, he said, 'Okay, look, I like golf. If you want to give me a couple clubs, that'd be great.' A week later, he sent the stock broker a note, and the stockbroker called and said, 'What is this?'
