He replied, 'Well, you wanted a couple clubs, so I'm giving you five—some don't have swimming pools, but others do.' It's okay whatever you lose in this life because God is going to give you back either in this life or the life to come, and you're going to have your mind blown.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that you cannot outgive God and that losses in this life are insignificant compared to eternal rewards.

illustrations.title: Farmer's Patience Analogy
illustrations.text: James says, 'Therefore be patient, brethren, until the coming of the Lord. The farmer waits for the precious produce of the soil, being patient about it until it gets the early and the late rain. You too be patient and strengthen your hearts, for the coming of the Lord is near.' This shows that just as a farmer patiently waits for the rains to bring the harvest, we must wait for God's timing.
illustrations.context: This analogy emphasizes the need for endurance and patience as believers wait for God's promises and the Lord's return.

illustrations.title: Paul's Affliction Quote
illustrations.text: Paul said this to the Corinthians: 'We are afflicted in every way, but not crushed; perplexed, but not despairing; persecuted, but not forsaken; struck down, but not destroyed.' He explains that we're always carrying in our body the death of Jesus so that the life of Jesus may also be manifested. This means that despite trials, believers endure because of the hope in Christ.
illustrations.context: This quote shows that believers face hardships but are not overcome, highlighting the need for endurance in faith.

illustrations.title: Persistent Child's Order
illustrations.text: Mom and dad took their son Jonathan to a restaurant. The waitress asked what he wanted, and Jonathan said he'd have a grilled cheese sandwich. She said they don't serve that, but Jonathan pointed out they have bread, cheese, and a grill, so she checked and they made it for him. Then he asked for a milkshake, and even though they didn't have syrup, he persisted by asking if they had a way to make it. I tell you that story because it shows something that pleases God about persistence and faith.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that endurance and confidence are essential to receive God's promises, just like the biblical Jonathan.

illustrations.title: Israel's Lost Confidence
illustrations.text: Israel threw away its confidence when they reached the Promised Land and saw the giants, deciding to go back to Egypt instead of trusting God. They planned to kill Moses and wandered in circles for the rest of their lives as a result. This generation never entered the Promised Land because they lacked perseverance under trial.
illustrations.context: This story warns that believers can make the same mistake of losing confidence, preventing them from receiving God's promises.

illustrations.title: Persistent Widow Parable
illustrations.text: Jesus told a parable to show that people ought to pray at all times and not lose heart. It was about a poor widow who kept going to an unjust judge, who didn't care about God or her. She persistently showed up every day until he grew tired and decided her case, proving that if even a wicked judge responds to persistence, God will certainly answer those who keep seeking Him.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize the need for enduring in prayer without giving up.

illustrations.title: Friend at Midnight Parable
illustrations.text: Jesus described a man who went to his neighbor at midnight, saying he had a guest and needed food but hadn't prepared. The neighbor initially refused because it was late and everyone was in bed. However, the man kept knocking persistently until the neighbor gave in, not out of friendship, but because of his sheer persistence and refusal to stop.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate how persistent asking leads to receiving, encouraging ongoing prayer.

illustrations.title: D.L. Moody's Prayer Story
illustrations.text: D.L. Moody had a list of 100 unsaved friends and prayed for them every day throughout his life and ministry. During that time, 96 of them came to Christ, and he crossed them off as they were saved. The other four received Christ by the end of his life, showing the power of persistent prayer.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to demonstrate that persevering in prayer for others' salvation aligns with God's will and yields results.

illustrations.title: 80-Year-Old's Four Marriages
illustrations.text: I read a story about a woman who was getting married at 80 years old, so the local newspaper sent someone to cover the wedding and interview her. She was marrying for the fourth time, and her new husband was a funeral director. When asked about her previous husbands, she explained that she first married a banker in her 20s, then a circus ringmaster in her 40s, a preacher in her 60s, and now a funeral director in her 80s. The interviewer asked why she chose men with such diverse careers, and she smiled and said, 'I married one for the money, two for the show, three to get ready, and four to go.'
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate enduring faith and living in anticipation of the Lord's coming, emphasizing perseverance in one's spiritual journey.

illustrations.title: Lighthouse in a Storm
illustrations.text: You know, that's a perfect description of a lighthouse. I saw this picture of a lighthouse off the coast of Oregon. Those waves are 100 feet over the top of it. I thought, what a perfect description of a believer in a storm. We're still the light in the storm, and we will survive the storm.
illustrations.context: Believers should remain steadfast and shine as lights even during challenging times like a pandemic.

illustrations.title: Sailing Through Faith Storms
illustrations.text: I'm not going to let my fear and discouragement and my losses cause me to pull in my spiritual sail. But as a believer with God's help, I'm going to hoist my anchor of fear, open my sail, and ask the Holy Spirit to fill it with fresh faith, and say, 'Lord, full steam ahead.' Why? Because my destination is heaven, and my Captain of salvation is at the helm. The Lord is saying to me and to you, 'Sail on, sailor. I've got seas, some of them rough, but if you'll trust me, you're going to come through this and be safe.'
illustrations.context: This analogy emphasizes persevering in faith and trusting God to navigate through life's difficulties.

illustrations.title: Online Viewership Isolation
illustrations.text: You may not know this, but after every service on Sunday and Wednesday night, I'm given a number of how many people were watching on YouTube, FaceTime, and the live stream. I'm encouraged that anyone is out there, but I only get numbers, not names or faces, so I'm clueless about who is watching. I was able to get a great response from hundreds in our church when I emailed asking how their families are doing, but each number is just an IP address or a device, and I can't reach through the internet to see and connect with you personally.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is emphasizing the impersonal nature of online ministry and his longing for real, face-to-face connections with his audience.

illustrations.title: Paul's Letters as Connection
illustrations.text: I was thinking about the Apostle Paul and how he had to have a relationship through the technology of his day, which was writing letters. For instance, to the church at Rome, he said, 'I long to see you that I might impart some spiritual gift to you that you may be established.' He feels like he needs to be right in the same room with them, and I feel that same feeling. Then, to the church at Thessalonica, he said, 'We were bereft of you for a short while in person not in spirit, and we were all the more eager with great desire to see your face,' and he says again, 'Night and day we keep praying most earnestly that we may see your face.'
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses Paul's quotes to illustrate his own longing for in-person fellowship and to emphasize the importance of seeing his congregation face-to-face.

illustrations.title: Last Supper Participation
illustrations.text: From what I can read in the Bible, at the Last Supper, there was not anyone who was just a spectator. No one watched others receiving communion; it was for everybody in the room. So, communion today is for everyone here, encouraging full participation just like back then.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses the Last Supper to emphasize that everyone should actively participate in communion rather than just observe.

illustrations.title: Jesus and the Last Supper
illustrations.text: Jesus took the bread at Passover and broke it, saying, 'This is my body. From now on, when you eat it, remember me.' The disciples did not have sealed cups, which is unbiblical, but after supper, Jesus took the cup, gave thanks for it, and said, 'This is the new covenant you've been waiting for centuries. It's here, in my blood. When you drink it, remember me.'
illustrations.context: To emphasize the establishment of the new covenant through Jesus' sacrifice and the call to remember Him.

illustrations.title: Hezekiah's Despair and Trust
illustrations.text: King Hezekiah was at a point in his life where he realized it was all over; he was told by God he was going to die, and that's the final word he thought. He wrote these words, recorded in Isaiah: 'Like a swallow or a crane, so I twitter.' He went on to say, 'I moan like a dove; my eyes look wistfully to the heights. Oh Lord, I'm oppressed; be my security.' This illustrates Hezekiah's vulnerability and his turn to God in distress.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize trusting in God rather than worldly things during times of upheaval.

illustrations.title: World Turned Upside Down Example
illustrations.text: The world is definitely turned upside down when the ACLU is defending the president's rights to communicate with social media. This shows how unexpected alliances can highlight societal chaos. Pastor Bob uses this to connect to broader themes of confusion in the world today.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating the current state of disorder to encourage reliance on faith over political instability.

illustrations.title: Solomon's Wisdom on Fear
illustrations.text: Solomon said, 'The fear of man brings a snare, but he who trusts in the Lord will be exalted.' Pastor Bob explains that putting trust in political parties or leaders leads to disappointment, but trusting in Christ does not. He connects this to reassure listeners that God's promise is reliable amid election turmoil.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to show that fearing human opinions or leaders traps people, while trusting God brings security.

illustrations.title: D.L. Moody Weather Quote
illustrations.text: Someone asked a man what the weather would be like today, and the man, a Christian, replied, 'Whatever I wish.' This offended D.L. Moody, who questioned why he said that. The man clarified, 'Oh, don't get me wrong, I'm not in charge of it. I just figured the weather's going to be whatever God decides, and whatever God decides is what I want.' That's a good place to be when things aren't the way you like them—say, 'I defer to your judgment, Lord, and I embrace it.'
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize trusting and accepting God's will during uncertain times.

illustrations.title: Bible Roulette Story
illustrations.text: It's an old story of a Christian man who wanted to know the will of God, just like many of us. Believing in God's sovereignty, he decided to open his Bible at random, put his finger on a passage, and take that as God's message. He prayed, opened the Bible, closed his eyes, and pointed to the verse 'Judas went and hanged himself.' Thinking that couldn't be right, he tried again and pointed to 'Go thou and do likewise.' He attempted it one more time and quickly gave up. This story illustrates the foolishness of that approach.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to demonstrate the dangers and foolishness of taking a Bible verse out of its context.

illustrations.title: Cop's Last Known Address
illustrations.text: Jesus made mention of it in what I call His last known address. When you're a cop, you write down people's LKA, their last known address. Well, Christ's last known address was about the end times; that was His last sermon, and He could have preached on anything but chose to talk about His coming and the last days and what they would be like.
illustrations.context: This analogy emphasizes the importance of Jesus's final message on prophecy to warn about falling away in the last days.

illustrations.title: Galatians Churches Warning
illustrations.text: By the way, I'll remind you that Paul wrote letters to churches in various cities, like the church at Ephesus, Philippi, and Corinth, but when he wrote to the Galatians, it's not about a single city—Galatia was a large area with many churches full of Gentiles who had become Christians. There was a problem: Jewish believers were pressuring these Gentile Christians to follow the Law of Moses, trying to make them add works to their faith. Paul wrote to tell them that they started by faith but were now trying to please God through performance and rules, and he warned them not to do that.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that adding works to faith, like the Galatians did, undermines true salvation through Christ alone.

illustrations.title: Catholic Confession Analogy
illustrations.text: It's like getting saved out of the Catholic Church and then feeling like you have to go to confession to a priest to get your sins forgiven, or deciding to keep the seven ordinances of the church to earn salvation. You can't go back to relying on rituals after placing your faith in Christ. Your faith has to remain solely in Christ, not in additional rules or practices.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that turning back to works or rituals for salvation, like the Galatians, means falling from grace and nullifying faith in Christ.

illustrations.title: Peter's Denial and Restoration
illustrations.text: Peter had an instance of denying Christ at the campfire. Remember, when the servant girl said, 'You're one of them,' Peter, who had stood up to the whole army, was taken down by a little girl. It's interesting, but while he had that instance of denial, he was restored at a different campfire, this one with Jesus and the disciples on the shore of the Sea of Galilee.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that even after denying Jesus, Peter was restored and remained faithful, emphasizing God's unwavering faithfulness.

illustrations.title: Peter's Martyrdom Tradition
illustrations.text: Peter was faithful until his death. According to church tradition, when they came to crucify him, Peter said he was not worthy to die the way his Savior died. So, they crucified Peter upside down as a martyr.
illustrations.context: This shows that despite his earlier denial, Peter lived and died in faith, proving Christ's enduring use of imperfect followers.

illustrations.title: Parable of the Sower Retelling
illustrations.text: Remember in the parable of the sower, there were four soils, but two don't bear fruit. One is among the thorns and gets choked out, never bearing fruit. The other has no root, so when the sun comes up, it scorches the plant because it had a shallow root system and was temporary. Jesus said these are those who believe for a while but then fall away.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that some people claim Christ but lack genuine faith, as they either produce no fruit or have shallow roots and eventually walk away.

illustrations.title: Salt Trampling Analogy
illustrations.text: Trampled underfoot is what they do with salt when it loses its savor. It's good for one thing: to be trampled under men's feet as worthless trash thrown out. This shows how something once valuable becomes useless and discarded.
illustrations.context: This analogy emphasizes that those who trample the Son of God treat His sacrifice as worthless and unclean.

illustrations.title: Jesus on Fear and Eternal Punishment
illustrations.text: Jesus said, 'Don't fear him who can only kill the body but can't touch your soul; fear him who can cast both body and soul into eternal hell.' This quote matters because it highlights that earthly death is nothing compared to eternal consequences, connecting to the severity of apostasy. Pastor Bob uses it to show that rejecting Christ leads to a far worse punishment than any physical death.
illustrations.context: This quote underscores the greater severity of spiritual judgment for those who turn away from Christ compared to Old Testament penalties.

illustrations.title: Pastor's Study Burden
illustrations.text: I share a few things that I've studied about. I have to study five to ten times as much as I'm ever able to give out. I'm responsible for all of it, but I'm not complaining—I love it. This illustrates the weight of knowledge and teaching.
illustrations.context: This example shows that the more one knows about faith, the greater the responsibility and judgment they face.

illustrations.title: C.S. Lewis on Hell
illustrations.text: Let me read you what C.S. Lewis said because I couldn't say it better than him: There are only two kinds of people in the end—those who say to God, 'Thy will be done,' and those to whom God says in the end, 'Thy will be done.' All that are in hell choose it by rejecting or neglecting such a great salvation. God has done everything He can to save everyone, and then they must make a decision: will they receive it?
illustrations.context: This quote emphasizes that people end up in hell by their own choice of rejecting God's salvation.

illustrations.title: Thomas Misses Church
illustrations.text: After Jesus rose from the dead, he appeared to the disciples on Sunday when they were gathered for their first church service, but Thomas wasn't there. When the others told Thomas about it, he didn't believe them and said he needed to see Jesus's wounds to believe. The next Sunday, Thomas came to church, and Jesus appeared again, directly addressing his doubt by showing his hands and saying, 'Stop doubting and believe.' This powerful moment highlights Jesus's response to unbelief.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize the importance of attending church and witnessing faith, warning against doubt and encouraging belief in Jesus.

illustrations.title: Murderer Seeks Pardon
illustrations.text: It happened many years ago in our nation's history when a man committed murder during a train robbery, killing a guard. He was found guilty and sentenced to death by hanging. Public sentiment was against capital punishment, so a movement began to seek a presidential pardon for him. This story illustrates themes of judgment and mercy in the context of facing consequences.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that Jesus can be either a savior or a judge, paralleling the man's situation with the choice to accept or reject God's grace.

illustrations.title: George Wilson's Pardon Refusal
illustrations.text: This man, named George Wilson, committed his first offense, and President Jackson issued a presidential pardon. Strangely, Wilson refused to accept it, which was unprecedented. The courts, up to the Supreme Court, decided that a pardon has no value unless accepted by the receiver. Chief Justice John Marshall stated that since Wilson refused, he must face the punishment. So, George Wilson was hanged to satisfy the law.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that a pardon, like salvation through Jesus, must be accepted to be effective.

illustrations.title: Hugging the Shadow Analogy
illustrations.text: Seven years ago, I went to Israel without Becky because our daughter-in-law was having a baby, so Becky stayed home. I was gone for 10 days and couldn't wait to get back. Imagine if, when I returned, Becky came out to greet me but hugged my shadow instead of me. I'd say, 'Hug me, I'm right here!' No one would do that, but that's what people do when they cling to ineffective things like the old laws instead of Christ.
illustrations.context: This shows that people might prefer shadows or superficial things over the real substance of faith in Christ.

illustrations.title: Forest Fires Benefit Growth
illustrations.text: They tell us forests need to have fires; all we see is destruction, but fires actually renew the forest bed. There are certain kinds of pine trees, like lodgepole pines, that won't release their seeds except through fire. It opens the canopy to let light in so new things can grow, and forests actually need occasional fires. Don't get me wrong, I'm not a big fan of forest fires, but it's true that they serve a purpose.
illustrations.context: Suffering, like forest fires, leads to renewal and growth in faith.

illustrations.title: Trees Strengthened by Wind
illustrations.text: They tell us that trees actually become stronger in storms because of the winds. There's a place in Arizona called Biosphere 2, an enclosed world three football fields long where they're growing things, but they've discovered that without wind, the trees do not produce reaction wood in their bark. Trees need wind to resist and develop strength to handle challenges like gravity. It's a very interesting thing that shows how external forces make them stronger.
illustrations.context: Challenges and trials, like wind, build strength and endurance in believers.

illustrations.title: Song About Hard Times
illustrations.text: Jamie Owens Collins, way back in 1975, sang a song from her album called Growing Pains called The Hard Times. In the song, she asks if the rain falling from the sky is keeping you from singing, or if the tear falling from your eye is because the wind is stinging. She reassures with lines like, 'Don't you fret now child, don't you worry, the rain's to help you grow, so don't try to hurry the storm along; the hard times make you strong.' A seed would never grow if there were never showers, and just look at all the flowers that come from the rain.
illustrations.context: Difficult experiences are necessary for spiritual growth and strength.

illustrations.title: Spiritual Physical Therapy Analogy
illustrations.text: Every new trial, every new tragedy including the one you're in right now, is kind of like spiritual physical therapy to strengthen our spiritual muscles. God is more interested in building your faith and character than resolving your problems. He's saying, will you trust me now, even if I don't change it immediately.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to illustrate that trials build spiritual strength and character, rather than God simply fixing problems.

illustrations.title: Early Disciples' Persecution
illustrations.text: The early disciples got beaten for their faith because they refused to stop witnessing, saying they had to obey God. They were released after the beating, but they went on their way from the presence of the council rejoicing that they had been considered worthy to suffer shame for the name. This shows their commitment despite the pain and mockery.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob retells this story to emphasize that enduring suffering and mockery for faith is a sign of being worthy, as the disciples demonstrated.

illustrations.title: Blessed Are the Persecuted Quote
illustrations.text: Jesus said, blessed are you when people insult you, persecute you, and falsely say all manner of evil against you because of me. Rejoice and be glad, for your reward in heaven is great, as they persecuted the prophets before you. This means you're in good company if people are mocking you for your faith.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to connect enduring insults and persecution to receiving a great heavenly reward, encouraging believers to see mockery as a blessing.

illustrations.title: Relative's Educated Family Remark
illustrations.text: I had a relative of mine who once wrote me and said, 'I thought you came from an educated family.' It was all I could do to keep my little educated mouth shut, which I probably didn't. This story highlights the tension of staying true to faith amidst criticism.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to illustrate the challenge of not conforming to worldly expectations and standing firm in faith.

illustrations.title: Peter's Denial of Jesus
illustrations.text: Remember what Peter did when he was following Jesus at a distance. Jesus is arrested, and Peter is in the courtyard, trying to be curious and find out what happens. Somebody recognizes him by his accent, so to prove he doesn't know Jesus, Peter starts changing his language and swearing to fit in.
illustrations.context: This retelling shows how Peter conformed to the world by denying Jesus, warning against being a spiritual chameleon.

illustrations.title: Spiritual Chameleon Analogy
illustrations.text: Some of us are bilingual; we talk a certain way at work with non-Christian friends and another way with our Christian friends. Don't be a spiritual chameleon that fits in by changing your behavior. This analogy emphasizes the danger of adapting to surroundings at the expense of true faith.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to challenge listeners not to alter their speech or actions based on their audience, highlighting the importance of consistent Christian identity.

illustrations.title: Nero's Persecution Story
illustrations.text: Maybe you've heard the story, but it is etched in my mind; it's said to have happened in the reign of Nero, who is blamed for the burning of Rome and the burning of Christians. This led to a great kingdom-wide, empire-wide persecution in the first century. Nero had heard evidently that some of the Christians were involved, sparking widespread suffering.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob references this historical event to illustrate the reality of identifying with persecuted Christians and the consequences of faith.

illustrations.title: Forty Soldiers' Martyrdom
illustrations.text: A Roman centurion named Vespasian learned that some of his soldiers had become Christians, so he was ordered by Caesar to execute believers in Jesus. He gathered his elite troops, including 40 specialized soldiers who had fought in gladiatorial games, and asked if any followed Christ; to his shock, all 40 stepped forward. Despite being given a night to reconsider, they reaffirmed their faith and were stripped of their uniforms, then marched onto a frozen lake to die from exposure. As they endured the cold, they chanted a modified version of their old chant: 'Forty wrestlers wrestling for you, O Christ, wishing to win for you the victory and from you the victor's crown.' Watchfires were lit around the lake, offering them a chance to renounce their faith and warm themselves, but they continued chanting until their voices weakened. Late into the night, one soldier broke and crawled to the fire, highlighting the immense pressure they faced.
illustrations.context: This story illustrates the extreme commitment and faithfulness required to follow Christ, even in the face of death.

illustrations.title: The Forty Martyrs Story
illustrations.text: Thirty-nine wrestlers were enduring persecution for Christ, facing death on a frozen lake rather than recant their faith. They continued wrestling through the night, determined to win the victor's crown for Christ, until something moved their commander Vespasian. He stripped off his clothes, joined them on the ice, and declared, 'Don't say 39 anymore, say 40,' standing with them to the end as they all died for their beliefs.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate that Christians should stand with those suffering for Christ, just as Vespasian joined the martyrs.

illustrations.title: Pastor Mike's Final Sermon
illustrations.text: Pastor Mike Swanson, a beloved youth pastor in his 30s, died of cancer, leaving behind a young wife and children. At his packed memorial service, we shared a shortened version of his last sermon, which he preached from this pulpit despite his frail condition. In that sermon, he reflected on the best day of his life—his wedding—and then emphasized that even that joy paled in comparison to heaven, assuring everyone of his eternal hope.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this example to show that Christians can accept earthly losses joyfully because they have a better, lasting possession in heaven.

illustrations.title: The Generous Sheik's Gift
illustrations.text: Heard a story of a stockbroker who made a lot of money for a Saudi Arabian sheik billionaire. The sheik was so grateful that he wanted to buy the stockbroker a gift, but the stockbroker said he couldn't accept it due to rules. Finally, the stockbroker mentioned he liked golf and suggested a couple of clubs. A week later, the sheik sent him five golf clubs, two of which had swimming pools, making it an extravagantly unexpected gift.
illustrations.context: This story illustrates that God's rewards in heaven are far greater and more surprising than anything we can imagine on earth.

illustrations.title: Heaven Beyond Imagination
illustrations.text: Can I tell you what God has in store for you is like at a different level than what you're thinking? I don't know exactly, it's like something beyond our wildest dreams—maybe even a whole solar system or galaxy. I just know it hasn't entered into our imagination, and it's going to be better than we can picture. We accept losses here because what's coming is so much greater.
illustrations.context: This analogy emphasizes that heavenly rewards are unimaginably superior to earthly things, encouraging endurance in faith.

illustrations.title: Boy's Grilled Cheese Request
illustrations.text: Heard the story of a couple who have a little boy named Jonathan, who's five years old. They take him to a restaurant, and the server asks for their order. Jonathan says he wants a grilled cheese sandwich, but it's not on the menu, so he cleverly asks if they have bread, cheese, and a grill, and they end up making it for him. Later, he asks for a milkshake, and even though it's not available, his persistent spirit shines through.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the spirit of venturing out in faith and believing for things others might not.

illustrations.title: Israelites' Lost Confidence
illustrations.text: The children of Israel threw away their confidence when they heard the report of the giants in the Promised Land. Up until then, they were excited, saying they were going to a land of milk and honey and felt safe. But once they arrived and faced the challenges, they wanted to go back to Egypt, saying it was impossible, and as a result, they wandered in circles for the rest of their lives.
illustrations.context: This shows that throwing away confidence leads to missing out on God's promises and enduring hardship unnecessarily.

illustrations.title: Chuck Smith's Final Sermon
illustrations.text: This is the last passage I heard Chuck Smith preach on because it was the last passage he preached on. He died this week after he delivered this one. It ties into the idea of persevering in faith like Abraham.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate the importance of spiritual strength and perseverance until the end.

illustrations.title: Persistent Widow's Plea
illustrations.text: Jesus told the story of a widow who was poor and kept showing up in court every day. The wicked judge didn't care about widows, but he was bothered by her persistence. Eventually, he decided her case just to get rid of her. Jesus used this to show how much more God will respond to those who cry out persistently.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is emphasizing that believers should pray persistently and not lose heart in their requests to God.

illustrations.title: Midnight Neighbor's Request
illustrations.text: Jesus told another story about a man whose friends came over unexpectedly, and he didn't have enough food. He went to his neighbor at midnight and kept knocking on the door. The neighbor initially refused because everyone was in bed, but he finally gave in to stop the knocking. Jesus used this to teach that persistent asking leads to receiving.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that people should keep asking, seeking, and knocking in prayer without giving up.

illustrations.title: Moody's Persistent Prayers
illustrations.text: D.L. Moody had 100 unsaved friends and kept a big list of them. He prayed for them every single day during his ministry. As a result, 96 of them came to faith in Christ, and at his funeral, the other four got saved, making it all 100.
illustrations.context: This story encourages believers to persevere in prayer for unsaved loved ones to build faith and see results.

illustrations.title: Luther's Faith Transformation
illustrations.text: This verse from Habakkuk, 'The just shall live by faith,' transformed Martin Luther's whole life. It was a pivotal moment that changed his understanding and approach to faith. Pastor Bob uses this to highlight the importance of living by genuine faith.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that genuine faith, as in Hebrews, is key to spiritual endurance and transformation.

illustrations.title: 80-Year-Old's Four Marriages
illustrations.text: An 80-year-old woman was getting married for the fourth time, which caught a local news channel's interest. The interviewer asked about her life and her new husband, a funeral director. She shared that her first husband was a banker, the second a circus ringmaster, the third a preacher, and now this one. When asked why she married men with such diverse careers, she smiled and said, 'I married one for the money, two for the show, three to get ready, and four to go.' This story illustrates the idea of being prepared and enduring for what's ahead.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to emphasize living with endurance and readiness for Christ's return, as mentioned in Hebrews.

illustrations.title: Fishing in Storms
illustrations.text: Storms make fishing challenging but not impossible, and some fish only come out when storms brew. This means that even in difficult times, opportunities for ministry persist. Jesus tells us to go fish despite the world's lockdowns or busyness. There are people who might be open to salvation now, especially during challenges, just as you might have shared with them before.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is encouraging listeners not to put their spiritual life or ministry on hold, even in tough times, because Jesus calls us to keep going.

illustrations.title: Believers as Lighthouses
illustrations.text: Jesus said you are the light of the world, and also that a person who hears and acts on his words is like a wise man who built his house on a rock, so it withstands storms. Combining these, we are like a lighthouse, standing firm against massive waves. For example, there's a lighthouse off the coast of Oregon that endures 100-foot waves crashing over it. This shows how believers should shine and remain steadfast in trials.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that believers must endure and shine as lights in the world, especially during storms, to guide others.

illustrations.title: Sailing Through Storms
illustrations.text: It's an interesting word; this word 'shrink back' in Greek was literally used for taking a sail on a ship and bringing it down, tying it off because it's too dangerous—you might get killed—so you stay put and go nowhere. We are not those who bring our spiritual sails down; if you give up, you make no progress and remain in the storm. Don't let fear, losses, depression, or thoughts cause you to pull in your sail—hoist your anchor, open your sail, and say, 'Holy Spirit, fill my sail afresh with faith—I'm ready to go, my destination is heaven, my captain is in charge, and I'm in safe hands.' Sail on, sailor.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to emphasize the need to endure and maintain faith during difficult times rather than giving up.

illustrations.title: Pastor's Viewer Numbers Story
illustrations.text: You may not know this, but after every Sunday service and Wednesday night, I'm given a number of how many people are watching on YouTube, FaceTime, and live stream. I look at those numbers and feel encouraged that anyone is out there, but I only see numbers, not names or faces, so I'm a little clueless about who you are. I once sent an email asking how families are doing and got great responses from hundreds in our church, but each viewer is just an IP address, like an iPhone or Android phone or a TV set, usually around Southern California with a few beyond. I'm thrilled to reach you through technology, but I can't see you to smile and tell you I love you, and for a pastor, that's a big deal.
illustrations.context: To express his longing for personal connection with viewers despite the limitations of online ministry.

illustrations.title: Apostle Paul's Letter Quote
illustrations.text: I was thinking about the Apostle Paul and how he had to maintain relationships through the technology of his day, which was writing letters. For instance, to the church at Rome, Paul said, 'I long to see you that I might impart some spiritual gift to you that you may be established.' He also wrote to the church at Thessalonica, 'We, brethren, having been bereft of you for a short while in person not in spirit, were all the more eager with great desire to see your face.' Paul expressed this desire repeatedly, showing he felt the need to be in the same room with them, just as I do with you.
illustrations.context: To connect Paul's yearning for face-to-face fellowship with his own desire to see his congregation in person.

illustrations.title: Song on God's Supremacy
illustrations.text: You know there's a song that says 'you have no rival you have no equal,' and he's powerful, he's the most powerful thing. But we often give power to things that are really powerless in our lives. This reminds us that God stands alone in His power, and we should focus on Him instead of letting trivial matters control us.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to highlight that God has no rival, encouraging listeners to shift their attention to Him as the true source of power.

illustrations.title: Comparison as Joy Thief
illustrations.text: Whether it's through comparison, what is it, comparison is the thief of Joy, right? We'll compare ourselves to others and give power to that. This means we let such comparisons control us, just like we might with other powerless things. Ultimately, it steals our joy and distracts us from God's unmatched power.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to show how comparison gives power to insignificant things, urging people to avoid it and focus on God instead.

illustrations.title: Treasure and Heart Connection
illustrations.text: It's another way we can honor him through our time by spending time here, our talents by serving him, and through our treasure because where our treasure is, our heart is also. This reminds us that giving is tied to our devotion. Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize honoring God in all aspects of life.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that honoring God involves giving treasure, as it reveals where our heart truly lies.

illustrations.title: Jesus Washes Feet
illustrations.text: Before Jesus allowed himself to be known as the bread and the cup in terms of his death at that Passover meal, the very first thing he did was wash feet, something he could have skipped. Peter would have preferred he skipped it, just as I know my own nature would be fine not dealing with my sin. It's not that big a deal, I might think, I can take care of it later, but he knows that my impurities keep me from experiencing all that he has.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that dealing with sin is necessary before fully engaging in worship, as Jesus prioritized washing feet before the Passover meal.

illustrations.title: Trash Truck Analogy
illustrations.text: The bottom line is it's not about me looking at myself as unworthy to take communion; sometimes people say, 'I'm just not going to take it today, it's been a bad day or week.' That's like saying, 'I'm not going to take my trash out, I've got too much,' when the trash truck is here. This is the time to be honest to God about your sins, even if it makes you uncomfortable.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates that avoiding self-examination during communion is like ignoring trash pickup when it's available, emphasizing the need to deal with sin promptly.

illustrations.title: Jesus Revolution Movie Impact
illustrations.text: Becky and I were watching the news the other day when a commercial came on that sounded like Greg Laurie. She confirmed it was him, promoting the Jesus Revolution movie. They made the film for 15 million dollars and hoped to recoup about 7 million, but it's now earned over 35.6 million at the box office and keeps growing. It's opening in new theaters and even going to other nations, and it's been nominated for four Grammys. The wonderful thing is that it's not just about a past event, but revealing the kind of God we have who wants to move in our day.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses the movie's success to illustrate that God is actively working and desires a fresh outpouring of His Spirit in the church today.

illustrations.title: Tombstone Pizza Commercial
illustrations.text: In this 1990s commercial for a frozen pizza company, there's a marshal about to be executed by bad guys. The bad guy tightens the noose and asks if it's too tight, and the marshal says no. Then he asks what the marshal wants on his tombstone, and the marshal replies, 'pepperoni and cheese.' In the next scene, the marshal is eating a hot piece of Tombstone pizza with the noose still around his neck, making the other guy jealous.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this commercial to illustrate that the question 'What do you want on your tombstone?' is profound, as it reflects how your life might be summarized and connected to your legacy.

illustrations.title: Enoch's Walk with God
illustrations.text: In Genesis 5, we are introduced to a man named Enoch. When he was 65 years old, he had a son, and after that birth, Enoch walked with God for 300 years. The account then simply says he was not, because God took him. This brief story stands out in a chapter full of genealogies, highlighting a life devoted to God. We don't know much else about him, like his wife's name or his occupation.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses Enoch's story to emphasize that a life of walking with God is what truly matters and will be reflected in one's legacy.

illustrations.title: Sunday School Drawing Story
illustrations.text: A Sunday school teacher told the kids to keep busy by drawing something while waiting for parents. The teacher walked up to a little boy who was busy making a picture and asked what he was drawing. He said he was drawing a picture of God. The teacher replied that no one knows what God looks like, and the boy responded, 'Well, I'm not done yet.'
illustrations.context: This illustrates that our understanding of God is incomplete and that we are still discovering Him.

illustrations.title: Isaiah on God's Incomparability
illustrations.text: In Isaiah, we read the words: 'To whom will you liken God and what will you compare him to?' This is a rhetorical question that emphasizes God is incomparable to anything else, as any comparison falls short. Pastor Bob explains that God is transcendent and holy, meaning He is different and set apart from all creation.
illustrations.context: This quote highlights God's uniqueness and transcendence to stress that nothing compares to Him.

illustrations.title: Genesis Creation Retelling
illustrations.text: In the beginning, God created the heavens and the earth. The earth was formless and void, darkness was over the surface of the waters, and the Spirit of God was hovering over the waters. Then God said, 'Let there be light,' and it was so. This creation act illustrates who God is, as He brings forth what was and will be.
illustrations.context: This retelling shows that God's creative power reflects His nature and emphasizes His role in fellowship.

illustrations.title: Grandson Flashlight Anecdote
illustrations.text: You see, light is a blessing when I'm in control of it. When my grandson has the flashlight and I'm trying to go to sleep, it's not so much of a blessing. This personal example shows how light can be disruptive in everyday life, contrasting with the idea of God's light.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that light can be a problem when not controlled, emphasizing the need to understand God's light before appreciating His love.

illustrations.title: Sun as Unapproachable Light
illustrations.text: He dwells in unapproachable light, like our sun. It's wonderful to see the sun at a distance, but it can be overwhelming up close. This analogy helps explain God's holiness and how He reveals Himself through light metaphors.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that God is holy and unapproachable, much like the sun, to teach about starting with God's light before understanding His love.

illustrations.title: 1 Timothy on God's Light
illustrations.text: In First Timothy 6:16, Paul says that God alone possesses immortality and dwells in unapproachable light, whom no man has seen or can see. Pastor Bob connects this to show that God is light in a profound, invisible way. This quote emphasizes God's unapproachable holiness and why we must understand it to have true fellowship with Him.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to explain that God dwells in unapproachable light, highlighting the need to grasp His holiness before exploring His love.

illustrations.title: Psalm 84 God as Sun
illustrations.text: Psalm 84:11 writes that the Lord God is a sun and a shield. Pastor Bob explains that when God wants to reveal Himself, He uses the metaphor of the sun, connecting it to light as a way to understand His nature. This quote illustrates how God employs everyday elements like the sun to teach about His character and protection.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to show that God reveals Himself as light and a sun, underscoring the importance of starting with His holiness for fellowship.

illustrations.title: Isaiah's Encounter with God
illustrations.text: He didn't say 'whoa, this is cool'; he said 'woe is me.' It was not a cool experience for him at all. The holiness of God is the most hazardous material you will ever experience in your life. Before Isaiah could discover God's grace, he needed to face God's holiness head-on, which put him in his place to begin with.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that encountering God's holiness is terrifying and necessary before experiencing His grace.

illustrations.title: Peter's Miraculous Catch
illustrations.text: Do you think Peter thought it was cool when Jesus caused fish to go into his net? He was a fisherman, but that's not how it went. The Bible says he got down on his knees and said, 'Depart from me, Lord, for I am a sinful man.' This shows that a miracle from Jesus led Peter to recognize his own sinfulness.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates that experiencing God's power, like a miracle, can reveal one's sinfulness and lead to humility.

illustrations.title: Jesus Calming the Storm
illustrations.text: When Jesus calmed the storm on the Sea of Galilee, the disciples were upset that He was sleeping while they bailed water. They woke Him and said, 'Lord, don't you care that we're going to die?' Jesus rebuked the storm, making it calm, and then rebuked them for their little faith. After the storm passed, the disciples became even more afraid, realizing they were in the presence of the holy God.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize that God's holiness is more terrifying than any external threat, once the immediate danger is gone.

illustrations.title: God as Consuming Fire
illustrations.text: It's interesting that God would reveal himself through the physical sun, which no man could approach without being destroyed. At the core of the sun, nuclear fusion creates hydrogen at 22 million degrees Fahrenheit, producing gamma rays that are absolutely destructive to humans. One pinhead of that material would kill every person within 100 miles, making it invisible and deadly light. God says, 'I am a consuming fire,' like the sun's invisible light that humans can't withstand.
illustrations.context: This illustrates God's holiness as something powerful and dangerous that humans cannot fully approach.

illustrations.title: Moses Seeking God's Glory
illustrations.text: Moses was the closest man on Earth to God and had found favor with Him. Moses said, 'If I've got favor with you, let me ask for something more—I want to see your face and your glory.' God responded that no man could be that close and survive, emphasizing His holiness. This shows Moses' desperation for more of God as a sign of true closeness.
illustrations.context: This retelling highlights that being close to God involves a deep desire for more of Him and reveals His unapproachable holiness.

illustrations.title: Morning Wake-Up with Becky
illustrations.text: Becky asked me what time it is, and I said it's almost six. She then asked if I wanted to get up, and I replied it's still dark. This personal moment illustrates how God's light comes each morning to wake us up and bring hope, just as the sunrise teaches us about renewal.
illustrations.context: This shows that God's light brings hope and awakens us to new beginnings, as described in Isaiah 60:1.

illustrations.title: Jeremiah's Lament and Destruction
illustrations.text: Lamentations is written by Jeremiah, the weeping prophet, after he predicted the Babylonian invasion that destroyed Jerusalem, burned the temple, and led to the captivity of the Jews. In this context of immense suffering and loss, Jeremiah recalls God's loving kindness and compassions that never cease and are new every morning. Despite the pain, he finds hope in the Lord, not in his circumstances.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that even in the midst of devastation, God's faithfulness and mercies provide enduring hope.

illustrations.title: Light of Morning Analogy
illustrations.text: God uses the light of a new morning to teach us that it comes to wake us up each day. This light symbolizes how God's light brings hope and renewal, reminding us to arise and shine. Just as the sun rises reliably, God's mercies are new every morning, offering a fresh start.
illustrations.context: This analogy emphasizes that God's light provides hope and awakens us spiritually, as seen in Isaiah 60:1.

illustrations.title: Spouse as God's Good Gift
illustrations.text: James 1:17 states that every good thing is bestowed by God, and Pastor Bob explains that for married people, a spouse is one of those good things. He urges couples to appreciate this by elbowing each other and affirming it, connecting it to God's faithfulness in giving blessings. This quote highlights how God's gifts, like marriage, reflect His ongoing goodness amid life's challenges.
illustrations.context: This quote illustrates that God's bestowed gifts, such as a spouse, are part of His unchanging goodness and provide hope in daily life.

illustrations.title: Stumbling in the Dark Analogy
illustrations.text: Somebody has defined the human shin as a device to find furniture in the dark. We are stumbling around before Christ comes into our life, not knowing where we're going or why we're going there. We don't know our purpose or the way, highlighting how darkness leads to confusion and error.
illustrations.context: This analogy illustrates how people live in spiritual darkness without Christ, causing them to stumble and lose direction.

illustrations.title: Chicken Protects Chicks in Fire
illustrations.text: National Geographic years ago covered a wildfire in the Midwest that destroyed pastures and farmlands. A photographer went out and found the farm burned to the ground, with the barn destroyed and many animals caught in it. They discovered a completely burned chicken, and underneath its wings, baby chicks emerged alive, having survived the fire. The chicken had given its life to protect its chicks, illustrating a powerful picture of sacrifice.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how God protects believers from the destruction of His holiness, much like a mother hen shields her chicks.

illustrations.title: Jesus as Hen Gathering Chicks
illustrations.text: You can't help but remember what Jesus said: 'Oh Jerusalem, Jerusalem, you who stoned the prophets and killed those sent to you, how often I have longed to gather your children together, as a hen gathers her chicks under her wings, but you were not willing.' This quote shows Jesus' desire to protect and gather His people, connecting to the wildfire story as an example of divine love and protection. It emphasizes that God's wrath falls on Christ instead, allowing forgiveness for sinners.
illustrations.context: This quote highlights that God's holiness and justice are fully satisfied through Christ, offering hope and protection to believers.

illustrations.title: Evangelists and Their Singers
illustrations.text: You may know the name George Beverly Shea, who was linked with Billy Graham for decades, a great baritone voice who sang at many crusades and died at 104 as a godly man. In the previous century, before Billy Graham, there was Dwight L. Moody, an incredible preacher and revivalist, and his singer Ira Sankey, who became famous alongside Moody as he preached and Sankey sang at the crusades. As Moody became famous, so did Sankey, with newspapers covering their work. This historical parallel shows the enduring impact of faithful ministry teams in spreading the gospel.
illustrations.context: This reference illustrates the consistency of God's work through history, linking to themes of faith and protection in evangelism.

illustrations.title: Ira Sankey's Wartime Song
illustrations.text: On a Christmas Eve in 1870, Ira Sankey was on a riverboat on the Delaware River when people recognized him and asked him to sing. He performed the hymn 'Savior, Like a Shepherd Lead Us' with his powerful baritone voice. As he sang, a Confederate soldier from the Civil War watched from the shadows, reminded of his mother who used to sing the same song to him. The soldier confessed that he had once aimed his rifle at Sankey during the war but couldn't pull the trigger after hearing the hymn, as it evoked memories and stayed his hand. This story highlights how a simple song can deeply impact a person's soul and decisions.
illustrations.context: The illustration demonstrates the transformative power of a hymn in preventing violence and evoking personal faith.

illustrations.title: Ira and the Confederate Soldier
illustrations.text: A Confederate soldier told Ira that he had aimed his rifle at Ira in the dark but couldn't pull the trigger. So, Ira put his rifle down and snuck away into the night. The soldier said, 'Sir, you never knew I was there, but your Shepherd was protecting you,' and at that point, Ira led the soldier to accept Jesus Christ as his Savior.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate how God protects believers in unseen ways, just as the Shepherd protected Ira.

illustrations.title: Jesus Reveals God to Philip
illustrations.text: Remember what Jesus said to Philip: Philip asked, 'Just show us the Father, and that's enough.' Jesus replied, 'Have I been with you so long, Philip, and you still don't know me? Anyone who has seen me has seen the Father.' This illustrates that Jesus makes the invisible God visible through His person.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that Jesus reveals the nature of God, making the invisible God approachable.

illustrations.title: Incarnation as God Slowing Down
illustrations.text: God dwells in unapproachable light, which you can't handle, but John says we've handled the Word of life. That's God slowing down to us. The Incarnation is God slowing down His deity, not diminishing it at all, but making it slow enough so you could handle Him literally and approach Him.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates how Jesus makes the unapproachable God accessible through the Incarnation.

illustrations.title: Jesus as the Light of the World
illustrations.text: It's interesting that Jesus says, 'I am the light of the world,' that visible light that can enlighten every person. This means Jesus brings revelation and clarity about God, just as light dispels darkness. Through this, we see how God has spoken to us in these last days through His Son.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize that Jesus enlightens people about God's nature and character.

illustrations.title: Light's Dual Nature Analogy
illustrations.text: Scientists for a long time tried to study light, saying it's a particle, no it's a wave, no it's a particle. Well, actually it's both simultaneously. It took Albert Einstein to explain the mystery of the nature of light. It's hard to understand, but anyone can experience and enjoy light, just like any child can turn on a light switch or go outside in the sun.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that Jesus's dual nature as fully God and fully man is mysterious yet accessible to everyone, not requiring deep expertise.

illustrations.title: Children's Light Capacity Story
illustrations.text: Children have a greater capacity to let light in because of how their eyes develop. I recognize this with our young people on staff; they don't turn the lights on in their offices even with natural light coming in. I'll walk around and turn the light on for them, joking that we pay the bills, because I can't see well without it.
illustrations.context: This shows that children naturally receive more light, symbolizing spiritual openness and the need to approach faith with childlike simplicity.

illustrations.title: Jesus in the Temple
illustrations.text: Jesus went into the temple at the end of his ministry and found the money changers selling animals in the court of the Gentiles, turning God's house into a den of thieves instead of a house of prayer. He drove them out, and then he began healing people there—the blind received sight, the lame started walking, and miracles happened. The children recognized him as the Messiah and cried out praises like 'Hosanna to the Son of David,' while the chief priests and scribes became indignant.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that children are often the ones who recognize and welcome Jesus as the Messiah.

illustrations.title: Barna Survey on Salvation
illustrations.text: Barna conducted a survey showing that 83 percent of people who claim to be born again got saved between the ages of 4 and 14. Pastor Bob notes that he is one of them, having had that experience himself. He adds that while it's rarer for older people, like those in their 50s or 60s, to come to faith, it's not impossible because God performs miracles at any age.
illustrations.context: This example highlights that children are more likely to accept faith, emphasizing the importance of early spiritual encounters.

illustrations.title: Audible Spectrum Perception
illustrations.text: When it comes to the audible spectrum, there's a range of sounds that human adults can't hear, called ultrasonic sounds, which are shown on a slide with a purple line indicating adult hearing limits. Certain animals can hear these sounds, much like how children seem to perceive spiritual truths that others miss. This illustrates that just as some creatures access frequencies beyond human capability, children have a unique ability to recognize divine things.
illustrations.context: This analogy shows that children can spiritually perceive what adults often cannot, similar to hearing beyond normal ranges.

illustrations.title: Wife's Tinnitus Healing Story
illustrations.text: My wife suffered for three years with tinnitus, a constant ringing in the ears that was horrible and very difficult for her. I was in the emergency room with her twice late at night, but they couldn't provide any help, and she underwent MRIs and every test to find the source. It was miserable, like a life sentence for those who endure it, so we kept praying. The Lord provided a doctor, a specialist at the Cleveland Clinic who had joined us on a trip to Israel and attends our church. She offered to fly us out for a three-day evaluation with different doctors, and we were thrilled, thinking this was the answer. Just before we went, after persistent prayer and fasting from some women, my wife woke me up in the middle of the night, crying that the tinnitus was gone.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to illustrate God's provision and the power of prayer, connecting to the idea of experiences beyond human senses.

illustrations.title: Tinnitus Healing Testimony
illustrations.text: A woman told me that the sound of her tinnitus was gone after prayer. She was so overjoyed that she wept and called her sister in the middle of the night to celebrate, as her sister had been one of the people praying for it. That was years ago, and it has never returned, showing the lasting nature of God's healing.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the complete and permanent healing that God provides.

illustrations.title: Family Frequency Test
illustrations.text: I preached about frequencies that only young people can hear, like those used in England to deter teenagers from lingering in stores. We decided to test it with my sons, grandchildren, and myself by playing the frequencies online. My little grandchildren could hear the specific frequency that no one else could, highlighting how youth perceive things differently.
illustrations.context: This leads to the point that God's healing restores wholeness, like the freshness of a child.

illustrations.title: Naaman's Leprosy Healing
illustrations.text: Do you remember when Naaman got healed of leprosy? It wasn't just a partial fix; the Bible says he ended up with the flesh of a little child, showing how thorough God's healing is. When God heals, He does a complete job, restoring everything fully.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that God's healing is perfect and restorative, not incomplete.

illustrations.title: Rock of Ages Hymn
illustrations.text: We used to sing a song about perfect justice and perfect mercy, capturing God's nature. The hymn by Augustus Toplady goes, 'Rock of Ages, cleft for me, let me hide myself in thee; let the water and the blood from thy wounded side which flowed be of sin the double cure, save from wrath and make me pure.' This quote shows the cross as a place of refuge, where God's justice and mercy meet to cleanse and save sinners.
illustrations.context: This emphasizes that the cross displays God's hatred for sin and His love for sinners simultaneously.

illustrations.title: Child's Forgotten Son Story
illustrations.text: A four-year-old came home from church and said he had memorized his first Bible verse. He shared it as, 'For God so loved the world that he gave his only forgotten son that whosoever believed in him might not perish but have everlasting life.' When his dad asked him to repeat it, he said the same thing, so the dad gently explained, 'Honey, do you know why Jesus is God's only forgotten son?' The child said no, and the dad replied, 'So he would never have to forget you. He will never forget you.'
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to emphasize that God never forgets His people, connecting it to the idea of being engraved on God's hands.

illustrations.title: God's Revelation to Pastor
illustrations.text: The other night, I said to the Lord, 'I don't know what you're doing.' He told me, 'Call unto me, and I'll show you great and mighty things you know not of.' That's the problem; I don't need to know everything because my job is to call to Him, trust Him, and expect Him to work.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is emphasizing the need to seek God actively and trust Him to reveal and accomplish His work.

illustrations.title: Ark as Christ Analogy
illustrations.text: Let me ask you how the Ark of Noah is like Jesus Christ. Whoever is in the Ark is safe from the judgment of God, just as in Christ there is no condemnation. The Ark is the only way to be saved, sealed by God, much like how God seals us in Christ through the Holy Spirit.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that the Ark represents salvation and security in Jesus Christ as the sole means of escaping God's judgment.

illustrations.title: Peter's Baptism Comparison
illustrations.text: Peter points out that eight souls were saved through water, drawing the analogy that baptism now saves you, not as a ceremony but through the appeal to God for a clean conscience. This corresponds to the judgment on the world in Noah's time and how God brings salvation through faith. It's faith demonstrated in baptism that matters.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is using Peter's reference to show that salvation comes through faith, mirroring the deliverance in Noah's story.

illustrations.title: Noah's Silent Ark Experience
illustrations.text: God says nothing during the time that Noah is in the ark for a year and ten days during the entire storm and flood. There's no rudder, no sail, no steering wheel; he's just bobbing with his family. Noah is in the center of God's will, doing what God called him to do, yet God chooses to be quiet. After five months, the Bible says God remembered Noah, showing that even in silence, God is present. This illustrates that storms in life may make you feel forsaken, but you're not.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that God can be silent even when you are faithfully in His will, emphasizing that such times do not mean abandonment.

illustrations.title: King Saul's Unheard Prayers
illustrations.text: In the Old Testament, King Saul is a good example of someone trying to hear from God because of his sin, but God refuses to speak. God says we're not talking to him due to his disobedience. This contrasts with Noah, showing that God's silence can sometimes result from sin.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to explain that God's silence is not always because you're in His will, as in Saul's case it stems from sin.

illustrations.title: David's Psalm of Trouble
illustrations.text: In Psalm 10, verse 1, David cries out, 'Why do you stand afar off, O Lord? Why do you hide yourself in times of trouble?' This reflects the feeling of being forsaken by God during hard times. Pastor Bob connects it to personal experiences where prayers seem unanswered and God feels distant. It reassures that even biblical figures like David felt this way, yet God remains faithful.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to comfort those feeling abandoned in their storms, showing it's a common experience even for the faithful.

illustrations.title: God's Promise to Jacob
illustrations.text: God made a promise to Jacob when he first met the Lord in Genesis 28, in a dream at Bethel, saying, 'I will be with you and will not forsake you; I will bring you back.' This promise was given to a conniving and sinful man who didn't deserve it. Years later, after 20 years, Jacob returns and thanks God, acknowledging that God kept His word through everything. It shows that God remains faithful despite our flaws.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that God never forsakes us, even if we feel alone in our storms.

illustrations.title: Storms as Life's Analogy
illustrations.text: Can I tell you something about this analogy of storms in the Bible? God's the ultimate weather controller, always right and in charge. In Psalm 107, those who go down to the sea in ships and do business on great waters have seen the works of the Lord and His wonders in the deep. He spoke and raised up a stormy wind, lifting up the waves of the sea; they rose to the heavens and plunged to the depths, their souls melting in misery as they reeled and staggered like drunk men at their wit's end. Then they cried to the Lord in their trouble, and He brought them out of distress, stilling the storm so the waves were hushed, guiding them to their desired haven.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to show that God intentionally brings people into storms to lead them to a place of dependence on Him for salvation and guidance.

illustrations.title: Job's Waves of the Sea
illustrations.text: Speaking of God, Job says this: God alone stretches out the heavens and treads on the waves of the sea. This shows that God has victory over the stormy waves, and Jesus demonstrated the same when he walked on water. It's unique among Jesus' miracles because it highlights his divine control rather than just healing or providing for needs.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to illustrate that Jesus walking on water demonstrates his divine authority and control over nature, as described in Job.

illustrations.title: Jonah's Path of Correction
illustrations.text: Sometimes God sends storms to correct us when we're going the wrong way, like with Jonah. Jonah was going the wrong way from where God had sent him to go, and God intervened with a storm. This example shows that divine storms can redirect us back to God's plan.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that God uses storms in the Bible to correct people who are straying from His path, as seen with Jonah.

illustrations.title: Jesus on Stormy Sea
illustrations.text: I think about when Jesus came to the disciples out on the Sea of Galilee. It was stormy and nighttime, and these veteran fishermen were used to crossing the lake, but they couldn't get across without Jesus in the boat. They were straining at the oars with water coming in, which was a bad sign, and then Jesus came to them in the middle of the night. John 6:21 says they were willing to receive him into the boat, and immediately the boat reached the land they were going to. I love that even though they had crossed the Sea of Galilee many times, they couldn't do it alone that night.
illustrations.context: In the midst of your storm, you must be willing to receive Jesus to reach your destination safely.

illustrations.title: Old Song of Promises
illustrations.text: There's an old song that says there are some promises in a letter written a long time ago, and they're not getting older—they're getting better because God still wants us to know. He didn't bring us this far to leave us; he didn't teach us to swim to let us drown; he didn't build his home in us to move away; he didn't lift us up to let us down. This means that when you can't hear God speaking, you have to hold on to what he's already said.
illustrations.context: You can trust God's promises to bring you through storms, even when He seems silent.

illustrations.title: Father's Relentless Rescue
illustrations.text: A father was told his son was in the hospital after an earthquake, but he discovered the son was at school and began digging through the rubble amid tragedy. Despite finding many children dead, he persisted and eventually learned his son was alive. This reminded me of the 1989 Armenia earthquake, where a father rushed to his son's flattened school and dug for hours, ignoring others who urged him to stop. He remembered his promise to always be there for his son and continued alone for 38 hours until he heard his son's voice calling back. His determination triumphed in the face of devastation.
illustrations.context: To illustrate unwavering commitment and love, like a father's persistence in seeking his child, mirroring spiritual truths of God's pursuit.

illustrations.title: Father Rescues Son in Collapse
illustrations.text: A son trapped in a collapsed building told the other kids not to worry because he knew his father would save them. The father arrived, and the son insisted the other kids be rescued first, trusting his father would come for him no matter what. This story illustrates unwavering faith in a promise of rescue.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that God's promise means He will always be there for you, even when you don't hear anything.

illustrations.title: Boy Misremembers Bible Verse
illustrations.text: A little boy came home after memorizing his first Bible verse, John 3:16, but he said it as 'for God so loved the world that He gave His only forgotten son.' His parents didn't laugh, and his dad explained that Jesus is God's only forgotten son so that God will never forget you. This humorous mix-up leads to a deeper truth about God's remembrance.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize that even if you feel God-forsaken, He will never forget you.

illustrations.title: Jonah's Story of Rescue
illustrations.text: Jonah thought he was in the depths of Sheol, far from God's presence, but he cried out to God and was rescued. Even in the remotest places, God reaches out and saves. This retelling highlights that no matter how far you've sunk, God is there.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that you are not in a God-forsaken place, as God is always present and rescues His people.

illustrations.title: Noah's Flood as New Creation
illustrations.text: It's interesting how God flooded the earth and then brought a wind to subside the waters. It rained for 40 days and 40 nights, and the waters increased for five months from the fountains below and above, covering the entire world until the highest mountains were submerged. Then God waited quietly, and the Bible says God remembered Noah as the wind started to pass over. This signifies a new creation, with Noah and his family like a new Adam and Eve, beginning again. In Genesis 1, the earth was formless and void, with darkness over the surface of the waters, and the Spirit of God was moving over them. The Hebrew word for Spirit is Ruach, which also means wind, just like here. So, the wind, or Ruach, is moving over the waters, signaling a brand new creation, bringing everything back to what God did.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is showing how the Noah flood story illustrates God's renewal and parallels the original creation, emphasizing spiritual rebirth.

illustrations.title: Sign of Jonah Retelling
illustrations.text: Jesus was asked by the Jews for a sign, and he replied that an evil and adulterous generation seeks after a sign, but no sign will be given except the sign of Jonah. He explained that just as Jonah was in the belly of the great fish for three days and three nights, so the Son of Man will be in the heart of the earth for three days and three nights. This story highlights the resurrection as the ultimate proof.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that the resurrection is the ultimate sign proving Jesus' identity.

illustrations.title: Missionary and Buddhist Story
illustrations.text: A true story: A missionary in a foreign country was trying to share about Jesus and Christianity with his Buddhist neighbor. The neighbor claimed there was no real difference, as both believed in a higher power. That day, a parade celebrated a supposed bone of Buddha, and the missionary explained that Christians would mourn if they found a bone of Jesus, because he rose from the dead, setting Christianity apart from other religions.
illustrations.context: This shows that the resurrection uniquely distinguishes Christianity from other faiths.

illustrations.title: Muslim Conversion Example
illustrations.text: There was a Muslim who came to Christ, and when his friend asked why he left Islam for Christianity, he explained that it didn't make sense to them. He said it was because of the unique truth of Christianity, likely pointing to the resurrection. This story underscores the difference between Christianity and other religions where founders remain dead.
illustrations.context: This reinforces that the resurrection is the key evidence that sets Christianity apart.

illustrations.title: Ask Directions Analogy
illustrations.text: If you were lost going down a road and came to a fork in the road with two men—one dead and one alive—who would you ask directions from? Jesus Christ is alive, not dead, and He said, 'I am the way, the truth, and the life; no one comes to the Father except through me.' This illustrates that we should follow the living guide, not a dead one.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to emphasize that Jesus is alive and reliable as the way to God.

illustrations.title: Garden Tomb Visit
illustrations.text: When we go to Israel, we visit the Garden Tomb, which may have been Christ's tomb or one just like it. It's a joy to go into that tomb and realize how empty it is, reminding ourselves that they came to His tomb and found it empty. Even if that's not exactly where Jesus was buried, the emptiness symbolizes His resurrection.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob shares this to affirm the reality of Jesus' resurrection and the empty tomb.

illustrations.title: Roman Persecution History
illustrations.text: For 300 years, the Roman Empire persecuted Christians with ten waves of persecution, killing sixty million Christians. If Rome could have produced the body of Jesus, they would have done it immediately to disprove the resurrection. They never could because the body wasn't there, proving Jesus rose from the dead.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to argue that the resurrection is true, as opponents couldn't disprove it.

illustrations.title: Disciples as Martyrs
illustrations.text: If the disciples stole Jesus' body to make people think He rose from the dead, then they went on to be arrested one by one and die torturous martyr deaths for a lie they knew was false. Plenty of people die for lies they believe are true, like those in the 9/11 attacks who were sincerely deceived. But no one dies for a lie they know is a lie if telling the truth would save them, as seen in the apostles' fates.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates that the apostles' martyrdom supports the truth of the resurrection, not a fabricated story.

illustrations.title: 9/11 Deception Example
illustrations.text: Just go back to 9/11, where people were very sincere and sincerely deceived, willing to die for their deception. This shows that people die for lies they believe are true. In contrast, the apostles wouldn't have died for a known lie.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to differentiate between sincere deception and the apostles' knowing the truth of the resurrection.

illustrations.title: Apostles' Deaths History
illustrations.text: Peter was crucified upside down because he didn't feel worthy to be killed as Jesus was. James was beheaded for his faith, and Matthew was clubbed to death. Each apostle, except John who was exiled and died of natural causes, faced torturous deaths for their testimony.
