illustrations.context: Pastor Bob highlights this to show that the apostles died for the truth of Jesus' resurrection.

illustrations.title: Noah's Raven Release
illustrations.text: At the end of the 150 days, Noah opened the window in the ark that he had made. He sent out a raven, and it flew here and there until the water was dried up from the earth. It's interesting that Noah became a spiritual bird watcher, and in the book of Job, it says to go to the animals and let them instruct you, go to the fowls of the air and they'll tell you there are lessons to be learned from the birds.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate the theme of testing and gaining insight through observation, connecting it to spiritual lessons from nature.

illustrations.title: Job's Lesson from Birds
illustrations.text: In the book of Job chapter 12, Job says go to the animals and let them instruct you, go to the fowls of the air and they'll tell you. There are lessons to be learned from the birds, as seen in how Noah observed the raven. This connects to understanding spiritual truths through creation.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that observing nature, like birds, can provide instruction and reveal deeper spiritual meanings related to testing and evil.

illustrations.title: Raven Devil Comparison
illustrations.text: Here we have an unclean bird, the raven, which Noah lets out of the ark and it doesn't come back. It goes to and fro throughout the earth, landing and eating anything, even garbage, much like how the devil operates. I find it raven-esque of the way the devil works, as seen when Satan tells God he's been going to and fro on the earth, similar to the raven's wandering.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to illustrate how the devil prowls and seeks, much like the raven in the biblical story.

illustrations.title: Two Natures in Man Quote
illustrations.text: As J. Vernon McGee says, there are two natures within man, even the same man—we have the old nature and the new nature. The old nature, like the raven, finds plenty in a deluge world filled with death to occupy itself. Pastor Bob connects this to the contrast between the raven and the dove to show the difference between impurity and purity.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to explain the internal conflict of old and new natures in believers, illustrated by the raven and dove.

illustrations.title: Man Pushing Away Life Preserver
illustrations.text: I saw a painting once of a storm with a man overboard. He was drenched and about to drown, with a life preserver just a couple feet away. It looked like he was reaching for it to be saved, but upon closer inspection, he was actually pushing it away. This illustrates how some people reject help even in dire situations. It's a powerful image of defiance against rescue.
illustrations.context: This illustration shows how people reject God, like those during the tribulation who deny Him despite knowing His existence.

illustrations.title: Man with Gun to His Head
illustrations.text: I had a man once who had a gun to his head, with the trigger cocked, ready to end his life. When I walked in, he was shocked, and I asked him to put the gun down, which he did. As I talked to him, he shared his misery—his marriage was a mess, he was an alcoholic, and he felt hopeless. When I mentioned Jesus, he refused, saying anything but that, even though he had nothing else. This story highlights how deception can make people turn away from the very help they need.
illustrations.context: This personal story emphasizes how the raven-like nature in people leads them to reject God despite their desperate circumstances.

illustrations.title: Matthew Henry on Restless Dove
illustrations.text: Matthew Henry the great commentator said it's like the nature of man, this dove that goes out, it goes to and fro looking for rest but doesn't find any until it returns to the one who sent it out to begin with. See, that's us, as humans seeking true rest.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that humans, like the dove, seek rest but only find it in God.

illustrations.title: Augustine on Restless Hearts
illustrations.text: Augustine said the same thing: our hearts are restless, God, until they find their rest in you. This connects to the idea that we must return to God for true peace.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is emphasizing that human hearts are restless until they find rest in God, mirroring the dove's experience.

illustrations.title: Dove as Holy Spirit Analogy
illustrations.text: In verse 9, the dove comes back to Noah, but it doesn't just land or fly by; then Noah put out his hand and took her and brought her into the ark to himself. I believe this is a type of the Holy Spirit, showing how we must reach out and receive it. It's like the Holy Spirit being available, but we have to actively take hold of it for fullness in our lives.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that believers must actively reach out to receive and be filled by the Holy Spirit, just as Noah did with the dove.

illustrations.title: The Unlit Firewood Attempt
illustrations.text: Years ago, I lived in Placentia, and our home had beautiful trees that the city would trim every so often. They would cut the trees into logs and stack them in front of houses. One winter, I wanted firewood for our fireplace but didn't have money to buy any, so I asked the workers if I could have the logs, and they said yes. I excitedly took them home, stacked them perfectly, and couldn't wait to build a fire. The next morning, I arranged the wood beautifully, lit some newspaper underneath, but the logs wouldn't catch fire no matter how hard I tried, even with kindling.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that one must actively participate and take steps by faith to receive what God offers, rather than waiting passively.

illustrations.title: Green Wood Burning Fail
illustrations.text: I took lighter fluid and squirted it all over the wood, but it just fizzled and sizzled without catching fire. I felt pretty stupid because the wood was green, full of sap and water from being freshly cut, and it needed to dry out first. A friend told me that things with life in them won't burn properly, and eventually, I got it to work after preparing it right.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that just as green wood full of sap won't burn, a person who is full of themselves cannot be filled by the Holy Spirit.

illustrations.title: Moses' Three Life Stages
illustrations.text: Moses lived to be 120 years old, and his life can be divided into three segments of 40 years. In the first 40 years, he thought he was somebody, raised as Pharaoh's son with wealth and wisdom, and tried to save his people, but God couldn't use him yet. In the next 40 years, he was in the desert watching sheep, learning humility, and then in the final 40 years, he started his ministry.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that God can use people only after they humble themselves and realize they have nothing to offer.

illustrations.title: Amundsen's Homing Pigeon Story
illustrations.text: The great Norwegian explorer Roald Amundsen was the first to discover the magnetic meridian of the North Pole and the South Pole. On one of his trips, he took a homing pigeon with him. When he reached the top of the world, he opened the bird cage and set it free. Imagine the delight of Amundsen's wife back in Norway when she looked up and saw the pigeon circling in the sky above; no doubt she exclaimed, 'He's alive! My husband is still alive.' So it was when Jesus ascended; he was gone, but the disciples clung to his promise to send the Holy Spirit, and what joy they had when that dove-like Holy Spirit descended at Pentecost.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate how the Holy Spirit confirms Jesus' promise and brings joy to believers, just as the pigeon confirmed Amundsen's survival.

illustrations.title: Waiting on the Ark Analogy
illustrations.text: You ever been on a boat for a little while and you're ready to get off? For me, it's about five minutes. I'm sure it was the same for Noah—this was a floating zoo, and I'm sure the animals couldn't wait to get off either. He had to wait until God told him to go.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to illustrate the impatience of waiting on God, like Noah on the Ark, emphasizing the need to wait for God's timing.

illustrations.title: Family Drive and McDonald's Joy
illustrations.text: I was listening to a song while driving home on a Wednesday night with my kids in the car. They didn't want the free food at church, so we ended up getting McDonald's instead, even though I thought it was expensive and unhealthy. My son was so excited about the toy he got, and I saw the pure joy in his heart, making me long to stay in that moment forever.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to illustrate the beauty and longing for simple, joyful family moments.

illustrations.title: Wayne's Son Building Memories
illustrations.text: Wayne, our sound man, told me a story the other day about his son. They were building things together when his son was just in a diaper, and he was nailing things into the house they built. Those nails are still in the walls somewhere, and it's just beautiful stuff about this life we have.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob shares this real-world example to highlight the enduring beauty of simple, shared family experiences.

illustrations.title: Cherishing Fleeting Family Moments
illustrations.text: I think those moments in our lives that we can't cling to because they'll pass. Our kids will grow and no longer require us to stop at McDonald's. Then we'll be driving home from church and think, man, I wish I could stop at McDonald's. You still can, but it's a good thing to ready our hearts and remind ourselves that He is already ruling and reigning, and the things of Earth will pass away.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that while we prepare for Christ's return, we should cherish present joys because earthly moments are temporary.

illustrations.title: Paul and Silas in Prison
illustrations.text: Just like Paul and Silas singing in prison, we want to see foundations shaken this morning, chains of prisoners falling off, and prison doors shaken off their hinges so that captives are set free. This draws from their story of praise leading to miraculous deliverance. It's a call for similar spiritual breakthroughs in our worship today.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how worship, like that of Paul and Silas, can shake spiritual foundations and bring freedom.

illustrations.title: Childhood Faith Experience
illustrations.text: As we often say from the platform here, our purpose as a church is that you may know God—it starts there so that you might really have a relationship with Him. I grew up knowing about God but I didn't know Him personally. I pray that is your experience, emphasizing the importance of a true personal connection with God.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating the difference between knowing about God and having a personal relationship with Him to encourage the audience to seek a genuine faith experience.

illustrations.title: Meeting Richard Nixon
illustrations.text: I grew up in Yorba Linda when I was six years old, and it became famous because of its most famous resident, Richard Nixon. In school, I did a report on him, copying details from the encyclopedia about his birth, his house in Whittier, his law practice, and his political career, which made me feel like I knew him. But I had never met him until he came to Yorba Linda to campaign for president, and I shook his hand as the candidate who later became president. Our interaction didn't go deep; it wasn't something to boast about like saying, 'Guess who I met today?'
illustrations.context: This illustrates the difference between knowing about God intellectually and having a personal relationship with Him.

illustrations.title: Paul's Farewell to Ephesus
illustrations.text: Think of Paul and his last words to the Elders of Ephesus. Remember, Paul was in Ephesus; he planted the church and stayed there for three years, longer than with any other church, and grew with a tremendous love for these people. At the end of those three years, he knew he was leaving and would never see them again until heaven. They wept together on the beach at Miletus. In Acts 20, verse 32, Paul said, 'Now I commend you to God and to the word of his grace, which is able to build you up and give you an inheritance among all those who are sanctified.'
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize the priority of accurate interpretation and the essential role of God's word in building up believers.

illustrations.title: Bible as Polygraph Analogy
illustrations.text: We are to measure everything by the Bible, which is our polygraph when it comes to people speaking from any pulpit or anywhere else. Whether it's a book you're reading, a seminar you attend, a poet you listen to, or a philosopher, you must check if they are speaking according to God's word. The Bible helps us discern truth from falsehood in all these areas.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that the Bible serves as a reliable tool to test the truthfulness of teachings and messages.

illustrations.title: False Prophets Warning Quote
illustrations.text: Jot down Jeremiah 23 and verse 16: Thus says the Lord of hosts, do not listen to the words of the prophets who are prophesying to you; they are leading you into futility, they speak a vision of their own imagination, not from the mouth of the Lord. This was the problem with the false prophets that's always been; they speak a word as though it's from God but it's not really from God. We must be cautious of such teachings today.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that false prophets rely on their own ideas rather than God's word, emphasizing the need to verify messages against scripture.

illustrations.title: Misinterpreting Scripture on Drunkenness
illustrations.text: I had a guy come to me years ago who said he knew Jesus would never get drunk but thought he'd get buzzed. I asked him what he meant, and he claimed it was in the Bible, specifically Ephesians 5:18, which says do not be drunk with wine to excess. He interpreted it to mean Jesus wouldn't get falling-down drunk but might get mildly intoxicated. I explained that the verse actually warns against drunkenness and intoxication as debauchery, not just extreme excess, and he admitted he had never seen it that way before.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show how people mistakenly twist Bible verses to justify unbiblical behavior.

illustrations.title: The Slave Bible Distortion
illustrations.text: Do you know in the 1800s there was a version of the Bible commonly called the Slave Bible? It was specifically selected for use by enslaved people and omitted parts that might encourage rebellion or freedom. This altered Bible was used to manipulate and control, showing how scriptures can be distorted to support perverse ideas. The Slave Bible illustrates the danger of taking verses out of context for selfish purposes.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to demonstrate how false teachers distort Scriptures, as warned in Peter's letters, leading to destruction.

illustrations.title: Slave Owners' Bible Distortion
illustrations.text: Slave owners took out parts of Exodus about liberation and emphasized sections in Colossians and Ephesians that spoke to slaves, justifying slavery. They created a Bible to encourage slave holders to teach it to their slaves, making them believe God wanted them kept in place. This manipulation was sick and exactly what slave owners did to maintain control.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate how scripture can be twisted to justify evil actions like slavery.

illustrations.title: Hitler's Scripture Enforcement
illustrations.text: Hitler had favorite passages in the Bible, specifically Romans 13:1-7 and First Peter chapter two, which deal with obedience to the government. During his reign, he required German churches to preach on one of these passages at least once a year to enforce that people must obey the government as God's will. This use of scripture helped hold the Third Reich together by misapplying biblical authority.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob shows how these passages were misused to support tyranny and violate the true intent of scripture.

illustrations.title: Satan's Temptation of Jesus
illustrations.text: The devil quoted the Bible to Jesus, trying to get him to disobey God's word by throwing himself down from the pinnacle of the temple. Satan referenced Psalm 91, saying God would give his angels charge to protect Jesus so he wouldn't dash his foot against a stone. However, Jesus knew the full context of the Psalm, including the part about trampling the serpent, and resisted the temptation because he was the author of scripture.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to demonstrate that even the devil misuses scripture, emphasizing the need to understand it in context.

illustrations.title: End Times Visa Implant
illustrations.text: I saw a commercial on TV last night for Christmas decorations, and that's why I knew Halloween was right around the corner. Then, I heard about the first guy in Europe who got a Visa card implanted in his wrist, and somebody sent me that information this last week. When I read about things like this that are happening, it reminds me of events in the Great Tribulation, making me realize the Rapture could be anytime now.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this real-world example to illustrate how current events signal the nearness of the Rapture and end times.

illustrations.title: L. Ron Hubbard's Scientology
illustrations.text: L. Ron Hubbard, the one who wrote Dianetics, was a science fiction writer who made this statement: writing for a penny a word is ridiculous. If a man wanted to make a million dollars, the best way would be to start his own religion. He did it, and when he died, he was worth over 100 million dollars with Scientology. This contrasts with the Bible's origin, showing that scripture does not have a human origin like Hubbard's creation.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that the Bible's origin is divine, not human-driven like Hubbard's religion.

illustrations.title: Wind Filling a Ship's Sail
illustrations.text: The Greek word for the Holy Spirit moving men is the same one used by Luke in the book of Acts to describe wind filling the sail of a ship and moving it across the waters. That's exactly what happened with inspiration: God's spirit filled men's minds with his thoughts. God used their personalities to write his perfect word, just as wind propels a ship forward.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that the Holy Spirit guided the Bible's writers, much like wind guides a ship.

illustrations.title: Incarnation as Inspiration Analogy
illustrations.text: Think of the Incarnation, where the Holy Spirit incarnated Jesus Christ inside a sinful, flawed human being. You have the perfect work of God coming through an imperfect person. That's a good picture of what happens with inspiration: God used sinful, imperfect men to create his perfect, inspired word.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show how God can produce perfect scripture through imperfect humans, similar to the Incarnation.

illustrations.title: Shakespeare and the Pen
illustrations.text: Shakespeare wrote some wonderful things, but nobody praises the pen; they might give him credit. So it is with the Bible: the attention doesn't go on the men who wrote it, but on the God who inspired them. In Psalm 45, the psalmist says, 'My tongue is the pen of a ready writer,' meaning he was ready for God to use his words.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates that credit for the Bible belongs to God, not the human writers, by comparing it to crediting Shakespeare over his tools.

illustrations.title: Parade View of Time
illustrations.text: If you go to the Rose Parade and sit on a corner, you watch the parade go by one event at a time—a band, then another marching band, then floats and horses, one after the other. But if you were up in the Goodyear blimp, you could see the entire parade from start to finish all at once. God dwells in eternity, outside of time, so He sees everything simultaneously, just like viewing the whole parade at a glance. This illustrates how God can predict the future because He observes all of time as one complete picture.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to explain how God can predict the future by dwelling outside of time, seeing all events at once.

illustrations.title: Daniel's Messiah Prophecy
illustrations.text: In the Book of Daniel, chapter 9, there's a prophecy about the Messiah coming and being cut off, as well as Jerusalem being destroyed, given hundreds of years before these events happened. It even predicts the exact day the Messiah would come, 483 years after the command to restore and rebuild Jerusalem, which was given by King Artaxerxes and recorded in the Book of Nehemiah. Jesus rode into Jerusalem on that very day, fulfilling the prophecy with incredible accuracy. This historical event shows how God's word is reliable and inspired.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this historical reference to demonstrate the accuracy of biblical predictive prophecy as evidence of God's inspiration.

illustrations.title: Prophecy as History's Mold
illustrations.text: It's been said that prophecy is the mold into which God has poured history. I like that. This quote illustrates how prophecy shapes and predicts real events, as seen in the context of biblical fulfillments.
illustrations.context: To emphasize that prophecy acts as a predetermined framework for historical events, particularly those related to the Messiah.

illustrations.title: Diocletian's Failed Persecution
illustrations.text: One of those emperors was a man named Diocletian, who made it against the law and even a capital offense to have a Bible. Christians were hunted, hiding in caves and forests, and killed in horrible ways. After persecuting the church and destroying so many Bibles, Diocletian was sure Christianity was wiped out and had a medal coined with the motto 'The Christian religion is destroyed and the worship of the Gods is restored.' However, within 25 years, Diocletian's wife and daughter accepted Christ, and soon after, Emperor Constantine ordered 50 perfect copies of the Bible to be made at government expense. This shows how attempts to eradicate the Bible ultimately failed.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate the indestructibility of the Bible despite severe persecution.

illustrations.title: Voltaire's Failed Prophecy
illustrations.text: The French philosopher Voltaire was a skeptic who hated Christianity and said that to destroy the Christian religion, we must first destroy man's belief in the Bible. He boasted that within a hundred years of his death, the Bible would disappear from the face of the Earth and claimed it took 12 ignorant fishermen to establish Christianity, but one Frenchman could destroy it. Voltaire died in 1728, but within 50 years, his own home was purchased by the president of the Geneva Bible Society and used to store Bibles for distribution. This ironic turn of events highlights the Bible's enduring presence.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to demonstrate that even intellectual attacks on the Bible fail, proving its eternal nature.

illustrations.title: Bible as Unbreakable Anvil
illustrations.text: The Bible has been called the anvil that has worn out many hammers, meaning it endures all attempts to destroy it. Throughout history, there have been many efforts to eradicate the Bible, but it remains standing strong. This metaphor illustrates how, like an anvil that outlasts the hammers striking it, God's word persists despite opposition.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to emphasize the historical indestructibility and eternal nature of the Bible.

illustrations.title: Augustines Conversion Experience
illustrations.text: This young man was 32 years old, his mom was a Christian and his dad was not, and he wasn't following the Lord at all. He had been living with his girlfriend for 13 years and had a child out of wedlock with her, but his mom never stopped praying for him. One day, he was sitting in a friend's garden, extremely depressed about his life, and he heard a little girl singing, 'Pick it up and read.' He followed the voice, opened a Bible on a nearby table, and his eyes fell on Romans 13:13-14, which pierced his heart with words about behaving properly and putting on the Lord Jesus Christ. Instantly, a clear light flooded his heart, and all darkness of doubt vanished away. This event led to his conversion in 386 AD, and he became one of the greatest theologians in church history.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the transformational capacity of the Bible to change lives through divine intervention.

illustrations.title: Gandhis Quote on Scripture
illustrations.text: It was Gandhi, who was not a Christian, who said that Christians have a book with dynamite in it, but they treat it like ordinary literature. Pastor Bob explains that this quote highlights how the Bible's power is often overlooked. He connects it to the tragedy that many treat God's word as just regular reading material, missing its explosive potential to change lives.
illustrations.context: This quote emphasizes that the Bible has immense power, yet Christians often fail to recognize and utilize it fully.

illustrations.title: Personal Bible Conversion
illustrations.text: I didn't even go to church, but someone gave me a Bible and I started reading it. I couldn't put it down, and God changed my life that day when I met Christ through the scriptures. This experience showed me the Bible's power firsthand.
illustrations.context: To illustrate how reading the Bible can personally transform a life.

illustrations.title: Shimabuku Village Story
illustrations.text: In early 1945, Clarence Hall, a correspondent in Okinawa, discovered Shimabuku, a remote village of a thousand people that stood out for its smiles, neat homes, fertile fields, and overall happiness amid the war's destruction. Thirty years earlier, an American missionary had left a Bible with two converts, who shared their faith and led the whole town to follow Christ and live by its teachings. They adopted the Ten Commandments as their law and the Sermon on the Mount as their social guide, resulting in no jails, no crime, no divorce, and a high degree of health and happiness. When Hall returned during a battle lull, the village remained a serene oasis, prompting his driver to remark that perhaps the world needed the Bible's weapons more than military ones. This true account highlights the lasting impact of God's Word on a community.
illustrations.context: To demonstrate the power of the Bible to transform an entire village and culture over time.

illustrations.title: Saul's Transformation Example
illustrations.text: Just think, if God can change Saul of Tarsus, who was the first terrorist in the church, into a Christian, then He can handle your son, your daughter, or any elected official. Jesus died for all of them. Let's not forget that God has the power to change any heart, no matter how dark.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that God can transform even the most hardened hearts, encouraging trust in God's power over human efforts.

illustrations.title: Spurgeon's Bible Quote
illustrations.text: It's Charles Hadden Spurgeon who said, 'Whenever I see a Bible that's falling apart, it usually belongs to someone who isn't.' I believe that's really true because the Word of God has a divine origin and the ability to transform anyone's life. This shows that engaging with the Bible deeply changes us.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize the Bible's transformative power and its role in personal change.

illustrations.title: Jesus as Biblical Symbols
illustrations.text: He's the king of kings and the Lord of lords, but don't stop there. He's also the sacrifice, Noah's rainbow, Abraham's ram, Isaac's well, Jacob's ladder, Moses's rod, David's sling, the fairest of ten thousand, the bright and Morning Star, the sweetest Rose of Sharon, the Honey in the Rock, the desire of the nations, my wonderful counselor, my Everlasting Father, my mighty God, and my prince of peace. The government of my life and your life rests upon his shoulders right now. He's Yeshua Hamashiach, the Son of the Living God.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that Jesus is central to the entire Bible, appearing in various symbols and roles.

illustrations.title: Marie the Blind Basket Weaver
illustrations.text: Her name was Marie; she was a blind basket weaver from a very poor family. She became a Christian and was taught Braille. She was given a Bible, which likely transformed her life through faith.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is using this story to emphasize the importance of trembling at God's word rather than just referencing it.

illustrations.title: Marie's Braille Dedication
illustrations.text: There was a woman who used a Braille Bible and loved reading the Word of God because she loved her Savior. Due to her profession and extensive reading, her fingers became calloused and damaged, so she couldn't read anymore. She even cut the skin off her fingertips hoping they would grow back more sensitive, but it was the nerves that were the problem. With tears in her eyes, she kissed her Bible goodbye for the last time and discovered that her lips were far more sensitive. She went on to read the entire Bible with her lips for the rest of her life.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate the extraordinary dedication required to engage with the Bible, challenging listeners to reflect on their own commitment.

illustrations.title: William's Tongue Braille Triumph
illustrations.text: There was another man named William in Scotland, a construction worker who wasn't a Christian at the time. He had an accident with dynamite that blew off both of his hands and blinded him, leaving him devastated and depressed. After someone shared the gospel with him and he got saved, he heard about Marie's story and tried to learn Braille with his lips, but the explosion had destroyed the sensitivity there too. He then discovered that his tongue was still sensitive and learned to read the entire Bible with it. For the rest of his life, he read through the whole Bible from Genesis to Revelation using his tongue.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to highlight the contrast between William's profound passion for the Bible and the audience's potential lack of engagement, urging greater dedication.

illustrations.title: Mike's Preaching Compliment
illustrations.text: The greatest compliment I've ever received came from my friend Mike, who grew up in the Lord with me and was there when this church started 37 years ago in my home. One Sunday, we ran into each other in line at Knollwoods, and he told me, 'Bob, when you preach, God smiles.' I'll never forget that; it's the highest encouragement I could receive, and it reminds me that I want God smiling at me in all areas of life.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the desire for God's approval and smile in everyday life, beyond just preaching.

illustrations.title: Ancient Sovereign's Smile
illustrations.text: The blessing in Numbers means that God smiles at you, just as when an ancient sovereign would allow you into their presence, give you favor, and smile at you. In those times, having the sovereign's smile meant you had the greatest power on Earth given to you. So, this shows what it truly signifies for God to lift up His countenance upon you.
illustrations.context: This explains the spiritual truth of God's favor as like an ancient ruler's approval, emphasizing the depth of divine blessing.

illustrations.title: Frozen Lake Caution
illustrations.text: One of my favorite stories—I don't even know who thought of it or if it actually happened—I picture it in the frontier days. This guy is traveling to the West Coast in winter, a big mistake, through the Rockies with his horse, all by himself. He comes to a frozen lake and is nervous about crossing, so he's tiptoeing with his horse behind him, using a stick to test the ice, terrified he'll fall through and die. As he's inching along on his knees, tapping the ice, he hears thunder and sees a stagecoach with six horses and men on it race right over the lake past him and to the other side. Yet, he continues tapping cautiously. That's too many of us who hesitate to fully trust God's word.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate how people often hesitate to fully trust God's word, like the cautious traveler, instead of boldly relying on it like the stagecoach.

illustrations.title: Old Testament Mountain Shaking
illustrations.text: Lord, you don't need to shake the mountain like you did in the Old Testament for us to react in physical fear. Instead, give us a passion and love for you in our hearts. Every time we read your Bible or hear it quoted, we would recognize these as the very words of God, making our souls and wills captive to it.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this historical reference to emphasize that true reverence for God's word comes from the heart, not from physical demonstrations of fear.

illustrations.title: Jesus in Nazareth Rejection
illustrations.text: Do you remember when Jesus came to Nazareth, the town he grew up in? You would think they would be excited to have their hometown hero, the Messiah, back in town. Unfortunately, they were so familiar with him that they didn't have faith to ask him to do much of anything. The Bible says he could not do any great work there because of their unbelief. They said, 'Is this not Jesus? We know him; he's the carpenter's son. We know his family.'
illustrations.context: This illustrates how familiarity with something sacred, like the Bible, can hinder faith and its effectiveness.

illustrations.title: Inscribing Bibles with Quote
illustrations.text: I write in every Bible when people ask me to autograph it: 'This book will keep you from sin or sin will keep you from this book.' I didn't write the Bible, and these aren't my words; they're somebody else's, but they're true and emphasize the importance of God's Word. This quote connects to how a young person can keep their way pure by guarding it according to the Word of God.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to show that engaging with the Bible helps avoid sin, while sin hinders engagement with it.

illustrations.title: Family Drive-Through Joy
illustrations.text: We were driving home from church on Wednesday night, and my kids didn't want the free food we had there. They held out and then asked if we could get McDonald's because they really wanted the toy that comes with it. So, we went through the drive-through, and there was so much joy in that moment as a dad. I sat there thinking, Lord, my life feels good and I'm grateful for this.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that enjoying life's moments doesn't conflict with anticipating Jesus's return, as it adds joy and perspective.

illustrations.title: Paul and Silas in Prison
illustrations.text: Just as Paul and Silas began singing and reciting the word at midnight when it was darkest, the Lord showed up and the prison was shaking at its foundations. The chains of all the prisoners fell off, which is pretty incredible. This shows how God can break through in the midst of hardship.
illustrations.context: This retelling encourages those watching online, perhaps in difficult circumstances, that worshiping God can lead to deliverance even in dark times.

illustrations.title: Jesus on Serving Others
illustrations.text: Jesus said the greatest of all should be the servant of all. If our Master did this, we should definitely do it as well. This ties into encouraging everyone to serve at events like Bless Fest, where we live out the principle of giving.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is using this quote to encourage Christians to lead by example through serving at Bless Fest.

illustrations.title: Moses and Joshua's Biblical Emphasis
illustrations.text: Think of Moses when it was time for him to leave; it was a transition, and the children of Israel weren't sure they were ready, but it was time. In Deuteronomy, Moses was going to die, and Joshua would take them into the promised land. He recites the law in the Book of Deuteronomy after those years of wandering in the wilderness, and then in Deuteronomy 8, he tells them not to forget God's word. We talked about this last week—you have to remember the word of God. Joshua, in Joshua 23:6, at the end of his ministry, says to the nation of Israel: be very firm to keep and do all that is written in the book of the law of Moses, so that you may not turn aside from it. Interestingly, this instruction was also given to Joshua at the beginning of his ministry in Joshua 1, as he was about to take on Jericho and cross the Jordan; the angel of the Lord told him not to turn from God's word.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating the priority of accurate interpretation of scriptures by showing how biblical leaders like Moses and Joshua emphasized the importance of God's word.

illustrations.title: Paul's Farewell to Ephesus
illustrations.text: Think about Paul the Apostle. He planted the church in Ephesus and stayed there for three years, giving his heart and soul to those people. Then he had a last meeting with the leaders and elders, where he told them they would never see his face again on earth, and they all wept. He commended them to God and to the word of his grace, which builds up and gives an inheritance among the sanctified.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate the importance and sufficiency of God's word in building faith and guiding believers.

illustrations.title: Isaiah's Warning on Truth
illustrations.text: Isaiah in his day said truth has stumbled in the streets, and he questioned why people turned to spiritists and fortune tellers instead of consulting God. He urged them to turn to the law and the testimony, meaning the Bible, and said that if people don't speak according to this word, it's because they have no light in them. This highlights the Bible as the standard for truth and discernment.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize that the Bible is the ultimate authority for detecting lies and false teachings.

illustrations.title: Awana Program for Kids
illustrations.text: Remember Awana, why we send our kids to Awana—we used to have that program to help them become approved workmen who don't need to be ashamed, rightly dividing the word of truth. It's about teaching kids to interpret and understand God's word correctly. This program serves as an example of practical ways to equip people in handling Scripture.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show the importance of rightly interpreting the Bible to avoid shame and ensure accurate teaching.

illustrations.title: Dave's Bible Misinterpretation
illustrations.text: I had a friend named Dave years ago who came to me and said, 'I know Jesus wasn't getting drunk, but I think he'd get buzzed with me.' I said, 'Excuse me?' He replied, 'Yep, it's in the Bible,' and showed me Ephesians 5:18 in his King James Bible, which says, 'Be not drunk with wine, wherein is excess.' He interpreted it as, 'See, Jesus says don't get excessively drunk, but it's okay to get a little drunk.' I explained, 'David, it doesn't say be not drunk to excess; it means that intoxication in any form is excess, so it's not saying don't get too drunk—just don't get drunk at all.' He was kind of hoping for that interpretation, as sometimes people innocently misread Scripture.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate how people can innocently misinterpret Scripture, leading to incorrect understandings of God's word.

illustrations.title: Slave Bible Distortion
illustrations.text: In the 1800s, there was a published Bible called the Slave Bible. It was edited to include only parts that slave owners wanted their slaves to read, like passages about slaves obeying masters, while omitting stories of liberation such as the Exodus. This was an attempt to use the Bible to justify slavery, which contradicts the Bible's true message of freedom and equality.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show how people can distort the Bible to support their own contradictory purposes.

illustrations.title: Hitler's Scripture Manipulation
illustrations.text: Adolf Hitler required German churches to preach from specific Bible passages, such as Romans 13:1-7 and 1 Peter 2, which emphasize obeying the government as ordained by God. He used these verses to demand blind obedience to his regime, even if it meant disobeying God. This misuse twisted the scriptures to justify evil actions.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates how authorities can misinterpret the Bible to enforce harmful agendas.

illustrations.title: Satan's Temptation of Jesus
illustrations.text: The devil quoted the Bible to Jesus, saying, 'If you are the Son of God, throw yourself down from the temple, for it is written that He will give His angels charge concerning you.' Satan used Psalm 91 to tempt Jesus into proving Himself, but omitted the parts about overcoming evil. Jesus refused, knowing the full context of the scripture.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob demonstrates that even the devil misuses scripture to lead people away from God's truth.

illustrations.title: Young Christian and Cult Magazine
illustrations.text: I remember as a young Christian, I was excited about the fact that God was real and the Bible was truth, so anything that mentioned Jesus or quoted Scripture seemed from the Lord. I started watching TV programs about Jesus and subscribed to a magazine called Plain Truth, thinking it was all good. Then a youth pastor visited my house, noticed the magazine, and told me it was from a cult, even though it talked about Jesus and the Bible. This experience taught me that we need to be discerning and not accept everything just because it quotes Scripture.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the importance of being discerning with teachings that quote the Bible to avoid being misled.

illustrations.title: Children and Lack of Discernment
illustrations.text: Just as little children will put things in their mouth that they ought not to, young believers can accept things without proper discernment. For example, if something quotes the Bible or talks about God, we might think it's true without questioning it. This analogy shows how we need to grow in wisdom to avoid spiritual dangers.
illustrations.context: This analogy highlights that new Christians, like children, may lack discernment and accept potentially harmful things.

illustrations.title: Adequate as Fully Furnished Army
illustrations.text: The word 'adequate' in the original language means fully furnished, not just barely sufficient. It was used to describe an army going out to battle, equipped with everything needed, or a ship ready to sail with all supplies on board. In this context, God's word is complete and provides all that's necessary for teaching, reproof, correction, and training in righteousness. This ensures that the man of God is fully equipped for every good work.
illustrations.context: This analogy emphasizes that Scripture fully equips believers for life and service, much like a prepared army or ship.

illustrations.title: L Ron Hubbard's Scientology
illustrations.text: Maybe you know the name L Ron Hubbard, a science fiction writer from the early 20th century. He once said that if a man wanted to make a million dollars, the best way was to start his own religion, which he did with Scientology. He wrote Dianetics and became worth a hundred million dollars by the time he died. This example highlights how human efforts to create religions differ from the Bible's divine origin.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that man's writings and religions, like Scientology, are motivated by self-interest and fall short of the Bible's true value.

illustrations.title: Gandhi's Bible Critique
illustrations.text: Even some unbelievers, like Gandhi, said that Christians have a book with dynamite in it, but they treat it like ordinary literature. Sometimes unbelievers reprove Christians for the way they handle the Bible, even though we claim it's the word of God. This quote underscores the need for Christians to honor the Bible's power in their lives.
illustrations.context: This quote points out that even non-believers recognize the Bible's explosive potential, challenging Christians to treat it with greater reverence.

illustrations.title: Wind Filling Sails Analogy
illustrations.text: The word 'moved' describes how the Holy Spirit moved men, like the wind that fills the sail of a ship and propels it across the waters. God's Spirit filled men's minds like sails with His thoughts, then used their personalities to write perfectly what He intended. This analogy shows how divine inspiration works through human vessels.
illustrations.context: This analogy explains that the Holy Spirit actively guided the Bible's writers, ensuring God's message was conveyed flawlessly.

illustrations.title: Incarnation of Jesus Analogy
illustrations.text: Think of the Incarnation of Jesus Christ: the Holy Spirit created the baby Jesus in Mary's womb, making Him the perfect, sinless Son of God through a sinful, flawed person. Similarly, God's Word is the product of the Holy Spirit, inspired and God-breathed, yet it comes through sinful, flawed human beings. This comparison illustrates how God uses imperfect people to deliver His perfect truth.
illustrations.context: This analogy demonstrates that the Bible, like Jesus, is divinely perfect despite being channeled through human imperfection.

illustrations.title: Parade View Analogy
illustrations.text: If you go down to a local parade or the Rose Parade in Pasadena and stand at the corner, you will see floats and marching bands go by one at a time. But if you're up in the Goodyear blimp, you can see the entire parade happening simultaneously. This gives a totally different view. God stands outside of time, seeing the end from the beginning just like that.
illustrations.context: To show how God perceives time differently from humans, allowing Him to predict future events.

illustrations.title: Prophecy as History's Mold
illustrations.text: It's been said that predictive prophecy is the mold into which God has poured history. I think that's a great statement. What God said will happen, then history proves it to be true.
illustrations.context: To illustrate that biblical prophecies are reliably fulfilled, proving God's sovereignty over history.

illustrations.title: Bible as Indestructible Anvil
illustrations.text: The Bible has been called The Anvil that has worn out many a hammer. This means that while attempts to destroy it have come and gone, the Bible remains strong and enduring. God promises that His word will stand forever, as Heaven and Earth may pass away but His word never will.
illustrations.context: To illustrate the historical durability and indestructibility of the Bible.

illustrations.title: Persecutions Under Diocletian
illustrations.text: For about the first 300 years of the church, there were waves of persecution killing Christians and trying to eradicate the Bible. Under Diocletian, authorities arrested Christians, executed those with Bibles, and burned most copies, believing Christianity was wiped out. He even created a medal claiming the Christian religion was destroyed and the worship of the gods restored, but 25 years later, his wife and daughter accepted Christ, and under Constantine, Bibles were being produced again.
illustrations.context: To demonstrate that despite intense efforts to destroy it, the Bible has endured, proving its indestructibility.

illustrations.title: Voltaire's Bible Irony
illustrations.text: Voltaire was an 18th-century philosopher who absolutely hated Christianity and the Bible. He boasted that within a hundred years of his death, the Bible would disappear from the Earth and claimed it took 12 ignorant fishermen to establish Christianity, but one Frenchman could destroy it. However, he died in 1728, and within 50 years, his home was purchased by the president of the Geneva Bible Society, who used it to store and distribute Bibles.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the Bible's enduring power despite human efforts to destroy it.

illustrations.title: Young Man's Scriptural Turnaround
illustrations.text: I meet people all the time, like this young man who was 32 years old with a believing mom but a non-believing dad. He had been living with his girlfriend for 13 years, fathered a child out of wedlock, and was extremely depressed, hating his life. One day, while sitting under a tree and near tears, he heard a voice like a little girl chanting 'pick it up and read,' which prompted him to read the Bible, leading to his transformation.
illustrations.context: This demonstrates the Bible's unique power to change lives on a personal level.

illustrations.title: Augustine's Heart Pierced
illustrations.text: Augustine was in his garden when he heard a voice from a neighbor's house, prompting him to pick up a Bible. He let it fall open to Romans 13:13-14, which described his own life of sin and urged him to put on the Lord Jesus Christ. Every word pierced his heart, and instantly, a clear light flooded his heart, banishing all doubt. This event in 386 AD transformed him into one of the greatest figures in the early church.
illustrations.context: Illustrates how God's word personally and powerfully changes lives from the inside.

illustrations.title: Robber's Redemption Through Books
illustrations.text: One dark night in a forest in Sicily, Italy, a robber held up a book peddler at gunpoint and ordered him to burn his books. The peddler asked to read from each book before burning it, reciting the 23rd Psalm, the story of the Good Samaritan, the Sermon on the Mount, and 1 Corinthians 13. Touched by the words, the robber spared the books and took them, eventually becoming a pastor due to their influence. This shows the power of God's word to change even a thief's life.
illustrations.context: Demonstrates the transformative power of Scripture to alter a person's path.

illustrations.title: Okinawa Village's Inspiration
illustrations.text: During World War II in Okinawa, war correspondent Clarence Hall discovered a remarkable village called Shimabuku that stood out amid the despair. Unlike other war-torn villages, this one was neat, fertile, and full of smiles, thanks to an American missionary who had visited 30 years earlier. The missionary stayed just long enough to make a lasting impact, turning the community into a shining example. This true story highlights how a brief encounter with faith can transform an entire area.
illustrations.context: Emphasizes how God's word and missionary influence can bring hope and change to communities.

illustrations.title: Shimabuku Town Transformation
illustrations.text: These new converts, with all the instructions to read the Bible and live by it, began sharing their faith with their neighbors. Before long, the whole town had accepted Christ and for 30 years had been following the Bible completely. They adopted the Ten Commandments as their legal code and The Sermon on the Mount as their guide in social conduct, teaching the Bible in their schools where students memorized scripture. Their courts made decisions based on God's word, resulting in no jails, no bars, no brothels, no drunkenness, no divorce, and a high degree of health and happiness. The narrator returned to the town during a lull in battle and found an oasis of serenity amidst the surrounding chaos of war trucks and troops. A Jeep driver remarked that maybe we're using the wrong weapons to make this world over.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the transformative power of God's word in creating a peaceful and moral community.

illustrations.title: Worn Bible Quote
illustrations.text: Spurgeon and Moody said, 'I have found that a Bible that's falling apart usually belongs to someone who is not.' Pastor Bob notes that they lived at the same time and explains that this means a well-used Bible often indicates a person whose life is not falling apart. He connects it to the idea that engaging with God's word brings strength and transformation.
illustrations.context: This quote emphasizes that a deeply used Bible reflects a strong, transformed faith in one's life.

illustrations.title: Prophet Warns Unfaithful King
illustrations.text: Do you remember that prophet that came to that king who at one time had been faithful to God but no longer? He said these words: the eyes of the Lord move to and fro throughout the whole earth, looking for someone to show himself strong on behalf of whose heart is fully his. This passage challenges us to have a heart fully devoted to God.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to emphasize that God is searching for people with fully devoted hearts.

illustrations.title: Familiarity in Nazareth
illustrations.text: Oh, be careful, it's very easy to become familiar with God's word just like they were familiar with Jesus in Nazareth. There, he could do no great work because of their lack of faith. We know him; he was raised here; we've known him his whole life, and that familiarity led to little faith.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates the danger of becoming too familiar with God's word, which can diminish faith and prevent God's work.

illustrations.title: Marie's Braille Bible Devotion
illustrations.text: Her name was Marie; she lived in the early 20th century, was poor, Christian, and blind, weaving baskets for a living. Someone gave her a Braille Bible, and she learned to read it with her fingers, deeply loving God's word. When her fingertips lost sensitivity from constant use, she desperately cut the skin off them hoping for new sensitivity, but it didn't work. She wept, kissed the Bible goodbye thinking it was the last time, and then discovered her lips were sensitive enough to read it. She read the entire Bible through with her lips, showing extraordinary dedication.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the importance of treasuring and revering God's word despite obstacles.

illustrations.title: William's Tongue-Reading Commitment
illustrations.text: It inspired a man named William, who was in construction from Scotland, not a Christian at first, but a rough, worldly guy. He had an accident handling dynamite that blew off his hands and blinded him, and during his dark recovery, someone shared the gospel, leading him to salvation. As a disabled blind man unable to work, he heard about Marie and wanted to read the Bible himself. Despite his lips being damaged from the explosion, he discovered he could learn Braille with his tongue. He read the entire Bible from Genesis to Revelation four times before he died, demonstrating profound reverence for God's word.
illustrations.context: This shows how true commitment to God's word can transform a life and inspire deep faith.

illustrations.title: Mom's Bible Expression
illustrations.text: My mom used to use a little expression for this when she heard stories like that. She'd hold up one finger on each hand and say, 'Jesus said, whoever is ashamed of my words, of him will the Son of Man be ashamed when he returns.' This gesture emphasized the importance of not trifling with the Bible. It's a simple way she illustrated the power of God's word.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to emphasize the consequences of being ashamed of the Bible and the need to trust it fully.

illustrations.title: Gold Rush Frozen Lake
illustrations.text: Back in the frontier days during the gold rush, stories tell of a man who was traveling alone across the Rockies in winter with his horse. He reached a large frozen lake that was too far to go around, so he decided to cross it despite the risks. He led his horse slowly, tapping the ice with a stick because he heard cracking sounds and feared it might break. As he proceeded cautiously, the story highlights the tension of uncertainty in his journey.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate the idea of testing or trusting the Bible, much like the man's careful approach to the ice represents caution in faith.

illustrations.title: Man on Ice Analogy
illustrations.text: A man is on the ice with nobody to rescue him, so he gets down on his knees and starts tapping the ice, slowly inching across it. Suddenly, he hears a thunderous roar and looks back to see a stagecoach with six horses and riders coming over the bluff, speeding right by him on the frozen lake and crossing the entire lake to the other side. Then, he continues tapping the ice cautiously. This is a picture of too many of us as believers.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to show that generations of believers often hesitate to fully trust and engage with God's word, much like the man doubts the ice despite evidence it can hold weight.

illustrations.title: Road to Emmaus Encounter
illustrations.text: Remember those two on the road to Emmaus; they were close to Jesus and loved him, but they were devastated that he was dead and didn't realize they were in the middle of God's will. When they shared their depression with Jesus without knowing it was him, he called them foolish and slow of heart to believe all that the prophets had spoken. Sometimes we don't fully believe God's word; we only believe the parts we understand and not the parts we don't yet grasp. Jesus opened up the Scriptures to their minds, showing them all the things concerning himself through the Old Testament, revealing that it's all about him. Later, after Jesus disappeared from them, they said, 'Did not our hearts burn within us when he spoke to us along the way?'
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate that people often fail to believe all of God's word, only trusting what they understand, and that God wants to reveal more through Scripture to address their struggles.

illustrations.title: Autographing Bibles Story
illustrations.text: Sometimes people come to me and say, Pastor, will you autograph my Bible? It's like I'm not the author, so I say, would you just write something because you led me to the Lord or I was here? Sure, so here's what I always write: This book will keep you from sin or sin will keep you from this book. These aren't my words; I steal them, but I use them to emphasize the importance of the Bible.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal experience to show how to actively share and value the Bible by inscribing a meaningful quote in it.

illustrations.title: Elder as Good Shepherd
illustrations.text: An elder is a shepherd, and I entitled my message 'Good Shepherd.' I would much rather talk to you about good shepherds or the Good Shepherd than about bad wolves, but we need to know about both, and that's why this text is here. It says of the Good Shepherd in Psalm 23, 'Your rod and your staff, they comfort me,' meaning you have the ability to deal with threats to me as a sheep. You prepare a table before me, which meant an area like a plateau or a mesa, a tableland where a sheep can eat in the mountains, and a shepherd protects that space.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to show that elders, like shepherds, must protect the church from threats such as false teachers.

illustrations.title: Reluctance as a Grandparent
illustrations.text: I'll be the first to admit there is nothing fun about confronting someone about something they're doing wrong. I don't like to do it at all, especially as a grandparent. As a parent, I didn't mind it as much, but as a grandparent, I don't like to be the one to spank my grandson; that's somebody else's job. My job is to spoil them, and I want to be good at that. But it is part of our responsibility as parents and in families.
illustrations.context: Illustrates the personal discomfort in confronting wrongdoing, emphasizing that such responsibilities are necessary in church leadership.

illustrations.title: Surgeon Avoiding Difficult Tasks
illustrations.text: Can you imagine if a surgeon said, 'I only do fun surgeries'? I don't want to be involved with pain or blood or uncomfortable recovery. They have a name for that kind of doctor; it's called a quack. So, while this isn't my favorite topic, it's in the Word of God, and we need to understand God's commands.
illustrations.context: Compares avoiding confrontation in the church to a surgeon shirking tough procedures, highlighting the importance of fulfilling duties despite discomfort.

illustrations.title: Protecting Children from Threats
illustrations.text: You know if you're a parent, you are concerned about any threat to any of your children. Anyone that's a threat to my child becomes my enemy. So you need to think that way scripturally when it comes to false teaching. We're called the household or family of the Lord, and we must protect it.
illustrations.context: Emphasizes that church members should protect against false teaching as fiercely as parents protect their children from harm.

illustrations.title: Henley's Poem of Defiance
illustrations.text: Charles Henley was a young man who had his leg amputated at 16 years of age due to tuberculosis, and a few years later, he was about to lose his other leg according to his physician. He refused to accept that fate and sought out a surgeon in Edinburgh who performed operations to save his leg. While recovering, he wrote the famous poem Invictus, with its final lines declaring, 'It matters not how strait the gate or how charged with punishments the scroll, I am the master of my fate, I am the captain of my soul.' Pastor Bob explains that these lines defy biblical truths, like the narrow gate in Matthew and the judgment scrolls in Revelation, illustrating a rebellious attitude of self-reliance. This story shows how rebellion can be disguised as virtue.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses Henley's story to show how rebellion is reframed as self-confidence, contrasting it with biblical submission to God.

illustrations.title: C.S. Lewis's Regress Analogy
illustrations.text: In C.S. Lewis's book The Pilgrim's Regress, characters John and Virtue are trying to navigate down a mountain when another character, Mother Kirk, offers to carry them but insists they follow her orders exactly. Virtue responds by saying, 'I cannot put myself under anyone's orders; I must be the captain of my soul and the master of my fate.' This exchange serves as Lewis's analogy to highlight the dangers of self-reliance and rebellion against divine authority. Pastor Bob connects this to the broader theme of rejecting God's control in favor of personal defiance.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to emphasize that rebellion manifests as a refusal to submit to God's guidance, mirroring the poem's message.

illustrations.title: McVeigh's Rebel Last Words
illustrations.text: Those words from Invictus were the ones that Timothy McVeigh chose as his last words before execution. He said, 'I am the master of my fate; I am the captain of my soul,' reflecting his self-sufficiency and rebellion. This illustrates how such an attitude led him, the Oklahoma City bomber, to his end, serving as a warning about the dangers of living without authority.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that rebellion, like McVeigh's, is a vice that masquerades as virtue and leads to disastrous mistakes.

illustrations.title: Rebellious Child in Class
illustrations.text: Like that kid who was told repeatedly in class to sit down, he finally sits but says to his teacher, 'I'm sitting down on the outside, but I'm standing up on the inside.' This shows outward compliance with inward defiance. It's a common struggle we all face, reflecting the rebellious attitude that says, 'I'll do it my way.'
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate how rebellion against authority persists internally, even when externally subdued.

illustrations.title: Shakespeare's Empty Words
illustrations.text: Shakespeare said that some people are full of sound and fury, signifying nothing. This quote describes those who talk a lot but say nothing of value, like the false teachers Paul mentions. Pastor Bob connects it to show how these deceivers use impressive words without real substance, leading others astray.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that false teachers are full of empty talk, much like Shakespeare's description, highlighting their lack of purpose.

illustrations.title: Jesus' Blind Guides Warning
illustrations.text: Jesus spoke of the false leadership of the Pharisees, calling them blind guides. He warned that if the blind lead the blind, both will fall into a ditch. This retelling highlights how such leaders deceive with reasonable-sounding words but ultimately mislead people.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that false teachers, like the Pharisees, are deceivers who lead others into spiritual danger.

illustrations.title: Head Covering Discussion
illustrations.text: I remember a gal who was attending our church and went to visit another church. She came back and told me that the church she visited had women wearing head coverings, and she had one on herself. She said it was such a blessing and asked if she could wear it at our church. I said she was more than welcome, but I warned her that soon she'd start questioning why other women weren't wearing it and why we didn't require it based on 1 Corinthians 11, which might lead her to leave.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate how legalism can start with personal practices and escalate to demanding uniformity, potentially causing division in the church.

illustrations.title: Lilith as Adam's First Wife
illustrations.text: For instance, there's the teaching about Lilith, who was supposedly Adam's first wife. What happened to Eve? Well, Lilith and heaven didn't get along; they had problems, and she became a demon. That's found in the Talmud, a collection of Jewish rabbinical writings.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate how Jewish myths are fabricated stories treated as true biblical history, leading people away from actual scripture.

illustrations.title: King Og and the Ark
illustrations.text: Or the teaching about King Og of Bashan, who was a giant that wrote on the roof of the Ark. That's how some explained the presence of giants after the flood. These stories were believed as true despite being mythical.
illustrations.context: This example shows how man-made myths distort biblical narratives and are not based on real events.

illustrations.title: Solomon's Son and Vampire
illustrations.text: Another myth claims that Solomon's son was bitten by a vampire. This was taught as if it were biblical history full of spiritual mystery. Such stories are examples of legends in Jewish writings that Paul would dismiss as untrue.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob highlights this to demonstrate how commandments of men, like these myths, mislead people from genuine spiritual truth.

illustrations.title: Pharisees' Talmud Sabbath Rules
illustrations.text: They taught that you should not look in a mirror on the Sabbath because you might be tempted to pluck out a gray hair, and that would be reaping. It was unlawful to move furniture on the Sabbath, but you were allowed to move a ladder only four steps. You couldn't wear jewelry or false teeth, as that might be seen as carrying a burden. It was even forbidden to eat radishes dipped in salt for too long, as that could pickle them and count as work. And while spitting on a rock was fine, spitting on soil made mud, which was considered mortar and thus labor.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how the Pharisees added burdensome rules to God's laws, making them impossible to keep.

illustrations.title: Jesus on Heavy Burdens
illustrations.text: Jesus said they tie up heavy burdens and lay them on men's shoulders, but they themselves are unwilling to move them with so much as a finger. This shows how religious leaders impose rules they don't follow. In the context of the sermon, it highlights the hypocrisy of adding to God's word.
illustrations.context: This quote demonstrates that adding to God's laws creates unbearable burdens that even the enforcers avoid.

illustrations.title: Airplane Degree Deviation
illustrations.text: You've heard this before, but I find it fascinating that if you are one degree off in an airplane, for every mile you fly, you're ninety-two feet off your target. That means you're a mile off for every sixty miles you fly. If you got on a plane at JFK in New York and flew to LAX, you'd end up forty miles out into the Pacific Ocean. Planes have very sensitive instruments called an HSI, a horizontal situation indicator, to help the pilot stay on course. As believers, we also have an HSI—it's the Holy Scripture and the Holy Spirit—to keep us on the right path.
illustrations.context: Even a small deviation from the truth can lead to significant errors in one's spiritual journey.

illustrations.title: Pharisees Seeking Notice
illustrations.text: Jesus said this of the Pharisees: they do all their deeds to be noticed by men. They broadened their phylacteries, those little boxes that contain scripture, as a way to show off. God told them to put the word on their hearts, but they turned it into a display for honor and influence. This illustrates how false teachers often act out of selfish motives rather than genuine care for others.
illustrations.context: False teachers are motivated by a desire for honor and influence, not by love for God's people.

illustrations.title: Orthodox Jews' Scripture Boxes
illustrations.text: The Orthodox Jews still do this today; if you go to Jerusalem, you'll see them carrying a little leather box with Scripture in it. They make a physical box to hold the scriptures on their foreheads and arms, as a way to keep God's Word in mind. But some people just make bigger boxes to show off, like they're boasting about how much scripture they have.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate how people can turn religious practices into outward shows of piety without true devotion.

illustrations.title: Epimenes' Quote on Cretans
illustrations.text: A poet named Epimenes, who lived in the 6th century BC, wrote that Cretans are always liars, evil beasts, and lazy gluttons, and he was one of the seven great minds of the Greek world. Paul quotes this to describe the false teachers, agreeing that it fits their nature. Later, Callimachus in the 3rd century BC said the same thing, and even a verb was derived from 'Cretan' meaning to lie and cheat.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this historical reference to show that the deceptive character of false teachers has been recognized for centuries and applies to the situation with the Cretans.

illustrations.title: Sandal Fitting Analogy
illustrations.text: Paul is basically saying that if the sandal fits, you got to wear it, meaning that the description of Cretans as liars and cheats applies to these false teachers. He's using this to point out that their nature matches the ancient criticisms. So, they're looking to take advantage of people with their smooth talk.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob employs this analogy to emphasize that false teachers should be recognized and confronted if the negative traits fit them.

illustrations.title: Drug Dealers and Sabbath
illustrations.text: Listen to this news article: A recent NYPD raid on a notorious Brooklyn drug ring uncovered a half-million dollar stash of oxycodone, along with heroin, cocaine, and other illicit drugs. What was unusual wasn't the drugs or their value, but that the ringleaders were observant Jews who refused to deal drugs during the Sabbath. They regularly warned their clients not to arrive after sundown on Fridays or before sundown on Saturdays, even sending messages like, 'We are closing at 7:30 on the dot and will reopen Saturday at 8:15, so if you need anything, you have 45 minutes to get it.' In one April message to 250 recipients, they emphasized this rule. They might be drug dealers, but at least they remembered the Sabbath day to keep it holy.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate how people can be religiously observant in one area while engaging in serious sin, paralleling it to those who profess faith but live immorally.

illustrations.title: Contagious Spread of False Teaching
illustrations.text: I'm sure you've had the experience where a son or daughter in your household gets the flu or a cold, and suddenly it spreads through the whole family. That's exactly what false doctrine is like—it's contagious. It starts with one person and moves on from there.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that false teaching is contagious and spreads through families or churches like a disease.

illustrations.title: Young Couple Misled by Book
illustrations.text: I'll never forget a young couple that was going to our church; the man and his wife had both given their lives to the Lord and were growing as young Christians. They loved coming to all the things we were doing and studying the Word. Then, the man read a book by another pastor and got very excited about the idea that God has forgiven us as Christians of all our sins, but he drew a wrong conclusion from it.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is showing how false teaching can mislead even dedicated young Christians through deceptive ideas in books.

illustrations.title: Couple and the Song
illustrations.text: I'll never forget how it started—it was just them thinking about this and feeling it was true until in church one Sunday we were singing a song by Phil Wickham's parents, John and Lisa, who were in the band Parable during the Jesus Movement. They were our worship leaders, and we sang 'Oh Lord forgive me, look upon my need,' but this couple went silent because they believed asking for forgiveness was wrong. Everyone else kept singing, which felt like heresy to them, and it highlighted how false teaching can divide a church. Eventually, they started their own home church celebrating their forgiveness.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how false teaching can spread from a small group and lead to division within the church.

illustrations.title: Demon Casting Doctrine
illustrations.text: There are people who say that as a Christian, you need to have a demon cast out of you, like claiming the reason you're overweight is due to the demon of gluttony. They suggest casting it out would solve the problem, but Pastor Bob points out that's not biblical. The Bible teaches that greater is He who is in you, and Satan can't touch believers, with no evidence of demons being cast out of Christians. This example shows how such false doctrines mislead people.
illustrations.context: This demonstrates that unbiblical doctrines, like casting demons out of believers, can distort spiritual truths and lead to confusion.

illustrations.title: Sadducees Question Jesus on Marriage
illustrations.text: In Matthew 22, the Sadducees, who were the liberal rulers of the temple and the priesthood, challenged Jesus with a hypothetical question about marriage in the resurrection. They described a woman who married one brother, then he died, so she married another, and he died too, and this happened multiple times—she's like a black widow. They mocked the idea, saying, 'We don't believe in resurrection, but if it exists, whose wife would she be since she had all these husbands?' Jesus silenced them by explaining they were wrong for not knowing the Scriptures or God's power, and He proved resurrection from Exodus, saying God is the God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, the living, not the dead.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate how false teachers like the Sadducees are silenced by the truth of Scripture.

illustrations.title: Stitch in Time Quote
illustrations.text: You know that phrase, 'a stitch in time saves nine.' Most of our kids have never heard that, so they have no idea what it means. We were teaching our grandchildren those phrases the other day. It means to nip something in the bud, get it early, and act preemptively to stop problems before they grow.
illustrations.context: This quote illustrates the importance of rebuking false teachings early to prevent them from becoming bigger issues.

illustrations.title: Healthy Sheep Analogy
illustrations.text: Healthy sheep just instinctively don't eat poisonous weeds. It's the sickly ones, the ones that aren't eating correctly, who seem to have an appetite for it. The Bible is both a vaccine for what's dangerous and an antidote for what's spiritually poisonous.
illustrations.context: This analogy shows that spiritually healthy people naturally avoid dangerous teachings, while the Bible serves as protection against spiritual harm.

illustrations.title: Garbage Truck Analogy
illustrations.text: The word detestable in the Greek means the same thing you feel when you get behind a garbage truck and smell the wafting odor coming into your car. It basically makes you almost nauseated, and you say, 'This is gross.' That's what he's calling those who teach that. This illustrates how truly repulsive and defiling certain behaviors are.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating the meaning of 'detestable' to show how defiling and repulsive certain mindsets are to God.

illustrations.title: Minds Like Cement Quote
illustrations.text: It's been said that some people have minds like cement—thoroughly mixed up and permanently set. That's the picture of someone who is disobedient and unpersuadable, not giving up wrong beliefs no matter what you say. This quote highlights how rigid and unchangeable such attitudes can be.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to explain 'disobedient' as being unpersuadable, emphasizing the need to evaluate and identify false teachings.

illustrations.title: Uprooting Poisonous Bushes
illustrations.text: When Becky and I bought our first house, the previous owner had planted bushes in front of it. He came by on his bicycle and was shocked to see I had removed them. I explained that the bushes were poisonous, and with toddlers around, I prioritized my children's safety over keeping his plants.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that there's a time to uproot what is planted, emphasizing the need to remove harmful things for greater good.

illustrations.title: Chemotherapy as Healing Method
