illustrations.text: Sometimes the only way to heal is to kill, and that's exactly what chemotherapy does. It targets and destroys harmful cells to promote overall health. This real-world example shows the necessity of such actions in certain situations.
illustrations.context: This demonstrates that there's a time to kill in order to achieve healing, applying to both physical and spiritual contexts.

illustrations.title: Glass Houses and Stones
illustrations.text: I remember teaching our sons the saying that those who live in glass houses shouldn't throw stones. Years ago, we asked if they had heard it, and their response showed they understood the idea of not criticizing others when you're vulnerable yourself. Pastor Bob uses this to connect the warning against hypocrisy with times when action is necessary.
illustrations.context: This quote illustrates the caution against throwing stones hypocritically, contrasting it with righteous actions like David's.

illustrations.title: David Facing Goliath
illustrations.text: The day that David faced Goliath, it was time to throw a stone as it was God's will. Goliath was an enemy of the Philistines keeping Israel from freedom, so David acted in obedience. This biblical account highlights the moment of decisive action against oppression.
illustrations.context: This retelling shows that there's a time to throw stones when it's aligned with God's purpose to defeat enemies.

illustrations.title: Achan's Punishment in Israel
illustrations.text: When Achan hurt the nation of Israel by taking banned items from Jericho, it led to their defeat and the death of 26 men, causing families to grieve. God commanded to take him out and stone him to address the sin. This story underscores the consequences of disobedience and the need for justice.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that there's a time to deal harshly with sin to protect and restore the community.

illustrations.title: Cleaning Out Old Items
illustrations.text: There's a time to keep and a time to throw away. You ever cleaned out your garage or your attic or the junk drawer and found your old 8-track player or Betamax? Some of you might need to look that up, as it's an example of outdated things we hold onto. This illustrates the need to discard what's no longer useful, just like we should with false teachings.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that just as we throw away old, useless items, we must discard false teachings.

illustrations.title: Doctor's Heart Disease Warning
illustrations.text: I went to the doctor several years ago and he recommended a heart scan for a calcium score. I asked about it because the first symptom for many with heart disease is death, which is hard to treat. He shared that his receptionist, who was in her 50s, died suddenly last week and never woke up, emphasizing how inconspicuous diseases can be deadly.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to illustrate how subtle and dangerous false teachings can be, like hidden diseases that lead to sudden demise.

illustrations.title: Burst Appendix Experience
illustrations.text: There are some diseases that can be treated with medicine, but others have to be removed from the body to ensure health. My appendix burst, and they didn't just give me IV antibiotics; they had to get it out or I would die. This shows that sometimes, like with false teachers, removal is necessary for the body's survival.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob compares removing a burst appendix to removing false teachers from the church to maintain spiritual health.

illustrations.title: Reactions to Leaving
illustrations.text: Once you tell people you're leaving, you get one of two reactions from them when you see them in the halls. Either they act like you've just won the lottery and they're so happy, or they treat you like you're terminally ill, looking at you as if you're fragile. I'm not fragile; you can still hug me and stuff. So I'm still here and ready to worship the Lord.
illustrations.context: To illustrate that despite his announcement of leaving, he remains present and approachable for worship and fellowship.

illustrations.title: COVID Tent Days Remembrance
illustrations.text: You ever have a song that takes you back to a moment in time? For me, it was during COVID when we were on Wednesday nights out here in what we now call our tent days. How many of you were around back then? Casey had started leading, and we were actually gathering again. I remember the nights with the parrots screeching. That takes me back to those COVID days.
illustrations.context: To show how a song evokes personal memories of challenging times like COVID, connecting to themes of readiness and gathering.

illustrations.title: Church Shutdown Broadcast Story
illustrations.text: I remember Raymond was relatively new to our church and we were broadcasting live when the government shut everything down. It was weird to talk to the congregation and believe by faith that someone was watching, so I printed pictures from the church directory and put them on the chairs. Those days were precious, as the Lord used our Tech folks and worship team to help us continue worshiping and trusting Him.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate how difficult times can still be precious and how God kept the church community together.

illustrations.title: Joke with Best Friend
illustrations.text: I used to joke around with my best friend, the guy who helped bring me to Christ when I was 13. We were so busy in ministry in the same church that we hardly ever spent time together, so we'd walk by each other and say, 'See you in heaven.' This reminded us that we'd have eternity together, even if not on earth.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to emphasize treasuring current moments with believers and looking forward to eternal fellowship.

illustrations.title: Missionaries in Persecution
illustrations.text: Rick and Rebecca Emmanacre have been missionaries with us since our church began, serving with Mission Aviation Fellowship where Rick is a pilot and they've worked around the world. They are currently in Armenia, where Armenians, many of whom are Christians, are being persecuted and forced to flee for their lives from Azerbaijan due to conflicts with Muslim communities. This situation involves severe displacement and potential genocide, highlighting a dire need for awareness and prayer.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this real-world example to emphasize the urgency of praying for persecuted Christians and global missions.

illustrations.title: Church's Early Days
illustrations.text: Our original missionaries, Rick and Rebecca Emmanacre, were there the night our church started with just 17 people in my living room. They have remained missionaries with us ever since, serving faithfully around the world with Mission Aviation Fellowship. Now, they are in Armenia amid a crisis of persecution.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob shares this personal story to illustrate the long-standing relationship with these missionaries and lead into the call for prayer.

illustrations.title: Living for Future Generations
illustrations.text: It's been said every one of us has to decide which generation we're going to live for, this one or the next one. Most of us are still living for this one, but it's a good thing when you start realizing that you don't know when the Lord is coming back. If He's not coming back in your lifetime, you're going to Him, and you want to make sure your life counts for this generation and the next.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize the importance of living with eternal perspective, focusing on the next generation rather than just the present one, as illustrated by the Israelites' story.

illustrations.title: Moses' Final Mission
illustrations.text: Moses was given a short bucket list before he died. He was told by the Lord to take full vengeance for the sons of Israel on the Midianites, and then he would be gathered to his people, meaning he would die. This mission was not just for Moses personally but to prepare Israel for their entry into the Promised Land, which would be filled with battles like those at Jericho and Ai.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate the importance of completing God's assigned tasks before death, even if the benefits are for others.

illustrations.title: Unfinished Business Warning
illustrations.text: It's been said that when it comes time to die, make sure that's all you have to do and there's no unfinished business. This means ensuring you've been forgiven by someone, reconciled with others, or completed what God wanted you to do. Pastor Bob connects this to Moses' situation, emphasizing the need to handle such matters to avoid regrets at life's end.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to stress the importance of resolving personal and spiritual unfinished business before death.

illustrations.title: Christian Life as Battleground
illustrations.text: We've heard it said that the Christian life is not a playground but a battleground. In fact, the Christian life is a lifetime of spiritual warfare, involving battles like those Israel faced in Canaan, starting with Jericho and Ai. Pastor Bob explains this to show that entering the Promised Land means ongoing fights and settling in amidst challenges.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to convey that the Christian life involves continuous spiritual battles, preparing believers for a life of conflict and perseverance.

illustrations.title: Balaam's Scheme Against Israel
illustrations.text: So then, after that, it is Balaam who teaches King Balak how, since he cannot curse the Israelites directly because he can't pronounce a word that's not from God, he's never going to get a curse from God. So, he figures out how they can bring a curse on themselves. And he says, just tell your daughters to invite the men of Israel, be friendly to them, invite them to come out to their feasts and parties, get them drunk, and worship Baal.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating how people can inadvertently bring spiritual harm upon themselves through temptation and idolatry.

illustrations.title: Phineas Stops the Plague
illustrations.text: Remember when Phineas the priest was so incensed because one of the leaders' sons took a woman into the camp where God's presence was? He went in and killed them both, which was radical and stopped the plague at that moment. It's a phenomenal story, but God took 24,000 Israelites because of their sin of idolatry and immorality.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate the severe consequences of sin and God's judgment on the Israelites.

illustrations.title: Midianites as Worldly Threat
illustrations.text: The Midianites are a picture and a type, kind of like Egypt, which I always joked is like Costco where you can get everything. Egypt is a type and a picture of the world, and so are the Midianites; they're a representation of the world under Satan's control. This enemy uses the world to become a threat to believers, showing we have unfinished business with worldliness in our lives.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to emphasize that believers must confront and stop ignoring threats from worldliness, as represented by the Midianites.

illustrations.title: Frog in Boiling Water
illustrations.text: We've all heard the example of the science experiment with the frog in the water. They turn up the heat one degree every hour, and the frog swims around until it boils in its own skin. But if you dropped the frog into boiling water, it would jump out immediately. This illustrates how subtle, slow changes can be deadly without realization.
illustrations.context: This shows how the world's influence on believers is often gradual and unnoticed, slowly choking out spiritual growth.

illustrations.title: Bob Vernon's Warning
illustrations.text: I remember hearing Bob Vernon, who was the assistant chief of police of LAPD, a Christian man, talk to the church I was growing up in. He discussed the problem he sees in many churches, where Christians try to be better than the world but still use the world as their standard. For example, in the 70s, while the world wore skimpy clothes and listened to horrible music, Christians opted for dresses just a little longer or music that was worldly but not as bad. He explained that this is a big mistake because it means we're not truly aligning with God's standards.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how Christians often err by setting their standards based on the world rather than on God's higher expectations.

illustrations.title: Samson's Strength and Fall
illustrations.text: Samson was one of our great examples; he could fight any enemy on the battlefield and wipe them out, like defeating a thousand Philistines with the jawbone of a donkey. That's an incredible feat, like a weapon of mass destruction. But he lost his sight, freedom, and power in the lap of his girlfriend, showing he could handle enemies but not personal temptation.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how spiritual heroes can be defeated by personal compromise rather than battlefield enemies.

illustrations.title: David's Victory and Lust
illustrations.text: We all know the story of David; he killed Goliath when no other man in Israel dared to fight, then led the nation to great victories against the Philistines. He was unbeatable in battle, never losing on the battlefield. But he lost the fight against his own lust when he saw his neighbor's wife bathing.
illustrations.context: This shows that even victorious leaders can fall to personal sins like lust.

illustrations.title: Peter's Boldness and Failure
illustrations.text: Peter declared he would die with Jesus when the soldiers came into the garden, pulling out a sword to fight instead of a fishing reel. It's surprising and bold, showing his readiness for physical conflict. Yet, this highlights how even the most devoted can falter in moments of personal trial.
illustrations.context: This example demonstrates that strong faith can still lead to compromise under pressure.

illustrations.title: Peter's Brave Yet Weak Moment
illustrations.text: Peter starts swinging his sword at a cohort of four to six hundred people, ready to fight them all alone since he's the only one with a weapon. He's making a stand until Jesus stops him, heals the ear, and tells him to put away his sword because those who live by the sword die by it, and Jesus doesn't need his help with angels at the ready. Later, brave Peter fails miserably by denying Jesus three times in front of a harmless slave girl just to blend in and avoid arrest, showing how little compromises can undermine big acts of faith.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that small compromises, not just major conflicts, can lead to failure in faith.

illustrations.title: Marriage and Old Flames Analogy
illustrations.text: You cannot stay friends with your old boyfriend or girlfriend when you get married, just as God says you can't maintain a friendship with the world. Picture yourself as the bride in love, saying you still want to hang out with the guy you used to be in love with, even if not as much anymore. God responds that it's the same for Him—flirting with the world means being unfaithful, so the ceremony can't proceed until you let it go.
illustrations.context: This analogy shows that friendship with the world is hostility toward God, making one an enemy of God.

illustrations.title: 9/11 Loss Comparison
illustrations.text: We'll never forget 9/11 and the people on the plane that went down and the Pentagon. How many? About 3,000 total—that's no small number of people to die on American soil. What if that number was eight times that? Do you think that there would not be somebody here in this room who knew somebody personally? This illustrates the scale of loss like the 24,000 Israelites who died.
illustrations.context: To emphasize the significance of the 24,000 Israelite deaths and the need for complete vigilance against threats.

illustrations.title: Israelites' Midianite Battle
illustrations.text: They come back after the war, having killed the Midianite soldiers and kings, and burned their cities and camps. They thought Moses would be thrilled, feeling they had done what was asked. But they brought the Midianite women and children back into the camp, which Moses saw as a Trojan Horse with the enemy infiltrating again. This mirrors the earlier incident that led to 24,000 deaths.
illustrations.context: To show how the Israelites failed to eliminate all enemy influence, allowing compromise to creep back in.

illustrations.title: Trojan Horse Infiltration
illustrations.text: What Moses sees is like a Trojan Horse; the enemy is in the camp again, just as when the 24,000 died because an Israelite brought a woman back. The Israelites don't see the harm, thinking of the Midianite women and children as valuable spoils rather than a threat. This analogy highlights how something seemingly harmless can introduce danger.
illustrations.context: To illustrate how incomplete victory can lead to hidden dangers and spiritual compromise.

illustrations.title: Abraham's Promised Land Vision
illustrations.text: Remember when Abraham was shown the promised land? God took him all over the land, saying wherever you walk, I'm giving it to you, and the Amorites and Canaanites were already there. The Bible tells us God was going to give the Canaanites 400 years until their sin was full or ripe. That's a long time, more than enough for them to repent, but they kept sinning and didn't.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that God gives people ample time to repent before executing judgment on their sins.

illustrations.title: Saul's Battle with Amalekites
illustrations.text: The classic passage is in 1 Samuel 15, where God sends King Saul on a mission to wipe out the Amalekites who had attacked Israel. Saul was supposed to kill every Amalekite, their king, and all livestock completely. But he spared King Agag and brought him back in chains as a war trophy, and Agag was even happy to be alive without grieving his losses. Saul also kept the best flocks alive instead of destroying them.
illustrations.context: This story emphasizes that failing to fully obey God's commands, like showing mercy where He does not, leads to disobedience and consequences.

illustrations.title: Samuel Kills Agag Ruthlessly
illustrations.text: Saul claimed he obeyed God by sacrificing the animals, but Samuel confronted him about the bleating sheep and lowing oxen. Saul made excuses, saying he feared the people and wanted to sacrifice to the Lord. Then Samuel had Agag brought out, and he killed him with a sword in front of everyone as an act of worship, showing the need to be ruthless with sin.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that we must be ruthless with sin's influence in our lives, just as Samuel was with Agag.

illustrations.title: Hacking at Sin's Branches
illustrations.text: Somebody said it this way: there are a thousand men who hack at the branches of sin for one who will strike at the root. This means many people deal with the surface issues of sin but fail to address the core problem. Pastor Bob connects this to the idea of being thorough in eliminating sin.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize the importance of striking at the root of sin rather than just its branches.

illustrations.title: Doctor Removes Suspicious Growth
illustrations.text: Like a lot of people, my doctor found a suspicious mole or growth, so they removed it and sent it to the lab. The results came back indicating it wasn't right, so they had to take more to ensure it was fully gone. Now it's finished, and I've got a scar, but imagine if the doctor said there were just a few cells left and left it up to me— that would be unwise, just as we must be thorough with sin.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to show that, like removing all cancerous cells, we must eliminate all sin in our lives completely.

illustrations.title: Solomon's Idolatry and Fall
illustrations.text: Solomon is going to be chosen to be the King after David. He's going to build the temple of God and be a great man of God, a type of Christ in his reign. From the beginning, he marries foreign wives, starting with Pharaoh's daughter, an unbeliever, and because he loves them, he builds shrines for their gods and even burns incense to those gods, falling into idolatry. He's the wisest man who became the wisest fool, showing how anyone can fall into the same problem. Little boys grow up to be Midianites, who weren't wiped out as intended, leading to oppression of Israel a hundred years later.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how seemingly harmless influences, like Solomon's marriages, can grow into deadly sin that affects future generations.

illustrations.title: Planting a Lawn with Weeds
illustrations.text: I don't know how many of you have ever planted a lawn. You might get beautiful sod that looks great for a while, but then weeds like crabgrass start appearing, making it a pain to remove. It's hard to get out the roots, much like dealing with cancer or deep-seated problems. You have to rip it up right away or use something strong like Roundup to eliminate it completely. Otherwise, it spreads and causes more trouble.
illustrations.context: This analogy emphasizes the need to deal with sin thoroughly before it grows and becomes destructive.

illustrations.title: Brownies with Dog Poop Example
illustrations.text: Years ago in our children's ministry, a woman wanted to teach the principle of purity to fifth and sixth graders. She brought fresh brownies for the kids and had them line up excitedly. But before serving, she told them there was a very small amount of dog poop in the mix, though she didn't specify where, and asked who wanted one first. The kids were horrified and no one stepped forward, showing how even a tiny impurity changes everything. She then compared it to a beautiful bottle of water with just a tablespoon of urine, which you'd probably not even notice but still ruins it.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how God views even small compromises in purity as unacceptable, unlike how we might overlook them.

illustrations.title: Isaiah's Awareness of Sin
illustrations.text: Isaiah wasn't overly concerned about his sins before he had a vision of the Lord. But once in God's presence, he suddenly became aware of his impurities, like his problems with his mouth that he hadn't noticed before. This shows how being in God's holy presence reveals sins we overlook in everyday life. The Bible highlights this as a moment of profound conviction.
illustrations.context: This retelling emphasizes that encountering God's purity makes us acutely aware of our own sin, which we don't notice in our sin-filled world.

illustrations.title: Fish in Water Analogy
illustrations.text: A fish doesn't feel wet because it's always been surrounded by water its whole life. But if you pull it out, it suddenly realizes how dry and uncomfortable that is, just like we don't notice sin because we're immersed in a world full of it. We breathe in sin every day without realizing it's abnormal. God, however, has never known sin, making our separation from Him stark.
illustrations.context: This analogy shows why we aren't sensitive to sin until we're in God's presence, as it's as natural to us as water is to a fish.

illustrations.title: Jesus Quote on Worldly Deeds
illustrations.text: Jesus, the most loving man who ever lived, said to the world, 'I testify that its deeds are evil.' Don't mistake this for an invitation to condemn people, as Jesus also said he didn't come to condemn. This shows we are called to separation without isolation or condemnation of unbelievers.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that Christians should separate from the world's evil without condemning unbelievers.

illustrations.title: Caterpillar to Butterfly Analogy
illustrations.text: Do not be conformed to this world, but be transformed—literally metamorphosized—like the caterpillar into the butterfly by the renewing of your mind. This transformation allows you to discern what the will of God is, that which is good, acceptable, and perfect. It's a picture of how spiritual change happens through God's work.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to illustrate that Christians must be transformed by renewing their minds rather than conforming to the world.

illustrations.title: Worldly Influences at Home
illustrations.text: When you come home from school or from your God-given job that you've been obedient to the Lord to go do, you need to see that many times you are already infected with worldly attitudes, worldly opinions, and worldly perspectives. Maybe it's a dirty joke or some criticism of a fellow worker, a boss, the governor, or the president. You've been around that, and even if you think it didn't affect you, it might have, to the point where you're bringing it back to your camp, your family, or your home. We need to be sensitized to that and say, 'Lord, I want to be pure when I am in your presence, with your people, or with my family.'
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to show that people can unknowingly bring worldly impurities into their spiritual and family life, just like the soldiers in the Bible.

illustrations.title: Jesus Washes Disciples' Feet
illustrations.text: At the Last Supper, Jesus washed the disciples' feet, taking the position of the lowest servant since no one else offered. When he went to wash Peter's feet, Peter refused, perhaps out of embarrassment or thinking it was too lowly for Jesus. Jesus responded that unless he washed Peter's feet, Peter would have no part with him, illustrating that we often miss deeper impurities in our lives.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to show that we need purification from compromises we might not even notice, just as Peter needed Jesus to wash his feet.

illustrations.title: Spiritual vs. Secular Life
illustrations.text: We tend to separate spiritual things from secular ones, like being spiritual only when we're at church or reading the Bible. God doesn't see our lives that way; He intends for us to have a spiritual relationship with everything and everyone. This means dedicating our entire lives to Him, not just specific moments.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that all aspects of life should be dedicated to God, not compartmentalized into spiritual and secular.

illustrations.title: Missionary in Everyday Jobs
illustrations.text: If you have a secular job like being a plumber or an engineer, you're actually a missionary in that role. We are on this planet not just to earn a living but to share our faith and live for God's glory. Anything in life can be purified and dedicated to God when we see it that way.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates that everyday occupations can be spiritual and redeemed when dedicated to God.

illustrations.title: Giving Up Idols Example
illustrations.text: I've met people who played the guitar and were incredibly gifted before they were saved, and then the Lord had them give up their guitar playing after they got saved because it was their god—it gave them fame and money. I've known people who love sports intensely, and God told them to give that up because it was getting in the way of their relationship with Him. Sometimes the Lord gives those things back when it's safe and healthy, so they can dedicate them to God's glory. This shows that talents must be used for God's purposes, not personal gain.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that God may require people to sacrifice worldly attachments to prioritize their relationship with Him and ensure activities glorify God.

illustrations.title: Israel in Egypt Quote
illustrations.text: Someone has said it this way: at the end of 40 years, God is trying to teach them a principle about worldliness because God took one night to take Israel out of Egypt, but it took 40 years to get Egypt out of Israel. Throughout our lives, the Lord is trying to remind us that this world is our enemy, not our friend, and we're too attached to it. This quote emphasizes that removing worldly influences is a lifelong process.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to show that overcoming worldliness takes time and effort, just as it did for the Israelites.

illustrations.title: Talent Show Story
illustrations.text: I heard about this young girl, 11 years old from right here in Yorba Linda, who was on America's Got Talent and got the golden buzzer after singing during a break. She wasn't even supposed to be on the show; they let audience members perform when the cameras weren't rolling. This story highlights how unexpected opportunities can showcase talents for God's glory. It's a reminder that talents can be used in surprising ways to honor God.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that even young talents, like this girl's singing, should be directed toward glorifying God rather than personal fame.

illustrations.title: Madison's Talent Show Performance
illustrations.text: In 2022, season 17 of America's Got Talent featured an 11-year-old girl named Madison Taylor from Yorba Linda, who was invited to sing from the audience during a break. She performed a passionate and riveting rendition of the hymn 'Amazing Grace,' stunning the audience and judges with her authority and emotion. The judges, including Howie Mandel, were so impressed that Mandel hit the Golden Buzzer, advancing her to the live shows and praising her talent. Despite the song's focus on God's amazing grace, the audience and judges celebrated her abilities while ignoring the spiritual message about God's redemption for lost souls.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how fallen humanity often overlooks the spiritual truth of God's grace, focusing instead on human talent in a tone-deaf world.

illustrations.title: Invisible Virus Analogy
illustrations.text: I remember during COVID how at first we were told that the virus could spread through everything, so everybody was overly cautious. We saw people wearing masks alone in their cars, thinking the virus might come through the vents or from someone who sneezed in the car. People were going to supermarkets and then coming home, some in hazmat suits, washing every piece of food. The fact is, you can't see a virus, making it hard to detect, just like worldliness.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that worldliness is an invisible danger, much like the COVID virus, which people couldn't see but still took precautions against.

illustrations.title: Gideon's Altar Destruction
illustrations.text: Remember Gideon, he's going to fight the Midianites, those idolaters, but before he can fight them, he has to tear down the altar in his dad's backyard. This story shows that we often have to deal with personal issues in our own lives first. It's about removing idols or distractions from our homes before we can effectively serve God.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses Gideon's story to illustrate the need to eliminate personal sins or distractions before engaging in spiritual battles.

illustrations.title: Be Separate from Unclean Things
illustrations.text: You know what it says in Second Corinthians 7, God says come out from their midst and be separate, saith the Lord, and do not touch what is unclean, and I'll welcome you and you'll be my sons and daughters. This means that whatever we're touching that's keeping us from enjoying God, we need to stop it because the Lord is warning us not to engage with it. Oh, I don't know about you, but I'll stop touching it to maintain that close relationship with Him.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses the Bible quote to emphasize the importance of separating from unclean influences to maintain purity and enjoy a full relationship with God.

illustrations.title: Faith Journey as Exodus Analogy
illustrations.text: You have had your own Red Sea experience where you were baptized and said goodbye to the world that used to dominate your life. Maybe you can relate to going through the wilderness with God providing for you. Perhaps you can relate to the Jordan River experience of moving from struggling with faith to experiencing God's promises. Every one of us has our own Red Sea, wilderness, Jordan River, and Promised Land experiences.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that believers go through stages of faith similar to Israel's journey, emphasizing personal growth and God's provision.

illustrations.title: Samuel's Ebenezer Stone Retelling
illustrations.text: Maybe like Samuel, you need to in the middle of the battle set up a stone of remembrance called Ebenezer, which means the stone of help. Samuel said that although the Philistines aren't destroyed completely, we have won up to now, and if we've won this far, He's going to take us all the way.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is using this to encourage believers to remember God's past victories to stay strong in ongoing battles and intercession for others.

illustrations.title: Fellowship as Shared Meal
illustrations.text: Jesus said in Revelation 3:20, 'Behold, I stand at the door and knock; if anyone hears My voice and opens the door, I will come in to him and dine with him, and he with Me.' This verse illustrates the idea of fellowship as sharing a meal with God, emphasizing intimate participation and nourishment from His sacrifice. Pastor Bob connects this to the grain offering, where priests ate the sacrifice to symbolize being satisfied and entering fellowship with the Lord.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to show that true fellowship is about a personal relationship with God, like sharing a meal.

illustrations.title: Modern Fellowship Example
illustrations.text: We often hear Christians talk about fellowship as simply spending time together, like going out for pie instead of just pie. In our culture, we use the word for relationships connected to people and food, and without food, it feels like halfway fellowship. Pastor Bob points out that this casual usage misses the deeper biblical meaning, focusing on our connection with God.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this example to contrast cultural misunderstandings of fellowship with its true biblical essence.

illustrations.title: Three for True Fellowship
illustrations.text: You know the old expression, 'Two's company, three's a crowd,' but for true koinonia, you can't have fellowship until you have three, and that third person is the Lord. This means that real fellowship between two Christians only happens when God is at the center. Pastor Bob explains that without a relationship with God, there's no genuine fellowship at all.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to illustrate that fellowship requires God's presence to be authentic.

illustrations.title: Marriage as Group Date Analogy
illustrations.text: I mean, can you imagine my wife and I are married, and if the only time we really got to know each other and talk was at church? Honey, I'll see you at church; we'll get closer there. No, no, that's not the way it works. Church ought to be the overflow of the intimacy you're building all the time, as God is available every day.
illustrations.context: This analogy emphasizes that fellowship with God should be a personal, ongoing relationship, not limited to church gatherings.

illustrations.title: Emmaus Road Encounter
illustrations.text: And so, the two on the road to Emmaus, after they realized they had been with Jesus when He was ministering to them, said, 'Did not our hearts burn within us when He spoke to us along the way?' When we look back and realize Jesus was with us, our lives are completely changed. This shows how personal encounters with Jesus transform us.
illustrations.context: This retelling illustrates that true fellowship with God involves recognizing His presence in everyday moments, leading to a deeper, life-changing relationship.

illustrations.title: Moses and Bronze Serpent
illustrations.text: As Moses lifted up the bronze serpent in the wilderness, the people were being bitten by serpents because of their grumbling, leading to death in the camp with Satan at work. God instructed Moses to lift up the bronze serpent so that those who looked at it would be healed. This story parallels Jesus being lifted up on the cross for salvation.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that Jesus, like the bronze serpent, must be lifted up for people to find salvation from sin and death.

illustrations.title: Zeal Consumes Jesus
illustrations.text: For zeal for your house has consumed me, and the reproaches of those who reproach you have fallen upon me. This verse from Psalm 69 is quoted in the New Testament regarding Jesus, who entered the temple and cleansed it by overturning the money changers' tables. It shows how Jesus' passion for God's house fulfilled this prophecy.
illustrations.context: This quote demonstrates that the burning process of the grain offering symbolizes Christ's consuming zeal and sacrificial role.

illustrations.title: Elijah's Sacrifice on Mount Carmel
illustrations.text: Remember when Elijah offered up a sacrifice to God on Mount Carmel, he repaired the altar, prepared it by putting the sacrifice on and cutting up the oxen, and then waited. The fire of God fell from heaven, likely lightning, and consumed the sacrifice completely, including the meat, the water, and even the stones. Those twelve stones represented the children of Israel, showing God's acceptance.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate how God's zeal and wrath consumed the sacrifice, paralleling it to God's acceptance of Jesus' sacrifice on the cross.

illustrations.title: Lightning Striking the Church Cross
illustrations.text: Amir shares about a priest who told the story that one day lightning struck the church on Mount Carmel and hit the stone cross on top, breaking it in half. The priest freaked out and ran away in fear. This event on the same mountain reminds us of when God sent fire to consume Elijah's sacrifice.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to connect the historical event of God's fire on Mount Carmel to the power and reality of God's actions in the present.

illustrations.title: Missionary Perfume Story
illustrations.text: I heard a story of a woman who worked for a mission agency that was getting people ready to go to the foreign mission field for the first time. She was one of the instructors preparing them to live in a foreign country and be witnesses for Christ. After lunch, she stood up and asked if anyone noticed anything different about her. They guessed things like her earrings or hair, but finally someone said she changed her perfume. She explained that in a new culture, even if you can't speak the language well, you can bring the fragrance of Christ through your attitude and how you treat people, and they will notice it immediately.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that one can minister and share Christ's fragrance through actions and attitude before fully articulating the gospel.

illustrations.title: Leavened Bread and Sin
illustrations.text: Sin is pleasurable for a season, just like bread with leaven that tastes good and is more palatable compared to unleavened bread. However, that leavened bread isn't good for you, as it ferments and pollutes the whole lump. We all know that a loaf of Wonder Bread might last a long time because of the stuff in it, but it's not truly nourishing.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating how sin may seem enjoyable at first but ultimately corrupts and harms like leavened bread.

illustrations.title: Yeast Spreading Through Dough
illustrations.text: The way yeast works is that it ferments and pollutes pervasively; you put a little leaven in, and it leavens the whole lump of dough. This shows how a small amount of sin in our life doesn't just affect one area but infects our entire self. That's why God emphasizes removing all leaven to maintain fellowship.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that even a little sin spreads and corrupts everything, just like yeast in dough.

illustrations.title: Cancer Affecting the Body
illustrations.text: Just like a little bit of cancer in my body isn't isolated to one part, but becomes a problem for the whole body, requiring treatment like chemo for everything. You can't separate it; it affects the entire system. In the same way, sin in one area impacts your whole relationship with God and others.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is emphasizing that sin in any part of life pollutes and affects the whole person and community, like cancer in the body.

illustrations.title: Leaven as Sin Analogy
illustrations.text: And just like leaven that puffs up, so sin or pride many times does exactly that. Paul in 1 Corinthians 5:7-8 uses this concept from Passover, talking about cleaning out the old leaven to be a new lump, as believers are unleavened because Christ our Passover has been sacrificed. This illustrates how sin expands and corrupts, much like leaven in dough.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is showing how sin or pride grows and affects spiritual life, emphasizing the need to remove it for true fellowship with God.

illustrations.title: Dad's Loan Record Discovery
illustrations.text: After Becky and I got married, finances were tough, and not long after, our refrigerator broke down because I accidentally put holes in it with an ice pick—it was my fault. We needed a new one but had no money, so my dad loaned us some, and we were grateful as we bought a new refrigerator from Sears. Later, while visiting my parents' house for our weekly card games, I snooped in my dad's den and found a detailed spreadsheet log of loans he had given to each of his five children, including me, with dates, amounts, and payment records. I realized I wasn't the only one who had borrowed money and felt a mix of surprise and relief knowing my siblings were in the same boat. This made me more aware of my own debts and how my dad tracked them without judgment, even though he never brought it up.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to illustrate that even though records of debts are kept, familial love persists, contrasting with God's grace and access despite sins.

illustrations.title: God Not Like Wizard of Oz
illustrations.text: God is not the Wizard of Oz with fireworks going off as you try to approach, saying stand back. That's not Him. That's why He taught us to pray, 'Our Father,' not 'Godfather'—He's Father God, and you don't have to be afraid of Him.
illustrations.context: To illustrate that God is approachable and not intimidating like the Wizard of Oz.

illustrations.title: Internal Conflict Analogy
illustrations.text: It's like there are two people inside of me, Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Flesh, and they're at war with each other. Too often, the bad guy wins. This shows the ongoing battle between my desires and God's will, as Paul described in his own life.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating the internal struggle between sinful nature and spiritual desires to emphasize the challenge of living for God.

illustrations.title: Apostles' Training by Jesus
illustrations.text: Think of the apostles of Jesus Christ; they were trained for three and a half years in the best seminary that ever existed, the Jesus Christ on earth seminary. They were called after a night of prayer, and Jesus chose those he wanted to follow him. Their job was to follow him, go with him, hang out with him, and watch him minister; they didn't start doing anything on their own at first. They spent that time enjoying him, discovering his heart, his teaching, his compassion, and the gospel. They built themselves up with knowledge of who he was and the character they needed, learning that he came to present the gospel of the kingdom to the Jewish people as the promised Messiah. Even though they knew the Great Commission and understood the gospel fully, they had to wait for the Holy Spirit to come upon them before they could begin. Jesus told them to stay in Jerusalem until they were clothed with power from on high.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that one may be called by God but still needs anointing and preparation before ministry.

illustrations.title: TV Stunts Analogy
illustrations.text: It's kind of like watching those guys on TV who do stunts or illusions with fire. They always warn, 'Please don't try this at home,' because you can't just watch and think you can do it yourself—you lack the necessary empowerment. Jesus made it clear to His disciples that apart from Him, they can do nothing, just as you couldn't perform those stunts without the proper skills.
illustrations.context: This analogy shows that the disciples needed God's anointing to carry out Jesus' work, much like one needs specific empowerment for dangerous feats.

illustrations.title: Lady at Funeral Story
illustrations.text: I remember after a funeral I did years ago, this lady came up to me and said, 'Can I just touch you?' I replied, 'Excuse me?' She explained, 'I need some of the anointing.' I thought, you obviously don't understand; I can't give you that—it comes from God and is available to every believer, not from me or through physical contact.
illustrations.context: This story emphasizes that anointing is from God and accessible to all believers, not something one person can transfer to another.

illustrations.title: Little Boy's Baptism Mix-Up
illustrations.text: I heard a story about a little boy who had been to a church baptism. His mom overheard him baptizing his toy soldiers in the bathtub, saying, 'I now baptize you in the name of the Father, the Son, and the whole East Coast.' This shows how people often get mixed up about the Holy Spirit, thinking it's all jumbled instead of central to everything in life.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating how people are confused about the Holy Spirit, treating it as mysterious or misunderstood.

illustrations.title: Starting Church as Young Pastor
illustrations.text: After Becky and I got married, I returned to police work for three and a half years, then the Lord worked through circumstances where my Christian chief encouraged me to start a church. I asked Pastor Chuck if we could begin in our home, and he graciously agreed; we started with 17 people, including friends from our church, and it grew slowly with beautiful fellowship. In that small church, everyone knew each other, making it a wonderful time of belonging and community. I was working full-time as a cop while also serving as a pastor, studying the Bible on my breaks and handling weddings, funerals, and counseling. We were three years into our marriage, had a one-year-old son and another child under three, and were struggling with finances after buying a house, but I felt called and excited about finally living out my ministry dream. Becky and I were balancing family life amid all this busyness, and one day she said we needed to talk because I was working about 80 hours a week.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the excitement and challenges of early ministry, family, and balancing multiple responsibilities.

illustrations.title: Marriage Crisis in Ministry
illustrations.text: We drove to Tri-City Park and sat down, where my wife told me she couldn't do this anymore and needed me to quit pastoring. I was torn because I felt called to ministry, but I also knew my marriage was paramount. I told her I would call the elders and make that Sunday my last if that's what she wanted. She then realized that my willingness to put her first was enough, and we moved forward in ministry together. This experience taught me that God wouldn't call me to destroy my marriage.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob emphasizes that God's calling should never harm one's marriage, prioritizing spousal relationships above ministry demands.

illustrations.title: Woman Touches Jesus' Garment
illustrations.text: Do you remember when Jesus was in the crowd, and everyone was around Him? He said, 'Somebody touched Me,' and everyone replied, 'Yeah, we all did,' but He meant that power had gone out from Him. There was a woman who had a hemorrhage; she had spent all her money on doctors and only got worse. She believed that if she could just touch the hem of His garment, she would be healed, so she did. Jesus knew it, not to shame her, but to let her give testimony of her faith. He waited for her, and when she came forward, she said it was her, and He told her, 'Your faith has healed you.'
illustrations.context: This story illustrates that touching or getting close to Christ, like the Old Testament sacrifice, changes and consecrates a person.

illustrations.title: Christ as the Stone Analogy
illustrations.text: Jesus said in Luke 20:18 that everyone who falls on that stone will be broken to pieces, but on whomever it falls it will scatter him like dust. This connects to the vision of Nebuchadnezzar in Daniel, where a stone not cut with human hands destroys all nations and turns them into dust. Christ is that stone of God, and in coming to him, we accept his blood that washes and cleanses us completely, but it also involves being broken. This illustrates the dual aspects of cleansing and breaking in our relationship with the Lord.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to show that accepting Christ involves both cleansing through his blood and personal breaking for holiness.

illustrations.title: Sin Offering as Christ's Sacrifice
illustrations.text: The sin offering, where the blood was shed, is offered to God alone and completely burned, not partaken by the priests. This is a type and picture of Christ satisfying the holy wrath of God in his sacrifice. When Christ offered himself on the cross, God put our sins on him, condemned him, and the fire of God's wrath fell, making it acceptable to God. We have absolutely nothing to do with that part of the sacrifice; it's solely for God.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates that Christ's sacrifice fully satisfies God's wrath and is accepted by God alone, emphasizing our lack of participation.

illustrations.title: Human Friendship Analogy
illustrations.text: You know, anybody you've ever built a real close friendship with, I'm almost sure that two things were true of that relationship: you've spent time together because you can't instantly know someone, so you spent time and went through experiences together, and you communicated. This shows that building a deep connection requires effort and interaction. Just as in human relationships, we need to apply this to our relationship with God.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that building a relationship with God requires spending time and communicating, just like in human friendships.

illustrations.title: Jesus' Friendship Quote
illustrations.text: Here's what Jesus said in John 15:15: No longer do I call you slaves, for a slave does not know what his master is doing, but I have called you friends, for everything the Father has made known to me, I have made known to you. This means open and honest disclosure and communication, which is what true friendship is about, whether in human relationships or with God. By sharing everything God revealed to Him, Jesus invites us into that same level of friendship.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is using this quote to emphasize that Jesus offers believers a friendship based on open communication and revelation from God.

illustrations.title: Israelites' Wilderness Journey
illustrations.text: The children of Israel took 40 years to reach the promised land, but we know it doesn't have to take that long. In their case, it did, and tragically, most of the people saved from Egypt never entered it—only those under 20 survived; everyone over 20 died in the wilderness. For the younger ones, it meant 40 years of their lives wandering, and some Christians today spend their entire lives circling in unbelief over something that shouldn't take so long.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to warn Christians against wasting their lives in unbelief, just as the Israelites did in the wilderness.

illustrations.title: God as Shepherd Guide
illustrations.text: He is the shepherd of my life, and a shepherd guides his sheep. His word guides me like a lamp to my feet and a light to my path. His Spirit also directs me, leading me to be spirit-led in every aspect of life.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates how God's word and Spirit provide constant guidance for believers, encouraging them to live spirit-filled lives.

illustrations.title: Gold in Bible Hills
illustrations.text: Whenever you get to a passage like that, there are a number of them in the Bible, you want to take out your spiritual pickaxe and remind yourself that there is gold in them thar hills. There's a reason for it being there, so don't pass it by. This encourages digging deeper into the text.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is using this analogy to encourage listeners to mine for deeper truths in seemingly dry Bible passages.

illustrations.title: Radio Program Inspiration
illustrations.text: I love this passage of Scripture; it was the basis of our radio program many years ago when we were on KWAY. We called our radio program Hidden Treasures because I do believe in getting into the scriptures and looking at the nuances within scripture. This shows how the passage influenced our ministry.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating how Proverbs 2 inspired his personal ministry work to emphasize discovering hidden truths in the Bible.

illustrations.title: Seeking Wisdom Quote
illustrations.text: Here's what it says in Proverbs 2: Make your ear attentive to wisdom, incline your heart to understanding. For if you cry for discernment, lift your voice for understanding; if you seek her as silver and search for her as for hidden treasures, then you will discern the fear of the Lord and discover the knowledge of God. Pastor Bob connects this to the idea of not skipping difficult passages, as it reveals the value of persistent searching in Scripture.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to explain why seeking wisdom in the Bible is like hunting for hidden treasures, urging deeper engagement with God's Word.

illustrations.title: Biblical Quote on Marriage
illustrations.text: Remember, the Bible says what God has joined together, let no man put asunder. We don't hear that term except maybe in weddings. This highlights God's original design for marriage as unbreakable, connecting back to the creation of man and woman as one.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize God's intention that marriage should not be broken apart.

illustrations.title: Divorce Debates in Jesus's Time
illustrations.text: The Pharisees and disciples wanted to know Jesus's view on divorce because it was a major controversy. There were two schools: the conservative School of Shammai, which allowed little grounds for divorce, and the liberal School of Hillel, which permitted it for almost any reason, like if a wife burned your food and made you angry. This historical context shows how divorce was handled in that era, similar to today's no-fault divorce where people can remarry easily.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate the historical backdrop of Jesus's teaching on marriage and the varying interpretations of divorce grounds.

illustrations.title: Jesus on Original Marriage
illustrations.text: Jesus didn't quote the rabbis or Moses when discussing divorce; instead, he explained that Moses allowed it only because of people's hardened hearts. He pointed back to the beginning, saying God made them male and female with the intention that nothing should separate them. Except for infidelity, which can deal a death blow to a marriage, Jesus emphasized that marriage was meant to be permanent as God designed it.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that God's original plan for marriage is unbreakable except in cases of adultery, highlighting the seriousness of marital commitment.

illustrations.title: Peter's Divine Revelation
illustrations.text: You remember what Jesus said to Peter when Peter declared, 'Thou art the Christ, the Son of the Living God.' Jesus replied, 'Blessed are you, Simon, for flesh and blood has not revealed this to you, but my Father who is in heaven.' In other words, this was a divine revelation that parents can't give; they can teach theological truths, but only God can impart that inner transformation. So, being born of God happens through divine action, not just parental influence.
illustrations.context: To illustrate that divine revelation and spiritual birth come directly from God, not from human sources like parents.

illustrations.title: Character Building Quote
illustrations.text: We read a quote just yesterday that said it takes 20 years to build a character but about five minutes to ruin it. You need to be careful with your life and your reputation, ensuring you're a person above reproach. The Bible echoes this in Proverbs 22:1, stating that a good name is better than great riches. This reminds us to guard our character diligently in a dark world.
illustrations.context: To emphasize the importance of protecting one's reputation and living above reproach.

illustrations.title: John's Heavenly Vision
illustrations.text: You remember when John got a tour of heaven in Revelation chapter 4. He heard a voice saying come up here, and he was suddenly in the spirit, up in heaven. He saw what heaven is like with the 24 elders worshiping, myriads of angels, and souls of the redeemed. Then he witnessed the unfolding of the future, including events after the church age up to Jesus Christ's return and the eternal state. It's an amazing preview, and he even saw the New Jerusalem coming down from heaven, where we're going to live forever—it's a picture of us.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize that believers' names are written in heaven, symbolizing eternal belonging and rest.

illustrations.title: Name on Foundation Analogy
illustrations.text: Now let me just ask you, if you saw your name on something that was built, like your own name on the foundation stone of the New Jerusalem, not just any name but specifically yours. Do you sense that you get a feeling like I belong here? This connects to Jesus saying He goes to prepare a place for you. It's a way to feel assured of your place in eternity.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates the idea of belonging in heaven through the personal significance of seeing one's name on the New Jerusalem.

illustrations.title: God's Time and Money Joke
illustrations.text: I love this story about a person who said he was talking to the Lord. He asked, 'Lord, how much is a million years to you?' And God said, 'That's like a second.' Then the person asked, 'Lord, how much is a million dollars to you?' God replied, 'That's like a penny.' So the person said, 'Lord, can I have a penny?' and God said, 'Sure, just a second.'
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate God's unique perspective on time, connecting it to the biblical idea that a day with the Lord is like a thousand years.

illustrations.title: Tombstone Dates Poem
illustrations.text: Somebody wrote a little poem about a man who stood to speak at the funeral of a friend. He referred to the dates on her tombstone, from the beginning to the end. He noted that the first was the date of birth and the second was the date of death, but what mattered most was the dash between the years, representing all the time she spent alive on earth. Only those who loved her know what that little line is worth, as it shows how she lived in love and spent her days. It reminds us that what matters isn't what we own like cars, houses, or cash, but how we live our lives.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this poem to emphasize that the time between birth and death is what truly matters in how we live and love.

illustrations.title: Life as a Breath
illustrations.text: On a cold day, you can see your breath when you exhale, something fleeting that appears and quickly vanishes. Pastor Bob compares our lives to this breath, highlighting how short and temporary they are. He ties it to the idea from Psalm 90 that our days are brief, like a vapor. This analogy underscores that life passes quickly, whether it's a good breath or a bad one, but the key is recognizing its brevity.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that human life is short and transient, urging reflection on how we use our time.

illustrations.title: Family Funeral Discussions
illustrations.text: When I was young, I remember my sons and I talking about death whenever someone passed away and we went to a funeral. They would worry that someday I might die, and I'd reassure them that it probably wouldn't happen soon unless Jesus returned. We'd even pick out songs for my funeral, like 'Meet Me at the Summit' by Bob Ayala, which talk about seeing each other in heaven. My sons would start crying as they imagined it, and I appreciated having a glimpse of their grief while I was still alive—it's kind of odd but meaningful.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to contrast human grief over death with God's perspective, emphasizing that we should view death as a joyful reunion.

illustrations.title: Precious Death in God's Eyes
illustrations.text: The Bible says that precious in the sight of the Lord is the death of his godly ones. He can't wait for that day, just like parents can't wait for the day their child is born. God is eager for you to be with Him face to face in heaven, so we should think of death in that positive light rather than with fear or sorrow.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob explains this quote to show that God views the death of believers as a precious event, like a long-awaited birth, highlighting the joy of eternal presence with God.

illustrations.title: Fire Evacuation Realization
illustrations.text: I remember down at the 7-Eleven when they were kicking us out of the neighborhood because they thought the fires would come over the hill and there might not be a home to go back to. It felt weird and surreal, but also okay, because it made me realize that if I lost everything physically, I don't lose that much. The only thing that really mattered was being with my wife and children, as they are in a whole different class of importance.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob emphasizes that family and relationships hold far greater value than material possessions.

illustrations.title: Moses Birth Brings Deliverance
illustrations.text: The children of Israel were 400 years in slavery in Egypt, and in Exodus we read about the birth of a little boy who was going to change all of that. Moses, that little boy, meant things were going to change because of him. God used his birth to lead the people out of bondage.
illustrations.context: God uses the birth of a child to bring significant change and deliverance for His people.

illustrations.title: Samuel Revives Prophecy
illustrations.text: In the days of Eli, when prophecies were few and men were not seeking God, the high priests and their sons were wicked and ungodly, making it seem like the light of prophecy would go out. But then a little boy was born, named Samuel, and God used him to bring prophecy and His word back in power. This birth restored spiritual direction for the nation.
illustrations.context: God uses the birth of a child to revive and strengthen His prophetic word during dark times.

illustrations.title: Obed Restores Naomi's Life
illustrations.text: Read the Book of Ruth; we don't know this story as much as we should. Obed is born, and he becomes a restorer of life to Naomi, who had lost everything—her husband and her son, leaving her with nothing. The Book of Ruth is all about redemption, and at the end, this little boy Obed restores what God gives back, starting with a new birth that brings life anew.
illustrations.context: God uses the birth of a child to illustrate redemption and restoration in times of loss.

illustrations.title: Enoch Walks with God After Birth
illustrations.text: The Bible tells us that Enoch began to walk with the Lord when his son Methuselah was born; it doesn't say he was walking with the Lord before that. He was 65 years old when this happened, and having a son changed his life and perspective on who he was and what he was living for. Sometimes God uses the birth of a child as a wake-up call to draw someone closer to Him.
illustrations.context: God can use the birth of a child to transform a person's life and deepen their walk with Him.

illustrations.title: Baby Grandson Story
illustrations.text: Look, I've got a baby at my house. We don't say, 'Hey Jeffrey, in three months, take out the trash or do the dishes.' He can't do that; he can't do much except be the cutest grandson in the world, and he does that really well. This illustrates that it's okay to be a baby spiritually, just like a real baby needs care and time to grow.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that spiritual babies need nurturing and time to mature, just like his grandson.

illustrations.title: Hosea's Prophetic Child Names
illustrations.text: For instance, if you read the book of Hosea, you discover that his children were named Lo-Ruhamah and Lo-Ammi. These names were given to convey a message to the people he was ministering to. Prophets in the Bible often used such names to illustrate spiritual truths.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating how prophets like Enoch used names prophetically to warn of judgment, emphasizing the need for repentance.

illustrations.title: Hugh Moore's Defiance
illustrations.text: There was a true story about Hugh Moore, an agnostic who claimed God doesn't exist. He publicly challenged God, saying if God existed, He should strike him dead right then, and he gave God five minutes to do it. The crowd, full of god-fearing people, watched in fear as the minutes passed, with some even fainting in anxiety. When nothing happened after five minutes, Hugh declared it proved God's non-existence, but someone wisely pointed out that all he really proved was that you can't exhaust God's patience in just five minutes. This story shows how God's patience endures even in the face of direct challenges.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate that God is slow to anger and abounding in loving kindness, emphasizing that people cannot exhaust God's patience.

illustrations.title: Enoch's Walk with God
illustrations.text: I heard a story of a man telling his son about Enoch, explaining that Enoch walked with God and was taken by Him because he was pleasing to God. The little boy imagined that Enoch and God walked together every day, enjoying each other's company. One day, as they walked, God said to Enoch, 'We're closer to my house than yours, so let's go to my house.' This shows that when you walk with the Lord, heaven becomes the most attractive thing in the world.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate that walking closely with God, like Enoch, makes heaven appealing and natural.

illustrations.title: Enoch's Walk with God
illustrations.text: I love Enoch's testimony. He wasn't just a believer who walked with the Lord privately; he was prophesying and calling people to repent. He lived in a dark world, getting ready for the pre-flood degradation of society, yet he walked with God and warned others to get right with Him.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses Enoch's story to encourage believers that they can faithfully walk with God even in dark times and share His message.

illustrations.title: Light in Dark Places
illustrations.text: You turn a light on in a dark room because it doesn't help where there's already plenty of light. If you have a candle, you put it where it's dark to make a difference. God places light in dark places, just as He did with Jesus in Galilee among those who walked in darkness.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to show that God positions believers in dark environments to shine His light and bring hope.

illustrations.title: Older Woman Attends Church
illustrations.text: I heard of this older woman who came to church every Sunday. She was skinny and had lost her hearing, so she could hardly hear the sermon at all. One person asked her why she bothered coming when she couldn't hear, and she replied that she came to show her neighbors whose side she was on and to go on record about her faith. She understood enough to know that her presence made a statement about standing for God.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the importance of publicly declaring one's faith and letting others know where you stand with God.

illustrations.title: Robert Louis Stevenson's Lamplighter
illustrations.text: My name is Robert Lewis Copan II, and I was named after Robert Louis Stevenson, who died as a young man. When he was a little boy, his nanny was getting him ready for bed, and he looked out the window at a lamplighter in the 1800s who lit the street lamps every night. Stevenson said he was watching a man punch holes in the darkness, and I connect this to how we can spread hope in a dark world through our actions and faith.
illustrations.context: This shows how ordinary people can bring light and hope to a spiritually dark world, just as God can use us to punch holes in the darkness.

illustrations.title: Punching Holes in Darkness
illustrations.text: Give people who see nothing and have no hope, where the past is bad and the future is gone, it's all dark. Could you use us to punch some holes in the darkness so that they can see the hope of Jesus Christ? This illustrates bringing light into despair.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that believers can bring hope and the light of Jesus to those in spiritual darkness.

illustrations.title: Alexa Prayer Experience
illustrations.text: This morning Becky and I were having coffee as we like to do, and we have a time of reading and praying, but she left the room for a minute. I usually ask Alexa about the weather, but I was in a different mood, so I said, 'Alexa, pray for me,' wanting to hear what she'd say. She said, 'I'll keep you in my thoughts,' and I thought that was a lie because no algorithm is keeping me on Alexa's mind all day. I noted how that's what politicians say with every tragedy—they're in our thoughts and prayers—but Alexa can't say she'll keep me in her prayers because she doesn't pray. I emphasized that thinking about someone and praying for someone are not the same thing.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate that simply thinking about someone is not equivalent to genuine prayer, encouraging listeners to engage in real intercession.

illustrations.title: Womb Comfort Transition
illustrations.text: You're conceived and spend nine months in the womb, and you're not even anxious for that to change. After nine months, you're so at home there that you'd stay as long as you could. That woman's body, your mama, didn't force you out early; it waited until the right time. This shows how people often fear transitions because they're comfortable where they are.
illustrations.context: This analogy illustrates how people might be afraid of transitioning to eternity because they are comfortable in their current state and reluctant to change.

illustrations.title: Dynamic Positioning of Platforms
illustrations.text: They have these drilling platforms in the ocean that use dynamic positioning technology. These platforms have thrusters adjusted by GPS satellites, constantly checking and repositioning themselves in nanoseconds to stay exactly over the oil well. It's amazing how this system keeps the platform steady without anchors or cement, serving as a powerful example of sensitivity and adjustment.
illustrations.context: God wants us to be very aware of his love and keep ourselves in touch with it, just as the platform constantly repositions itself.

illustrations.title: Vastness of the Grand Canyon
illustrations.text: If you have ever been to the Grand Canyon, you will understand why it's impossible to describe it adequately to someone who's never been there. It's 277 miles long, 18 miles wide, and over a mile deep at its deepest point, with the highest point reaching 8,803 feet. When you're staring into it for the first time, you're usually in a state of awe, and it's been well said that words can't capture its true essence.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the breadth, length, height, and depth of Christ's love, which surpasses knowledge and is hard to fully comprehend.

illustrations.title: Experiencing Grand Canyon and Falls
illustrations.text: Grand Canyon must be experienced before it is known, just like Niagara Falls. If you're only familiar with Niagara Falls from a special, you haven't truly felt it—you need to go there and feel the rumbling under your feet. It's awesome, and this illustrates that God's love, like these wonders, must be personally experienced to be fully understood.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to show that God's love must be experienced firsthand, not just intellectually known, as Paul prayed for the church.

illustrations.title: Experiencing Parental Love
illustrations.text: Your parents told you they loved you throughout your life, and you understood that's what parents do. But if you have the privilege of having a child, something changes—you start to realize that's what your mom and dad felt, and you didn't fully know it until now. You can't just study that kind of love; you have to experience it firsthand.
illustrations.context: This real-world example emphasizes that understanding God's love requires personal experience, similar to realizing parental love through parenthood.

illustrations.title: Friend Craig's Sketch Insight
illustrations.text: I have a friend who's in heaven now, and he was an artist and sign maker. Craig once told me that while reading the passage in Ephesians about the length, width, height, and depth of God's love, he started sketching on a piece of paper. As he drew, he realized everything in this world is three-dimensional, but God's love has four dimensions, and his sketch turned into a cross, revealing that Christ's love encompasses those dimensions.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob shares this personal story to illustrate how the four dimensions of God's love are embodied in the cross of Jesus Christ.

illustrations.title: God's Love Like Ocean
illustrations.text: It's been said God's love is like an ocean you can see the beginning of it but you can't see the end of it. How true that is, as it illustrates the vast and unending nature of God's affection. This comparison emphasizes the boundless extent of divine love.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to show the everlasting and immeasurable quality of God's love.

illustrations.title: Jonah's Disobedience and Redemption
illustrations.text: If you're not thinking of Jonah at that point, you ought to be, because that's where he was disobedient to God, the storm came, and they threw him overboard. He was so rebellious that he'd rather drown than obey God, but then he changed his mind. From the depths, from the gates of Sheol, he cried out to God, remembered the promises, prayed in faith, and God heard his prayer.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob retells Jonah's story to illustrate that God's love reaches even the deepest places of rebellion and despair.

illustrations.title: Basking in God's Love at Beach
illustrations.text: You can go to the beach with your family and take your lawn chair, book, sunglasses, cell phone, or iPad, and you're at the beach but not in the ocean. You can enjoy the beach and like the waves without getting wet at all. There are a lot of people who can admire, appreciate, and stand in awe of the love of God, sing about it, but they're not truly immersed in it.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to urge people to fully engage with God's love rather than just observe it from a distance.

illustrations.title: Unstoppable Rain Analogy
illustrations.text: You cannot keep God from loving you any more than you can keep it from raining, but you can put up an umbrella. God sends the sun and the rain on the righteous and the wicked equally, and you can't stop it from raining or the sun from shining, but you can cover yourself if you want. It's like using sunblock or a burka to block it out, though I don't know why you would.
illustrations.context: This analogy illustrates that God's love is inevitable and cannot be stopped, just like rain or sun, but people can choose to block it out.

illustrations.title: Couple's Daughter Story
illustrations.text: Like that couple whose daughter started to be attracted to a druggie at school, and they knew he was bad news, so they prayed hard as Christians. They introduced her to a very good-looking Christian young man at church. She lost all interest in the druggie as a result.
illustrations.context: This story shows that the way to overcome attraction to the world is by introducing something better, like falling in love with the Lord.

illustrations.title: Israel's Early Devotion Retelling
illustrations.text: God said to his people, 'I remember concerning you the devotion of your youth, the love of your betrothals when you were following after me in the wilderness through a land not sown.' He's talking about the way they were when they first came out of Egypt, starting that trek to the promised land, excited with God's presence and power that had just released them from bondage.
illustrations.context: This retelling illustrates that initial excitement and love for God can counter temptations, similar to the devotion Israel had in their early days.

illustrations.title: Chasing Becky's Secret Note
illustrations.text: Becky and I had just begun dating, and I remember she was writing something on a piece of paper. I asked her what she was writing, and she said, 'Oh, nothing.' That made my curiosity go crazy, so she folded it up. I said, 'Let me see,' but she refused, and I started chasing her to get the paper.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the excitement and passion of a new love relationship, paralleling the initial devotion one should have for God and the need to return to it.

illustrations.title: Personal Dating Story
illustrations.text: She didn't want to give it to me, so I got it without hurting anybody. On that piece of paper, this girl that I had just started dating had been writing her own name with my last name. This illustrates a point about past affections and how they relate to our spiritual relationship.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to emphasize remembering a simpler, more affectionate relationship with God, like in the early days of dating.

illustrations.title: Elderly Couple Driving
