illustrations.text: I remember hearing the story of this elderly man and his wife driving down the street behind a young couple. The wife saw the young man with his arm around the girl and said she wished they could be like that again. The husband replied, 'I never moved. Come on over here.'
illustrations.context: This illustrates that God hasn't moved away; it's we who have drifted, and we can return to that close relationship.

illustrations.title: Bumper Sticker Reminder
illustrations.text: Remember the old bumper sticker: 'If you don't feel close to God, guess who moved?' This simple phrase highlights that God remains steadfast, and it's up to us to draw near again.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to point out that in a distant relationship with God, it's the person who has moved, not God.

illustrations.title: Philip Bliss Hymn History
illustrations.text: The author of the hymn 'Oh How I Love Jesus' is Philip Bliss, who wrote it and saw it become extremely popular during Moody Evangelistic Crusades. Bliss later felt convicted that the song emphasized human love for Jesus too much, so he wrote another hymn to balance it. This reflects how even good theology can prompt deeper reflection on our affections for God.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that our love for Jesus should stem from His love for us first, urging a return to genuine devotion.

illustrations.title: Becky's Baby Talk Story
illustrations.text: I remember Becky and I used to talk in baby talk for a while, though I'm not saying you need to do this with your spouse. She started it, not me. Once, when I was a cop, she called the police department thinking I answered the phone, but it wasn't me. She accidentally called the dispatcher by a special name she only uses for me, which was a little weird. This shows how we have special words that only we understand in our relationship.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to illustrate the special, intimate relationship between believers and God, as described in the Song of Solomon.

illustrations.title: Children Imitating Loved Ones
illustrations.text: Listen, children by nature imitate the one that they know loves them. If you know the love of God, you are going to be motivated to be like the Lord. That's exactly why Paul wrote in Ephesians 5:1, 'Therefore be imitators of God as beloved children.' Children who feel loved want to be like their parents; they want to do what their dad does, and girls want to do what their mom does.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that knowing God's love motivates believers to imitate Him, just as loved children imitate their parents.

illustrations.title: Don Francisco's Song on Obedience
illustrations.text: I have the words of a song that are convicting and a blessing at the same time; it's an older song by Don Francisco. He wrote this: I don't care how many buses you own or the size of your Sanctuary; it doesn't matter how steep your steeple is if it's sitting on a cemetery. I don't care if your pastor is superpowered and your program is always new; what you need is love and truth, and then men are gonna come to you. It doesn't matter if you know the Bible if it's all just in your head; the thing I need to ask you, Jesus says, is have you done the things I said. Hey folks, that song is absolutely right on.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses the song to emphasize that true faith and love for God are demonstrated through obedience and actions, not just appearances or knowledge.

illustrations.title: Morning Dew Analogy
illustrations.text: God said your love is just temporary, Israel, like the morning cloud or the dew that goes away early. On our way to church this morning, it was misting and probably going to clear up, not supposed to rain the rest of the day—that's like June gloom in Southern California, with low clouds and a bit of wetness, but it'll burn off. This illustrates how fleeting human love can be compared to God's unchanging love.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to show that Israel's love for God is temporary and fades quickly, unlike God's eternal love.

illustrations.title: Falling in Love Changes
illustrations.text: You remember when you fell in love and how you might change some things you normally did and liked to do. For example, I didn't know that I even cracked my knuckles, but I don't think I've done it in a long time because Becky said she doesn't really like that. This shows how love motivates us to please the one we love, just as we should seek to please God.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates how the love of Christ compels us to do things that please Him, not out of obligation but from a desire to show love.

illustrations.title: Racketball and Relationship Sacrifice
illustrations.text: I used to play racketball a lot, thinking I was good at it, but it wasn't something Becky and I did together, so I wasn't as interested in it anymore. You might say that shouldn't be the way, but don't judge me—judge yourself. Love is about sacrificing your preferences for the person you love, just like that.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to illustrate that true love involves giving up personal preferences for the sake of others.

illustrations.title: Jesus' Humble Sacrifice
illustrations.text: Have this mind in you which was also in Christ Jesus, who though he existed in the very form of God, didn't regard equality with God as something to be held onto; he emptied himself, took on the form of a servant, and died for sins he never committed because he loved you. This shows how Jesus sacrificed everything out of love. It's an example of true selflessness that we should emulate.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob retells this biblical story to demonstrate that Jesus' sacrifice exemplifies the kind of love that involves giving up everything for others.

illustrations.title: Grandson's Question on Return
illustrations.text: I mentioned to my grandson in the car as I picked him up the other day that I'd be teaching on Christ's coming, and Jeffrey said, 'Oh grandpa, is he coming soon?' I thought, wow, he doesn't know that for sure, but it reminded me of the anticipation we should have. This simple conversation highlights how we should live in eager expectation of Jesus' return.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob shares this personal story to emphasize the importance of living in anticipation and expectation of Christ's return.

illustrations.title: Jesus' Promise in Revelation
illustrations.text: Can I remind you that twice in the Book of Revelation, including the very last words of Jesus recorded in the Bible, Jesus said, 'I am coming soon.' The last words in response to that are, 'Even so, come quickly, Lord Jesus,' which is one of the best prayers we can offer. This quote matters because it urges us to pray daily for God's kingdom to come and live in eager anticipation.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this biblical quote with explanation to connect it to the point of anticipating Christ's mercy and living expectantly.

illustrations.title: Grandson's Heaven Conversation
illustrations.text: The other day, my grandson came with me after church, and we sat down together. I asked him what he was studying in Sunday school, which led to him asking questions about heaven. He wondered if we'd recognize each other and if he could fly—these are big questions for a six-year-old. We talked about what the Bible says, and he kept asking more, like about people who have died and what the kingdom will be like. It was one of the most fun conversations we've had, and then his sister joined in, eager to hear everything from the beginning.
illustrations.context: This story illustrates that the best way to wait anxiously for the Lord is to be in love with him, as seen in the child's excitement about Jesus's return.

illustrations.title: Pat Terry's Excitement Song
illustrations.text: Pat Terry wrote these words around 1975: Just as the lightning comes from the East and flashes even to the West, so shall the coming of the Son of Man be. He sings about putting on your Sunday best and can't wait to see Jesus in his glory as he bursts from the sky, to be held in his arms, and to hear the trumpets sound. This song expresses eagerness for heaven, walking the streets of gold, and checking into a mansion, connecting it all to the Bible's promises. Terry's lyrics remind us of the joy in anticipating Jesus's return.
illustrations.context: This quote emphasizes the excitement of waiting for Jesus, showing how being occupied with him means looking forward to his coming with anticipation.

illustrations.title: Jewish Wedding Analogy
illustrations.text: It's a picture of a Jewish wedding. The son who lived with his dad would build a place for him and his wife in his father's house, then he would go get his bride and bring her back. It's exactly what Jesus is saying: you're my bride, and I'm preparing a place for you, but I'm going to come get you and take you back there—that's the Rapture.
illustrations.context: This analogy illustrates that the Rapture is like a Jewish wedding where Jesus prepares a place and returns for his bride.

illustrations.title: Reverse Surprise Party Example
illustrations.text: I don't know if any of you have ever attended a reverse surprise party. That's where you were supposed to be ready to shout surprise for the person whose birthday it was, but they took too long to arrive, so the people arranging it had you come too early. You ended up eating, drinking, talking with friends, and getting caught up in conversation, so when the person of honor walked in, you were all busy and the surprise was on you instead.
illustrations.context: This example warns that Christians should stay alert and ready for Christ's return, just as one should be prepared for a surprise event.

illustrations.title: Lamb Inspection for Forgiveness
illustrations.text: Remember when a man who wanted forgiveness for his sins came to the priest? He brought a sacrifice, like a lamb, goat, or ox, and the priest inspected the lamb, not the man, to ensure it was acceptable. God has accepted the blood of the Lamb, so it's not about us earning anything. We don't deserve heaven because we became Christians; it's all about God's mercy.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is emphasizing that salvation depends on Christ's sacrifice, not on personal worthiness or good works.

illustrations.title: Three Surprises in Heaven
illustrations.text: It's been said there will be three surprises in heaven. The first surprise is that there'll be some people you thought wouldn't be there, and they will be. The second surprise is that some you thought for sure would be there, won't be. The third surprise is how did I get here, highlighting that salvation is by grace alone.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that eternal life is based on God's unchanging mercy, not on human efforts or expectations.

illustrations.title: Surprises in Heaven Quote
illustrations.text: Like that person who wrote these words: I dreamed death came the other night and Heaven's Gates swung wide. With kindly grace, an angel ushered me inside, and to my amazement, I saw folks I'd known on Earth, some I had judged unfit or of little worth. Indignant words rose to my lips but were never spoken, for every face showed stunned surprise, as no one expected me.
illustrations.context: This quote illustrates that there will be surprises in heaven due to God's mercy, emphasizing that He saves us despite our failings.

illustrations.title: Distance Between Head and Heart
illustrations.text: It's been said that the greatest distance in the world is the 18 inches between a man's head and his heart. This refers to the gap between intellectual knowledge and emotional connection. In the context of faith, it highlights how one might know about God but not truly feel a deep love for Him.
illustrations.context: This quote underscores the importance of bridging the gap between knowing about God and having a heartfelt love relationship with Him.

illustrations.title: Umbrella Closing Analogy
illustrations.text: I don't know how many umbrellas we have at home; we have several and get a few more on trips with different kinds. It's not uncommon for Becky to pick one up and say, 'How do you close this one?' They're not all the old-fashioned type; some have a button, and others require a different method, and I don't understand it any better than she does. But if you're here feeling distant from God and saying, 'I don't know how to close the umbrella,' God isn't asking you to figure it out yourself. He's simply asking you to come to Him and let Him take care of it.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses the umbrella analogy to show that God wants people to come to Him for help without needing to know how to fix their own spiritual struggles.

illustrations.title: Renewing Marriage Vows
illustrations.text: I sometimes have the privilege of renewing people's vows with them when they say, can you redo our vows? We've been married 10, 20, or even 50 years. I think it's biblical to renew vows, as God renews his commitment to Israel multiple times. It's not necessary for salvation; you renew to reaffirm 'I still do,' just as believers can reaffirm their commitment to the Lord.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that believers can renew their commitment to God, similar to renewing marriage vows, to live out their faith.

illustrations.title: Rebekah's Selection Story
illustrations.text: Abraham's servant prayed for guidance at the spring, asking God to show him the right woman by a specific sign. Rebekah arrived, offered him water, and even watered his camels without hesitation. He learned she was from Abraham's family, gave her gifts, and sought permission to take her as Isaac's wife. The family agreed, blessing Rebekah as she departed with the servant. This story highlights God's faithful leading throughout.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this retelling to illustrate God's guidance and the Holy Spirit's role in everyday decisions, as seen in the chapter.

illustrations.title: John the Baptist's Identity
illustrations.text: It's interesting that when the leaders of Israel sent people to ask John the Baptist who he was—whether he was the Christ, the Prophet Moses spoke of, or Elijah—he denied all of that. They pressed him, saying, 'Who are you then, so we can report back?' And he replied, 'I am the voice of one crying in the wilderness, make straight the way of the Lord,' quoting from Isaiah. He made it clear that it's not about him at all, emphasizing his role as a messenger.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that someone filled with the Holy Spirit focuses on the Lord rather than themselves.

illustrations.title: Jesus in Gadara
illustrations.text: Remember when Jesus went to Gadara, one of the cities of the Decapolis across the Sea of Galilee. The only welcoming party was a man possessed by a legion of demons, living in the tombs, cutting himself, and terrifying everyone. Jesus cast out the demons, and the man was suddenly in his right mind, sitting at Jesus' feet and wanting to go with him. But Jesus told him to return to his own house and describe what great things God had done for him, sending him back to his family first even as the people of the area asked Jesus to leave.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize that one should first share their faith and testimony with their own family.

illustrations.title: Noah Building the Ark
illustrations.text: Noah preached the gospel as he built the ark, which took many years as he warned of coming judgment. Though he wasn't successful in getting his neighbors on board, he ensured his own family was saved. At the end of his ministry, having his family on the ark was enough.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates that prioritizing and saving one's own family through faith is sufficient and impactful.

illustrations.title: Jesus's Brothers' Unbelief
illustrations.text: Jesus's brothers grew up with him, the perfect sinless Son of God, yet they did not believe in him. They couldn't accuse him of hypocrisy, but still rejected his message. His brother James only believed after Jesus died and rose again, showing that sometimes faith comes after significant events. This illustrates that even those closest to us might not believe until later, and God remains faithful beyond our efforts.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that witnessing to family is difficult, as even Jesus's brothers didn't believe until after his resurrection, encouraging patience in evangelism.

illustrations.title: Laban's Introduction and Greed
illustrations.text: Rebecca had a brother named Laban, who ran outside to the man at the spring when he saw the ring and bracelets on his sister's wrists. Laban heard Rebekah's words about what the man said and went to meet him as he stood with the camels. Laban is described as a worldly man from Abraham's family who believed in Yahweh, showing how material attractions like jewelry drew him in. This sets the stage for later stories involving Laban and Jacob.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to highlight how material things can draw people in, illustrating spiritual attraction and the character of worldly individuals in biblical narratives.

illustrations.title: Laban as Nominal Christians
illustrations.text: They're kind of like nominal Christians that they have a belief and they have the right vocabulary but they're not really pictured as the bride here; there are people who don't really have that personal relationship with God so Laban can use all the right words but what he's attracted to are the gifts.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that some people, like Laban, may have the correct beliefs and words but lack a genuine spiritual relationship.

illustrations.title: Unbeliever in Church Service
illustrations.text: If the whole church assembles and all speak in tongues, an ungifted man or unbeliever enters, he'll say you're nuts, but if all prophesied, that means if all speak the Word of God led by the Holy Spirit, and an unbeliever enters, he'll be convicted by all, he's called to account by all, the secrets of his heart are disclosed, he'll fall on his face and worship God, declaring that God is certainly among you.
illustrations.context: This retelling shows that genuine operation of the Holy Spirit's gifts can convict and attract unbelievers, making God's presence evident.

illustrations.title: Camels as Semis
illustrations.text: Remember, the camels are kind of like semis; they're the ones carrying all the wealth and stuff in there.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize the role of the camels in the story as carriers of valuable items, symbolizing importance in the narrative.

illustrations.title: Simon the Sorcerer's Motives
illustrations.text: In the New Testament, we're introduced to a man named Simon, often referred to as Simon the sorcerer. He saw the power of the Holy Spirit when the Apostles laid hands on people, and it changed lives. Simon wanted that power for himself, thinking he could buy it with money to gain authority and prestige. Peter rebuked him, saying his heart wasn't right and to keep his money because his motives were self-serving.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate how self-serving motives, like Simon's desire for power, corrupt genuine ministry.

illustrations.title: Servant's Refusal to Eat
illustrations.text: The servant, after a long journey, had food set before him but refused to eat until he told his business. Laban urged him to speak, and he proceeded. This moment highlights the servant's dedication to his mission over personal needs. It contrasts with self-serving characters like Laban.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that doing God's will is singularly satisfying and prioritizes duty over personal comfort.

illustrations.title: Jesus at the Well
illustrations.text: Remember the occasion when Jesus is at the well in John chapter 4. The disciples returned from town and urged him to eat, but Jesus said he had food they didn't know about. They misunderstood, thinking of physical bread, but Jesus explained that his food is to do the will of God who sent him and to accomplish his work. This shows Jesus prioritizing spiritual fulfillment over physical needs while ministering to the woman.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to contrast self-serving motives by illustrating that doing God's will is more satisfying than material things.

illustrations.title: Jesus' Ministry Passion
illustrations.text: Do you know the Bible says that at times Jesus was so busy ministering he didn't have time to eat? That's when his family came to try to take him away because they said he was out of his mind. Even though he was passionate for a lost world, he prioritized God's work over his own needs, showing that true fulfillment comes from obeying God.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how being filled with the Holy Spirit leads to prioritizing God's mission over personal needs.

illustrations.title: Abraham's Servant Testimony
illustrations.text: In verse 34, the servant says, 'I am Abraham's servant. The Lord has greatly blessed my master so that he has become rich with flocks, herds, silver, gold, servants, maids, camels, and donkeys. Sarah, my master's wife, bore a son to my master in her old age, and he has given him all that he has.' This servant bears witness to the wealth of the Father and the Son, mentioning the Lord five times, the father six times, and the son five times in just 12 verses. It's like the Holy Spirit, who doesn't speak of himself but reveals the truth about God.
illustrations.context: This shows that the Holy Spirit reveals the wealth and truth of the Father and Son, just as the servant testified about Abraham's blessings.

illustrations.title: Preacher Feedback Story
illustrations.text: It's like that guy who went to hear those two famous preachers, and when someone asked what he thought, he said it was quite something. He mentioned that the first preacher talked a lot about himself, but the story cuts off here, implying a contrast in focus. This anecdote highlights the importance of preachers focusing on Christ rather than themselves. Pastor Bob uses it to emphasize staying centered on Jesus.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the need to preach Jesus Christ exclusively and not oneself or other agendas.

illustrations.title: Rich Father's Auction Story
illustrations.text: Remember the story of the rich father with one son and that big art auction after the father died. There was a poor servant who had grown up in the house with the son and loved him, so he bid on the portrait of the son that nobody else wanted. He didn't have much money, but he was the only bidder and got it. As soon as he took the portrait, the auctioneer announced that the auction was closed because the father's will stated that whoever takes the son gets everything else the father had. You take the son, and you get everything the father has.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that accepting Jesus, the Son, means receiving all that God the Father offers.

illustrations.title: Cop's Court Testimony
illustrations.text: I've been in court a lot as a cop and never once said, 'I'm kind of shy, can I just act it out?' You have to open your mouth and share firsthand experience. No hearsay is allowed; we need the best evidence, like the actual original, not a copy or what someone else said. This illustrates that being a witness means speaking from what you've seen and heard.
illustrations.context: This example shows that being a witness requires firsthand experience and verbal testimony, just as in a court of law.

illustrations.title: Apostles' Mount Experience
illustrations.text: Peter talked about the Mount of Transfiguration, saying we did not follow cleverly devised tales when we made known to you the power and coming of our Lord Jesus Christ. We were eyewitnesses of his majesty; we were on the mountain, we heard God speak, and we were there. This personal account emphasizes that their testimony came from direct experience, not secondhand stories.
illustrations.context: This retelling highlights that true witnessing comes from personal, firsthand encounters with Jesus.

illustrations.title: Early Christians' Defiance
illustrations.text: When the early Christians were forbidden to preach and talk about Jesus, they said, 'We can't help but speak about the things we have seen and heard.' This statement reflects their compulsion to share their experiences despite opposition. It's hard to argue with someone's personal experience, as it forms the core of authentic testimony.
illustrations.context: This reference illustrates that genuine witnessing arises from personal encounters that cannot be silenced.

illustrations.title: Servant's Testimony at the Well
illustrations.text: The servant is rehearsing what happened at the well. He prayed and asked God for guidance, setting out a sign like a fleece: let the one who offers not only a drink but also to water the camels be the right one. That's incredible—who would do that? But that's exactly what she did, and it was that fulfillment that made it clear to him and everyone else that she was the one for Isaac.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that sharing personal experiences with God serves as a powerful testimony to convince others of faith.

illustrations.title: Gamaliel's Warning in Acts
illustrations.text: Remember when Gamaliel in the Book of Acts warned the Sanhedrin, who were unsure what to do with Peter and John after the miracle where a lame man was healed. The people were excited about this miracle, so the Sanhedrin hesitated on their next steps. Gamaliel, a member of the Sanhedrin, advised them wisely.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate how people recognize and accept God's work, making it hard to argue against divine intervention.

illustrations.title: Krispy Kreme Fad Example
illustrations.text: He says take heed what you do to these men because if what they represent is of man, it won't last. Don't worry about John and Peter; it'll peter out. There are plenty of examples of uprisings where people get excited, but fads come and go, like Krispy Kreme which was once popular but things change and it fades away.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that human-led movements or fads do not endure if they are not from God.

illustrations.title: Sanhedrin Warning Retelling
illustrations.text: A respected member of the Sanhedrin says to the other members, take heed what you do to these men, be very careful. For if what they are representing is of man, it won't last, so don't worry about John and Peter; it'll peter out. There are plenty of examples of uprisings that fade, but if this is of God, you might be found fighting against God, which you don't want to do.
illustrations.context: This retelling emphasizes the need to discern whether something is from God or man to avoid opposing divine will.

illustrations.title: Revelation Quote Explanation
illustrations.text: Jot down Revelation 22 and verse 17: The Spirit and the Bride say, 'Come,' and let the one who hears say, 'Come,' let the one who is thirsty come, let the one who wishes take the water of life without cost. The Holy Spirit and the Bride of Christ say the same thing, issuing an invitation to the lost world. This shows that the Spirit-filled bride bears witness and invites others to come drink of the water of life for free.
illustrations.context: This quote highlights how the Holy Spirit and the church together invite people to receive eternal life, emphasizing the compelling witness of faith.

illustrations.title: Abraham's Servant Analogy
illustrations.text: It's kind of like the servant is saying God has made a decision about who is going to marry Isaac, a decision which you cannot argue with. In this story, Laban and Bethuel have no argument to offer and must comply. So, the servant, like the Holy Spirit, gives a compelling witness that leads to acceptance of God's plan.
illustrations.context: This analogy shows that God's decisions are final and unarguable, urging listeners to align with divine choices.

illustrations.title: Kingdom of God as Tree
illustrations.text: Jesus said that the kingdom of God is like a small plant that grows into a big tree, where the birds of the air can nest and find shade. They're not even part of the tree, but they receive blessings from it. This illustrates how God's work extends to others around it.
illustrations.context: God uses believers to bring blessings to non-believers nearby.

illustrations.title: Judas as Warning Example
illustrations.text: Think of Judas, who followed Jesus and the disciples, experiencing all the blessings like having his feet washed, seeing miracles, and hearing teachings. He was very close to Jesus but ultimately not a true follower, serving as a warning that it's possible to be tight with God's people and think you're saved without actually being so. This shows the danger of false assurance.
illustrations.context: One can be near faith and blessings without true salvation.

illustrations.title: Parent's Worry for Unsaved Son
illustrations.text: Somebody came up to me on Sunday and said they have an adult son who is unsaved and not walking with the Lord. They asked what if he never does and if they have no influence on him at all. This is not uncommon, and I have strong convictions about it.
illustrations.context: Believers may feel powerless but God can still work through them.

illustrations.title: Servant's Plea to Not Delay
illustrations.text: When they arose in the morning after agreeing to the engagement, the servant said, 'Send me away to my master.' Her brother and mother replied, 'Let the girl stay with us for a few days.' It's an idiom; when they say days, it might mean a period of time, like ten days or even months. Then, after that time, she could go. But the servant urged, 'Do not delay me, since the Lord is prospering my way, send me away so I may go to my master.'
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate the contrast between the servant's immediate obedience and the world's tendency to delay.

illustrations.title: Delayed Response to Faith
illustrations.text: I remember sharing some years ago after a Love Song concert in the tent, which tells you how long ago it was; I'd taken them down to Calvary Chapel of Costa Mesa, and they were moved to tears by all the people that got saved that night. When I talked to them afterwards, they said, 'I know Jesus is the Lord, I don't have any question about that, but I can't really follow him right now because my boyfriend's not a Christian and he wouldn't go for that, so I can't right now, but I will.' A few years later, when I witnessed to the same relative, she said, 'I know the Lord is true, I have no doubt about it, but my husband doesn't believe and I can't when he's like that—he drinks and does stuff, so there's no way that would work, but I do believe and someday I'm going to give my life to the Lord.' A few years after that, when I witnessed to her again, she said she doesn't believe at all and to this day she's a total agnostic who mocks Christians and mocks me.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the urgency of immediately responding to God's call, as delaying can lead to a hardened heart and eventual rejection of faith.

illustrations.title: Pharaoh's Delay with Plagues
illustrations.text: What was it that Pharaoh said when Moses asked when he wanted the plague removed? He said tomorrow, meaning one more day with those pests. Seriously, it's like Pharaoh is choosing to wait, putting off the relief God offered.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that delaying a response to God's call makes it harder to accept later.

illustrations.title: World's Warning to Believers
illustrations.text: When the world sees someone come to the Lord, they might agree there's a God, but they say don't get so radical, don't go overboard with this faith thing. You don't have to go to church every Sunday or Wednesday night; Christmas and Easter are enough, so just relax and stay with us. This is like telling the bride not to fully commit.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is showing how the world discourages full commitment to faith, urging people to keep things moderate.

illustrations.title: Rebekah's Journey of Faith
illustrations.text: So Rebekah says, I'm ready to go now, right now, not tomorrow, about 10 days later. She didn't really know exactly where she was going; she'd never been to Canaan, five hundred miles away. Can you imagine that long journey of faith to meet someone she'd never met but whom God had chosen for her?
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is emphasizing that while God makes His choice, individuals must personally decide to follow, as Rebekah did.

illustrations.title: Camel Ride Analogy
illustrations.text: Have you ever ridden a camel? I'm not talking about the short ride on the Mount of Olives; that's just a photo op. Most of us haven't, but if you have for any distance, you know it's a very rough ride. They are called the ships of the desert because they have that same swaying motion that can make you seasick, and you can't wait to reach your destination.
illustrations.context: To illustrate the challenging and anticipatory nature of Rebekah's journey to meet Isaac, emphasizing the discomfort and eagerness involved.

illustrations.title: Rebekah's Journey Retelling
illustrations.text: I was thinking about this; I'm sure every night she got off that camel, sat at the campfire, and probably said to the servant, 'Tell me some more about the Son that I'm going to meet soon, tell me about his miraculous birth, about that time on the mountain when his father was going to offer him up, and about the angel and how God worked.' And the servant might have said, 'I can tell you more, but I've already told you that story last night.' This imagines the servant sharing stories of God's faithfulness during the long trip.
illustrations.context: To highlight how stories of God's promises and miracles would have sustained Rebekah during her journey, connecting to themes of divine sovereignty and human responsibility.

illustrations.title: Holy Spirit to Wedding
illustrations.text: She is spirit-led; she's going to be carried away by the Spirit to a wedding. She's on a heading for a wedding, and so are you and I. That's exactly what the Holy Spirit is going to do: take us to heaven. There, we'll meet our Savior face to face, and it will be wedding day, going to the chapel and getting married.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that the Holy Spirit will lead believers to heaven, similar to being taken to a wedding.

illustrations.title: Young Christian Learning Experience
illustrations.text: One of the things that I learned as a young Christian was that the Lord loved me and I knew He would teach me through His word. It was good to have a Christian friend or two. But the Lord wants to do a lot of His work through the body of Christ. He purposes to use His people, and some of those people that He wants to use in your life you might not know yet.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to emphasize that God works through the body of Christ, encouraging participation in community groups for spiritual growth and support.

illustrations.title: Kids' Access to Parents' Bed
illustrations.text: My kids have a different version of that song; it's about being in my father's bed, there's a place for me. They prefer our bed because they have unfettered access to me and my wife. They don't knock politely; they barge in at 2 a.m., and I'm left wondering if it's an emergency or just them taking over the space. The other night, I heard screaming from my toddler's room, ran in expecting something terrible, and found him sitting up looking at his blankets. I pulled them back, he laid down, and I realized he just needed help. Then my son came in, woke me up saying 'Wake up, where's Dad?' and I told him, 'Dude, I'm Dad, just sleep.' This shows how they always have access to us.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to illustrate that believers have direct access to God the Father through Christ, just as his kids have to him.

illustrations.title: Bold Access to God
illustrations.text: We have a father that went to great lengths to reach us, that gave up his son to die on a cross to pay for our sins and reconcile us to him, so that you can have unfettered access and can barge into his room. Let us come boldly before the throne of grace and we'll find the mercy that we need when we need it the most. Whatever it is that you've carried in here that maybe is binding you from really experiencing what it's like to be a part of God's family, cast it off because whom the Son sets free is free indeed.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that believers can have direct and confident access to God as a loving Father, encouraging them to let go of barriers.

illustrations.title: Declaring Child of God
illustrations.text: We're going to sing another song: I'm no longer a slave to sin, I'm a Child of God. Sometimes it's just good to declare who we are and whose we are. He is who he claims to be because of that empty tomb, and then he says now you are who I claim you to be—you are my kids.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote from the song to illustrate the importance of affirming one's identity as a child of God, based on Jesus' resurrection.

illustrations.title: New Parent's Prayer Insight
illustrations.text: If you didn't know, my son turned one this week and he is now one year old. As a new parent, I've learned the importance of prayer. My wife and I are praying hard for him. I encourage you, if you're a mom, to join this ministry to pray and invest in our children not just with actions but before the Lord.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses his personal experience as a new parent to encourage moms to participate in the Moms in Prayer ministry.

illustrations.title: Growing Up in Jesus Movement
illustrations.text: Pastor Bob shares that he's excited about the movie The Jesus Revolution because he grew up during the Jesus movement days it depicts. He mentions that Pastor Greg Laurie held a pre-screening for pastors and staff, and he got to see it early. This personal experience makes the film meaningful to him and ties into his enthusiasm for sharing it with others.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is using this personal story to encourage people to watch the movie and connect with its themes of revival and outreach.

illustrations.title: 1970s Revival and Jesus Movement
illustrations.text: Some of you in this room lived through those days, and it's uniquely exciting. For those who didn't, it's worth seeing and thanking God for what He's done, realizing the blessings He brought through the Holy Spirit's work in the 1970s revival. This led to Calvary Chapels all over the world still honoring the philosophy of ministry that God used to raise up Pastor Chuck. The movie focuses on Pastor Chuck's ministry before the Jesus movement began, as well as the story of Lonnie Frisbee, whom God used, and Greg and Kathy.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating how God worked through the 1970s revival to bring spiritual blessings and expand the church.

illustrations.title: Conversation on Church Compromise
illustrations.text: I was just with some people last night, and we were talking about how Christians and churches today often accept all kinds of compromise because they reflect the world rather than the Lord. God's standards haven't changed at all, but our world continues to get darker and darker before Christ's return.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how modern Christians are compromising with worldly values, emphasizing the increasing darkness before Christ's return as warned in the scriptures.

illustrations.title: Parable of Delayed Return
illustrations.text: Jesus told the parable of the person who said, 'I believe my master's coming, just not anytime soon.' As a result of thinking the master was delayed, he fell into a worldly lifestyle, getting drunk and beating up his brothers and sisters. This teaches us the importance of realizing that Christ's coming should change how we live, keeping us aware and expectant.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the danger of laziness and ungodly living when one doesn't truly expect Christ's imminent return.

illustrations.title: Planning to Welcoming Shift
illustrations.text: I like what one pastor said: he used to be so focused on prophecy that that's all he would teach on. Then he started teaching on other parts of the Bible, and a friend asked why the change. He replied, 'I realized I should probably move off the planning committee and onto the welcoming committee,' meaning it's not up to us to plan exactly when Christ comes, but to be ready for it when He does.
illustrations.context: This quote emphasizes the need to balance focus on prophecy with overall biblical teaching to ensure readiness for Christ's coming.

illustrations.title: Two Time Zones Analogy
illustrations.text: When I go to Israel, my Apple Watch shows two times so I know what time it is there and back home. I have to live in two time zones to avoid mistakes like calling my son at the wrong hour. This illustrates how every Christian should be aware of living in two dimensions: the present world and the coming presence of God.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that Christians must live aware of both their earthly life and their heavenly citizenship.

illustrations.title: France Travel Story
illustrations.text: I went to France with Becky some years ago and visited the Loire Valley, which was beautiful. I noticed there were no police officers after leaving Paris, so I drove fast like on the Autobahn. When I got home, I received two speeding tickets in the mail because they monitor speeds electronically.
illustrations.context: This personal story emphasizes that just as Pastor Bob prefers the familiarity of home over foreign places, Christians should recognize heaven as their true home.

illustrations.title: Rabbi's Simple Life
illustrations.text: True story: This was Rabbi Heim Herzog's life, a prominent Hebrew scholar and chief Rabbi who lived in the old section of Jerusalem. He resided in a very small, Spartan apartment with only a chair, desk, and bed. When a woman from New York visited and asked about his lack of furniture, he replied by asking where hers was, and she said she didn't bring it because she was just traveling.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that believers are merely travelers on earth, with their true citizenship in heaven.

illustrations.title: Flooded Towns Example
illustrations.text: There are many towns in the United States that don't exist anymore because they were completely underwater due to the building of dams and water works in the 20th century. When a town was going to be relocated, people stopped painting their homes, mowing their lawns, and putting all their money and time into their houses because they knew it was about to be destroyed. This changed the way they lived day to day because they saw what was coming.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the need to live with the end in sight, as the world is passing away.

illustrations.title: Special China Analogy
illustrations.text: The word holy means to be set apart, like the utensils in the temple that were only used for God's glory and not for everyday purposes. If you have special China in a cabinet, you only bring it out for occasions like Thanksgiving or maybe never, reserving it for that specific purpose. This idea shows how we should be set apart for God.
illustrations.context: This explains what it means to live a holy life, being reserved for God's service.

illustrations.title: Signing Letters His Truly
illustrations.text: You see, a long time ago I stopped signing my letters and emails as 'yours truly.' Instead, I sign them as 'his truly.' That needs to be the way you think, because that's who you are—you have been set apart for the Lord. This habit reflects that my primary allegiance is to God, not to my earthly roles.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that Christians should prioritize their allegiance to God above all else.

illustrations.title: Heaven as Coming Attraction
illustrations.text: Heaven is the ultimate Coming Attraction. Earlier in First Peter, it says to fix your hope completely on the grace to be revealed at the revelation of Jesus Christ. This analogy shows that we should place our hopes on eternal promises rather than temporary things, avoiding disappointment in life.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is emphasizing that Christians should fix their hope solely on the grace brought by Christ's return to avoid discouragement.

illustrations.title: Hezekiah's Prayer for Life
illustrations.text: God told Hezekiah you're going to die, it's time for you to die, say goodbye. Hezekiah prayed and sought the Lord, and God said okay, I'll give you 15 more years. It's like wow, I'm glad I prayed about it; it wasn't really set in stone that appointment I got.
illustrations.context: Prayer can influence God's timing and decisions, showing that outcomes are not fixed.

illustrations.title: Nineveh's Repentance from Judgment
illustrations.text: He sends Jonah out to tell the city of Nineveh you're 40 days, God's going to destroy you by fire; that was his whole gospel message. They repented when they heard that, and God did not bring the judgment on them. It's not a foregone conclusion that we can say the time and date is set in stone.
illustrations.context: Repentance and prayer can change God's planned judgments, affecting the timing of events.

illustrations.title: Noah's Ark Readiness Analogy
illustrations.text: It's time for the bride to be made ready, just as it was time to raise the family out of judgment on the ark when everybody was in their seats and on board. This illustrates the preparation needed before God's actions. When everyone is prepared, then it's time for God to move.
illustrations.context: This analogy emphasizes that spiritual preparation, like the ark's readiness, is essential before God's judgment and return.

illustrations.title: Peace of God Through Prayer
illustrations.text: In Philippians 4:6-8, it says be anxious for nothing, but in everything by prayer and supplication with thanksgiving, let your requests be made known to God. Then the peace of God will guard your hearts and minds in Christ Jesus. This peace comes from surrendering your life to the Lord and trusting Him to handle your worries.
illustrations.context: This quote illustrates how believers can experience God's peace through prayer and surrender, beyond just initial salvation peace.

illustrations.title: Humorous Wedding Statue Joke
illustrations.text: I was at a wedding with my wife some years ago at a beautiful traditional church in Orange. They had organ pipes up front and a full-size statue of Jesus front and center with his hands raised, likely depicting the scene from Luke where he blessed his disciples as he ascended to heaven. I liked it but couldn't stop staring and made a regrettable joke to Becky, saying it looked like Jesus was playing volleyball. She started giggling, even though it was supposed to be a serious and reverential time. As a pastor, I now repent for that comment, as it might have been irreverent.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to illustrate the concept of being ready for the spiritual wedding by contrasting a light-hearted real-life wedding experience with the seriousness of faith.

illustrations.title: Jewish Wedding Analogy
illustrations.text: A Jewish man would live with his mom and dad in his father's house until the time of the wedding. When it was time to get married, he would leave his father's house, go get his bride, and prepare a place for her by building a house attached to his father's house. He would then take her back to his father's house. This is the picture of what Christ will do in the Rapture, coming to take us to his Father's house where we'll be while the Great Tribulation occurs.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to illustrate how Christ's return in the Rapture mirrors a Jewish wedding, emphasizing preparation and the journey to the Father's house.

illustrations.title: 1970s Prophecy Experience
illustrations.text: I remember when Pastor Chuck shared about the Gog and Magog invasion in Ezekiel. We were studying these things back in the 70s, and I had never heard of them before then. It felt like all these prophecies were being fulfilled as Russia threatened to invade Israel, and the President of the United States put all our Armed Forces on high alert. This event highlighted the tension and expectation of end-times prophecies.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob shares this personal story to emphasize God's patience in delaying Christ's return for the sake of salvation, even amidst exciting prophetic fulfillments.

illustrations.title: Excitement for Rapture Delay
illustrations.text: I remember thinking this could happen at any time. We were so excited that we planned to get a lawn chair and sit on the roof to make it easier. You get super excited in moments like that because the Lord could come at any time, but then when he doesn't that day, week, or year, you might start to feel like you're getting excited about nothing.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to illustrate how excitement about Christ's return can turn to discouragement if it doesn't happen immediately, emphasizing to see the delay as an opportunity for spiritual growth.

illustrations.title: Hidden Things Belong to God
illustrations.text: The Bible says the hidden things belong to God. When you ask what those are, I don't know because they're hidden. That's from Deuteronomy 29:29. There are some things we don't know, but we should focus on the things that have been revealed to us in the Bible so we can obey Him. It's amazing how many Christians focus on the unknown instead of what God has clearly shown us.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize focusing on revealed truths rather than hidden ones to better understand and obey God.

illustrations.title: God's Kindness and Patience
illustrations.text: Paul talked about God's patience in Romans 2:4, saying, 'Do you think lightly of the riches of God's kindness and forbearance and patience, not knowing that it's the kindness of God that leads you to repentance?' This verse reminds us that God's patience is meant to draw us to change our ways. It's not something to take for granted, as it's tied to His kindness encouraging repentance.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to illustrate that God's patience is connected to repentance and is a review of Paul's teachings on living faithfully.

illustrations.title: Vulnerable to False Teaching
illustrations.text: As a young Christian, I didn't know my Bible well, even though I went to church every Sunday and carried a Bible, which made me very vulnerable. I watched a TV show about God and the Bible, hosted by a very intelligent and good-looking guy who talked about scriptures and prophecies, and I was amazed by it. They offered a free magazine, so I subscribed because I thought it was great for a Christian like me. When my youth pastor visited and saw the magazine on the coffee table, he pointed out that it was from a cult, and I was shocked because they didn't reveal that on TV. This experience shows how easy it is for Christians to get sucked into false teachings without realizing it.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how a lack of biblical knowledge makes one vulnerable to false teaching and the importance of discernment.

illustrations.title: Bereans' Scriptural Examination
illustrations.text: Paul the Apostle preached in many places, including Berea and Thessalonica, where people got saved in both. However, Luke noted that the Bereans were more noble-minded than those in Thessalonica because they received Paul's message with great eagerness but examined the Scriptures daily to verify it. As a result, they were commended for their diligence. Paul didn't criticize them for questioning; instead, he approved of their careful approach, saying it was good that they weren't just trusting his words blindly.
illustrations.context: To emphasize that knowing God's Word well protects believers from error and false teachers.

illustrations.title: Jesus' Temptation Example
illustrations.text: We see Jesus as our example when, after he was baptized, he was driven by the Holy Spirit into the wilderness. There, he fasted for 40 days, and then Satan came to tempt him. The temptations paralleled those that Adam and Eve faced, as described in 1 John 2:15—the lust of the flesh, the lust of the eyes, and the pride of life. The Bible says Jesus was tempted in all points as we are, yet without sin. These are the three areas of vulnerability, and the first one involved bread because Jesus was starving. Satan questioned Jesus by saying, 'If you are the Son of God, turn these stones into bread.' This illustrates how Satan attacks after God makes a statement about us.
illustrations.context: Knowing the Bible helps detect lies and resist temptation, just as Jesus did.

illustrations.title: Barney Fife's One Bullet
illustrations.text: You guys remember Barney Fife, the deputy sheriff under Andy Griffith in Mayberry. I watched an episode where Barney was teaching Opie gun safety, and everything he said was right until he accidentally shot a hole in the porch in front of everyone. Andy made him hand over his gun, and eventually, Barney wasn't even allowed to carry a loaded one—he just had one bullet in his pocket for emergencies. I think sometimes Christians are like that, running around with only a verse or two memorized, like 'Jesus wept,' which isn't enough ammo for every situation.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is emphasizing that Christians need to memorize more scripture to be prepared for temptations and challenges, rather than relying on just a few verses.

illustrations.title: Demons' Unsaving Knowledge
illustrations.text: Remember, the demons in the Book of James know a lot about God. They know there's a God and they've stood in His presence, even before they were cast out of Heaven. Of course, they know there's a God, but that doesn't save anybody. Knowing there's a God, knowing Jesus is God, or knowing Jesus rose from the dead—believing those things are true—saves nobody. We're talking about a relationship that's transformative.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that intellectual knowledge of God does not lead to salvation, emphasizing the need for a personal relationship.

illustrations.title: Jesus Rejected by His Own
illustrations.text: Remember what John writes in John 1: Jesus Christ the Messiah came to his own, the Jews, but his own received him not—they rejected him. However, to as many as accepted and received him, he gave the authority to be called children of God, even to those who believe on his name—not just believe he exists, but put their weight down on him. They were born not of the will of man or of the flesh, but of God. This describes any true Christian who has received Christ.
illustrations.context: This shows that true salvation comes from personally receiving and believing in Jesus, not just knowing about him.

illustrations.title: Nicodemus and New Birth
illustrations.text: Remember Nicodemus, he was a guy who believed in God, taught people about God, believed the Bible, and even thought Jesus might be the Messiah. We know that you're a teacher come from God; no man can do the things you're doing except God is with him. Nicodemus said that, but Jesus told him, 'Unless you're born again, you'll never enter the Kingdom of Heaven.' Don't deceive yourself about your own status.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize that even a devout believer like Nicodemus must be born again to enter the Kingdom of Heaven.

illustrations.title: Siblings Misbehaving at Home
illustrations.text: You know, I'm the youngest of five children, and when we were young, every once in a while when my mom and dad would go on an errand together, like to the store, we'd think, 'Mom and Dad are gone, what am I going to do? Let's do something we're not allowed to do.' I remember once we started something mischievous, like a pillow fight or whatever it was.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate human temptation and the need to grow in grace when left without guidance.

illustrations.title: Childhood Pillow Fight Mishap
illustrations.text: I was in a fun pillow fight with my siblings, but it turned bad when I swung at my sister Carol and she ducked, causing me to hit and shatter one of my parents' lamps into pieces. Everyone blamed me and I felt alone and terrified, so I ran out of the house and sat on the curb, waiting for my parents and crying over what I'd done. When my dad arrived, he comforted me with a hug and said we could replace the lamp but not me, showing that mercy means not getting what I deserved.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to illustrate that mercy is not receiving the punishment one deserves, as demonstrated by his father's forgiveness.

illustrations.title: Hide and Seek Analogy
illustrations.text: You played the game as a kid or even now. There's that point where whoever's 'it' says, 'Ready or not, here I come!' and counts to 100 super fast, but time flies by faster than you think. When you go looking, you're supposed to cry out, 'Olly olly oxen free,' meaning it's time to come back. Maybe you're here and you've been putting off your return to the Lord, and He's saying it's time—what are you waiting for?
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize the urgency of returning to the Lord without delay, as time cannot be reclaimed.

illustrations.title: Summer Nights Revival Event
illustrations.text: Last Sunday night, we had an incredible time at our second to last Summer Nights event with hundreds of people coming out to skateboard, which is my passion. I fell several times but didn't get hurt, so He brings broken things back to life apparently. We had axe throwing and great fellowship, but what excited me most was seeing so many people come out to hear the gospel. Up until this point, we've seen about 20 people make professions of faith in Jesus Christ, and on that night, 22 people raised their hands because I was counting and saw them going up—it was amazing. Whether it was a recommitment or first-time faith, I saw many folks I'd never met before, and God is clearly doing a work.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating how God is actively reviving hearts through community events and personal encounters.

illustrations.title: Angel's Paternity Leave Story
illustrations.text: Angel, who usually works in the control room, is not here tonight because he's on paternity leave. His wife had their baby today, named Aaron James, who weighs eight pounds one ounce, and they're both doing well. We're excited about this new addition and ask for your prayers as he spends time with his family.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is highlighting the joy of new life and encouraging community support through prayer.

illustrations.title: Mary's Kitchen Ministry Example
illustrations.text: We are involved with Mary's Kitchen in Orange, a long-time ministry that feeds the homeless using donations like our leftover food from services. There's a new effort by the city council or community to close it down because some are tired of seeing homeless people, which concerns us as it would leave many without help. Gary Wyman and his wife Nancy lead a related ministry, and we're asking you to sign a petition to present to the city council to prevent closure without another solution for those in need.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating the importance of advocating for and supporting ministries that help the homeless.

illustrations.title: Vision of God's Powerful Wave
illustrations.text: Many years ago, before we were in this building, I had a vision while driving to our old church on Orange Street in Anaheim. I was worshiping the Lord and looked to the east, seeing a massive wave in my mind's eye, two or three times the height of the mountains. It was enormous and coming in, but I felt no fear as God spoke to my heart, saying this wave represented His power to flood and revive every part of the community, healing the broken, restoring the dead, and mending marriages. He assured me that He has both the power and the will to do it, encouraging me to share this with the congregation.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal vision to illustrate that God has the power and desire to bring revival to the community.

illustrations.title: Vision of the Well
illustrations.text: A few weeks ago, I had a different kind of vision during worship. I saw a well and walked over to it, seeing my reflection in the water. I dropped a pebble in, and instead of an image emerging, the water rose up, clear and refreshing. God spoke to my heart, saying this is what He wants to do—a work in our community and hearts like we've never seen. It's both a well and a wave of His power.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal vision to illustrate that God wants to bring a powerful, refreshing work in their community and personal lives.

illustrations.title: Jesus on Living Water
illustrations.text: Jesus said, 'If anyone is thirsty, let him come to me and drink, and out of his innermost being shall flow rivers of living water.' This He spoke of the Spirit, as the Bible explains. God wants to do a work in us, our church, and community that we've only dreamed of, reminding us of His resources. It's an encouragement to believe He can exceed our expectations.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that God desires to pour out His Spirit, bringing renewal and more than what people are currently praying for.

illustrations.title: 1970s Revival Experience
illustrations.text: I lived through a revival in the 1970s in southern California, an incredible work of the Holy Spirit, as some of you did too. It was a time of powerful spiritual movement that I witnessed firsthand. God is speaking to my heart that He can do even more in our community today than what happened back then. This encourages us to believe for greater things in our own lives and church.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob references this historical event to inspire belief that God can perform a greater work now than in the past, despite current challenges.

illustrations.title: Psalm on Joy in Presence
illustrations.text: The Bible says in His presence there's fullness of joy at His right hand there are pleasures forever more. So I want to learn how to get into and stay in the presence of God. It's my greatest delight to be in His presence; I enjoyed Him tonight with you already and I want Him to teach me more.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize the joy and pleasures found in God's presence, encouraging listeners to learn how to stay close to God.

illustrations.title: Conference Speaker's Voice Story
illustrations.text: I'll never forget, I was at a pastor's conference many years ago, and we had come back from lunch. The guys were talking, and the speaker started, but everyone got quiet because his voice sounded so familiar. It turned out to be John Corson's son, who sounded just like his dad, and he even said, 'Yeah, I know, the apple doesn't fall far from the tree.' This illustrated how children often pick up traits from their fathers.
illustrations.context: This shows that character traits are often handed down from father to son, similar to the priest's garments being passed on.

illustrations.title: Jesus' Quote on Spiritual Fathers
illustrations.text: Jesus talked about this principle when he said to the Pharisees, 'You are of your father the devil.' He was highlighting how they followed in the footsteps of their spiritual father, emphasizing the inheritance of traits. Pastor Bob connects this to show that just as physical characteristics are passed down, spiritual ones can be too, though in this case, it's a sobering example.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that people can inherit negative spiritual traits from their influences, reinforcing the idea of 'like father, like son'.

illustrations.title: Grandson Imitating Father
illustrations.text: My grandchildren lived with me for three years, and I had the privilege of having them. My youngest grandson is Jeffrey, and I have a picture of him at one year old wearing my shoes. He could hardly walk and would fall over when he tried, but he wanted to walk in my shoes. It's built into children, especially boys, to imitate their fathers. He even imitates me by saying 'all right' just like Chuck Smith, even though he has no idea who Chuck Smith is. It's a funny thing he does.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how children naturally imitate their parents, emphasizing the importance of parental example in passing on character and faith.

illustrations.title: Parenting as Farming Analogy
illustrations.text: Somebody described parenting like farming, and it's a good comparison. In farming, you can't guarantee a healthy crop because you can't control the weather. You can, however, do things that ensure you'll never have a healthy crop, so you need to avoid those mistakes. It's the same with parenting; there are actions you can take that will make sure your kids don't turn out right, but you have to trust God with the parts you can't control.
illustrations.context: Parenting requires avoiding mistakes and trusting God for outcomes, just as farming does.

illustrations.title: Jesus' Sermon in John 6
illustrations.text: Jesus gave this sermon in John 6, and it stumbled a lot of people because he appeared to say you have to literally eat his flesh and drink his blood. As many were leaving, Jesus asked his disciples if they would go too. Peter responded that they had nowhere else to go because Jesus has the words of eternal life, even though Peter didn't fully understand. Jesus explained that his words are spirit and life, emphasizing the spiritual truth behind his statements. This shows how Jesus used challenging words to test and focus on his true followers.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this retelling to illustrate that fellowship with the Lord involves internalizing Christ's words, as they bring spiritual life.

illustrations.title: Eating as Spiritual Internalization
illustrations.text: When you eat, you take food in and break it down with your teeth and saliva, then it goes to your stomach and intestines where it's finely digested to nourish every cell in your body. This process allows you to grow, heal, and gain energy, as what you eat literally becomes part of you. Just as food nourishes the body, we must internalize God's word personally and practically so it becomes part of our faith.
illustrations.context: To illustrate how believers must go beyond knowing God's word intellectually and internalize it for spiritual growth.

illustrations.title: Bible as Milk Manna Meat
illustrations.text: It's been said that the Bible is milk for the baby Christian, manna for the daily faith we need, and meat for the mature believer. We are to partake progressively of all of them to grow in our salvation and spiritual maturity. This shows the Word of God provides nourishment at every stage of faith.
illustrations.context: To explain how God's word offers different levels of spiritual nourishment for believers at various stages of growth.

illustrations.title: Ruminating on the Word
illustrations.text: The primary Hebrew word for meditate is 'haga', which means to ruminate, like a cow chewing its cud. This involves pondering and breaking down thoughts deeply, just as a cow thoroughly digests its food. In the same way, we should meditate on God's word to internalize it fully.
illustrations.context: To show that meditating on God's word requires deep, repetitive reflection for true understanding.

illustrations.title: Cow Chewing the Cud Analogy
illustrations.text: When a cow eats grass, it goes down into the rumen, one of its four stomachs. They chew it just enough to swallow it, then store it for later. They bring it back up and spend time relaxing while chewing the cud to get more benefits from it, and this happens repeatedly. It's kind of like ABC gum—already been chewed. The idea illustrates how we should meditate on God's word.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that meditating on God's word involves repeatedly reflecting on it, not just hearing or reading it once.

illustrations.title: Paul's God-Breathed Scripture
illustrations.text: It's all what Paul said he called it theopneustos, it's God-breathed, all scripture is from God. It's prophetic, it's God's word, it came from God. It's unique, it's inspired, it's perfect, and it's all about Jesus Christ. So when we realize that, we understand that every bit of scripture is the testimony of prophecy, meaning it's all from God's mouth and centered on Christ.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that all Scripture is about Jesus and comes directly from God, reinforcing that the entire Bible is prophetic and focused on Christ.

illustrations.title: Mother Bird Feeding Analogy
illustrations.text: You ever seen a mother bird feed a baby bird? You will very rarely see them pick up a full worm and deliver it whole. They regurgitate it; that's how they do it. They eat it, partially digest it, and then give it back to the babies. I hate to say it, but folks, that's the idea.
illustrations.context: To illustrate that we must internalize the Word of God before ministering it to others, just as a mother bird processes food before feeding her young.

illustrations.title: Parrot That Wouldn't Talk
illustrations.text: I heard the story years ago of a woman who went to a pet store and bought a parrot to keep her company since she lived alone. The next day, she returned it because it wouldn't talk, and the pet store suggested adding a mirror, saying parrots love mirrors and might start talking if they see their reflection, so she bought one. When that didn't work, they recommended a ladder, explaining that a happy parrot loves going up and down, so she bought that too. Finally, they suggested a swing to loosen it up, and she reluctantly purchased it, but the next day, the parrot died. The pet store owner was shocked, and she was very sad.
illustrations.context: To show that Christians who rely on superficial spiritual efforts, like occasional church attendance, will remain spiritually weak and unfulfilled, much like the woman's futile attempts to make the parrot talk.

illustrations.title: Deathbed Food Query
illustrations.text: Did he ever say anything? She replied, yes, right before he died, he said, 'Don't they sell any food down at that store?' Yeah, right. I think of how many Christians are struggling spiritually, and God wants to feed you spiritually. You need to take responsibility for learning to be a self-feeder.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate that Christians must take personal responsibility for their spiritual feeding, just as the man realized his physical hunger too late.

illustrations.title: Woman Meets Author on Train
illustrations.text: I remember hearing a true story of a woman who was on a train, traveling across the country as a young lady in her 20s with a friend. She met an attractive young man in another seat, and they struck up a conversation since they were both unmarried; she was impressed with his life stories and experiences. He mentioned he had written a book, which was uncommon back then, and she pretended not to know it since she had tried reading it before and found it terribly boring. When he offered her a copy, she accepted it despite her reservations, and after enjoying their time together and feeling attracted to him, she decided to read it again that night in her sleeper car. To her surprise, now that she had met the author, the book that was once the most boring thing in the world became incredibly exciting, and she couldn't put it down. She read the whole thing within a few hours and couldn't believe the difference.
illustrations.context: This story illustrates how encountering Jesus personally makes the Bible come alive, transforming it from something dull to deeply engaging.

illustrations.title: Passover Lamb Fully Eaten
illustrations.text: Remember in the Passover, as we studied in the book of Exodus, the Passover lamb had to be completely eaten. That's a picture of needing to receive all that Christ has done for you. That's God's intention, showing we can't leave spiritual leftovers.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that salvation requires fully accepting Christ's sacrifice without partiality.

illustrations.title: Manna Must Be Gathered Fresh
illustrations.text: For that matter, the manna we've already studied, when God provided the manna, He said go out and gather what you need. If you tried to sleep in, it would melt in the sun and be gone. Or if you tried to store it, maggots would appear, because it wasn't meant to be left over.
illustrations.context: This shows that spiritual truths must be applied daily and not hoarded without practical use.

illustrations.title: Chief's Good Day to Die
illustrations.text: There's an old movie, I think it's a Dustin Hoffman movie, where he gets captured by Indians and is raised with them. I remember the scene with the chief, who's getting old, and he stands up and says, 'This is a good day to die.' He lays down thinking he's going to die, but then it rains on his face, and he wakes up realizing it wasn't his time.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the need for daily surrender and readiness, as in taking up the cross every day.

illustrations.title: Corpse and Temptation Analogy
illustrations.text: What's the picture? The person who has died has no struggle with temptation because I've never seen a corpse tempted. I mean, think about it—have you ever seen a corpse lie, gossip, lose its temper, overeat, complain, or gripe? No, a corpse does none of these things. We are called to follow Jesus by dying to ourselves daily, just like a corpse is free from sin.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to illustrate that dying to self means ceasing from sin and living for God's will, as one no longer struggles with temptations.

illustrations.title: Jesus on Altar Swearing
illustrations.text: Jesus spoke about the mistake that the Jews had about swearing by different things. He said, 'You guys say whoever swears by the altar, that's nothing, but whoever swears by the offering on the altar, he's obligated.' You blind men, which is more important, the offering or the altar that makes it holy? Therefore, he who swears by the altar swears both by the altar and by everything on it.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that whatever touches the altar becomes holy, emphasizing Christ's holiness.

illustrations.title: Healing by Touching Cloak
illustrations.text: In Matthew 14:36, they began to entreat Him that they might just touch the hem of His cloak, and as many as touched it were healed or made whole. This shows how whatever touches Christ becomes holy. Pastor Bob connects it to the idea that interacting with Christ brings healing and sanctification.
illustrations.context: To demonstrate that whatever touches Christ becomes holy, linking it to spiritual purity.

illustrations.title: Spurgeon on Daily Prayer
illustrations.text: Spurgeon said, 'Prayer is the key of the day and the lock of the night; it opens the door of blessings in the morning and it secures the door safely every night.' This quote relates to the morning and evening sacrifices, illustrating how prayer frames the day with spiritual protection and provision. Pastor Bob uses it to connect daily routines to seeking God's presence.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob connects this quote to the importance of starting and ending the day with prayer and sacrifice.

illustrations.title: Priests Daily Fire Ritual
illustrations.text: One of the interesting things about the priests is their first job of the day was to remove all the ashes from the previous day and start a new fire for the sacrifice of that day. This pictures getting reconciled with God each morning. It's a historical practice that illustrates the need for daily renewal and fresh mercies.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show the importance of beginning each day reconciled with God, as His mercies are new every morning.

illustrations.title: Shower Cleansing Analogy
illustrations.text: You wash up before you go to work and take a shower. God says to start out by getting washed, clean, and forgiven. This means seeking forgiveness every morning, just like you clean yourself physically to start the day fresh.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating the importance of beginning the day with spiritual cleansing and forgiveness to maintain intimacy with God.

illustrations.title: Sacrifices Retelling
illustrations.text: They would lay their hands on these sacrifices, identifying themselves with it, and then the animal would be killed. At the end of the day, they would finish it and say, 'Lord, thank you for your faithfulness.' This is a beautiful picture of staying in touch with the Lord and keeping short accounts with God.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is using this to show the practice of morning confession and evening thanksgiving for ongoing fellowship with God.

illustrations.title: Marriage Irritation Example
illustrations.text: If you're married, sometimes you irritate your spouse. Keeping short accounts means getting things right with them quickly, just as we should with God. This humorous example highlights the need for prompt reconciliation in relationships.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating the concept of keeping short accounts with God by drawing from everyday marital conflicts.

illustrations.title: Awkward Offense in Relationships
illustrations.text: When we offend each other, there's that awkward time afterward where we wait for someone to say sorry. We all know pride often keeps us from dealing with it, so the distance lingers until someone pretends it never happened or finally says, 'Okay, I'm sorry, please forgive me.' Fact is, we want to get right with each other but we're too prideful to handle it properly.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how pride creates barriers in human relationships, mirroring how it affects our relationship with God.

illustrations.title: God's Eager Forgiveness
illustrations.text: The Lord is way more ready to forgive than some people ever are. When you say you're sorry to God, He just says, 'Forgiven,' without hesitation. Unlike some who might respond with 'You ought to be sorry,' God doesn't hold it against you.
