illustrations.context: This analogy emphasizes that God is quick to restore fellowship after sin, encouraging believers to keep a short account with Him.

illustrations.title: God's Promise in Exodus
illustrations.text: God says that at the doorway of the meeting place, it shall be a continual burnt offering for your generations, and there He will meet with you and speak to you. This is about God's passion for relationship, as He brought the sons of Israel out of Egypt to dwell among them and be their God. The whole place, the altar, and Aaron and his sons will be consecrated by His glory so He can be with His people.
illustrations.context: This retelling shows that consecration and sacrifice enable God's presence and revelation in our lives.

illustrations.title: Israel Trip Example
illustrations.text: Think about me going to Israel for about 10 days while Becky stays home. We haven't seen or talked to each other during that time, and when I come back, she says, 'Hey, can we spend some time together?' I might say, 'I'm pretty busy; why don't we get caught up while I'm doing stuff?' This shows how we sometimes treat our relationship with God, wanting to talk to Him on the go without dedicated time. Just as Becky wants quality time, God desires the same from us.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to illustrate the importance of spending dedicated, quality time with God, beyond just talking to Him throughout the day.

illustrations.title: Samuel's Call Retelling
illustrations.text: Remember, Samuel learned to be a prophet, meaning he learned to hear from God and speak for God as a little boy. He was taught by Eli, the high priest who was backslidden, but Eli at least knew how to hear from God and instructed Samuel. When God called Samuel's name, Samuel thought it was Eli and ran to him, not realizing it was the voice of the Lord. This story shows that even someone inexperienced like Samuel needed guidance to discern God's voice.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob retells this to emphasize that consecration and being right with God are necessary for Him to reveal Himself clearly.

illustrations.title: Bond Servant Dedication
illustrations.text: In the Old Testament, a person became a bond servant out of love for their master. If they were allowed to be set free but refused, the master would take them to the doorpost, use an awl and a hammer to pierce their ear, attaching it to the doorpost. That hole in their ear became a symbol of complete dedication, saying, 'I am bought and paid for, dedicated for life out of love for my master.' The picture is that my ear is now open to listen to the Lord. Essentially, it means from now on, I have an ear only for my master. In Revelation, it says, 'Let him who has an ear hear,' emphasizing it's about readiness to obey rather than just having physical ears.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that true dedication to God, like a bond servant, opens one's ear to hear and obey Him.

illustrations.title: Three Guys Funeral Joke
illustrations.text: There were three guys talking about what they would like said at their funeral. The first guy said he'd like people to say he was a very loving man, a good father, and a good husband. The second guy said he'd like them to say he was really good at his job, that he studied hard, worked hard, and made a difference in the world through his profession. The third guy said he'd like them to say, 'Look, he's moving.'
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to introduce the topic of funerals in a light-hearted way, highlighting how people might reflect on their legacy or add humor to a serious subject.

illustrations.title: Jesus on Tragic Deaths
illustrations.text: Jesus was asked why God allowed some people to be killed through acts like terrorism or accidents, such as when Herod mingled the blood of the Galileans or a tower fell on some people. He responded that these victims weren't worse sinners; that's not why they died. His conclusion was to warn that everyone will perish unless they repent, emphasizing that death is coming and we must be ready for it.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that death can come suddenly and requires repentance to prepare for eternity.

illustrations.title: Birth as Death Transition
illustrations.text: We often equate birth and death, but they are very different. When you're born, you've already been conceived, with your soul and body put together nine months earlier, so it's like relocating from the womb. Death, however, is a transition where your soul leaves your physical body forever to enter a completely different realm, much like moving from the womb to the outside world, and it's the biggest event in your life.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that death is a significant and eternal transition, urging listeners to view it with importance and preparation.

illustrations.title: Grieving Without Hope
illustrations.text: I don't know if you've ever been to a funeral where somebody was grieving and it was clear they had no hope. I have, and they're terrible. It was such a sad place to be, and I just grieve for that wife who had zero hope for herself or her husband, as she felt her life was over.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that Christians should grieve differently from those without hope, as worldly grief lacks eternal perspective.

illustrations.title: Jesus Wept at Lazarus's Funeral
illustrations.text: The shortest verse in the Bible is Jesus wept, which happened at Lazarus's funeral. He didn't weep because Lazarus died, but because he was grieving with those who were grieving. Jesus knew he would raise Lazarus from the dead, so his tears show that weeping is an appropriate response even for those with hope.
illustrations.context: This demonstrates that believers can and should grieve, but with hope, as Jesus did.

illustrations.title: Herod's Forced Mourning
illustrations.text: When Herod was dying, he gave orders that respected rabbis in Jerusalem be killed on the day he died. He wanted mourning across the land so history would associate the grief with his own death. Thankfully, the order was rescinded and never carried out, making it a tragic example of desperation.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate the tragedy of trying to artificially create mourning for one's death, contrasting it with genuine legacy.

illustrations.title: Live to Be Mourned Quote
illustrations.text: It's been said that on the day you were born, you cried while the world rejoiced, so live in such a way that when you die, the world will cry and you'll rejoice. This quote highlights the importance of building a meaningful life. Pastor Bob connects it to the idea of leaving a positive impact.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to encourage living a life that inspires genuine mourning and rejoicing, emphasizing personal legacy.

illustrations.title: Hospital Visit for Friend
illustrations.text: I was just at the hospital a couple days ago because word came that my close friend had died. I spent time with his family and with his body, praying over him and thanking the Lord for his life. It's a way to honor someone even after they've passed, though it's often unfamiliar and emotional.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to show that it's acceptable and meaningful to show affection to a deceased body as a way to honor the person.

illustrations.title: Woman Anoints Jesus
illustrations.text: A woman poured out her ointment on Jesus, and people said it was a waste. Jesus responded that she did it for his funeral and that she understood what was coming. He even said her story would be included in his own story, so everyone who hears about him will hear about her too.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the value of preparing for death and understanding Jesus' sacrifice.

illustrations.title: Egyptian Embalming Practices
illustrations.text: The ancient Egyptians embalmed the bodies of their kings and Pharaohs for the afterlife, believing the soul would return to the body. They would bury the king along with his wives, servants, animals, money, and food to serve him in the next life. This practice was tied to their beliefs about crossing into the afterlife.
illustrations.context: This contrasts with Joseph's practical embalming of Jacob for a journey, highlighting cultural differences in burial customs.

illustrations.title: Boy's Flower Note
illustrations.text: I think of a little boy who gave his kindergarten teacher some flowers and wrote a note saying these flowers will fade and die but you'll smell forever. This story shows a child's innocent way of thinking about preservation and memory. It's a simple example of how people try to make things last beyond their physical end.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the practical reasons for embalming, like preserving the body for travel, in a light-hearted way.

illustrations.title: Egyptian Mummification Ritual
illustrations.text: Here's the process of how mummification took place in ancient Egypt. You insert a hook through a hole near the nose and pull out part of the brain, make a cut on the left side of the body near the tummy, remove all the internal organs, let them dry, and place the lungs, intestines, stomach, and liver inside canopic jars. You place the heart back inside the body, rinse the inside with wine and spices, cover the corpse with Natron or salt for 70 days, and after 40 days, stuff the body with linen or sand to give it a more human shape. Finally, after the 70 days, you wrap the body from head to toe in bandages and place it in a sarcophagus, which is a type of coffin.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate the biblical mourning period for Jacob, showing how historical practices align with themes of grief.

illustrations.title: Jesus Weeping at Funeral
illustrations.text: By the way, that's what Jesus did at Lazarus's funeral; he wept with those who wept. This shows Jesus empathizing with the grieving, even though he knew he would raise Lazarus. It's an example of sharing in others' sorrow as commanded for Christians.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize that weeping with those who weep is a key Christian practice, as demonstrated by Jesus.

illustrations.title: Child's Silent Comfort
illustrations.text: A family lost a child in a terrible accident or disease. Their neighbors had a little girl who used to play with her. One day, this girl came home late from school because she went next door, climbed onto the grieving mother's lap, and simply cried with her without saying a word. This act showed pure empathy. It's a powerful reminder of how to support others in grief.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that the best way to comfort someone grieving is to be present and share their sorrow without needing to say anything.

illustrations.title: Roots of Relationship Analogy
illustrations.text: The longer you know someone in this life, the deeper the roots of that relationship grow into your heart. When they die, it's like tearing up those deep roots, causing immense pain. This process highlights the natural difficulty of loss and the need for mourning. Everyone experiences this in their own way, and it's essential to allow time for healing.
illustrations.context: This analogy emphasizes the depth of emotional pain from losing a loved one and the importance of properly mourning that loss.

illustrations.title: Pastor at Gas Station
illustrations.text: Or, this pastor went into a gas station before a three-day weekend, and there were all these cars lining up for gas. The attendant recognized the pastor and said, 'Sorry, pastor, I don't know why everybody waits to the last second to go on a long trip.' The pastor replied, 'Same way in my business.' This story highlights how people often procrastinate on important preparations, just like with funeral plans.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate how people delay preparations for significant events, drawing a parallel to planning for one's own funeral.

illustrations.title: Fred's Resemblance in Death
illustrations.text: I was talking to Becky when I went to see my friend Fred, who was my age. There is a distinct look that a person has who has died, but what amazed me is how much Fred looked like his father. I knew his father; he was my first boss, and his dad owned a gas station where I had my first job at 13. I was there when his dad died, and Fred looked a lot like his dad when he died. It was just interesting to me, though I'm not saying it means something deeper.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the biblical idea of being gathered to one's fathers and the connection between family in death.

illustrations.title: Barzillai's Desire to Die at Home
illustrations.text: In Second Samuel 19:37, Barzillai was an 80-year-old man who came to welcome King David back to the land after Absalom's rebellion. He met David at the Jordan and David invited him to live in Jerusalem, offering to provide for him and appreciating his support. But Barzillai declined, saying he wanted to return to his home to die in his own city near the grave of his father and mother. This shows his strong desire to be with his family in death.
illustrations.context: This story highlights the importance of family relationships and the comfort of being buried with loved ones, tying into faith and God's promises.

illustrations.title: Friend's Passing Brings Comfort
illustrations.text: When I sat there with my friend, I wished he was alive so I could pray for his healing and comfort him, but he was gone. I knew he was with his wife Carol, who passed a couple years ago, and his parents Fred and Della, who had been waiting for him. I felt utterly encouraged because he was with Jesus, and it would be selfish to want him back.
illustrations.context: Illustrates that death for believers is a transition to being with loved ones and Jesus, providing encouragement during grief.

illustrations.title: Young Woman's Final Wish
illustrations.text: I remember going into this 19-year-old girl with cystic fibrosis in the hospital; she was very sick and wouldn't be getting out. She asked if I do funerals and requested that I handle hers and share the gospel with her family. She wanted her death to be used by God to bring her unsaved family to Jesus so they could be in heaven with her.
illustrations.context: Demonstrates how facing death can inspire believers to focus on evangelizing their loved ones for eternal reunion.

illustrations.title: Drive-Through Funerals Trend
illustrations.text: You may think this is a joke, but it's not. There are drive-through funeral services in several states, like Virginia, LA, and Michigan. This is a place where you can drive up, the curtains open, music begins, and you have three minutes to pay respects. It's ridiculous and catching on as a chain, showing how our culture wants to get things done quickly, even mourning.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to contrast modern rushed culture with the thorough honor in the biblical story.

illustrations.title: Presidential Entourage Analogy
illustrations.text: Have you ever seen a president or a governor come through town and the entourage that goes with them? If you've never seen that, it's pretty amazing to watch, with all the people and spectacle. This illustrates the incredible procession in the biblical story, like a head of state arriving with great pomp.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to help visualize the grandeur of the mourning procession for Jacob.

illustrations.title: Officer Steve's Funeral Procession
illustrations.text: When Becky and I were part of the funeral procession for Highway Patrol sergeant Steve Lacan just a few months ago, the services were held at Harvest Church followed by an incredible procession. There were hundreds of highway patrolmen and police officers, about a thousand in uniform, making it unlike anything I've ever seen. We were in our car toward the back of the long line, with the hearse carrying the body surrounded by CHP motor units with lights on and cops controlling every intersection. People on the streets of Riverside didn't know who was being honored, but they stopped, watched, and pulled out their cell phones as everything halted. It felt so right that the world paused to honor this man, even though he wasn't honored in his lifetime, and I thought how precious that moment was.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to illustrate that true honor often comes after death, similar to biblical figures like Jacob.

illustrations.title: David Livingstone's Legacy
illustrations.text: I heard a story about David Livingstone when he was young. You know he was a missionary, and they were talking about what they wanted to be when they grew up. His brother said he wanted to be rich and famous, but David Livingstone, who was already a Christian, said he wanted to bring as many people to Christ as he could and live for Him fully. He went to Africa and saw many people get saved. His brother did become wealthy, but he became famous because of David Livingstone, and his epitaph reads, 'Here lies the brother of David Livingstone.' We've become famous because of the one we're related to.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that our honor and glory come from our relationship to Christ, just as the brother's fame came from David Livingstone.

illustrations.title: Carrying My Dying Mom
illustrations.text: You know, if you've lived long enough to have a mom or dad pass away, you may have had this experience where the one who carried you becomes the one you have to carry. I'll never forget when my mom was dying. This illustrates how family members must care for their parents in their final days, just as Joseph's sons did for Jacob.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that death is a time for family members to walk together, emphasizing the role of sons in burying and honoring their father.

illustrations.title: Carrying My Mother
illustrations.text: I remember my mom needed to be moved from a couch to a bed, so I picked her up in my arms and carried her. I thought I had never carried my mother before, but this was the time for it, especially since she had carried me many times in my life. It felt appropriate, mirroring how sons carry their father in his final days.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the role reversal in family caregiving during illness and death.

illustrations.title: Biblical Family Reunions
illustrations.text: It's interesting that in the Scriptures, Isaac and Ishmael, who weren't close, came together to bury their father Abraham. Similarly, Jacob and Esau reunited for their father Isaac's burial, and the twelve brothers gathered with Joseph to bury Jacob. These stories show how death brings estranged family members together.
illustrations.context: This retelling highlights how death unites families, even those with conflicts.

illustrations.title: Family Gathering at Death
illustrations.text: My original family, with one brother and three sisters, came together for the night when we knew my dad was dying. We went to my parents' mobile home in South County and watched the monitor as he neared the end of his life. It was a special time for us, as we hadn't been together like that in many years, and his death brought us close in a way we hadn't experienced before.
illustrations.context: This story shows how a parent's death reunites family members despite life's busyness.

illustrations.title: Ribs and Family Bonding
illustrations.text: One of my fondest memories is my dad's service, where he requested no funeral but for us to go out and have ribs, which he paid for. My brother and I, who are vastly different in our worldviews—he's a liberal atheist and I'm not—went to the rib joint and talked about childhood memories. We wept together, celebrating our father and bridging our differences in that moment.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how a parent's wishes and death can foster unexpected family unity and emotional healing.

illustrations.title: Unconventional Burial Stories
illustrations.text: I know people who have buried their loved ones, like their husbands, in their front yard—I'm not sure if it's legal, but they did it. My sister buried her husband and spread his ashes in the Jordan River. You might think that's weird or inappropriate, but these examples show how people handle death differently.
illustrations.context: To illustrate that it's wrong to judge others' funeral plans, as burial methods vary widely.

illustrations.title: Sarcophagus Burial History
illustrations.text: The sarcophagus used in Israel even today means 'flesh-eating' because the limestone causes the body to decay faster. They buried bodies to let them decay quickly, then scooped the bones to the side to gather with the family. This practice was common and shows how ancient cultures handled the dead efficiently.
illustrations.context: To demonstrate that there's nothing unbiblical about different burial methods, like cremation or quick decay.

illustrations.title: Joe Bailey's Grief Experience
illustrations.text: Joe Bailey wrote a book after losing three of his children over several years. In his book titled 'A View from a Hearse,' he shares his profound experiences with grief. This story highlights the pain of loss and the importance of not adding to someone's sorrow.
illustrations.context: To emphasize that we should not add to the grief of those who are mourning.

illustrations.title: The Two Comforters
illustrations.text: Beyond the grave, he talked constantly and said things I knew were true, but I was unmoved and wished he'd go away. He finally did, and another came and just sat beside me. He didn't talk or ask leading questions; he simply sat with me for an hour or more, listened when I spoke, answered briefly, prayed simply, and left. I was moved and comforted, and I hated to see him go. This illustrates the difference between empty words and genuine presence.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to emphasize that true comfort comes from simply being present with someone in pain, rather than trying to explain their suffering.

illustrations.title: Job's Miserable Comforters
illustrations.text: What did Job say about all his friends who had all kinds of ideas as to why God was doing it and what it meant? He called them miserable comforters. This quote from Job highlights how unhelpful it is to offer speculative explanations during someone's hardship. Pastor Bob connects it to the idea that we should avoid such approaches when supporting others in tough times.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to show that people in distress don't need explanations for their suffering; they need companionship and empathy.

illustrations.title: Childhood Pretty Feet Memory
illustrations.text: I grew up the youngest of five children with three sisters and one brother. In our medicine chest, there was a bottle that looked like lotion, labeled 'pretty feet,' which I thought was an oxymoron. It was some kind of dead skin remover, mostly used on elbows rather than feet. I remembered this when reading Romans 10:15, which quotes Isaiah about beautiful feet bringing good news.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to illustrate the biblical concept of 'beautiful feet' as something unexpectedly meaningful.

illustrations.title: Evangelists Who Shared Gospel
illustrations.text: I think of the two men who shared the gospel with me many years ago; they had beautiful feet because they brought me the information about how I can know my Savior. This changed my life forever. Their act of sharing good news exemplifies the verse about beautiful feet.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob shares this to emphasize that those who bring the gospel have beautiful feet in a spiritual sense.

illustrations.title: Song of Solomon Feet Quote
illustrations.text: I think also of the bride as described in the Song of Solomon, which we've studied on Wednesday nights as a picture of Christ and the church. In Song of Solomon 7:1, it says, 'How beautiful are your feet in sandals, O prince's daughter.' The Bride of Christ, like the bride of Solomon, is portrayed as having beautiful feet, symbolizing grace and purpose in sharing good news.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to connect the biblical imagery of beautiful feet to the church's role in evangelism.

illustrations.title: Jesus' Sending Commission
illustrations.text: You remember that Jesus, after He died and rose again, said this to His disciples: 'As the Father has sent Me, so send I you.' I jokingly say that means Jesus said, 'Tag, you're it. I'm going home.' But God's plan now is to use you in a similar way as He used Jesus, sending you into the world to fulfill His purposes.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to illustrate that Christians are sent by God to know Him and make Him known, continuing Jesus' mission.

illustrations.title: Prisoners of War Analogy
illustrations.text: In other words, the church is militant and going into a lost world where there are prisoners of war. Remember, sinners are not the enemy; they are held captive by the enemy to do his will. But we are going in to bring men and women out alive. That's why we are here on this earth.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that Christians must actively evangelize to rescue sinners from spiritual captivity.

illustrations.title: Carl Henry's Gospel Quote
illustrations.text: God's remedy for man's sin and situation is 100 percent effective all the time, but the question remains: will it ever be applied to the infected? As Carl Henry once said, the gospel is only effective—it's only good news—if it gets there in time. This highlights the urgency of sharing the gospel.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob emphasizes that the gospel must be shared promptly to be effective in saving people.

illustrations.title: Lifeguard Analogy
illustrations.text: A Christian not knowing how to lead someone to Christ is like a lifeguard that doesn't know how to throw out a life preserver. It's essential for us to be prepared to share the gospel. This illustrates how critical it is for believers to fulfill their role in evangelism.
illustrations.context: To emphasize that Christians must know how to lead others to Christ, just as a lifeguard must know how to save someone.

illustrations.title: Woman Unaware of Jesus
illustrations.text: I have met people who did not know who Jesus was, including a gal who was our children's ministry director. She said she was in high school in Orange County and had never heard the name Jesus or what He had done until a friend told her about Christ. This shows that even in familiar places, many people remain unaware of the gospel.
illustrations.context: To illustrate that billions of people, even in the US, may not know about Jesus, encouraging believers not to assume everyone is informed.

illustrations.title: Pastor's Coming to Faith
illustrations.text: When I came to faith, all I needed to know was that I needed to know Him and how to do it. There are people all around us who need just that. People won't call on Christ in saving faith if they've never heard the gospel, if they don't understand who He is, what He's done, and why that's good news, and how to come to know Him.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that simple faith in knowing Jesus is essential for salvation and that many people around us need this basic understanding.

illustrations.title: Bride in Song of Solomon
illustrations.text: In the Song of Solomon, chapter five, verses two and three, the bride is talking about her relationship with the bridegroom. She says, 'I was asleep but my heart was awake. A voice! My beloved was knocking. Open to me, my sister, my darling, my dove, my perfect one, for my head is drenched with dew, my locks with the damp of the night.' But she responds, 'I've taken off my dress; how can I put it on again? I've washed my feet; how can I dirty them again?' This shows the bridegroom calling for the bride to come out and follow him, but she's not ready.
illustrations.context: This retelling emphasizes that the bride's feet are beautiful when used for witnessing, highlighting the importance of following the Lord and sharing the gospel.

illustrations.title: Spurgeon on Christian Mission
illustrations.text: Charles Haddon Spurgeon wrote that following Jesus on His mission is out where souls need saving, and that's the reality for every one of us. He said every Christian here is either a missionary or an impostor. You are either trying to spread abroad the kingdom of Christ or else you do not love Him at all.
illustrations.context: This quote underscores that every Christian must actively engage in evangelism, or they are not genuine in their faith.

illustrations.title: Cure for Cancer Analogy
illustrations.text: Think about it this way: if you found the cure for cancer, would you share it? You would say absolutely. Well, guess what? You have the cure to death and hell, so go out and share it. We have no reason not to.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to emphasize that Christians should share the gospel because it is the ultimate solution to spiritual death, just as one would share a cure for a deadly disease.

illustrations.title: Elijah and the Arameans Retelling
illustrations.text: I think of the time of Elijah recorded in 2nd Kings chapter 7, where Jerusalem was surrounded by the Aramean army, cutting off food supplies and causing a terrible famine. People were starving, and four lepers at the gate decided that staying in the city would mean death, so they went out to the enemy camp. To their surprise, the camp was empty because God had caused a supernatural noise that made the Arameans flee, leaving behind food and supplies.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob retells this story to illustrate the urgency and opportunity for Christians to share the gospel, showing how taking a risk can lead to discovering abundance where danger was expected.

illustrations.title: Lepers Share Good News
illustrations.text: These lepers sneaked into the first tent and started taking food, eating it and stacking it up outside. They went to another tent, enjoying themselves immensely. Then one said to the other, 'We are not doing right; this is a day of good news, but we're keeping silent,' so they decided to tell the king in Jerusalem that there was plenty of food. They realized they had to share what they knew about the Lord's provision.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to emphasize that believers have an obligation to share the good news of God's kindness with others, just as the lepers did.

illustrations.title: Sergeant's Unexpected Conversion
illustrations.text: When I was a police officer, I had a sergeant who was a huge guy and didn't like Christians, making it clear in various ways. I tried to avoid him, but after I left the department, I returned for a visit and he wanted to talk. He told me that some people came to his door, shared about Jesus Christ and what He did on the cross, and led him in a prayer to receive Christ, radically changing his life. He explained that he never went to church because he already knew he was going to hell and didn't want to hear it confirmed.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob shares this to show that people may already sense their need for salvation but require the full gospel message to find hope in Jesus.

illustrations.title: East Coast Grave Visit
illustrations.text: Becky and I were back on the East Coast and visited her grandfather's grave in Rhode Island at a little cemetery near a little church. As we were driving out of the church parking lot, I saw signs all over saying, 'You're now entering your mission field.' This was a reminder for the people who attended that church every Sunday, as they drove out, to see themselves entering their mission field. We used to have similar signs in our church above the doors.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that everyday environments are mission fields for sharing the gospel.

illustrations.title: Dinner at Friend's House
illustrations.text: I went over to his house for dinner years ago, and he had a sign above his front door that said, 'You're now entering your mission field.' This reminded him and his wife every time they walked out the door that they were entering their mission field. Some of you might need signs on both sides of your door for the same reason.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize that Christians are missionaries in their daily routines.

illustrations.title: Organization's Missionary Motto
illustrations.text: One organization has this motto that I like: every Christian is a missionary and every unsaved person is a mission field. I use this to show that being a missionary isn't about quitting your job or going overseas; it's about recognizing your role in everyday life. This motto connects directly to the idea that all Christians are sent with a message, just like the word 'missionary' means in Latin.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to redefine missionary work as something accessible to every Christian in their daily lives.

illustrations.title: Brittany's Missionary Insight
illustrations.text: Years ago, the Schafer family was part of our church and they went on missions trips to Mexico every couple of months. Their daughter Brittany, about seven or eight years old, always joined them. On one trip, an adult asked her if she wanted to become a missionary when she grew up, and she simply replied, 'No, I already am one.' This story shows how even a child can embrace the role of a missionary in daily life.
illustrations.context: To illustrate that anyone, even a child, can be a missionary in their everyday activities.

illustrations.title: Cross the Sea Quote
illustrations.text: As has been said, you do not need to cross the sea to be a missionary; you need to see the cross. Sometimes, you just need to cross the streets to share with someone who doesn't know Jesus. Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that missionary work starts with personal faith and local outreach.
illustrations.context: To show that being a missionary involves seeing the cross and engaging in nearby evangelism, not just traveling abroad.

illustrations.title: Hesitant Christian Conversation
illustrations.text: I've heard Christians say, 'If the Lord opens the doors, I'll go,' when considering serving in ministry. Instead, a better approach is to pray, 'Lord, I'm going; if you don't want me to, close the doors.' This reflects a proactive commitment to the Great Commission rather than passive waiting.
illustrations.context: To encourage believers to actively pursue God's call instead of waiting for clear signs.

illustrations.title: Spurgeon on Evangelistic Urgency
illustrations.text: Spurgeon said that millions have never heard of Jesus. We ought not to ask if we can prove that we ought to go, but if we can prove that we ought not. I say amen to that, as it challenges us to act.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize the need for proactive commitment to sharing the gospel without hesitation.

illustrations.title: Wesley on Fully Committed Believers
illustrations.text: John Wesley once said this, and I think it's so right on: Give me 100 people who fear nothing but sin and desire nothing but God, and I care not whether they be clergymen or laymen. Such alone will shake the gates of hell and set up the kingdom of heaven on earth. This highlights the power of total dedication.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob connects this quote to the call for being fully committed followers of Christ rather than casual ones.

illustrations.title: Isaiah's Humble Encounter with God
illustrations.text: I think of Isaiah, who when he gets into the presence of God, becomes aware of his failings. When Isaiah saw the Lord high and lifted up in Isaiah 6, he said, 'Woe is me.' Sometimes we think if we saw God, we'd be excited, but Isaiah felt like he was going to die, showing the weight of God's holiness. This illustrates how humility leads to grace.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that recognizing one's shortcomings in God's presence is essential for God to use a person.

illustrations.title: Isaiah's Encounter with God
illustrations.text: Isaiah was doing his job as a prophet, pronouncing God's judgment on different people until he reached chapter six. There, when he saw the Lord, he cried out, 'Woe to me, for I am a man of unclean lips.' An angel flew quickly, took a burning coal from the altar, touched Isaiah's lips, and it was painful but powerful as God forgave his sin. Immediately after, God issued an invitation, saying, 'Whom shall I send and who will go for us?' Isaiah responded, 'Here am I, send me.'
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that recognizing one's sin and seeking forgiveness prepares one for God's calling.

illustrations.title: Dry Grass Wildfire Analogy
illustrations.text: Lord, I see a field of dry grass, just ready for a lit match to be dropped into it. Would that happen here tonight, and would it spread like a wildfire into our communities and workplaces? Lord, I fear there are many here tonight who need to wake up or be reminded why we're here.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating the potential for spiritual revival to ignite suddenly and spread rapidly, urging listeners to be prepared for awakening.

illustrations.title: Welsh Revival Encounter
illustrations.text: I heard a story years ago about some people who went to Wales to witness the famous Welsh Revival that had broken out there. They arrived excited but didn't know exactly where to go. So, they approached a policeman and asked, 'We are here to see the revival; can you tell us where it is?' He replied, 'I can tell you where the revival is.' This illustrates how God's movement draws attention from everyone, even everyday authorities.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to show that when God moves in history, the world notices and gets involved.

illustrations.title: Pentecost Story Retelling
illustrations.text: I know that on the day of Pentecost when the Spirit of God fell, tons of people came because of the mighty rushing wind and people speaking in tongues, with things happening that attracted them. It's not that this is bad, because people get saved, but it shows how curiosity draws crowds. God uses these moments, yet we must be careful about our motives.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate how people are naturally curious about signs of God's movement, like in revivals, but true revival starts personally.

illustrations.title: Fire Quote Analogy
illustrations.text: There's an old saying: you don't have to advertise a fire because people just come looking when there's one. For example, like how four or five cop cars with lights and sirens down the street drew my attention, making me want to go see what was happening. This shows how human nature responds to excitement without needing promotion.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to explain that genuine revivals, like a fire, naturally attract people due to curiosity, but personal surrender is key.

illustrations.title: Cop Cars Personal Story
illustrations.text: There were four or five cop cars racing down the street the other day, and the people in my car and I said, let's go see what that's about because I wanted to know. We tried to chase and see what was happening, as it's just human nature to be curious about such things. This illustrates how we are drawn to excitement, much like people to a revival.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob shares this to show that curiosity drives people to investigate events, paralleling how crowds form around spiritual movements without true personal change.

illustrations.title: Gypsy Smith Revival Quote
illustrations.text: Gypsy Smith years ago said to people who wanted to see revival: draw a circle, go home, draw a circle, get in that circle, and then when everything in that circle is dedicated and surrendered to God, the revival will begin. In other words, revival starts with personal surrender in your own space. This means God is ready to revive one heart at a time if we're willing.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that true revival begins with individual dedication to God, rather than waiting for large events.

illustrations.title: Pastor's Recent Cut
illustrations.text: You shall not cut yourself as stated in Deuteronomy. I know that happened to me just a few weeks ago when I accidentally cut myself. But since I'm not under the Old Testament law, I guess it's okay. This personal experience highlights the difference between ancient commands and modern faith.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses his personal injury to show that believers today are not bound by Old Testament laws.

illustrations.title: Isaiah's Vision of Holiness
illustrations.text: In his vision that changed his ministry and really his life, Isaiah sees the Lord high and lifted up. He hears the seraphim, which are a class of angels meaning 'the burning ones' in Hebrew. He sees these angels crying out, 'Holy, holy, holy.' When John has a vision of Heaven, we're not covering that yet on Sunday mornings.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate the profound spiritual truth of God's holiness as revealed in biblical visions.

illustrations.title: Modern Self-Harm Practices
illustrations.text: People cut themselves today, especially when going through difficult times. You might know someone who struggles with cutting, often teenage girls, but it's not limited to them. People who don't feel in control of their lives sometimes turn to self-harm as a way to cope. This is a very ancient kind of thing that persists in various forms.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that self-harm is a contemporary expression of ancient grieving practices, emphasizing how God's people should be different in how they handle grief.

illustrations.title: Prophets of Baal on Mount Carmel
illustrations.text: In First Kings chapter 18, there was a competition on Mount Carmel between Elijah and the 450 prophets of Baal. Elijah challenged them to call on their god to answer by fire, but no one responded. They got worked up, crying out and yelling, and eventually started cutting themselves with stones, bleeding to get their god's attention.
illustrations.context: This story shows how people in the world turned to self-harm in pagan rituals, contrasting with how God's people should grieve without such practices.

illustrations.title: Demon-Possessed Man in Gadera
illustrations.text: Remember when Jesus went to Gadera and got off the boat, he was met by one or two demon-possessed men. They identified themselves as inhabited by a legion of demons and lived in the tombs. One of the attributes was that he would break shackles, scream, and cut himself, showing the destructive influence of the demons.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how demonic forces lead to self-harm and chaos, reinforcing that Satan seeks to destroy lives physically and spiritually.

illustrations.title: Thief's Destructive Intent
illustrations.text: Jesus said the thief, referring to the Devil, comes to rob, kill, and destroy. He wants you dead spiritually, to stay dead spiritually, and even dead eternally. He'll be happy to take you out physically if allowed, highlighting Satan's ultimate goal of destruction.
illustrations.context: This quote emphasizes that Satan aims to harm and destroy, urging believers to recognize the spiritual battle and live in holiness.

illustrations.title: Childhood Funeral Memory
illustrations.text: I was probably 10 years old and attended a funeral at a Lutheran Church in Yorba Linda. My neighbor Scott's father had been killed in a car accident, so my mom and my family went to support his mom and family. I don't remember anything said at the funeral, but I'll never forget his wife uncontrollably weeping as the service ended. She was clinging to the casket and didn't want to let them take it out of the church, literally being almost dragged behind it.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate how unbelievers grieve without hope, contrasting it with how believers should grieve.

illustrations.title: Empty Tent at Camp
illustrations.text: I remember years ago we were up at camp and we did tent camping, though we've progressed to cabins now. I'll never forget when somebody needed to talk to me because I was the pastor, and they were told I was in my tent resting. They stood outside calling for me, not knowing I wasn't there—I had gone to the river or store and was on my way back. As I approached, I saw them talking to my empty tent, asking questions. I called out hello, and it struck me how it's like talking to a believer's grave—they're not there either.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate that believers are not in their graves after death, as they are present with the Lord.

illustrations.title: Greg Laurie on Before Life
illustrations.text: I like what Greg Laurie says. He points out that we often call what happens after we die the afterlife, but this life is so short compared to eternity, so we shouldn't think of it that way. He suggests we call this life the before life because it's just a brief thing, and the real life is coming, which is what we're all getting prepared for.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to remind believers that life is short and they should act in a way that prepares for eternity.

illustrations.title: Jesus at Lazarus's Funeral
illustrations.text: Jesus wept at Lazarus's funeral and then he raised him from the dead. This shows that it's okay to grieve, just as Jesus did. So, follow his example: grieve with those who grieve, but don't grieve as those without hope, because you're missing them temporarily, not forever.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate that believers should grieve with hope, knowing they will see loved ones again in heaven.

illustrations.title: Fine China for Holiness
illustrations.text: Maybe you grew up in a household with special dishes that your mom only used when company came over, like fine China she took out of her China hutch and put on the table for Thanksgiving. That's a good way to understand holiness—something reserved for a very specific purpose. Similarly, implements in the temple were holy because they were exclusively used for God's purposes in worship and sacrifices, and believers are set apart in the same way.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to explain that holiness means being set apart for God's specific purposes, not being sinless or perfect.

illustrations.title: Jewish Protection from Plagues
illustrations.text: One writer explains that in the Middle Ages, when plagues and diseases devastated Europe, the Jewish people were often protected from many of those illnesses. People at the time mistakenly believed this protection came from magic or witchcraft, leading to persecution of the Jews. However, as time has passed, we now understand that their protection likely resulted from their adherence to dietary and hygiene laws from the Old Testament. This historical example shows the practical wisdom in God's commands.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate the ongoing benefits and wisdom of following God's laws, even if they are not binding today.

illustrations.title: Absurd Egyptian Remedies
illustrations.text: For example, here's an Egyptian scroll written at approximately the same time as Deuteronomy. It propagated the following: to prevent gray hair, take blood from a black cat, mix it with the fat of a rattlesnake, and eat it twice daily. Or to reverse baldness, take fat from a cat, a horse, a crocodile, a hippo, and a snake, mix it together and eat it; and if you have a severe case of baldness, add a tooth of a donkey that has been cooked in honey. When we read these things, we chuckle because of their absurdity, but when we study the scriptures written at the same time, we see them proving to be medically correct and profound.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to highlight the wisdom and timeless accuracy of biblical dietary regulations compared to the absurd practices in contemporary ancient writings.

illustrations.title: Orthodox Jewish Hand-Washing
illustrations.text: They had all kinds of strict rules not only about what to eat but how to ceremonially wash their hands. It wasn't about eating with some dirt on their hands; it had to do with going through a ceremonial washing, which is still done by Orthodox Jews today. If you go to a hotel restaurant in Israel, you'll see they have special sinks for this, and they don't use soap; it's just a ceremony where water has to pass over their hands.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates that Jesus was addressing ritual purity rather than actual cleanliness, showing that not following the ritual does not defile a person.

illustrations.title: Spurgeon on Worry
illustrations.text: Somebody called worry the wrong use of the imagination. Spurgeon called it the dark room where negatives are developed. This illustrates how feeding on unhealthy thoughts, like worry, develops negativity in our lives, much like developing photos in a dark room.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to show that worry fuels negative thoughts and contributes to inner turmoil, emphasizing the need to avoid such mental feeding.

illustrations.title: Divided Hoof Analogy
illustrations.text: I'm going to make an analogy here, based on J. Vernon McGee's interpretation, which I agree with. God declares an animal with a divided hoof clean, symbolizing a spiritual walk that is clearly divided from the world. This means we are to be in the world physically but not of it in our values, as Jesus taught in his prayer. We must avoid conforming to worldly ways and instead be transformed by renewing our minds, as described in Romans 12:2 and other scriptures.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to emphasize that believers should maintain a clear separation from worldly values and behaviors.

illustrations.title: 1930 Pagan Ritual Discovery
illustrations.text: In 1930, there was a discovery in one of the archaeological digs of a pagan culture that would boil a goat in its mother's milk. They would then take the substance and sprinkle it on their fields to make them more fertile. This phrase is used three times in the Old Testament, emphasizing that God's people should not imitate such worldly practices to seek blessings.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that believers should avoid adopting pagan customs when pursuing fortune and blessings, just as the Israelites were commanded.

illustrations.title: God's Control in Ruth
illustrations.text: Go read the book of Ruth; she chanced upon a field that just happened to be Boaz's. Isn't that interesting? This clearly shows that what appears to be chance to us is God in charge of it. They also cast lots to figure out property, and it fell exactly as God willed, not by coincidence.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that God controls what seems like chance, emphasizing divine sovereignty.

illustrations.title: Futility of Lucky Charms
illustrations.text: I don't believe in lucky charms, and I don't mean the cereal. I'm talking about the ones people carry, like a rabbit's foot. That rabbit wasn't very lucky for the rabbit itself. It doesn't bring any real luck, so why rely on it?
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that believing in luck is pagan and Christians should avoid such superstitions.

illustrations.title: Origin of Fortune
illustrations.text: We use the word 'fortune,' but it actually comes from Fortunata, an ancient Greek Goddess. There is no such goddess governing you; instead, there's a God who loves you. This highlights why we shouldn't attribute events to fortune.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that concepts like fortune are rooted in pagan beliefs, not Christian truth.

illustrations.title: Cow's Rumination Process
illustrations.text: Pastor Bob asks how many stomachs a cow has, explaining it has four compartments and describing how the cow eats grass, then regurgitates it to chew more thoroughly for better nourishment. He compares this to the word 'ruminate,' linking it to meditating on God's word as mentioned in Psalm 1, where the blessed person is like a tree planted by water because they constantly reflect on Scripture. This process shows how we need to let God's word go deeper than just hearing it, affecting our thoughts, feelings, and actions.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that just as a cow ruminates to extract full nourishment from food, believers should meditate on God's word to fully absorb and apply it in their lives.

illustrations.title: Sheep Digesting Grass Quote
illustrations.text: Pastor Bob mentions Epictetus, a second-century philosopher who gathered his students and said that a sheep doesn't vomit up the grass it ate at the shepherd's feet to impress him, but instead digests it to produce wool and milk. He explains that this quote highlights the importance of internalizing what we take in, just as we should with God's word. By connecting it to Scripture, Pastor Bob emphasizes that merely knowing the Bible isn't enough; we must let it transform us.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to show that believers should digest and apply God's word in their lives to produce spiritual fruit, rather than just possessing knowledge to impress others.

illustrations.title: Testing God Through Tithing
illustrations.text: Malachi 3 is the only place in the Bible where God commands his people to test him, even though we're told elsewhere not to test the Lord. God says in Malachi 3:10, 'Bring the whole tithe into the storehouse so that there may be food in my house, and see if I will not open for you the windows of heaven and pour out a blessing until it overflows.' This is an exception where God invites testing, specifically in the area of giving and tithing, as it's tied to trusting Him with finances. Have you ever tested God in that area by faithfully tithing?
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that tithing is a way to trust and fear God, as He promises abundant blessings in return.

illustrations.title: Three Guys Tithing Joke
illustrations.text: Like the three guys were talking about deciding how much to give to God. The first one said, 'I draw a circle, throw my money up in the air, and keep whatever lands in the circle, giving the rest to God.' The second guy said, 'I do the reverse: whatever lands in the circle goes to God, and the rest is mine.' The third guy said, 'You're both wrong; I throw my money up, and God can keep whatever he wants.'
illustrations.context: This illustrates different humorous attitudes toward giving and highlights the importance of generous proportional giving.

illustrations.title: Billy Graham on Tithing
illustrations.text: Billy Graham said, 'If the law commands tithing, how could love do anything less.' This quote emphasizes that under the law, tithing was required, and in the spirit of love, we should at least meet that standard. Pastor Bob uses it to connect to the idea that failing to tithe was seen as robbery in the Old Testament.
illustrations.context: This quote reinforces that Christian giving should be at least as generous as the Old Testament command, driven by love rather than obligation.

illustrations.title: New Christian's Tithing Story
illustrations.text: I once had a guy tell me he was a new Christian and he heard about someone who tithes only 5% of his income. I didn't want to discourage him, but I knew the word 'tithe' actually means 10%. People often get surprised at the idea of giving that much, but in the Bible, it was commanded as 10%. Anyway, it's a reminder that understanding giving starts with the basics.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate common misconceptions about tithing and the importance of accurate biblical understanding.

illustrations.title: Ivan the Great's Baptism Tale
illustrations.text: There's an interesting true story from history in the 15th century during the reign of Ivan the Great, the Czar of Russia. He was too busy with his empire to find a wife, so his friends arranged a marriage with the daughter of the king of Greece, but she required him to join the Greek Orthodox Church. Ivan agreed and brought 500 of his armed forces, who also needed to be baptized. The priests initially refused because the soldiers were involved in warfare, but they found a solution: the soldiers went into the water for baptism while holding their swords above the water to keep them dry. This story shows the lengths people went to for commitment. It's fascinating and has even been depicted in paintings.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to highlight themes of full commitment and adaptation in faith, possibly connecting to the idea of obedience like in tithing.

illustrations.title: R.J. Lernov's Generous Giving
illustrations.text: His name is R.J. Lernov, some of you have heard of him, most of you just a name, but he was famous in his day as a Christian who became very wealthy by creating earth-moving equipment during World War II. He was known as God's businessman and held more than 300 patents for his designs, which we still use today. As money flowed into his business, he believed all riches belonged to God, so he and his wife began giving away 90% of their income and living on just 10%, making them reverse tithers. He often said, 'I shovel out the money and God shovels it back, but God has a bigger shovel,' meaning he continued to gain wealth despite his giving. He also warned that if you give only because it pays, it won't pay off, emphasizing that true giving isn't about personal gain.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show the value of generous giving and surrendering wealth to God without selfish motives.

illustrations.title: Rockefeller's Turn to Giving
illustrations.text: We'll close with this amazing true story about John D. Rockefeller. He became a millionaire at 33 and the world's first billionaire by 53, but by then he was a shell of a man, suffering from alopecia and looking like a mummy. He could only digest milk and crackers, couldn't sleep, wouldn't smile, and was immersed in anxiety, with doctors predicting he'd die within a year. One morning, he remembered a dream about not taking his successes to the next world and realized he wasn't in control of his life. He then called his attorneys and managers, announcing he wanted to channel his assets into hospitals, research, and mission work, establishing his foundation. His focus shifted outward, leading him to help the underprivileged and fund medical discoveries like penicillin and cures for malaria, tuberculosis, and diphtheria. The most amazing part is that his life transformed through this act of giving.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to show that God's blessing comes from working and giving to others, rather than just accumulating wealth for oneself.

illustrations.title: Giving Leads to Longer Life
illustrations.text: He began to give back a portion of all that he had earned. His body's chemistry was altered so significantly that he got better. It looked as if he would die at 53, but he lived to be 98.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that giving to God can bring unexpected blessings and health, encouraging people to trust God with their finances.

illustrations.title: Reluctance to Preach on Giving
illustrations.text: I told the Lord many years ago that I don't want to preach on passages about giving because I know some people will think that's all I care about, like we'll take multiple offerings or put up a thermometer to raise money. The Lord responded that I don't get to skip it and must preach on what He wants, not just what makes me comfortable or avoids criticism. This experience shows I need to prioritize God's direction over my own fears.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating the need to obey God's calling even on uncomfortable topics like giving.

illustrations.title: Saul's Radical Conversion Story
illustrations.text: When Saul was saved on the road to Damascus, it was a pretty radical conversion as radical as they can get. He was blinded and fell to the ground, realizing that Jesus, whom he thought was dead, is actually the Messiah and the savior of the world. This was a massive wake-up call, like an 'aha moment on steroids.' The first thing he said to Jesus was, 'What would you have me to do?' It's only natural that we want to do what the Lord asks, but we can jump ahead without understanding the basis.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that believers should first grasp what God has done before rushing into action, to avoid unnecessary struggles.

illustrations.title: Boat in the Ocean Analogy
illustrations.text: Someone described it this way: It's like a boat in the ocean. A boat is made to be in the water, but it's trouble when there's water in the boat. Similarly, the church is made to be in the world until Christ comes for us, but there's trouble when there's worldliness in the church.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that Christians should be in the world but not of it, to avoid spiritual trouble.

illustrations.title: Pastor's Encounters with Struggles
illustrations.text: As a pastor, I get to meet with people who are going through hard times and are Christians. They often come after the service or make an appointment, and I love being part of their lives. But sometimes, the real issue isn't the problem itself but how we're relating to it, and it's not uncommon for someone to come in where I can tell just how they're handling it.
illustrations.context: This shows that Christians need to focus on heavenly perspectives when facing earthly problems.

illustrations.title: Israel Trip Confusion
illustrations.text: When I go to Israel once a year, and we're heading there in March with about a hundred of you—I can't wait—but I know it's in a different time zone, ten hours ahead of us. For some reason, my thinking gets muddy, maybe because of jet lag, and I sometimes forget whether it's ten hours ahead or behind. I think I know, so I'll call one of my sons or the staff back home to tell them something I need them to do. This illustrates how physical circumstances can cloud our understanding, much like spiritual truths.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to show how confusion in daily life mirrors the need to grasp our spiritual identity in Christ.

illustrations.title: Martin Luther's Two Dates
illustrations.text: Martin Luther said he only has two dates on his calendar: today and that day, meaning the day he'll stand before Jesus Christ. Every day I live now is in light of that. Every Christian lives in two time zones, walking by faith and realizing we are in Christ in heaven now, even if we can't see it.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that Christians should live with an eternal perspective, focusing on today in light of the future day of judgment.

illustrations.title: Teenage Backyard Revelation
illustrations.text: I was about 15 years old and going through a hard time when my whole world felt like it was falling apart. I sat in my parents' backyard on a gloomy, dark day, feeling like everything was foreboding, and looked up at the sky. Suddenly, the clouds shifted, revealing a hole of pure blue sky with light beaming through, which felt like God saying that not everything is dark—up above, it looks great. It's like being on a plane that rises above a storm, breaking through to clear skies. God wants us to live with His perspective, not just what we see in our troubles.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob shares this personal story to illustrate that believers should adopt God's higher perspective on their problems rather than being consumed by immediate difficulties.

illustrations.title: Political Quote on Stance
illustrations.text: A politician was quoted on a TV interview saying, 'In politics, how you stand depends on where you sit.' He was talking about the Senate and which side of the aisle you're on. Pastor Bob connects this to spiritual life, explaining that just as a queen exercises authority from her throne, a Christian's stand and walk depend on their spiritual position.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that one's perspective and actions in life depend on their spiritual focus and position.

illustrations.title: D.L. Moody Ship Fire
illustrations.text: The story is told of D.L. Moody on a steamship crossing the Atlantic when a fire broke out in the engine room. Everyone formed a bucket brigade to fight the fire, and Moody's chief of staff suggested they go pray instead of helping. Moody refused, saying they would pray while fighting the fire, otherwise there would be nothing left to pray for.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to show that being heavenly minded means being actively involved in earthly good, not withdrawing from practical action.

illustrations.title: Friend's Faded Zeal
illustrations.text: I went to Biola in the 1970s and met a close friend who ministered in a Spanish-speaking church. He was passionate for the Lord, a Bible major like me, and even invited me to preach at his church where he interpreted. A couple of years after we graduated, I ran into him and noticed the joy and sparkle in his eyes were gone; he had gotten married and started working for his father-in-law in a jewelry store, which changed him completely. The passion to serve God vanished as he became focused on worldly things like gold rings.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how the cares of the world and riches can choke out one's relationship with God and diminish spiritual passion.

illustrations.title: High School Stock Obsession
illustrations.text: When I was in high school, I owned three shares of Levitz furniture stock, which I bought for a little over $100. I would pick up my dad's newspaper every day and check the stock market page to see how it was performing, getting excited about any gains. I watched it daily for months, letting it consume my attention even though it was just a small investment. This experience shows how something seemingly harmless can become an idol if it takes priority over other things.
illustrations.context: This demonstrates how the deceitfulness of riches and desires for worldly things can distract from one's faith and become an idol.

illustrations.title: Selling Stock for Prom
illustrations.text: When it was time for prom, I had no money to go and found someone willing to join me if I bought dinner. Orange Hills was expensive for a 15-year-old, and I needed a way to get there. So, I sold my stock—all three shares—and made a little bit of money. After selling it, I never once looked up Levitz furniture again; I didn't care anymore. This story shows how our focus shifts based on what we value.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that where your treasure is, your heart will be, emphasizing the need to focus on heavenly things.

illustrations.title: Conversations with Grandkids
illustrations.text: I love talking to my grandkids about heaven; they have lots of questions, and I don't have all the answers, but I enjoy it. They ask things like, 'Are we going to be able to do this or that?' and I tell them it's going to be better than we can imagine. I just like discussing it because God's Word promises it's beyond our best thoughts. This helps keep our minds on eternal truths.
illustrations.context: This encourages spending time with others talking about heaven to strengthen our spiritual focus.

illustrations.title: Song About Jesus's Return
illustrations.text: Years ago, somebody wrote a song: 'I can't wait to see Jesus in his glory as he bursts from the sky, to be held in his arms and see the glimmer in his eye.' The lyrics go on, 'Tell me how it's going to be; read it from the Bible again because Jesus is coming again.' This song expresses excitement for heaven and reminds us to look forward to it based on Scripture. I share it to highlight our anticipation of Christ's return.
illustrations.context: This quote emphasizes the joy of anticipating Jesus's return and the importance of basing our hope on the Bible.

illustrations.title: Funeral Insensitivity Analogy
illustrations.text: In the past, at a funeral, you have somebody who's passed away in the casket. The person in the box does not care what you think of their tie; they are not worried about that. They don't care if you have the right kind of potato salad or what songs you're singing, because to be dead biblically means to be separated and insensitive to those things. This illustrates that, as believers, we should be dead to the world's opinions and values.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to explain that believers should be insensitive to worldly opinions, just as a dead person is unaffected by their surroundings.

illustrations.title: Paul's Journey to Jerusalem
illustrations.text: Paul the Apostle told the believers he was going to Jerusalem, and they tried to dissuade him, warning that the Jews there hated him and might kill him. Despite this, Paul said he was bound by the Spirit and on his way, knowing that bonds and afflictions awaited him in every city. He declared that he did not consider his life as dear to himself, so that he might finish his course and ministry, testifying to the gospel of the grace of God. This shows Paul's commitment as one who was crucified with Christ and dead to things that once controlled him.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob retells this story to illustrate that believers should reckon themselves dead to sin and the world, following Paul's example of prioritizing his ministry over personal safety.

illustrations.title: George Muller's Life of Faith
illustrations.text: George Muller ran an orphanage where over 10,000 kids were cared for and led to the Lord through his ministry. He didn't have money but prayed, and God provided miraculous stories. Later in his life, when asked the secret of God's powerful use of him, Muller said, 'There was a day when I died utterly to my opinions, preferences, tastes, and the world's approval or blame.'
illustrations.context: To illustrate the spiritual truth of dying to self in order to be used powerfully by God.

illustrations.title: Daily Phone Reminder
illustrations.text: One of my screenshots on my phone says, 'This is a good day to die.' Jesus said we must deny ourselves and take up our cross daily. That's my goal today: to die to my own opinions and be alive to God.
illustrations.context: To emphasize the daily practice of self-denial and living for God.

illustrations.title: LA Cemetery Billboards
illustrations.text: I drove through LA twice last week and saw large billboards for Rose Hill Cemetery, claiming it's America's best. I wondered who voted for that and how they rated it on a scale of one to ten. It's absurd how we get strong opinions about things that don't matter in the eternal scheme, like cemetery ratings.
illustrations.context: To show that we should not worry about trivial worldly things that have no eternal significance.

illustrations.title: Baptism as Personal Death
illustrations.text: When I was baptized in 1975 at the church in a simple baptismal tank on the stage, it was like attending my own funeral. There were people there, and not one of them said they'd miss the old me because anything else would be better than what I used to be. I was right there with them, and I tell you, you wouldn't have liked me before—some of you might not like me now, but that's okay. The fact is, I'm not what I used to be, and I praise God that I'll never be that person again, and neither will you.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that for Christians, baptism signifies that death is already in the past, changing how we view it.

illustrations.title: Congo Missionaries' Secret
illustrations.text: A few years ago, some missionaries who had ministered in the Congo got together with past missionaries and the people who had come to Christ there for a big celebration with speakers and a meal. The oldest surviving tribesman from the Congo, who had been saved in the early days of the ministry about a hundred years prior, got up to speak and shared a terrible secret that only he knew. He said that when the missionaries first came, his parents and the other people there didn't know if what they were preaching was true. I'm the only one alive who knows this, he explained.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the long-term impact and challenges of missionary work in spreading the gospel.

illustrations.title: Tribe Poisons Missionaries
illustrations.text: He said this is the terrible secret: my tribe poisoned many of the missionaries. They didn't know it; we poisoned their food, and many of them died over months for a few years. They decided to test them by watching how they handled dying, and the missionaries died exactly as they lived, with joy in their hearts, saying goodbye to their wives, children, parents, and friends, knowing they were going to heaven. This testimony led my tribesmen to start coming to faith.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that the way believers face death can powerfully testify to their faith and lead others to Christ.

illustrations.title: Living Life Backwards
illustrations.text: Somebody said the secret of living the life of a Christian on earth is to live it backwards. We start our Christian life with baptism, a picture of death, and then we begin to live. Jesus was born in a cave in Bethlehem, wrapped in swaddling clothes, and he came to die—it was not an accident but his purpose. Living life backwards means embracing the certainty of heaven from the start, just as Jesus did.
illustrations.context: This analogy emphasizes that true Christian living involves starting with the end in mind, focusing on eternal certainties rather than earthly dreams.

illustrations.title: James Calvert's Mission
illustrations.text: James Calvert was a missionary in the 19th century who brought the gospel to the cannibals in Fiji. He was the first man that was willing to go there and share the message despite the dangers. This historical figure exemplifies the courage required to spread faith in hostile environments.
illustrations.context: This reference shows that missionaries like Calvert demonstrate the power of living out faith boldly, as part of the theme of facing challenges for the gospel.

illustrations.title: James Calvert's Missionary Sacrifice
illustrations.text: James Calvert was willing to go share the gospel with the cannibals in Fiji, despite the dangers. The ship's captain called him insane and warned that he and his team would die. Calvert replied that they had already died to themselves before arriving. He ministered there for 18 years, seeing great results, including the king's conversion to Christ. The king repented of his sins, like polygamy, and lived for the Lord until his death, even ceding the Fiji Islands to Great Britain.
illustrations.context: This story illustrates that to be used by God, one must die to self and fully commit to living for Him.

illustrations.title: Grandchildren's Enthusiasm for Interests
illustrations.text: I have two grandchildren around six and seven years old, and my youngest granddaughter Lilly is six. She comes alive when talking about American Girl dolls; we took her to the store in LA, and she was overjoyed, even trying to buy a doll though we were just looking. Watching her excitement was amazing and showed what energizes her. My grandson Jonah gets equally animated when discussing superheroes or video games. This demonstrates how people light up about their passions.
illustrations.context: This personal story explains what it means to be truly alive to something, paralleling how one should be alive to God.

illustrations.title: Bach's Help and Glory Inscription
illustrations.text: Johann Sebastian Bach, when writing his musical masterpieces, always began by writing the letters JJ, which stand for two words in Latin meaning 'help me Jesus.' He knew he needed divine assistance to create his works. At the end of each manuscript, he initialed it with SDG, standing for 'soli Deo Gloria,' meaning 'to God alone be all the glory.' Pastor Bob shares this to highlight how Bach relied on God and gave Him credit, emphasizing that we too should seek God's help and direct glory to Him.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses Bach's practice to illustrate the importance of relying on Jesus for help and giving all glory to God in our endeavors.

illustrations.title: Pastor's Preaching Help Request
illustrations.text: I personally am very blessed by Bach's example. When I'm getting ready to share the Word of God or preach, I write three words in my quiet time: help, help, help, with exclamation points. I do this because I know I need God's assistance when representing Him in front of people. Without God moving through me, nothing significant will happen, but with His help, miracles can occur.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob shares his personal ritual to emphasize his dependence on God for effective ministry and to encourage others to seek divine help.

illustrations.title: John's Humble Identity
illustrations.text: The religious leaders sent emissaries to ask John who he was, since he was preaching like someone important. They questioned if he was the Messiah, and he firmly said no. They then asked if he was the Prophet like Moses or Elijah as foretold, and again he denied it. John simply responded by quoting Isaiah, declaring himself as just a voice crying in the wilderness, emphasizing his role in preparing the way.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this retelling to illustrate John's humility and his focus on pointing others to Jesus rather than himself.

illustrations.title: Henry Morrison's Missionary Life
illustrations.text: The name was Henry Morrison. He was a career missionary in Africa in the 20th century. After 40 years of service, he had to return home due to failing health. I always think of Phil and Darla Lewis from our church; Phil's father was a frontier pioneer missionary in Ethiopia at the beginning of the 20th century, the first to share the gospel with many people there. Phil followed in his footsteps and wanted to die on the mission field.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the passion of living fully for Christ, where one's life decreases so that Christ's increases through dedicated service.

illustrations.title: Henry Morrison's Overlooked Return
illustrations.text: Henry Morrison served as a missionary for 40 years, loving his work and seeing many people saved, but he had to come home due to health issues.
