As he arrived on a ship in New York, he expected a warm welcome from the churches and people who had supported him, but instead, a huge crowd with banners and a brass band was there for Teddy Roosevelt, who was on the same ship returning from a hunting expedition in Africa. No one was there to receive Henry, which filled him with depression after his years of service. He felt the Lord whisper, 'You're not home yet, Henry.' Later, at the church that sent him, no one was gathered, and his wife urged him to settle it with the Lord, hearing the voice again. That night, he had a vision of heaven where thousands of Africans he had led to Christ welcomed him, and God whispered once more, 'You're not home yet, Henry.' This reminded him not to expect recognition in this life from people or even the church.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate that true reward and recognition come in heaven, not from earthly sources.

illustrations.title: Bride's Revelation Moment
illustrations.text: There's a special moment in a wedding when we're all waiting for the bride to enter. The groomsmen and pastor come in first, but then the doors open and the bride appears, looking more beautiful than ever. That revelation of who she really is mirrors how the creation waits for the revelation of the sons of God. It's a powerful picture of eager anticipation.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the eager expectation of creation for the revelation of believers as God's children.

illustrations.title: Chuck Smith's Heaven Quote
illustrations.text: Remember Chuck Smith used to say, 'Well, I hope he gives me Hawaii—it's alright.' He said this in the context of looking forward to heaven, suggesting contentment with whatever God provides, like a hammock section. Pastor Bob connects this to the idea that believers will rule and reign with Christ, far beyond just getting by in heaven. It's a reminder that God's plans for us are greater than we imagine.
illustrations.context: This quote emphasizes that Christians underestimate their future roles and should look forward to ruling with Christ.

illustrations.title: Pregnant Woman Expectation
illustrations.text: When a woman is pregnant, we say she's expecting, and her whole life counts down to that single event. As believers in Jesus Christ, every day we are one day closer to our own launch date. This analogy shows how life revolves around anticipation, just as creation waits for the revelation of the sons of God. It's a progressive buildup to something glorious.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that believers should live with eager anticipation for their future revelation, much like a pregnancy leads to birth.

illustrations.title: Chuck Smith's Pinups Quote
illustrations.text: Pastor Chuck said this once in a sermon: 'The girls who are pinups in my day are pitiful now.' He used this to point out how people often look back to the past with nostalgia, like thinking they had a better body back then. Pastor Bob connects it to the idea that we should look forward instead of backward, as our best is yet to come in Christ. This highlights the futility of dwelling on the past.
illustrations.context: This quote encourages believers to focus on future glory rather than past regrets or nostalgia.

illustrations.title: Stage with Greg Laurie
illustrations.text: I was on stage with Greg Laurie many years ago at the Harvest Crusade, which was fun but a bit weird as I sat there worshiping with cameras around. He preached about heaven, saying there would be no sickness, no dying, no pain, and that we'd be able to eat whatever we want without getting fat. This made me realize how we still tie our ideas of heaven to earthly things, like food and comfort. It's a great message, but it shows we're very much connected to this world.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show how people relate heaven to familiar earthly pleasures, highlighting our limited understanding of its true glory.

illustrations.title: Camp Trials and Comfort
illustrations.text: We just got back from a Christian camp with cabins, running water, showers, and heaters, which feels like staying in the Hilton compared to our past camping experiences. Even though it's comfortable now, I still have trouble sleeping the first night and think about going home soon. Any problems are just for a short time, reminding me that earthly trials are temporary. This helps me look forward to heaven more.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate how current trials make heaven increasingly attractive as we age.

illustrations.title: Girl's Wonder at Stars
illustrations.text: A girl was walking with her dad at night and looked up at the stars. She said, 'Daddy, if the wrong side of heaven is this beautiful, I can't wait to get to the other side.' This simple exchange highlights the anticipation of heaven's glory. Pastor Bob uses it to show how earthly beauty points to greater things.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that the beauty of creation makes heaven more appealing and helps endure life's hardships.

illustrations.title: Farther Along Song Quote
illustrations.text: The old song says, 'Farther along we'll know more about it, farther along we'll understand why. Cheer up, my brother, live in the sunshine; we'll understand it all by and by.' Pastor Bob connects this to the idea that in heaven, we'll gain answers to our current questions. It serves as a reminder to hold on through difficulties with hope.
illustrations.context: This quote emphasizes that heavenly hope provides perspective on life's unanswered questions.

illustrations.title: Boy's Treasures in Heaven
illustrations.text: As a boy, I thought of heaven as a city with domes and spires, inhabited by angels. But as loved ones died, I began to see it as a place with people I knew, including my little brother and acquaintances. Now, there are so many loved ones there that I sometimes think I know more people in heaven than on earth. Pastor Bob shares this to show how losses make heaven feel more personal and real.
illustrations.context: This illustrates how accumulating losses transfers loved ones to heaven, making it more attractive.

illustrations.title: Fred's Faith in Cancer
illustrations.text: Fred, my first boss and his wife Della, are there in heaven. Fred came to faith in his last days while battling cancer. This reminds me that no matter when we turn to God, we can be part of that eternal gathering.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that loved ones who have passed on, even those who found faith late in life, are waiting in heaven.

illustrations.title: Paul's Rapture Quote
illustrations.text: Paul put it this way: we won't precede those who have fallen asleep in Jesus, but when that trumpet sounds, the Bible says we all will be caught up together with them to meet the Lord in the air, and thus we and them shall ever be with the Lord. This means we'll all be reunited. Pastor Bob connects this to the assurance that believers never say goodbye forever.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is using this quote to emphasize that Christians will be reunited with loved ones in heaven at the trumpet's sound.

illustrations.title: Heavenly Family Reunion
illustrations.text: The biggest family reunion in all of time in history is going to happen when that trumpet blast goes off. You guys and I are going to be there, and so are you. We'll all be caught up together and be with the Lord forever, never saying goodbye again.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is using this analogy to highlight the joy and permanence of being reunited with loved ones in heaven.

illustrations.title: Personal Worship Struggle
illustrations.text: For too many years, I was more concerned with what people thought of me than what I thought of Him. I think it's so important that we learn to be free without being a distraction. You know what I'm saying, and I'm just telling you for myself that this was my experience.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to emphasize the need for wholehearted worship without worrying about others' opinions.

illustrations.title: Pentecost Power Retold
illustrations.text: When believers allow the Spirit of God to fill them, as on the day of Pentecost, it was clear something powerful was happening with these people. Some people thought they were drunk, but there was a real power at work. When they spoke about God and started praising Him, it was attractive to the Jewish people who had come and saw the work of God in their hearts.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates how the Holy Spirit's filling leads to passionate expression that draws others to God.

illustrations.title: Unadvertised Fire Analogy
illustrations.text: There's an old expression that you don't have to advertise a fire because people just show up and come to look. It means that when God's Spirit ignites us with passion, it naturally draws others without extra effort. This illustrates how our genuine enthusiasm for God can attract people to Him.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show that authentic passion for God will naturally attract others, just like a fire draws onlookers.

illustrations.title: Aaron's Sons and Strange Fire
illustrations.text: Two of Aaron's sons, who were in the priesthood, offered strange fire to the Lord, and fire came out from God's presence and killed them. We know they didn't honor or obey God in their sacrifice, though the exact reason isn't told. God then warned Aaron not to grieve over it, or he too would face consequences, emphasizing that God must be treated as holy because His actions are righteous. This event made everyone cautious about entering God's presence. Aaron knew this radical truth as he prepared to minister.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate the hazardous consequences of not honoring God, showing the importance of obedience in approaching Him.

illustrations.title: Restrictive Access Analogy
illustrations.text: Someone wrote this, and it's well written, so let me share it with you. Suppose you're an Amorite, an Ammonite, or a Jebusite watching the Israelites set up a huge tent. You ask an Israelite what they're doing, and he says it's the tabernacle where God meets his people. But he explains it's only for Israelites, and even then, only Levites can handle it, only Aaron's family can serve as priests, and only the high priest can enter once a year on Yom Kippur—or risk death.
illustrations.context: This analogy highlights how extremely restrictive and exclusive access to God was in the Old Testament.

illustrations.title: Uzzah and the Ark Incident
illustrations.text: Azza was a priest trained in how to carry the Ark of the Covenant properly on poles, but when David brought the Ark to Jerusalem, they placed it on a cart with wheels. The oxen stumbled, causing the Ark to start falling, and Azza reached out to steady it. Immediately, God struck him dead on the spot during this excited procession. David got angry and called the Ark dangerous, sending it to Obed-Edom's house for three months. When David heard of the blessings on Obed-Edom's house, he realized his mistake and decided to bring the Ark back, honoring God by sacrificing oxen every six steps. This event transformed David's understanding of honoring God's presence. We see in Scripture how God moves when we get right with Him.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate the seriousness of God's holiness and the consequences of casual disobedience in ministry.

illustrations.title: Ananias and Sapphira Retelling
illustrations.text: In Acts 5, Ananias and Sapphira were in ministry and sold some property. They claimed to dedicate all of it to the Lord but only dedicated part, wanting to appear more generous than they were. Peter confronted them, and both died right there, causing fear to come upon everyone who heard the story.
illustrations.context: To emphasize that God is holy and judges sin, even in the New Testament, showing His unchanging nature.

illustrations.title: Familiarity Breeds Contempt Explanation
illustrations.text: It's this old saying you've heard: familiarity breeds contempt, which means that when you're really familiar with something or someone, like growing up with them or becoming comfortable, you can risk not respecting them the way you should. This can happen in relationships like between children and parents or grandparents and grandchildren. Pastor Bob uses it to warn about the dangers in life, especially with God.
illustrations.context: To illustrate how familiarity can lead to a lack of respect, even in spiritual matters.

illustrations.title: Car Ride with Police Chief
illustrations.text: I'll never forget I was in a car coming back from academy graduation with the chief of police and two captains. As a detective, I was several ranks below them, but I had spent time with the chief, a Christian, so we talked, prayed, and even went to events together. Sometimes I called him by his first name, Hal, showing our familiarity, which made me comfortable around him despite his high position.
illustrations.context: To show how familiarity can risk diminishing respect in relationships, even with authority figures.

illustrations.title: Disrespecting the Chief
illustrations.text: I was talking to Hal, and I noticed the captains kept calling him Chief. They were trying to get the message across that his name and title deserved respect, but because of my familiarity with him, I had stopped treating him with the respect he earned. It dawned on me that my relationship was undermining the regard I should give him, and the captains weren't happy with me for not using his title.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate how familiarity can lead to disrespecting authority, similar to how people failed to honor Jesus.

illustrations.title: Jesus' Unbelieving Hometown
illustrations.text: Jesus had a hard time being believed in his own hometown of Nazareth because people knew him as the carpenter's kid and his brothers and sisters didn't believe in him until after his resurrection. They questioned where he got his wisdom and essentially asked, 'Who do you think you are?' This lack of faith came from years of familiarity with him. Even in Capernaum, his headquarters city, people celebrated him but didn't truly honor or respect him.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob retells this to show how familiarity can prevent people from truly respecting and believing in someone, like Jesus.

illustrations.title: Moses and the Immature People
illustrations.text: God took Moses to task harshly when he got upset with the people for demanding water, as they were acting very immature like babies. The people were complaining and not trusting God, similar to how a baby cries when hungry or uncomfortable because they don't know how to communicate maturely. God sees his children as immature when they don't trust him, and this led to severe consequences for Moses.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this retelling to emphasize that immaturity and lack of trust in God can lead to judgment, urging listeners to mature in their faith.

illustrations.title: Moses and the Rock
illustrations.text: The people are in a different place with God and complain that He brought them into the wilderness to kill them. Moses gets angry and doesn't reflect God's character, striking the rock in frustration instead of honoring God. As a result, God judges Moses more severely because he should have known better, and Moses is barred from entering the Promised Land.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the importance of treating God as holy and the consequences of failing to do so.

illustrations.title: Chuck Yeager's Determination
illustrations.text: There's a movie called The Right Stuff about the early astronauts, including Chuck Yeager, who in 1947 became the first man to break the sound barrier in the Bell X-1 rocket plane. Other test pilots tried and died before him, highlighting the risks involved. Despite breaking his ribs in a horse-riding accident shortly before his flight, Yeager hid his injury because he knew it would prevent him from flying, and he found a way to close the cockpit despite the pain.
illustrations.context: This example shows the idea of having the 'right stuff' for challenging tasks, paralleling the preparation and determination needed in spiritual matters like the high priest's role.

illustrations.title: Broomstick Improvisation Story
illustrations.text: Someone gives him a broken-off broomstick and says, 'Here, use this,' and he manages to shut the thing with it anyway. He was still willing to go up and do it. It's an interesting story that highlights determination in the face of limitations.
illustrations.context: To illustrate that Aaron was the right person for his role, willing to carry out his duties despite challenges.

illustrations.title: Bull as Cross Analogy
illustrations.text: The bull is a sin offering where blood has to be shed, which is a picture of the cross and Jesus' sacrifice. This shows how the Old Testament ritual foreshadows Christ's atonement. It's a comparison that brings the spiritual truth to life.
illustrations.context: To demonstrate that the bull's sacrifice represents Jesus' death for sins.

illustrations.title: Ram as Consecration Analogy
illustrations.text: The ram is a burnt offering that speaks of consecration, representing how Christ lived a fully surrendered life to God. This extended comparison highlights the idea of total dedication. It's used to connect Old Testament practices to Jesus' example.
illustrations.context: To show that consecration in the burnt offering mirrors Christ's committed life.

illustrations.title: Garments as Character Analogy
illustrations.text: The garments of the high priest are used to describe character, showing that he had to wear a particular set to perform the sacrifice properly. This paints a picture of how our spiritual clothing represents righteousness and holiness. It's an analogy drawn from biblical imagery to illustrate personal transformation.
illustrations.context: To explain that the high priest's garments symbolize the character required for ministry, linking to believers' new selves.

illustrations.title: Bathing as Cleansing Analogy
illustrations.text: The high priest had to bathe as a picture of cleansing before entering ministry, symbolizing purity required for service. This contrasts with Jesus, who was always clean and didn't need cleansing. It's an analogy that highlights the perfection of Christ compared to human priests.
illustrations.context: To illustrate that true cleansing comes through Christ, who was inherently pure.

illustrations.title: High Priest's Glory Divested
illustrations.text: The high priest's garments that he would normally wear were actually beautiful, as God said they were for beauty and for glory. They were very colorful and distinct, with robes bordered by pomegranates and bells, a jeweled breastplate, and a golden plate across his forehead. But on Yom Kippur, he would lay aside his regal robes and wear only the simple linen garments worn by the other priests. This action illustrates the high priest entering God's presence humbly for the sacrifice.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to show how Jesus, as our High Priest, divested Himself of glory to offer the ultimate sacrifice.

illustrations.title: Jesus' Humility in Philippians
illustrations.text: The Bible tells us that Jesus, our High Priest, existed in the form of God but did not regard equality with God as something to be held onto. Instead, He emptied Himself, taking the form of a bondservant and being made in the likeness of men. He humbled Himself by becoming obedient to the point of death, even death on a cross. Therefore, God exalted Him and gave Him a name above every name, so that every knee would bow and every tongue confess that Jesus Christ is Lord.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob connects this quote to emphasize that Jesus divested Himself of glory, just as the high priest did, to offer the sacrifice for sins.

illustrations.title: Speck and Log Quote
illustrations.text: Remember what Jesus said: if you're going to try to take a speck out of your brother's eye, you better make sure there's not a log hanging out of your own eye. That's King James language for a pole, like I don't think you can see well enough to get the speck out if you've got a telephone pole in your eye. You need to deal with your own issues first, or you're just being a hypocrite.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that one must address their own sins before ministering to others.

illustrations.title: Airplane Mask Analogy
illustrations.text: It's that old thing they tell you on the plane about the oxygen mask. If it falls down because you've lost pressure, and you have a child with you, put it on yourself first. It might sound selfish, but if you don't, you'll be unconscious and unable to help them. The point is, you have to take care of yourself before you can assist others.
illustrations.context: This analogy illustrates that ministers must prioritize their own spiritual health before helping others.

illustrations.title: Song on Sheep and Goats
illustrations.text: There's an old song I don't know if you've ever heard: I don't want to be a goat, nope, because a goat ain't got no hope, nope. I just want to be a sheep. It's based on Matthew 25, where Jesus separates the sheep and the goats.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses the song to illustrate that goats represent the unsaved, contrasting with the saved sheep in biblical teaching.

illustrations.title: Debt Payment Analogy
illustrations.text: It's like this: you lose your job and can't make your mortgage payments, so the bank decides to foreclose on your house. Then someone comes and pays off your entire debt, so you keep your house. But even then, you might still have terrible credit, yet in this case, it's as if your credit is fully restored because Jesus paid for our sins and removes our guilt and shame.
illustrations.context: This analogy illustrates how Jesus not only forgives sins but also eliminates the associated guilt and shame.

illustrations.title: East from West Separation
illustrations.text: God removes our sins as far as the east is from the west, not from the north to the south. If you go east, you keep going east forever without meeting the starting point, unlike north and south which eventually meet. This means your sins are permanently separated from you, so God doesn't look at them anymore.
illustrations.context: This analogy emphasizes that God completely and irretrievably separates us from our sins.

illustrations.title: Love Ignores Wrongs Quote
illustrations.text: The Bible says in 1 Corinthians 13 that love does not take into account a wrong suffered. God is love, as stated in 1 John 4:8, so He does not hold your sins against you. This means that once Jesus paid for your sins, God treats you as if you never committed them.
illustrations.context: This quote demonstrates that God's love ensures He does not remember our sins after forgiveness.

illustrations.title: Incense as Prayer Symbol
illustrations.text: Incense is a picture in the Bible in the temple of prayer. Revelation talks about it, saying the prayers of the saints are mixed with the incense. The priest would go in and offer this sweet holy incense, and it would go up as smoke. From outside the temple, you would see these billows of smoke going up into heaven. It was a time that the nation would come and pray, picturing their prayers ascending to God with the priest interceding.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating how prayer, particularly praise, is the means to enter God's presence.

illustrations.title: God Enthroned on Praises
illustrations.text: Here's what we read in Psalm 22, the very psalm that Jesus was quoting on the cross: God inhabits the praises of His people, or He is enthroned upon the praises of Israel. This shows that God is enthroned on the mercy seat. The mercy seat is where God's presence dwells, and it's entered with prayer and praise.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is using this quote to show that praise is essential for entering God's presence and experiencing His mercy.

illustrations.title: The Grateful Leper
illustrations.text: Think of the ten lepers: nine get healed, one gets saved. It's the one who comes back to say thank you, actually to praise God. Because he praises God, he enters into the presence of Jesus in a way the others never did.
illustrations.context: Gratitude and praise lead to deeper intimacy with God.

illustrations.title: JFK Assassination Memory
illustrations.text: I don't know how many of you were alive in 1963 when JFK was assassinated. I remember I was in first grade, and the lunch lady came running through the campus screaming and crying. They put us on buses and sent us home; it was traumatic for the nation, as people wondered what would happen next, who was behind it, and if more violence would follow.
illustrations.context: The death of a leader creates national vulnerability and fear, similar to the time of King Uzziah.

illustrations.title: Isaiah's Throne Vision
illustrations.text: Think of Isaiah in the Old Testament, Isaiah 6: in the year that King Uzziah died, who had been a good king for over 50 years, it was a time of vulnerability for the nation. Isaiah has a vision and sees the Lord high and lifted up, being worshipped by angels. He realizes that while the earthly throne is unoccupied, the heavenly throne is firmly occupied by God.
illustrations.context: God's sovereignty provides assurance during times of earthly uncertainty.

illustrations.title: John's Exile and Return
illustrations.text: John was the only living apostle left, as the others had been martyred, and around 95 A.D., Emperor Domitian tried to kill him by boiling him alive, but he survived miraculously. So, Domitian exiled him to the island of Patmos to isolate him. In that difficult place, John had an incredible vision, seeing a throne in heaven and realizing that Jesus is still in control, even when things seem out of control on earth. The next year, Domitian was assassinated, and John returned to minister, showing that God orchestrates events in His time.
illustrations.context: To illustrate that God remains in control despite apparent chaos and evil.

illustrations.title: Philippians on Worry and Thanksgiving
illustrations.text: In Philippians 4:6, it says to be anxious for nothing, but in everything, by prayer and supplication with thanksgiving, present your requests to God. This means don't worry, but instead, bring your concerns to God with a thankful heart. Even in tough times, like when Paul wrote this from prison, there's always a reason to rejoice and be thankful by remembering God's past faithfulness.
illustrations.context: To emphasize that prayer with thanksgiving helps overcome anxiety and connects us to God's presence.

illustrations.title: Psalm 22 and God's Faithfulness
illustrations.text: In Psalm 22, Jesus on the cross cried out, 'My God, my God, why have you forsaken me?' even though He felt unheard, He remembered that God is enthroned upon the praises of Israel and had answered the cries of their forefathers by saving them. This shows that in the midst of suffering, we can find reasons to praise God by recalling His historical acts of deliverance. It's a reminder that God remains faithful, just as He did for past generations.
illustrations.context: To show that reflecting on God's past actions provides reasons for thankfulness and praise in difficult times.

illustrations.title: Paul and Silas in Prison
illustrations.text: Paul and Silas are in that city's jail, put there by the Philippian rulers after being beaten, and at midnight, they are praying and praising God. I've always wondered what they were saying—maybe 'Rejoice in the Lord always'—even though it was strange for them to sing praises after such suffering. Then, God intervenes, shaking the earth and causing the whole jail to fall apart, showing that praise brings you into God's presence where He can change everything.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate that prayer and praise bring peace and access to God's power, even in dire circumstances.

illustrations.title: Gideon's Idol Confrontation
illustrations.text: Before Gideon could go defeat the army, God told him to tear down his father's idol in the backyard that night. Gideon was afraid and did it secretly because he worried about his dad and the neighbors' reactions. This upset the neighbors so much that they wanted to kill him, emphasizing that God requires dealing with sin at home first.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that one must address personal sin before serving God externally.

illustrations.title: Moses and Circumcision Issue
illustrations.text: God called Moses to set His people free and tell Pharaoh to let them go, but first, God was going to kill Moses because he hadn't circumcised his son. This shows Moses was compromising his relationship with God, likely due to his wife's influence. It's a reminder that impurity at home can hinder serving the Lord.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating how easy it is to overlook sin in personal life while trying to serve God.

illustrations.title: High Priest's Atonement Ritual
illustrations.text: When the high priest goes into the holy place to make atonement, no one else can be in the tent of meeting until he finishes the sacrifice for himself, his household, and all of Israel. This ensured that atonement was complete before access to God's presence. It foreshadows how the veil in the temple tore when Jesus died, opening access to God only after His sacrifice was finished.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is showing that full atonement must be completed before anyone can enter God's presence.

illustrations.title: Jesus' Seven Points of Bleeding
illustrations.text: It's been pointed out that Jesus bled from seven different places in His body, symbolizing completion and perfection. These include His back torn by the whip, His head from the crown of thorns, His hands and feet from the nails, and His side from the spear. This might prefigure the complete work of Christ's shedding blood as mentioned in the Bible.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is connecting this to the idea of seven as a number of completion in the Bible, illustrating the perfection of Christ's sacrifice.

illustrations.title: Corrie Ten Boom's No Fishing Quote
illustrations.text: God puts our sins in the depths of the ocean and then posts a sign saying no fishing allowed. In other words, this means don't go fishing for somebody else's past sins or even your own. Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that God wants our sins to be completely forgotten and not revisited.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that God casts our sins away forever, so we should not dwell on them or bring them back up.

illustrations.title: Scapegoat Release Analogy
illustrations.text: You see the releasing of the scapegoat uses the same word in the Greek Septuagint as in the New Testament for forgive, meaning God has released our sins and allowed them to be gone. The one responsible for burning the sacrifice outside the camp is a picture of Christ's crucifixion, where God's wrath fell on Him. In both cases, these figures return to the camp, symbolizing restored fellowship with God's people.
illustrations.context: This analogy illustrates how God forgives sins and restores fellowship through Christ's work.

illustrations.title: Jesus' Promise of Presence
illustrations.text: Remember what Jesus said to His disciples: 'Lo, I am with you always, even to the end of the age.' This quote shows a wonderful picture of fellowship being restored, just as the figures in the Day of Atonement return to the camp. It connects to the idea that God's presence endures despite our need for repeated repentance.
illustrations.context: This quote emphasizes that fellowship with God is ongoing and eternal, even after ministry or atonement.

illustrations.title: Israelites' Exodus Retelling
illustrations.text: Think about the Israelites: they had all been saved from Egypt, out of the house of bondage and their old lives. They had been biblically baptized when they went through the Red Sea, identifying with Moses as their savior. This event pictures how even the saved need to take sin seriously and repent repeatedly.
illustrations.context: This retelling illustrates that salvation does not eliminate the need for ongoing repentance and seriousness about sin.

illustrations.title: Annual Doctor Checkup Analogy
illustrations.text: It's kind of like your annual checkup with your doctor. You go in because you want to get things taken care of that you're aware of or not aware of. You don't want to wait until you're so damaged by something that they have to take you to the emergency room in an ambulance. The same thing is true spiritually: eternal forgiveness is one and done, but repentance and restoration need to be done again and again.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that just as people need regular medical checkups to maintain health, believers need ongoing repentance to maintain their spiritual fellowship with God.

illustrations.title: Jesus Cleansing the Temple Twice
illustrations.text: Jesus in his ministry cleanses the temple how many times? Twice that we know of, right at the beginning of his ministry and at the end. He kicked the guys out that were selling doves and changing money. Why did he have to do it twice? Because it got the same way it used to be.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is using this story to show that spiritual cleansing, like the temple, may need to be repeated due to recurring sin.

illustrations.title: Jesus as Sacrificial Animals
illustrations.text: Lord, how grateful I am that you came to be my sin sacrifice, pictured through different animals. In this passage, you were the bull that took my place and died, shedding your blood for me. You are the ram that lived a totally consecrated life, completely set apart for God, and you came to die for me. I have never lived my life totally consecrated to God, but I thank you, Jesus, that you did. You became a curse for me, the goat that was slain for my sin and that takes away the shame of my sin so I don't have to look at it.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating how Jesus fulfilled the Old Testament sacrifices to show God's provision for sin and redemption.

illustrations.title: Loving Correction Example
illustrations.text: It's kind of like when you love somebody and you say, 'Hey, you're bleeding,' or 'Hey, can I help you with that?' You're doing it in love, sharing something helpful. Sometimes you might say to somebody, 'Hey, you've got something in your teeth,' because you care and don't want them to go out like that. This isn't about laughing at them or making fun of them; it's about genuine concern.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is contrasting the Holy Spirit's loving conviction of sin with Satan's condemning accusations.

illustrations.title: Moses' Birth and Flight
illustrations.text: A man from the house of Levi married a Levite woman, and she bore a son who was beautiful, so she hid him for three months. When she could hide him no longer, she placed him in a wicker basket among the reeds by the Nile. Pharaoh's daughter found the child, had pity on him, and adopted him as her son, naming him Moses because she drew him out of the water. As Moses grew, he witnessed the oppression of his people, killed an Egyptian in anger, and fled to Midian when Pharaoh sought to kill him.
illustrations.context: To highlight God's selection of Moses as a deliverer, pointing to Jesus as the ultimate savior.

illustrations.title: Pharaoh's Oppression of Israelites
illustrations.text: If you weren't with us, you need to know that at the end of the last chapter, the nation of Israel had grown from a family of 70 to about two million people, all in Egypt due to a famine, and God raised up Joseph to help run the land. Pharaoh became concerned that there were too many Jews and feared they might take over or align with enemies, so he tried to reduce their population by ordering the Jewish midwives to throw baby boys into the Nile. The midwives feared God and didn't obey, instead telling Pharaoh that Hebrew women were stronger and gave birth before they arrived. Pharaoh then escalated by commanding all Egyptians to cast every newborn son into the Nile while keeping the daughters alive. God blessed the midwives for their faith, and despite the persecution and enslavement, the Israelites continued to multiply.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating the theme of faith and God's protection amidst persecution to show how belief in God leads to deliverance.

illustrations.title: Haman's Plot Against Jews
illustrations.text: In the book of Esther, remember it's Haman who wants the King to put out an edict to kill all the Jews and it's Mordecai and Esther who are the heroes of that story.
illustrations.context: This illustrates the ongoing hatred toward the Jewish people as part of Satan's attempts to annihilate them before the Messiah.

illustrations.title: Hitler's Final Solution
illustrations.text: In more recent times last century, it was Hitler with an attempt to destroy all the Jewish people; the final solution was to kill, and he killed some 6 million Jews in Europe.
illustrations.context: This shows a historical pattern of anti-Semitism aimed at wiping out the Jewish people to prevent the Messiah's lineage.

illustrations.title: Mothers Praising Babies
illustrations.text: I suppose pretty much every mother when she has a baby says isn't he gorgeous or isn't she amazing, and that's just human nature. Sometimes you have that situation where somebody says look at my baby isn't he beautiful or isn't she beautiful, and a lot of times they are. Now every once in a while, you might have to say something like oh, nice hair or beautiful ears or that smile, and sometimes you'd have to go well, he's a baby, just the way it is.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate that mothers naturally see their children as beautiful, connecting it to how Jochebed saw Moses.

illustrations.title: Acts Quote on Moses
illustrations.text: Listen to what the New Testament says about this in Acts 7:20; it was at this time that Moses was born and he was lovely in the sight of God, and he was nurtured three months in his father's home. This is from Stephen's sermon, right before he was put to death. It shows that Moses was beautiful not just to his mother, but to God himself.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that parents should see their children as precious and beautiful to God.

illustrations.title: Rubberband Theology Quote
illustrations.text: John Corson said he told his kids they are going to follow the Lord whether they want to or not, because they are God's by design. He explained that they can run from God, but it's like rubberband theology: you can go as far as you want, but you'll hurt when you come back because you're meant for God. Pastor Bob shares this to emphasize seeing children through God's eyes.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to encourage parents to believe that their children are part of God's plan and will ultimately return to Him.

illustrations.title: Moses's Crying Explanation
illustrations.text: J Vernon McGee says that Moses evidently had a healthy set of lungs and was crying a lot, making it hard for his mother to hide him any longer. This realization led her to understand that the situation was up and she needed to act. Pastor Bob connects this to the idea that circumstances can force parents to release control.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to illustrate that parents must release control and trust that God is still in control of their children's lives.

illustrations.title: Egypt as Worldly Influence
illustrations.text: If we realize Egypt is a type of the world as we've discussed in the Bible, it's like this: Moses's mom wanted to protect him from being exposed to the world, but she discovers it's not possible. By the way, there are some parents in the church today who are convinced they can do what Moses's mom couldn't do. I'm going to keep my kids from ever being exposed to this wicked world, but we can't fully accomplish that task throughout their lives.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to show that parents cannot completely shield their children from worldly influences, just as Moses's mother could not.

illustrations.title: Children Testing Faith
illustrations.text: Personally, I strongly believe that children are one of God's primary ways to test our faith. You know, every time I've ever said that, I always get laughs, and I don't know why—it's either people who don't have kids or who do. But either way, children and marriage are key ways God challenges our faith.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob illustrates that God uses children as a primary means to test and strengthen believers' faith.

illustrations.title: Moses's Basket as Ark
illustrations.text: It says wicker basket in the Hebrew, and the King James version calls it an Ark. It was a little wicker basket she covered with tar, just like Noah's Ark, using the exact same Hebrew word. This word is only used in two places in the Bible: in Genesis 6 through 9 about Noah's Ark and here about this basket. You might say Moses was saved through water, similar to how Noah was saved. Both the Ark of Noah and this basket are types of Christ, emphasizing that salvation depends on being in Him.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this analogy to illustrate that salvation is through Christ, just as being in the Ark saved Noah and Moses.

illustrations.title: Ark as Salvation Analogy
illustrations.text: The judgment of God fell on the whole world, but the people who are saved are those in the Ark, like people in New York regardless of whether they had a quiet time before it rained. It's not about how good you've been doing; it's whether you're in the Ark. The same principle applies to everyone: what matters is if you're in Christ by faith, saving you from the judgment around you.
illustrations.context: This analogy emphasizes that salvation comes from being in Christ, not personal efforts.

illustrations.title: Herod's Massacre and Flight to Egypt
illustrations.text: When Jesus was born, Herod asked the wise men where they came from and where they were going to worship the King of the Jews. He consulted the scribes, who quoted Micah 5, saying the Messiah would be born in Bethlehem, so Herod sent soldiers to kill every baby boy in Bethlehem who was two years old and under to eliminate this potential king. However, God was ahead of him and gave Joseph a dream, instructing him to take the child and flee to Egypt, where Jesus was hidden for a few months until it was safe.
illustrations.context: This story illustrates God's protection and the importance of being in Christ to escape judgment.

illustrations.title: Moses Hidden in Egypt Parallel
illustrations.text: Moses, the savior of the Old Testament, was hidden in Egypt for three months as a baby to protect him. Similarly, Jesus was hidden in Egypt for a few months after his birth to escape Herod's threat. This parallel shows how God works ahead of danger to preserve his chosen ones.
illustrations.context: This illustrates God's consistent pattern of protection for key figures in biblical history.

illustrations.title: Moses' Sister Watching Faith
illustrations.text: In verse 4, Moses' sister, who was older than him, stood at a distance to see what would happen to her baby brother after he was placed in the river. She was watching her parents' decision to put him in the Ark and float him on the Nile, a counterintuitive act of faith amid danger. This scene pictures children observing their parents' faith in action, learning from their trust in God.
illustrations.context: This story points out that children are watching and learning from their parents' faith decisions.

illustrations.title: Surfers and Heavenly Seas
illustrations.text: I know people who surf hate that verse about no seas in the new earth. I'd say, don't worry about it; whatever you can do with surfing is going to be even better in heaven. I guarantee it will be better in the new kingdom.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that heaven will be superior to earthly experiences, even if something like surfing seems lost.

illustrations.title: Ruth's Providential Encounter
illustrations.text: In the Book of Ruth, Ruth and Naomi were poor widows in Bethlehem, facing a famine and barely scraping by. They gleaned in the fields as allowed by God's law, which permitted the poor to gather leftover crops. Ruth, the younger widow, went out to glean and happened to end up in a field owned by Boaz, who was in a position to redeem her. The writer hints that this was no coincidence but God's hand at work. It's a setup we can see clearly in hindsight.
illustrations.context: This shows how God's providence guides events, even when they seem like coincidences, and is often recognized only after the fact.

illustrations.title: Atheist Neighbor's Groceries
illustrations.text: There was a Christian lady who lived next door to an atheist, and every day when she prayed, he could hear her and thought she was crazy for believing in God. He often harassed her, mocking her faith and insisting there was no God, but she continued praying faithfully. One day, she ran out of groceries and prayed about her situation, thanking God for what He would provide. The atheist overheard her, decided to test her faith, and went to the store to buy a bunch of groceries. He dropped them on her porch, rang the doorbell, and hid to see her reaction.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that coincidences are often God's anonymous work, demonstrating His providence in everyday life.

illustrations.title: Old Lady's Providential Groceries
illustrations.text: There was an old lady praising the Lord with all her heart, jumping up and down, singing and shouting. The atheist jumped out of the bushes and said, 'Hey, you crazy old lady, like I told you, there's no God. God didn't buy you those groceries; I did.' Then she started running down the street, shouting and praising the Lord. When he caught up to her, she said, 'Well, I knew the Lord would provide me with some groceries, but I didn't know he was going to make the devil pay for them.'
illustrations.context: This illustrates God's providence in providing for needs in unexpected and humorous ways.

illustrations.title: Moses' Divine Rescue
illustrations.text: Moses' mother put her son in a basket in the river, not knowing what would happen to him. Pharaoh's daughter came to that exact spot at the right moment and found him. Even though her father wanted all Jewish boys dead, God made her heart tender when she saw the crying baby. This was a divine appointment set up by God.
illustrations.context: This shows God's providence in orchestrating perfect timing for salvation and protection.

illustrations.title: Grandson's Faith Experience
illustrations.text: Becky, how old were you when you received Christ? My two-year-old grandson asked Jesus to come into his heart the other day. A lot can happen in three years in a child's life, as God can do significant work even at that age.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that children can have meaningful spiritual encounters early in life, emphasizing the potential growth in the three years Jochebed had with Moses.

illustrations.title: Jochebed's Sacrifice and Blessing
illustrations.text: They used to nurse babies for about three years before weaning them, so it's very likely that Jochebed gave up her son and got him back the same day for around three years of nursing and raising him. A little three-year-old can learn a lot, and she must have felt blessed to realize he was alive, nurse him, and raise him before he went to live in the palace with the best education she could never afford. On top of that, she got paid for it, which is a perfect Romans 8:28 situation.
illustrations.context: This retelling shows how God turns difficult situations into blessings, as seen in Jochebed's experience with Moses.

illustrations.title: Sacrifices for God Rewarded
illustrations.text: Peter says we've left everything for Jesus, and Jesus promises that no one who gives up houses, brothers, sisters, mother, father, children, or farms for His sake will receive a hundred times as much now, along with persecutions, and eternal life later. For example, if you give up your unsaved boyfriend, it doesn't mean you'll have 100 guys calling you, or if you quit an unethical job, 100 recruiters will call, but it does mean that any losses will be worth it in the end. You'll never regret anything you give up for the Lord.
illustrations.context: This analogy explains that giving up things for God leads to greater rewards, despite temporary losses, based on Mark 10:28-30.

illustrations.title: Romans 8:28 in Action
illustrations.text: What a blessing that Jochebed not only got to raise her son for three years but also got paid for it. I talk about a Romans 8:28 situation, where God works all things for good for those who love Him. This connects to how God turns our sacrifices into unexpected blessings.
illustrations.context: This quote illustrates that God brings good out of difficult circumstances, as in Jochebed's story.

illustrations.title: Moses Drawn from Waters
illustrations.text: The very one drawn out of the water, Moses, was saved from death while other babies were being killed, and he would later save his brethren through the waters of death at the Red Sea. This is a picture of baptism, as described in Romans 6:4, where we are buried with Christ through baptism into death, so that we might walk in newness of life. Just as Moses led the nation of Israel through those same waters, which meant death for the Egyptians but salvation for the Israelites, it illustrates how God rescues His people.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating how Moses' rescue from the Nile foreshadows God's salvation and baptism for His people.

illustrations.title: Moses Kills Egyptian Secretly
illustrations.text: Moses looked this way and that way, and when he saw no one around, he struck down the Egyptian and hid him in the sand. He thought he had gotten away with it, but God saw everything. This event shows that we can't hide our actions from God's sight, as no creature is hidden from Him.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that God sees all our actions, even when we try to keep them secret.

illustrations.title: Buried Tires Resurface
illustrations.text: Years ago, tires had more rubber in them, but one problem was trying to bury them in landfills. Because of the air inside the tires, they would eventually come back to the surface over time. People would cover them over, build homes, and then 20 or 30 years later, the tires would pop up in people's yards. That's kind of like sin—you can bury it, but it will come back.
illustrations.context: This illustrates that sin, like buried tires, cannot remain hidden and will eventually resurface, causing harm.

illustrations.title: Moses' Rejection and Deliverance
illustrations.text: Moses was educated in all the learning of the Egyptians and was a man of power in words and deeds. When he was approaching the age of 40, he decided to visit his brethren, the sons of Israel. Seeing one of them being treated unjustly, he defended him and struck down the oppressor, supposing that his brethren would understand God was granting them deliverance through him. But they did not understand it at all.
illustrations.context: This retelling shows that the one rejected by people, like Moses, is the one God chooses for deliverance, drawing a parallel to Jesus.

illustrations.title: David's Anointing Delay
illustrations.text: David sensed he was called to be great because he was anointed with oil by the prophet Samuel, but he didn't immediately become king. Instead, it took years and many hard experiences before he ascended to the throne. This shows that having a calling doesn't mean instant fulfillment.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses David's story to illustrate that God places desires in your heart for ministry long before you actually fulfill them, emphasizing the need for patience.

illustrations.title: Joseph's Dream Wait
illustrations.text: Joseph had dreams that his brothers would bow down to him, but he made the mistake of sharing them, which caused problems with his family. Despite this, it took years before he was elevated to a position of power. This pattern shows that God's timing for callings isn't immediate.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses Joseph's story to demonstrate that God instills desires and dreams early, but prepares you over time before bringing them to fruition.

illustrations.title: Meeting Becky Early
illustrations.text: I met Becky years before we dated, and at first, neither of us was interested in the other. We were just at church, where I was involved in a college ministry trying to get other students to attend Sunday school, but she wasn't particularly interested in joining. Over time, things changed, showing that some connections take time to develop.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal story to illustrate that just like biblical figures, personal desires or callings may not happen immediately but require preparation and waiting.

illustrations.title: Meeting Becky at Thanksgiving
illustrations.text: I remember we were at a Thanksgiving event, and she was sitting right next to me. I didn't think much of it at first, just seeing her as another girl, but when we held hands as instructed, I felt an electric spark and thought she was the one. Years later, when I brought it up, she didn't even remember that night, even though it made a big impression on me. This shows how God can plant desires or inklings in our lives long before we're ready, preparing us for what He has in store.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this personal experience to illustrate that God places desires or awareness in our lives well before we are prepared for them.

illustrations.title: Paul's Wisdom in Corinthians
illustrations.text: Paul says in 1 Corinthians 1:20-21, 'Where is the wise man? Where is the scribe? Where is the debater of this age? Has not God made foolish the wisdom of the world? For since in the wisdom of God the world through its wisdom did not come to know God, God was well-pleased through the foolishness of the message preached to save those who believe.' This quote matters because it highlights that human wisdom alone cannot lead to knowing God, and instead, God uses the simple message of the gospel to save believers. Pastor Bob connects it to show that even brilliant people, like Moses, can't save themselves through their own strength.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to emphasize that God's wisdom makes human wisdom foolish and that salvation comes through the preached message, not human effort.

illustrations.title: Moses' Life Stages
illustrations.text: You could take Moses' life of 120 years and divide it into three 40-year segments. The first 40 years, he was in Egypt thinking he was something. The next 40 years, he lived in the deserts of Midian as a shepherd, learning he was a nothing and a nobody. The final 40 years, starting at age 80 when he saw the burning bush, he discovered all that God can do through a nobody like him.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating how God humbles individuals before using them for His purposes.

illustrations.title: Jesus and the Inheritance Dispute
illustrations.text: In Luke 12, someone in the crowd said to Jesus, 'Teacher, tell my brother to divide the family inheritance with me.' Jesus replied, 'Who appointed me a judge or an arbiter over you?' This wording is virtually identical to what the Hebrew said to Moses in Exodus, highlighting a biblical parallel. Pastor Bob uses this to show how people question authority in similar ways across Scripture.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that biblical language and themes remain consistent, emphasizing the reliability of God's Word.

illustrations.title: Moses Confronts the Slaves
illustrations.text: Basically, what's happening is Moses sees one Jewish slave offending another Jewish slave and he says that's wrong, you're brothers, stop it. This guy knows Moses murdered an Egyptian the day before, so he retorts, who do you think you are, a righteous judge today when you were a murderer yesterday. Moses is ready to judge others while ignoring his own sin. Jesus uses this story to teach about hypocrisy in judgment.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this to illustrate the danger of hypocrisy when judging others, as Moses was guilty of greater sin.

illustrations.title: Jesus and the Inheritance Dispute
illustrations.text: Jesus has a man who says, hey, my brother is not treating me right, he's keeping all the inheritance for himself. Jesus responds, who made me a judge over you? He knows he is the ultimate judge, but instead of addressing the brother's greed, Jesus warns the man about his own greed. This shows that when we seek to judge others, we must first examine ourselves. Jesus uses this to highlight the principle that judgment will come back to us.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is making the point that Jesus redirects judgment back to the accuser's own faults, emphasizing personal accountability.

illustrations.title: James on Judging Others
illustrations.text: Jot down James 4 verses 11 and 12: Don't speak against one another, brethren; he who speaks against a brother or judges his brother speaks against the law and judges the law. But if you judge the law, you're not a doer of the law but a judge of it. There is only one lawgiver and judge, the one who is able to save and to destroy; but who are you who judge your neighbor? Pastor Bob connects this to show that judging others positions us against God's law, reminding us that only God has that authority.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this quote to reinforce that we should not judge others because only God is the true judge.

illustrations.title: Bible Study Lock Pick Story
illustrations.text: I remember at a Bible study in high school, a girl had her keys locked in the car. They asked if anyone could help, and I tried with a hanger but couldn't get it open. Then another guy used lock picks to open it in about ten seconds. He explained that he used to be a burglar but got saved, and I thought, praise God, He's turning that around.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to illustrate how God redeems past sins and turns them for good, just as He did with Moses.

illustrations.title: Church Member Confession Story
illustrations.text: I remember being called by a guy in our church 20 years ago who said he needed to talk to me. He came for an appointment and confessed that his background check would show he had murdered someone. I was surprised and said I would never have guessed it, and he shared his story, showing how God can redeem even the worst sins. We both learned from it that past actions don't define our destiny.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob uses this story to emphasize that people are not defined by their past sins, as God can redeem anyone, including murderers like Moses and David.

illustrations.title: Gang Member's Transformation
illustrations.text: There was a guy in a gang at a party where somebody got shot with the guys he was running with, and he was convicted of murder and served his time. Later, he came to Jesus, and his life has been completely different ever since. He was ashamed of his past but is now glad and thankful that he came to talk to me about it.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is illustrating that everyone has a sinful past but can experience complete change through faith in Jesus.

illustrations.title: Paul's Basket Escape
illustrations.text: In the New Testament, Paul is an example of a basket-case. He began his ministry and had to be led over the wall in a basket because he was so on fire for Jesus that the people of Damascus wanted to kill him. He was out of control for Jesus, and they needed to learn to be more wise. This shows how God works with those in difficult situations.
illustrations.context: Pastor Bob is using this to encourage trusting God with out-of-control situations, like a 'basket-case' child or personal challenge.
